HEADLINE: BUSH WILL MEET GORBACHEV TO GET 'BETTER ACQUAINTED' IN TALKS AT SEA NEXT MONTH;
'Interim' Sessions

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31

 BODY:
Saying he does not want to ''miss something'' in the rapidly shifting terrain of East-West relations, President Bush announced today that he would meet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union in December for two days of unstructured talks.
Mr. Bush said at a news conference that the ''interim, informal'' sessions with the Soviet leader, which would precede their ''full-scale summit'' planned for the late spring or early summer of 1990, will take place in the Mediterranean, alternating between American and Soviet naval vessels on Dec. 2 and 3. [Excerpts from the news conference, page A19.] Previous Meeting The meeting will be Mr. Bush's first with the Soviet leader as President. As President-elect, Mr. Bush met with Mr. Gorbachev on Governors Island in New York harbor last December.
Making a simultaneous announcement in Moscow, the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, said that while the main aim of the talks was for the two leaders to get to know each other better, they might also use the opportunity to provide ''directives'' to their foreign policy advisers, laying the basis for the 1990 meeting. 
The announcement of the December meeting, secretly arranged between Washington and Moscow in discussions going back to July, raised a number of questions about the Administration's handling of relations with the Soviet Union in recent months.
 
Quayle Urged Caution
If Mr. Bush's senior aides were aware of planning for the meeting, which the White House said they were, it was unclear why Vice President Dan Quayle publicly advocated a cautious approach to dealing with Mr. Gorbachev, and why Robert M. Gates, the deputy national security adviser, was prepared to give a speech last week that offered a gloomy assessment of Mr. Gorbachev's prospects for reshaping his country.
The Gates speech was canceled when Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d objected to it.
If plans for a meeting this year were developing over the summer, with general agreement by the end of August -the time frame described by the White House - it was also unclear why Mr. Shevardnadze rebuked Washington in September for failing to move more swiftly to deal with Mr. Gorbachev.
Mr. Bush denied any policy disagreements within his Administration, and said the idea for the December meeting stemmed from his desire to explore with Mr. Gorbachev the fluid political situation in Eastern Europe before they sit down for intense talks next year over arms control and other issues.
''I just didn't want to, in this time of dynamic change, miss something, something that I might get better first-hand from Mr. Gorbachev,'' said Mr. Bush said at the White House news conference.
Moving his hands past each other in the air, he explained, ''I don't want to have two gigantic ships pass in the night because of failed communication.''
The announcement of what the White House called a ''non-summit summit'' and what the Democrats called ''a saltwater summit'' reflected a softening in the public attitude of the President, who had said he would take a more skeptical and less ''romantic'' approach to Mr. Gorbachev than President Ronald Reagan did.
It also marked a new public stance on holding unstructured talks with Mr. Gorbachev, which the White House earlier in the year suggested would be unwise. Secretary Baker, in two recent speeches, called for a more active approach to dealing with Mr. Gorbachev, apparently reflecting Mr. Bush's view that a friendlier, faster pace on talks would benefit both sides.
 
'Put Our Feet Up'
President Bush said the shipboard meetings would not be negotiating sessions on arms control, but rather a chance for the two leaders to ''put our feet up'' and exchange views on a wide array of subjects, including the progress of Soviet internal reform, the changes in Eastern Europe and the state of the American and Soviet economies.
''Our talks will be informal in character, designed to allow us to become better acquainted with one another and to deepen our respective understanding of each other's views,'' Mr. Bush said in his opening statement. ''Neither President Gorbachev nor I anticipate that substantial decisions or agreements will emerge from this December meeting.''
Referring to economic assistance, Mr. Bush said, ''Maybe this is one of the items that we will be discussing.''
''What I want to make clear to Mr. Gorbachev,'' Mr. Bush said of perestroika, the Soviet program of economic and political change - ''and I don't think there's been a disconnect with the Soviets - is that we do want to see it succeed.''
 
A Matter of Soviet Pride
But the Soviets were sensitive on the point, and at the Moscow news conference today, Mr. Shevardnadze asked that reporters not write that his Government intended to ask for economic help to promote perestroika. The Soviets' plan must be carried out at home, the Foreign Minister said, and to suggest that they would appeal for American aid ''touches our national dignity.''
The President, whose cautious response to the changes in Eastern Europe has attracted criticism from Congressional Democrats and European allies, conceded that he has changed his mind about the pace and tenor of superpower progress.
''You know, there was one time when I felt that such a meeting wouldn't be productive, and I think it is going to be productive,'' said Mr. Bush, who was wearing a tie with an orange pumpkin design in honor of Halloween.
White House aides said President Bush and a handful of advisers - including the chief of staff, John H. Sununu; Mr. Baker; Mr. Quayle; Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser, and his deputy, Mr. Gates, and the press secretary, Marlin Fitzwater -have been secretly arranging the Mediterranean meeting for more than three months. And yet Mr. Bush did not object to the way that Mr. Quayle and Mr. Gates continued to express cautionary assessments of the Soviets.
 
Yea-Sayers and Naysayers
''The ratio of optimistic and pessimistic views with regard to the Soviet Union is constantly shifting,'' a top Bush official said. ''Just because someone acknowledges the presence of one or the other at any given time doesn't mean that there is any disagreement among us.''
Mr. Bush, who was warning the Western allies only last spring against ''a growing complacency'' about the Soviets, said today that his change of heart came after consultations with the allies in Europe and after watching ''the rapidity of change in Eastern Europe and the emergence of democracies in this hemisphere.''
Mr. Bush said that the shift to a higher gear was his own idea. The President, who likes to conduct an intensely personal style of diplomacy, either on the phone or face to face, said he decided that he needed to examine Mr. Gorbachev's agenda ''first-hand.''
''He's been feeling for a while that he should say to Gorbachev, 'Come on down and let's talk if you want,' '' a senior adviser said. ''But it's hard to find a venue where both parties could be relaxed.''
 
How It Began
Administration officials said that the President began thinking about a two-track strategy for an informal meeting and a formal summit with the Soviet leader in June, after his trip to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in Brussels the month before. His belief that the time was right ''gelled,'' his advisers said, after a trip in July to Eastern Europe and his participation in the Paris economic summit meeting, where he talked to the leaders of the Group of Seven industrial nations about his plans.
His aides said he was also moved by his meetings with leaders in Poland and Hungary, including the Solidarity founder, Lech Walesa, and by their requests that he be more supportive of the Soviet leader.
His advisers said that Mr. Bush drafted a letter to Mr. Gorbachev proposing the meeting on Air Force One on his way back from the economic summit conference on July 18, and that Mr. Gorbachev accepted early in August. The two Governments exchanged a series of cables with suggestions about where and how the meeting could be conducted, and what issues it might encompass. But they were determined to keep it secret until the more substantive 1990 summit conference was announced.
Today's announcement fits a pattern established by the Bush White House. Whenever officials are pelted with criticism on a major issue, they huddle in secret and come up with a grand strategy designed to dispel criticism.
 
A Top Democrat Is Positive
The reaction from allies and Congress was largely positive. Asked if he felt that Mr. Bush had struck a blow against his reputation for timidity toward developments in Eastern Europe, the Democratic Speaker of the House, Representative Thomas S. Foley of Washington, replied, ''It certainly helps, helps in that direction.''
Although there are many details yet to be planned, the Bush advisers are determined that they not be ''sandbagged'' by the Soviets, as many American officials felt the United States was during the ''informal'' summit talks with the Soviets in Reykjavik, Iceland, three years ago when President Reagan almost agreed to a hastily improvised idea to abolish all offensive ballistic missiles within 10 years.
''If anyone is aware of the dangers of Reykjavik, it's Bush, who was Vice President at the time; Scowcroft, who criticized it at the time, and Quayle, who was a hawk in the Senate and was appalled by it at the time,'' a senior official said. ''We are all very alert to the fact that that is not the model to be followed. You'll see a lot of subtle effort over the next month to lay the groundwork for lower expections.''
Asked today if the Soviets would have any surprises in the Mediterranean, as they did at Reykjavik, Mr. Shevardnadze smiled and said, ''Let's wait and see.''

HEADLINE: BUSH WILL MEET GORBACHEV TO GET 'BETTER ACQUAINTED' IN TALKS AT SEA NEXT MONTH;
East Europe as Catalyst

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Oct. 31

 BODY:
Eastern Europe has not been on the formal agenda of a Soviet-American summit conference since World War II, but it will certainly be a major topic when George Bush and Mikhail S. Gorbachev hold their shipboard summit meeting in December.
There seems little doubt that the sweeping changes in Eastern Europe were a catalyst for today's sudden announcement, and have come to dominate the East-West agenda even though both sides have agreed in advance that there will be no formal agenda when the two Presidents gather for an informal exchange of views.
What Mr. Gorbachev seems to want most of all - more, even, than the political lift the Mediterranean encounter might give him at home - is reassurance from Mr. Bush that the United States will not try to exploit the retrenchment of Communism for some strategic advantage.
 
Stunning Momentum in East
Mr. Bush, in turn, will want to know that Mr. Gorbachev is sincere in signaling that Moscow will let the changes in Eastern Europe go on without interference. 
Mr. Bush said today that his decision to meet the Soviet leader on an informal basis, contrary to Washington's long preference for well-scripted summit meetings, was driven in part by the stunning momentum of democratic movements in Eastern Europe.
''What changed my mind on it was consultation with our allies, the rapidity of change in Eastern Europe, the emergence of democracies in this hemisphere, and this concept that I just didn't want to, in this time of dynamic change, miss something,'' the President said.
 
German Reunification Raised
Events in Eastern Europe have moved faster than anyone in Moscow or Washington expected. They have included the rise of a Solidarity Government in Poland, the transformation of the Hungarian Communist Party and sudden shifts in East Germany that have brought the question of German reunification into the open.
The new East German Communist leader, Egon Krenz, arrived in Moscow today on his first foreign trip since he replaced Erich Honecker on Oct. 18.
More than anything else, East Germany, where throngs of demonstrators have been demanding legalized opposition groups, free elections and an end to censorship, has caught both superpowers unawares and increased the urgency of a calming conversation.
''I don't think anybody is quite ready yet for the German question,'' said Zbigniew Brzezinski, the former national security adviser, who is in Moscow as part of an academic delegation conferring with the Soviet experts about Eastern Europe.
''If reforms in East Germany take the shape of Hungary or Poland, then you have to ask, what is the point of East Germany?'' he added. That raises the prospect of East Germany's being absorbed into its western neighbor.
''I don't think they are ready for that,'' Mr. Brzezinski said. ''They see that sort of unification as much too premature and destabilizing.'' Soviet officials and American specialists say the Soviets are willing to see Eastern Europe move toward democracy and free markets, toward demilitarization and possibly even toward neutrality, as long as they do not see a threat to their own security.
 
'Finlandization Now O.K.'
''The Finlandization of Eastern Europe is now O.K. with the Soviet Union, without any concessions by the West,'' said Charles Gati, a professor of political science at Union College in Schenectady, N.Y., who is the leader of the American academic group visiting Moscow.
''Finlandization'' is often used these days to refer to Soviet satellites' evolving independent states, like Finland, that are mindful of Soviet security interests.
''All they ask of the West is to make sure it does not go beyond Finlandization into anti-Sovietism,'' said Mr. Gati, who predicted that the two leaders would discuss Eastern Europe in December.
For Mr. Gorbachev, summitry has been a way of creating an international calm that allows him to focus on his pressing domestic crises.
Ideally the Kremlin would like to see Western intentions reflected in concrete progress toward arms agreements, including both cuts in nuclear arsenals and reductions of conventional forces in Europe.
 
Warsaw Pact Restructuring Seen
Georgi K. Shakhnazarov, a close aide to Mr. Gorbachev who has specialized in Eastern European affairs, said in an interview today that Moscow was prepared for a ''restructuring'' of the Warsaw Pact, including the eventual withdrawal of Soviet troops from Poland and Hungary and guarantees that the alliance will not interfere in internal affairs of its members.
But he said this should be a mutual withdrawal negotiated with the West, rather than a Soviet retreat from the territory of its allies.
''The troops will be withdrawn, but it will be done within the framework of the all-European process,'' he said. ''From the standpoint of mutual confidence and stability, it would be much better for everyone if it happens on the basis of common consent, with participation of both alliances.''
Aside from arms control, Mr. Gorbachev may also want to clarify the motives behind Western economic packages aimed at Poland and Hungary, and to appeal for lowering of economic barriers between East and West.
Mr. Gorbachev will find the creeping Westernization of his allies somewhat easier to sell at home if he can argue that it may bring economic benefits here, such as loosening American restrictions on sale of technology and on Soviet participation in international trade and economic organizations.
 
Profits From the Imagery
Even if the shipboard meeting does not produce tangible agreements, Mr. Gorbachev can expect to profit from the atmospherics. The comforting imagery of the two men using warships for a friendly get-together, the language and gestures of mutual understanding, may make the helter-skelter transformations in Eastern Europe seem more manageable.
Mr. Bush has already demonstrated by his cautious diplomacy during visits to Poland and Hungary that he is sensitive to the Kremlin's feelings about Eastern Europe.
Mr. Gati, who has worked as a State Department consultant on Eastern Europe, said it was in the American interest, too, to continue this policy of reassurance. Otherwise, Mr. Gorbachev's easygoing policy might face a challenge from hard-liners here.
''It's not in our own interest now to rub it in,'' he said. ''Russia is retrenching, but we don't want it to happen so fast as to produce a counter-reaction here.''

HEADLINE: Bush and Congress Reach Accord Raising Minimum Wage to $4.25

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31

 BODY:
Ending a long political deadlock, the Bush Administration and Congressional leaders compromised today on an increase in the minimum wage to $3.80 an hour next year and $4.25 in 1991.
The minimum wage has been $3.35 since 1981.
The agreement came after President Bush accepted a steeper rise in the wage floor than he had wanted, and Congressional Democrats retreated from their opposition to a training wage for teen-agers below the statutory minimum.
 
Training Wage Is Spelled Out
The training wage would be $3.35 in the first year and $3.61 in the second. It could apply, under the agreement, only to workers ages 16 through 19 in their first job, and it could be paid to a particular worker for no more than six months. Opponents of a training wage have argued that it would exploit new workers and take jobs from established ones. Proponents maintain that a lower wage would encourage businesses to give young people a break. 
Republican lawmakers said they had put pressure on the White House to accept the compromise after Mr. Bush's decision last June to veto a rise in the minimum wage to $4.55.
''Many of us,'' said Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, ''felt this was not an issue where we ought to be standing up - holding up - a 30- to 40-cent-an-hour pay increase at the same time we're talking about capital gains, for instance.''
 
Awkward Political Position
Mr. Bush and Republican lawmakers have made a reduction in the capital gains tax rate their top legislative priority this year. Some Democratic critics of the cut have contended that it would primarily benefit wealthy taxpayers. Republicans said it was awkward for them politically to support that while opposing a wage increase for the lowest-paid workers.
As recently as his news conference this morning, the President was threatening to veto a higher minimum wage program. If it contained elements ''that I can't take, I'll send it right back,'' he said. Administration and Congressional leaders said the outline of the deal was reached Monday, and the compromise was refined today.
Mr. Bush issued a statement tonight saying that the agreement was ''consistent with the criteria I set forth,'' and that he was especially pleased by the inclusion of a training wage.
 
Defining a Training Program
If employers wanted to pay the subminimum to workers for more than three months, they would have to establish with the Labor Department that they were providing a genuine training program. The details of what would be considered a training program were still being drafted tonight.
John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, said the basic parts of the compromise were suggested to the White House last week by Lane Kirkland, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., and were negotiated with Congressional leaders. The Kirkland proposal, Mr. Sununu said, ''was something we could live with.''
Mr. Kirkland issued a statement tonight welcoming the compromise and saying that the proposal for a training wage contained ''adequate safeguards so youth are not exploited and older workers not displaced.''
A spokesman for the United States Chamber of Commerce took issue with Mr. Kirkland. Bob Martin, director of the Chamber's employee relations policy center, said the higher minimum would ''leave hundreds of thousands of workers without their first job.''
''We were just cut out of the debate,'' Mr. Martin added. The first minimum wage, 25 cents an hour, was enacted in 1938, and the floor has been raised periodically since then. Since 1981, when it was increased to $3.35 from $3.10, consumer prices have risen by more than a third. Senator Edward M. Kennedy, the Massachusetts Democrat who heads the Labor and Public Welfare Committee, observed today that if the wage floor had merely kept up with inflation since 1981 it would be $4.79 today.
 
Many Women at Minimum
The new rates would go into effect April 1, 1990, and April 1, 1991. In recent years, it has been legal to pay some students less than the minimum wage, but if the compromise approved today is enacted, it would be the first time the law has allowed a widespread subminimum.
About 4 million workers, out of the 60 million Americans paid by the hour, work at the minimum wage, and several million more earn less than $4.25. The Labor Department says more than three of every 10 workers earning the minimum wage are teen-agers, and 70 percent of the minimum wage workers are women.
An increase in the wage floor can be expected to have a ripple effect as higher-paid workers get raises to maintain the differential between them and the lowest paid.
Last year, House Democrats proposed an increase to $5.25 over three years. In his election campaign, Mr. Bush countered with a proposal for an increase to $4.25 over three years and a lower training wage for all workers.
 
Veto Was Sustained
In May, Congress approved a rise to $4.55 over three years with a limited training wage. The President vetoed the bill on the ground that it was inflationary, would slow economic growth and would cause a loss of jobs. Congress was unable to override the veto.
Democrats hoped to be able to use the veto as an example of how the Bush Administration was callous toward poor workers. But that argument did not seem to take hold until this fall, when the capital gains debate caught fire.
The compromise was announced by Congressional leaders at a news conference this afternoon, to the dismay of the White House. An Administration official who had been involved in the negotiations complained that ''the understanding was the announcement would be done on a bipartisan basis.''
 
Vote May Come Soon
Democratic leaders said they had no choice but to announce the deal since they were taking it before the Rules Committee today in preparation for a House vote as soon as Wednesday.
After the announcement, Labor Secretary Elizabeth H. Dole hurried to the Capitol to hold a news conference of her own.
In the end, both sides claimed credit. Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the Democratic leader, called it a ''victory for working Americans,'' and the Speaker of the House, Thomas S. Foley of Washington, said an increase in the minimum wage was ''a principal item on the Congressional agenda.''

HEADLINE: Better Relations Depend on U.S., Deng Tells Nixon

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Oct. 31

 BODY:
China's senior leader, Deng Xiaoping, met with former President Richard M. Nixon today and told him that it was up to the United States to take steps to improve relations with China.
''Frankly speaking, the U.S. was involved too deeply in the turmoil and counterrevolutionary rebellion that occurred in Beijing not long ago,'' Mr. Deng said. ''China was the real victim, and it is unjust to reprove China for it.''
''We hope that China and the United States will solve as soon as possible the problems in their relations and will create a sound basis on which to promote future ties,'' Mr. Deng said. ''However, it is up to the U.S. to take the initiative. The U.S. is capable of taking some initial steps.'' 
The tough comments were the latest in a series of mixed signals from the Chinese.
 
'No-Holds-Barred Exchange'
On Monday, for example, the Government announced that martial-law troops would be withdrawn from Tiananmen Square and replaced by armed police officers, in a move apparently calculated to coincide with Mr. Nixon's visit and to show that life is returning to normal in the capital.
On the other hand, the troop presence outside the American Embassy has been substantially increased since Saturday, the day of Mr. Nixon's arrival, and an American diplomat said there had been an increase in harassment of United States diplomats and their dependents.
A member of Mr. Nixon's party who attended the meeting with Mr. Deng said it was a ''courteous but a very tough, no-holds-barred exchange.''
Mr. Deng seemed tired and not as fit as in other recent public appearances. Instead of walking out to greet his guest, as is customary, Mr. Deng remained at his chair and Mr. Nixon was brought to him. Mr. Deng, who is 85 years old, slurred his words and his hands trembled.
 
Gain Seen in Common Ground
Mr. Nixon, who is deeply respected in China because of his landmark 1972 Presidential visit, which began the process toward normalization of relations between Washington and Beijng, is on a private fact-finding trip to China. He is to report to President Bush on his return, and both sides seem to hope that the trip will improve Chinese-American relations.
''I have watched Chinese-American relations very closely for 17 years,'' Mr. Nixon told Mr. Deng. ''There has never been a more difficult crisis than at the present time in those relations, because this time the concerns developed not from those who are foes of China, but from those who are friends of China. It is very important in our talks, if we can examine those differences and repair the damage that has been done to the respect in the U.S. among China's friends for some of China's leaders.''
The meeting lasted for three hours, including lunch, and covered a range of subjects, including the violent suppression of the democracy movement in early June, Chinese-Soviet and American-Soviet relations, the changes under way in Eastern Europe and the prospects for further liberalization in China, said the member of Mr. Nixon's party who attended the session.
 
'Profound Disagreement'
After the meeting, Mr. Nixon told reporters that for all the disagreements between the United States and China, there is more common ground than at the time of his visit in 1972, and that this common ground can lead to a process of repairing relations.
''Today we have a profound disagreement about a very tragic incident, but that disagreement is not going to derail the relationship between these two countries,'' Mr. Nixon said. ''It should not. It should be discussed, and we should attempt to resolve it as well as we can. We must build from here. If we could do it in '72, we can do it now.''
This afternoon, Mr. Nixon also met with Jiang Zemin, the Communist Party leader. The member of Mr. Nixon's party said the discussion included topics like the military crackdown in early June, political and economic liberalization, China's business climate and Chinese university students here and abroad.
 
U.S. Shrugs Off Accusations
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (Reuters) -The United States is not especially concerned about Deng Xiaoping's charge that Washington was involved in the June unrest in Beijing, a State Department official said today.
The official, who asked not to be identified, said increased Chinese security around the American Embassy in Beijing may have been the result of Halloween festivities at the embassy but was without justification and amounted to harassment of Americans.
He said United States officials would be watching to see whether Chinese leaders heeded Mr. Nixon's advice that the two countries had to work together despite differences over the killings near Tiananmen Square.

HEADLINE: Beijing's Course: Spinning in Circles

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Oct. 31

 BODY:
The conventional wisdom these days, especially abroad, is that a circle of elderly leaders is dragging China backward toward a rigid planned economy, undoing many of the economic and political changes of the last decade.
But seen up close, China seems less to be marching backward than to be spinning in circles, in the view of many diplomats and Chinese analysts. They portray the still-fractured Communist Party as a millipede that has lost its sense of direction, and while the steps backward get the most attention, other limbs are digging in or even struggling to go forward.
One such limb is Wu Jinglian, a top economic adviser to the Government and a man who has proved himself to be committed to change. Last year, Mr. Wu lost the ear of the leadership because he was too radical; he urged allowing prices to float freely instead of being set by the state. Now, Mr. Wu appears to be very influential once more, and he is surprisingly optimistic. 
''We have two alternatives,'' he said in an interview. ''One is to let the economy move on toward market-oriented reform. The other is to strengthen administrative controls. I don't know which direction the leadership will take. But we can make use of the situation to carry out step-by-step price reform.''
 
Freeing of Prices Seen
Mr. Wu's point is that price restructuring is more of a possibility now than it was at the beginning of this year, because freeing prices is easier to accomplish when inflation is low. The Government has already brought transportation prices closer to market levels, and the Government spokesman, Yuan Mu, has said other prices would also be raised in coming years.
''The reforms that are necessary may be easier to carry out now than they were before,'' said Albert Keidel, who runs Rock Creek Research, a research concern in Bethesda, Md., that focuses on the Chinese economy.
Nicholas Lardy, a China expert at the University of Washington, said, ''I'm very skeptical of the view that reform is dead in the water for the next year or two.''
This relatively optimistic perspective is far from universal, and many young Chinese intellectuals brim with despair. But amid the crosscurrents there is an eddy of hope that seems to be little recognized by popular sentiment abroad.
''We are still at an intersection,'' a businessman said the other day. ''It's not over yet.''
 
Mixed Signals Abound
While the hard-line editorials get the most foreign comment, China's newspapers abound in mixed signals. Detecting a pattern to all this is a complex task. Almost no one predicted the democracy movement this spring, the subsequent re-emergence of the old-guard leadership, the violence of the crackdown or the rise of Jiang Zemin as Communist Party leader.
At least in the political realm, there is a limited consensus among diplomats and scholars about China's aims. While the experts disagree about how far the repression will go, most concur that the Government is determined to crush dissent and is adamantly opposed to further political liberalization.
But even in politics, there has been more talk than action - partly because of the widespread proclivity of Chinese officials to pledge allegiance to the new policy and then quietly do what was happening before. The first major call for a purge, for instance, came on June 25, and yet so far almost nobody has been drummed out of the party.
Culture Minister Wang Meng was pushed of office, and so was the Governor of Hainan, Liang Xiang. But the overwhelming majority of provincial leaders, Central Committee members and local cadres have emerged unscathed by the simple expedient of expressing enthusiasm for the new policies, Chinese and foreign analysts say.
 
Some Surprising Rises
Surprisingly, some people who were sympathetic to the democracy movement have even seen their status rise. Wan Li, a Politburo member who was in the United States when martial law was declared and who then breached orders by returning to China, has gained influence in recent months. And Rong Yiren, the country's best-known businessman, is believed to be under consideration for a major Government post, even though he apparently encouraged employees to support the movement.
In its comments on the economy, the Government has made clear its intention to reassert controls and slow down growth. Many Western economists are reluctant to criticize such steps. A period of retrenchment in which the economic base is enlarged and a legal and banking system are developed would be very useful, they say - if it was followed by further liberalization.
Liu Guoguang, one of the most influential economists these days as an adviser to the present leadership, also insists that the restructuring will continue. Instead of the rigid Marxist one might expect to find serving as an adviser to leaders like Prime Minister Li Peng, Mr. Liu is a thoughtful academic who argues that a pause for breath now is essential to build a base for further economic liberalization later on.
When the Government has put the economy in order in a couple of years, the restructuring will resume and accelerate, he said. He noted that the Government was continuing its experiments with stock markets, and he emphasized that it was not against further change.
''Both price reform and enterprise reform are unavoidable,'' Mr. Liu said.

HEADLINE: Excerpts From Bush's News Conference on Plan to Meet Gorbachev at Sea

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from President Bush's news conference today:
 
OPENING STATEMENT
President Gorbachev and I will meet Dec. 2 and Dec. 3 aboard U.S. and Soviet naval vessels on alternate days in the Mediterranean. Our discussions will cover the current international situation and developments in U.S.-Soviet relations. And in view of the full-scale U.S.-Soviet summit to be held in the United States during the late spring or early summer of 1990, President Gorbachev and I have agreed that an interim informal meeting at this time would be appropriate. Our talks will be informal in character, designed to allow us to become better acquainted with one another and to deepen our respective understanding of each other's views. Neither President Gorbachev nor I anticipate that substantial decisions or agreements will emerge from this December meeting.
 
QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
 
Q. Mr. President, what do you hope to accomplish with this? I mean, is the economy going to be one of the main parts of the agenda or do you have arms control? 
 
A. I think there will be talk of a wide array of subjects without a specific agenda. And this is what I proposed to Mr. Gorbachev several months ago, after our return from the Paris Economic Summit. We've been working on this all that time.
I made the proposal to Mr. Gorbachev. And I'll say this, they immediately and enthusiastically - he did -thought this was a good idea.
 
The Soviet Economy
 
Q. There's been some speculation that a meeting of this type might be intended - an idea to revamp the Soviet economy. Are you trying to get some ideas together to go to this meeting with some type of proposal like that?
 
A. Well, I'm sure that now that the meeting is announced, there will be an awful - many suggestions as to the subject we should discuss. . . . But there's not going to be an agenda or meeting that could be seen to fail or succeed on whether we make agreements of this nature. That's not what this meeting is about. And so, the President - President Gorbachev -will have been in Italy, and it seemed like a very convenient way to do this. But there's not going to be - there's nothing off the table, nothing on it. It's not going to be an arms-control meeting. Clearly, the summit will drive the arms control agenda.
 
Gorbachev's Changes
 
Q. How do you assess Mr. Gorbachev's reforms? Do you think he's in trouble?
 
A. I want to talk to him about their economy, our economy, a wide array of subjects. And we have - I've said over and over again, we want to see perestroika succeed. And they know this. There hasn't been a disconnect.
 
Bush's Plan for Meeting
 
Q. Now that it's out, sir, could you tell us a little bit about the steps that led to this, your proposal, how and when it was made, and so forth?
 
A. Well, I did say that I made the proposal - I believe it was in July -in writing to the President, and then got a very prompt response, and then we've been going back and forth at that level, and then it's been discussed by the Secretary of State and Mr. Shevardnadze, the details worked out.
 
Q. When was it agreed upon?
 
A. Oh, a month ago, I'd say.
 
Q. Mr. President, since July, several of your very top officials have said publicly that they didn't see any value in having a summit if it couldn't be carefully prepared, absolute guarantee of success with some kind of a serious outcome. You're saying that's off.
 
A. Well, they weren't speaking for the President. I've told you what I think.
You know, there was one time when I felt that such a meeting wouldn't be productive, and I think it is going to be productive, but it's not going to be an agenda meeting. We first set the summit. That will drive the arms-control agenda. That's out there with a date on it - rough time frame on it - and the other is rapid change going on. I now have a much clearer view of how our allies feel on East-West relations. We've got problems in this hemisphere that I want to discuss, and so the two are not inconsistent.
 
Arms-Control Issue
 
Q. Mr. President, the last time there was a summit like this was in Reykjavik, and it evolved into a rather free-wheeling arms-control negotiation that caused consternation in Europe, because at one point, we were talking about eliminating all nuclear weapons, which Europeans felt would give the Soviets an advantage because of their preponderance of conventional superiority. What guarantees are there that that won't happen at this meeting?
 
A. Well, because it's - neither side thinks it's going to happen, and we have a summit, an arms-control summit, a summit which will be dominated by arms-control issues already established, separate and apart, and the Soviet leader and I both understand the kind of meeting we want to have, so I don't think there's any confict there at all.
 
Support for Gorbachev?
 
Q. Mr. President, is one of your purposes in having this meeting to give Gorbachev a political boost at home?
 
A. No. I hadn't particularly thought about that. If it does, fine.
 
Groundwork for Talks
 
Q.Mr. President, to what extent have the events in Eastern Europe caused you perhaps to want to accelerate this? Or will that be a major factor in your discussions?
 
A. I expect there will be a lot of discussion of that. But, as I indicated, the genesis of this was in July when there was certainly change. We'd just come back, as you recall, from Poland and Hungary. And there's been a lot of dramatic change since then - in Germany, some moves in Czechoslovakia. So things have moved, but I can't say that it, that the meeting was predicated on the change in Eastern Europe solely.
 
Stance on Eastern Europe
 
Q. You say this pre-summit summit is not meant to bail out Mr. Gorbachev politically. How about yourself? You've been criticized by the Democrats for being too timid toward Eastern Europe and toward Gorbachev, helping him with perestroika. Do you think it will help you?
 
A. That's not why we're doing it, but if that should be the fallout, so be it. We've known what we're doing. We've been on this track for some time. I've elected to remain very quiet in the face of a good deal of sentiment that we were missing an opportunity. And that, that hasn't perturbed me because we've got good people that know what we're doing in terms of the Soviet Union. And if people see that a little more clearly now, so be it. That's a plus.
 
Accusations of Timidity
 
Q. It seems as though you're going there without any initiatives. And we're trying to read between the lines here. If that's the case, aren't you going to be accused once again of being timid?
 
A. Oh, I'm sure somebody'd politically accuse me of anything, I mean, but that's not the point. I tell you one thing, our allies will be delighted about this. They've just been informed this morning, and I guarantee you there will be enthusiasm through much of the free world and a lot of the rest of the world. But, look, I don't expect to have everybody that's been firing away at me up there jump up with joy.
 
Turnaround on Talks
 
Q. This is exactly the kind of meeting that you and your aides have been saying for months, you did not want, and it seems exactly the kind of meeting that Gorbachev, given his domestic troubles, needs very, very much. What changed your mind?
 
A. What changed my mind on it was consultation with our allies; the rapidity of change in Eastern Europe; the emergence of democracies in this hemisphere, and this concept that I just didn't want to, in this time of dynamic change, miss something, something that I might get better firsthand from Mr. Gorbachev.
 
Choice of Venue
 
Q. Mr. President, what made you decide to meet on a ship?
 
A. Well, we can do it without too much fanfare. . . . Where there's a relatively few number of people, not a lot of crush of bodies out there, and a chance to put our feet up and talk.
 
Summit Meeting or Not?
 
Q: Mr. President, between hemispheric summits and drug summits and Gorbachev summits and economic summits, you're doing a lot of mountaineering. Let me ask you this
 
A: This one isn't a summit. So scratch this one off your list of things to worry about. I've got to make that point over and over again. Summits take on a definition, an expectation of grand design and grand agreements, and that's not what this is.
 
Bush's East Bloc Vision
 
Q. Mr. President, one of the criticisms that's been made is - by the Democrats particularly - is that this is a really unique time for you, that after 40 years of calling for free markets and open society, that you have chance to perhaps cement some of these changes in the Eastern Bloc in Europe and in the Soviet Union. Do you have some kind of plan or vision for getting that accomplished? Is this part of it?
 
A. We're seeing it move, aren't we? We're seeing dynamic change, and I want to handle it properly. I want to do whatever the U.S. can do to facilitate these kinds of changes.
 
Gorbachev's Surprises
 
Q: Mr. President, you say you have confidence in the Soviets. What assurances do you have that you won't be surprised by something Mr. Gorbachev might bring to the table? It's widely believed that President Reagan was somewhat sandbagged in Reykjavik.
 
A: He's free to bring anything he wants. There's no agenda. But there's - the idea that arms control - we might be surprised on arms control. I don't worry about that because we've got an understanding that the already announced summit meeting will handle those items.
 
The Gates Speech
 
Q. Mr. President, were you upset at all by Secretary of State Baker's . . . (This portion was inaudible on tape, but refered to Mr. Baker's supression of a speech by Robert Gates, the deputy national security adviser.)
 
A. I've discussed this matter with Mr. Baker, and Mr. Gates, and Mr. Scowcroft, even discussed it with Marlin Fitzwater. Don't say I don't reach out . . . We've got a good, strong team coping with these problems, and you - the degree in which Bob Gates and the Secretary of State are together, and Brent and John Sununu. Why, it's - we've been very lucky. And so, I don't get all exercised about that kind of thing. I know everybody else does around here, but I don't.
 
Outlook for Gorbachev
 
Q. Mr. President, as recently as this summer, some of your senior advisers, dare I say some in this room, were expressing doubts that Gorbachev would survive all of his internal political difficulties. Did you ever share those views? And has anything happened - what has happened to turn you around?
 
A. Look, we are looking at everything we can regarding the rapid changes that are taking place not only in Eastern Europe but in the Soviet Union. And we've got very thoughtful people outside the Government that give me their opinions. And I don't think anybody has a corner on all the wisdom, but I can't speculate on that question. . . .
 
Q. But, sir, you wouldn't be meeting with him, of course, if you thought he was a goner. . . .
 
A. A goner, no, I don't - I don't -that word never entered my mind. So you know, you hear a lot of crosscurrents about how successful perestroika is going to be. But one thing you get from all the Soviet leaders is, ''Look, the clock isn't going to be set back and we are going to go forward with perestroika.'' . . .

HEADLINE: In Seattle Mayoral Race, a Sense of the Possible

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Oct. 31

 BODY:
If this city is America's most livable metropolis, as two publications recently concluded, there is scant evidence in its first wide-open campaign for mayor in 12 years.
As in most American cities, the issues here are crack in the neighborhoods, gridlock on the freeways, racial tensions and a declining public school system. What may be different about Seattle is that none of the problems are considered insurmountable.
Two City Hall veterans, Douglas N. Jewett, who is 42 years old, and Norman B. Rice, 46, are vying to succeed Mayor Charles Royer, retiring after three terms to head the Institute of Politics at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University. 
 
Each Would Break Ground
If Mr. Rice, a City Council member since 1978, is elected, he would become the first black mayor of Seattle, a city with a black population of about 10 percent. Mr. Jewett, who has been the City Attorney for 11 years, is seeking to become the first Republican mayor in more than 20 years. The race is officially nonpartisan, and Mr. Jewett has downplayed his party affiliation in seeking to lead the Democratic city.
An old villain in the Pacific Northwest, Los Angeles, has been raised by both candidates as an example of what Seattle could become if measures are not taken to preserve the quality of life. To curb suburban sprawl and limit growth caused in part by an increasing number of Californian moving to the area, Mr. Jewett has proposed changing the zoning of certain areas of the city so they can be filled with apartment houses.
Both men favor mass transit, a combination of a new rail system with the existing buses, as a solution to clogged roadways, and say the city cannot expect any help from the Federal Government in putting together a system.
 
Each Has a Ballot Measure
Each candidate has championed a ballot measure to help his cause. Mr. Rice backs a proposal that would increase the city's business and occupation tax to pay for 102 more police officers, which he says should be enough to make most neighborhoods feel safe from drug dealers.
The centerpiece of Mr. Jewett's campaign has been a pledge to end the busing of schoolchildren to achieve racial integration. Since the program began in 1978, public school enrollment has declined by more than 20,000; fewer than 40,000 students attend public schools, half the amount of the early 1970's.
Parents have complained about two-hour, crosstown bus rides for a half-day of kindergarten and have criticized the school board for being intransigent. The busing measure has dominated the campaign thus far.
 
Schools 'in a Death Spiral'
Mr. Jewett helped draft an initiative that will appear on the ballot on Tuesday, the same day as the mayoral election, which would use city money to promote integration without busing. The schools, Mr. Jewett said, ''are in a death spiral.''
Mr. Rice, who ran for mayor in 1985, said he entered the race this year because he viewed the anti-busing intiative as a threat to racial stability. In July, he called the initiative ''a terrible new ingredient'' in Seattle politics. But he has since offered a plan to end busing in four years.
Although polls show the initiative has wide support, both of the city's daily newspapers have been highly critical of the measure. Seattle city legal officials tried, unsuccessfully, to keep it off the Nov. 7 ballot, challenging its validity in court.
Some of Mr. Rice's supporters have accused Mr. Jewett of playing to racial fears, comparing his anti-busing campaign to George Bush's use of Willie Horton, a black man who committed crimes after he was furloughed from a Massachusetts prison, in the Presidential election last year.
In one heated exchange last week, Mr. Rice accused Mr. Jewett of ''wanting to keep black kids on one side of town.'' Mr. Jewett replied that busing has fostered segregated schools because so many whites have left the system.
 
Making a Name in a Backwater
Raised in Chicago, Mr. Jewett graduated from Dartmouth College and Yale University Law School and came to Seattle in the 1970's. When elected City Attorney in 1977 at the age of 31, he quickly made a name for himself with an office that had always been a backwater.
He explored forming a third political party, and then became an early supporter of John Anderson, the former Congressman who ran as an independent candidate for President in 1980. Using the nuclear freeze movement as his main campaign theme, Mr. Jewett ran in 1982 as a Republican challenger to Senator Henry M. Jackson, who trounced him by a 3-to-1 margin.
As City Attorney, he drew fire for setting up police road blocks to stop drunken drivers and for organizing a campaign to outlaw posters on city telephone poles, both of which were criticized as violations of the Constitution.
 
A Broadcaster and Banker
Mr. Rice, raised in Denver, is a graduate of the University of Washington and worked as a broadcaster and a banker before entering city politics in 1978.
A rising star on the City Council, Mr. Rice found his career stalled following two lackluster campaigns, one for mayor in 1985 and one for Congress in 1988. Endorsed by Mayor Royer this year, Mr. Rice is just now starting to show some movement in the polls. The race is viewed as a tossup.
With its robust economy and relatively low crime rate, this city of 500,000 people is thought to be in good shape for the next 10 years no matter who is elected mayor. Money Magazine and Places Rated Almanac have recently called Seattle the most livable city in the nation, a mixed blessing for a city whose residents fear that excessive growth will lead to deterioration.
''We've got so much going for us -we're relatively new; everybody here seems to care passionately about the environment; the citizens are involved in a range of issues - that no problem seems unbeatable,'' said Mike Lowry, a former Congressman from Seattle who now teaches at Seattle University.

HEADLINE: How Yonkers Can Move Forward

 BODY:
General election contests for mayor and the City Council give voters in Yonkers, N.Y., clear choices between the past and the future.
In 1985 Federal District Judge Leonard Sand found that Yonkers had deliberately promoted racial segregation in public housing and education for nearly 40 years. A voluntary desegregation plan has been instituted in the schools. But a majority of the seven-member City Council continue to resist the judge's order to build moderate- and low-income housing. 
Preoccupation with the housing issue distracts from Yonkers's considerable problems of economic development, crime and drugs. Moving forward aggressively will require new leadership. First and foremost that means re-election of the Mayor, Nicholas Wasicsko, a Democrat who has steadfastly and courageously argued for compliance with the housing order.
His Republican opponent, Henry Spallone, a retired New York City policeman, has been one of the most vocal and defiant Council members.
If Mr. Wasicsko is to be more effective, however, he will need like-minded new Council members. In the Second District we prefer the Democratic challenger, Ed Cousens, a financial manager, over the Republican incumbent, Peter Chema, a businessman who has opposed the housing order.
Another defiant Council member, Edward Fagan, a Republican, faces a credible challenge in the Sixth District from Ralph Ferraioli, an insurance company executive. Mr. Ferraioli, a Democrat, deserves support for his sensible emphasis on communication to make the housing remedy work.
In the Third District, the Democrat Barbara Cola seeks to fill the seat held by her late husband, Charles Cola. Her Republican opponent, John Spencer, seems more focused on carrying out the housing order and on sound fiscal management.
Seeking the Fourth District seat previously held by Mr. Spallone are Elliott Palais, Democrat, a university administrator, and Salvatore Sialiano, Republican, a businessman and former policeman. Mr. Palais offers more enlightened leadership. In other Council races, we are pleased to repeat September primary endorsements of Joe Farmer, a Democrat, in the First District and Thomas Dickerson, a Republican, in the Fifth District.

HEADLINE: We Need a Federal Disaster Relief Fund

 BODY:
To the Editor:
May I offer a serious suggestion on how this country can create in advance the huge funds necessary for speedy reconstruction and rehabilitation after earthquakes, hurricanes, tornadoes, floods, forest fires, droughts and other natural disasters?
Government agencies and relief organizations often do not immediately have the enormous financial resources for the needs following a San Francisco Bay area earthquake, a Hurricane Hugo and other catastrophes, especially when they follow in rapid succession. 
Many agree with President Bush's adamant position on no new taxes. But who could object if the Federal Government were to create a national disaster fund to be drawn upon as necessary anywhere in the country. Such a fund could be created, for example, by increasing taxes on gasoline, cigarettes, liquor, beer and even possibily telephone calls, so that every taxpayer makes some contribution, even those who don't own a car, smoke or drink.
The fund would spare states and communities the crushing and often impossible burden of repairing their local infrastructures and economies without having sufficient resources available on the local level. The relief fund could also lessen the political rancor that too often follows a major emergency, as we are seeing in San Francisco.
Such a national disaster relief fund should be set up to be inviolate, and impervious to political machinations, much as the Social Security system is protected.
 
DAN WALLACK
 New York, Oct. 20, 1989

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: FOOD NOTES

BYLINE: By Florence Fabricant

 BODY:

Pre-Marathon Pasta On Saturday evening, more than 10,000 participants in the New York City Marathon are expected to do their carbo-loading at Tavern on the Green at the annual pasta party sponsored by Ronzoni Foods Corporation. They will dine on three dishes selected from more than 60 recipes submitted by restaurants last week in three categories: traditional, cold salad and vegetarian.
The winners were ziti with tomato sauce from Mamma Leone's in the traditional category, cold sesame chicken with fusilli from Sam's Restaurant in the cold salad category and rotelli with mashed potato sauce and tomatoes from the Quilted Giraffe.
For the pre-marathon dinner, 4,000 pounds of pasta will be served to the runners cafeteria-style in shifts, beginning at 4 P.M. The meal is free and open to all registered runners. 
In conjunction with the marathon, Ronzoni is also donating 14,000 pounds of pasta to City Harvest to help feed the homeless. The Business of Food The Roundtable for Women in Food Service, an educational group, will hold a seminar for would-be entrepreneurs on Monday at the Art Directors Club, 250 Park Avenue South (at 19th Street). Four women who have been successful in starting their own food businesses will offer insights and answer questions.
The program begins at 5:45 P.M. and includes dinner. Panel members are Stacy Bogdonoff, a partner in Neuman & Bogdonoff, a Manhattan catering shop; Susan Axelrod, who owns Love and Quiches Ltd., on Long Island, which sells foods to shops and restaurants; Julie Flik of Flik International Corporation, a food-service management company in New York, and Doris Simpson, who owns Muirhead, a restaurant in New Jersey.
Admission is $35 for members, $45 for nonmembers. For reservations, call 212-439-0580.
 
Survey on Beef
In a telephone survey conducted for the Beef Industry Council by the Gallup Organization this summer, 40 percent of 801 adults nationwide said they ate less beef than they did five years ago. Five percent said they ate more.
Of the respondents who said they ate meat as a main meal the day before, 52 percent said they ate beef and 29 percent said chicken. Yet, when asked whether they preferred broiled sirloin, broiled chicken or broiled flounder, about the same number (40 percent) selected beef as chicken (37 percent). Twenty percent preferred fish.
The responses indicate that people still like to eat beef despite concerns about fat and cholesterol, the council said. The margin of sampling error was plus or minus 4 percent. A Spicy Chutney Two chefs, Eric and Jeanne Lewin of Easton, Conn., have adapted a family recipe and come up with a wonderful, mildly spicy, temptingly sweet and chunky chutney for fall menus. Called Pomerals Country Chutney, it is made with peaches, apples, dates, pineapple, onions, peppers and raisins and is seasoned with vinegar, brown sugar and spices.
The chutney is sold in nine-ounce jars for $3.95 at Le Petit Gourmet, 44-35 Douglaston Parkway, Douglaston, Queens, and at Lexington Gardens, 32 Churchill Road, Newtown, Conn. It is $4.50 at Made in Connecticut, 1 Liberty Street, Danbury, Conn. Debut of '87 Bordeaux A preview tasting of the 1987 Bordeaux vintage, along with a sampling of wines from the more highly regarded 1986 vintage, will be held on Nov. 13 at the Marriott Marquis, 46th Street and Broadway, from 6 to 8 P.M. This is the first time the Bordeaux Wine Bureau, a delegation of 26 producers, has opened its tasting to the public. The producers will be on hand to discuss their wines.
For tickets, which are $35, call the International Wine Center at 212-268-7517 or send a check to the center, at 231 West 29th Street, Suite 210, New York, N.Y. 10001.
On Nov. 14, Daniel Beck, an expert on Scotch whisky, and his associate, Roger Parson, will hold a tasting of single-malt Scotches at Harvey's Chelsea Restaurant, 108 West 18th Street, from 7 to 9:30 P.M. They will begin by giving a history of Scotch whisky, then guide the group through a tasting of the various styles of single malt, or unblended, whiskies.
There will also be a tasting of Scottish foods, including meat pies and haggis. The cost is $50 a person. Advance reservations are required. Checks may be sent to Spirited Tastings, 5608 Riverdale Avenue, Bronx, N.Y. 10471. For more information call Mr. Beck, 201-440-9299, or Mr. Parson, 212-796-8034.
 
Helping Those With AIDS
SOME of the proceeds from ''The Open Hand Cookbook'' (Pocket Books, $18.95), a collection of menus and recipes contributed by 63 California chefs, will benefit Project Open Hand, which provides meals for people in San Francisco with AIDS.
Robert C. Schneider, a chef who has served as a volunteer for the project, compiled and edited the collection. The well-detailed recipes are easy to follow and organized according to seasons.
Among the inviting menus for fall is Paul Bertolli's salad of fennel, mushrooms, Parmesan cheese and white truffles, followed by duck legs braised with onions and cabbage. For dessert, there are Seckel pears poached in red wine with burned caramel.

HEADLINE: Warner Brothers Plans To Distribute 'Roger'

 BODY:
''Roger and Me,'' the darkly comic documentary film about unemployment in Flint, Mich., will be commercially distributed by Warner Brothers, the film company said Monday.
''Roger and Me,'' which was critically praised at the New York and Toronto film festivals, will have its premiere on Dec. 22 in theaters in New York, Los Angeles and Toronto, and will be released in additional theaters around the country in January and February. 
A Warner Brothers executive, who asked not to be identified, said Warners had paid $3 million for the worldwide distribution rights.
''Roger and Me'' is the first film by Michael Moore, who is the movie's writer, narrator and sometime protagonist. The film, which shows the effects of recent General Motors Corporation plant closings in Flint, was made for $260,000. Part of the funds for the film came from a weekly bingo game in Flint.
As part of the deal, Warner Brothers and Mr. Moore will each contribute $25,000 to pay for housing for homeless families in Flint.

LENGTH: 1409 words

HEADLINE: Many Japanese Wary On Mitsubishi U.S. Deal

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 31

 BODY:
During the last few years, as Japan's larger real estate companies poured billions of dollars into overseas investments, the prestigious Mitsubishi Estate Company stood apart, being content to collect rents from its vast holdings at home and to watch their value soar.
Now that the century-old real estate giant, one of the wealthiest investment institutions in the world, has taken its most significant step abroad with its acquisition of a 51 percent stake in the Rockefeller Group for $846 million, many in Japan remain just as surprised by what they consider an odd deal.
The complicated deal leads Mitsubishi into some problems, and it will possibly have its shareholding diluted in 11 years to less than 20 percent. $1.3 Billion Mortgage A real estate investment trust sold in 1985, Rockefeller Center Properties Inc., owns a $1.3 billion mortgage on the key property of the group, Rockefeller Center. That trust's holdings can convert into a 71.5 percent interest in the group in the year 2000, which would leave Mitsubishi holding 51 percent of the remaining 28.5 percent stake. To counter such a conversion, it might be forced to buy back the shares in the trust owned by the public, and this could be expensive. 
Thus far, some of those shareholders have not been very pleased with their investments. A Manhattan lawyer familiar with the situation said today that while ''you could probably count the unhappy stockholders on one hand,'' there was a stockholder suit pending against Rockefeller Center Properties in the New York State Supreme Court that was filed four years ago.
The suit charges that the real estate trust's original offering documents were false and misleading in that they did not mention that NBC was thinking of leaving Rockefeller Center. The investment trust maintained that it had complied with all disclosure requirements. Eventually NBC decided not to move.
The trust's units closed today at $19.75 a share, up by 25 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange. The units had an original offering price of $20 a share four years ago.
 
Cash Flow Committed
While Mitsubishi gets enormous prestige from owning a piece of Rockefeller Center, the center's cash flow is entirely committed to the investment trust until the year 2000 and the bulk of Mitsubishi's real assets in the deal come from only three properties that are not part of the trust: the Time & Life Building, half of the McGraw-Hill Building and vacant land behind the Exxon Building.
Since Mitsubishi owns 51 percent of the Rockefeller Group, it owns 51 percent of the Time & Life Building, 51 percent of the group's half interest in the McGraw-Hill Building and the vacant land. Of course, if it buys out the trust's holders over the coming 10 years, it would own considerably more of everything.
Mitsubishi also faces the prospect of a backlash from Americans tired of seeing well-known United States assets acquired by wealthy Japanese interests. People involved in the planning for the deal said that Mitsubishi was initially planning to acquire 80 percent of the Rockefeller company, but agreed to take only 51 percent, with the prospect of an increase later, hoping to mute public reaction in the United States.
 
A Modest Impact
All this is for an investment that will have a modest impact at best on a company whose assets are worth, by one estimate, a mind-boggling $84 billion. The company also faces a huge job back home: it is planning a 30-year, $45 billion redevelopment of its choicest but aging properties, as it struggles to remain competitive in the dynamic Japanese real estate market.
''Mitsubishi Estate has been slower than everyone else in moving overseas, but they are so rich that frankly they don't need to do anything,'' said Alan Woodhull, the real estate analyst for Merrill Lynch Japan. ''And now they're stepping into one of the touchiest properties in New York. I mean, Rockefeller Center's where New York puts its Christmas tree.''
Still, Mitsubishi has proved its naysayers mistaken in the past by taking the long view. The Rockefeller Group could prove an excellent partner for future developments in the United States, a point emphasized by the company today at a news conference.
''This is a long-term propostion,'' said Jotaro Takagi, president of Mitsubishi, who added that the two had discussed co-development ideas in the past. ''We are participating in the future of the Rockefeller Group.''
 
Important Break in 1890
The company got its most important break in 1890, when it acquired most of what is now called Marunouchi from the Japanese Government. It was marginal land located at the northern end of the Imperial Palace gardens in central Tokyo, but Mitsubishi was patient.
After the war, as Japan's economy went into high gear, Mitsubishi developed row upon row of elegant office blocks, some elegant and some unexciting, most of them without the retail shops and neon of many other central Tokyo districts.
The buildings filled up and the value of the land soared, particularly when a real estate boom got under way in the 1980's. The company now manages nearly 2.5 million square meters of floor space, of which it owns 95 percent.
Today, the vacancy rate is about one-tenth of 1 percent. Mitsubishi listed its total assets at $8.2 billion as of March 31, but that vastly understates the market value of these properties, analysts said. The extraordinary inflation of Tokyo real estate prices over the last decade has brought enormous wealth to Mitsubishi.
 
Asset Value of $84 Billion
Mark Brown, the real estate analyst here for Barclays de Zoete Wedd, estimated Mitsubishi's total asset value at about $84 billion, at current market values, of which more than 90 percent is in Tokyo. Mitsubishi Estate's assets are shared in part with other members of the Mitsubishi group of financial and industrial companies, which directly own more than 20 percent of Mitsubishi Estate.
''I couldn't believe'' the $84 billion number ''when I first saw it,'' Mr. Brown said.
Mr. Woodhull of Merrill Lynch said, ''I don't think anybody really knows because the numbers are so theoretical.'' But he added that it was at least $22 billion, and likely much more. The reason for this huge variance is that there are very few purchases of property in Marinouchi to give some reflection of the values in this prime area.
Mitsubishi Estate also has relatively little debt. Its long-term debt stood at only $2.7 billion as of the end of March.
 
Steady Stream of Profits
As a result, the company has a reliable and steadily growing stream of profits. It had a net income of $270 million for the fiscal year that ended March 31, at the then prevailing exchange rates. Its revenues stood at $2.1 billion.
But all that wealth has brought some headaches. First, Mitsubishi has several big new developments under way, including construction of a 73-story tower and complex in Yokohama. Analysts said, though, that it has few such projects relative to its size, and that few will be coming on stream in the next few years.
Second, its holdings in Maranouchi are in need of a major revamping. Many of the structures, none of which rise much more than 10 stories, are aging quickly. And in addition to the physical deterioration of the area, Mitsubishi commands rents in the area that are, on average, about half of the top market level for new space, analysts said.
''The most they can hope for is an increase of around 15 percent or so every two years,'' said Mr. Brown of Barclays de Zoete Wedd. ''At that pace, there is no way they can catch up with what they would get for a new building.''
 
Push to Decentralize
The problem with the redevelopment of Marunouchi that Mitsubishi has planned is that the city of Tokyo and the national government are pushing hard to decentralize, not build concentrations of skyscrapers downtown. There is governmental resistance to allowing Mitsubishi to construct taller buildings.
Mitsubishi seems to be unfazed by these problems and it clearly knew of the Rockefeller Group difficulties, but went ahead nonetheless. The people involved in the deal said that the company leaped at the opportunity almost as soon as it was offered in September, knocking several other large Japanese real estate companies out of the running.
''An investment opportunity arose,'' said Mr. Takagi, Mitsubishi's president. ''We considered it and made a decision.''

HEADLINE: Keeping Tabs on the Mega-Shoppers

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WALTHAM, Mass., Oct. 31

 BODY:
Warren E. Norquist may not cut much of a figure at the local mall, but he was clearly born to shop. As worldwide director of purchasing and materials management for the Polaroid Corporation here, he spends $900 million a year, nearly half the money taken in by the large camera, film and electronics company, with the energy and sophistication of a teen-ager buying clothes or videotapes.
In purchasing everything from gum arabic to advertising to elevator maintenance, Mr. Norquist not only has a major impact on the success of Polaroid, but provides clues to the future course of the nation's economy. His activities and those of his counterparts at other industrial companies are tallied monthly by the National Association of Purchasing Management for its Purchasing Managers' Index. 
This seven-year-old index, published the first business day of each month, has gained growing prominence over the last year or two as economists and the securities markets strain for the first glimpse of the next recession.
 
'Secret Weapon in Forecasting'
The sharply increased attention to the purchasing index comes as the manufacturing sector it covers continues to shrink as a portion of the total economy. Some top economists, however, have long found the index's data on orders, production, inventories, employment and the speed of deliveries by suppliers to be highly useful.
The late Walter W. Heller, a former chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, once described the report as ''the most reliable single indicator and for many years my secret weapon in forecasting.''
Wednesday's reading is widely expected to be the sixth consecutive report below 50 percent, the point separating business expansion and contraction.
''Things are slowing down right now, not precipitously but there are places,'' Mr. Norquist said, citing the lack of bottlenecks in the supply chain and the unsolicited price cuts being offered by vendors fearful of losing business. Although prices are not a component of the index, they are included elsewhere in the trade association's report and are closely scrutinized for signs of the inflationary pressures that encourge stockpiling.
About half the $900 million that Mr. Norquist spends each year goes for materials used directly in Polaroid products; the other half is for things like buildings, equipment, services and goods consumed in production or offices.
 
No Sign of Stockpiling
There is still no sign of corporate buyers seeking to stockpile goods before prices go up, Mr. Norquist said, though certain products, like the titanium oxide Polaroid uses for its film, are in tight supply.
While the purchasing association refuses to identify any of its survey participants, and Mr. Norquist will neither confirm nor deny a role, he is widely assumed in the industry to be one of the survey respondents.
Mr. Norquist, a 58-year-old native of Jamestown, N.Y., with an engineering degree from the University of Michigan and a degree from the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration, heads a department of 160 people that includes 80 professional buyers, three of whom hold Ph.D's. He is considered a top practitioner of a craft that he and others contend is generally underappreciated in corporate America.
Even Polaroid, which appears to believe that good purchasing management can contribute to corporate success in ways not widely realized, does not list him among the top 20 officials named in its annual report. 8,000 Polaroid Vendors ''A lot of money is to be made in purchasing,'' Mr. Norquist said this week. Not surprisingly, much of the job of a purchasing manager is keeping track of prices and the availability of the items he needs.
In all, Polaroid deals with about 8,000 vendors, about 1,000 of whom sell product components, generating some 95,000 purchase orders a year. Some 275 suppliers are considered important, selling Mr. Norquist at least $250,000 worth of goods and services. An increasing number of suppliers, about a score now, are linked by computer to Mr. Norquist's department so that orders can be placed and confirmed almost instantaneously.
An industry committee, known as X-12, has facilitated this by creating a national format for such transactions. But corporate purchasing, with Mr. Norquist in the vanguard, is moving far beyond the notion, still widely embraced by governments and others, that price - assuming a certain quality - is nearly everything. Even for commodity products, like the methyl ethyl ketone that Polaroid buys in vast quantities, the aim is to cultivate long-term relationships.Mr. Norquist also expects suppliers not to gouge him when the market gives them the upper hand.
The key to successful purchasing, as in any negotiation, is to be well armed with facts. Typically this involves analyzing the supplier's own costs, the five major elements of which are materials, labor, factory overhead, general and administrative costs and profit.
 
Zero-Based Pricing
Believing that increases in the costs of any of these elements should not be accepted at face value as justification for an increase for the price of the product, Mr. Norquist has devised an analytical method he calls zero-based pricing, a first cousin to the zero-based budgeting once advocated by the Carter Administration.
One example of its successful implementation occurred when a supplier of compressed gas asked for a 20 percent increase based on higher electricity prices. Polaroid research found that while electricity had risen that much nationally, the supplier's own utility had not raised prices at all, and the increase for the gas was avoided.

HEADLINE: Indicators Rose 0.2% In September

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31

 BODY:
In a sign of continued but slow growth, the Government's chief economic forecasting gauge inched ahead two-tenths of 1 percent in September for its second straight monthly advance.
The Commerce Department said today that the September increase in the index of leading indicators followed an advance in August of five-tenths of 1 percent, slightly higher than the gain of three-tenths of 1 percent initially reported. The often-volatile index was unchanged in July, down from the one-tenth of 1 percent increase originally reported.
Though the index of leading indicators showed sluggish growth, analysts expressed concern about how the economy would fare in the immediate future. 
''The economy looks very soft right now,'' said Bruce Steinberg, senior economist for Merrill Lynch Capital Markets in New York. The next few months ''will be a period of vulnerability,'' he added.
Underlining that worry, the Commerce Department also reported that sales of new homes plunged by 14 percent in September, their steepest decline in nearly eight years. But some of the analysts said the housing sector was stronger than the report suggested.
 
Wage Costs Up 1.6%
The Labor Department, meanwhile, reported that employers' costs for wages and benefits of workers climbed by 1.6 percent in the third quarter and by 5.1 percent in the last year, with health insurance premiums again raising benefit costs faster than salaries.
Four of the 12 forward-looking business statistics that make up the composite index of leading economic indicators contributed to its September gain.
The index that measures consumer expectations was the largest positive contributor last month and the primary cause for the August and July revisions, the Commerce Department said.
Other positive factors were an increase in the money supply, a longer average work week, as well as higher stock prices.
The other statistics pointed down, led by a decrease in manufacturers' new orders for consumer goods. That was followed by a decrease in manufacturers' unfilled orders, fewer orders for plants and equipment, fewer building permits and higher initial unemployment claims. Two other negative factors were faster vendor performance, meaning declining demand, and lower prices for sensitive materials, which indicated weakening demand.
 
Index at 145% of Base
The various changes left the index at 145 percent of its 1982 base of 100. So far this year, the index has fallen at an annual rate of one-tenth of a percent, compared with an increase of 3.8 percent for the first nine months of 1988.
The economy has been slowing since the Federal Reserve Board acted last year stem inflation. But while inflation appears to be abating, the analysts said they were concerned that the Fed's grip could spur a recession.
Mr. Steinberg of Merrill Lynch and other economists pointed to excessive inventories and slackening orders for durable goods, including less demand for new automobiles, as primary threats to the economy because both could lead to growing unemployment and stagnant growth.
 
Trade Deficit Concerns
The economists are also concerned about the nation's trade deficit, which increased in August after falling for two straight months, and declining corporate profits, which could affect stock market prices.
Mr. Steinberg and Lawrence Chimerine, the senior economic adviser for the WEFA Group Inc., an economic forecasting group in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa., noted that the consumer confidence category was the primary positive indicator in the September index.
Consumer spending, which accounts for two-thirds of the nation's economic activity, accounted for much of this year's growth so far.
