HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
What Crisis In Productivity?

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
SHAKEN by the latest jeremiads from economists? Wait a while; they are bound to change their minds. The latest target for revisionism is the productivity crisis, the declining rate of growth in output per worker that, some argue, is transforming America into a nation of poorly paid burger flippers and Toyota salesmen.
''Productivity and American Leadership'' (M.I.T. Press, $29.95), a reassessment by William Baumol and Sue Anne Batey Blackman of Princeton University and Edward Wolff of New York University, musters impressive evidence suggesting that the lag in productivity is temporary and that Japan's challenge to American supremacy will run out of steam.
The depressing numbers are real enough. Productivity growth has indeed slumped since the mid-1960's. But the authors say the figures have been bouncing around a trend of about 2.2 percent annual growth for the last century. And a half-dozen previous slumps were deeper, if not longer. It is thus plausible, though not provable, that this latest bad patch is a rebound from a productivity boom after World War II. 
The downturn in productivity would probably not have drawn so much attention if it had not been accompanied by more direct signs of economic senescence - the rusting of the steel belt, the rise of low-wage service industries, the invasion of high-technology markets by the Japanese. But here, too, the three economists assert, there is less to worry about than meets the eye.
Sectors of the economy that had traditionally led in productivity are still leading, and still doing well. Paradoxically, it is the spectacular growth in output per worker in manufacturing in the 1980's that generated the sense of malaise.
Pressed by foreign competition, American industry plowed tens of billions of dollars into new machinery and technology. Manufacturing employment fell as companies automated, but total output rose. Manufacturing productivity actually gained more in America between 1979 to 1986 than it did in West Germany.
What, then, explains the huge shift of jobs into service industries, or the loss of world market share in high technology? Unlike manufacturing, productivity gains in services come slowly, or not at all. As the authors point out, it takes as much labor today to play a Scarlatti sonata on the harpsichord as it did in the 18th century.
Thus, while the share of services in total output has not changed, the service sector has absorbed almost all the growth in labor supply since World War II. Japan's parallel shift toward service jobs started later. But between 1965 and 1980 the proportion of the work force in services rose by 30 percent - three times the rate in the United States.
Japan, the authors concede, has done spectacularly well in increasing its world market share of technology-based exports from 7 percent in 1965 to 20 percent in 1984. But most of Japan's gains did not come at America's expense. The United States slipped from 27 to 25 percent, while the combined share of West Germany, Britain and France fell from 35 to 29 percent.
The most soothing argument offered by the three authors is the convergence theory. It is only natural, they claim, that once-poor economies are catching up with America. They are in the best position to exploit technology invented elsewhere. Moreover, their citizens have far more pressing reasons for thrift, creating the pool of cheap capital needed to use the imported technology. Once these countries achieve affluence, it is argued, the worm will turn.
What the three economists do not say is that the economic pessimism that has infected Americans has little to do with productivity statistics and a lot to do with their own experiences. And here, one suspects, much of the personal malaise comes from the failure to protect the losers from the consequences of rapid economic change.
The drop in manufacturing employment may, for example, be a healthy consequence of overdue automation. But that is no consolation to a rubber worker who ends up driving a delivery van at half the pay. The return to technical training may have gone up. But that is no consolation to a 19-year-old who lacks the money - and perhaps the intelligence - to become an engineer.
Does America have a productivity problem? As the three economists convincingly argue, no one really knows. But many Americans certainly do have a problem making ends meet, and they are only too willing to look for scapegoats.

HEADLINE: Democrats Offer a Deal On Gains Tax in Senate

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31

 BODY:
In a move aimed at breaking a logjam on Capitol Hill, Democratic Congressional leaders today offered Republicans a deal that would permit prompt passage of a debt limit bill and allow a Senate vote on cutting the capital gains tax.
After a late afternoon meeting at the White House with President Bush, House and Senate Republicans made a counteroffer intended to insure that the capital gains vote would occur under more favorable circumstances. In an arrangement unlikely to please Democrats, the Republicans want to tie the vote to legislation on health insurance that has broad bipartisan support and is therefore less likely to be filibustered. 
The months-long battle over capital gains has complicated efforts to compromise on a deficit reduction package. Today's offer by the Democrats was intended to pave the way for agreement on that package, as well as some of the extraneous issues linked with it.
 
Home for Thanksgiving
Senators in both parties said that a major selling point of both proposals was the promise that Congress could adjourn before Thanksgiving.
The Democratic proposal would require Republicans to muster a 60-vote super-majority on capital gains and would prevent them from attaching the measure to other legislation this year if they failed on the first attempt, as Democrats expect to happen. By their own admission, Republicans remain shy of the 60 votes and have tried to attach the tax cut to unrelated bills where they would need only 51 votes.
The Senate Republican leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, told reporters today that while 60 votes were not in hand, he had not given up. The tone of Mr. Dole's remarks, however, suggested that he is looking for a way to convince the White House that it has is futile to press for a capital gains cut this year. ''Sooner or later you have to face up, you are going to need 60 votes,'' he said. Adding that a fight over attaching a capital gains cut to the debt limit bill would only result in a ''who blinks first'' contest, he said, ''that doesn't seem to be a very good strategy to me.''
The House has approved a temporary cut in the capital gains tax as part of its deficit reduction package, but there is no such measure in the Senate version. Last week, Republicans moved to attach the capital gains proposal to a bill providing aid to Poland and Hungary, and the Senate has stalled on that measure since then.
 
Parliamentary Tactics
Republicans and the Administration have argued that a majority of Senators favor a reduction in the capital gains tax, but that the will of the majority is being thwarted by Senate Democratic leaders using parliamentary tactics to prevent a vote on the substance of the proposal. Republicans may, however, have a difficult time in getting even 51 votes on the tax cut because many Democrats who would favor a lower rate are pledged to support the Democratic leadership on procedural votes.
The deal proposed by the Democrats also envisions swift passage of economic aid to Poland and Hungary and separate congressional action on child care assistance bills. Changes in the catastrophic health insurance program would be handled as part of the deficit reduction package, as would the extension of a variety of popular tax breaks due to expire this year and the repeal of a 1986 tax provision barring discrimination in employer health benefit plans. It is these proposals that the Republicans want to package with the capital gains cut.

HEADLINE: Japanese Are Concerned About Rockefeller Deal

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 31

 BODY:
A Japanese developer's purchase of the majority interest in Rockefeller Center and other mid-Manhattan properties stirred concern today in business and political circles that were already apprehensive about the recent negative publicity over Japanese acquisitions in the United States.
Government spokesmen repeatedly emphasized that, as was the case in the Sony Corporation's purchase of Columbia Pictures last month, the Mitsubishi Estate Company's proposed purchase of the Rockefeller Group was not a hostile act but one invited by the American owners.
''We are monitoring reactions very carefully in the United States,'' said one Japanese official, asking not to be identified. ''We can easily see an emotional wave coming out as a result of this deal.'' 
 
Sensitive Trade Talks
For several months, Japan has been in delicate trade negotiations with the United States. Japanese officials acknowledge that the bargaining is complicated by heightened American sensitivity to Japanese real estate purchases.
In the last year, business leaders have been informally cautioned by the Government to avoid buying ''conspicuous'' properties in the United States, to avoid just such a negative reaction, Government officials say.
Earlier this year, for example, an official at a large real estate development company that is a rival to Mitsubishi Estate said it had been asked not to bid for the Sears Tower in Chicago because of the growing sensitivity of Japanese holdings.
''In principle, business is business,'' said a Japanese business official, who also asked not to be identified. ''That's a Japanese philosophy, too. But I think Japanese businesses should be more conscious about their moves to avoid apprehension from the American people.''
 
Biggest U.S. Investment
According to a recent survey prepared by the United States Commerce Department's Bureau of Economic Analysis, Japan has the largest direct foreign investment in American commercial real estate than any other country - $10.017 billion worth in 1988, compared with $515 million in 1983.
This figure excludes Japanese holdings in American corporations, either minority or majority shares, and such other matters as the intangible accumulation of general influence. The figure also leaves out joint ventures, including several automobile factories in North America that Japanese experts say will lead to the production of as many as 2.3 million Japanese cars each year in the next few years.
Japanese officials and business executives were taken aback by the negative publicity surrounding Sony's $3.4 billion deal for Columbia Pictures, after which some commentators asserted that the American reaction amounted to racism toward the Japanese.
 
Extensive News Coverage
This evening, Japanese news organizations, including all the primary news shows, featured the proposed purchase of Rockefeller Center as a integral part of their presentations. Several of the shows featured maps of Manhattan, with colored buildings showing the extent of Japanese holdings.
Reports were also taped or filmed on Monday night from Rockefeller Center in New York City, including man-on-the-street interviews with passers by, some of whom looked incredulous when informed by a Japanese correspondent about the purchase.
''What?'' said one New Yorker. ''I don't believe you.''
The correspondent said Rockefeller Center was ''a symbol for New Yorkers and for most Americans'' that contained ''the most beautiful illuminated Christmas tree in the West'' and that public reaction was certain to be negative.
At a news conference this morning, after the deal was disclosed in New York, officials at Mitsubishi Estate and the Rockefeller Group emphasized that the same people who managed Rockefeller Center and the group's other valuable mid-Manhattan properties would continue doing so.
Another example of heightened business concern about the purchase of American businesses and real estate was the creation last month of a Committee on Public Affairs at Keidanren, the largest Japanese business association, which recently urged that Japanese businesses investing in America take steps to become ''good corporate citizens'' there.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Minnesota Banks Go Different Ways

BYLINE: By Eben Shapiro

DATELINE: MINNEAPOLIS

 BODY:
FOR decades, First Bank System Inc. and the Norwest Corporation, two large banking companies based in Minneapolis, were so similar that they were often referred to as the Minnesota twins. But these days, the twins are by no means identical. ''They're kind of like Arnold Schwarzenegger and Danny DeVito,'' said Ben Crabtree, a banking analyst at Dain Bosworth Inc. in Minneapolis, referring to a movie comedy last year about twins with strikingly different physiques and personalities.
Norwest, after struggling for much of the 1980's in the shadow of its rival, is now flexing its muscles and has turned in nine straight quarters of record earnings. In turn, First Bank, which not long ago dazzled the investment community with its unorthodox approach to banking, has stumbled badly. 
''They never seem to be clicking at the same time,'' Mr. Crabtree said. ''There is a historic tendency for one to be up when the other is down.''
Thomas K. Brown, an analyst at Paine Webber Inc., said: ''The joke in the investment community is that you usually buy one and sell the other. That's been a pretty good investment strategy for the 80's.''
First Bank, currently the unloved twin, reported dismal third-quarter results last month, barely posting a profit for the period. Earnings were $6.1 million, nearly an 87 percent drop from the $46 million it reported a year earlier.
For much of the decade, however, it had prospered under the guidance of its former president, Dennis E. Evans. Under Mr. Evans, a securities analyst by training, First Bank ''had a much broader view of the type of earning assets it could put on its books,'' Mr. Crabtree said. He steered the bank into new areas like merchant banking, capital markets and, most significantly, bond trading. Mr. Evans ''took it away from a deposit-and-loan-driven bank to one that basically thought of itself as kind of an arbitrager in the money markets,'' Mr. Crabtree said.
That strategy led to First Bank's well-publicized fiasco in the bond market. After several years of strong earnings, fueled largely by bond-trading profits, Mr. Evans finally bet the wrong way on the direction of interest rates, leading to a $300 million loss and his resignation in 1988.
DeWalt H. Ankeny Jr., the chairman, resigned Sept. 21 after disclosures about problems in First Bank's loans for leveraged buyouts. Before he departed, Mr. Ankeny set in motion a drastic reorganization aimed at creating a smaller institution that would emphasize lending.
Clearly, First Bank has lost its appetite for risk. Days before he resigned, Mr. Ankeny said, ''We must seriously consider eliminating or downsizing some of our businesses that have risk characteristics that exceed their reward potential.''
Of more immediate concern to investors is the future of First Bank's 41-cent quarterly dividend, which may be cut because of accounting charges from the restructuring. Analysts, however, seem fairly optimistic that First Bank management will be able to make the third-quarter payment. After the most recent flurry of bad news some analysts feel the stock price of First Bank has hit bottom. Yesterday, First Bank's shares closed at $17.625, up 87.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange. ''You can make money in the stock,'' said Mr. Brown of Paine Webber, who rates the stock a step beneath an outright buy recommendation. ''The market is being overly punitive.'' Other analysts still have questions about the outlook for First Bank. ''The situation is quite clouded,'' said Kenneth F. Puglisi, an analyst at Keefe, Bruyette & Woods Inc. ''I'd like to see who is going to be running the company before we make too many decisions about what to do with the stock.'' The board is searching for a new chief executive. Norwest's chairman, Lloyd P. Johnson, has engineered a remarkable turnaround. Last month, Norwest reported net income of $60.1 million in the third quarter, an 11.5 percent increase from $53.9 million a year earlier.
Norwest stock, which has risen more than 43 percent this year, closed unchanged yesterday at $21.75 on the New York Stock Exchange.
In the early 1980's, the bank was beset by troubled agricultural and overseas loans and a costly foray into mortgage banking.
Some analysts think that Norwest's stock will continue to climb. In a Sept. 28 report, Thomas H. Hanely, an analyst at Salomon Brothers, issued a strong buy recommendation for Norwest stock. Mr. Hanely called Norwest ''a deeply undervalued franchise'' and said investors' views were still colored by the negative events at Norwest earlier in the decade.
In January, after years of delay, Norwest moved its headquarters into a striking new skyscraper designed by Cesar Pelli, replacing the bank's old headquarters, which burned to the ground in 1982. The new building has ''had an impact on our image and morale,'' Mr. Johnson said in a telephone interview.

HEADLINE: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
Beatrice Forced to Reduce Size of 'Junk Bond' Offering

BYLINE: By ANISE C. WALLACE

 BODY:
The Beatrice Company yesterday priced $250 million in ''junk bonds'' but was forced to scale back the offering by $100 million from the planned $350 million.
A person close to the transaction said investors showed a lukewarm response because part of the proceeds ultimately may be used to issue dividends to Beatrice shareholders, including Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, the New York leveraged buyout firm. ''A lot of investors felt the offering was a vehicle to put money in K.K.R.'s pockets,'' he said. 
That perception kept some portfolio managers from buying the securities. ''I don't want to see money being upstreamed away from the operating company,'' said J. Michael Pokorny, portfolio manager of the $760 million Delchester Fund, a junk bond fund offered by the Delaware Management Company in Philadelphia.
 
Effect of Continued Wariness
Market participants said the continued wariness of junk bond investors could be likely to raise the costs for some companies seeking financing in this market, including the R. P. Scherer Company and Morningstar. While strong companies like Continental Cablevision Inc., which sold $350 million of junk bonds yesterday in this country and $100 million of floating-rate notes in Europe, are able to sell their bonds, other companies are being forced to pay higher interest rates, offer equity kickers or provide more protection for bondholders.
Demand for the securities of Continental Cablevision yesterday was said to be strong. The company, the fourth-largest cable television operator in the United States, plans to use the proceeds of its offering to repurchase outstanding notes and reduce some of its bank debt. The bonds were priced at par to yield 12 7/8 percent.
Beatrice's $150 million of ''reset'' notes were priced yesterday at a yield of 13.75 percent, with the rate to be reset each year to keep the notes trading at 101 percent of par. The company's $100 million floating-rate notes have an initial coupon of 12.9 percent and will pay 4.25 percentage points above the London interbank offered rate. In addition, Beatrice agreed to tighter covenants than planned, restricting the company's ability to issue new debt.
 
Financing Plans Disrupted
The unsettled conditions in the junk bond market are disrupting the financing plans of other companies. Yesterday an investment banker at B.T. Securities Corporation, a subsidiary of Bankers Trust Company, said that the firm's proposed offering of $150 million for Morningstar, a dairy company that was spun off from the Southland Corporation, the convenience store operator, would probable be revised, perhaps by substituting a reset note for the planned fixed-rate bonds.
''The cost of getting this done far exceeds what we thought,'' said Charles A. Quattrochi, a managing director of B.T. Securities. The Morningstar offering would represent the commercial bank's first venture into junk bond underwriting.
At the same time so-called price talk for a $150 million offering of junk bonds for R.P. Scherer, a pharmaceutical company, includes a coupon of more than 14 percent and some equity in the company. Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., the underwriter, owns 95 percent of the stock and has a $116 million short-term bridge loan to Scherer at a rate of 6 percentage points above the prime lending rate.

HEADLINE: About New York;
A Fishy Epic: Not-So-Old Man Versus the Sea

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

 BODY:
There was a point, late in his career, when people thought Hemingway might be slipping. Then he wrote ''The Old Man and the Sea'' and won the Nobel Prize for literature. The book's cover says the story of an elderly man's fight with a big fish has ''the simplicity of a fable, the significance of a parable and the drama of an epic.''
And so will this column. What awaits you is man versus fish against the gritty backdrop of New York City. 
The sun rose thinly from the sea (page 32), as the Flamingo III sliced through the morning mist. A flock of black ducks landed near a stand of rushes. Wisps of pink were streaked across a pale sky. The Coney Island parachute jump hovered in the distance. Cars whizzed over a Belt Parkway bridge, carrying commuters on their lonely terrestrial journey.
Then the Flamingo III slipped under the bridge, out of Rockaway Inlet and into the Atlantic Ocean. The water was no longer flat as a mirror. The boat rose and fell rhythmically. Suddenly, a popping sound punctured the silence. A can of beer had been opened.
We looked around the cabin. There were snapshots of people and fish. There was a television tuned to Bullwinkle. There was a prayer that when we ended up in the ''Lord's great landing net,'' we might be ''big enough to keep.''
And there was a framed personal ad: ''Wanted: A good woman who can clean and cook fish, dig worms, sew and who owns a good fishing boat and motor. Please enclose photo of boat.''
Three generations of one family have captained Flamingos, each sailing from a dock at Gerritsen Beach, about 10 blocks from the piers of Sheepshead Bay. They are what is known as ''party boats,'' and not only in honor of the exuberant souls who have performed swan dives from the top deck.
The idea is that a party of regular folks can pay a modest amount and pursue the rich man's sport of deep-sea fishing ($25, including all equipment, for more than eight hours).
The hundred or so party boats in the New York area hearken to a rich tradition: The Taurus, a 240-foot-long paddlewheel steamer, sailed out of Battery Park in the early years of this century, carrying 1,500 happy anglers.
Our companions included an unemployed truck driver who had one letter of the word LOVE tattooed on each finger, a man who called himself only Al the Dentist (''Al Dente,'' chortled his girlfriend) and three off-duty firefighters with four cases of beer.
Dave Johnson, a crew member, spelled out the attraction this way: ''It's relaxation, peace, action.'' (A dramatic pause) ''It's actually pretty close to having sex.'' (A longer, less dramatic pause) ''But just about everyone would choose sex every time.''
A man called Red, an 80-year-old retired pipefitter who once landed 100 bluefish in the same day, said, ''It's better than hanging out in a barroom somewhere.''
Time passed, and the ocean seemed like a fishless desert. (Page 10.) We pursued a formidable foe. Bluefish, the crew and fellow fishermen said, relish eating their own young and think nothing of biting a hunk out of much bigger fish. They fill their stomachs, regurgitate and eat some more. ''It might be the only fish in the ocean that kills just to kill,'' said Jeff Cruz, first mate.
The men who chase bluefish are just as aggressive. Captain Bob Wiegand uses electronic fish finders, conversations with other skippers and constant observation with binoculars to dart from one potential fishing spot to another. Fishermen cast their lines before the boat has even stopped. Manifestly, they cannot tolerate being in one place for more than two minutes and 31 seconds without landing a lunker.
''These people are bloodthirsty,'' said a woman named May Lui, who is between things.
Our lines kept getting hopelessly tangled, until crewman arrived to straighten us out. Were people snickering? The hours dragged on. Our casting improved, but our luck didn't. Then lightning struck. A fish seized the line. He fought like a lion. But we fought back and remembered what Hemingway said to his piscine adversary: ''I love you and respect you very much. But I will kill you before this day ends.'' (Page 54.) The dead fish weighed over 15 pounds.
Two hours later, we glided back into Rockaway Inlet. Unlike some expeditions, we had seen no whales or seals or giant sea turtles. Just the shimmering beauty of a silver lure flying through the clear air on one of the last days of a perfect Indian summer.
Far away, the World Trade Center towers looked like a child's toys. In our pocket were winnings from a pool for catching the biggest fish. A long subway ride loomed ahead.

HEADLINE: Socialist About to Win Liberal Isle in Rural Sea

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ITHACA, N.Y.

 BODY:
When Benjamin Nichols is on the campaign trail in his quest to become the next mayor here, he talks about issues rarely discussed in central New York: taxing developers to pay for affordable housing, the possibility of rent control and legislation that would enable gay couples to register as domestic partners.
In nearby towns, the proposals might be causes for alarm. However, in Ithaca most people barely blink. Even the fact that Mr. Nichols, 69 years old, is a member of the Democratic Socialists of America is taken in stride. 
Ithaca, known for its scenic gorges and Cornell University, is a liberal city. The Common Council has voted to support a freeze on nuclear activities and to offer sanctuary to Central American refugees. George McGovern carried Ithaca in the 1972 Presidential election, as did the Rev. Jesse Jackson in the 1988 Democratic primary.
''It's clearly an island of liberal-left feeling in a sea of conservatism,'' said the local Assemblyman, Martin Luster.
 
Loss by 3-Term Mayor
The chairwoman of the Tompkins County Democratic Party, Irene Stein, said the politics had been moving to the left since the early 1970's, when growing numbers of Cornell students settled here after graduation. Democrats first outnumbered Republicans in 1972; the ratio is now 2 to 1. Republicans still are in the majority in most rural areas.
In the primary in September, Mr. Nichols defeated a three-term mayor, John Gutenberger, a moderate whose strength was in bringing groups together, but who was attacked as being too accommodating to developers and as not being strongly enough on the side of union workers fighting Cornell.
Mr. Nichols faces a Republican lawyer, Jean Cookingham, but his election is almost assured in the overwhelmingly Democratic city.
Mr. Gutenberger had encouraged development, mainly in the Collegetown area, near Cornell. Apartment complexes have been built, including one by the family of Mr. Gutenberger's wife. Some residents said the buildings had revitalized the area. Others complained about increasing traffic and the destruction of neighborhoods.
 
Chorus of Complaints
''The scale is no longer what I would call a human scale,'' said Dan Hoffman, an alderman who ran against Mr. Gutenberger in 1987 and lost by fewer than 50 votes.
Others complained about a lack of affordable housing and the low quality of jobs. Although Tompkins consistently has the lowest unemployment rate in the state, many jobs are in low-paying service industries.
A coalition of groups joined to put up a candidate against Mr. Gutenberger. Environmental groups and many unions united. Blacks, who have virtually no representation in the city's government, worked hard to elect Mr. Nichols, as did homosexuals.
Mr. Nichols is rooted in the American left. He was born on Staten Island in 1920 to parents who were Communist Party members, and he has spent much of his life in politics. He helped his parents organize a union, supported the Spanish Loyalists, protested Southern segregation, marched aganst the Vietnam War and supported Mr. Jackson for President.
 
Town-Gown Relations
''He's a walking history of progressive movements in this century,'' said Al Davidoff, president of a local of the United Automobile Workers and Mr. Nichols's campaign coordinator.
Mr. Nichols is a World War II Army veteran. Before retiring, he was a professor of electrical engineerng at Cornell for 40 years. In 1987, Mr. Nichols was elected to the Common Council. He said affordable housing and new jobs would be high on his agenda, as well as having Cornell pay for its share of services.
''Cornell and Ithaca are intertwined,'' Mr. Nichols said. ''It goes without saying Ithaca wouldn't be anything like it is without Cornell. Cornell as an institution does not feel quite the same way about Ithaca.''
Mr. Nichols, who called for an examination of rental housing, said he also wanted to re-examine zoning and increase taxes on developers.
''Any candidate that promotes laws that would interfere with private property, promotes big government and reduces freedom is not in the interest of people who improve the economy,'' the president of the Tompkins Chamber of Commerce, Girard Oberrender Jr., said Mr. Nichols said, however, that at heart he was a pragmatist.
Some Democrats have formed a Democrats for Cookingham group. In general, however, the criticism of Mr. Nichols has been muted. A few letters to the editor in newspapers expressed concern about his politics, but some people have said they believe governing will force Mr. Nichols to compromise.
Mr. Nichols's backers hope to empower groups that are removed from politics. ''We have a wonderful opportunity,'' Mr. Davidoff said, ''to elect someone who is an activist, a champion, someone who doesn't say the status quo needs tinkering with, but says, 'We need to change the priorities.' ''

HEADLINE: Stadium Plan May Fall Victim to Quake

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 31

 BODY:
An 85-year-old survivor of the 1906 earthquake is making an impassioned plea on the radio here that voters approve a ballot measure to allow construction of a new baseball stadium that would keep the Giants in San Francisco.
The elderly man's commercial represents a shift in tactics by proponents of the stadium, led by Mayor Art Agnos, who saw their Election Day hopes tumble in the wake of the Oct. 17 earthquake, which rocked the region during the World Series.
Before the quake, polls showed voters nearly evenly divided on the measure to build the downtown stadium, which is on Tuesday's ballot. Since the quake, in a city that sustained more than $2 billion in damage, the polls show the measure headed for defeat. 
 
Rebuilding Support for Stadium
In the hectic days after the quake, which claimed 64 lives and severed much of the Bay Area's network of highways and bridges, Mr. Agnos abandoned the ball park campaign as a frivolity and reassigned its staff to run shelters for the displaced and homeless. But as the World Series resumed last weekend, sending a televised message to the world that this was not a city in rubble, Mr. Agnos set out to rebuild support for the new stadium.
While the Oakland Athletics were sweeping the Giants at San Francisco's Candlestick Park, widely regarded by fans and players as baseball's most uncomfortable ball park, the Mayor was testing arguments on voters distracted by the earthquake and its subsequent turmoils and worried about how the city would pay for its rebuilding.
Until the quake, the stadium measure was viewed as a midterm vote of coincidence in Mr. Agnos. That is no longer the case, with the Mayor's popularity at an all-time high because of his leadership during the crisis, according to a poll released here yesterday. But, if the stadium measure is defeated, the Giants have said they will leave the city, which would be a particular blow as San Francisco struggles to help its tourism industry.
Proponents of the new stadium have taken several tacks with their post-earthquake pitch:
* The new ball park, a 45,000-seat horseshoe opening onto the Bay not far from downtown, would be a sound deal, costing $75.2 million in city money and generating $633.1 million in revenue over 40 years.
* None of the city's contribution to the privately built stadium would come from the general fund, and would thus not impede earthquake efforts.
* Concerns that the new site is on landfill are not valid.Certain landfill neighborhoods sustained terrible damage in the quake, like the Marina district. Others, including the financial district, stood firm because of newer building codes, which would apply at the stadium.
 
Capitalizing on New Mood
But opponents of the ball park have capitalized on the post-earthquake mood and rebutted each of these arguments, sometimes with cost-benefit analyses and sometimes by touching fears.
The radio commercial, by contrast, is an emotional appeal for emotional times. The elderly man, Dr. Albert Shumate, does not speak of the $20,000 in damage to his house from the recent quake, which, measuring 7.1 on the Richter scale of ground motion, was the most devastating in the nation since the 8.3 temblor of his childhood. Instead, Dr. Shumate talks of the indomitable spirit of San Franciscans early in the century, about their resolve to rebuild on a grand scale.
In the aftermath of the 1906 devastation, San Francisco built exuberantly and the monuments of those years are central to the legend of a plucky city risen from the ashes. Just three years after the big quake, the city won the right to host the Panama Pacific International Exposition, and the Palace of Fine Arts stands today as a reminder of that 1915 extravaganza. Also in those years, a new City Hall was built, as well as an auditorium and a library.
''We look back at that generation and the marvelous feat of rebuilding,'' said Corey Busch, the executive vice president of the Giants. ''They did it with a vision, with us in mind. We need to take a step back and think about our place in history.''
This harkening to the spirit of 1906 offends stadium opponents. ''Let's charge ahead with transportation programs,'' said Jim Firth, a leader of the opposition campaign. ''Let's charge ahead by bringing buildings up to code. Let's charge ahead by rebuilding the Marina. The idea that the stadium is the only way to climb out rubs me the wrong way.''
 
Newspapers Are Boosters
Just as they did in 1906, when the city was considering a bid for the exposition, the local newspapers are supporting the new stadium, with strong endorsements in both The Chronicle and The Examiner last weekend. The language of both editorials was upbeat, but the implied message was that San Francisco needs the stadium as an antidote to reduced tourism and retail sales, fewer conventions and lowered property values.
The Mayor is not mincing words in this regard. ''I need to draw private investment into the city,'' he said. ''I need to stimulate the economy.''
Brief consideration was given to postponing the election, said Ed McGovern, a close aide to the Mayor who is on leave from City Hall to run the ball park campaign. That course was not taken for a variety of reasons, he said, including concern that the economic impact of the earthquake would worsen with time, making a later election riskier.
It remains unclear what the Giants would do if the stadium measure loses. As part of the deal, the Giants' lease, which runs until 1994, was amended to allow an immediate exit if the measure is defeated. That amendment could be challenged by a petition campaign and forced onto the ballot for voter consideration.
 
Nearby Areas Considered
But if the amendment stands and the stadium is defeated, the Giants are free to go. The two most attractive new homes, Santa Clara County and Sacramento, do not have stadiums and would need at least three years to build one. Leaving for a city with a stadium is possible, Mr. Busch said, although he declined to speculate about whether that might happen.
Instead, the Giants' executive vice president pointed to the sharp mood changes here since the earthquake. Early last week, many saw resumption of the World Series as sacrilege, Mr. Busch noted, but by week's end baseball became a valuable civic catharsis.
A similar opinion change could occur over the ball park. ''Last week's conventional wisdom,'' he said, ''is this week's poppycock.''

HEADLINE: EDUCATION;
Lessons

BYLINE: By Edward B. Fiske

 BODY:
Prophets frequently go without honor in their own country. So can educational innovators in their own school districts.
In the mid-1970's Community School District 4 in East Harlem began allowing parents to choose the elementary and junior high schools their children would attend.
To give meaning to the choices, teachers were encouraged to create alternative schools using different teaching methods and curriculums. The district now has 52 schools in 20 buildings. 
The innovations have been credited with raising test scores, increasing attendance and reducing incidents of violence and other serious disciplinary problems.
As a result, District 4 attracts visitors from as far away as Europe, and Deborah Meier, director of the Central Park East Secondary School, which developed new methods for motivating students and evaluating their achievements, was honored with a MacArthur Foundation ''genius'' award.
Despite such accolades, budget problems, scandal and school politics now threatens the program. ''Everything I care for is at stake,'' Ms. Meier said.
Parental choice is a two-edged sword. In cities like Chicago extensive magnet-school programs have contributed to racial and economic polarization. In District 4 in East Harlem the alternative schools plan has brought out the entrepreneurial instincts of teachers, has reduced the size of schools and has enhanced contact between teachers and parents. The trick, it seems, is to give parents enticing alternatives and to make sure that they understand their options.
Almost by definition, alternative schools stretch the limits of the system. The New York City Board of Education recognizes only the 20 school buildings in District 4, not the 52 schools, and the schools are run not by principals, but by directors who are technically teachers. ''Officially we've never existed,'' Ms. Meier said. ''We're living a fiction.'' Hiring is complicated because staff members must often teach several subjects, defying seniority lists and central office computers. Even telephones are used differently. In most schools telephones are found only on the desks of administrators and secretaries. But in alternative schools, where teachers often call parents to discuss a child's progress or wonder why the child is not in school, telephones are more accessible. That can lead to educational benefits and the misuse of telephones.
For such reasons, the survival of alternative schools depends largely on the political protection they receive. The alternative schools in District 4 enjoyed such protections under Anthony Alvarado, who was the district superintendent when the schools were created, and his successor, Carlos Medina.
The situation changed in December, however, when Mr. Medina was suspended after allegations that he used public money for private purposes. Mr. Medina said he expects to be exonerated, and backers view the accusations as politically motivated. On Monday, the district's fiscal director was dismissed for ''mismangement.''
''If you can discredit the district, you don't have to bother discrediting the program,'' said Sy Fliegel, a former associate superintendent who helped develop the choice approach.
Supporters of the alternative schools asserted that Shirley Walker, the acting superintendent, has sought to undermine their efforts. They say she forced them to take disproportionately greater cuts than regular neighborhood schools in the district and has not fought hard enough for renewal of a $1.4 million Federal grant for schools with specialized curriculums.
Ms. Walker did not return telephone calls seeking her comments.
''We're celebrating choice at a time when we're in a crisis in this district,'' said Ray Rivera, a parent with two children in district schools. ''Instead of increased support, we're getting less support.''
The alternative schools of District 4 have been successful because they did what most people say all schools should do: they put educational objectives first.
''We decided not to spend a lot of time on governance issues but rather to talk about teaching and learning,'' Ms. Meier said. ''We told parents or teachers that if they had a good idea, they could have a school.''
The immediate political threat to District 4 may ease if Mr. Medina is restored to office, but the long-term challenge remains to find ways to institutionalize some of the better educational things that are happening despite, rather than because of, its structures. The Board of Education could, for example, distinguish between ''buildings,'' and ''schools,'' thus giving alternative schools a legitimacy they now lack.
By themselves, new structures like parental choice and alternative schools cannot guarantee success. But smothering them with bureaucratic procedures intended for traditional schools may well guarantee mediocrity.

HEADLINE: EDUCATION;
New Program Will Train Minority Teachers

BYLINE: By JULIE JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31

 BODY:
Reflecting concern about the sharp declines in the number of black and Hispanic teachers, five colleges and universities have established a long-term program to recruit and train minority members for teaching careers.
The consortium is the latest response to concerns shared by educators, members of Congress and Education Secretary Lauro F. Cavazos about shortages in minority teachers at a time when many urban public school classrooms are predominantly filled with black and Hispanic children.
Designed as a model for areas with large minority populations, the pilot project includes Fordham University and City College of New York, Xavier University, Hostos Community College and California State University at Dominguez Hills. In addition, the project is joined by the Ana G. Mendez Educational Foundation, which operates three private colleges in Puerto Rico. 
In the first year, beginning next fall, the schools will work with urban high schools with large minority enrollments to recruit interested students in grades 9 through 12. The students will participate in an intensive program of Saturday and summer college enrichment courses throughout their high school years to ''stimulate them to enter a college as an education major.''
 
Counseling and Advice
The students will also receive guidance counseling on selecting and applying to colleges and help in seeking financial aid. While there are existing networks among various teachers' colleges, this project is among the first to link large urban colleges, like CUNY or Fordham with a historically black institution, Xavier, and those that have historically served Hispanic students.
Of the nation's two million teachers, about 7 percent are black and 3 percent are Hispanic or belong to other minorities, said Antoine M. Garibaldi, Xavier's dean of arts and sciences, who has studied minority teacher recruitment and employment for the last eight years. Historically, he said, black colleges have produced at least half the nation's minority teachers.
But in a shift first noticed around 1975, black and Hispanic college students increasingly opted for other professions as affirmative action programs opened career avenues and as teacher salaries failed to keep pace with inflation. Teacher salaries this year averaged $29,629. While the figure is an all-time high, according to the most recent American Federation of Teachers salary survey, it is not even $800 above the 1972 average when adjusted for inflation.
David R. Merkowitz, a spokesman for the American Council on Education, said this pilot project is the latest of several efforts to bring higher education together with elementary and high school educators in search of solutions to the problem.
In 1977, of 87,083 students who graduated with bachelor's degrees in education, 4,253 were black and 2,223 were Hispanic. By contrast, a decade earlier, 143,462 students graduated with education degrees; 12,922 were black and 3,050 were Hispanic.

HEADLINE: Run for the Money Doesn't Always Pay

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY

 BODY:
By finishing first in the Los Angeles Marathon seven months ago, Art Boileau of Canada and Zoya Ivanova of the Soviet Union each won $26,385 and a Mercedes-Benz worth more than $30,000. Those same prizes are available to the first-place finishers Sunday in the New York City Marathon, and if Boileau and Ivanova are first again, they would qualify for a $300,000 bonus for winning both races. Or so it seems. As a citizen of a market-economy nation, Boileau is entitled to any prize he wins. That is not yet the case for Ivanova. 
For all the changes wrought by perestroika in the Soviet Union, the system has not evolved to the point that elite Soviet athletes competing outside of the country are entitled to all their spoils. In Los Angeles, Ivanova's official take was the car and the maximum cash award allowed by Soviet authorities, 500 rubles, which is about $800 at the current exchange rate. The same ceiling applies Sunday to Ivanova and the other Soviet athletes competing: Raisa Smekhnova, Eugeny Okorokov and Rustam Shagiev.
 
A Question of Fairness
A victory by Ivanova would make Goscomsport, the national sports federation, the biggest potential winner, with Ivanova generating as much as $325,585 if she finishes first.
But is that fair? ''Not an easy question to answer,'' she said yesterday through a translator. ''It is not totally fair. But so far, perestroika is not yet complete.''
For years, Soviet athletes competing in Western nations were required to return all their winnings to the federation. Often, promoters would slip the athletes money under the table, whereupon the athletes would buy items unavailable to them in the Soviet Union, like quality stereos and tape players. But the official winnings always flowed to the state.
Over the last three years, the rules have been relaxed. ''According to agreements each athlete makes with the committee, the athlete gets a small percentage of the winnings,'' Ivanova said. Negotiating With Federation For some athletes, the arrangement has still been unsatisfactory enough to bring the issue into the open. Earlier this year, Natalya Zvereva, the Soviet Union's leading tennis player, announced that she intended to keep all her earnings. Since then, she has engaged a marketing firm to represent her; the firm, which also represents Andrei Chesnokov, the top Soviet male player, is negotiating with the Soviet authorities a financial arrangement acceptable to Zvereva and Chesnokov and the state.
In the Soviet Union, running marathons is a relatively new phenomenon, and long-distance runners have yet to achieve the same status as tennis players. But that, too, may be changing.
''In the coming year, there will be negotiations between the Soviet sport committee and each federation,'' Ivanova said. ''The federations want to put in for 30 percent for each athlete.'' She laughed. ''But that is only for next year, not this year.''
Like Ingrid Kristiansen of Norway, the favorite among the women in Sunday's marathon, Ivanova, who is 37 years old, was a cross-country skier before she turned to running in 1981.
Among her best performances were a victory in the 1981 European Cup, a silver medal at the 1987 world championships and her victory this year in Los Angeles, where she defeated the Olympic champion, Rosa Mota of Portugal, among others, with a time of 2 hours 34 minutes 42 seconds. Her personal best is 2:27:57, which brought her third place in the 1987 Tokyo Marathon. At the 1988 Olympics in Seoul, South Korea, she finished ninth, in 2:30:25.

HEADLINE: Yankees And Mets Diverge On Salary

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
The number of baseball players earning $2 million or more continued to climb this year, to a record 20, but two even more intriguing economic developments involved the average team salaries of the Mets and the Yankees.
Only one year after the Yankees became the first baseball team ever to reach the $700,000 plateau, their average salary plummeted well below $600,000 and the Mets soared well beyond $800,000.
A salary study by The New York Times, based on data obtained from management and player sources, shows that the Mets' average was $858,575, a staggering increase of more than 40 percent over their $605,895 average in 1988. The Yankees' average dropped more than 20 percent, from a major league-leading $718,670 to $562,032, only the eighth highest in the majors this year. 
The Mets' average is so stratospheric that it is 21 percent higher than the second highest average, the $711,375 of the Oakland Athletics, the World Series champions.
 
Two Sets of Numbers
The average salaries are computed officially before the end of the year by the Players Association and by baseball's Player Relations Committee. The figures of the two groups never agree precisely because they use different methods of determining the value of certain payments.
The average major league salary that emerged from The Times's study is $491,199. The Players Association average is expected to be a few thousand dollars higher than that figure. The Player Relations Committee's preliminary figure, pending inclusion of post-season awards, is $488,424. Last year, the two groups' averages were, respectively, $438,729 and $430,688.
The Mets' and Yankees' payrolls went in opposite directions from the start of the season to the end. The Mets began at $790,643 but added Frank Viola, who with Orel Hershiser had the highest 1989 salary, and Juan Samuel. The Yankees started at $708,247, then shed Rickey Henderson and his $2.12 million salary plus six other players earning $500,000 or more. They also wound up with five players earning the minimum $68,000, compared with one on opening day.
The Mets, who next year will lose the $2 million salaries of Gary Carter and Keith Hernandez, had four players at that level or higher, twice the number of any other team. Their total of nine players at $1 million or more also led the majors.
 
Viola and Hershiser in Lead
The total number of players at the $2 million plateau rose to 20 from 12 last year and 6 in 1987. Viola and Hershiser led the elite group with incomes of $2,766,667. Fourteen clubs had players in the sport's uppermost class.
For the first time, every club had a player earning $1 million or more. A year ago, San Francisco, Pittsburgh, Cleveland and Seattle did not. The total in the $1 million circle was 106, up from 74 last year and 60 in 1987.
Ninety-one players earned the minimum, compared with 82 last year. The Mets were the only team without such a player.
The salaries include all money earned this year except for the post-season awards given by the Baseball Writers Association. The winners of those awards have not been determined, but some players will gain bonuses because of them.
Kevin Mitchell, for example, is expected to be named the National League's most valuable player and would earn $100,000. The leading contenders for the American League award would also receive bonuses, Cal Ripken Jr. $100,00 and George Bell $50,000. Bell would also receive $30,000 if he finished second through fifth in the voting. Ryne Sandberg is certain to finish in the top 10 in the National League voting and pick up an extra $20,000.
Mike Scott and Bret Saberhagen would each gain an extra $100,000 if they won the Cy Young Award in their league. Dave Stewart is expected to finish second to Saberhagen; that would bring him $75,000. ----Hernandez Declares Keith Hernandez, no longer wanted by the Mets, whom he helped return to championship status, declared himself a free agent yesterday. He was one of 18 players who filed and raised the total free agents to 36 in two days.
Hernandez, a 36-year-old first baseman, has indicated a desire to head west and possibly play for the San Diego Padres. Jack McKeon, the Padres' manager, has said that he would consider trying to sign Hernandez, but that the player would have to accept a salary significantly lower than the $2 million he earned this year.
The Padres, on the other hand, will have to make a lucrative offer to retain Mark Davis, their No. 1 relief pitcher, who joined Hernandez on the free-agent list yesterday. Davis led the major leagues in saves with 44 this year.
Other pitchers who filed were Bryn Smith of Montreal; John Tudor of Los Angeles; Craig Lefferts of San Francisco; Dennis (Oil Can) Boyd, Greg Harris and Dennis Lamp of Boston; Jim Gott and Neal Heaton of Pittsburgh and Mark Thurmond of Baltimore.
Tony Phillips of Oakland, Pat Sheridan of San Francisco, Gary Pettis of Detroit, Keith Moreland of Baltimore, Steve Lake of Philadelphia, Ed Romero of Milwaukee and Dave Anderson of Los Angeles also added their names to the list.

HEADLINE: The 2 Ships of Statecraft Will Meet Off Malta

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1

 BODY:
The White House said today that next month's shipboard meetings between President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union would be held off the coast of Malta in the Mediterranean, and that the theme would be minimalism.
''The President is going to try to keep it to a minimum,'' said Marlin Fitzwater, President Bush's spokesman. ''Limited staff in attendance. A minumum of ships in the area. A low-key attitude among the people on board. A minumum of hassle.'' 
Mr. Bush announced Tuesday that the meeting would take place aboard Soviet and American naval vessels in the Mediterranean on alternate days, Dec. 2-3.
 
Memories of Iceland
The inner circle of Bush advisers, who regard the last ''informal'' summit in Iceland as a nightmare that left relations between the superpowers strained and confused, will also try to keep minimal expectations.
Mr. Gorbachev surprised President Reagan at that 1986 meeting by proposing extensive cuts in strategic nuclear weapons.
If Mr. Gorbachev were to show up with a briefcase full of arms proposals, Mr. Fitzwater said the President would simply say something like: ''Thank you very much for your views. We will consider these in due time.''
''That would not prevent them from talking about arms control in a general way,'' Mr. Fitzwater said, adding that there have been a number of discussions back and forth between the National Security Council staff of the President and Soviet counterparts in which the Americans have expressed firm desires about tone and tenor.
 
The Familiar Ground
''Both sides agree that they are not going to negotiate agreements or contracts,'' he said. The President will study his briefing books about Eastern Europe and the Soviet economy, but basically he wants to stay within areas with which he is, as Mr. Fitzwater says, ''thoroughly familiar.''
''These will be friendly, private discussions on Eastern Europe, glasnost, perestroika, our progress in the conventional weapons talks, the NATO and Warsaw pacts.''
The White House advance team will leave next week for Malta, a Mediterranean island with a highly charged political environment, pulled between East and West. Lying between Libya and Sicily, the tiny island republic has 320,000 residents and, at 100 square miles, is about the size of Queens, New York. It was once a stopover for the Crusaders as they left Europe to do battle.
The ties of Malta to the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, and to Libya, where about 10,000 Maltese citizens live and work, have long been a source of annoyance for the United States and the Western allies.
 
The Libyans in Malta
It did give White House officials pause, when they settled on Malta as the base site for the floating summit meeting, that Libyans have the right of entry without visas to Malta. The area has also been a hotbed of terrorism, with dogfights between American and Libyan warplanes. In 1985, an Egyptian airliner flying in the region was hijacked by terrorists.
But the two leaders will be spending the night on their heavily secured battleships, officials said, and they added that they are not worried about Libyan terrorist attacks on reporters.
The two countries were engaged today in a discussion of warship parity, to make sure that both sides have the same number of ships in their fleet. Ideally, the United States would like to use the Belknap, which is the flagship of the Sixth Fleet. But it is in port undergoing repairs and it is not clear whether it will be ready in time for the meeting.
The Belknap, a guided missile cruiser, has had a mixed record of sidling up to other battleships. In a famous incident in 1975, the Belknap collided with the aircraft carrier John F. Kennedy, setting off a series of fires and explosions that, subsequent reports said, came dangerously close to the Belknap's nuclear arsenal.

HEADLINE: Budget Problems Deepen for Massachusetts and Its Governor

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, Nov. 1

 BODY:
Financial troubles here in Massachusetts have gone from bad to worse in the last three months, and amid the calls for new taxes and more cuts in state spending, there is a flood of anger at Gov. Michael S. Dukakis and his unsuccessful Presidential campaign.
Critics of Mr. Dukakis and experts outside the state agree that Massachusetts could have stemmed some of its budget woes if it had started making cuts 18 months ago. But at the time, Mr. Dukakis was in the middle of his Presidential bid and was promising that if elected he would deliver to the rest of the nation his ''Massachusetts Miracle,'' a thriving economy and low unemployment. At that time, too, the Democratic-controlled State Legislature was loathe to do anything that would hurt Mr. Dukakis's campaign. 
Changes in the Federal tax laws in 1986 resulted in substantial revenue losses in Massachusetts and other states. In addition, states in the Northeast have been hurt by a softening real estate market and cutbacks in industries. But most of them made up their losses with revenue from other sources or acted quickly to cut their budgets.
''A big part of the reason Massachusetts is having so much trouble is that it allowed its problems to accumulate,'' said Steven D. Gold, director of fiscal studies for the National Conference of State Legislatures in Denver. ''And that was because of the Presidential campaign.''
As a result, he said, Massachusetts has one of the worst budget deficits in the nation.
''The level of cynicism in Massachusetts is at an unprecedented high,'' said State Representative Marjorie O. Clapprood, a Democrat. ''There are a lot of feelings of anger and betrayal that one, he lost, and two, that in the process of running he covered up a fiscal situation that could have been manageable 15 months ago and has now spiraled into a crisis.''
Mindy Lubber, press secretary for Mr. Dukakis, agreed that ''there's no question that if the Governor was in Massachusetts full-time versus on the road, things might have been able to be done differently.'' But, she said, the state's revenue figures were regularly published and there was never a cover-up.
 
The Deficit Deepens
Mr. Dukakis announced in July that the state would face a $491 million deficit this fiscal year. He called for deep cuts in social service programs and a 15 percent temporary increase in the personal income tax. The Legislature grudgingly approved his program.
Then, early last month, Mr. Dukakis announced that the deficit for this year would actually be about $500 million larger. He recommended more cuts and further tax increases.
The Legislature, under the pressure from taxpayers and businesses, is struggling to come up with a budget-balancing package.
Lawmakers say the money that can be cut is down to nickel-and-dime amounts, and the voters' opinion of another tax increase is hardly favorable.
''Most people think there's a limit to how much you can cut,'' said Al Frezza, chief of staff for the House Speaker, George Keverian.
Mr. Gold said Massachusetts is more dependent on corporate and personal income taxes than most other states. About 14 percent of its revenues come from corporate taxes, and 47 percent, the third-highest in the nation, from personal taxes.
''They were really vulnerable if they had trouble with those taxes, which they did,'' Mr. Gold said.
The latest state estimates put annual revenue growth at 3.2 percent, down from 6.5 percent last year. For most of the 1980's until early 1988, rates had were 8 percent to 16 percent.
It was during the boom years that Massachusetts expanded its services. The Legislature approved a universal health insurance program that was scheduled to go into effect in 1992. But the state's current problems may undermine that program.
Barbara Anderson, executive director of an anti-tax lobbying group, Citizens for Limited Taxation, said any new attempt to raise taxes will face fierce opposition.
''People are fed up,'' Ms. Anderson said. ''They're not expanding their businesses, and consumers aren't buying things because they feel insecure about their jobs.''
 
The Legislators' Problem
A tax package intended to raise $855 million a year was postponed last week by Mr. Keverian, the House Speaker. After pressure from other House Democrats, he said he would first introduce a $100 million savings plan.
The Dukakis Administration, meanwhile, has prepared a $350 million savings plan, said Charles A. Baker 3d, the Assistant Secretary of Administration and Finance. That plan, while not covering the entire deficit, includes $150 million in spending cuts, $140 million in savings measures and $60 million in revenues like Federal reimbursements.
State legislators, many of whom face re-election next year, are reluctant to discuss new taxes.
''The first year I was here, we were up to our elbows in cash, and it was easy to be in government,'' said Representative Robert Havern, a Democrat on the House Taxation Committee. ''Now people are stressed out financially. The problem now is that people can't defend raising taxes until they make serious cuts.''
Some residents favor higher tax. On Monday, about 300 elderly people dressed in skeleton costumes marched through the State House chanting, ''Read our bones: We want taxes.''
''What we were trying to make clear is that there is a horror show going on and people have really been hurt,'' said Al Norman, the director of Mass Home Care, an association of companies that are paid by the state to provide services to low-income elderly people in their homes.

LENGTH: 450 words

HEADLINE: House, 382-37, Approves Bill To Raise the Minimum Wage

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1

 BODY:
By a lopsided margin, the House today approved legislation to increase the minimum wage to $4.25 an hour by 1991 and to create a $3.35 training wage for workers under 20 years old.
The vote was 382 to 37, with Republicans accounting for all but two of the negative votes. Congressional Democratic leaders and the Bush Administration announced a compromise Tuesday on the wage issue, ending a long impasse. 
With the Senate pledging to take similar action soon, legislators predicted today that President Bush would be able to sign the legislation into law by Thanksgiving, enacting the first increase in the minimum wage since 1981, when the current level of $3.35 an hour was reached.
The first raise of 45 cents an hour, to $3.80, would take effect next April and the second in April 1991.
 
Earlier Bill Vetoed
A bill passed by Congress in May that would have raised the minimum to $4.55 an hour was vetoed by President Bush because he said it would be inflationary. His veto was sustained.
Debate today was largely perfunctory, with many lawmakers declaring the wage increase imperfect but a reasonable outcome in the long quest for a way to bridge the Democrats' desire to restore much of the purchasing-power loss of the minimum wage in the 1980's and the Administration's insistence on some kind of apprenticeship wage.
Under the measure, teen-agers with little experience would be allowed to be paid 85 percent of the minimum wage for their first three months in the work force and for an additional three months if enrolled in a sanctioned training program.
The Labor Department is to develop guidelines for deciding what programs qualify.
 
Two-Tier System Assailed
The loudest objection to the legislation came from Carl C. Perkins, a Kentucky Democrat who said the installation of a two-tier pay system was against the interests of American workers and represented a sellout of them to Mr. Bush. The other Democrat voting no was Representative George Miller of California.
The Republicans who opposed the bill complainted of the loss of jobs they said would occur because of the increase and a rise in inflation they said would follow the raise. But some Republicans also argued for aiding the members of poor families who work by means of expanded tax credits.
The training wage applies to people 16 through 19 years old, except for migrant and seasonal agricultural workers. But some members contended these workers should be eligible for the training wage.
The House was prevented from procedural rules from addressing this issue today but an agreement emerged that efforts would be made in the Senate to authorize the lower minimum for the agricultural workers.

SECTION: Section A; Page 30, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 332 words

HEADLINE: Costa Rica Breaks the Mold

 BODY:
Costa Rica has announced what could be a dramatic breakthrough in stalled efforts to reduce the bank debt of third world countries. The plan could serve as a model for negotiations between creditor banks and other debtor nations.
Third world countries owe the banks $600 billion. But they can't pay it back without devastating the lives of their citizens. Last spring Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady called on banks to grant debt reduction in exchange for international guarantees on the remaining balance. For their part, the debtor nations had to adopt pro-growth, market reforms. But until last Friday only Mexico and the Philippines had reached agreement with the banks, and the terms provided limited relief. 
Costa Rica will do much better. With money from the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank and several donor countries, it will buy back 60 percent of its debt at about an 80 percent discount and will pay a lower interest rate on the rest. That will cut its $1.8 billion debt by a stunning $1 billion.
The Costa Rican settlement is comprehensive: every bank takes a hit. First a bank must sell back most of its loans at a substantial discount. Only then will it qualify for guarantees on the remainder of its loans. Unlike the Mexico deal, banks can't avoid debt reduction by burying Costa Rica in new loans.
The negotiations succeeded partly because of the monetary fund's new policy of supporting nations that are in arrears because of bank intransigence. The I.M.F. determined that Costa Rica had undertaken suitable economic reforms and that the banks had been laggard in responding. The precise terms of the Costa Rican agreement may not work for larger debtors. But continued pressure on banks by the I.M.F. - and the United States - will be necessary.
Countries like Mexico and Venezuela have swallowed the painful medicine of economic reform without much reward. The Costa Rican agreement breaks the mold and gives beleaguered nations cause for hope.

HEADLINE: Help, at Last, for the Working Poor

 BODY:
When President Bush vetoed a $4.55 an hour minimum wage bill in the spring he invited a legislative compromise: a smaller minimum wage increase combined with an expansion of tax credits for the working poor. Fortunately, that compromise is about to become reality.
On Tuesday, Congressional leaders and the Bush Administration agreed to raise the minimum wage to $4.25 an hour from $3.35 by 1991. Yesterday the House approved the plan. Separately, House and Senate committees have approved expanded tax credits for low-income families. The combination could constitute a potent weapon against poverty. 
Mr. Bush rightly prefers tax credits to minimum wage increases. Because most low-wage workers, like students, are not from poor families, lifting the minimum wage helps poor and non-poor alike. And higher wages will cause employers to hire fewer workers. The number of lost jobs may not be large but many of them would have gone to the most disadvantaged youths. Minimum wage hikes would also have to be passed along to consumers, including the poor.
Expanding the Earned Income Tax Credit is a better way to help the working poor. When low-income workers with children claim the credit, the Treasury sends a check to supplement wages. Only poor families benefit, and the cost is fairly apportioned among all taxpayers.
Then why even consider a compromise that includes an increased minimum wage? Because an expanded tax credit adds too much to the Federal deficit. Raising the income of low-paid workers by boosting the minimum wage to $4.25 would lower the outlays under the tax credit.
The House bill on tax credits would cost about $5 billion more than the Senate's. But the extra money is worth spending. The House tax credit would expand with family size. And families with children under age 6 would get a supplement. The Senate version expands the tax credit only for families with children under 4, and its provisions, unlike the House's, are not indexed for inflation.
The Senate version has one praiseworthy feature not in the House bill: It would make refundable the tax credit for expenditures on dependent care, thus enabling poor families to enjoy this benefit. Under current law the credit is available only to families wealthy enough to pay taxes.
Even under the House bill, a family of four with a single full-time worker earning a $4.25 minimum wage would fall more than $4,000 short of the poverty line, according to estimates by the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities. And the minimum wage agreement still includes a regrettable subminimum ''training wage,'' for newly hired teen-agers. That provides a needless incentive to substitute teen-agers for older workers.
Still, the flaws in the bills hardly outweigh the artful coupling of a new minimum wage and a generous expansion of tax credits. That adds up to powerful relief for the working poor.

HEADLINE: Revised City Charter Will Save Money, and It's Constitutional

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The most respected watchdogs of New York City government finances, including the Citizens Budget Commission, the New York City Chamber of Commerce and Industry, and Comptroller Edward V. Regan endorse the proposed revisions to the City Charter that will appear on the ballot Nov. 7.
W. Bernard Richland (letter, Oct. 17) exemplifies efforts to portray the proposed reforms as expensive or wasteful. He overstates costs and ignores the benefits and savings. 
For example, he states that the independent budget office would cost $31 million a year - the same as the Mayor's Office of Management and Budget. The proposed charter sets the new office's budget at one-tenth of the Mayor's department - or $3.1 million. Moreover, one of the budget office's jobs would be to identify waste and inefficiency that could be eliminated from city government. Its operations should be a net saving.
Mr. Richland writes that the charter would require designating borough commissioners in 12 city agencies at a cost of $12 million. But the borough commissioner proposal affects nine city agencies, five of which have borough commissioners. The cost of four additional borough commissioners would be about $1.7 million, resulting in better city services.
Mr. Richland says that an ''additional bureaucracy,'' including new deputy mayors, would cost at least $10 million. But the charter proposals would eliminate some bureaucracies and reorganize and consolidate others. Besides the budget office, two new commissions and one new board would be established. The net additional effect would be a city spending increase of about $600,000 a year. The benefits include more competition for contracts by women- and minority-owned businesses, and greater public access to information about government programs. The proposals do not call for more deputy mayors. The Charter Revision Commission's staff estimates that when fully phased in, the absolutely necessary costs of the reforms would be about $8 million a year; desirable expenditures would be another $8 million.
The largest component of this is $4 million a year for an expanded City Council with greater responsibilities. The commission believes this would make New York government more representative and responsive.
The charter reforms also call for more staff for the Department of City Planning, which should speed review of economic development projects and generate savings.
Costs would be more than offset by savings, principally from reforms to the city's procurement system. Frank Cary, former chairman and chief executive officer of I.B.M., who headed the recent private sector survey of city government operations, has written that he ''strongly supports'' the commission's contract reforms. The State Commission on Government Integrity criticizes the current contracting system as wasteful and endorses the proposed reforms as lessening opportunities for corruption.
The Charter Commission took full account of New Yorkers' concern about the city's financial future in proposing reforms to fix the city's now unconstitutional government.
 
FREDERICK A. O. SCHWARZ JR.
Chairman, New York City
Charter Revision Commission
 New York, Oct. 30, 1989

HEADLINE: Dollar and Deficits Walk the High Wire Together;
Piper Must Be Paid

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I suspect that no one who has successfully completed a course in money and banking would argue with your conclusion in ''Fighting Fire With Money'' (editorial, Oct. 17). If I understand you, while the Federal Reserve has learned the need to supply liquidity to the market in times of extreme uncertainty, ''The nation's capacity to produce goods and services depends on healthy capital markets'' - which can be assured in the long run only by cooperation between our savers and borrowers.
You state that ''Securities markets transfer money from savers to corporations, which then invest in plants and equipment.'' What you do not say, however, is that corporate America does not always invest the money wisely, nor does our other principal borrower, the Federal Government. What you have missed is one of the first lessons of college economics: a little leverage can be a dangerous thing. In 1929 it was the leverage in the markets that made the crash so devastating. We learned that lesson in one sense and largely removed the leverage from the markets by regulation. Unfortunately, we seem to have subsequently transferred that leverage to both the public and private sectors by our increasing willingness to finance the growth of government, corporate America and even our private lives with borrowed money. We have convinced ourselves that as long as we can afford the monthly payments, the amount of debt is almost irrelevant. 
The longer-term problem implicit in your words is that we haven't always invested our savings wisely. In the early 1960's we coined the term ''deficit spending'' to rationalize Federal programs we couldn't afford; in the 1970's we realized that real estate prices can fall as well as rise; at the beginning of this decade we learned that the price of energy, like the price of all other commodities, is a function of supply and demand, and in 1989 we are beginning to appreciate that ''junk'' bonds have been properly labeled since the first one was issued.
While, as you note, ''the Fed is prepared to step in once more to protect the larger economy of Main Street from the latest debacle on Wall Street,'' it is time for all of us to pay attention to the lessons of the past. Perhaps the markets are trying to tell us to stop relying too heavily on a vehicle of our own creation to save us from our own mistakes.
At the end of the day, our debts must be repaid - the sooner we begin, the greater will be the return on all our investments.
 
FRANK J. KEELER
New York, Oct. 18, 1989
 The writer is president of Invesco Mim International.
