SECTION: Section A; Page 30, Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 431 words

HEADLINE: Dollar and Deficits Walk the High Wire Together

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''Let the Dollar Drift,'' you proclaim (editorial, Oct. 24). Right on!
But that means supporting the Treasury aim of getting the dollar down to push exports up and not, as you advise, supporting Federal Reserve policy. 
You come close to the central issue when you point out, ''Merely buying and selling foreign currencies . . . does little to offset strong market forces.'' And, ''To lower the value of the dollar effectively, the Fed must pump up the money supply in order to lower domestic interest rates.''
But what is so wrong with that? You raise the hoary fear of higher inflation and assert that the Fed's ''primary task is to stifle inflation.''
The task of the Fed and economic policy in general should be to set the framework for a prosperous, high-employment nation, living well today and investing adequately in its future. Low real interest rates are major pillars of that framework.
Obsessions about inflation are major obstacles, more inexcusable when the overall price level is almost stable and serious inflation clouds exist only in the minds' eyes of those for whom these are perennial fears. There has been no serious inflation in this country since that unleashed by the oil-supply shocks - not by excess money or spending - of a decade ago. Arguing that easier money and credit would bring large price rises has as much substance as similar fears about our supposedly huge budget deficits, which have been accompanied by a drop of almost two-thirds in rates of inflation.
In guarding excessively against inflation, the Fed keeps money and credit tight and interest rates high. That makes the dollar scarce and dollar holdings profitable. While investors believe the Fed will continue to do this, sporadic counter efforts in currency markets will do little to dissuade them from keeping the value - and cost - of the dollar high.
It is thus the Fed that is not letting the dollar drift. And the high interest rates and high cost of the dollar contribute mightily to the trade and budget deficits you frequently lament.
A lower dollar would indeed again turn the trade deficit down as, with some lag, did the decline that began in 1985. And each one percentage point fall in interest rates would reduce the Federal budget deficit directly by $20 billion as Treasury interest payments are reduced, while bringing considerably further reductions with the added tax revenues from a more prosperous, high-investment economy.
 
ROBERT EISNER
William R. Kenan Prof. of Economics
Northwestern University
 Evanston, Ill., Oct. 25, 1989

HEADLINE: Why I Ended The Cease-Fire

BYLINE: By Daniel Ortega Saavedra; Daniel Ortega Saavedra is president of Nicaragua.

DATELINE: MANAGUA, Nicaragua

 BODY:
On Feb. 25, 1990, Nicaragua will celebrate free, fair and democratic elections. The president, vice president and legislature elected then will take office, with full constitutional powers, on April 25, 1990.
These are my solemn pledges to the Nicaraguan people. I have also made these pledges in the multilateral agreements of the Central American presidents signed this year in Tesoro Beach and Tela. 
Last month, 1.75 million Nicaraguans - more than 90 percent of eligible voters - registered to vote in a process applauded by all international oberservers. I shall continue doing everything I can to insure that the current electoral process remains democratic and that, as in 1984, our elections are judged free and fair by the international observers.
Regrettably, increased military activity by the contras, aimed at subverting the electoral process, threatens my ability to protect the right of Nicaraguan citizens to campaign openly and vote for the political party of their choice.
That is why I decided reluctantly that the Government's unilateral cease-fire could not be extended.
During October, contra units newly supplied and infiltrated from Honduras closed more than 50 voter registration centers, preventing thousands of citizens from registering to vote. They targeted for assassination known Sandinista supporters -prominent community leaders, party activists and candidates for municipal offices - and slit their throats.
On Oct. 21, the contras ambushed reservists who were on their way to register to vote, killing 19 and wounding six. Last Tuesday, they murdered four farmers at a cooperative near San Miguelito. At my invitation, observers from the United Nations, the Organization of American States and the U.S. embassy visited the scene of the attack to view the corpses and interview survivors.
Why the upswing in contra violence? The success of our electoral process has made them desperate. They fear that free elections, duly recognized by the international community, will end their flickering hopes of continuing the war.
Their only chance, as they see it, is to step up attacks on civilians, forcing the Government to impose necessary security measures. The Government's reaction is then to be presented to the world as evidence of its hostility to democratic elections.
The contras' main supporters inside Nicaragua - the National Opposition Union, which, like the contras, was manufactured, bought and paid for by the U.S. - are already accusing me of plotting to cancel the elections. In fact, this is precisely what they want me to do. They are as convinced as I am that when the elections are held - and they will be -the Nicaraguan people will give the Sandinistas a landslide victory.
My principal goal at the hemispheric summit in Costa Rica last weekend was to obtain the assistance of the assembled heads of state in ending contra violence. I wanted them to use their collective influence to secure full implementation of the Tela Accords, which call for the demobilization and disarmament of the contras by Dec. 5. That is the most effective way to stop contra attacks on our citizens and electoral process.
It is now clear that there is little point in concentrating our peace efforts around the single issue of a ceasefire. We do not consider it an acceptable ceasefire when we cease and the contras fire. For peace to be achieved, the war itself must be stopped. There is no other way to end the war than to start immediately the demobilization of the contras.
President Bush reacted with a torrent of personal invective. He accused me of spoiling the ''garden party'' in Costa Rica. Well, life in my country is no ''garden party.'' Eight years of war financed and directed by the Reagan and Bush Administrations have seen to that.
Even now, despite the universal praise our electoral process has earned, President Bush has taken steps to increase the suffering of the Nicaraguan people. Last week he renewed for another six months the economic embargo that has strangled all commerce between Nicaragua and the U.S. since May 1985.
Worse, President Bush has blocked all efforts to demobilize and disarm the contras as called for in the Tela Accords. He has kept the contras intact militarily by continuing to provide them with non-lethal assistance. Such direct U.S. aid violates the Tela Accords, which mandate that assistance may be provided only for demobilization, and only through a special commission.
President Bush may not intend to reactivate the contras militarily. Latin American leaders close to him tell me that he, too, wants to demobilize the contras, but not until after Nicaragua's elections. Allegedly, he fears that demobilizing them before the elections would expose him to charges of betrayal from right-wing elements of the Republican Party. Thus, current U.S. aid is supposedly intended to placate these extremists, not to resurrect the contras.
Nevertheless, the contras have used Mr. Bush's aid to increase combat activities and to inflict more death and destruction on our country.
All well meaning people want two things in Nicaragua between now and February: An end to the fighting and the holding of democratic elections. In spite of everything he has done, President Bush may mean well. He can demonstrate this by supporting prompt demobilization of the contras.
This might expose him to cries of betrayal from right-wing extremists. But the alternative is to continue to condemn the Nicaraguan people to listen to the daily cries of grief from those whose loved ones are slaughtered by the U.S.-created and financed contras.
A truly ''big man'' would have no difficulty making the right choice.

GRAPHIC: Drawing

HEADLINE: ABROAD AT HOME;
The Estonian Test

BYLINE: By Anthony Lewis

 BODY:
''Polls show it,'' Marju Lauristin said. ''It's the will of the Estonian people to be an independent country.'' Then she laughed and added, ''Now the only problem is how to fulfill this will.''
Ms. Lauristin is a teacher of journalism and sociology at Tartu University in Tallinn: hardly a political springboard, one might think. But last year she helped found the Popular Front of Estonia. This year she was elected to Mikhail Gorbachev's new Congress of People's Deputies and then to the Supreme Soviet. 
Now she is a, perhaps the, leading voice for Estonian independence. On her first visit to the United States, I asked her whether she really thought it was possible to solve what she cheerfully called ''the only problem'' - getting Soviet agreement to independence.
''We have a scenario to achieve it in five to seven years,'' Ms. Lauristin said. ''Peacefully. Nobody is talking about violence.
''To start, we think the Soviet Government will at least recognize the fact that it annexed the Baltic States in 1940.'' It would admit, that is, that Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania were taken by military force, not with the popular consent that has been the official version of the event.
Why would Mikhail Gorbachev make such an admission? I asked.
''It's a test of his promise to finish with Stalinist history,'' Ms. Lauristin said.
Honesty about what happened in 1940, she argued, would also release economic energies in the Baltics. And development there would benefit the Soviet Union.
''When Mr. Gorbachev goes to Finland,'' she said, ''everyone in Estonia can see him on Finnish television. When we hear his speech in Helsinki [praising Finland as a model of stability], everybody can imagine the same speech in Tallinn.
''If the Soviet Union had conquered Finland in 1940, it would be a Soviet republic today in the same unhappy economic state as the others. And it couldn't help the Soviet Union.''
The next step toward independence, Ms. Lauristin said, would be to negotiate ''a special status for Estonia in the Soviet Union.'' It would have a confederal relationship: ''more freedom to build up democratic institutions, a multi-party system, a market economy.''
Finally, Estonians would negotiate a right to decide their attachment to the Soviet Union by referendum. That is, self-determination.
Were people in Moscow shocked, I asked, when they heard such ideas?
''At first yes,'' Ms. Lauristin said. ''But the Supreme Soviet has heard many radical ideas now. Every week, step by step, the idea of self-determination is becoming more acceptable.''
The next session of the Supreme Soviet, in December, may well confront the Baltic question. It will have a report from a commission, of which Ms. Lauristin is a member, on the Hitler-Stalin pact of 1939. And it will contain reports from similar commissions in the three Baltic republics.
''Our Estonian commission said that all actions of the so-called Revolutionary Government in 1940 were illegal,'' she said, ''because they were taken under the pressure of Soviet forces. The report declares that the declaration of unity with the Soviet Union was null and void. My mother, who is 87 now, is a member and signed the report.''
There is a strange personal element for Marju Lauristin in the effort to correct false history. Her father, Johannes, was the first leader of the Estonian Communist regime after Soviet annexation. He died in 1941. Ms. Lauristin said her mother explained that he ''was fooled by Stalin. It's clear now. But then it wasn't.'' In the Supreme Soviet, Ms. Lauristin's role is not limited to Baltic matters. She is a supporter of President Gorbachev's reform program at a time when it is under attack because of severe economic problems. (She remains a Communist Party member.) ''The threat is that neo-Stalinists may use the economic situation to rouse the population against perestroika,'' she said. ''Their solution will be to go back to a centralized, militarized, totalitarian system. It's a real threat. In the crisis, people look for enemies: intellectuals, the Baltics, cooperatives. . . .
''The Supreme Soviet is a very important school, a school of democratic procedure and rational thinking. It must show people, on television, that both sides are there making their arguments. It must show that the economic crisis cannot be solved without political reforms.''

HEADLINE: ESSAY;
Giving War a Chance

BYLINE: By William Safire

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
For accommodationists, this week was the best of times and the worst of times.
The spring of Hope blossomed with the revelation of a pre-summit summit session at sea, symbolic of President Bush taking the plunge into helping the Soviet dictator rescue his economy in payment for freedom in Eastern Europe. (The ''who lost Gorbachev?'' threat got to him.) But simultaneously, the winter of Despair blew in with the decision by the Nicaraguan dictator to give war a chance - thereby causing embarrassment to doves from the U.S. Congress to Central America who had insisted that peace would flow from our cutoff of military aid to the contras. 
What does this jarring juxtaposition of events teach us? How can President Ortega's double-cross prepare us to deal with President Gorbachev?
First, we should thank the Nicaraguan strongman and his junta for reminding us that real Communists play to win. Staying in power is the name of their game. Mr. Ortega's promises of free elections, reiterated as his 120,000-man army breaks the cease-fire, are intended only to fool our Congress and disarm his opposition.
Second, we should never underestimate the capacity of accommodationists to fall back further. After the shock of the Communist declaration of war on its opponents wears off, we will hear a cacophony of alibis: We should never have given humanitarian aid to our debilitated allies; the remaining contras deliberately thrust their noses into Communist fists, etc.
Third, we should remember that appeasement does not always lead to war; sometimes it leads to surrender. Amid outraged cries on Capitol Hill, I-told-you-so's from the White House and fierce hand-wringing at the U.N., one waits in vain for a call to re-arm the opposition. ''If Mr. Ortega wants to resume the killing again,'' intones the White House spokesman, ''that is his business.''
Our business, it seems, is to prattle about ''the peace process''; to rub the noses of the gullible Central American leaders in its failure; to luxuriate in world condemnation of the victorious despot; to pretend our inaction is a clever way to avoid giving Communists an excuse for canceling elections, and to continue to be the patient pygmy of the North.
Take a parallelogram: While Mr. Gorbachev permits thugs and tyrants to be ousted in his sphere of influence, Mr. Bush permits the likes of Manuel Noriega and Daniel Ortega to repress freedom in our sphere.
That cannot be our foreign policy. Nobody suggests that we send in the Marines, by jingo, but we bear some responsibility for human rights in our backyard. We should have learned by now that no chorus of miffed outsiders shouting ''For shame!'' is going to oust the Communist regime in Nicaragua.
More effective than this so-called diplomatic pressure will be a combination of (1) a clear Presidential articulation of the goal to help Nicaraguans replace a regime that will find any excuse to kill its opposition; (2) serious and sustained military pressure by contras supplied with plenty of the most lethal aid, and (3) economic pressure beyond an embargo.
Now we come to the confluence of the Dickensian epoch of belief and epoch of incredulity, to see how the best of times can be used to ameliorate the worst of times.
The Communist regime repressing freedom in Nicaragua is supported financially by the Communist regime repressing freedom in Cuba, which in turn is kept afloat by a massive subsidy from the Communist regime in the Soviet Union, which is led by the man who needs our help.
We should not expect Mr. Gorbachev to pick up the phone and say to Mr. Castro, ''Tell Ortega to hold a free election in February or I start saving a billion a year in bailing out Cuba''; nothing so crass as that. Subtler diplomatic channels exist to get the identical point across.
Is it too much to expect the sherpas preparing the floating summit session to suggest a way to improve the atmosphere beforehand? One way would be to get their clients in Cuba to call off the dogs in Nicaragua - to refrain from taking advantage of U.S. irresolution in Central America just as we refrain from taking advantage of Soviet weakness in Eastern Europe.
Linkage lives. Mr. Bush extracted nothing from the Gorbachev need for summit spectaculars, but that was before the Ortega double-cross.
The Soviet leader wants absolution in advance for crackdowns to come. Not only should that trap be sidestepped and Baltic independence urged, but the Soviet subsidy of the Cuban subsidy of the Ortega offensive should be put down as an unfriendly act.

HEADLINE: California to Act on Temporary Tax for Quake Aid

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Nov. 1

 BODY:
The California Legislature will meet Thursday in a special session to vote on a temporary increase in the state sales tax to raise $800 million for earthquake relief and repairs.
State officials said the money would not nearly cover the full cost of repairing roads, bridges and buildings damaged by the Oct. 17 quake.
But a larger package would run afoul of state taxing and spending limits imposed by the voters in recent years. Thus consideration of more money for earthquake relief will await the results of a referendum already scheduled for June 1990, when voters will decide whether to ease the spending limit imposed in 1979 as part of a statewide tax revolt. 
Legislative leaders and Gov. George Deukmejian agreed Monday on the plan to add a quarter-cent to the sales tax, which ranges from 6 to 7 cents throughout California, depending on local levies. The increase would begin Dec. 1 and end 13 months later.
 
Costs in the Billions
The Governor, a Republican who has built a political career on his opposition to tax increases, said the money raised, when added to $3.45 billion in Federal emergency aid and a portion of the state's $674 million budget reserve, would be adequate to cover the state's initial costs of damage from the quake.
Officials of the San Francisco Bay Area estimate at least $10 billion will be needed for repairs and relief. Roadways and buildings that are the responsibilities of state and local government suffered an estimated $5 billion in damages.
''The quarter-cent is inadequate, and probably grossly inadequate, to meet our needs,'' declared Don Perata, an Alameda County Supervisor, who along with other county supervisors has written to the Governor and Legislature urging immediate imposition of a penny sales tax increase.
 
Other Earthquake Bills
The State Seismic Safety Commission, meeting in San Francisco on Tuesday, concluded that the temporary sales tax increase will barely touch the state's long-term costs of repairing damages from the quake.
The Legislature, which would normally not reconvene until January, will also vote this week on bills to provide tax relief for earthquake victims, put highway construction programs on a faster track than normal and set up a compensation fund for individuals unable to receive adequate relief from Federal disaster funds.
To spend a one-cent sales tax increase, as called for Tuesday by officials in Alameda County, legislators would have to waive the limit temporarily and then cut state spending in future years.
 
Trouble Before Tremor
A special election could be called to lift the limit and raise taxes sooner, but the Governor and legislative leaders fear that early approval of new taxes might hamper efforts to pass a June 1990 ballot measure aimed at freeing the state from some of the restraints caused by the spending limit. The measure would amend the state's Constitution to remove new gasoline taxes from the spending limit, then allow for a 9-cent-a-gallon tax increase over the next five years to pay for construction and repairs of the state's highways, which were badly deteriorated even before the earthquake.
By imposing a relatively modest tax increase now and spreading it out over two of the state's fiscal years, which begin July 1, the state can avoid bumping against the limit, which is tied to a complicated formula involving inflation and population growth.
To avoid overspending its limit, however, the state may simply shift most of the new tax money to counties, which in some cases may have to call special local elections to allow them to spend over their limits to make repairs.

HEADLINE: Prosperity Seen After Pain of Quake

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 1

 BODY:
These days, getting a table at the Washington Square Bar and Grill is easy. Ed Moose, the owner, says business at his usually bustling North Beach establishment is off at least 20 percent since the Oct. 17 earthquake.
''We're losing about $1,000 a day,'' Mr. Moose said.
At nearby Fisherman's Wharf, Michael Sabella, partner and chef at Sabella's, A Restaurant, said: ''Business has been terrible, off 70 percent. I just wish that soon everybody would realize that the majority of San Francisco is back to normal.'' 
Hotels and restaurants have begun laying off employees as business has dropped as much as 85 percent at some of them. The major department stores in the Union Square shopping area say they are still experiencing slow sales. And many people are out of a job as a result of the business decline.
 
Long-Term Outlook Excellent
But if the aftermath of the quake has all but halted some businesses, economists say the long-term outlook for the broader economy of the Bay Area remains excellent. Repair costs and revenue shortages that some businesses will suffer will be offset in the economy as a whole by increased construction, the economists say.
Still, the short-term effects for certain businesses are dire, particularly for those dependent on tourism. Generating about $3.4 billion in revenue annually, tourism is the city's No. 1 industry.
Many hotels are operating at a fraction of their typical occupancy rates, and some stores say they fear the closing of the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge will cost them their crucial East Bay business for the Christmas season. Small service businesses, from taxis to dry cleaners, have already seen a substantial drop in income as the effect of the business dropoff ripples down the economic structure.
 
Unemployment Is Seen Rising
Before to the earthquake, San Francisco's unemployment rate was 4.2 percent. The San Francisco Chamber of Commerce says the current rate has not been calculated but it is presumed to be significantly higher, the result primarily of the layoff of employees at hotels and restaurants.
Tapan Munroe, chief economist for the Pacific Gas and Electric Company, said there is likely to be a negative impact on the employment rate for about three months, primarily affecting hourly workers in retail sales. ''But as the aid money flows into the region we're going to see a boom,'' he said. ''Six months from now we will see a very positive effect.''
The boom will primarily benefit workers with more skills, at least at first. ''The entire engineering and construction industry will see a very significant boom, not just in San Francisco, but the entire 10-county area surrounding it,'' Mr. Munroe said. In addition to repairs and new construction, there will extensive upgrading of buildings to meet current standards for earthquake resistance.
 
Fewer Optional Purchases
The losses to personal wealth will mean fewer optional purchases for some time, said Stephen E. Roulac, chief executive of the Roulac Consulting Group, a unit of Deloitte Haskins & Sells, an accounting firm. ''Clearly we're going to have a redirection from consumer non-durable goods'' to replacement and repair of damaged structures and property, he said.
Reconstruction costs and the resulting increases in rent or real estate prices will reshape the demographics of some neighborhoods and business districts, the economists said. Small locally owned businesses could be displaced by chains in areas like Santa Cruz's Pacific Garden Mall, while the residential hotels and dilapidated apartments of San Francisco's Tenderloin district are less likely to be repaired than replaced with more expensive housing.
Mr. Roulac said a longer-term impact of the quake will be to push lower-income people out of the city, perhaps to Oakland, and to draw upper-middle income families back, as damaged hotels and apartment buildings in some run-down areas are replaced with new condominiums.
''Places like the Tenderloin will require such high capital costs to bring structures to seismic standards that only upper-middle-class people will be able to afford to live there,'' he said.
The quake also raises the question of the vulnerability of any industry that is concentrated heavily in Northern California, like personal computers. But few are expected to shift operations in response to it, economists and executives say. Rising real estate prices and labor shortages have already prompted many companies to move manufacturing out of the Bay Area and will continue to do so, not the forces of nature, they say.
''In general, for the economy as a whole, it probably will be hard to notice'' the quake's impact, said Randall Pozdena, assistant vice president and economist for the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco. ''There will be a shortfall while there's disruption of business, but offsetting that will be money coming in from outside the area, which, on balance, will probably make the situation a wash.''
 
Real Estate Outlook Bright
Based on previous earthquakes, the impact on real estate values is likely to be limited and temporary, Mr. Pozdena said. After the 1971 quake in the Sylmar area of Southern California, ''home sales volume dropped for two or three months, but then returned to the trend of the basin as a whole, and prices remained about the same,'' he said. ''After the 1906 earthquake, housing prices actually went up.''
Despite the damage and disruption, Mr. Munroe of Pacific Gas and Electric, he sees some real long-term benefits arising from the quake, like a much-needed upgrading of Bay Area transit systems, and a greater willingness from employers to experiment with flexible work schedules and having employees work at home by using personal computers and facsimile machines. ''We only act and do difficult things when there's a crisis,'' he said. ''This may be a great opportunity.'' But the businesses dependent on tourists want people to know the city offers a great opportunity for visitors now. A few restaurants at Fisherman's Wharf and nearby Pier 39, another favorite tourist site, have begun giving customers stamped postcards to write to friends and relatives to tell them that most of San Francisco is back to normal.

HEADLINE: U.S. Regulation Urged for Money Exchanges

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1

 BODY:
The chairman of the Senate Banking Committee said today that he was preparing legislation to regulate thousands of small businesses through which recent immigrants send money to relatives and also through which vast sums of illegal drug money are laundered.
A small percentage of these storefront operations, which are mostly in cities, are legitimate and licensed under some state laws. They transmit money to other states and countries, cash checks and exchange different currencies.
But the vast majority of them are unlicensed and unregulated and currently fall between the cracks of Federal and state efforts to combat money laundering and consumer fraud. The worst problems are in New York, Florida, California and Texas, where some regulators estimate that billions of dollars are being funneled through the check-cashing and money-transmitting businesses to destinations in South America and Asia. 
 
'It's a 50-State Problem'
Senator Donald W. Riegle, chairman of the Committee on Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs, said the laundering of illegal drug proceeds through these operations is ''not a one-state problem or a one-city problem.''
''It's a 50-state problem and it is an emergency, so I think we need a Federal answer,'' the Michigan Democrat said, adding that legislation to regulate such activities ''would be put on the fast track.''
''Launderers are making an increased use of check cashing and other neighborhood operations,'' Mr. Riegle said. ''This would do the most to disrupt the flow of money into and out of the country.''
He said the Bush Administration ''has not made an effort to control this problem.''
Mr. Riegle made his remarks in response to questions sent through his spokeswoman, Karolyn Wallace, and at a hearing earlier in the day before the banking Subcommittee on Consumer and Regulatory Affairs.
 
Loophole for Drug Dealers
At the hearing, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, the New York Republican who also sits on the banking committee, said the current system of state regulation and nonregulation of the money-transitting operations was ''a loophole that drug dealers are exploiting to the fullest.''
The proposed legislation, which woulafaffect t,usands of checcacashi c companies, money exchgeges and transtttting seicices, comes in response to a handful of cases brought by prosecutors and a recent complaints by state regulators who said state laws and procedures were too weak to enable them to monitor these businesses or prosecute them adequately.
The transmitters typically take cash - often delivered in suitcases or cartons - and then repackage it in less suspicious money sacks and deposit it into a bank account under the name of a real or fictitious company. From there it can be electronically transferred in seconds to Latin America or Asia.
Regulators say the check-cashing operations and money exchangers are often used to convert huge volumes of cash into money orders or checks, which can be easily transported across the border or deposited in a bank account without arousing suspicion.
 
Senator's Proposals
Mr. Riegle said the legislation probably would require the businesses to have a certified seal in a conspicuous place to show that they had been licensed. It would also enable Federal authorities to prosecute those businesses that do not comply with the new laws. He said money for the enforcement of the new Federal law would come from the illegal money that would be seized.
Senator John F. Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts, said the legislation would be moving quickly and might be ready after the winter recess.
''We're going to be working pretty hard at getting it out as soon as we can,'' said Mr. Kerry, who has been holding hearings on money-laundering issues. ''But we don't want to rush through with something without fully exploring its consequences.''
Salvatore R. Martoche, assistant secretary of the Treasury for enforcement and the Administration official overseeing controls on money laundering, said the Administration would not take a position on Mr. Riegle's proposals until he reviewed them.
 
Trade Group's Defense
Jerome S. Gagerman, chairman of the National Check Cashers Association, a trade group that represents more than 600 businesses that operate more than 1,500 check-cashing locations, said there was no need for further regulation. ''The overwhelming majority of check cashers know their responsibilities and comply with all of the regulatory requirements,'' he said.
The Federal Bank Secrecy Act requires banks to report domestic deposits of more than $10,000, but regulators say the money-transmitting and check operations make it easy to conceal suspicious transactions.
Bank regulators in New York have already identified more than 130 illegal operations and believe that many more exist. These operations have been identified through complaints of fraud that have been filed by legitimate customers who are often recent immigrants trying to send money to relatives in Latin America. The penalty for such operations under the state law is a misdemeanor punishable by a maximum sentence of one year in jail and a $500 fine.
''The penalty is merely a slap on the wrist,'' said Timothy D. Mahoney, the director of the special investigations division of the New York Department of Banks.
Similiar problems confront regulators in other states. State bank regulators are meeting this week in Austin, Tex., to explore the growing problem. Florida's comptroller, Gerald Lewis, said that in his state, ''it's a monumental problem.'' He added in his testimony that the state did not regulate check cashing or money transmitters.
 
Trade Alternative to Drugs
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -President Bush today announced a package of trade initiatives to help create ''economic alternatives to drug trafficking'' for Colombia, Bolivia, Peru, Ecuador and Venezuela.
The initiatives grew out of a promise Mr. Bush made to President Virgilio Barco Vargas of Colombia last month to expand economic trade as part of the war on drugs.
The White House said the initiatives were intended to bolster trade with the Andean nations. It said they will include expanding the list of agricultural and industrial products that will be allowed into the United States duty-free. The White House gave no specifics.

HEADLINE: Notebook;
St. John's Hoping for Playoff Spot

BYLINE: By WILLIAM N. WALLACE

 BODY:
While bowl-game speculation has begun at the major college level, playoff talk is also rife at the small college level. Does St. John's, with an 8-0 record for the first time in its football history, stand a chance? What about Montclair State (6-1-1) and Trenton State (7-0-1)?
Of the 87 teams in the East playing at the Division III level, only four will be chosen for the 16-team playoffs for the championship won by Ithaca last year and Wagner the year before. Selections will be made on Nov. 12. 
The Division III poll, conducted under the auspices of the National Collegiate Athletic Association but carrying no official weight, again this week has two upstate New York teams first and second, Cortland State and Union, both 8-0.
St. John's, which has games left against Georgetown (2-6) and Hofstra (6-2), is third; Trenton State fourth, and Montclair State is tied for fifth with Lowell.
Montclair and Trenton are tied for first in the New Jersey Athletic Conference after their 31-31 tie on Saturday. The race is far from over because each team has two league games left, the second one Nov. 11 against a strong opponent with a winning record. Montclair finishes against Glassboro State (4-2-2), while Trenton meets Ramapo (5-2).
The competition is so keen that a team with two defeats stands little or no chance of getting an N.C.A.A. playoff bid. That would include Wagner (5-2), following defeats by Hofstra and C. W. Post, that marked the first time the Seahawks lost consecutive games in Walt Hameline's nine years as head coach.
 
Costly Injury for Wagner
John Lavelis, C. W. Post's defensive end, was partly responsible for Wagner's demise. His hard sack of Ray Benvenuti knocked the Seahawk quarterback out of the game and out for the season. Lavelis, a transfer from Delaware with 17 sacks for the season, has also accounted for 145 yards lost by opponents.
Wagner has an intersectional opponent for Saturday's home game, Wisconsin-Platteville, which had 571 yards rushing in its last game, a 57-14 rout of Wisconsin-Superior.
 
Unusual Feat for Snyder
Columbia had something to cheer about in its loss to Bucknell, its seventh straight of the season. Galen Snyder, the inside linebacker, had a part in 35 tackles, an unbelievable total that was verified by coaches from the game film. Bucknell had 83 plays, so Snyder, a transfer from Duke, helped stop 42 percent. No wonder he was the Eastern College Athletic Conference defensive-player-of-the week for Division I-AA.
Judd Garrett of Princeton was the offensive choice for his game against Harvard.
 
Liberty Bowl Awaits Winner
An invitation to the Liberty Bowl in Memphis on Dec. 28 and the Commander-in-Chief Trophy will be the probable rewards for the winner of the Air Force-Army game at Colorado Springs on Saturday.
The Cadet defense will have its hands full against Dee Dowis, the quick 155-pound quarterback for the Falcons.
In Air Force's last game, a loss to Texas Christian, Dowis lacked impressive statistics. But his coach, Fisher DeBerry, said Dowis should still be a strong Heisman Trophy candidate, ''for what he means to us. He's excellent.''
Mike Thorson, Army's cornerback, was one of the 11 senior scholar-athletes from Division I-A teams that won $4,000 graduate scholarships from the National Football Foundation. Thorson, majoring in economics, has a 3.995 grade-point average.
Other Eastern players who won scholarships were Mark Kamphaus, the Boston College quarterback, and Steve Tardy, a Rutgers offensive lineman.
 
Tough Schedule for Fordham
Fordham, outscored by 148-24 in losing its four Colonial League games, drops back to the Division III level for its final two contests, both at home. But Coach Larry Glueck warns it will not be easy against Hofstra and C. W. Post.
Eddie Pearson, the senior back who contributed so much to the Rams in previous seasons, has played little because of a chronic ankle injury. ''He can't seem to get well,'' Glueck said.
 
All for Naught
Dave Murphy, the Holy Cross senior cornerback, has blocked 10 punts in his career. He had two against Brown plus a block of a conversion placement. . . . Dave Goodwin's 445 yards passing was the second-highest total in Colgate history. But his team was beaten by Lafayette, 38-33.

HEADLINE: Progress Reported in Opera Strike Talks

BYLINE: By JOHN ROCKWELL

 BODY:
After intensive bargaining Monday through yesterday, the New York City Opera and its orchestra said yesterday afternoon that they had made substantial progress in settling the orchestra's six-week-old strike.
As a result, the company announced that it was proceeding with its spring musicals season at the New York State Theater in Lincoln Center, which it had threatened to cancel if a settlement had not been reached by yesterday. There are no plans, however, to revive the regular fall opera season, which had been scheduled to run until Nov. 19 and which the company canceled on Oct. 12. 
By joint agreement, no details of the terms that have been agreed upon will be released. Both Martin J. Oppenheimer, vice chairman of the City Opera and its chief labor negotiator, and John Palanchian, vice president of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, said the progress made yesterday did not constitute a tentative agreement. When such an agreement is approved by the orchestra's negotiating committee, it must be submitted to the full 69-member ensemble for ratification.
''We still have a number of noneconomic issues to resolve,'' Mr. Oppenheimer said. ''They are important to both sides, but we are confident we can work them out in the next few days.''
Mr. Palanchian cautioned that ''a couple of those issues do have some economic impact.'' The two sides are to meet again today.
Mr. Oppenheimer said a new contract must still be negotiated with the American Guild of Musical Artists, which represents 250 company solo singers, choristers, dancers and stage directors. Traditionally, guild pacts have followed the guidelines of the orchestra contracts. The previous federation and guild contracts expired May 30.
Christopher Keene, the new general director of the City Opera, has been known to be exploring ways of reshaping the company's repertory schedule, which in the fall has meant up to eight performances a week.
Mr. Keene said yesterday that the new contract would provide a ''very productive framework and structure for us to make changes.''
Except in 1986, every contract negotiation between the City Opera and its orchestra since 1962 has provoked a labor dispute. In 1983, there was a 54-day strike. The terms of the resulting contract embittered the orchestra. Asked if the new pact was likely to alleviate some of that bitterness, Mr. Palanchian said, ''Unless something unforeseen happens, I think so.''
The spring musicals seasons have been underwritten by a five-year $5 million grant from the late philanthropist Lawrence Wien. The 1990 musical, to run Feb. 26 to April 22, is known to be ''The Sound of Music'' by Richard Rodgers, but the final rights have not yet been obtained. The run will represent the last year of the Wien commitment, and Mr. Keene is thought to be less enthused about continuing spring musicals than was his predecessor, Beverly Sills.
The main issues in the strike, which began on Sept. 13, have been the company's initial attempt - since abandoned - to eliminate the six weeks beyond the regular 23-week opera season in which the players have been provided either employment or half-pay supplemental income, and the orchestra's desire for wages and a workload that would bring them closer to such orchestras as those of the San Francisco Opera and the Lyric Opera of Chicago. An average City Opera orchestra member earned about $27,000 last year.
At an informal bargaining session on Monday, the company was said to have presented a new proposal, to which the orchestra responded at a noon session on Tuesday. There was another four-hour session Tuesday night, and one at noon yesterday.

HEADLINE: Bush Seeks An Edge on Gains Tax

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1

 BODY:
Seeking to regain a tactical advantage in his fight for a cut in the capital gains tax, President Bush is seriously considering proposals to make permanent the $16 billion in automatic spending cuts that took effect on Oct. 16, Republican Congressional leaders said today.
The capital gains tax and the spending cuts have become linked in the Congressional maneuvering over how to fashion a deficit-reduction plan that would undo the spending cuts and at the same time permit final action on a number of other measures attached to the House version of that plan.
Those measures include modifications to the catastrophic health insurance program and a temporary cut in the capital gains tax.
 
Reductions in Medicare
The spending cuts - $8 billion from the Pentagon budget and $8 billion from a variety of domestic programs - have already reduced reimbursements for Medicare beneficiaries by 2 percent and would eventually force sharp reductions in education grants. 
Over time, they would also mean cuts in military personnel on active duty and could require layoffs of other Federal employees, including drug-enforcement agents, law-enforcement personnel and air traffic controllers.
The cuts were required under the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings balanced-budget law because Congress failed to meet the law's deadline for devising its own deficit-reduction plan.
The Republican leaders who met with Mr. Bush on Tuesday to discuss tax and budget strategy said the President had made no decision on whether to let the automatic budget cuts stand. But they said his top advisers - Richard G. Darman, the budget director, and John H. Sununu, the chief of staff - were strongly in favor of such a course. Mr. Darman has publicly urged this for some time.
 
Advantages for White House
Allowing the spending cuts to become permanent could help the White House meet next year's targets for cutting the deficit and also assist it in tactical maneuvering this year to get a vote on cutting the capital gains tax.
Congressional Democrats have proposed a deal in which the deficit-reduction plan would include changes in the health insurance program and the extension of a variety of tax breaks popular in both parties.
Republicans contend that if Mr. Bush were to veto such a Congressional deficit-reduction plan or simply to tell Congress there was no need for one, Democrats would have to deal with the health insurance program and the tax breaks in a separate tax bill. Under those circumstances, some Republicans think they would gain the leverage they now lack to force a Senate vote on cutting the capital gains tax.
Administration officials and Congressional Republicans said the option had become more attractive to President Bush in recent days because of new calculations suggesting that the effect of permanent cuts on the Pentagon budget would not be as severe as previously thought.
Administration and Congressional officials said Mr. Sununu had been presented with the numbers and believed they demonstrated that the Pentagon ''could survive'' the automatic spending cuts for a year.
''Sequester has some attractive benefits to it,'' the White House press secretary, Marlin Fitzwater, told reporters today, using the technical term for the automatic spending cuts. ''We are looking at what it would do. We are planning it into the economies of all the departments, including the Pentagon, and we think we can handle it.''
Senate Democratic leaders said that they take the Adminstration's threat of a permanent sequester seriously, but that it would not be enough to change any minds on a capital gains tax cut. ''We simply are not going to be blackjacked into voting for it on the basis of a sequester,'' said Senator Jim Sasser, the Tennessee Democrat who heads the Senate Budget Committtee.
''It is clear that the White House is coming more and more to wanting a sequester,'' said Senator Bob Packwood of Oregon, the senior Republican on the Senate Finance Committee and chief sponsor of a plan to cut the capital gains tax rate permanently.
 
'Whole New Ball Game'
Mr. Packwood, who conceded that Republicans are currently at a tactical disadvantage, said that if Mr. Bush were to agree to make the spending cuts permanent, ''it's a whole new ball game.''
Mr. Packwood said the Administration had determined that even with the automatic budget cuts in effect, the amount the Pentagon will spend in the current fiscal year will be only $3 billion less than it would spend if the cuts were rescinded. Initially, he said, the estimates had indicated a gap of $12 billion to $15 billion.
Congressional budget specialists confirmed those estimates, adding however, that because much of the Pentagon's spending is planned on a multi-year basis, automatic cuts this year could pose serious budget difficulties for the Pentagon in fiscal 1991.
Mr. Sasser disputed the Administration's calculations on the Pentagon budget for the current fiscal year and said the effects of making the automatic spending cuts permanent would be more damaging to the Pentagon than the Administration is now suggesting.
 
Report From Gingrich
Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the House Republican whip and one of those who attended the Tuesday meeting with the President, said Mr. Bush was not prepared to accept a deficit-reduction plan that ''did not meet his goals.''
But Mr. Gingrich said he thought the President would sign a deficit plan if he had an agreement from Senate Democrats that there would be a vote on the substance of a capital gains tax cut proposal.
Although Mr. Gingrich and Mr. Packwood clearly favor the idea of making the automatic spending cuts permanent, that view is not shared by two leading Senate Republicans -the Senate minority leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, and the senior Republican on the Senate Budget Committee, Pete Domenici of New Mexico.

HEADLINE: U.S. Eases Threats of Sanctions

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1

 BODY:
Because South Korea, Taiwan and Saudi Arabia have started cracking down on pirated versions of American films, records, pharmaceuticals, software and other products, the United States eased a threat of trade sanctions against them. But Washington left five other countries on its priority watch list: Brazil, India, Mexico, China and Thailand.
The United States also warned Malaysia and Turkey that they must provide better protection.
Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, issued a status report today on how the United States is faring in its effort to curb losses on American products - estimated at up to $61 billion a year - because of inadequate protection abroad of ''intellectual property rights.'' 
 
Trade Sanctions
Mrs. Hills's report said some trading partners were tightening their rules because of the possible sanctions and ''the growing realization around the world that denial of adequate and effective protection of intellectual property rights is harmful to the national economic interests of all trading nations.''
South Korea, Taiwan and Saudi Arabia were removed from the so-called ''priority watch list,'' which serves as a warning that a country is being closely scrutinized as a prelude to a possible investigation and trade retaliation.
Under the 1988 Omnibus Trade and Competitiveness Act, sanctions were mandated against countries that deny ''adequate and effective protection'' to copyrights, patents and other intellectual property.
The Saudis agreed to enact a copyright law protecting among other things literary works, software and sound recordings. It is the first such law in a Persian Gulf nation. Taiwan has cracked down on theaters that use ordinary videocassette machines to show pirated American films. South Korea arrested textbook pirates, including the owner of one of its largest pirate book operations, Tower Press.
 
Next Report in April
The International Intellectual Property Alliance, comprising 1,600 companies with $270 billion of gross revenues last year, voiced concern that greater improvement had not been made.
Eric Smith, the general counsel of the organization, warned that it would seek a sanctions designation for some or all of the five countries remaining on the priority watch list if their performance did not improve by April 30, which is when the trade representative makes the next status report.
In addition to the ''priority watch list,'' the United States has set up a second category of countries whose trading practices it is dissatisfied with, though not to the same degree as the others.
Seventeen countries were put on this list in May. Today, Mrs. Hills made no changes to the list except for the warnings given to Turkey and Malaysia.
 
'Disturbing Developments'
Mrs. Hills spoke of ''recent disturbing developments in Turkey'' and noted ''continuing slow progress in Malaysia.'' She said that ''as a result, over the coming weeks the United States Government will step up efforts to make progress with both these countries.''
Turkey, said Mr. Smith of the Intellectual Property Alliance, ''has not been forthcoming at all in improving its level of protection and enforcement for U.S. copyrighted works, other than sound recordings.''
He added that a legislative amendment proposed by the Turkish Ministry of Culture threatens to close down the newly opened video market in Turkey as well.
Akin Istanbullu, economic and commercial counselor at the Turkish Embassy, said the warning was not expected by his Government and that any more detailed comment would have to come from Ankara.
 
No Accord With Malaysia
The argument with Malaysia is over its unwillingess to sign an agreement with the United States that would give American works protection. Pirated American books, audios, software and films find an easy market in neighboring Singapore.
Ahmad Fuzi, Deputy Chief of Mission at the Malaysian Embassy, said his Government has had discussions with the United States and ''we hope that the matter will be resolved to the satisfaction of both sides.''

HEADLINE: More Antitrust Challenges Are Expected Under Bush

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1

 BODY:
The Bush Administration will be challenging many more large mergers and suing more companies for false advertising than the Reagan Administration did, Administration officials and antitrust experts are predicting.
These experts say a less ideological approach to free markets by President Bush, a belief that antitrust enforcement was far too lax in the 1980's, and pressure from state law-enforcement officials will result in the Government's stiffer attitude.
''I don't want to draw comparisons with the prior Administration, but I do take a pragmatic approach to antitrust enforcement,'' said James F. Rill, the new Assistant Attorney General in charge of the Justice Department's antitrust division. ''I will require hard evidence before I make a decision not to challenge a merger that otherwise looks like it could have anticompetitive effects.'' 
The new approach is likely to take a clearer shape on Friday, when Janet D. Steiger, the new chairwoman of the Federal Trade Commission, and Mr. Rill are scheduled to address antitrust attorneys at the Harvard Law School and present their agendas.
Mrs. Steiger declined to be interviewed before her speech.
Indeed, though few anticipate a return to the hyperactive antitrust policies of the 50's and 60's, the attorneys foresee a noticeable change from the Reagan years, when the Justice Department and the Federal Trade Commission permitted almost every big merger to go through unchallenged.
Charles F. Rule, President Reagan's last antitrust chief at the Justice Department, commented, ''You do get rumblings that suggest they are not quite as confident in the market and feel the Government should get more involved.''
 
Stronger States' Role
The apparent change in policy comes as many state attorneys general have been increasing their antimerger and false advertising lawsuits, as well as advocating tough anti-takeover laws, contending that they are only filling a vacuum created by relaxed antitrust enforcement by the Reagan Administration.
That has actually led some companies to seek more action on the Federal level. They say that a unified Federal policy will be more welcome than 50 different policies by state officials and legislatures.
Yet the antitrust experts warn that toughening Federal policy on mergers and false advertising may be difficult, since for years Federal courts have upheld the more permissive approach and may not be inclined to reverse themselves.
Any changes, the antitrust professionals say, would primarily reflect Mr. Bush's pragmatic approach to problems and his willingness to compromise to promote policy.
''Most people in the Reagan Administration came with certain strong principles they wanted to articulate and enunciate,'' said Mr. Rule, the Reagan antitrust official. ''The Bush folks are going to be more pragmatic and less viewing themselves in the role of leading the policy debate.''
 
A Vigorous Agenda
Even though the President still believes in free markets, he proposed a vigorous agenda in his 1988 Presidential campaign, promising safer work settings and a cleaner environment - a course that, if pursued, could bring a confrontation with big business over mergers, as well as with advertisers over the accuracy of their campaigns.
One indication of a more aggressive policy came in July, when Mr. Rill attended a meeting of state attorneys general and promised cooperation in antitrust enforcement. He also agreed to set up an executive working group on antitrust issues made up of top Federal and state officials.
Last week, Mr. Rill and Mrs. Steiger and five state attorneys general met for the first time.
Many of the experts attribute the development to the new aggressiveness of the National Association of Attorneys General. In 1987, the state officials set stricter guidelines on mergers that made it easier to challenge large takeovers, and they have begun a more aggressive antitrust program, often challenging mergers that the F.T.C. or the Justice Department approved in the Reagan Administration.
 
Two Merger Challenges
Two such cases from last year involved separate mergers of California supermarket chains that would have left the companies controlling 50 percent of the grocery business in Southern California - the $2.5 billion merger of Lucky Stores with American Stores' Alpha-Beta chain and Vons' $408 million purchase of Safeway Stores' supermarkets in Southern California.
When the trade commission decided not to block the mergers, John Van de Kamp, the California Attorney General, challenged them, contending that the monopoly potential could cost consumers $400 million in higher prices. He settled the Vons case late last year, but the American Stores case is pending before the United States Supreme Court, which is likely to hear arguments early next year.
 
Any Change Supported
For many antitrust experts, any change that increases the number of cases the F.T.C. and Justice Department bring will be welcome. While Democratic and Republican Presidents had tended to support vigorous antitrust policies through the 1970's, much of the theory on antitrust changed under the Reagan Administration.
Guided by economic theories of unfettered markets developed at the University of Chicago, the Reagan antitrust officials saw little reason to stop even the largest merger that might concentrate market force with two or three companies, provided that the market could be easily entered by new participants.
This was opposed by many Democrats in Congress, who contended that lax antitrust policies only fueled the takeover craze of the 1980's, and the trade commission and the Justice Department were frequently criticized.
''You had the F.T.C. going after ophthalmologists in Boston and taxi drivers in St. Paul, instead of looking at the beer industry, a billion-dollar industry where there has been incredible concentration,'' said New York Attorney General Robert Abrams.
As such, the National Association of Attorneys General stepped in, bringing a flurry of cases, which in the end may have caused more difficulty for big business than had the Federal agencies under Reagan conducted a more vigorous effort. Daniel Oliver, the last Reagan F.T.C. chairman, noted that in many of the cases brought by the state officials, Federal courts have upheld the mergers, often citing the Chicago school's reasonings, and it might be hard for the Bush Administration to reverse the trend.
''Now you have hundreds of Federal judges that were appointed by Reagan sitting on the bench and worked with the Administration to bring merger policy to where it is today,'' said Mr. Oliver, who believes antitrust policy should not change. ''You are not going to see quick changes there.''

HEADLINE: Control Data, MIPS in Pact

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 1

 BODY:
MIPS Computer Systems Inc. and the Control Data Corporation said today that they had reached an agreement through which Control would resell computers made by MIPS.
The announcement, which follows a technology-sharing agreement disclosed two weeks ago, came in conjunction with MIPS's introduction of a new high-speed general purpose computer, the RC6280, which will sell for about $150,000. 
Control Data indicated that it would announce specific configurations and packaging of MIPS computers in early December. The company said that by the end of 1991, it expects to have sold more than $100 million of MIPS systems.
MIPS, which is based in Sunnyvale, Calif., produces computers and chips based on reduced instruction set computing, or RISC, a technology for speeding computing by reducing nonessential tasks.

HEADLINE: Growth Still Modest, Fed Report Says

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1

 BODY:
The nation's economic growth continued to vary from slow to moderate early this fall, the Federal Reserve said today in its latest economic survey, but it did not mention any inflationary problems.
''Consumer spending is mixed, with a number of districts describing retail sales as steady to growing slowly,'' the summary of the survey said. ''Manufacturing activity is also mixed, with some districts reporting weakness in orders and shipments. 
''Weakness of construction in some markets contrasts with evidence of some improvement elsewhere,'' the summary continued. ''Resource industries, including the energy sector, appear to be improving, as is agriculture generally.''
 
The 'Beige Book'
The survey by the Fed's 12 district banks, called the ''beige book'' or ''tan book,'' is compiled every six weeks to prepare for meetings of the Federal Open Market Committee, the Fed body that sets monetary policy. The next meeting is on Nov. 14. Recent economic indicators show sluggish economic growth after the Fed tightened credit to ease inflationary pressures. As inflation appeared to abate this summer, the central bank eased its grip.
The latest survey was prepared at the Fed's bank in Kansas City, Mo., based on information obtained before Oct. 10.
Seven of the 12 districts mentioned prices. They were ''generally stable'' in Boston, while ''moving up, but at a slackening pace'' in Philadelphia.
Cleveland expects ''very little moderation in inflation'' through the end of the year, while Richmond reports a slower rise in input prices. Respondents in the Atlanta district ''reported only modest wage or price pressures.''
In the Kansas City district, ''retail prices and prices of manufacturers' inputs have changed little in recent months,'' the survey said, while ''wage and price increases remain modest'' in the San Francisco district.
 
Retail Sales Mixed
In the retail area, the survey said: ''Sales of apparel, basic housewares and other nondurables are described as relatively strong. Sales are weaker for discretionary, big-ticket items such as furniture, home appliances and consumer electronics.'' ''
Manufacturing activity was described as slowing in the Philadelphia, Chicago and Cleveland districts; varied in Richmond and St. Louis, and improving in Boston, Dallas and San Francisco.
The San Francisco district reported that most businesses in its area ''have resumed operations since the earthquake, but road closures and property damage are delaying a complete return to business as usual.'' The quake, which occurred on Oct. 17, has claimed 66 lives.
The Richmond district said that many of the usual South Carolina participants in its survey did not respond because of Hurricane Hugo, which struck on Sept. 21. But it said the hurricane had little effect on the industrial base of either of the Carolinas, although agriculture sectors were severely affected.

HEADLINE: Fall in Nation's Manufacturing Slows in October

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
The manufacturing sector of the nation's economy continued to decline for the sixth consecutive month in October, but at a lesser rate, according to an index published yesterday by the National Association of Purchasing Management.
Other indications of slowing economic growth came as the Commerce Department reported that orders for manufactured goods and construction spending were unchanged in September. And the Federal Reserve reported that the economy's growth was slow to moderate in the fall.
''These numbers mean that the economy is growing slowly, but they do not mean that we are headed for a recession at this point,'' said Maury N. Harris, chief economist at Paine Webber Inc. He said the lack of inflationary pressure would give the Federal Reserve the opportunity to stimulate the economy before a recession can develop. 
 
G.N.P. Growth Outlook
David M. Jones, director of research at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, said: ''All the numbers we saw today reflect a pattern of slow to moderate growth. It looks like we will have real G.N.P. growth of 1.5 percent in the fourth quarter compared to 2.5 in the third. I do not see any recession at this time.''
The purchasing managers' index rose to 47.6 percent in October, up from 46 percent in September. A reading below 50 indicates that the manufacturing sector is slowing and one below 44 indicates a decline in real gross national product.
''The manufacturing economy entered the final quarter of 1989 with the sixth consecutive monthly decline,'' said Robert J. Bretz, chairman of the association's business survey committee. ''Continued declines in vendor deliveries and price indexes indicate that supply is considerably greater than demand. However, the sharp turnaround in new-orders growth, after four months of decline, hints of a possible continued easing in the overall future rate of decline in the manufacturing economy.''
 
New Orders Index Rises
The new-orders index rose to 51.4 percent in October, up from 45.4 percent in September and 45.1 percent in August. But some outside economists cautioned that seasonal factors might have unduly enhanced the October new-order figures.
Mr. Bretz noted that the managers' index had averaged 49.3 percent for the first 10 months of the year. ''Past experience indicates that if this average were to continue for the final two months, it would be consistent with real G.N.P. growth of about 1.7 percent for all of 1989, unchanged from last month,'' he said.
The association reported that prices fell for the fifth consecutive month, and at a faster rate than in September. The price index fell to 41.9 percent, from 43.1 percent the previous month, to stand at the lowest level since December 1982 when it was at 31.9 percent.
Deliveries were faster in October for the sixth straight month, with the delivery index standing at 42.7 percent, the lowest level since May 1982.
Analysts said the price index decline and the faster pace of deliveries indicated that there is little danger of inflation, which was also not mentioned as a problem in yesterday's Federal Reserve report.
''There's not much indication of inflationary pressure, which gives the Fed leeway to react,'' Mr. Harris said.
Mr. Jones said he felt the agency would be cautious in an effort to keep inflation low and to discourage speculative takeovers, but agreed that its freedom to act had been enhanced.
Production and inventories declined in October, both at a rate slightly greater than September. The production index stood at 48.4 percent, down from 48.5 percent. The association's report said Hurricane Hugo appeared to have reduced output in the apparel and textile industries.
The inventory index declined to 44.7 percent from 45.1 percent. Purchasers reported that they were working to bring their inventory levels down to match lower production rates.
Employment was down in October for the ninth consecutive month, with the index dipping to 45.8 percent from 45.9 percent.
Purchasers reported that lead time for the delivery of production material remains virtually unchanged in October from the rates of the previous two months, indicating the ready availability of most materials. Managers reporting delivery times of 30 days or less increased to 55 percent from 54 percent in September and August.

HEADLINE: Orders to U.S. Factories Hold Steady

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1

 BODY:
Orders to the nation's factories for manufactured goods remained steady in September, but would have fallen had it not been for the second-largest increase in military orders in history.
Analysts viewed the Commerce Department report, released today, as another sign of weakness in the manufacturing sector, which will result in continued sluggishness in the overall economy in the months ahead.
The Commerce Department said orders for both durable and nondurable manufactured goods totaled a seasonally adjusted $236.7 billion in September. That included a 59.6 percent gain in military orders, to $12.7 billion, the largest advance in that category since a record 68.3 percent rise in June 1988. 
Without the military factor, orders actually declined 2.1 percent, the department said.
''It continues to show sluggishness in the manufacturing sector,'' David Berson, an economist of the Federal National Mortgage Association, said of the report. ''I think we'll see it pretty flat for a while.''
The report said orders for nonmilitary capital goods had decreased for the second month in a row. Those orders, a measure of business investment plans, were off 5.2 percent after dropping 10.4 percent in August.
The economy, especially the manufacturing and housing sectors, has been struggling to deal with high interest rates as the Federal Reserve tightened credit to slow inflation.
 
First Decline Since '87
Factory inventories posted their first decline since February 1987, dropping one-tenth of 1 percent, to $371.2 billion. If inventories increase without a corresponding gain in new orders, it could indicate production cutbacks in the future as factories try to get rid of goods on shelves and backlots.
Shipments of manufactured goods fell 1.6 percent, to $234.4 billion. Orders for durable goods, which are high-cost items expected to last more than three years, rose two-tenths of 1 percent, to $127 billion, raised by a 7.2 percent increase in electrical machinery, to $20.8 billion.
Primary metals orders were up nine-tenths of 1 percent, to $11.4 billion. But nonelectrical machinery orders, including computers, were off seven-tenths of 1 percent, to $22.5 billion.
Transportation equipment orders, on the other hand, fell 4.7 percent, to $34.8 billion, as declines in autos and nonmilitary aircraft more than offset gains in military aircraft orders. Without the drop in transportation, total orders would have risen eight-tenths of 1 percent.
Orders for nondurable goods were down three-tenths of 1 percent to $109.7 billion, led by a decline in food products.

HEADLINE: Construction Spending Unchanged in September

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1

 BODY:
Construction spending was unchanged in September after surging in August, reflecting continued weakness in that segment of the economy.
The Commerce Department said today that residential, nonresidential and government construction spending totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $415.6 billion in September. In August, construction spending jumped 1.5 percent, after declines of 1.8 percent in July and eight-tenths of 1 percent in June. 
Spending rose in August because of a strong 5.3 percent increase in government building and a 2.9 percent gain in nonresidential construction. But David Berson, an economist at the Federal National Mortgage Association, said that pace of spending could not be sustained because of government budget problems and a glut of vacant office buildings.
The construction industry has been among the sectors of the economy hardest hit by the Federal Reserve's campaign to keep inflation in check. But the Fed has been easing its grip on the economy, and analysts have been looking for a slight pickup in construction spending as interest rates fall.
 
Mortgage Rates Decline
The interest rate on fixed-rate mortgages declined from a peak of 11.22 percent in March to 10.16 percent at the end of September, according to the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation.
Private construction was off 1.2 percent last month to an annual rate of $327.6 billion, reflecting declines in both residential and nonresidential building.
Residential building, which accounts for nearly half of construction spending, fell nine-tenths of 1 percent, to a $191.9 billion rate. That included a drop of 1.1 percent in single-family construction, to $111.5 billion, and a 2.2 percent decline in apartment building, to $22.7 billion.
Nonresidential construction, including factories and office buildings, fell 2.6 percent, to $99.1 billion at an annual rate. This category represents about 20 percent of construction spending.
The volatile government projects category, representing another 20 percent of construction spending, was up 4.3 percent, to $88 billion.
The total construction spending figure for the first nine months was up 1 percent from the comparable period of 1988.

HEADLINE: Continued Growth Is Seen

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31

 BODY:
The economy, which is about to enter its eighth year of expansion, is likely to continue growing at least until 1991, a poll of leading business executives has found.
Of 53 chief executives who were asked last week for estimates of when a recession might start, 61 percent said they thought one would start in 1991 or later, 29 percent estimated the second half of next year and 10 percent feared a downturn in the first half of 1990, the National Association of Manufacturers said. 
Despite the rosy outlook, the trade group's president and chief economist, Jerry Jasinowski, said the economy needed lower interest rates to help stem the dollar's rise. A higher dollar makes United States exports less competitive abroad.
He also said that the Federal Reserve's goal of eliminating inflation within five years is unrealistic. He added that if the goal was pursued too ruthlessly the economy, now in the second-longest period of expansion since World War II, could be thrown into a recession.
The association's survey found that despite the dollar's rise earlier this year, 56 percent of the manufacturers polled expect their foreign sales in 1990 to be about the same as they were this year, with 42 percent planning for an increase.

HEADLINE: Dow Rises 0.82, to End Session at 2,645.90

BYLINE: By PHILLIP H. WIGGINS

 BODY:
Stocks ended mixed yesterday on moderate volume, failing to build on the strong rally of the previous session.
The Dow Jones industrial average edged up 0.82 points, to 2,645.90, after trading in a narrow range for the entire session. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange contracted to 154.2 million shares, from 176.1 million on Tuesday, when the Dow gained 41.60 points. 
The broader market fared better yesterday with the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks gaining 0.84, to 341.20. The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 0.60, to 188.84. Advancing issues on the Big Board outnumbered declining ones, 847 to 644.
 
Indications of Economic Growth
Several economic reports released yesterday signaled that the nation's economy continues to grow at a slow rate. But on the encouraging side, many analysts said the new data increase the likelihood that the Federal Reserve will push interest rates lower.
The Commerce Department reported that orders for manufactured goods and construction spending were flat in September. And the latest survey by the National Association of Purchasing Managers showed that the manufacturing sector weakened in October for a sixth straight month, although at a lower rate.
Some analysts said the state of the economy was still unclear to market participants, many of whom are awaiting tomorrow's reports on October unemployment and late-October automobile sales.
''Small investors and traders apparently are utterly confused,'' said Kenneth S. Hackle, president of Systematic Financial Management in Fort Lee, N.J. ''On the one hand, they feel the economy may have topped out, which would normally signal a weak equity market, but on the other hand, interest rates are in check and stocks represent a good value on a longer-term basis, which was manifest by Tuesday's Great Northern Nekoosa merger offer.''
Great Northern Nekoosa was the most active stock yesterday, falling 1 3/8, to 61 1/2, on a volume of 5.1 million shares.
 
Georgia Pacific Off 1/2
Georgia-Pacific, which has made a $3.19 billion takeover offer for Nekoosa, said it is considering selling certain Nekoosa assets not essential to its forest-products operations if the bid succeeds. Georgia-Pacific dropped 1/2, to 50 3/8.
Mr. Hackle noted that the automobile and technology sectors were weak. In the auto group, Ford slipped 1/4, to 47 1/8; Chrysler fell 1/8, to 21 1/4; but G.M. gained 5/8, to 45. In the technology area, I.B.M. dipped 1/4, to 100; Digital Equipment was off 3/4, to 92 3/4; Motorola slipped 1/4, to 55 5/8, and Control Data was also off 1/4, to 18.
The AMR Corporation, parent of American Airlines, rose 1 3/4, to 73 1/8, on rumors that Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. had placed AMR stock on its restricted list and that the real estate developer Donald J. Trump might have a renewed interest in taking over the airline.
Texaco was the second most active issue, rising 3/4, to 53 3/8, on a volume of 4.4 million shares.
