HEADLINE: Campaign Profile;
Warily, Giuliani Learns To Embrace the Voters

BYLINE: By DON TERRY

 BODY:
A white-haired woman put on a scratchy recording of ''New York, New York'' at a Brooklyn community center the other day and claimed the first dance with Rudolph W. Giuliani, gently nudging another woman aside.
Mr. Giuliani's aides were beaming as the Republican-Liberal mayoral candidate did a couple of spins with the woman, a television news crew following every step.
It was the kind of image that the campaign has been trying to convey for months with mixed results.
Mr. Giuliani and his aides have had no trouble portraying him as a hard-nosed, law-and-order former Federal prosecutor whose battle cry is crime, crime, crime. But presenting him as a warm, compassionate man has been a harder task. 
 
Thumbs-Up Sign
For months Mr. Giuliani, who is 45 years old, came across as an arm's-length candidate, shaking hands stiffly and rarely shedding his suit jacket.
It was his first bid for elective office, and he was basing it largely on the reputation he built in five and a half years as United States Attorney in Manhattan, as a crime fighter who captured crooks and headlines. The image gave his campaign its initial momentum, but it did nothing to soften the public's perception of him.
Over the last few weeks, however, he has seemed more relaxed, becoming more generous with his smile. He has been flashing an occasional thumbs-up sign and increasingly taking off his coat.
His campaign aides say he is shy, not cold. He can be a real cutup at parties, they say. He has been known to sit around with friends and exchange dialogue from ''The Godfather,'' the bloody gangster epic he confesses to have seen six or seven times. Asked to quote a line from the movie, Mr. Giuliani said: ''Keep the cannoli. Drop the gun.''
But his favorite movie is ''It's a Wonderful Life,'' the Christmas classic about small-town virtues. He has seen the film at least 30 times.
 
Jeans and a Movie
To escape the pressures of the campaign in September, Mr. Giuliani and his wife, Donna Hanover, a television news anchor at WPIX, put on their jeans and slipped away to see ''When Harry Met Sally.''
''First, we had hot dogs at Nathan's,'' said Ms. Hanover, who is on maternity leave from her job. ''It was a wonderful date. Just like the old days.''
''I really enjoy movies,'' Mr. Giuliani said in a separate interview. ''One of the things we've been deprived of during the campaign is the opportunity to see many movies.''
Mr. Giuliani mixed business with pleasure when he and a campaign aide attended a late-night showing of ''Do the Right Thing,'' Spike Lee's film about racial tension and misunderstanding.
He said he was drawn to the film by news articles suggesting that the movie's portrayal of New York as a racially tense city could become a campaign issue.
''It did what a work of art is supposed to do,'' he said. ''It expanded your thinking. You leave it saying you can have two people look at the same world and see a different world.''
Mr. Giuliani's spare time is spent with his family. During the campaign he has had to manufacture spare time. He has often taken his son, Andrew, 3 1/2, to campaign events.
A few days before the primary in September, his three-car caravan was rushing along a Brooklyn highway when his car pulled off the road so Andrew could play in a park.
Mr. Giuliani was late for his next event.
Last Sunday, Mr. Giuliani had responded to press questions with an edge in his voice, sharp as a knife.
Minutes later, Mr. Giuliani's voice turned soft and sweet as he lifted Andrew, who was tired and crying, onto his lap and rocked him to sleep.
''You'll feel better,'' Mr. Giuliani crooned, stroking the boy's blond hair, ''as soon as you take a nap.'' A Taste for Opera, Sports and Raisin Bran Mr. Giuliani said he likes to read biographies. Of particular interest, he said, was ''The Power Broker,'' Robert A. Caro's work about Robert Moses, the urban planner.
He is also an opera fan. He has 150 opera recordings, and Verdi is one of his favorite composers. Opera, he said, ''gives you a wonderful feeling, a real sense of having captured the universe.''
He also loves to watch the football Giants on Sunday afternoons, although his wife said she was the bigger fan.
''I'm the one who says 'The football game is about to start,' '' she said. ''I'm the one sitting in front of the television first.''
To relax, Mr. Giuliani sometimes drives his Cadillac Seville through the Hudson Valley, classical music filling the car.
But in crisscrossing the city during the campaign he has had to abandon many of these pastimes.
Typically, he is too busy making a speech or shaking hands to have much time to eat. So at the end of a long day of campaigning, often around midnight, Mr. Giuliani has a heaping bowl of raisin bran and a Klondike ice cream bar.
''Everybody seems to think Rudy takes himself so seriously,'' Ms. Hanover said. ''He doesn't. He takes his integrity seriously. Rudy doesn't tell jokes, but he's very funny. He can see the humor in everyday situations. He has a bemused way of looking at the world.''
In his campaign commercials, Mr. Giuliani paints himself as a take-charge guy. The image is not purely pre-Election Day hype. When it came to courting Ms. Hanover, his second wife, Mr. Giuliani was a whirlwind.
''I fell pretty much immediately in love with Donna,'' Mr. Giuliani said. ''It took her a little longer, a few weeks, I think.''
Six weeks after meeting her on a blind date in Miami in 1982, Mr. Giuliani proposed marriage at Disney World. They were married in 1984 and in addition to Andrew, they have a baby daughter, Caroline. His first marriage, to a second cousin, ended in divorce after 14 years. Mr. Giuliani had the marriage annulled so he could remarry in the Roman Catholic church.
He may be a political novice, but Mr. Giuliani has had plenty of experience in front of news cameras; his largest triumphs as United States Attorney were announced at well-attended news conferences.
A graduate of New York University Law School, Mr. Giuliani has held high posts in the Justice Department in both the Ford and Reagan Administrations.
As a high-ranking department official, he was the main defender of its policy of detaining illegal Haitian immigrants. The administration maintained that the Haitians were not political refugees, as they contended, but that they had come to the United States only to better themselves economically. Human rights groups criticized the detention camps, saying many internees were political refugees, fleeing a repressive dictatorship.
In another controversial Justice Department matter, Mr. Giuliani settled a criminal case that involved bribery charges against executives of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation and that had been inherited from the Carter Administration. Mr. Giuliani dropped the charges, calling them unfair.
In 1983, he was appointed the United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York.
His office prosecuted important tax cases, including one against an international commodities broker, Marc Rich. It was said to be the largest tax case ever.
He also went after corrupt public officials. Two prominent Bronx Democrats, former Representative Mario Biaggi and former Borough President Stanley M. Friedman, were convicted in a bribery scheme.
Typically, Mr. Giuliani announced indictments to packed news conferences and irritated some other law-enforcement officials who said he was showing off for the cameras.
The camera also captured several setbacks that the aggressive Federal prosecutor suffered during his tenure. The divorce-fixing prosecution of Bess Myerson for supposedly trying to influence a State Supreme Court Justice ended in an acquittal. Not long after that, a Federal judge ruled that the Government had failed to prove Mr. Giuliani's charge that the Genovese crime family controlled the main union at the Fulton Fish Market He resigned last January and soon joined the law firm of White and Case. Then last spring, he announced he was running for mayor. He is on an unpaid leave of absence from the law firm, which paid him $260,000 for four months' work.
Mr. Giuliani is the Republican Party's best hope of capturing City Hall in more than 20 years. An East Sider In Discount Suits Until he went to work for White and Case, Mr. Giuliani earned less than $80,000 a year during most of his tenure as United States Attorney.
He has not bought a new suit in more than a year. When he does buy suits it is at BFO, a discount store. They are often either gray or dark blue. His ties are typically red.
''He's not a vain person at all,'' Ms. Hanover said. ''His clothes are functional. He's forever getting some kind of sauce on his red ties. But it's only the red ties. We haven't figured out why.''
The Giulianis live in a two-bedroom cooperative apartment on East 86th Street, a short walk from Gracie Mansion, the mayor's official residence.
Mr. Giuliani's 80-year-old mother lives next door, in an apartment he purchased. Mr. Giuliani said he had hoped to knock down a wall between the two apartments but the campaign delayed his plans.
Until the campaign, his taste in food was ''pretty basic:'' steak hamburgers prepared medium rare, raisin bran, Klondike bars and ''all kinds of pasta.''
While campaigning, especially during the summer for the Republican primary, Mr. Giuliani sometimes attended a half-dozen ethnic festivals in a day.
''I would end up eating four or five different kinds of food,'' he said. ''I really enjoyed it.'' A Lifelong Love Found in a Record Bin Mr. Giuliani has been in love with opera since he was 12 or 13 years old. One day he was searching the record bins of a department store on Long Island for a few rock-and-roll 45's. As he was leaving he noticed a sale bin.
The first thing he saw was a recording of ''Julius Caesar,'' by Handel. Mr. Giuliani was enrolled in a classical music class at school, so he decided to buy the recording but did not think he would like it much. The price was right, though, 99 cents.
He put the record on the stereo and ''almost immediately'' he was hooked. He eventually gave away several boxes of rock-and-roll records and replaced them with operas and classical music.
He still has that first 99-cent record.
''Rudy knows in-depth the story lines of all the operas,'' Ms. Hanover said. ''My reservation about opera is they always have a sad ending.''
There is one popular musician he does enjoy. For the last few years, the Giulianis have celebrated the New Year, dancing alone in their living room to the recorded voice of Frank Sinatra, perhaps after attending a small dinner party near their home.
As they glide by the Christmas tree, ''New York, New York,'' ''Strangers in the Night'' and ''I Did it My Way'' float through the room.
As a teen-ager and young man, Mr. Giuliani greatly admired John F. and Robert F. Kennedy. He worked for the Democratic Party on Long Island, where his family moved from Brooklyn when he was 7, and was a registered Democrat for years.
One of his oldest friends, Peter J. Powers, who is now Mr. Giuliani's campaign manager, said the young Giuliani was a passionate Democrat. The men first met at Bishop Loughlin Memorial High School, an all-boys Catholic school in Brooklyn.
They also attended Manhattan College in the Bronx and law school at New York University together. After law school, during the Vietnam War, Mr. Giuliani went on to become a clerk for a Federal judge and received a military deferment.
''We always talked about politics,'' Mr. Powers said. ''He was a liberal Democrat, and I was a conservative Republican. Man, would we fight. People used to pass us and ask, 'How can you guys be friends after you argue like that?' ''
''It was never personal,'' he added. ''We just had a difference of opinion. I'm a little bit more moderate. We both moved a little bit. We're a lot closer now than we were then. I guess we had an influence on each other.''
Mr. Giuliani was enrolled as a Democrat until 1973, when he became an independent partly out of disappointment with the direction of the party under George S. McGovern the year before. He joined the Republican Party in 1980. At the Age of 3, A Lesson About Life Mr. Giuliani has a bit of a temper. As United States Attorney, he was known to be a demanding boss who was not relucant about showing his displeasure.
''If somebody makes a mistake, it never gets me angry,'' he said. ''It only gets me angry if it's a purposeful mistake, meaning somebody who could have done better and didn't or keeps making the same mistake over and over again.''
''I get angry at myself,'' Mr. Giuliani sighed, ''particularly the second time. I try to demand good performance out of myself, although not perfection. I know you make mistakes''
Rudolph William Giuliani was born in 1944 in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, the only child of Helen and Harold Giuliani, who owned a bar in the neighborhood.
When Mr. Giuliani was about 3 years old, his father, a dedicated Yankees fan, bought his son a Yankees uniform and cap. Mr. Giuliani's mother dressed him in the uniform and sent him out to play in Flatbush. He was pounced on by a group of boys almost immediately. They were Dodger fans.
''They took the hat and threw it in the mud,'' Mr. Giuliani recalled. ''They threw me in the mud, too, and probably whacked me around a little bit. I ran upstairs and either my mother or father said, 'Well, now you're going to be a Yankee fan.' ''
''So,'' he continued, ''I kept wearing that Yankee uniform, and I kept getting thrown in the mud.''
He is still a Yankee fan.

HEADLINE: To Woo Soviet Jews to Israel, A $2 Billion Drive Is Mounted

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Nov. 2

 BODY:
The Jewish Agency announced a campaign today to raise $2 billion by 1993 to help attract Soviet Jews to Israel and absorb them into society with new housing, education and job training programs.
Much of the money is expected to come from the United States. But agency officials sidestepped questions on whether any of the new housing would be built in the occupied West Bank. 
Representatives of the agency's board of trustees said the Israeli Government would supply $1.5 billion of the total aid, though the Government is expected to appeal to the United States Government for assistance with its portion of the budget. The $500 million remaining is to be solicited from American Jews through special fund-raising campaigns.
The Jewish Agency is a large, quasi-government organization that serves as a liaison between Israel and the rest of the world's Jews. Agency officials, like others in the Government, expect 100,000 Soviet Jews to come to Israel in the next three years.
 
U.S. Is Still Favored
Immigration figures reached an all-time high in October, when 1,400 Soviet Jews moved to Israel. But they were among more than 9,000 Jews who left the Soviet Union, most of whom immigrated to the United States.
Soviet Jews are expected to continue favoring the United States over Israel, which they perceive as beset with economic and political problems. But Israeli officials, including Finance Minister Shimon Peres, believe that a surge in the construction industry tied to building new homes for Soviet Jews will help revive a lagging economy.
Agency officials said they would spend $1 billion to build 25,000 new housing units and refurbish 5,000 existing homes for Soviet Jews in the next three years. They said some of that is expected to come from United States foreign aid for housing.
A recent call by Housing Minister David Levy to build for Soviet Jews in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip was censured by American officials and Israeli leftists. The United States stipulates that foreign aid to Israel not be used in the occupied territories.

HEADLINE: Soviets Faulted on Regional Conflicts

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2

 BODY:
A senior Defense Department official complained today that the Soviet Union was continuing to fuel regional conflicts, offering a more pointed critique of Soviet conduct than Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d has in recent speeches.
Today's speech by Paul Wolfowitz, Under Secretary of Defense for policy, came two days after President Bush announced he would meet next month with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, and seemed to continue a public debate among senior Administration officials over Soviet policy.
In the weeks immediately preceding previous summit meetings, American officials have often muted their differences and tried to present a unified front. But the speech by Mr. Wolfowitz was markedly different in tone and emphasis from Mr. Baker's remarks, although the Administration said that the Wolfowitz text had been reviewed and was generally consistent with its views. 
''Amidst all of the 'new thinking' in the Soviet Union, there's a lot of 'old policy' on regional conflicts,'' Mr. Wolfowitz said at a conference in Pittsburgh sponsored by the University of Pittsburgh and the Chautauqua Institution. The conferences, which began in 1985 and include ranking American and Soviet officials, have become a barometer of American-Soviet relations.
''The Soviet Union and its allies continue to supply large amounts of sophisticated military equipment to countries like North Korea, Nicaragua and Libya, which threaten their neighbors and support international terrorism,'' he added.
 
An Accusatory Tone
The basic theme of Mr. Wolfowitz's address - that unless the superpowers made progress in defusing regional conflicts, recent gains in Soviet-American relations would be jeopardized -was consistent with points made by Mr. Baker and other Administration officials.
But the emphasis and tone of the speech was more accusatory, reflecting the Pentagon's continuing efforts to depict Moscow as a source of potential trouble. Similar expressions of skepticism about Soviet intentions have been expressed by Vice President Dan Quayle, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger and the deputy national security adviser, Robert M. Gates.
Just last week Administration officials said that Mr. Baker prevented Mr. Gates from delivering a speech because it was deemed to be too pessimistic about Mr. Gorbachev.
The speech by Mr. Wolfowitz stirred special interest because it was the first policy pronouncement by a senior Administration official since the announcement of the December summit meeting. The speech itself fits a pattern in which the State Department, notably Mr. Baker, has generally underscored opportunities for achieving mutually advantageous agreements with the Russians, while the Defense Department raises doubts about Moscow's current policies.
The more wary Pentagon assessment appears to reflect greater suspicion of Mr. Gorbachev as well as concern about evaporating support in the Congress for military spending.
In discussing regional conflicts, Mr. Wolfowitz said that the superpowers' rivalry was not the main cause of regional conflicts, an important distinction from the early Reagan Administration years when President Ronald Reagan blamed Moscow for most of the trouble in the world.
 
Economic Development Cited
''To dampen regional conflict, we must ultimately deal with their causes, most importantly through efforts to promote economic and political development,'' Mr. Wolfowitz said.
But drawing an analogy with the worsening of American-Soviet relations in the 1970's as a result of regional disputes, Mr. Wolfowitz cautioned that the current improvement in relations could be ''again buried in the quicksand of regional conflicts'' unless the superpowers acted to prevent this.
While praising the withdrawal of Soviet troops from Afghanistan among other developments, Mr. Wolfowitz complained in strong terms about Soviet military aid to Afghanistan, Soviet-bloc aid to Nicaragua and Moscow's sale of arms to North Korea.
''Does the withdrawal of troops from Afghanistan and other countries reflect a recognition that the peoples of these countries are entitled to Governments of their own choosing?'' Mr. Wolfowitz asked. ''Or does it simply reflect a decision to pursue the same ends by different, less costly, and less controversial means? Unfortunately, today the weight of evidence still appears to support the latter conclusion.''
Secretary Baker also criticized Moscow for shipping arms to Afghanistan, Ethiopia and Cambodia in his Oct. 16 address in New York. But the tone of the complaints was more muted.
Surveying world trouble spots, Mr. Wolfowitz said that Moscow was sending more than $250 million in military aid a month to the Afghan Government.
Mr. Wolfowitz also complained that Moscow had recently shipped advanced fighter planes, surface to air missiles and radars to North Korea.
''There are disturbing signs that North Korea may be in the process of developing a nuclear weapons capability, raising even more questions about the purpose of Soviet military support to this irresponsible Government,'' he said.

HEADLINE: Mr. Ortega's War

 BODY:
Whatever Daniel Ortega's intention, the Nicaraguan President's renunciation of a cease-fire with contra rebels has confounded hopes for free elections and an end to his nation's interminable war. He has left room for retreat, and could yet reverse himself. For now, the Sandinista leader needs to reckon the costs of throwing a grenade into a promising, arduously wrought regional peace plan. 
Dooming the cease-fire won't revive a majority in Washington for a failed and divisive policy of military aid to contras. Mr. Ortega knows that. But if Managua dishonors its pledges for a credible election on Feb. 25, the reaction will be strong and just: Nicaragua's neighbors will further isolate the Sandinista Government. European credits, so critical to Nicaragua's battered economy, will dry up. And Washington will press Moscow very hard not only to cut back its support for the Sandinistas but also to lean on Soviet allies to do the same.
To the world and his own people, Mr. Ortega argues that he is merely responding to contra violations of the cease-fire. Indeed, there have been cease-fire violations and killings, but by both sides. The contras have balked at disbanding their camps in Honduras, as required by the regional peace plan, but the Sandinistas have also balked at direct talks with rebels on truce violations.
Mr. Ortega had a chance to make his case, soberly and on the merits, at a regional summit meeting in Costa Rica last week. He could have tried to mobilize diplomatic pressure to overcome Washington's foot-dragging on demobilizing the contras, and U.S. indifference to rebel reinfiltration into Nicaragua. Instead, he redeclared war and raised serious doubts about whether he's ready to risk free and fair elections.
It is not a waning insurgency that appears to be Mr. Ortega's real target, but a swelling United Opposition Union. This is evident in police harassment of opposition rallies, and in Mr. Ortega's efforts to tar the union as a contra front ''manufactured, bought and paid by the United States.'' The rebuke rings hollow from a regime whose huge army is equipped by the Soviet Union and Cuba.
The White House rightly describes Mr. Ortega's decision as an ''affront.'' It affronts first of all Central American leaders who hammered together a peace plan with no help from the Reagan Administration. It affronts Europeans like Felipe Gonzalez of Spain, who pleaded for a democratic outcome in Nicaragua. It also embarrasses Mikhail Gorbachev, who has encouraged riskier democratic experiments in Eastern Europe.
And finally, it undermines Secretary of State Baker, who in March brokered a bipartisan compromise for phasing out all U.S. aid to the rebels in return for Managua's commitment to free elections. Mr. Ortega has reason to think again before he deepens Nicaragua's isolation and further impoverishes his people.

HEADLINE: Japan Buys the Center of New York

 BODY:
Japan's Sony Corporation bought Columbia Pictures last month. Now Mitsubishi is paying $846 million for 51 percent of the Rockefeller Group, owner of Rockefeller Center, the vibrant Art Deco cluster of 19 buildings in the heart of New York City. Is the transfer of American assets to Japanese ownership something to worry about? 
In an immediate and practical sense, the answer is no. Foreign investment is a mark of confidence in the U.S. economy. British and Dutch investors have accumulated large American holdings without causing great anxiety. It would be xenophobic, even racist, to single out Japan because of the size of its American holdings, which, though growing fast, are still half the size of Britain's.
It's also hard to object to specific sales like that of Rockefeller Center. Its owner is happy to have found a buyer. And the sale will bolster New York's commercial real estate market.
So why worry? Even if the concern is mainly over symbols, many people are puzzled that the centerpiece of America's most renowned metropolis is about to pass into foreign ownership. The leading American corporations that have offices in Rockefeller Center - NBC, Time Warner and Morgan Stanley - will now have a Japanese landlord. What's happened? Japan's trade surpluses with the United States have persisted at about $50 billion a year. These dollars eventually come back to America, and one form in which they have done so has been a wave of Japanese investment in real estate. Japanese companies already own 30 percent of downtown Los Angeles and much of Honolulu.
The sale of Rockefeller Center is not exceptional in itself. But as a conspicuous symbol of Japanese investment, it is a sharp reminder of Japan's growing economic strength. The purchase of some of America's best-known assets by its leading economic competitor is thus a double medicine. It's beneficial both as an investment - and as a warning of the greater efficiency of Japan's economy.

HEADLINE: What the Mayoral Candidates Aren't Saying

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Both David N. Dinkins and Rudolph W. Giuliani have deceived the public by not discussing in depth the view held by many economists and business people that New York City faces long-term economic problems far more serious than those of 1975.
It is evident that there is a diminishing number of middle-class people in all but one borough, Staten Island. It is also clear that the city will continue to lose revenue from public and private taxpayers as it tries to cope with homelessness, drugs, inferior education, insufficient housing and other problems that require far more money than the city can provide, even with state and Federal revenues. 
New York City is not alone in this situation, which is faced by almost every other older, large American city. Why aren't the mayoral candidates discussing it? Where will Mr. Dinkins get the billions needed to fight crime and drugs, hold business in a city with the highest expenses in the country, improve an education system that has been handing diplomas to semiliterates for more than a decade and restore the people's confidence? Mr. Dinkins talks about sending ''educational SWAT teams'' into failing high schools, but what they are is anyone's guess.
Nor has Mr. Giuliani spent campaign time making voters aware of the seriousness of our economic picture. It's long past time that these politicians spoke the 1989 equivalent of Winston Churchill's ''I have nothing to offer but blood, sweat, toil and tears.'' Churchill raised his countrymen's spirit in 1940, but was truthful about the effort involved to bring victory.
In contrast, Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Dinkins offer the people only platitudes. They have done and said nothing to make me believe they are capable of guiding this city toward the next century.
 
STEPHEN WAGNER
 Staten Island, Oct. 21, 1989

HEADLINE: IN THE NATION;
Drama in Virginia

BYLINE: By Tom Wicker

DATELINE: WILLIAMSBURG, Va.

 BODY:
He's a moderate Democrat believed to be running ahead of a conservative Republican opponent who has relied heavily on ''negative'' advertising.
He boasts far more experience in elective office than his adversary and he has been aided by his pro-choice stand on the emotional abortion issue.
He would be the first African-American to hold the major post he seeks, but he has neither made nor suffered overt racial appeals.
Like David Dinkins, the Democratic candidate for mayor of New York, moreover, if L. Douglas Wilder is elected governor of Virginia it will be mostly because he is not a black radical but a middle-of-the-road politician whose views are more conventional than alarming. 
Not that Mr. Wilder can't turn on the voters when the spirit moves him. Following his white Republican opponent, J. Marshall Coleman, to the podium of the state N.A.A.C.P. convention here recently, Mr. Wilder deftly seized a natural advantage.
''I remember the fight to make [Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday] a holiday,'' he declared, his voice rising. ''I remember who signed that bill and I remember who vetoed it. I remember whose Administration vetoed it!''
Thunderous applause signaled that his audience remembered too: Democratic Governor, now Senator, Charles Robb signed a King holiday bill after Republican Governor John Dalton had vetoed an earlier one with the concurrence of his Attorney General - J. Marshall Coleman.
Mr. Wilder also won a standing ovation for his apt phrasing of the abortion issue to garner the broadest support:
''Government has no right to interfere in the most personal decisions its citizens make. Virginians want a governor they can trust and a governor who will trust them . . . and I trust the women of Virginia to make the right decisions for themselves.''
To the Women's Political Caucus of Norfolk, Mr. Wilder made mocking reference to the racial undercurrent - how strong it is no one claims to know - that many believe will affect the voting in a state that once was a stronghold of segregation.
''People come up to me and say, 'Let's get serious. Is Virginia really going to do this thing?' ''
To which, he said, he liked to reply with a story about ''a little old lady'' who did not quite hear a question about her support for him when he ran for lieutenant governor in 1985.
''Only a heartbeat what?'' she asked.
When it was explained that he would be ''only a heartbeat'' from the governor's office, she replied: ''That's one reason I'll vote for him.''
For the most part, Mr. Wilder is stressing his 20 years of experience as a State Senator and Lieutenant Governor. Meeting with editors and reporters of The Lynchburg News and Daily Advocate (under a bust of Carter Glass, once a conservative Democratic power in the U.S. Senate), Mr. Wilder roamed knowledgeably for 90 minutes over a variety of questions about Virginia's prospects and problems - including such local matters as a hotly disputed highway bypass around Charlottesville that would speed trucking access to Lynchburg.
Mr. Wilder regularly promises to continue the resurgence of the Virginia economy, which he attributes to Democratic Governors Robb and Gerald Baliles. In per capita income, he points out at every stop, the state has risen since 1980 from 26th in the nation to ninth, and ranks first in ''per capita job creation'' - creating 300,000 new jobs between 1986 and 1987, with the unemployment rate now at only 3 percent.
It was ostensibly these economic gains to which he referred, but racial reference seemed unmistakable when he pledged to the N.A.A.C.P.: ''I am committed to building upon Virginia's historic gains.'' And one of his most frequently repeated themes -potent racially as well as economically - is that ''this election comes down to one simple fact: in the last eight years, the people of Virginia have come too far to want to turn back now!''
Undoubtedly they have economically, and maybe they have racially. As the last campaign week began, a Washington Post poll gave Mr. Wilder a lead of 52 to 37. Some Virginians think that's overoptimistic, but the chances are good that Doug Wilder was speaking of more than the elderly when he said at the Beth Sholem Home in Norfolk, ''I've been there for you and I know on Nov. 7 you'll be there for me.''

HEADLINE: Housing Plan Dominates Yonkers Race

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: YONKERS, Nov. 2

 BODY:
One year after Yonkers was almost bankrupted by contempt fines when four City Councilmen refused to comply with a housing desegregation plan, the entire seven-member Council is up for election in a vote widely seen as a referendum on the plan.
Neighborhood groups have lined up behind two slates of candidates who are defined less by parties than by their stands on the housing issue: whether to dig in and continue to resist, or build the court-ordered housing and move on.
Legally, the battle is all but over. The United States Supreme Court has upheld a Federal judge's 1985 finding that Yonkers discriminated against blacks by confining public housing to one side of the city. Next spring, construction is to start on public housing on the city's mainly white east side. 
But those who fought the housing plan last year and now seek election again vow to pursue new legal appeals.
 
Picking Sides
''The hard-working employee who buys a house is being trampled by an unfair judge,'' said Henry Spallone, who is the most outspoken Councilman opposing the housing plan, and who now is running for Mayor. ''The question of individual right is being trampled.''
The election has drawn all segments of this city of 194,000 into the controversy. From the mainly black, urban southwest to the mainly white, suburban east side, posters are appearing in living-room windows and homes are buzzing with small gatherings to hear candidates' views.
''We've been put on notice that we can't afford to neglect local legislators,'' said Gene A. Capello, who is supporting the re-election campaign of Mayor Nicholas C. Wasicsko, who has urged Yonkers to comply with the housing order.
Keith Hoover, an illustrator who is president of the Park Hill Residents' Association, whose members individually support compliance, said, ''People see that it's time to make a choice. They are starting to grasp all the lost opportunities and forfeited programs due to the City Council's obsession with fighting the housing.'' Two summers ago, when the Council resisted the housing order, a Federal judge imposed fines that doubled daily. When the fines reached $1 million a day, the Council reversed its position.
Both sides say the contest for control of the Council is close.
Leading the charge for Mr. Spallone is the Save Yonkers Federation, an umbrella organization of 43 neighborhood associations. It contends that the 200 units of low-income housing ordered by the court would pull down property values and bring crime and drugs.
Additional support has come from Local 456 of the Teamsters Union, which represents city sanitation workers and custodians.
 
'Bankruptcy Is Better'
A bumper sticker popular during last year's financial crisis has reappeared: ''Bankruptcy is better.''
On the other side, several neighborhood groups have joined to oppose Mr. Spallone. And the Yonkers Federation of Teachers - worried that a Spallone mayoralty would harm fragile, but so far successful, voluntary school desegregation - has sent out 70,000 letters and fliers and made 30,000 calls on behalf of Mayor Wasicsko.
In southwest Yonkers, several black congregations have heard sermons about the significance of the election.
''In the past,'' said the Rev. Luther A. Evans, pastor of Community Memorial Baptist Church and president of the Ministerial Fellowship, a group of 12 black churches, ''I have steered away from making any open comments about politics, but I cannot continue to do so now. You have to have a mayor who would at least uphold the law. Mr. Spallone is a lawless person, and he would make Yonkers a lawless city.''
 
Power Is in Council Majority
The contest between Mr. Spallone and Mr. Wasiscko is mostly symbolic, for Yonkers has a weak-mayor form of government. The mayor is a member of the City Council but has little more power than the other members.
Power lies in a Council majority, as Yonkers saw last year when Mr. Spallone, then a Democrat, and three Republicans defied the desegregation plan and cast the city into financial crisis. Mr. Spallone switched his party affiliation earlier this year, avoiding a primary contest with Mr. Wasicsko.
''We need four or more anti-housing councilmen who are going to put forward our feelings at every possible turn and legally fight the remedy,'' said Jack O'Toole, president of the Save Yonkers Federation. ''We need Mr. Spallone to the extent that we need four votes our way on the Council.''
 
Closely Watched Fifth District
The most closely watched race is in the Fifth District, which is in east central Yonkers and includes both expensive and working-class neighborhoods. A strong housing opponent and eight-term Republican Councilman, Nicholas V. Longo, lost the Fifth District primary to Thomas A. Dickerson, who favors complying with the housing plan. Mr. Longo's support came almost entirely from the working-class neighborhoods, and Mr. Dickerson's from the wealthy neighborhoods.
Now Mr. Longo is running on the Conservative line, while George Oswald, who is believed to oppose the plan, is running as a Democrat.
In the First District, which includes the southwest corner of Yonkers and most of the city's minority neighborhoods, the Democrat, Joe L. Farmer, who supports compliance, faces Ronald S. Jones, a Republican who opposes the housing plan.
In the Second District, which is southcentral Yonkers and includes integrated working- and middle-class neighborhoods, the Democrat, Ed Cousens, who wants the housing built, is running against Councilman Peter Chema, who defied the desegregation order.
 
Dominate Issue
In the Third District, which is northwest Yonkers and includes integrated middle-class neighborhoods, Barbara C. Cola, the widow of Charles Cola, a Ccouncilman who voted to bring the city into compliance, is running as a Democrat against John D. Spencer. Mr. Spencer has taken a stronger position in support of compliance.
Mr. Spallone's bid for mayor vacated the Council seat in the Fourth District, where Elliot Palais, a Democrat, is running against Salvatore Sialiano, a Republican. Neither favors the low-cost housing, but advocates of compliance generally support Mr. Palais, believing he is closer to their position. The Fourth District is southeast Yonkers and includes modest neighborhoods where opposition to the court-ordered housing is the strongest.
In the Sixth District, which is northeast Yonkers and includes middle- and upper-middle-class neighborhoods, the candidates take opposite stands. The Republican incumbent, Edward J. Fagan Jr., who defied the court order, is opposed by Ralph Ferraioli, who supports the housing plan.
Mayor Wasicsko said he had hoped that the housing issue would not obscure other problems facing Yonkers, like crime, drugs and economic development. But his opponent's stand has made broader discussion impossible, he said.
''All the problems that an aging city has, we have,'' he said, ''and for the last two years they've been festering while we've been tilting at windmills.''

HEADLINE: 2% Cut in Agencies' Budgets Is Ordered by Cuomo Administration

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK

DATELINE: ALBANY, Nov. 2

 BODY:
The Cuomo administration ordered a 2 percent cut in the operating budgets of state agencies today, saying the reduction was needed because the state had overestimated tax revenue and faced a potential deficit of almost $300 million this year.
The State Budget Director, Dall W. Forsythe, told fiscal officers of the agencies that it was up to them and their commissioners to decide where reductions would be made. The directive came as the state budget office issued its assessment of the state's finances at the midpoint of the fiscal year.
Last year the state was also forced into a major midyear correction after conceding that original revenue estimates had been too optimistic. But the gap cited this year, $277 million, was far below the $2 billion deficit the state announced last November, when it imposed a temporary hiring freeze and announced delays in signing major contracts. 
The cuts, which will also apply to the State University and City University systems, are intended to pare about $135 million from state spending. The rest of the gap, budget officials said, might be closed through reductions in payments to local governments, which would require approval by the State Legislature when it meets here in January.
In saying that the state's budget situation was manageable, Mr. Forsythe conceded that his projections were based on the assumption of an upturn, similar to the one that occurred at the end of last year, in key revenues between now and the end of March, when the fiscal year ends. The Budget Director called this expectation ''reasonable,'' but said that if it did not materialize, the state's fiscal picture could be far worse than what is projected.
Several commissioners and other officials said the spending reductions, while seemingly small compared with steps they were asked to take last year, were nevertheless painful because they would come from budgets already trimmed at the request of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. The Governor repeatedly called for ''austerity'' and ''discipline'' last spring as the $47 billion budget was being prepared.
No agency appeared this afternoon to have drawn up specific plans for cuts, although several officials said they believed they would be able to avoid layoffs.
Among the options said to be under consideration are hiring freezes, elimination of some low-priority programs, maintenance deferrals and reductions in travel.
Mr. Forsythe's report also indicated that the state might consider further reductions in the contributions it makes to the state employee pension plan, a money-saving measure it employed earlier this year.
That possibility drew an angry reaction from State Comptroller Edward V. Regan, the custodian of the plan, who said its long-term security ''cannot be jeopardized by the State Budget Division using these pensions as an annual budget-balancing tool.''
 
Faulty Assumptions
Last year's shortfall was attributed largely to faulty assumptions about the effects of Federal tax revisions, as well as the effects of the plunge in the stock market in October 1987. This year, Mr. Forsythe cited lower than expected revenues from corporate, sales and real-estate taxes, and a general slowdown in the Northeast economy.
Whatever the cause, some officials said it was disturbing that a shortfall had occurred again. ''With all the problems last year, it doesn't seem sensible to have chosen economic assumptions that were so optimistic,'' said Cynthia B. Green, senior analyst with the Citizens Budget Commission, a private watchdog group. ''You'd think they would have wanted to err on the other side.''
If there is no significant improvement in the state's fiscal health, it is widely expected that Governor Cuomo will use that picture to bolster his case for deferring a planned $400 million tax cut next year.
The State Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, however, repeated his strong support for the tax cut today and said a deferral should not be prompted by judgments about the state's economy made ''without complete data in hand.''

HEADLINE: In Westchester, 2 Moderates Battle for Top County Post

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 2

 BODY:
In the race for Westchester County executive, voters will choose between two moderate candidates who diverge dramatically in their assessment of Westchester and their approach to government.
The two-term Republican incumbent, 56-year-old Andrew P. O'Rourke, known for his warmth and wit, sees Westchester as a premier place to live, with unparalleled services. There are problems, to be sure, he acknowledges, but under his direction the county has addressed them at an appropriate clip, he maintains.
''On the big social-fabric issues, we are evolutionary, not revolutionary,''
Mr. O'Rourke said. ''One of the drawbacks of democracy is that things take a long time.'' 
 
Threats to County Stressed
His challenger, Richard Brodsky, 43, a four-term State Assemblyman and Westchester native, also likes the county, but says he sees threats to its quality of life. He cites problems ranging from rising property taxes to a lack of affordable housing.
The lawmaker, described by some colleagues in Albany as intelligent and creative but also a bit abrasive and impatient, says he would confront the county's problems with a greater sense of urgency.
''In bureaucracies of this size, we must seize them and shake them up,'' said Mr. Brodsky, who prefers to characterize his style as ''tenacious.''
''If you've seen his campaign literature,'' Mr. Brodsky said of Mr. O'Rourke, ''it's yellow and blue, with big smiles and the American flag. Ours is black and white, with energy and solutions - and the American flag.''
Only one Democrat has held the county executive post since it was created in the 1930's. Mr. Brodsky's initiation into county politics in the mid-1970's was as legal counsel to that man, Alfred B. Del Bello, who went on to become Lieutenant Governor from 1983 to 1985.
 
More Democrats Registered
Nonetheless, Westchester's reputation as a Republican stonghold is slipping. In 1985, Democrats pulled ahead of Republicans in registered voters for the first time, according to the Board of Elections. This year there are 163,250 registered Democrats, 152,447 Republicans and 101,568 unaffiliated voters.
Over the last 20 years Westchester, one of the wealthiest counties in the nation, has gone from a New York City bedroom community to a corporate showcase. But with that growth has come soaring housing costs and rising problems in traffic, solid-waste disposal and drug abuse.
The county government has expanded along with its responsibilities. Presiding over 10,000 employees and an annual budget edging toward $1 billion, Mr. O'Rourke points to several accomplishments:
He has helped people get off welfare with a program requiring them to work and has spurred housing for low-income and homeless people through public-private partnerships. He has saved open space by buying tracts of land, fostered recycling programs, begun drug-education classes countywide and raised awareness about AIDS and Lyme disease. His balanced budgets, coupled with a $130 million surplus, have given Westchester a triple-A bond rating.
 
Curb on Taxes Proposed
But Mr. Brodsky faults him for a 79 percent increase in county property taxes since 1983 and has proposed limiting future increases to no more than the rate of inflation for the non-mandated portion of the budget. He has also proposed $12 million in cuts from next year's budget, including layoffs for county workers.
Mr. Brodsky criticizes Mr. O'Rourke for blaming the state and Federal Government for his inability to solve the county's crisis with homeless people. Aside from New York City, Westchester has the largest population of homeless people in the state. Barred by state law from building permanent housing, the county will spend $64 million this year to shelter more than 4,000 homeless people in motels.
Mr. Brodsky insists that state law prevents county governments only from issuing bonds to create housing. He says he would use tax dollars to build and rehabilitate apartments.
The State Comptroller's office, however, says counties are prohibited from engaging in any housing activity, other than making contributions to services like sewer and water lines. An amendment to the State Constitution that would give counties the power to build housing has been introduced in the Legislature and received initial approval.
Mr. Brodsky, a fervent advocate of abortion rights, has also criticized Mr. O'Rourke for his stand on this issue. Mr. O'Rourke has said he is personally against abortion but supports a woman's legal right to one.
 
Contrasting Personalities
In Albany Mr. Brodsky has led the fight for tougher ethics laws, the barring of alcohol in certain sections of public stadiums and the routing of low-cost energy to industries in southeastern New York. The Greenburgh resident is a graduate of Ardsley High School, Brandeis University and Harvard Law School.
''Richard is extraordinarily bright,'' said Suzi Oppenheimer, a Democratic State Senator from New Rochelle. ''He has a creative intellect that often makes him appear impatient and abrupt, because he's always a few steps ahead of everyone else.''
Mr. O'Rourke grew up in Hell's Kitchen on the West Side of Manhattan. His mother was blind and on welfare; after school he delivered fish and worked as an usher. He attended Fordham University on a scholarship, receiving a Bachelor of Science degree and a law degree, and then went to New York University, where he earned a master's degree in law. He lives in Yonkers.

HEADLINE: Pop/Jazz;
9 Days and Nights of the Blues

BYLINE: By PETER KEEPNEWS

 BODY:
THE blues is a hot property again.
Persuasive evidence that the country is in the midst of another blues revival can be heard for nine days starting tomorrow night at 8, when the second annual Benson & Hedges Blues festival begins at the Beacon Theater.
The focal point of the festival will be the Beacon, which will play host to concerts tonight and next Friday and Saturday. One dollar from the sale of each ticket is to be donated to Emmaus House, a privately run shelter in Harlem for the homeless.
On Sunday and through next week, there will also be free showcases for traditional and acoustic blues and workshops and symposiums about the blues. The first event is to take place on Sunday at the Henry Street Arts for Living Center. ''The Legacy of the Blues'' is to present R. L. Burnside, a 62-year-old guitarist who is one of the last practitioners of the authentic Mississippi Delta style, and Bill Neely, a Texas guitarist in his early 70's who was one of the first white musicians to play the blues. The blues scholars and film makers John Allison and Alan Govenar are to provide commentary. 
In addition, five Manhattan clubs that regularly feature the blues - Brother's Bar-B-Que, Delta 88, the Lone Star Roadhouse, Tramps and Under Acme - will join forces on Monday in what is being billed as a ''Blue Monday Blues Bash.'' (What this means is simply that all five will be presenting blues acts under the aegis of the festival, although the organizers are hoping that some kind of multi-venue jam session will take place.) The Lone Star Roadhouse will also offer blues shows on Tuesday and Wednesday nights.
''The blues is more popular than it has ever been as far as I'm concerned,'' said Willie Dixon, the 74-year-old songwriter and singer who is an architect of electrified Chicago blues. ''People have beome wiser about it - wise that blues is the roots.'' Mr. Dixon is to perform on Nov. 10 at the Beacon Theater.
Last year, Benson & Hedges Blues lasted six days, and smaller versions of the event were held in St. Louis and Atlanta. This year, the schedule has been expanded, and George Wein, whose Festival Productions stages this event and the JVC Jazz Festival, said similar blues packages would be presented in St. Louis, Atlanta and Dallas and possibly in Chicago and Los Angeles.
What's behind the latest blues revival? There are all sorts of possible explanations, most of which boil down to words like simplicity and roots. One explanation was offered by Katie Webster, a pianist and singer who is to be performing at tomorrow night's concert called ''Dynamic Blues Divas,'' with Etta James, Nell Carter and Mavis Staples.
''I think people are getting back down to basics now,'' said Miss Webster, who is 50 years old and who has been performing for three decades, but whose career had been moribund for several years until the early 1980's.
''They're realizing that even though there are various fads of music, blues and jazz and gospel will always be around,'' she said. ''Some of the songs that were hits five years ago, you don't hear anymore. You don't even hear from the artist. But you can always hear someone doing something by Muddy Waters or Albert Collins or B. B. King. They're staples in the music, and they're always going to be there.''
Many of those songs have been written by Mr. Dixon, who will be at the Beacon on Nov. 10 with Albert King, Dr. John and a jazz-oriented all-star ensemble called Blues Summit. Mr. Dixon is probably the most prolific songwriter in blues history and certainly the most successful: his compositions include ''Spoonful,'' ''The Seventh Son'' and ''Hoochie-Coochie Man.'' As a producer, arranger and house bassist at Chess Records in Chicago in the early 1950's, he helped create the electrified updating of the classic Mississippi Delta approach that was an important forerunner of rock-and-roll.
''Blues is the greatest music on the face of the earth,'' Mr. Dixon said. ''It gives the people music plus rhythm plus wisdom. It speaks the word just as it is: I love you, I don't like you. It says what's what. The words speak the truth; you don't have to guess what they mean.''
If simplicity is a key to the lasting appeal of the blues, that does not mean that the genre lacks variety, as the festival's offerings demonstrate. Tomorrow night's concert features both blues singers and singers influenced by the blues. Two singers on the bill, Miss Carter and Miss Staples, are not generally thought of as blues artists. Miss Carter's usual territory is Broadway and the cabaret world, while Miss Staples began her career as a gospel singer and is currently most often heard in a pop-soul context.
The concerts next weekend at the Beacon - the show on Nov. 11 is to feature the Fabulous Thunderbirds, Bobby Blue Bland, John Lee Hooker and the team of Buddy Guy and Junior Wells - will present electrified blues (although not too electrified; there will not be a synthesizer or a drum machine in sight). Meanwhile, the free showcases will look to older rural blues.
''I would like to get people interested in not only the electric blues, but also the acoustic blues, which is still alive in Mississippi,'' said the blues scholar Mr. Allison, who was introduced to the music at an early age by his father, the singer and pianist Mose Allison, who grew up in Mississippi. The son, who is working on a film about the current Mississippi blues scene, said many of the more traditional performers still ''don't have much of an income at all.''
 
Black and White
On the other hand, many of the music's surviving giants are making a better living now than they ever have, and many young musicians who just a few years ago might not have even considered a career in the blues are doing extremely well by it. Quite a few of those younger artists are white, a phenomenon that is accepted if not always welcome by such veterans as Mr. Dixon, who said: ''A lot of white people can sing and play real well, but a lot of them don't have all the qualifications. It's hard to deliver if you haven't lived the life.''
While the music remains fundamentally black, its current audience is overwhelmingly white. Miss Webster estimated that her typical audience is 80 percent white, although she added, ''I don't think black people are getting away from the blues; they're just taking a recess from it.''
This year's festival will not include any shows at the Apollo Theater; the Benson & Hedges Blues concert held there last year ''just didn't go,'' Mr. Wein said. ''The economics of the black community are such that young blacks are not supporting this kind of concert,'' he said.
But to take the blues to black listeners, the festival is to feature free concerts at two Harlem auditoriums: one by Jessie Mae Hemphill on Tuesday night at the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture and one by Sunnyland Slim on Wednesday night at the Studio Museum in Harlem.
 
Where the Blues Are Going to Be
Benson & Hedges Blues, a nine-day festival, will feature performances and film screenings, some free, around New York City. Festival information: 787-2020. For more information, call the clubs. Here is a schedule of events.

HEADLINE: Review/Film;
Private Detectives and Public Peculiarities

BYLINE: By JANET MASLIN

 BODY:
The dark cloud that is ''Second Sight'' has a silver lining, at least for the economy-minded. Both John Larroquette (star of television's ''Night Court'') and Bronson Pinchot (''Perfect Strangers'') are much, much funnier for free.
Not even the laziest, drowsiest, most accommodating home video viewers will ever find much to laugh about in ''Second Sight.'' Mr. Pinchot, wearing a long-haired fright wig, plays a guileless nut named Bobby McGee who has been struck by lightning and turned into a psychic. Mr. Larroquette, misanthropic as ever, plays the business partner who is happy to exploit Bobby to suit the needs of their detective agency, and who's also glad to put his protege's powers to other uses. Thanks to him, Bobby supplies vital statistics about available women and functions as a remote-control television tuner. 
This could well have been funny, since Mr. Pinchot has such a genius for weird effects, and since the screenplay also throws in a parapsychologist (played by Stuart Pankin) who spouts New Age jargon. Joel Zwick's direction is so outstandingly maladroit, however, that it squelches any possible humor, which in any case is pitched dangerously low. That the psychic's seizures can be stopped by feeding him chocolate-covered peanuts may give some idea of the audience at which ''Second Sight'' is aimed.
The story, which connects these wacky detectives with the College of Cardinals, is least appetizing when it introduces Bess Armstrong as a perky, lovestruck nun. There seems to be a car chase every 15 minutes. One of the film's few interesting peculiarities is its pacing, since it demonstrates the same degree of artificial liveliness from beginning to end. Aside from the cheap blue-light special effects that are supposed to simulate an airplane's passing through the Callahan Tunnel in Boston, there's nothing in the last reel to distinguish it from the first.
''Second Sight'' is rated PG (''Parental Guidance Suggested''). It includes rude language and a couple of bathroom jokes.

HEADLINE: Business Digest

 BODY:

The Economy
Senate Republicans effectively abandoned efforts to win a capital-gains tax cut this year, giving up plans to attach the measure to a debt-limit bill. A clear victory for the Democrats, the concession is a serious setback to President Bush, who had made the tax cut a centerpiece of his election campaign. Just weeks ago, he appeared to have a victory within his grasp. [Page A1.]
Three men were indicted for running a company that New York's Attorney General says illegally transmitted about $70 million to the Dominican Republic and other countries. [D1.] 
The quality of U.S. economic reports is being undermined by budget cuts, staff reductions and the problems of gathering data, economists say. For instance, the September report on durable goods nearly missed its scheduled release. [D1.]
Nonfarm productivity increased at a 2.1 percent annual rate in the third quarter. The gain was overshadowed by data showing an anemic gain in manufacturing productivity and wage inflation. [D2.] Big retailers reported modest to good October sales. [D2.]
 
Markets
The New York Stock Exchange announced strict limits on computerized trading of stocks, which has been criticized as causing wild swings in prices. The exchange will ask brokers and institutional investors to refrain from trades that ''destabilize'' the market, reduce the use of a computerized order system when prices are falling, and in some cases make it possible for individuals' orders to be executed faster than those of institutions. [A1.] The changes could create confusion about market prices. [D6.]
A Senate committee approved legislation intended to increase Federal oversight of the futures markets and to strengthen self-regulation at the commodity exchanges. [D3.]
Weakness in computer stocks pushed down the Dow industrials. After being off about 30 points in the afternoon, the Dow climbed back to a close of 2,631.56, down 14.34. [D6.]
Prices of Treasury securities rose modestly in light trading, as dealers awaited the release of employment data. [D13.]
Gold futures settled $6 to $6.20 higher, reaching three-month highs on the Comex amid fears of a worsening outlook for equities. [D14.] The dollar finished mixed in light trading. [D14.]
 
Companies
Ford said it would buy Jaguar for nearly $2.38 billion, in a deal that reflects the eagerness of big car makers to acquire prestigious brands. G.M., which had been in talks with the British luxury car maker, said the price ''could not be justified.'' [D1.] Chrysler workers in St. Louis rejected a proposal for a four-day workweek. [D4.]
Two Knoll International executives were sued by United Technologies and Gibbons Green, who contend that financial information about Sheller-Globe was fabricated before it was sold. [D12.]
A three-month strike is beginning to hurt Nynex's bottom line, its executives and analysts say. [D1.] A.T.&T. will raise its rates for the rental of residential telephone equipment. [D4.]
Forstmann, Little is trying to raise $3 billion from institutions to invest in public companies without borrowing. [D1.]
Sears may not sell its landmark tower in Chicago after all, and is considering alternatives. A decision is expected this year. [D2.]
Integrated Resources agreed to sell several businesses to Broad for about $170 million. [D4.]
Penguin Group named Morton Mint to become chief executive of Penguin USA. But rumors were plentiful about who would get the top job at Random House. [D5.]
 
Today's Columns
Underlying Britain's political crisis is a deep, historic question: How much sovereignty should Britain be willing to sacrifice to join Europe? Leonard Silk: Economic Scene. [D2.]
Compaq is expected to introduce a bold desktop computer, but investors pummeled its stock after the company said October sales were below expectations. Market Place. [D6.]
The top creative job at Ogilvy & Mather/New York is a bit like managing the Yankees, Bill Hamilton says. Advertising. [D5.]

HEADLINE: Strike Begins to Squeeze Nynex

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
A three-month telephone strike by two unions representing 60,000 workers of the Nynex Corporation is beginning to hurt the regional Bell telephone company's bottom line, Nynex officials and telephone industry analysts say.
Nynex, the holding company that owns New York Telephone and New England Telephone and provides local telephone service to seven Northeastern states, has seen the number of telephone lines in service decline because new ones cannot be installed quickly enough. That, in turn, has taken a bite out of revenues and profits.
At the same time, large business customers have looked to competing companies for private-line telephone service, a loss of market share that some analysts say Nynex will not be able to win back soon.
 
Other Strikes Settled
Nevertheless, Nynex says it can hold out for many more months before the strike begins to have a financially devastating effect on it. 
Strikes at other regional telephone companies were settled over the summer, but analysts say that Nynex has been forced to take a harder line because it faces a more difficult operating environment. For one thing, Nynex has significantly higher operating costs than other ''Baby Bells'' because the older telephone equipment and switches in its network are expensive to maintain and because it operates in a region of aging cities and dense population that requires more labor to provide services.
In addition, Nynex is facing widespread opposition to a petition it has filed with the New York State Public Service Commission for a $360 million rate increase to offset revenues lost because it can no longer automatically charge for phone-line maintenance.
The debt-rating division of Standard & Poor's said Monday that it was considering lowering Nynex's rating because of the company's declining earnings and the likelihood that it would not receive a rate increase.
Given the length of the strike, which involves wages and medical benefits, several analysts have lowered their estimates for what the company will earn for the year. Jack Grubman, a telecommunications analyst with Paine Webber, reduced his earnings estimate to $5.85 a share, from $6, for 1989 and to $6.20, from $6.50, for 1990.
''There are serious costs associated with a strike of this nature, mostly in forgone revenues, and that tends to hurt financial results for a quarter or so,'' Mr. Grubman said.
Officials at other regional telephone companies affected by strikes last summer agreed with the analysts. The officials, who asked not to be identified, said their calculations showed that a strike of more than two months would have hurt their profits in the fourth quarter and for the year.
 
'Nobody Makes Money in a Strike'
Robert J. Eckenrode, the vice chairman of Nynex, said the strike ''is having a negative impact on revenues because we have a continuing backlog of new installations, because our focus during the strike is keeping those folks who are already in service in service.''
''In terms of the general question, 'Are we losing money in the strike?' the answer is nobody makes money in a strike,'' he said. ''While we in the short term have some expense reductions, we also have increased costs from folks doing security and overtime. Put it all together, and the strike is close to an aggregate financial neutral.''
Nynex and the unions have entered an arbitration period, but union officials close to the negotiations said the talks are going nowhere. Referring to the strike, Mr. Eckenrode said Nynex ''can run this thing for an extended period of time if we have to.''
''Quite honestly, we are struggling to get this over and the very fact that the mediation process is going forward is a positive sign,'' he said.
In the third quarter, Nynex's net income dropped 14.8 percent to $288.7 million, or $1.47 a share, from $338.9 million, or $1.72 a share, a year earlier. Revenue rose 4 percent, to $3.31 billion, from $3.18 billion, mainly from the company's acquisition of AGS Computers and growth in its nonregulated operations.
Nynex attributed the decline in earnings to higher taxes and interest costs and to fewer installations of new telephone lines because of the strike. Nynex said the number of access lines in service at the end of the third quarter was off 18,000, to 14.972 million, from the previous quarter.
Hit especially hard by the strike has been New York Telephone, where profits have been lower than expected because of the economic slowdown in the New York City area and competition from small telephone concerns that build private networks and lease lines to businesses.
 
Manhattan's Importance
Analysts have criticized Nynex for being too dependent on corporate phone customers in Manhattan. At New York Telephone, 25 percent of the revenue comes from only 1 percent of the business customers. In the face of the slowdown, large companies in the New York area have been cutting costs, and telecommunications expenditures have been high on their lists.
Nynex does not disclose earnings for each division, but its telephone operations contribute the bulk of its profits. Last year, telephone operations generated revenue of about $10.33 billion. Mr. Eckenrode said that regulated telephone services account for about 85 percent of Nynex's revenue and that New York Telephone represents two-thirds of that.
''The biggest danger coming out of the strike is that business customers are saying that they no longer want to subject themselves to the risk of relying on Nynex for service and they are looking at 'bypass' vendors,'' said Joel Gross, an analyst with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. ''The Teleports of the world are going to get even more business, and it's not because they are cheaper but because businesses want some insurance.''
Teleport, a company that runs a satellite and fiber-optic communications center on Staten Island that links business centers in New York and New Jersey, sends and receives vast amounts of data used by banks, brokerage houses and other information-intensive businesses over its private network. Teleport serves about 120 buildings in the New York area.
Robert Atkinson, Teleport's senior vice president for regulatory and external affairs, said the company had received ''a flood of inquiries'' since the strike began from companies needing new circuits immediately.
''You lose your job as a corporate telecommunications manager if the lines go down, so the most logical strategy is to diversify your suppliers and not to put your eggs in one basket,'' Mr. Atkinson said.
In recent years, Nynex has fallen short of investors' expectations and its stock performance has been the worst of the Baby Bell issues. Nynex shares are about 22 percent higher than they were at the beginning of the year, compared with 42 percent for shares of the Bell Atlantic Corporation and 23 percent for those of U S West Inc.
Nynex shares closed at $78.875 yesterday, down 37.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Mr. Gross of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette said he considered Nynex's stock a bargain. ''People are saying that the company is not competent, the region's economy is sinking and the regulatory environment is difficult,'' he said. ''But the fundamentals of this company are not quite as bad as the attributes. And it's just a matter of time before things pick up.''
 
Reason for the Strike
The strike began Aug. 6 when talks between the company and some 60,000 members of the Communications Workers of America and the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers broke off over a proposal by management to shift some health-care costs to workers.
With the nation's telephone system highly automated, residential and business customers who dial directly have not felt any immediate effect from the strike beyond delays in reaching directory-assistance operators. Customers, however, have experienced widespread delays in obtaining repairs and new services.
During the strike by operators, installers, maintenance and clerical workers and other personnel, there have been more than 200 reports of vandalism, and local telephone service in some areas has been disrupted by vandalism. In addition, a union worker picketing in Mount Pleasant, N.Y., died in an accident involving the car of a Nynex worker.

HEADLINE: For Gatherers of U.S. Data, A Close Call Last Month

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
This is the story of a near miss in the troubled world of data gathering.
Except for some snow delays, missing a release date for an important economic report is virtually unheard of. But for several hours on Monday, Oct. 23, officials in the Commerce Department and the Census Bureau thought the September report on orders for durable goods could not be finished in time for its scheduled release on Oct. 24.
Officials said they were considering a delay because several companies had not supplied the monthly data needed to produce an accurate report. Only with repeated calls to the companies and extra hours of work into the evening were the data obtained and the report finished in time. 
 
A Fragile Process
The episode is but one example of the fragility of the process of collecting data and producing regular economic statistics. More and more economists and statisticians are criticizing the reports the Government agencies are producing because their quality is being undermined by budget cuts, staff reductions and the problems of gathering data.
Many of the figures collected are provided voluntarily, which is a growing problem because companies are more likely now to cut costs by choosing not to provide the data. Or they just may not worry as much about getting it in on time if that causes problems for them.
Adren Cooper, a Commerce Department information officer who deals with this and other economic reports, said he was worried that people do not realize how close the department sometimes comes to not getting a report out. ''I would hope if we fail to deliver that the financial markets don't go into a panic,'' he said.
Ruth Runyan, the chief of the manufacturers' shipments, inventories and orders division in the Bureau of the Census, said that the bureau would not release an economic report if it was determined that the data base was too small and that the report would be subject to a major revision in the following months. She said there had been several times during her 10 years that such a possibility was considered. But in the end, she said, no report had ever been delayed.
 
'Alternative Positions' Weighed
She said that on the morning of Oct. 23 officials ''were considering alternative positions'' because several large companies had not supplied the regular monthly data on durable goods - products like kitchen appliances and automobiles, which are expected to last three years or more. ''We didn't have it and we weren't sure we were going to have it,'' she said.
The companies, which she would not name, have always supplied the data voluntarily. She said that as of that Monday morning several large companies had not yet compiled the data themselves. But she would not say why there had been a delay.
She said the companies were not deliberately holding up the data. But she did say that ''we always have some companies who set their priorities and we will be at the lower end of it.''
Officials in the Bureau of the Census continued to press the companies for the data and finally were assured by early afternoon that the figures would be supplied in time for the September release to be prepared. The report showed a drop in orders of one-tenth of 1 percent in September, following a rise of 3.9 percent in August. A larger decline was avoided because of the second-largest increase in military orders on record.
Ms. Runyan said the bureau spends a lot of time every month calling the companies involved to remind them about the data.
She said the important lesson of the near miss is that the bureau is willing to delay a report if it feels it will not be based on sufficient data. She said she would rather take her chances on a delay than report a figure she knew would be revised significantly.

HEADLINE: 3 Are Indicted Over Money Transfers

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON

 BODY:
The Attorney General of New York said yesterday that three men had been indicted for running a company that had illegally transmitted about $70 million to the Dominican Republic and elsewhere in Latin America in more than 500,000 transactions.
The case is the second to be brought in the state against a business accused of failing to get a license to transmit money, although New York authorities have identified more than 135 such operations that lack licenses.
Most of these inner-city operations are used by recent immigrants to send money to relatives abroad. But banking authorities say that as banks become more vigilant about drug traffickers who try to deposit cash and then transfer it, these storefront businesses are being used wittingly and unwittingly to move narcotics profits to Latin America and Asia. 
In response, state prosecutors and banking regulators in New York have stepped up their efforts to prosecute the unlicensed money transmitters.
Robert Abrams, the Attorney General, said there was no evidence that the three indicted men, who ran a company with 15 branches called Dominican Dollar Express, knew they may have been laundering illegal drug profits. But he and the state banking superintendent, Jill M. Considine, said at a news conference yesterday that state regulators had been overwhelmed and lacked the manpower and tough laws to prosecute these unlicensed operations that transmit money abroad.
''We don't know what the money was from,'' Ms. Considine said. ''We cannot tell precisely what goes on at an unlicensed entity.''
Mr. Abrams added that the law regulating the transmitters ''is an absolute joke and a mockery of the law-enforcement process'' because the maximum penalty for not being licensed is a year in jail and a $500 fine. To get a license, a money transmitting operation must pass an investigation by the Banking Department and post a $500,000 bond.
 
Loan Sharking Accusation
The three men named in the indictment face a stiffer sentence, however, because they are also accused of loan sharking, for which the maximum sentence is 15 years in prison and fines of either $5,000 or double the amount illegally gained. Mr. Abrams said the defendants had used customers' deposits to make loans at 30 to 50 percent interest.
State bank regulators from around the nation have been meeting this week in Austin, Tex., to explore the growing problem of illegal money transmitters. The Senate Banking Committee chairman, Donald W. Riegle Jr., Democrat of Michigan, is also preparing legislation to regulate money transmitters.
The few cases that have been brought by state prosecutors around the nation have usually been developed by regulators who received complaints that immigrants who sent money had been defrauded. Ms. Considine said that other storefront operations were being investigated and that bank examiners had combed local ethnic newspapers for advertisements for money transmitting services. 2 Are Released on Bail Erasmo Taveras and Raul Quiroz, two of the three men indicted yesterday, pleaded not guilty before State Supreme Court Justice Brenda Soloff. They were released on $162,875 bail, the amount that had been seized from the Dominican Dollar Express headquarters at 591 West 181st Street in Manhattan.
The third man, Pedro Alegria, was said by state prosecutors to be in the Dominican Republic. Mr. Abrams said the state would contact Interpol, the international law-enforcement network, to try to have Mr. Alegria arrested and deported.
Peter Crusco, an assistant Attorney General, said Mr. Alegria had been appointed by the President of the Dominican Republic five years ago to be the country's tourism representative in New York. Mr. Crusco said Mr. Taveras and Mr. Quiroz, who live in the Bronx, had run large travel agencies in New York.
Mr. Abrams said that the men ran a loan sharking operation, called Credimatic, that lent money to small local businesses like bodegas and dry cleaners that had been unable to obtain loans from banks.
