HEADLINE: A Japanese Strategy for Boeing

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEATTLE

 BODY:
The Boeing Company, once fiercely independent and self-reliant, is turning to partnerships with the Japanese in the belief that there is no better way to preserve its position as the world's leading aircraft manufacturer. But the emerging alliance is not without a conflict: while the Japanese try to learn everything they can about making airplanes, Boeing tries to hide its most important techniques.
Until recently, the Japanese have mainly been suppliers of aircraft parts, even whole body sections, to Boeing. But now, although Boeing has made no announcement, its executives made clear in interviews that for the rest of the century the company will try to work principally in partnerships with Japanese to design and produce new aircraft.
Boeing's partnership strategy gives Japan a leg up toward its stated goal of becoming adept at manufacturing commercial airliners, a high-tech industry in which it lags far behind the United States. A Commerce Department aerospace expert, Sally Bath, speaks approvingly of Boeing's partnership approach, but others attack it as giving away aircraft technology and manufacturing prowess to the Japanese. 
 
Inherent Conflicts
The partnership has already begun at Boeing, and the conflict inherent in the uneasy alliance shows up in the daily routine. Forty Japanese engineers from three companies work alongside Americans at Boeing's design center for new aircraft. This number is likely to quintuple, Boeing says, once work starts on a new aircraft, probably the 767X, a twin-engine jetliner with 300 seats. Boeing and Japanese officials have begun talks to determine how the partnership may function for the 767X.
But the movements of the Japanese engineers here are restricted. They are not, for example, allowed inside factories, to observe Boeing's production techniques. They are kept away from wing design, an important technology. And they cannot enter the computer rooms that use special software to analyze how well a new design might stand up in flight.
''This is software that took Boeing 20 years to perfect, and the Japanese don't have access,'' James T. Johnson, a Boeing vice president, said.
The Japanese engineers are redesigning aircraft parts and taking part in wind-tunnel tests of some aircraft designs. But in meetings, when a delicate subject comes up, the Japanese are asked to leave, Mr. Johnson said. ''They are excellent engineers and aggressive,'' he explained, ''and when they ask you what you have in your notebook, you sometimes have to tell them, no, they can't see it.''
The point of all this is to keep the Japanese as subordinate partners, without enough manufacturing or marketing know-how to rival Boeing as a competitor. Boeing single-handedly accounts for 2 percent of the nation's export revenue, primarily from overseas sales of its commercial airliners. Exports brought Boeing $7.9 billion in sales last year, or 46 percent of its total.
But even as partners, the three Japanese companies - Mitsubishi Heavy Industries Ltd., Fuji Heavy Industries Ltd. and Kawasaki Heavy Industries Ltd. - could become important players in aircraft manufacturing in the 1990's. That would happen if they managed to make their partnership indispensable to Boeing, said Heather Heath, an aerospace specialist at the Harvard Business School.
''Boeing has to be concerned that it is creating a time bomb for the next generation,'' Ms. Heath said. ''The Japanese will in time acquire enough skill and make a big enough contribution to demand an ever bigger share of the partnership.''
Boeing executives recognize this danger, but say they are forced to adopt the partnership strategy anyway, not only for the 767X but also for future models. ''It is no longer realistic for us to go it alone,'' said Lawrence W. Clarkson, a Boeing senior vice president.
Two big reasons are cited. One is that airliners, like the proposed 767X, can require $4 billion to develop and then do not return a profit for a decade. Boeing says it cannot afford to risk so much money alone, and the Japanese are eager investors.
But most important, the Japanese airlines are big, essential Boeing customers, buying, for example, more 747's and 767's than airlines in other nations. As part of the bargain, they insist on being partners in the manufacture of the planes that they buy, Boeing executives say.
For years, there have been quid-pro-quo deals in the aerospace industry. To sell planes to, say, an Italian airline, Boeing and other manufacturers have agreed to buy parts from Italian companies, or engage in other exchanges. But they had stopped short of full partnership, until Japan pressed the issue.
 
Race With Airbus
''In my opinion, had the Japanese developed a partnership relation with Airbus instead of us, they would be flying Airbuses today instead of our airliners,'' Mr. Clarkson said, referring to the European aircraft manufacturing consortium.
Boeing signed its first partnership deal with the Japanese in 1986, insisting that it be limited to the three companies, although the Japanese Government had wanted others to be included. Recently, Japanese officials said they would continue with partnerships for the manufacture of large jetliners for at least a decade because the world market is not big enough for Japan to break in on its own.
For Boeing, the 1986 partnership was the biggest step in a globalization process that started in the mid-1970's. Since then, Boeing has turned increasingly to foreign suppliers for parts, and now 15 percent of some airliners come from abroad. The parts are made to Boeing's specifications, although in a few cases, parts design was done by subcontractors.
The first Boeing-Japanese partnership gave the Japanese companies a 25 percent stake in the development of the 7J7, a 150-seat aircraft with two turboprop engines. Some 115 Japanese engineers came here to help develop the plane. When Boeing suspended the 7J7 program for lack of what it considered an adequate market, the number was cut to the interim staff of 40 engineers.
Now Boeing and the three Japanese companies say they are beginning to negotiate a 767X partnership - one that would require assembly of the plane in Seattle, with many of the parts and some body sections purchased in Japan and in other countries. In fact, the Japanese would play an important role in designing the 767X's fuselage and in developing composites used in the aircraft's skin, Mr. Johnson said.
If Boeing has its way, the partnership would give the Japanese companies a 25 percent stake, just as in the 7J7 deal, and would include the numerous technology exclusion clauses in the 7J7 agreement, according to Mr. Johnson, who ran the 7J7 program, and to Roy B. Phillips, director of international programs.
''There is no question that when you collaborate with people, there is a technology transfer,'' Mr. Phillips said. ''The question is how do you do it without compromising your technology lead.''
Boeing officials expressed optimism that a contract will be signed. ''They are determined to be in the aircraft business,'' Mr. Clarkson said of the Japanese. ''But for the foreseeable future, we believe that they will be happy to do so as a partner.''
But some economists think that partnership with the Japanese will inevitably cost Boeing its leadership in commercial aircraft. Among them is Clyde T. Prestowitz, a Japan specialist at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace. He says that in place of the Japanese partnership, Boeing should turn to the Federal Government. Help may come partly in the form of altered antitrust rules that would encourage Boeing to make partnership deals with American aerospace companies.
''It is easy for me to imagine that Boeing's bargaining position vis-a-vis the Japanese will erode,'' Mr. Prestowitz said, ''and by the 21st century Japan will be producing supersonic aircraft, with Boeing as their minority partner.''
Boeing has its own defense of the partnership strategy. Its executives say Japan will not go it alone because it cannot justify the outlay for commercial aircraft manufacturing - no matter how important the industry. This approach holds that the Japanese home market for jetliners is not big enough to support aircraft manufacturing until the Japanese become efficient enough to export.

An article in Business Day on Nov. 3 about the Boeing Company's partnerships in Japan misidentified an aerospace specialist at the Harvard Business School. She is Heather Hazard.

HEADLINE: Ford to Buy Jaguar for $2.38 Billion

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Nov. 2

 BODY:
In a deal that reflects the continuing consolidation of the world auto industry and the eagerness of big car makers to acquire prestigious brands, the Ford Motor Company announced today that it plans to buy Jaguar P.L.C. for a total of nearly $2.38 billion.
The friendly deal ends several weeks of jockeying to link up with the British luxury car maker between Detroit's two largest producers, Ford and the General Motors Corporation. G.M. had been negotiating to buy a large stake in Jaguar, an option the British company's chairman, Sir John Egan, a former G.M. executive in Europe, preferred because the proposed purchase stopped short of a takeover and thus would have insured Jaguar's independence. Jaguar and G.M. had been discussing a linkup for roughly nine months.
 
Effect of British Ruling
But the British car maker's independence seemed doomed when the British Government, in keeping with its free-market leanings, declared last Tuesday that it was willing to lift a state restriction that could be used to bar another company from owning more than 15 percent of Jaguar until the end of 1990. Thus the favored car of British executives and Cabinet ministers, including Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, was all but certain to fall into foreign hands. 
The Ford-Jaguar linkup is the most significant of a handful of purchases and stake holdings in European luxury and sports-car makers by Detroit producers. Smaller moves during the past few years include G.M. linking up with Group Lotus, Ford buying 75 percent of Aston Martin Lagonda, and Chrysler picking up Maserati and Lamborghini. Until now, the targets have been mostly tiny high-performance producers.
Increased competition from the Japanese moving into the luxury-car sector, the high cost of developing new models, and a downturn in the crucial American market have made it increasingly difficult for smaller car makers like Jaguar to go it alone. Others, such as Saab-Scania A.B. and Volvo A.B., are scrambling to find big well-heeled partners. Unusual Statement by G.M. Today after the Ford offer, G.M. declined to enter the bidding and took the unusual step of publicly stating that Ford's bid price ''could not be justified.'' Ford's bid of $13.32 a share is nearly twice what Jaguar's market value was before Ford announced its intent to buy control of the company in mid-September.
Ford had $5.8 billion in cash and marketable securities as of Sept. 30. But even so, the Standard & Poor's Corporation announced today that $40 billion of Ford's long-term debt and $30 billion of its commercial paperare being evaluated for possible downgrading. S.&P. cited the Jaguar deal and the recent $3.35 billion purchase of the Associated Corporation.
Ford's offer may seem extraordinarily high for a company that made 51,939 cars last year and is now barely breaking even. But Ford executives made it clear that they were paying a premium for the Jaguar name and would invest heavily to turn the British company into a much bigger producer.
''One of our first tasks will be to discuss with Jaguar management its plans for future model development and the actions necessary to expand its manufacturing and product development resources,'' said L. Lindsey Halstead, chairman of Ford of Europe. ''Our intention would be to increase Jaguar's sales volume.''
Analysts expect Ford to invest $1 billion or more in Jaguar to double or triple its output and have it manufacture a high-volume car that would sell for $30,000 to $40,000. Ford has failed to score much of a success in either that market or the one that Jaguar is already in: luxury cars that sell for $40,000 to $60,000.
Ford tried unsuccessfully to establish a European luxury import franchise in the United States. It was called Merkur and had two models: the XR4Ti, which had a base price of $19,759, and the Scorpio, base price $28,407. Ford has just stopped selling the XR4Ti, and it announced last month that it would also stop selling the Scorpio.
At a news conference today, Sir John said G.M. had known that Jaguar expected Ford to make an offer for the company this week. But he added that Jaguar did not inform G.M. of Ford's bid, and thus did not give it a chance to top the offer before accepting it.
This afternoon, G.M. said it could not justify even trying to match Ford's bid. Ford offered 8.50 ($13.32) a share, or a total of $2.11 billion, for the 86.8 percent of Jaguar it does not own. Since Sept. 19, when Ford declared its intent to acquire control of Jaguar, it had purchased 13.2 percent of the company for $262.1 million.
G.M. said in a statement, ''After an intensive review of Jaguar's products and plants and in view of the losses currently being sustained by them, together with Jaguar's significant future cash and other requirements, G.M. concluded that the maximum value that could be assigned to all of the Jaguar shares was very significantly below the 8.50 being offered.''
G.M. added, ''The premium of approximately 1.3 billion ($2 billion) over book value at yearend 1988 could not be justified.''
Although Daimler-Benz A.G. of West Germany had been negotiating possible joint ventures with Jaguar, analysts do not expect offers from other companies. The price Ford has offered would be too high for big European car companies, and Japanese companies would be reluctant to get into a takeover battle, they said.
Sitting next to Mr. Halstead at the news conference, a subdued Sir John stressed that Ford had promised Jaguar considerable autonomy. Under the agreement Jaguar's headquarters and manufacturing operations would remain in the West Midlands section of central England, it would have its own board, and it would maintain a separate dealer network. Mr. Halstead was evasive when asked about the possibility of making Jaguar cars outside Britain; he did not rule it out, but reiterated his commitment to British production.
Even before the takeover battle erupted, it became clear that changes in the market made it impossible for a small car maker like Jaguar to go it alone, said Sir John, who has headed the company for nine years. The economies of scale and bargaining clout of a giant parent like Ford, he added, would also enable Jaguar to obtain lower prices for components.
 
Jaguar's Recent Results
Like other European makers of luxury cars, Jaguar has also been hit hard by exchange-rate problems and a downturn in the United States, its most important market. In the first half of this year, Jaguar barely broke even, and analysts expected no better performance, and possibly a loss, for the full year. Last year, Jaguar had an after-tax profit of $51.4 million on sales of $1.99 billion.
With the chance of a takeover battle between Ford and G.M. gone, Jaguar's shares fell 50 pence (78 cents) today on the London Stock Exchange and closed at 8.29 ($12.99).
In trading on the New York Stock Exchange today, Ford's share price fell 62.5 cents, closing at $46.50.
About 26 percent of Jaguar's shares are held in the United States in the form of American depository receipts. Americans hold as much 20 percent in the form of shares bought on the London Stock Exchange.
Jaguar, once a Government-owned company, was turned over to the private sector in 1984 and was heralded as one of the success stories of the Thatcher Government's programs to get the Government out of business.

HEADLINE: Productivity Rose 2.1% In 3d Quarter

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2

 BODY:
Productivity in the nonfarm sector of the nation's economy increased in the third quarter, but the improvement was overshadowed by other data suggesting that a slump in manufacturing was far from over and that wage inflation remained stubborn.
The Labor Department reported today that overall productivity in the nonfarm sector climbed by an annual rate of 2.1 percent from July to September, nearly double the revised 1.1 percent gain of the second quarter.
But the department also reported that manufacturing productivity improved at an anemic annual rate of 1.4 percent. Gains in factory output reached a three-year low, and unit labor costs rose at their fastest rate since 1982, a recession year. 
 
Effect on Manufacturing
''Manufacturing is clearly soft,'' said David Wyss of DRI-McGraw Hill, an economic forecasting firm. ''The economy is slowing down, and that is going to be felt disproportionately by manufacturing.''
Donald Straszheim of Merrill Lynch & Company said, ''Manufacturing is not likely to improve much until well into next year.''
The 1.4 percent gain in the annual rate of manufacturing productivity was dramatically lower than the 3.7 percent revised rate for the second quarter. The third-quarter number represented the smallest productivity increase since the fourth quarter of 1987.
Manufacturing output was up by an annual rate of 1.3 percent in the third quarter, the smallest gain since 1986. Hours worked in American factories declined by a tenth of 1 percent at an annual rate, after falling a revised two-tenths of a percent in the second quarter.
September unemployment data showed a manufacturing employment drop of 103,000, a sign to analysts that manufacturers were trying to cut costs and raise productivity.
But the outlook remains bleak for the next several months, the analysts said, because rising unit labor costs will exacerbate the already unfavorable position of most American manufacturers in world markets.
 
Labor Costs Up
The Labor Department said unit labor costs rose at a rapid 4.5 percent annual rate in the quarter, after falling at a revised annual rate of 1 percent in the second quarter. It was the largest quarterly increase in unit labor costs in manufacturing since a 9.7 percent annual gain in the first quarter of 1982.
The overall numbers for the nonfarm sector were somewhat more encouraging, but still underscored the recent economic slowdown and the persistent upward pressure on wages.
The 2.1 percent nonfarm productivity gain resulted from a 3.1 percent rise in output and just a 1 percent gain in hours worked. The increase in hours worked was the lowest in more than three years.
Hourly compensation in the entire nonfarm sector rose at an annual rate of 5.3 percent, down from the second quarter annual rate gain of 5.6 percent, but still reflecting inflationary pressures.
''Inflation is still a very serious problem,'' said Elliott Platt, a senior vice president at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc.
The productivity gain helped offset the effect of wage gains on unit labor costs in the overall nonfarm sector. Wages increased at an annual rate of 3.2 percent in the third quarter, after rising at a revised 4.5 percent in the second quarter.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Compaq Sales Dip Alarms Investors

BYLINE: By Thomas C. Hayes

DATELINE: HOUSTON

 BODY:
COMPAQ COMPUTER is widely expected to introduce a bold desktop computer that can match the speed and power of more costly minicomputers made by Digital Equipment and others.
But Wall Street was not thinking that far ahead yesterday. When the Compaq Computer Corporation said early in the day that its October sales were 10 percent below expectations, its shares tumbled more than $18 each in heavy trading. Compaq's stock finished the day at $89.125, down $16.875, on the New York Stock Exchange. It was the most-active issue on the Big Board, with volume of 5.7 million shares, and the second-biggest loser in percentage terms. 
Rod Canion, Compaq's chief executive, told analysts in a morning conference call that profits in the fourth quarter would not reach their projections and would not match the $91.9 million, or $2.18 a share, earned in the quarter of 1988.
The unspoken message was that for the first time since it was founded in 1982, Compaq would not post higher profits over a comparable year-earlier quarter. Many investors read the message as a sign that sales in the personal computer sector, and in technology in general, were faltering. Shares of Apple Computer, I.B.M., Intel, Microsoft and Lotus Development also lost ground.
Analysts who follow Compaq say the setback should be temporary for several reasons. First, orders for the new lightweight LTE laptop computer Compaq introduced two weeks ago have cut into sales of its heavier year-old laptop, the SLE, more quickly than expected. Compaq does not expect to catch up with LTE orders until the spring.
Compaq's new desktop machines, based on the Intel Corporation's new 486 microprocessing chip, are expected to be introduced Monday in Houston. Analysts said the company would probably sell fewer of the powerful machines this quarter than expected, because Intel, the sole maker of the 486 chip, is behind schedule on shipments. It has to correct recently discovered errors in the chip.
More broadly, the growth rate of sales of desktop computers in the United States has slowed gradually throughout 1989. This reflects a familiar pattern of buyer caution that occurs before the introduction of flashy desktop products.
One factor in Wall Street's reaction is that Compaq's shares had risen so sharply, climbing 31 percent in October to a high of $110 a share, that a period of profit-taking has been considered likely. Yet, even as they were lowering projections for the fourth quarter and for 1990, many analysts said the stock's sharp drop on Thursday has created a buying opportunity.
At the end of trading yesterday, Compaq's shares sold at a price less than 10 times the average amount of earnings projected for 1990 and about 12 times the amount for this year. ''That's why it's a good buy,'' said Michelle Preston, a technology analyst for Salomon Brothers in New York. The 30 stocks in the Dow Jones industrial average were trading at price somewhat higher than earnings in the last four quarters.
''I've talked to Apple, Microsoft and some dealers and nobody is seeing a big slowdown in the industry,'' Ms. Preston said. She was referring broadly to hardware and software suppliers for the desktop computer business., She also said production delays for the new 486 machine should not hurt sales or profits at Compaq next year. Most of the company's sales next year will come from desktop models based on Intel's 386 chip and from its fast-selling laptop models.
Ms. Preston said she kept her 1990 profit forecast at $9.60 a share, although she lowered her estimate for this year to $7.45 a share, from $8.25.
Charles R. Wolf, an analyst at First Boston, cut his estimate for 1990 earnings to $9.50 a share, from $10. ''I can't put my finger on exactly which factor is the dominating reason for the apparent slowdown'' in sales at Compaq, he said, adding that a general slowdown in the nation's economy might have played a part. Over all, Compaq's sales growth should regain momentum next year, he said.
Michael S. Swavely, president of Compaq's North American unit, said in an interview that fourth-quarter sales should rise by 15 to 20 percent, to almost $800 million. That would place Compaq's sales for its seventh year of business at $2.9 billion. For the nine months through September, Compaq's sales rose 50 percent to $2.1 billion, compared with sales a year earlier.
Storeboard, a research firm, recently said the growth rate in sales for the domestic personal computer market slowed this year from an increase of 26 percent in the first quarter, to 5 percent in the third quarter. Compaq's reading of the slowdown is that potential buyers were biding their time until the new generation of 486 products reaches the market. Sales for most desktop makers should rise at a faster clip next year because product advances will expand the market and aging computers will be replaced with newer lower-cost models.
''There are a number of very strong factors driving market growth through the 1990's,'' he said.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Light Trading in Treasury Issues

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities rose modestly in light trading yesterday, as dealers awaited the release today of employment data for October.
Most money-market economists expected a rise of about 150,000 non-farm payroll jobs, with a slight drop in manufacturing employment for October. Manufacturing jobs sagged by a huge 103,000 in September.
Estimates on the figures varied widely, but the case for a weaker-than-expected report gained some currency yesterday after the report of a big rise in initial unemployment claims for the week ended Oct. 21. 
''A payroll number of under 100,000 and another decline in manufacturing employment to go with September's big drop would please the market,'' said James R. Capra, a senior vice president at Shearson Lehman Government Securities.
''But it will take a combination of weak numbers in the employment release to create an imperative for the Federal Reserve to ease policy immediately. Absent that combination, the market will start to lose ground, because it is priced about as far ahead of the Fed as it can get right now.''
Mr. Capra was referring to yields on short-term bills and notes being already well below the 8 3/4 percent level that analysts say is the Fed's target for the overnight Federal funds rate. Short-term money market rates tend to move in response to anticipated or actual changes in the funds rate.
 
Debt Legislation
While the initial jobless claims data provided some support to prices yesterday, dealers sold some securities during afternoon trading when news reports from Capitol Hill suggested that legislation to raise the nation's debt ceiling might soon pass. Quick passage would allow the Treasury's quarterly refunding auctions to begin as scheduled on Nov. 7.
''It is inevitable that the auctions will take place, and there is now a high probability they will take place on schedule,'' said William V. Sullivan, Jr., a senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds. ''Congress doesn't have many options, because the Treasury will go into default on Nov. 9. I would think that next week we will have when-issued trading in the issues to be sold.''
On Wednesday, the Treasury said that if the debt ceiling is raised it will start the refunding auctions with a $10 billion sale of three-year notes on Nov. 7, $10 billion of 10-year notes on Nov. 8 and $30 billion of 30-year bonds on Nov. 9. An additional $10 billion of cash-management bills will also be sold next Thursday.
The prospect of auctions next week did not inspire a very large sell-off of secondary Treasury issues, however.
By late in the day, the 8 1/8 percent bonds of 2019 were offered at a price of 102 30/32, up one-quarter, to yield 7.86 percent.
Among note issues, the 8 percent 10-year Treasury notes were offered at 100 29/32, up 3/32, to yield 7.86 percent. And the 7 5/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 99 23/32, up 2/ 32, to yield 7.78 percent.
Treasury bill rates were unchanged to slightly lower yesterday.
In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.71 percent, down 6 basis points, or hundreths of a point. Six-month bills were unchanged at an offered rate of 7.50 percent. And one-year bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.27 percent, down 2 basis points.
 
Money Supply Report
The Federal Reserve Board reported that two of the three measures of the nation's money supply were unchanged for the week ended Oct. 23. The third and broadest measure, M3, rose by $4.9 billion. The report had no effect on prices in the credit markets.
Activity in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds was very light, dealers reported, with prices of most securities rising by one-eighth point.
Prices of most secondary tax-exempt municipal bonds were also up by about one-eighth point, market participants said at the close of a session in which few securities changed hands.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Gold at Three-Month High As Stock Market Weakens

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The gold futures market drew strength from the stock market's decline yesterday, reaching three-month highs on the Commodity Exchange in New York amid growing fears of a worsening outlook for equity investments.
Gold settled $6 to $6.20 higher, with the contract for delivery in December at $382.90 an ounce, its highest settlement since July 26. Silver finished 10.2 cents to 10.6 cents higher, with December at $5.29 an ounce. 
The gold market's gains more than offset its modest losses in each of the three previous sessions.
Analysts said the strength stemmed partly from the stock market's steep losses during the day, although stock prices rebounded after the gold futures market closed.
 
The Appeal of Metals
The stock market's volatile performance in recent weeks has sent many investors running to the perceived safety of precious metals and gold stocks, and yesterday's drop in stock prices encouraged the trend.
''This is a thrust, and it's intensifying,'' said Bette Raptopoulos, metals analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. in New York.
Gold was also supported by the dollar's weakness and the inflationary implications of generally higher commodity prices yesterday.
Copper futures weakened on news that a contract dispute at a Chilean copper mining complex had been settled. Copper settled 9 cents to 3.35 cents lower, with the contract for delivery in December at $1.134 a pound.
 
Pork Bellies Are Active
Frozen pork belly futures rose sharply on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange in anticipation of new demand from Eastern Europe. Yugoslavia recently bought some United States pork bellies, the Soviet Union is interested in buying some and the United States was scheduled to sign an agreement today that would lead to the shipment of up to 10,000 metric tons of bellies to Poland.
Pork bellies finished 0.05 cent to 1.12 cents higher, with February at 58.72 cents a pound, Grain and soybean futures posted moderate gains on the Chicago Board of Trade, supported by rumors of pending export sales of United States grain to the Soviet Union and China.
Oil futures prices finished lower on the New York Mercantile Exchange, unable to sustain a brief technical rally at midday. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 1 cent to 7 cents lower, with December at $20.01 a barrel.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Finishes Day Mixed As Traders Await Reports

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar finished mixed in light trading yesterday as dealers awaited the release of new data on the nation's economy.
But the price of gold, spurred by new foreign demand, rose sharply. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery rose $6.20 an ounce, to close at $380.40. 
The dollar fluctuated in a narrow range as dealers awaited today's release of United States unemployment figures for October.
Kevin Lawrie, a vice president at the Bank of Boston in New York, said currency dealers were looking for a slight increase in unemployment, which would have a negative effect on the dollar.
''Higher unemployment generally signifies a slowdown in the economy, possibly moving toward a more recessionary atmosphere,'' he said, and putting pressure on the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates.
Lower interest rates make American securities less attractive to foreign investors, dampening their need for dollars.
Much of yesterday's trading centered on other currencies, particularly the pound, which took a beating after rumors that one or possibly two British Government ministers had resigned because of insider-trading offenses.
Despite a denial issued by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's office, the pound still lost more than 1.5 cents against the dollar. The traders said the West German mark and Japanese yen directly benefited from the pound's troubles.
In late New York trading, the dollar finished at 143.43 yen, down from 143.80 yen late on Wednesday. And a pound cost $1.5695, less than the $1.5755 of Wednesday.
Other late-dollar rates in New York, compared with those late on Wednesday, included: 1.8424 West German marks, down from 1.8505; 1.6162 Swiss francs, down from 1.6260; 6.2490 French francs, down from 6.2740; 1,354.75 Italian lire, down from 1.358.75, and 1.1733 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1743.
Silver prices were mixed. On the Comex, silver bullion for current delivery rose to $5.255 an ounce, from $5.150 on Wednesday.

HEADLINE: Morris DeGroot, 58, A Statistics Professor

 BODY:
Morris H. DeGroot, professor of statistics and industrial administration at Carnegie Mellon University, died of lung cancer yesterday at his home in Pittsburgh. He was 58 years old. 
Professor DeGroot joined Carnegie Mellon in 1957 and became a University Professor, the school's highest faculty position. He wrote three books on economic theory.
He was a member of Gov. Milton J, Shapp's committee to study the health effects of a nuclear power plant in Shippingport, Pa., supporting the view that low levels of radioactive emissions affected infant mortality.
Born in Scranton, Pa., Professor DeGroot graduated from Roosevelt University and earned master's and doctor's degrees from the University of Chicago.
He is survived by his wife, Marilyn; a daughter, Jenny, of Chicago and a son, Jeremy, of Berkeley, Calif; a stepson, Craig Fischer of Baltimore and a stepdaughter, Jill Sweeney of Scranton, Pa.; his parents, Archibald and Florence of Scranton and a sister, Phyllis Weinstein of Rochester, N.Y.

LENGTH: 1045 words

HEADLINE: Panel Concludes U.S. Lacks Data To Assess Offshore Drilling Impact

BYLINE: By ALLAN R. GOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3

 BODY:
In a setback to supporters of offshore drilling, a panel of the National Academy of Sciences has concluded that the Government lacks enough information to assess the environmental consequences of oil and gas drilling off the coasts of California and Florida.
In its report, the panel concluded that more studies on possible environmental and economic damage were needed before decisions on leasing and production could be justified at the three sites it studied. The sites cover as many as 13 million acres off Florida's southwest coast, 6.7 million acres off Southern California and 1.2 million acres off Northern California.
The conclusions, in a report requested by a study group appointed by President Bush, do not make an explicit case against leasing or drilling at the three sites, where experts estimate there are appreciable amounts of oil and gas. 
But the academy panel's reservations put considerable pressure on the Administration to back away from its support of offshore leasing in the two states, where there is vehement opposition from Republicans and Democrats alike.
Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. has already acknowledged, in response to reporters' questions this week, that political opposition in Florida and California is so great that it might take 10 years or more for drilling to begin.
Mr. Lujan's comments were the first acknowledgment by the Administration that offshore oil and gas leasing in the two states was improbable.
Offshore drilling has been going on in Southern California, the Gulf of Mexico and Prudhoe Bay in Alaska for years. But such projects have been put on hold by a one-year Congressional moratorium that forbids leasing activities on 84 million offshore acres, including those covered by the study. Some leases have already been negotiated with oil companies in the tracts off Florida and Southern California. The moratorium was recently expanded to cover more territory after the Exxon oil-tanker spill off Alaska last March.
President Bush, keeping a campaign promise, announced last February that he would delay oil leasing activities in tracts off Southern and Northern California and southwestern Florida pending recommendations of a study group headed by Mr. Lujan, whose department oversees the offshore oil leasing program.
Mr. Lujan's group, which expects to make its recommendations by the end of this year, asked the academy to study the adequacy of existing oceanographic, ecological, social and economic information about those areas. The study, which cost $300,000, was led by John W. Farrington, a professor at the Boston campus of the University of Massachusetts.
In presenting the report to Mr. Lujan's study group, Dr. Farrington emphasized today that it did not address the issue of whether leasing should go forward. But environmental groups and and Democratic and Republican opponents of offshore drilling immediately used the report as ammunition.
Gov. Bob Martinez of Florida, a Republican, said, ''I remain opposed to oil and gas exploration activity off the southern Florida coast, and I hope the findings of such a prestigious organization as the National Academy of Sciences persuades the Federal Government to eliminate the risk by prohibiting the activity.''
 
'Rash, Imprudent and Unforgivable'
Senator Pete Wilson, a California Republican who is running for Governor in next year's election, said: ''It would be rash, imprudent and unforgivable to allow any leasing off California to occur given these findings. The experts agree that we just don't have the information we need to assess the risks involved in Outer Continental Shelf development.''
Oil industry representatives said today that if better information was needed before leasing could go forward, then it should be gathered. But the American Petroleum Institute, which represents major oil companies, said earlier academy studies had found little evidence of environmental harm asssociated with offshore oil production.
Another industry representative said that he was surprised by the study's results but that the President's group would make its decision based on several factors. ''It obviously makes their job a little more difficult, but it is only one input,'' said Carl Schmid, a spokesman for the National Ocean Industries Association, a trade group for offshore oil producers.
Although the academy report dealt only with three specific sites, it raised concern among offshore drilling opponents about the adequacy of environmental information in other parts of the Outer Continental Shelf where leasing is under consideration, including the Georges Bank off Massachusetts.
''It's quite devastating to the Interior Department and raises a lot of questions about similar information in other parts of the Outer Continental Shelf,'' said Lisa Speer, a senior staff scientist with the Natural Resources Defense Council, an environmental group that has fought offshore drilling.
The Administration today reiterated its support for oil exploration of the Outer Continental Shelf, which extends 200 miles offshore, but only if it can be done in an environmentally sound manner.
A spokesman for Mr. Lujan, Steve Goldstein, said the study had provided the President's group with ''the conditions you need to meet before going forward'' with drilling but that it had made no decisions about what it would recommend to the President.
 
Findings of Panel
The academy panel concluded that at all three sites there was a lack of information on potential environmental effects to make sound decisions on development and production. As for decisions on the leasing of tracts, the panel said that available information on oceanographic, ecological and socioeconomic effects was marginal or inadequate at the sites off Florida. It also found inadequate information in some of the categories it studied for the California tracts.
The panel looked at such socioeconomic issues as the impact of leasing and drilling on the fishing industry, tourism and unemployment. Its oceanographic studies examined ocean currents to determine where oil from a spill would land. In the case of Florida, it found that oil from a spill would probably reach coastal areas, and might even move around to the east coast.

LENGTH: 815 words

HEADLINE: Iran Notes Anniversary Of Fall of U.S. Embassy

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Nov. 3

 BODY:
Iran will mark the 10th anniversary of the seizure of the United States Embassy in Teheran with a large demonstration organized by one of country's most militant politicians.
The rally, called by Ali Akbar Mohtashemi, who was removed as Interior Minister in August, is widely seen by foreign diplomats and some Iranians as the latest effort in a campaign by militant Iranian politicians to upstage Hojatolislam Hashemi Rafsanjani, the President. The militants are seen as trying to block the President's economic programs and revive the virulent anti-Western outlook that characterized the foreign policy of Islamic revolutionary Iran.
Mr. Mohtashemi is expected to address the rally in his first public appearance since he was removed from the Cabinet. 
At a news conference last week, President Rafsanjani played down the idea of celebrating the anniversary of the Nov. 4, 1979, takeover, which began the 444-day hostage crisis and poisoned American-Iranian relations for a decade, saying, ''usually we do not celebrate such events.'' But the Iranian President conceded that there is ''a difference in thinking'' among the Iranian leadership.
 
Iranian Visits Beirut Shiites
Last month, in another unmistakable challenge to President Rafsanjani, Mr. Mohtashemi visited Beirut to confer with the pro-Iranian leaders of the Party of God, a Shiite Muslim militia that he helped form.
In an interview today with the official Iranian press agency, Mr. Mohtashemi pointedly said he went to Lebanon ''to assure Lebanese Muslims and all revolutionary brethren that there has been no change in our policies after the passing away'' in June of Iran's supreme revolutionary leader, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini. The visit to Lebanon was dismissed only a few days ago by an Iranian Foreign Ministry official as a private enterprise.
Since taking took over as President of Iran in August, Mr. Rafsanjani has seen his efforts to improve ties with Arab and Western countries and revive the Iranian economy derailed by a hard core of militants in Parliament and among the clergy who oppose better ties with Arab gulf neighbors or with the West. Mr. Mohtashemi is known to have the backing of several other militant Iranian leaders, including Ayatollah Khomeini's son, Ahmed.
''Rafsanjani's grip on power was never that firm,'' said Baqer Moin, an author and expert on Iranian affairs in London. ''It could be strengthened only if he dramatically improves economic conditions by improving relations with the West, something that militant clergy members are blocking. Being the pragmatist he is, Rafsanjani may move in the end to become the leader of the radicals intead of sinking.''
 
Plan to Display U.S. Embassy
The rally planned for Saturday is to coincide with the start of a trial for a number of former Iranian officials accused of being spies in the employ of the American Central Intelligence Agency, according to reports from Teheran.
Iranian officials also said they might open the gates of the captured American Embassy compound to the public for the first time. The Iranian press agency said the embassy would be open for five days as a museum for American spying.
The takeover of the embassy provoked a break in diplomatic, economic and strategic American-Iranian relations, bringing an end to decades of cooperation between the two countries. It also brought about the fall of the moderate Government of former Prime Minister Mehdi Bazargan.
The holding of 52 American diplomats as hostages for 444 days has left a bitter memory that neither Iranians nor Americans have been able to overcome over the last decade.
 
Militants Oppose Ties to West
The revival of hard-liners in Teheran comes after many months in which President Rafsanjani has tried to end the estrangement of Iran by signaling his desire for better relations with neighboring Arab countries and the West.
But the militant members of the ruling clergy, including Mr. Mohtashemi and a substantial part of Parliament, as well as the new revolutionary guide, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, failed to support the Iranian President, or acted against his will.
Ayatollah Khamenei was considered an ally of President Rafsanjani, but a few days ago he appointed a militant member of the Iranian Revolutionary Guards, Ali Shamkhani, as commander of the Iranian Navy.
On Wednesday, Ayatollah Khamenei called on Iranians to ''wage perpetual struggle against arrogant powers headed by the United States,'' and on that same day, the Iranian Parliament enacted a law allowing the arrest of Americans anywhere in the world who are accused of harming the interests of Iran.
The law was in response, the members of Parliament said, to the United States move to allow the Federal Bureau of Investigation decision to arrest suspected terrorists without seeking permission of the countries they reside in a few months ago.

HEADLINE: Pace of New Jobs Calms Recession Fears

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3

 BODY:
The Labor Department reported today that the economy created new jobs at a brisk pace in October, calming fears that it might have begun to skid toward recession. In addition, factory employment stabilized after plunging in September.
In all, 119.2 million Americans held civilian or military jobs, and 6.6 million were unemployed, for an unemployment rate of 5.2 percent. That was the same level as in June, July and September. 
The unemployment rate for civilians only was unchanged from the September level, 5.3 percent.
While growth has been spotty in manufacturing and other areas of private industry, the bright spot has come with an increase in jobs in state and local government.
The Commissioner of Labor Statistics, Dr. Janet L. Norwood, noted today that private job growth had averaged only 110,000 jobs monthly over the past four months, half the growth rate of the first half of 1989.
In addition, some analysts predicted today that the figures for job growth in state and local government would probably be revised downward.
Still, an increase of 233,000 jobs, as determined by the department's survey of businesses, was significantly more than most analysts expected. It was therefore taken as reassurance that sluggishness in housing and much of manufacturing, particularly among automobile makers, had not spread to the entire economy.
 
A Surge in Teachers
The slump in the auto industry appears likely to continue; Chrysler Corporation today announced layoffs of 4,000 workers at plants in Michigan, Missouri and Wisconsin.
''There is weakness in the manufacturing sector, but it's not deepening,'' said Norman Robertson, an economist at the Mellon Bank Corporation in Pittsburgh. ''It provides more evidence that the slowdown is not deteriorating into a recession.''
For the second consecutive month there was a surge of 95,000 new jobs, after seasonal adjustment, in local government, largely among teachers, administrators and other school employees who were added for the fall term.
But there was also a second consecutive decline, although a scant 3,000, in goods-producing jobs. In addition, the number of jobs lost since March among manufacturers of durable goods swelled to a total of 155,000.
''This continues to show the split nature of the economy,'' said David W. Berson, an economist at the Federal National Mortgage Association. ''Services are quite strong, while goods are getting weaker, though at a slower rate.'' He agreed with other analysts that today's report was likely to make the Federal Reserve less eager to ease credit, especially in light of recent inflationary pressures. including higher wages and employment costs. A weak economy normally prompts the Federal Reserve to relax credit, thereby reducing interest rates in an effort to spur economic growth.
In New York State, the unemployment rate declined seven-tenths of a point, to 4.7 percent, last month. But the unemployment rate was higher than that of October 1988, when it was 4.2 percent. There were 405,000 unemployed New Yorkers in October, as against 467,000 in September and 359,000 in October 1988.
In New Jersey, the unemployment rate climbed above 5 percent for the first time in three years, reaching 5.1 percent. In September the rate was 4.6 percent. Last October, the rate was 3.9 percent. There were 207,000 unemployed New Jersey residents in October, up from 186,000 in September and 153,000 in October 1988.
''The slowdown in New York and New Jersey is more than anything we have seen on the national scene this year,'' said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner for the Labor Department.
 
Moonlighting on Rise
In her monthly appearance before the Joint Economic Committee of Congress today, Dr. Norwood said there had been an acceleration in the trend of Americans' holding more than one job apiece. Citing a new survey, whose details will be made public Monday, she said increases in multiple jobholding accounted for nearly two-thirds of the difference in jobs added the last four years.
Other department figures showed that regional disparities in employment are narrowing. Among the four major regions, the unemployment rates are 4.5 percent in the Northeast, 5.3 percent in the Midwest, 5.3 percent in the South and 4.7 percent in the West. These figures are not seasonally adjusted. The rates in the Northeast and Midwest deteriorated last month from the September rates, while those for the South and West improved.
The length of the factory workweek fell 18 minutes, to 40.8 hours, but this was partly because of a strike at the Boeing Company that affected hours but not the number of employees.

HEADLINE: Prohibition Was a Triumph for Minority Rule

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In ''Actually, Prohibition Was a Success'' (Op-Ed, Oct. 16), Mark Moore supports his argument with data on public health, violent crime and alcohol consumption.
His claim that home production was legal is wrong, and his use of statistics overstates the benefits of Prohibition. Violent crime rates and alcohol consumption were decreasing and public health was improving long before Prohibition was enacted. Improvements in the economy, in working conditions and medical care, as well as changing demographics, can explain most of the decline in the cirrhosis death rate. The general death rate declined at about the same rate. The alcoholism death rate was about the same before as during Prohibition. 
Crime rates may be the most telling statistics. Before a rash of state prohibitions, World War I prohibition and Prohibition itself, the United States experienced a long-run decline in violent crimes. But violent and property crimes increased through the Prohibition period, only to reverse dramatically after repeal in 1933.
Alcohol consumption declined during Prohibition, but mostly among teetotalers. Some found substitutes, such as narcotics and hashish. Most important, while beer consumption fell dramatically, wine and spirits consumption increased. Also, alcohol products tended to be more potent. Irving Fisher, a champion of the dry cause, noted that ''it requires only a tenth as much of bootleg liquor as of pre-Prohibition liquor to produce a given degree of drunkenness.''
While this may seem exaggerated, compare the effects of crack cocaine and black-market heroin with the cocaine in Coca-Cola and the heroin pills sold by the Bayer Company before the Harrison Narcotics Act. The potency of marijuana has increased several hundred percent since it was outlawed in 1937.
The only success that can be attached to prohibitions is the ability of one group to impose its wishes (not necessarily morality) on another. The only amazing difference with alcohol Prohibition was that a minority was able to impose its wishes on a majority of voters - the drinking class.
 
MARK THORNTON
 Auburn University, Ala., Oct. 19, 1989
 
The writer, an Auburn assistant professor of economics, wrote his dissertation on Prohibition.

HEADLINE: DIALOGUE: Reinventing City Government
Charter Revision: Yes or No?;
It's Urban Paralysis.

SERIES: TOMORROW'S NEW YORK: The Next Mayor - An Occasional Series

BYLINE: By Melvin Miller and Charles E. Schumer; Melvin Miller, a Democrat, is Speaker of the State Assembly; Charles E. Schumer, a Democrat, is a Representative from Brooklyn.

 BODY:
New York City needs a strong, streamlined government to deal with the challenges it faces in the next decade. Problems like building drug rehabilitation centers, cutting budgets, housing the homeless and keeping businesses in New York will require decisive action that could alienate some constituencies.
New York desperately needs clean lines of authority so that important choices can be faced and responsibilities shouldered. The city needs a strong mayor and a strong City Council. Unfortunately, the proposed charter revision, with its emphasis on overlapping bureaucracies and decentralization, is a prescription for urban paralysis. 
The Charter Commission avoided deciding who should make decisions. Instead, it simply expanded the number of decision makers. This convoluted structure will further drain city coffers, make government less responsive and increase the time the city spends fighting with itself.
Consider the circuitous path that a land-use decision will take under the new charter. It starts with a formal application to build something. Next, a local community board ''helps'' design an environmental review. The application then goes to the Department of City Planning for certification.
Next, the Community Board and the Borough President conduct reviews, and the City Planning Commission holds public hearings and votes. The City Council then has to grant its approval, but that can be vetoed by the Mayor. Finally, the Council can override the veto with a two-thirds vote.
This is a recipe for paralysis. Every layer of bureaucracy has a platform and enough power to hold up the process. No one has enough authority to make decisions. While the Charter Commission seeks to promote democracy, it reaches for its goal simply by adding more voices to a chorus that is already a cacophony.
In the crucial area of budgeting, for example, the commission creates an Independent Budget Office that will do much the same work as the City Comptroller. And the budget process as a whole is a complicated labyrinth, with the mayor, comptroller and the City Council having overlapping roles and ill-defined responsibilities.
Consider the predicament of an agency awarding a contract. Oversight and regulation are divided among the procurement policy board, Council committees, comptroller audits and the borough president, who evaluates contract performance. The system is an open invitation to nit-picking and obstructionism.
This procedure would be bad enough on its own, but the charter revision calls for free floating ombudsmen who have no responsibility but to criticize what is being decided. Stripped of any real power, the five Borough Presidents and the City Council president will complicate an already confused procedure.
These problems would not be so objectionable if the revisions met their goal of making government more democratic. Unfortunately, this potpourri system of governing boards will make government more difficult for citizens to follow and hence less accountable.
As always, the special interests will have no trouble figuring who is the appropriate person to lobby. But it will be easy to hide crucial decisions from the average New Yorker. These new dark corners in the governmental process will increase the potential for corruption and influence peddling.
Are we complaining that the charter revision is too much democracy? No. It is too much government. In an age where the needs of an individual are zealously protected by courts and local politicians, government must be structured so that the needs of the whole community are given weight as well. By creating so many governmental entities responsive to individual concerns, the needs of the community will be lost.
Next Tuesday, New Yorkers can strike a blow for efficient city government by voting against the revised charter and sending the Charter Commission back to work.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Looking to the Next Mayor to Fight Crack and Build Hope

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO

 BODY:
Up to four times a month, burglars break into the Blue Diner, using a sledgehammer to crash through walls and ceilings, taking anything in sight, from the cash register to meat.
Nick Tzivas, 53 years old, and Mike Doliadis, 49, who have owned the restaurant at East 138 Street and Canal Place in the Bronx for 20 years, point to the men who clean windshields at a nearby stoplight, or drop in to peddle car batteries. The ''crackheads,'' Mr. Tzivas calls them, and he and his partner just wait for the next hit.
The Mott Haven section - bound by a bustling commercial strip to the north, a reviving industrial zone to the west and the Harlem River - is held hostage to drugs, its residents say. ''We need a change,'' said Mr. Tzivas. Fighting Crime and Crack For Mr. Tzivas, the law-enforcement background of the Republican candidate, Rudolph W. Giuliani, is just what Mott Haven needs. But in this Democratic stronghold, where David N. Dinkins defeated Mayor Edward I. Koch by almost 3 to 1 in the primary, many voters see Mr. Dinkins as the one most committed to cleaning up the neighborhood. ''Dinkins definitely wants to make a difference,'' said Nidia Lopez, 50, who has lived in the Mott Haven Houses housing project for 11 years with her husband and two daughters and is a member of South Bronx People for Change, a church-based community group. 
''He's said there's a need to go after the principals, not only the ones who sell drugs on the street. He's also for putting more money into education.''
Elva Maxwell, 38, a mother of eight and a Mott Haven resident for five years, also plans to vote for Mr. Dinkins, but, like many of her neighbors, she questions whether anyone, Democrat or Republican, can help.
''I'm sure anybody in a position of authority is going to try, but there's so much you can do. This is an epidemic. This isn't going to go away.''
Mott Haven is the largest neighborhood in Community Planning District 1, a 2.8-square-mile section of the South Bronx that also includes Melrose and Port Morris. Of the district's 80,300 residents, an estimated 38,000 live in Mott Haven. Sixty-three percent of the district's population is made up of Hispanic residents and 33 percent is black, the 1980 census shows. The population is also young and poor - a quarter falls between ages 14 and 24, and nearly half receives some form of public assistance.
The district has the city's largest concentration of New York Housing Authority units. More than half of its residents live in housing projects.
Housing, or the lack of it, is a major issue in Mott Haven and surrounding neighborhoods. Community board officials estimate that 5,000 people want but cannot get public housing. Housing that is available has poor maintenance and security, they said.
 
Crack Touches Everything
But residents say nothing is worse than crack.
The drug seems to have touched everything and everyone. It is sold and smoked openly outside schools and on thoroughfares, day and night. Police said that easy access to the area by expressway and subway has spawned hardcore dealing spots that feed not only residents but suburbanites. Elizabeth Montalvo, 32, just joined a tenant patrol in her housing project. Since June, about 25 residents at 205-207 Alexander Avenue have put in shifts in the lobby, signing in visitors and watching for suspicious-looking strangers.
But the screening has not deterred the crack smoking that goes on in hallways, stairways, elevators and on the roof, Ms. Montalvo said.
She said her 5-year-old son can identify a discarded crack vial.
''Before he was 5 he was saying, 'Look Mommy. That's crack,' '' she said. ''I get a tremendous headache from the smell.''
 
Seeing Dealers Out the Window
Crack has cast a shadow over signs of revitalization in and around the neighborhood. The commercial district known as the ''Hub'' at East 149th Street and Third Avenue is adding new stores, and a shopping mall is planned for a few blocks north. Nearby Port Morris, a manufacturing center of about 400 businesses, has been targeted by the state for economic development. In a block-long lot on Brook Avenue overrun by weeds and trash, a billboard boasts that 112 two-family homes will be built on the site by spring. The homes will sell for $145,000 to $150,000.
Louis Ramos, 50, who lives near the lot, is not impressed. ''The buildings come up but we have to see about the conditions of the area. One new building doesn't mean that the situation is going to go away.''
John Carney, 65, a real estate investor who owns several brownstones on Alexander Avenue between East 138th and East 140th Streets, lives in Mott Haven's historic district, where he said brownstones sell for $150,000 to $185,000. Mr. Carney said that from his window, he can see dealers selling drugs on the street, barely two blocks from the police precinct house.
''People line up just like in a supermarket,'' he said.
 
'We Don't Have a Solution'
Police average 160 drug-related arrests a month in Mott Haven and its neighboring communities, but residents said such enforcement is not enough. The precinct operates with as few as seven patrol cars a shift. There are only 18 housing authority officers patrolling 11,000 project units, community board officials said.
Residents must also contend with the crime beget by drugs, from stripped cars littering the neighborhood to murder. Police Capt. Bernard M. Gillespie of the 40th Precinct, who said crime this year is up ''slightly,'' acknowledges: ''We don't have a solution. We all admit we don't have the resources.''
At St. Pius V Church at East 145 Street and St. Ann's Avenue, Father Paul Le Blanc has stopped reporting burglaries to the police. His church and school have been broken into so often, he said, that the paperwork was taking too much time.
''I don't see how anybody could steal a crucifix and then sell it on the street, but they do,'' he said.
 
An Insidious Drug
Father Le Blanc, pastor at St. Pius V for 13 years, said that although residents clamor for more police, the drug problem must also be tackled through treatment and education. He said crack leads to more than crime. The low test scores of the area's students, he said, show that the drug is insidious. The area is also afflicted with health problems including high infant mortality rates and babies who are born with the AIDS virus.
''There are kids in our school whose parents have used or are using drugs,'' he said. ''The effect on the kids is tremendous because their role models are those who sell and those who use.''
The Democratic primary vote in the Mott Haven-Hunts Point electoral district yielded 12,519 votes for Mr. Dinkins and 5,092 for Mr. Koch. Mr. Giuliani received 186 votes in the Republican primary, and Ronald S. Lauder, 151.
Luz Gonzalez, 55, a homemaker and homeowner who has lived in Mott Haven since 1969, said her primary vote for Mr. Dinkins was her first ever against Mr. Koch. She plans to vote for Mr. Dinkins again in November. Can Promises Be Kept? She said that the Mayor ''did a lot of good things but I didn't like how instead of uniting the ethnic groups he tried to separate them.'' She said, ''I don't agree with any politician who tries to separate humanity by race.''
Dinkins supporters here dismiss the recent controversy over his finances, attributing it to politics. ''A lot of what you hear is not true,'' said Leola White, 48.
But race is an issue among some residents. A 27-year-old Hispanic mother of four who requested anonymity said she planned to vote for Mr. Giuliani because she believed Mr. Dinkins would only represent the interests of blacks.
A Mott Haven resident of 30 years, Maria Feliciano, 46, expressed a view of political candidates held by many. ''They make promises and then they don't do the things they said they were going to do. Dinkins is a good candidate, and the other one, too. Everything they say about drugs are good things. If only they did them when they get in office.''
State Assemblyman Jose E. Serrano, a Democrat who represents Mott Haven, said that ''one ingredient that some candidates forget is that people are also looking for hope.''
Said Father Le Blanc: ''We haven't lost hope, but we are seriously pressed against the wall.''

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST, SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 4, 1989

 BODY:

 
 
The Economy
 Five Senators were asked whether campaign contributions from the chairman of Lincoln Savings prompted them to intervene with Federal regulators on Lincoln's behalf. The questions, in letters from the chairman and vice chairman of the Senate Ethics Committee, are the first indication of the committee's interest in the Lincoln matter. Congressional aides say the panel has not decided whether to open a full-scale investigation. The House Banking Committee is also scrutinizing the Senators' actions. [Page 1.] 
 The U.S. unemployment rate remained at 5.2 percent in October, calming fears that the economy is sliding into a recession. The Labor Department reported that the economy created jobs at a fairly brisk pace, and factory employment stabilized after plunging in September. The overall jobless rate remained at 5.2 percent, the same level as in June, July and September. The increase in jobs slightly exceeded the rise in the number of people in the labor force. [9.] The top antitrust officials in the Bush Administration said in their first major policy statements that they would strengthen enforcement policies. They singled out the airline and health-care industries for scrutiny. [33.]
 
 
 
Markets
 Some pension-fund money managers vowed to ignore the Big Board's restrictions on computerized trading, saying they have an obligation to seek the best possible yields for their clients. [33.]
 Treasury notes and bonds fell after the Government reported that nonfarm employment grew more than expected and because of a Congressional stalemate over the U.S. debt ceiling. [36.]

HEADLINE: As Sales Slip, a Model Plant Suffers

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FAIRFAX, Kan.

 BODY:
If ever an automobile plant was an unlikely candidate for idling, the jewel of General Motors' modernization strategy here was it.
But on Oct. 27, G.M. closed this mammoth complex near Kansas City for two weeks ''to balance inventories of Pontiac Grand Prix,'' a euphemistic way of saying there have been too many cars and too few buyers.
The shutdown illustrates the seriousness of the recent sales slowdown for the nation's auto makers. The Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation have also been shutting assembly plants for few-week stints recently. [On Friday, Ford announced that three of its plants would be temporarily closed, and Chrysler said it would permanently shut its Jefferson Avenue assembly plant in Detroit, effective Feb. 2. Chrysler is also canceling one of two shifts at a St. Louis assembly plant. There is little relief on the horizon. The three major Detroit producers reported on Friday that car sales in October fell 14 percent.] ''Everyone is running scared; they're concerned about their jobs,'' said Bud Carroll, president of local 31 of the United Automobile Workers. 
Older auto plants building mature models are inevitably shut down when sales slip. But the new Fairfax plant is exclusively producing Pontiac's Grand Prix - a car on which G.M. has pinned much of its hope for strong sales. The four-door version of the Grand Prix was introduced only in October. The list price for both models is $14,564.
Relations between hourly workers and managers at the Fairfax plant are harmonious, and concepts like work teams, popularized by the Japanese, are being used in an attempt to improve the product.
But after six years of strong vehicle buying - an extraordinarily long streak extended by rebates, discounts and subsidized financing - consumer demand for new cars and trucks has been waning. Because of the discounts, dealer profits in 1989 have been thin. Thus dealers are now reluctant to rebuild inventories until they see more buyers. While it is not surprising that dealers might have trepidations about ordering older Pontiac models like the 6000, even orders for the Grand Prix, which was introduced two years ago, have been disappointing.
 
'It's a Little Scary'
''Last year we kept 50 to 60 Grand Prix in inventory; this year our target is 30,'' said Mark Miller, owner of Mark Miller Pontiac in Salt Lake City. ''The soothsayers all are saying we'll have a dropoff in volume. G.M. announced rebates on 1990 cars before the cars got to the showroom. Customer traffic is off. It's a little scary.''
But even if buyer demand had remained as strong as in recent years, the Fairfax plant would face another problem: industrywide overcapacity. Domestic manufacturers as a group have too many assembly plants in North America, and the situation is worsening as Japanese auto makers continue to open plants. G.M., building about 1.5 million vehicles fewer than a decade ago and now operating at 70 to 80 percent of capacity, has by far the most idle capacity. The Big Three as a whole are operating at about 87 percent of capacity.
Roger B. Smith, the chairman of General Motors, has declared the closing of outdated plants a tactic in the company's modernization strategy. The production of those plants is supposed to be shifted to a smaller number of new and more efficient plants, like those in Fairfax and Hamtramck, Mich., and the Saturn plant in Spring Hill, Tenn.
Under this scenario Fairfax workers should be feeling much more secure than they do. But many of the 3,200 hourly workers are nervous. Earlier this year they were idle for four weeks for ''inventory balancing.'' They get 70 to 90 percent of their pay through unemployment benefits.
 
Car Impresses Workers
 ''This doesn't look good for anyone's job,'' said Steve Bohannon, an hourly worker. ''Everyone has got so much confidence that G.M. is going to turn it around. I don't like it.''
Layoffs notwithstanding, General Motors workers have been impressed with the design and the quality of the Grand Prix, said Dan Mallett, the union's shop chairman. ''Everywhere we go our members ask people they see driving the Grand Prix how they like their cars,'' he said. ''We haven't gotten a single complaint.''
Interviews with dealers indicate they are pleased, too. Lee A. Beaman, a Pontiac dealer in Nashville, called the four-door ''a good-looking and great-performing car.
''I'm a little perplexed about why it isn't a roaring success,'' he said.
John Middlebrook, a G.M. vice president and general manager of Pontiac, thinks the Grand Prix's troubles are temporary because the four-door model is not yet well known in the marketplace. But he wonders how much rebates might have to grow to motivate consumers jaded by discounting. ''Is a $1,000 rebate now a ho-hum for consumers?'' he asked. ''It just might be.''
General Motors opened the $1 billion Fairfax plant for production in 1987 and dedicated it to the Grand Prix, one of the company's midsized cars that also include the Chevrolet Lumina, Buick Regal and Oldsmobile Cutlass Supreme. General Motors, which has scaled down this program, known as the G.M. 10 line, to account for heightened competition, designed Fairfax to produce more than 200,000 Grand Prix; under current conditions, the plant may not build 175,000 in the coming year.
 
Other Plants Slow
 ''As we fill out the model line, we still feel we can use the capacity of the plant,'' said Mr. Middlebrook, noting that General Motors will build a higher-performance version of the Grand Prix, called STE, in January. Another G.M. 10 model could be added to Fairfax to pick up the slack, but Mr. Middlebrook pointed out that other G.M. 10 plants are in similar situations.
To help assure a high level of quality and productivity at the new plant, the local union in 1987 agreed to reduce job classifications for hourly workers to 2, from 124, and for skilled workers to 10, from 17. The company installed 240 robots, compared with 2 at the old plant. Mr. Carroll said the so-called team concept, which allows flexibility in job rotation and puts more responsibility in the hands of workers, ''is working well, but we had it at the old plant, too; we just didn't have a name for it.''
Modern management concepts learned from Japanese auto makers are in evidence as well. For example, seats arrive only as needed, saving inventory expense, and are arranged ahead of time by the supplier in the precise sequence they are needed, saving time and obviating confusion.
While some historic tensions remain between managers and the union, both sides agree there is more mutual trust and respect. But they share a frustration that the car they build is not selling better.
''We have upgraded; I don't think there is a vast difference between our cars and the Japanese cars,'' said Tim Danahy, the plant's personnel director. ''What's happening to us brings home the competitive situation in this country. It's a damn fine car; we need more people to buy it.''

GRAPHIC: Incomplete Pontiac Grand Prix cars were left on the assembly line last Friday when General Motors closed its assembly plant in Fairfax, Kan., for two weeks. (NYT/David Hutson)

HEADLINE: U.S. Notes and Bonds Decline on Job Data

BYLINE: By H.J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury notes and bonds dropped and Treasury bill rates climbed yesterday, partly because of a larger-than-expected rise in nonfarm employment last month and partly because of a Congressional stalement over legislation that would raise the national debt ceiling.
Although many participants in the fixed-income market viewed the employment data as a statistical aberration, they believed the figures would preclude any easing of interest rates by the Federal Reserve in the near future.
Before the market opened, the Government announced that the number of nonfarm jobs increased by 233,000 in October, up from the rise of 201,000 reported the month before. Many economists expected a rise of no more than 150,000 jobs. 
''Aside from the suspect employment numbers, the Treasury securities market was also unsettled by the ongoing stalemate over raising the national debt ceiling,'' said Leif H. Olsen, who heads an economic consulting and money-management firm bearing his name in New Canaan, Conn. ''Unless the debt-ceiling wrangle is resolved over the weekend, there may not be any auctions of T-bills, much less the mid-quarter refunding sales scheduled for next week.''
Expecting that Congress would raise the debt ceiling from its current level of $2.87 trillion before Monday, the Treasury had planned to auction $16 billion of bills at its weekly sale on Monday, up from $15.6 billion last week. The scheduled refunding auctions include one for $10.25 billion of three-year notes on Tuesday; one for $10 billion of 10-year notes on Wednesday, and one for $10 billion of 30-year bonds on Thursday.
 
Lack of Guidelines Seen
 Even if the debt ceiling is raised by Monday, Mr. Olsen said, dealers and other potential bidders will be without the benefit of pre-selling guidelines. Normally, Treasury securities dealers discuss coming sales with their expected customers and acquire a sense of the market value of the securities after they are auctioned.
Nor did the bond market have the benefit of observing Japanese trading patterns, because virtually all financial institutions were closed in Japan yesterday in observance of Culture Day, a national holiday.
As for the October employment data released yesterday morning, Mr. Olsen noted that the 233,000 increase included a rise of 95,000 jobs in local government. He said: ''Many of us believe the local government jobs consist mainly of teachers and others involved in eduation who returned to their jobs in September, but were not tallied until October. If so, we can expect the October numbers to be substantially revised downward next month.''
Largely as a result of these uncertainties, the benchmark Treasury long bonds, the 8 1/8 percent issue maturing in 2019, were being offered late in the session at 102 7/32, down 22/32. The yield rose to 7.93 percent, from 7.86 percent the day before; the yield was 7.84 percent a week earlier. In Chicago, the spot December Treasury bond futures contract closed at 99.8, down 19/32 on the day.
Among other representative Treasury issues traded in the secondary market, the new 7 5/8 percent notes of 1991 fell 12/32, to 99 11/32, for a yield of 7.99 percent; the 8 percent notes of 1996 dropped 17/32, to 100 7/32, with a yield of 7.96 percent, and the long notes, the 8's of 1999, declined 16/32, or a half-point, to 100 8/32, and now yield 7.96 percent.
 
Bill Rates Climb
 Uncertainty over the Treasury bill auctions on Monday contributed to a rise in rates. The discount rate on 90-day bills rose 10 basis points, to 7.83 percent; six-month bills climbed 17 basis points, to 7.69 percent, and the one-year bills closed up 17 basis points, at 7.48 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
With the Federal Reserve refraining from money-market operations, the Federal funds rate traded unchanged for most of the day at 8.75 percent, before easing to 8 11/16 percent at the close. That rate is what banks charge each other for temporary loans.
