HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up Slightly in U.S. After Posting Loss Overseas

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar turned in a mixed performance in domestic trading yesterday, finishing slightly higher against several currencies.
Gold prices fell in New York after rising overseas. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery slipped $1.90 an ounce, to $378.50. 
The dollar rose on foreign exchange markets worldwide after the Labor Department reported that American employment figures for October were stronger than had been expected.
The report that nonfarm payroll employment rose by 233,000 last month, compared with a growth of only about 150,000 forecast by economists, suggested that the economy had unexpected strength and that the Federal Reserve would not move immediately to encourage lower interest rates.
''The market was sort of stunned,'' said Robert Ryan, the vice president of foreign exchange trading at the Bank of New York.
But after an hour of frantic dollar buying, activity slowed and the currency began falling, finishing in Europe at levels mostly lower than had been reached late on Thursday.
''The market's initial reaction to the jobs data was positive, but once the market analyzed the data, we realized they still indicated a weak economy,'' a London currency dealer said.
Mr. Ryan said rumors also arose that Japanese officials might raise interest rates to support the yen, and the speculation hurt the dollar and other currencies.
The dollar posted some late gains in New York, Mr. Ryan said, as the traders balanced their positions before the weekend.
In late New York trading, the dollar slipped to 143.25 yen, from 143.43 yen late on Thursday. The dollar gained against the pound, which fell to $1.5685, from $1.5695.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with those of late Thursday, included: 1.8467 West German marks, up from 1.8423; 6.2630 French francs, up from 6.2490; 1.6205 Swiss francs, up from 1.6162; 1,356.50 Italian lire, up from 1,354.75, and 1.1723 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1732.
On the Comex, silver for current delivery fell by 2.8 cents an ounce, to $5.227.

HEADLINE: F.D.A. PLANS ACTION ON AN ANIMAL DRUG

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4

 BODY:
The Food and Drug Administration is moving against a widely used, powerful animal drug because it contaminates supplies of milk and pork. The F.D.A. could either ban the drug outright or impose dosage limits that would make it impractical to use.
The Government's plan to eliminate the drug, sulfamethazine, from the food supply is prompted by new results from animal studies providing clearer evidence than ever before that sulfamethazine causes cancerous tumors of the thyroid glands of rats and mice. These findings come 14 years after scientists at the Federal agency and the Department of Agriculture identified illegally high residues of the drug in pork as a threat to consumers.
 
'Black Crepe' for Drug
''We are proceeding on the basis that this compound causes tumors,'' said Dr. Gerald B. Guest, director of the Center for Veterinary Medicine at the F.D.A. ''We have several steps to complete, but I expect that in six months we will propose to withdraw this drug from the market. You can hang out the black crepe for sulfamethazine.'' 
Manufacturers of sulfamethazine, which has annual sales of about $60 million in the United States, said they disagreed with the Government's interpretation of the animal studies and would oppose the change in policy when it is made official, probably by next spring.
Representatives of the milk and pork industries and most veterinarians say that sulfamethazine is safe at the levels now found in food.
''Sulfa drugs have been used in human medicine since the 1930's,'' said Fred Gutzmann, a marketing manager at the American Cyanamid Company in Wayne, N.J., a large distributor of medicated mixtures for feed and water that contain sulfamethazine.
''The effect that is seen in the rodent studies is something that would not occur and does not occur in humans even with direct use under long-term therapeutic use. We don't think there is any science that justifies the F.D.A. removing this product from the market.''
Representatives of the milk and pork industries note that alternatives to sulfamethazine are available. But eliminating the drug would make livestock farming more difficult by forcing growers to change their procedures. In addition, the alternative drugs could increase the cost to livestock producers, although they might not pass the added cost along because there are many other factors bearing on prices for consumers.
The animal and drug industries are planning to fight the F.D.A. move, not only because of the cost to livestock producers and the value of the drug sales, but because they fear the Government could move against all sulfa drugs used in raising livestock.
To speed growth and prevent respiratory diseases small amounts of sulfamethazine (pronounced sul-fah-METH-eh-zeen) are mixed into feed or water for many of the 90 million pigs raised each year in the United States. Dairy farmers most often administer the drug to cows in the form of a large pill, or bolus, to treat diseases of the lungs and cure hoof infections.
 
Any Level in Milk Is Barred
The Government prohibits sulfamethazine residues in pork products from exceeding 100 parts per billion and prohibits any level of the drug in milk.
Sulfamethazine, an anti-bacterial compound, was smong a handful of animal drugs introduced in the late 1940's and 1950's that helped to transform the structure of American livestock farms. Because it is inexpensive and effective against an array of diseases in hogs and cattle, sulfamethazine made it possible for farmers to improve the economic efficiency of producing meat and milk by closing down outdoor corrals and confining large numbers of infection-prone animals in production houses and feeding pens.
The issue now is whether sulfamethazine is itself a carcinogen or produces physiological changes in rodents that lead to cancerous tumors. Steve Kimbel, a spokesman for the Animal Health Institute, the trade group for the $2.5 billion-a-year animal drug industry, said some scientists who have reviewed the new studies say high levels of sulfamethazine administered to the rodents caused the pituitary glands to produce higher levels of a hormone that stimulated the thyroid, producing the cancerous lesions.
 
High Doses Called Factor
Mr. Kimbel said the industry was prepared to argue in Federal hearings that rodents are prone to such lesions when exposed to high concentrations of sulfamethazine. But when exposed to low levels of the drug, the lesions do not appear in the rodents and they would not appear in people, said Mr. Kimbel and other industry executives.
The long regulatory history of sulfamethazine is the latest illustration of the difficulty Federal agencies are having in untangling the web of scientific, political and economic issues before toxic substances can be eliminated from the food supply.
In almost every case, the most difficult conflict to resolve is the actual hazard posed by the substance versus its usefulness to farmers. The conflict is a little easier for the Food and Drug Administration because the Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act, the law that regulates animal drugs, directs that if a substance is determined to be unsafe and is found in food, it must be withdrawn from use.
In 1975, the Department of Agriculture and the Food and Drug Administration discovered that 15 percent of all pork sold in the United States contained residues of sulfamethazine that exceeded the Federal safety limit. The Government began a program to warn farmers they were in violation of the law and to teach others how to be more careful in using the drug.
 
Violations Reduced
The problem persisted in the 1980's, although violations found in pork samples that were tested were reduced to 1 percent this year from 5.3 percent in 1985, according to the F.D.A. The declining levels, though, were not low enough to satisfy the Japanese, who threatened last year to halt purchases of American pork because of sulfamethazine residues. Japan and the United States began a program to screen pork to be shipped to Asia.
The lower levels did not calm state officials either. In Iowa, the center of the nation's $9.1 billion pork industry, 47 of the 41,000 farms that raise hogs were investigated by the State Department of Agriculture after the discovery of illegal amounts of the drug in pork.
In March 1988, the F.D.A. was jolted again when it discovered sulfamethazine residues in 5 of 49 samples of milk collected from 10 cities. Despite education campaigns and warnings from the Government, some dairy farmers continue to sell the milk of cows treated with the drug even though it is illegal to have any level of sulfamethazine in dairy products. The problem was halted after the farmers stopped adding the milk of the cows being treated to regular milk supplies.
 
Contaminated Milk in California
California, the nation's second largest milk producer behind Wisconsin, has been one of the most aggressive states in regulating violators. On Oct. 10, state inspectors discovered contaminated milk on a large dairy farm in Riverside County near Los Angeles and ordered the farm to destroy 3,300 gallons. It was the third time in a year that the California Department of Food and Agriculture had ordered a farm to dump contaminated milk, said Leon H. Jensen, the state's dairy program coordinator.
Health specialists said sulfamethazine can produce minor allergic reactions in a small percentage of the population exposed to it. The more serious problem is the research indicating the drug could cause cancer, Dr. Guest said.
''I don't think there is a serious direct public health threat,'' Dr. Guest said. ''There has been a long history of use in man. But there is a study of sulfamethazine that resulted in tumors and that's a problem. We have a law that says if you have a drug that causes tumors in animals you have to treat it ultraconservatively.''
The latest test results grew out of cancer studies begun by the F.D.A. in 1980 at the National Center for Toxicological Research in Jefferson, Ark. The long-term studies involved feeding rats and mice varying doses of sulfamethazine over two years to determine the drug's potential to cause tumors. In 1981, the first studies were halted after researchers discovered errors in the dosages fed to the rodents. A year later, new studies were begun that were completed and published in April and May.
Dr. Guest said the evidence was now strong enough to remove sulfamethazine from the market, but Government regulations require hearings and public notices before that final step is taken. The agency is waiting for the final assessment of the risk posed by the drug. Dr. Guest said that assessment might be ready by February.

HEADLINE: IN THEIR FIRST DEBATE, DINKINS AND GIULIANI GO AT IT, GENTLY

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
David N. Dinkins and Rudolph W. Giuliani mirrored the messages of their candidacies in largely gentle but unrelenting jousting last night in the first of two televised debates on the final weekend of their New York City mayoral campaign.
Mr. Dinkins, his characteristic deliberateness punctuated by several carefully aimed barbs, declared that ''what we need is a mayor, not a prosecutor,'' and said Mr. Giuliani ''doesn't like to admit he's a Republican.''
Mr. Giuliani, slightly stiff in the second debate of his political career, countered that he represented the best chance for change - ''I'm the reformer,'' he said - and was the best equipped to combat crime and drug addiction.
He painted Mr. Dinkins as a candidate of the past and said: ''People usually don't run for mayor of the City of New York who haven't paid their taxes for four years. People don't usually run for mayor of New York who are involved in so many violations of the law and ethical duties.'' 
 
Another Debate Today
Mr. Dinkins, the Democratic nominee, and Mr. Giuliani, the Republican-Liberal candidate, fielded eight questions during their hourlong debate on WABC-TV. They were joined by Henry Hewes, the Right to Life Party candidate, who will also participate in today's second and last debate at 11 A.M. on WNBC-TV.
The candidates touted what they consider their strenghths - for Mr. Giuliani, his experience as a Federal prosecutor and his political independence, for Mr. Dinkins his government experience. They also responded to perceived weaknesses - with Mr. Giuliani saying he was as compassionate as anyone else and Mr. Dinkins insisting that ''I'm no one's man but my own.''
Echoing another theme of his campaign, Mr. Dinkins repeatedly said that Mr. Giuliani did not want to say ''the R-word - he doesn't like to admit he's a Republican.''
Mr. Hewes said both his debate rivals ''stand for the status quo.'
 
'No One Has a Monopoly'
The first question - asked of Mr. Giuliani - touched on a delicate issue in the contest: how to foster racial harmony.
Mr. Giuliani, looking a bit wary but speaking in even, measured tones, repeated a theme he has sounded often in his campaign, saying, ''No one person has a monopoly on that.''
He said he favored an expanded city youth corps to provide college scholarships to young people, who would then be required to work for the city for a time. He said he would make sure his administration reflected the city's diversity.
''I think I would have a particular responsibility, given the nature of this election, to make sure that that occurred, and I'm committed to it,'' Mr. Giuliani said.
Mr. Dinkins, in his response, said it was ''important that we have role models that young people understand.'' Mr. Hewes said New York ''must see itself as a very pluralistic city.''
Mr. Giuliani responded that ''talking about unity and healing is important'' but that ''what we need to do is move this city forward again and not just talk about general platitudes.'' If crime continues to increase, he said, ''then we're actually going to have more disunity and disharmony.''
 
Tax Issue Raised Again
Mr. Dinkins was asked whether the voters should take his financial problems into consideration when assessing his managerial abilities, including his failure to file income tax returns for four years and the recent controversy surrounding his transfer of stock in a broadcasting and cable television company to his son, David Jr. ''No question about it,'' he said. ''The voters should look at my total record.''
His tax problems, Mr. Dinkins said, are ''something that occurred 20 years ago.''
''I apologized,'' he said. ''It is something that should not have happened.'' He later paid all taxes, interest and penalties.
Mr. Dinkins said there was nothing improper about the stock transfer and that he had held a long news conference detailing the transfer.
''When that was over,'' he said, ''the newspapers of this town, save one, endorsed David Dinkins with full knowledge of that.''
 
Hewes 'Not Happy' About Taxes'
Mr. Hewes said he was not ''happy that David did not pay his taxes'' but said he was nonetheless confident of Mr. Dinkins's integrity.
Mr. Giuliani said the two men were ''running almost like a ticket here.'' Then he attacked. ''One issue that is probably more important is character and integrity of the person who is going to run this city for the next four years,'' Mr. Giuliani said.
He accused Mr. Dinkins of a cover-up regarding the stock transfer and demanded that Mr. Dinkins release his stock records.
 
Old Patterns Resurface
Asked about the problems facing New York City schools, Mr. Giuliani chided Mr. Dinkins for not wanting to criticize the Board of Education, while Mr. Dinkins said the Republican-controlled New York Senate had failed to give city schools their fair share of state education aid.
The two major candidates were vague on how they would tackle the crisis that all three candidates agreed exists in city schools. Mr. Giuliani said he would trim the bureaucracy and enforce drug-free zones around the schools. Mr. Dinkins pointed to what he called his own ''fine accomplishments in the field of education,'' without being specific.
Halfway through the debate, Mr. Dinkins threw out his two main accusations against Mr. Giuliani. First, he teased him, saying he hated the ''R-word,'' and linking him to the Republican administration in Washington, which he called the source of the city's homeless problem.
''Mr. Giuliani does not like to admit that he is a Republican,'' said Mr. Dinkins. ''He gets annoyed when I call him a Republican.''
Mr. Dinkins then zeroed in on his opponent for what he characterized as his prosecutorial zeal when he served as United States Attorney for Manhattan. ''He is a prosecutor, and I appreciate that as prosecutor he has behaved rather zealously,'' he said.
 
Comfortable With Crime
Mr. Giuliani was perhaps most comfortable dealing with the subject he knows most about: crime. ''I'm glad you asked that question,'' he said when one of the panelists asked him how he would fight crime and drugs.
He ticked off a long list of proposals, saying, ''If we keep going merrily along, this city's going down.''
Mr. Giuliani said the city should attack drug trafficking as a business, arrest more drug buyers, reduce police overtime pay by improving arrest booking procedures, and press the Legislature for a death penalty and a better law to seize the property of drug dealers.
''We're going to have to start arresting people who buy drugs,'' he said. ''It's a misdemeanor; it won't overcrowd our prisons, but it'll send a message.''
Mr. Dinkins repeated his pledge to double the number of community patrol police officers in his first term, and to place a police officer on every subway train 24 hours a day. Using notes to cite dates, he criticized Mr. Giuliani for intially calling the death penalty a ''phony issue'' in the race and then later emphasizing it.
Mr. Giuliani, in his rebuttal, faulted Mr. Dinkins's proposal for putting police officers on subway trains, saying two-thirds of subway crime occurs on platforms and in stations.
On a question about how to solve the city's budget gap, Mr. Giuliani said the city needed to refinance bonds and increase the efficiency of collection of money owed the city from fines, while Mr. Dinkins also called for greater effiency in government.
 
Many Major Problems
Mr. Dinkins was asked about what he will tell New Yorkers fed up with crime, dirty streets and the lack of housing, to get them to stay in the city.
Mr. Dinkins said crime and drugs are a major problem. But housing and homelessness is also ''a serious problem.''
''Not only for humane considerations because those are God's children too that we see lying about, but almost to recognize that it adversely impacts tourism, for instance,'' Mr. Dinkins said.
''We have homeless because of poverty and lack of affordable housing,'' he said. ''Why do we have lack of affordable housing? Republican friends who slashed the budget from some $31 billion down to under seven.''
 
'Has to Get Control'
Mr. Giuliani said crime was the most important issue facing the city.
''You have to deal with first things first,'' he said. ''New York City has to reduce crime. It has to get control of the drug problem.''
Until that happens, Mr. Giuliani said, the city's problems will continue to fester.
The two candidates tried to use their closing statements to correct what were perceived as the flaws of their candidacies. Mr. Giuliani, burdened with the image of the severe prosecutor, began to smile as he delivered his final remarks, and offered his thanks from each member of his family, even listing his infant daughter, Caroline.
Mr. Dinkins, who is repeatedly asked to explain away the views of his associates, past and present, ended with a vow to be ''no one's man but my own.''
Mr. Giuliani said his mayoralty would represent a real break with the past. He said he is ''not satisfied'' with the New York of 1989, and linked the boarded-up buildings and other signs of economic devastation in New York city to the corruption that has dogged the Democratic administration in City Hall in recent years.
Mr. Dinkins, reading a prepared statement, used general phrases that asked New Yorkers ''to stand up for our beliefs,'' and appealed to the city's tradition of tolerance. ''I want to be a mayor who reaches for what is best in our instincts and in our hearts,'' he said. ''I want to be mayor for everyone.''
 
'In the Mood' Greets Dinkins
Both Mr. Dinkins and Mr. Giuliani arrived at the WABC studio on the Upper West Side nearly an hour before the debate began. Mr. Dinkins was greeted outside the studio by more than 100 supporters, who chanted his name as the big-band hit ''In the Mood'' played on a loudspeaker.
Mr. Dinkins said he felt no butterflies, and he appeared rested and confident, having found time to nap for two hours before the debate, he said.
Mr. Giuliani had addressed Hispanic ministers on the Lower East Side and white Catholics at a Knights of Columbus hall in the Marine Park section of Brooklyn earlier in the day.
Mr. Dinkins continued yesterday to wrap himself in a cocoon of prominent Democrats. Today, he is to attend a teachers union breakfast, rallies on the Lower East Side and in Queens, and a fund-raising event in Harlem.
He was formally embraced yesterday by the United States Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine, and Senator Daniel P. Moynihan of New York, Mayor Raymond J. Flynn of Boston, and Representatives Eliot L. Engel of the Bronx, Floyd H. Flake and Thomas J. Manton of Queens, Charles B. Rangel of Manhattan, and Charles E. Schumer and Edolphus Towns of Brooklyn.
 
Giuliani Lagging in Polls
Mr. Mitchell said, ''At a time when the differences between people are being exploited, at a time when division and hatred rule throughout the world on racial, ethnic and other lines, what we need are leaders who ask and reach for the best in people, who can bring people together.'' He asked voters to view the mayoral race as a referendum on negative campaigning, in which, he suggested, the Republicans had indulged.
Mr. Giuliani has been lagging 10 or more points behind Mr. Dinkins in every public opinion poll made public in the final week of the campaign. Worse still for Mr. Giuliani, the polls indicated that Mr. Dinkins had slowed or even stopped the Democratic defections that appeared to have been prompted by revelations about his stock holdings and his campaign staff, which had kept him on the defensive for much of last month.
Within about 15 minutes last night -roughly the time allotted to each candidate for answers, rebuttals and a closing statement - Mr. Giuliani needed to accomplish in person what he hoped his television commercials have been achieving: rattling Mr. Dinkins just enough so that his calm facade crumbled and exposed what Mr. Giuliani contends are flaws in judgment, character and competence.
Jabbing too hard, even Mr. Giuliani's advisers acknowledged, would be risky. A withering assault, the kind Mr. Giuliani perfected as a Federal prosecutor, reinforces his reputation among some people as mean-spirited and fails to demonstrate his compassion.
 
'Has to Remain Standing'
For Mr. Dinkins, the stakes were smaller.
''He has to remain standing,'' said Andrew Cuomo, the Governor's son and a Dinkins adviser.
''Dinkins has one asset,'' said Mark Green, another adviser. ''He's invariably been underestimated.''
Mr. Dinkins had insisted that debate invitations be extended to all four candidates of the regular parties - those whose mayoral candidates automatically qualified for the November ballot because the party's gubernatorial candidate received at least 50,000 votes in the last election. Mr. Giuliani wanted one-on-one debates with Mr. Dinkins.

HEADLINE: MORE AIR ROUTES FOR U.S. AND JAPAN

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4

 BODY:
Japan and the United States have reached agreement on a major expansion of airplane flights between the two countries, the Bush Administration said today.
The agreement, initialed at 5:30 A.M. Sunday in Tokyo after six days of intensive negotiations, will open new cities in both countries to flights by American and Japanese airlines.
Secretary of Transportation Samuel K. Skinner, in a statement, called the agreement ''the most dramatic expansion of air services to Japan since the original bilateral aviation agreement was signed in 1952.'' 
International air service is governed by agreements between pairs of nations, with each country awarding the right to fly on agreed routes to one or more of its domestic airlines.
Until the new agreement is formally ratified and route assignments made, it will not be entirely clear what airlines will serve which cities.
 
Pacific a Growing Market
The agreement opens up substantial new markets for airlines that are eager to take part in the most rapidly growing international air market, the Pacific region.
Mr. Skinner also said the agreement, coming at a time of continued tension over trade issues between the two nations, ''reflects the strength of our friendship with Japan and the importance of our economic alliance.''
The agreement covers both passenger and cargo flights, and increases the frequency of flights along existing routes, the number of cities that can be served, and the ability of airlines to make one-stop flights within the two countries.
Under the agreement, United States airlines will be able to operate along new routes between three American cities and Tokyo. They will also be given new routes from three American cities to Japanese cities other than Tokyo or Osaka.
 
New Routes to 3 U.S. Cities
Japanese airlines will gain routes from Tokyo to three new American cities, and from cities other than Tokyo or Osaka to three American cities.
The Japanese airlines will also be permitted to add one-stop continuing service to three other American cities.
And existing service by Japan Air Lines' on the Tokyo-Seattle-Chicago route will increase in frequency from five to seven flights each week.
David Prosperi, a Transportation Department spokesman, said that six American air carriers now fly between the United States and Japan, and that three Japanese airlines serve the United States.
He said the new agreement was expected to result in a 30 percent increase in flights between the two countries.
 
New Cargo Service Planned
In addition to the new passenger routes, the agreement included many provisions for new cargo air service.
While most consumers are unaware of the cargo flights, they are an important and growing market.
The United States wil be allowed to designate an additional all-cargo airline for service to japan. A currently designated all-cargo airline will be authorized to serve an additional point in Japan, chosen from three cities: Nagoya, Fukuoka or Sapporo.
The current quota of 300 annual charter flights, many of them for cargo, will be increased to 400 immediately and to as many as 450 beginning next year.
Japanese airlines will be allowed to operate eight weekly cargo flights to Chicago, and NCA, a Japanese all-cargo airline, will be allowed to serve Los Angeles and Chicago for the first time.

HEADLINE: Shanghai's Mayor Gains Credit as Pragmatist

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SHANGHAI

 BODY:
When a foreigner asks young Chinese to name the leaders that they respect, the usual response is a long silence. But a few names do spark some enthusiasm, and one that comes up most regularly is Zhu Rongji, the boss of Shanghai.
Mr. Zhu, a lean 61-year-old economic planner by background, has won a reputation as a pragmatist and a tireless promoter of Shanghai's economic development. He is seen as more concerned with economic results than with Communist orthodoxy, and thus somewhat out of tune with the central Government. That is a reputation that does him no harm with most people. 
''He's not a hard-liner, like the ones in Beijing,'' said a junior high school teacher here. ''He's really trying to help Shanghai.''
Mr. Zhu's career has soared in the last two years, and many diplomats and Chinese believe that he will earn a Politburo seat in the next year or two. It is customary for the head of China's largest city to serve on the Politburo, although this would be a big step for a man who now is only an alternate member of the Central Committee.
Mr. Zhu became Mayor of Shanghai in April 1988, and this August he assumed the additional post of Shanghai party chief. He succeeded Jiang Zemin, now the national party leader, the man whom China's senior leader, Deng Xiaoping, has picked to be the core of the next generation of leaders.
A fluent English speaker whose son is a university student in Wisconsin, Mr. Zhu has been struggling to bring new vigor to this dilapidated city of more than 12 million people. One of his first actions was to order tourism officials to arrange for all the public toilets in the city to be cleaned.
He has also struggled to attract more foreign investment to Shanghai, a particularly difficult task since the crackdown in June. Just a few weeks ago, the city announced the formation of a committee of foreign business executives to give the city special counsel.
''Shanghai seems to be getting a bit more business these days than Beijing,'' a Western executive in China said, and one explanation may be the stark contrast in leadership styles in each city. The leaders of Beijing, Party Secretary Li Ximing and Mayor Chen Xitong, are political hard-liners who vigorously denounced the democracy movement.
Mr. Zhu, on the other hand, has said very little about ideology. Just a few days ago, in one of his first major speeches since the crackdown, he called for continued economic restructuring.
Intellectuals and workers interviewed in Shanghai gave Mr. Zhu high marks for his handling of the democracy movement, and several contrasted the leniency here with the violence in Beijing.
 
Use of Troops Avoided
After the bloodshed in the capital on June 4, Shanghai erupted with demonstrations and a virtual general strike. Mr. Zhu responded with a nationally televised speech on June 8, avoiding polemics but appealing for stability and order as the way to get the economy moving.
He said the city would never call in troops; instead, civil servants were sent into the streets to clear the blockades, in as calm a way as possible.
One reason for Mr. Zhu's handling of the demonstrations may be his own painful experience beginning with the anti-rightist campaign of 1957. He was then accused of being a rightist, based on a brief speech he made criticizing aspects of the Communist system. He was officially rehabilitated only in 1979. He rose rapidly to become deputy minister of the State Economic Commission, and in 1988 he was transferred to Shanghai. A native of Hunan Province, he has proven popular here even though he cannot speak the Shanghai dialect.
One of Shanghai's most serious problems is its inability to get raw materials to run its factories, and Mr. Zhu recently made a remarkable trip to coal-producing parts of the country to plead for coal and other raw materials. The trip involved some loss of face, but it conveyed the image of a leader willing to do whatever is necessary for the city, residents say.

LENGTH: 668 words

HEADLINE: COMPROMISE ON JET IS WELCOMED ON L.I.

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BETHPAGE, L.I., Nov. 3

 BODY:
An unusual compromise agreement in Congress to build 18 F-14 fighter jets on Long Island before the program is canceled buys time to reduce the Island's dependence on defense spending, officials and business leaders officials said today.
In April, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney announced that the Pentagon had eliminated financing for the F-14D Tomcat, the largest contract for Long Island's largest employer, the Grumman Corporation. Canceling production could have meant the loss of 5,600 jobs at Grumman and more than 15,000 jobs in other related businesses on Long Island, economists said.
But on Thursday, House and Senate negotiators gave Grumman a reprieve, agreeing to buy 18 new Navy planes in the 1990 fiscal year at a cost of about $1 billion. In exchange, Grumman must promise to end F-14 production when the last jet is delivered, probably in two or three years. 
The agreement eased fears of an immediate economic reversal. ''Economic growth will slow, but instead of a jolt, it will now be a soft landing,'' said Thomas Conoscenti, an economist at Polytechnic University in Farmingdale.
 
Six-Month Campaign
Despite the highly unusual provision for eventual elimination of the program, the compromise marks a victory for Long Island's Congressional delegation, which waged a six-month all-out campaign to save the program.
Lawmakers played down the ominous-sounding termination clause, contending that the Navy's planned replacement plane for the F-14 is far behind schedule, and that more new F-14's may be needed to fill the gap.
''No Congress can bind a future Congress,'' said Representative George J. Hochbrueckner, Democrat of Coram. He is a former Grumman engineer who worked on the F-14 program.
There were sighs of relief today at Grumman headquarters here. The company has cut its work force on the Island by 6,000 to 19,000 in the last three years, largely because of the elimination of the A-6 bomber program and a general decline in Government spending on the military.
 
Remaining Competitive
''It's too early to celebrate, but we can all be pleased at the progress being made,'' the Grumman chairman, John O'Brien, said in a statement.
The compromise package must still clear the Congressional appropriations process, as well as the full House and Senate, before it reaches President Bush. But officials in Washington and Long Island said they did not anticipate any snags.
Aerospace analysts said the agreement gave Grumman time to continue to diversify into products like advanced airborne radars, computer data systems and electronic monitoring programs. At the same time, they said, it would allow the company to position itself to remain competitive if the Navy's proposed advanced tactical fighter plane is delayed. The F-14 program accounts for about 20 percent of Grumman's annual sales of $3.6 billion.
For the broader Long Island economy, the agreement staves off a bumpy period. In the last decade, defense spending has been a shrinking part of the Island's manufacturing base, accounting for 6 percent of all jobs here now compared with 15 percent 10 years ago, the chief economist for the Island's Regional Planning Board, Pearl M. Kamer, said.
''This gives the Long Island economy a couple more years to adjust to more fundamental problems,'' said Representative Thomas J. Downey, Democrat of Amityville.
Long Island's Congressional delegation - which also includes Robert J. Mrazek, a Democrat, and Norman F. Lent and Raymond J. McGrath, both Republicans - used a two-pronged lobbying strategy. Advancing an argument for national security, the lawmakers stressed the need for the Navy to replace its aging planes.
Because Grumman has operations and subcontractors in virtually every state, the lawmakers also impressed upon their colleagues that a blow to Grumman on Long Island would strike a blow to jobs everywhere. In the process, the lawmakers called in every political favor owed to them. ''I am now chitless,'' said Mr. Downey.

HEADLINE: Kean's Successor to Face Lean Times

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
New Jersey's new governor will inherit a state budget that has doubled to $12 billion in eight years but is now static and teetering on uncertain revenue projections.
Leaner economic times lie ahead, and it is generally acknowledged that Gov. Thomas H. Kean's successor will have little room to add expensive new programs unless he makes cuts in government and the budget that Mr. Kean and the Legislature have assembled since 1982.
In six budgets ending in 1987, New Jersey's spending increased an average of 9 percent a year, compared with average annual growth of 7.9 percent for all other states, according to the Washington-based Advisory Commission on Intergovernmental Relations.
In the 1987 fiscal year, New Jersey's spending was $3,034 per capita, compared to the average of $2,685 per capita for all states, according to the Tax Foundation Inc., a Washington group that studies government finance. Only five states - Alaska, Wyoming, New York, Minnesota and California -outspent New Jersey per capita. 
 
More Government Jobs
Jobs in the state's 19 departments have grown from about 58,000 to nearly 70,000 since Mr. Kean's first year, state budget officials said. About 10,000 of the 12,000 new positions, or about 83 percent, were created in the four departments that had the sharpest budget growth in the last eight years -the Department of Environmental Protection, up 170 percent; the Department of Corrections, up 159 percent; the Department of Law and Public Safety, up 127 percent, and the Department of Human Services, up 83 percent, according to the State Treasurer's office.
Of the $6.1 billion growth in state spending between mid-1982 and last July, state aid to schools accounted for the largest single portion, up $1.6 billion, or 26 percent of the total increase, the Treasurer's office said.
School aid is one of the fixed, formula-driven accounts that is taking larger portions of the state budget annually. Others include pensions for state workers and local police officers, firefighters and teachers; employee health and fringe benefits; Medicaid; welfare, and bonded debt service.
These fixed accounts consume 57 percent of the current budget.
In his budget message last January, the Governor warned that state spending for school aid, Medicaid, and pensions and health benefits could grow to two-thirds of the state budget by the year 2000, and, unless curbed, could start eroding spending for the environment, public transit, higher education and other programs.
But there is little movement for reform. And even though lawmakers held this year's $12 billion budget about even with last year's, there has been little criticism of the state's brisk spending rate this decade.
''In periods of enormous prosperity, governors and appropriation committees have a compulsive desire to spend monies that are there; that's the nature of government,'' said Bruce Coe, who heads the New Jersey Business and Industry Association.
 
Avoiding the Label of Big Spender
Despite the doubling of the budget, Mr. Kean has avoided the ''big spender'' label some attached to his predecessor, Brendan T. Byrne, who also saw the state budget double under him.
''Tom Kean's initiatives have been much more focused on symbolic improvements in the state,'' said Richard W. Roper, director of the Program for New Jersey Affairs at Princeton's Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs. Mr. Kean's principal themes have been improving the state's image, luring tourists, cutting corporate taxes to attract business and ''getting the state from under the shadow of New York and Philadelphia,'' Mr. Roper said.
But there have been some costly expansion programs, too.
Tougher new mandatory prison sentences this decade have led to construction of four state prisons, growth in daily inmate population to 20,000 from 8,000 in eight years and the hiring of nearly 4,000 corrections workers, mostly prison guards, state figures show. The prison budget has increased $291 million to $509 million.
The local school aid budget of $3.6 billion, up $1.6 billion since mid-1983, is exceeded by only six states.
The environmental department's operating budget has grown by $117.6 million to $197 million and its work force has grown by 1,400.
The human services budget, which includes $133 million in welfare payments this year and $865 million for Medicaid, has increased by $987 million, or 83.4 percent, and its staff has increased by 2,200 in the Kean years.
About 2,300 new jobs were created in the Department of Law and Public Safety to expand the state police force and staff the state's takeover of motor vehicle agencies.
But there is worry now that the rate of government expansion has outstripped the state economy's ability to pay for it. State unemployment has just climbed to 5 percent for the first time in three years. And there are already signs of slippage in revenues from sales, income and corporation taxes. Will Taxes Have to Be Raised? Richard V. Sinding, president of the Princeton-based Center for Analysis of Public Issues, believes that the new governor will be forced to raise taxes shortly after taking office.
The Democratic candidate, Representative James J. Florio, has complained that government has grown too big, and he has promised an audit to search for waste.
''He sees no need for new taxes,'' said Jon Shure, his spokesman.
His Republican opponent, Representative Jim Courter, has pledged not to raise taxes.

Sauro); Representative Jim Courter talking with Alice Salzberg yesterday at the Vineland Shopping Center in Millville, N.J. (NYT/John Sotomayor)

HEADLINE: VIDEO;
Dealers Bestow Their Laurels

BYLINE: By Hans Fantel

 BODY:
As an attempt to pinpoint superior design, it's rather like the Miss America contest. Dealers from every part of the United States vote for their favorites in video equipment, and this ballot forms the basis for the annual Grands Prix awarded by Audio-Video International, a major trade journal.
Three models are chosen in each category, and among bare-bones VCR's - i.e., the simplest and cheapest kind with monophonic sound with no pretensions to high fidelity - the winning three were Mitsubishi's HSU30R ($499), Panasonic's PV-4920 ($399) and RCA's VR450 ($399). Even though they are in the bottom price bracket, all have four separate magnetic heads rather than just two, as was the case in economy VCR's. The extra heads improve special effects, such as slow-motion or still-frame display. Mitsubishi's entry was cited for its elaborate provisions for finding a particular program segment on the tape, which is unusual in this price class. 
Panasonic's model is the only one in this group with bar-code programming. This allows the viewer to program the VCR for recording a broadcast during an absence simply by running a penlike sensor over printed program listings, provided that these listings include bar graphs. (Many of them do nowadays.) In addition, this model also offers several helpful simplifications in conventional programming, along with editing facilities and circuit refinements (such as a comb filter) to increase the clarity of the picture.
RCA's entry in this group stands out by its compactness. Only 14 5/8-inches wide, it fits in well with standard audio components in a combined audio-video installation.
Among VCR's equipped for stereo high-fidelity sound, the winners were Panasonic's PV-S4990 ($1,599), Sony's EDV-7500 ($1,950) and the JVC HR-S5000U ($1,299). Both Panasonic and JVC feature Super-VHS circuitry to achieve high image resolution of about 400 horizontal lines. This exceeds present-day television broadcast and cable transmission norms and and thus allows recording off the air (or off cable) with almost no loss of image quality.
Panasonic again features bar-code programming, and this particular model can also be programmed from afar, simply by calling it on the telephone. It responds like an answering machine, awaiting instructions to be issued through a telephone touch pad. Moreover, digital circuits are used to reduce the graininess of the image and to provide clear stills and steady slow-motion along with numerous other special effects. Indexing and quick-search devices make it easy to find a particular program segment on a tape. The JVC model also offers several convenient search and indexing methods, along with aids to editing .
The Sony is the only VCR among the Grand Prix winners that operates in the Beta format, which still has faithful adherents among videophiles intent on the best possible image quality. It will not play VHS tapes, but in the ED Beta mode (ED stands for Extended Definition) it achieves remarkable image sharpness with 500 lines of resolution - the best of any current VCR. It is therefore of particular interest to those who use their video equipment in a semiprofessional manner.
The growing demand for higher image quality has spurred interest in videodisk players, which offer a noticeably better picture than standard VHS cassettes. The swift expansion of the videodisk repertory has hastened public acceptance of this format, even though it has no recording functions and can only be used for playback.
The videodisk players mentioned here play not only all sizes of videodisks (12, 8 and 5 inches) but also handle standard (sound-only) CD records, which function on the same principle of scanning the recorded signal with a laser beam. The three winners in this group are the Philips CDV488 ($1,300), the Pioneer CLD3070 ($1,200) and the Yamaha CDV-1600 ($799).
Despite its more modest price, the Yamaha player offers excellent video quality and advanced audio circuitry featuring Yamaha's distinctive ''hi-bit'' technology to decode digital audio signals. What has been sacrificed to achieve the lower price is not basic performance but some of the special operating feeatures offered on the costlier Philips and Pioneer units.
For example, both Pioneer and Philips have a so-called jog-shuttle control. This allows the viewer to proceed stepwise from one still frame to the next either in forward or reverse direction. Moreover, the speed of the progression from frame to frame is continuously variable. A noteworthy asset of the Philips is its digital memory to store single frames, resulting in jitter-free stills and smooth slow-motion displays. Pioneer's distinction is its ability to play both sides of a videodisk without the need for manual reloading.
The video Grands Prix, like most contests of this kind, have their detractors. They point out that in a highly competitive field crowded with many entries of comparable merit, such awards are necessarily somewhat arbitrary. Yet there is no doubt that the winning models were thoughtfully chosen and clearly rank among the best.

HEADLINE: Europe's Buyout Bulge

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
The mergers and acquisitions movement that started to snowball in Europe three years ago has grown into an avalanche that is remaking the Continent's corporate landscape. That avalanche will likely continue to thunder as companies rush to prepare for the more competitive era that will result as the European Community scraps internal trade barriers by the end of 1992.
Nonetheless, the old world's takeover scene may never grow as frenzied as America's. While hostile takeovers are a way of life in freewheeling America, they disturb European gentility. The well-mannered Europeans prefer forming alliances to mounting hostile takeovers. They also have little appetite for ''junk bonds'' and leveraged buyouts.
Even so, many companies are expected to tender hostile bids, meaning the takeover climate in Europe could grow nastier. Acquisition-minded European companies began by snapping up small fry, but are now looking at bigger catches as they strain to compete with giants in America and Japan. 
''The pain level in restructuring will increase,'' said Martin Waldenstrom, chairman of Booz Allen Acquisition Services, a Paris-based merger consultant. ''A lot of small companies have been taken over; now you have to go to larger ones. They think they can remain independent, but they might not be able to. That means the hostility index will definitely go up over the next few years.''
Tensions are already mounting. Sir James Goldsmith's recent gargantuan $21 billion hostile bid for B.A.T. Industries, the British conglomerate, made even many people in London's financial district, where unfriendly offers are more common, question whether the takeover movement had reeled out of control. Nations that permit unfriendly bids are angry at others, most notably West Germany and Switzerland, where they are virtually verboten. And some American executives grumble that it is far easier for European companies to take over American companies than vice versa. Many European companies are off limits because they are state- or family-owned.
Feeding the tension is the rush by American investment banks to expand their merger and acquisition staffs in Europe. British and French investment banks have reacted by building up their own M. & A. operations, and some people now question whether there will be enough business.
''I predict a shakeout,'' said Philippe Haspeslagh, a professor at the Insead Business School in Fountainebleau, near Paris. ''Europeans will always rely less on investment bankers than Americans do because a larger portion of their activity will be done in-house and will not be hostile.''
Still, investment bankers claim there is plenty of work, at least for now. ''There will be a lot more activity throughout Western Europe as more companies concentrate on building up their core businesses,'' said Yves Istel, chairman of Wasserstein Perella International.
The takeover pace has indeed accelerated. In 1988 alone, there were close to 500 mergers and acquisitions within Europe, with the value of intra-European deals soaring to $81.5 billion last year, up from $11.1 billion in 1985. Cross-border mergers and acquisitions soared to 42.4 percent of all intra-European deals last year, up from 13.8 percent in 1985.
''The world is changing, and we have to do mergers and acquisitions to change with it,'' said Jean-Rene Fourtou, chairman of Rhone-Poulenc, the French chemicals giant that has made more than 15 acquisitions over the last two years.
 
An Overheated Market
 Hardly a day goes by without a major M. & A. announcement out of France, Britain or the Netherlands - where most targets are located. Even the staid West Germans, long considered immune to merger mania, are getting into the act as scores of entrepreneurs there who founded businesses after World War II sell their concerns as they near retirement.
The last few weeks illustrate how overheated Europe's takeover market has become. Groupe Bull, France's largest computer company, announced plans to buy Zenith's computer operations for $635 million, while Unilever, the Anglo-Dutch consumer goods giant, acquired Boursin, the French cheese company.
Meanwhile, the Scandinavian Airways System and Swiss Air announced they would buy stakes in each other, and Banque Paribas is making a hostile $2 billion bid for control of Navigation Mixte, a French conglomerate. That comes after Allianz, Germany's largest insurer, agreed to pay $1 billion for half of Navigation Mixte's insurance operations. In addition, Michelin, the French tire maker, said it would buy Uniroyal for $690 million.
''Even though the Europeans may feel what has happened is dramatic, it is nowhere yet the level it can be,'' Professor Haspeslagh said.
Europe's takeover movement began in heavy industries like steel and chemicals, which are now consolidated. Automobiles, defense and food processing were hit next.
The latest go-go area, however, is services. The European Community is just starting to break down the barriers on cross-border banking and insurance, and companies are moving quickly to take advantage. Banks in northern Europe, where population growth is stagnant, are eagerly developing bridgeheads in fast-growing southern Europe, and banks in Spain and Italy, which are ''overbanked,'' are busy consolidating.
In the last month, Dresdner Bank, Germany's No. 2 bank behind Deutsche Bank, agreed to buy France's Banque Internationale de Placement, while Westdeutsche Landesbank, West Germany's No. 4 bank, set up a joint investment bank with Britain's Standard Chartered Bank.
Meanwhile, in insurance, Groupe Victoire, a large French insurer, is paying $2 billion to acquire Colonia Versicherung A.G., Germany's No. 2 insurance company. And Axa-Midi, one of France's largest insurers, has bought Equity and Law, the British insurance company.
''All this is helping tie Europe together,'' said John A. Nelson, managing director of Lazard Brothers & Company, the London investment bank.
Officials in the banking and insurance industries say these mergers may make these financial concerns more efficient by allowing them to consolidate back-office operations. European banking titans like Deutsche Bank and Banque Nationale de Paris are confident that their takeovers will make them more formidable on the global scene.
 
Airlines Join Forces
 For now, however, the greatest ferment is in Europe's airline industry. After British Airways acquired British Caledonia last year, Swiss Air and S.A.S. formed a partnership that involves joint marketing and cross-shareholdings. Lufthansa and Air France have also signed a cooperative accord. And British Airways and Royal Dutch Airways are studying whether to buy 20 percent stakes in Sabena, Belgium's flag carrier. British Airways is seeking to buy a stake in United Airlines, while KLM is one buyer of Northwest Airlines.
''There is a globalization of the industry, and all the airlines in the world are being driven together,'' said Norman Lornie, a spokesman for British Airways. ''You can't stand still. That's the way of the world.''
The pattern in the airline industry shows how many Europeans turn to alliances instead of to expensive and often bitter takeovers. The high degree of state ownership often rules out mergers. For instance, it would be hard for Frankfurt-based Lufthansa, which is 64.5 percent state-owned, to acquire or merge with Air France, which is entirely state-owned.
The liberal attitude of Europe's antitrust laws toward joint research and development also makes mergers often unnecessary. For example, Philips N.V., the Dutch electronics giant, and Siemens A.G., West Germany's largest electronics company, formed a $1 billion venture to develop a one-megabit computer chip.
Some of the preference for alliances comes down to psychology. ''The U.S. manager typically has a greater need for control, whereas many managers in Europe are more comfortable with ambiguity and partnerships,'' Professor Haspeslagh said.
When officials at Guinness P.L.C., the London-based beer and spirits company, were looking to link up their distribution operation with a company strong in champagne and cognac, an obvious candidate was Moet-Hennessy. But rather than moving to buy the world's leading champagne and cognac maker, Guinness formed an alliance with it.
''The only people who benefit in a hostile takeover are the outgoing shareholders,'' said Anthony Tennant, Guinness's chairman.
Nonetheless, unfriendly takeovers are catching on. Sir James Goldsmith's bid for B.A.T. is a sign that huge, American-style hostile bids have arrived in Britain. Last year's hard-fought but unsuccessful bid by Carlo de Benedetti, the Italian industrialist, for Societe Generale de Belgique showed that hostile offers had jumped the English Channel to take root on the Continent. As Paribas's bid for Navigation Mixte makes clear, hostile bids have become a regular feature on Paris's Bourse.
 
Intolerant of Takeovers
 But many countries do not show the same tolerance to these bids as do France and Margaret Thatcher's laissez-faire Britain. Switzerland, Germany and the Netherlands have barriers to unfriendly takeovers that an Olympic hurdler would find difficult to overcome. In the Netherlands, the Government permits elaborate, layered antitakeover measures, while in Switzerland many companies limit shareholders to 3 percent of the voting rights, even if they own 20 percent of the stock.
In West Germany and Switzerland, the cozy links between banks and their corporate clients form, as in Japan, another obstacle. German companies lack the array of poison pills seen in the United States, but can often count on friendly German banks to rescue them from hostile attacks.
Sometimes banks will buy up shares of a targeted client to push up its stock price. Or, because many shareholders give them their proxies, these banks can vote to prevent a management ouster.
The aversion to junk bonds is another major obstacle to the success of hostile bids in West Germany and elsewhere on the Continent. ''I don't think Europe's institutional investors are prepared to go to high-yield bonds, especially given the shaky environment in the States,'' said George Taucher, a professor at the Imede business school in Lausanne.
But some merger experts say that if a landmark hostile takeover battle succeeds in West Germany, it could pave the way for others. ''Siemens would be the ideal target,'' said Carl-Matthias von der Reche, a director of corporate finance at Bank Julius Baer. ''With its 25 billion Deutsche mark cash position, it would almost pay for itself.''
 
A Lack of Reciprocity
 The German takeover market may also loosen up as many family-owned German companies go public to cash in or to raise capital to expand. This could vastly increase the number of potential targets in Germany and allay tensions with the British and Americans over the lack of reciprocity. ''There will be an evolution toward more of a level playing field,'' said Mr. Istel of Wasserstein Perella.
At the moment, the differences in attitudes among European nations are creating friction. For example, many in British complain that Siemens, the electronics concern, could make a successful hostile bid for Plessy, the British electronics company, but a British concern would almost certainly fail in a hostile offer for a West German entity. The issue came to the fore last year when Nestle S.A., of Switzerland, made a successful hostile bid for Rowntree, the British chocolate company.
Some United States Congressmen are also bothered by the lack of reciprocity and have drafted legislation to place stricter limits on foreign takeovers of American companies to even the score. While European companies spent $38 billion last year to acquire American companies, Americans doled out just $8 billion to purchase European operations. American companies have made select purchases in Europe to participate in niche markets - as evidenced by Ford Motor Company's agreement last week to buy Jaguar P.L.C. But their takeovers in Europe have been limited in large part because many multinationals established operations there long ago.
''The I.B.M.'s, Exxon's and G.M.'s would like to do acquisitions in Europe, but they find it very difficult to pick up anything of size,'' said Mr. Waldenstrom, the consultant.
Some Europeans worry that a surge in hostile takeovers would shift their focus to short-term profitability. Executives like Helmut Maucher, Nestle's chairman, and Albert Herrhausen, Deutsche Bank's chairman, argue that European companies have been able to grow slowly but surely in part because management does not have to worry non-stop about the short term as it does in America.
''We should remember that some of the countries most hostile to unfriendly takeovers have some of the most efficient economies in the world,'' Mr. Waldenstrom said. ''Look at Germany and Japan.''
Still, even in West Germany, some people like the idea of hostile bids, asserting that many companies have to be jolted into caring more about profitability. ''Some hostile takeover business in Germany would wake up some managers who have grown fat and sit there like civil servants,'' said one German fund manager.
Many Europeans, however, hope that their continent can strike a balance. ''The real dilemma,'' Professor Haspeslagh said, ''is how can you have German-style corporate decision making with an English-style market for corporate control?''

LENGTH: 2032 words

HEADLINE: Philanthropy for the 21st Century

 BODY:
The fourth-generation Rockefellers are confronted with their own mortality. As most of these heirs to one of the nation's wealthiest dynasties step deeper into middle age, they are searching for a meaningful way to leave their imprint.
In the last several years, some of the 22 fourth-generation members of the family, who range in age from 22 to 61 and call themselves ''the cousins,'' have started to take a more active role in the Rockefeller Brothers Fund, the family's main vehicle for philanthropy. They have also moved to coordinate their own personal philanthropy and moved environmental causes to the top of their agenda.
''We decided the only way we could retain our identity as a family was through shared social purpose expressed through philanthropy,'' said Steven C. Rockefeller, one of the cousins. 
The unrelated move by the Rockefeller Group last week to sell an interest in some of its choicest assets will ensure that future generations of the family have wealth if they choose to carry on the deep tradition of philanthropy established by their forebears. The sale of such showcase properties as Rockefeller Center and the Radio City Music Hall represents a forward-looking strategy. In diversifying the family's assets held in trust, which had become dominated by real estate, the Rockefeller trustees are ensuring that future Rockefellers will have resources in the 21st Century and beyond. On Monday, the company and David Rockefeller Sr., chairman of the Rockefeller Group, announced that it had sold a 51 percent stake in the company to Mitsubishi Estate Company of Tokyo.
While some of the younger Rockefeller cousins had been rumored to be interested in cashing out their interests in the company, Mr. Rockefeller insisted ''there are no payouts.'' The $846 million in proceeds from the sale revert to unbreakable family trusts established by John D. Rockefeller Jr. in 1934. The proceeds, he said, are unlikely to be distributed during the lifetimes of any of the cousins.
But they could in time provide increased income from the trusts for their children and their children's children. These future generations will carry on a philanthropic-mindedness that has been a part of the family since John D. Rockefeller founded the dynasty. Using his fortunes from the Standard Oil Company, in 1913 he created the Rockefeller Foundation, one of the country's 10 wealthiest philanthropies, with assets of $2 billion today. He leaves a legacy of great institutions including the University of Chicago, the Rockefeller University and the Rockefeller Foundation.
Shaping the youngest generation in the family's philanthropic mission starts at a tender age. For example, Alida Rockefeller Messinger, 40, says she was only 5 years old when her late father, John D. Rockefeller, 3rd, began talking to her about giving.
''My father and mother's greatest fear was that their four children might take their wealth for granted and grow up spoiled and arrogant,'' she said. ''They wanted us to learn early that with wealth comes responsibility.''
In fact, the cousins, who include physicians, lawyers, educators and environmentalists, will leave their children a strong history of philanthropy. Although the cousins' inheritance has not been quantified and extends through a network of more than 100 financial trusts, their combined annual personal contributions to philanthropic causes are said to total in the tens of millions. They contribute to the schools where they have studied, the communities in which they live and a range of highly individualized interests in the arts, sciences, health, in civil rights causes and now, increasingly in environmental movements, on both the global and local levels.
Still, the cousins have grown up in the formidable shadow of their fathers and uncles. John D. Rockefeller Jr.'s six children, the third generation of Rockefellers, formed the Rockefeller Brothers Fund in 1949, which has since been the main vehicle for the family's charitable activities.
These scions, the so-called ''Brothers Generation,'' include John D. Rockefeller 3d, who is known worldwide for his support of population control and as a patron of Asian culture; Laurance Rockefeller, a venture capitalist and conservationist; David Sr., the former chairman of Chase Manhattan, and civic leader; Winthrop, a former Governor of Arkansas, and Nelson, the United States vice president and former New York Governor.
Only Laurance, 79, and David, 75, survive. The others, including Abby, the only Rockefeller sister, died during the 1970's.
The cousins have fewer resources than the brothers. But they have established several individual foundations with their trust money.
And since the mid-80's, they have begun to exert greater influence over the affairs of the Rockefeller Brothers Fund. In 1985, Laurance resigned his seat on the board, giving the cousins 8 of 9 family seats on the fund's 17-member board. And two years ago, David Rockefeller, Jr., a board member and a leader among the cousins, succeeded his father as chairman of the fund's board.
David Jr. has played a pivotal role in reorganizing and strengthening the family institutions. And with his talents for conciliating differences, he is trying reunite the cousins, who have never been a cohesive group and many of whom have an almost obsessive insistence on privacy. At the urgings of his father, and to insure a smooth transition, David Jr. invited the other cousins as well as outside experts to help shape an agenda for the fund.
Their suggestions helped form the foundation of ''A strategy for the 80's,'' an agenda adopted by the fund in 1983. The agenda is built on a ''one world'' theme, pushing the fund further into environmental programs. While the fund was an early contributor to research on greenhouse gases and global warming, today it invests fully 40 percent of its money in programs to protect the world's water, forests, land and air resources.
The recent sale of Rockefeller Center to Mitsubishi is in keeping with that spirit of ''one world.'' David Jr. said Thursday that it was ''a reminder of how small the global village has become and the importance of close partnerships among the world's peoples and nations.''
Alluding to the new relationship between the Rockefeller and Mitsubishi interests, he added: ''The closer we operate in business, culture or the environment, the more secure and healthier we will be.''
The cousins' recent shift comes years after soul-searching. Most are now in their 40's and 50's, and came of age during the turbulent 60's, a time of campus demonstrations against the Vietnam war and clamoring for social change. Some of them marched, joined anti-war groups and supported nuclear disarmament efforts.
It was a period of alienation and confusion, and a number of them, troubled by the times and their own family identity, sought psychiatric help. Steven, 53, recalls the period as painful. Now a professor of religion at Middlebury College in Vermont, he has embraced Zen-Buddhism, which he said ''opened him up'' but has not closed him off to Christianity.
Some changed their names to disassociate themselves from the family. Sandra Rockefeller, Abby's daughter, dropped the family name and still lives privately in Cambridge, Mass.
Still, a few have high profiles. The most visible cousin is John D. Rockefeller 4th, the 52-year-old senator and former governor of West Virginia.
And most have given to their favorite causes privately. Many of the cousins are active in environmental issues. Abby M. O'Neill, the oldest of the cousins, is vice-chairman of the board of the Colonial Williamsburg Foundation. Preserving the Virginia landmark city has been an interest of the Rockefeller family since the 1920's.
Abby Rockefeller, David Sr.'s daughter, shocked some family members when she set up business in Cambridge to market a Swedish composting toilet - a concept that is beginning to catch on.
Winthrop Paul Rockefeller, Jr., 41, who is said to have inherited at least $550 million as his father's sole heir, is believed to be the richest cousin. An outdoorsman, his wide-ranging interests include serving on the boards of the Nature Conservancy, Ducks Unlimited, which seeks to protect migrating waterfowl, and the Bill Foundation, which is concerned with preserving migrating species like marlin and sailfish. He is chief executive officer of Winrock Farms, which raises livestock and crops.
The health of the environment is also a major concern of Larry Rockefeller, an attorney, and his wife, Wendy Gordan Rockefeller, an expert in toxicology. Both are on the staff of the Natural Resources Defense Council, an environmental group that campaigned successfully to remove the ripening agent, Alar, from the market. Wendy is also a co-chairperson with Meryl Streep of Mothers and Others for Pesticide Limits, a public education campaign that called attention to the dangers of the Alar, which is sprayed on apples.
Social causes also a favorite cause among the cousins. David Jr.'s private philanthropic interests focus on strengthening American public education. He is chairman of Recruiting New Teachers, an organization in Cambridge that elicited almost 250,000 responses to a campaign by the Advertising Council seeking pre-college instructors.
Two years ago, Dr. Lucy Waletzky, a Washington psychiatrist and co-founder of the Medical Illness Counseling Center, created ''DateABLE,'' in Chevy Chase, Md., a service that helps people who live in isolation with and without physical disabilities to meet and make social contacts. ''It's a dating service with 200 members and chapters now in San Antonio and Cleveland,'' she said.
Alida Rockefeller supports a radio station owned and operated by the Oglala Indians on the Pine Ridge reservation in South Dakota. Neva R. Goodwin, an economist, serves on the board of the College of the Atlantic, a small institution in Bar Harbor, Me., which gives only one degree - in human ecology.
In the cousins group, where women outnumber men, Laura R. Chasin has taken the lead in carving out an interest in ''reproductive responsibility,'' the name she gives a bundle of concerns including contraceptive research and pro-choice and civil rights issues. ''I'm prepared to spend the next 20 years learning what I have to know,'' she said after calling together an informal meeting of experts this summer to outline a possible philanthropic role in these causes.
Although their interests remain wide-ranging, the cousins are developing new cohesion in their private philanthropic efforts. Two years ago, they formed a Family Philanthropy Committee. Headed by Steven Rockefeller, the group meets every two months toidentify areas of mutual interest and collaboration. Three generations sit on the 10-member committee: David Rockefeller Sr., seven members of the fourth generation and two from the fifth.
In addition, the cousins appointed Ira S. Hirschfield to head another committee to more closely coordinate the philanthropic endeavors of the individidual family members, the Rockefeller Brothers Fund and the Rockefeller Family Fund, a smaller philanthropy, with $34 million in assets, createdin 1967 to serve as a training ground for the young family members.
The arrangement was made in part because of the dovetailing interests of the cousins and the foundations. For instance, because of an initiative by Larry Rockefeller, the Rockefeller Family Fund was prompted to support the Conservation Law Foundation, which using litigation, has pressured utilities to develop energy-conservation practices.
That the cousins are impelled to continue their great-grandfather's legacy was underscored when the family and guests convened to honor the patriarch's 150th birthday last weekend at his 2,700-acre Pocantico Hills estate, with a sweeping view of the Hudson.
As David Rockefeller Jr. reflected the accomplishments of that ''legendary man,'' he asked the group to ponder several thoughts. ''What is the current plight of man?'' he asked the group. ''What is the condition of our planetary nest? And what is philanthropy doing to respond to these conditions?''

HEADLINE: WEEK IN BUSINESS;
Computer Trading Put on a Leash

BYLINE: By STEVE DODSON

 BODY:
Curbs on computerized trading of stocks are being established by the Big Board in an effort to reduce market volatility. The New York Stock Exchange chairman, John J. Phelan, said investor confidence was being eroded by violent swings in stock prices. Pressure for such a move has been mounting in reaction to the 190- point plunge in the market on Oct. 13 and the volatility in subsequent days. In the last two weeks most big Wall Street firms, under prodding from large clients, said they would cease index arbitrage for their own accounts. The Big Board's changes include asking large traders to refrain from trades that ''destabilize'' the market and curbing the use of a computerized order system when stock prices are falling. The first limit on program trading, a 15-minute delay on orders, would be imposed when the Dow Jones industrial average has fallen 30 points. 
 
*
 Ford is buying Jaguar for $2.38 billion. The deal for the British luxury car maker ends a sparring match between Ford and General Motors, which had been talking all year with Jaguar about a linkup. Ford is paying $13.32 a share, twice what Jaguar was selling for in mid-September when Ford said it wanted to seek control. G.M. said the price Ford was paying ''could not be justified.'' Jaguar last year made 51,939 cars, and it is barely breaking even. Analysts said Ford would try to capitalize on Jaguar's prestige by investing heavily to turn the company into a high-volume maker of cars selling for $30,000 to $40,000.
Chrysler is retrenching, laying off 4,000 workers and ending production of its subcompact Dodge Omni and Plymouth Horizon.
 
*
 Jobs data showed strength in the services sector but further weakening in manufacturing. The unemployment rate was unchanged in October at 5.2 percent and the economy added 233,000 jobs. The expectation for jobs growth had been about 150,000, and analysts said the large number would discourage the Federal Reserve from making any moves soon to lower interest rates. On the other hand, the manufacturing sector posted its seventh straight month of declines, losing 13,000 jobs.
The index of leading indicators inched up two-tenths of 1 percent in September. Other September data showed sales of new homes falling 14 percent while factory orders and construction remained unchanged.
 
*
 Control of Rockefeller Center was bought by Mitsubishi Estate of Japan. For $846 million in cash, Mitsubishi will get 51 percent of the Rockefeller Group, whose portfolio includes some of mid-Manhattan's most valuable and well-known properties, like Radio City Music Hall. Mitsubishi is part of a 28-company empire that includes the auto maker. It will now be the landlord of some big names in American business, including Time Warner, NBC, and Morgan Stanley. David Rockefeller said the deal was an effort to diversify the investments of the family trust.
 
*
 The stock market meandered, with the strongest move, a 41-point gain, coming on Tuesday. But a poor earnings report from Compaq Computer depressed the technology stocks and the overall market. At Friday's close the Dow stood at 2,629.51, a gain for the week of 32.79 points. Bond prices turned down on Friday after the jobs report was taken as a sign that the Fed will not be easing interest rates soon. Gold prices reached $380 an ounce, a three- month high.
 
*
 A 9.7 percent stake in UAL has been accumulated by Coniston Partners, a New York buyout firm that said it would seek control of the board of the company, which is the United Airlines parent. Coniston said it did not intend to break up UAL but wanted to take actions to increase the stock price. A $300-a-share bid by UAL pilots and managment fell apart last month, contributing to the big Oct. 13 plunge in the stock market. UAL shares have since traded around $180.
 
*
 A $3.1 billion offer was made by Georgia-Pacific for Great Northern Nekoosa. The unsolicited bid was considered a shocker in the paper and forest-products industry, which had a reputation as a ''gentlemen's club'' in which members did not raid one another. Great Northern was cool to the offer it described as ''uninvited.'' The day of the announcement Great Northern's shares soared more than $20 to nearly $63, a sign that Wall Street expects the $58-a-share bid to be topped.
 
*
 Miscellanea. Sears's chairman said the headquarters tower in Chicago might not be sold after all. The company is believed to be having trouble getting the $1 billion or more it wants for the world's tallest skyscraper . . . Miller Brewing said it would introduce a beer-flavored no-alcohol drink next year . . . Reebok introduced a $170 pair of inflatable basketball shoes.
