HEADLINE: BUSINESS FORUM: WALL STREET'S DILEMMA;
Program Trading Is Not the Culprit

BYLINE: By PAUL T. JONES; Paul T. Jones is chairman of the Tudor Investment Corporation, a futures oriented money management firm in New York.

 BODY:
Program trading bashing has become as fashionable today as attacking Communists was during the McCarthy era. Ban program trading -or so the argument goes - and stock market volatility will dissappear, the Dow Jones Industrial Average will stabilize and the small investor will return to the market. It is an appealing argument, consistent with the feel-good, forget-reality philosophy that has been pervasive in the country since 1980.
But the argument does not address the fact that stock market volatility levels in 1987 (and by implication, 1989) were, according to the Brady Commission Report on the 1987 market collapse, ''no higher than those seen at times in the early 1970's and 1940's, and are substantially lower than the levels attained at various points in the 1930's'' when of course there was no program trading. 
The argument also does not address the fact that a 2800 Dow cannot be legislated or mandated. Markets go where the underlying fundamentals dictate they will go, irrespective of program trading. And the argument fails to address the fact that asking the small investor to come back to the market to compete with today's professionals is like asking me to fight Mike Tyson.
Blaming 10 institutions and a few computers for the $200 billion worth of destruction that occured on Oct. 13, is a dangerous mistake. For program trading and the very existence of stock index futures are symptomatic of - and not causal to - the problems we face with capital formation in the United States in general.
Since 1980, the persistent message from Washington has been that debt and leverage are responsible and useful tools in the conduct of Government policy and private business. But if there is anything that contributes to volatility, it is leverage. How can one fault members of the investment community who utilize 5 percent margins when some Government agencies are operating with negative net worths.
The above discussion is important but still leaves untouched the substantive question of the merits of program trading. Specifically, does program trading add anything to the capital formation process and does it add unwanted volatility? I believe that in isolated instances program trading adds to volatility in the very short-run - hours and days - not weeks and months.
At the same time, stock index futures do provide an excellent hedging vehicle for investors. Because they provide this hedging mechanism these instruments may induce certain large investors to commit larger percentages of their assets to securities. In this way, program trading would contribute positively to the capital formation process.
Even so, the public's perception is that program trading is a destabilizing influence. This perception is a problem that must be addressed. There are two possible solutions: First, ban program trading, which in turn will virtually eliminate trading in stock index futures.
The other, better, approach would be to increase margins on futures contracts to 20 percent and simultaneously impose an immovable 2 percent daily price limit on the stock index and options futures markets. These steps would dampen speculation in futures and options, thereby reducing volatility. These actions also should prevent futures from leading the underlying cash market in periods of panic when logic and reason are as scarce as career Yankee baseball players. Price limits force people using futures and options as substitutes for buying or selling shares to return to the cash market.
If these proposals were in operation, portfolio insurance, which is based on program trading, would never have existed in 1987, and many of the worst fears of a futures related sell-off would be mitigated. Trading without limits has no merit for it presupposes people always act in a rational fashion.
It is my hope that historians do not make the mistake of attributing the crashes of 1987 and 1989 to program trading and stock index futures. They are but one part of a much larger fiscal and social debt problem. I am also not sympathetic to the fund managers' cries against program trading because I believe their participation in leveraged-buyouts is economically destructive. In my opinion, buyouts induce more volatility over the long-term than the most egregious occurrences in the futures markets.
As to those Congressional critics of program trading, I suggest they first help resolve America's real problems by undertaking a new commitment to fiscal responsiblity and discipline. Unless the Government and private sector address the real and rapidly growing problem of excess leverage, America's markets in the 1990's may face an unprecedented level of volatility, for which there will be no one to blame but ourselves.

GRAPHIC: Paul T. Jones (NYT/John Sotomayor)

HEADLINE: Japan's Foreign Aid Problem

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
Yoshito Kimura has a $23.5 billion headache.
As director of development policy at the Export-Import Bank of Japan, that's how much he has to help the Government lend to the third world as part of Japan's ambitious effort to ''recycle'' its cash surpluses to heavily indebted countries. Mr. Kimura's problem is that he has a mere five professionals and a handful of personal computers to evaluate the dozens of exceedingly complex loan proposals that cross his desk.
Kanetaka Kijima, deputy director of the department recycling Japanese capital to countries in Europe, the Middle East and Africa, also has a problem; he has discovered that, as the Export-Import Bank studies loan proposals from poor African countries, a part of the world all but ignored by the Japanese previously, he does not have enough officials who speak French, the region's most common language.
These are just a few examples of the hurdles, both large and small, that the Japanese Government must overcome as it faces a challenge unlike any it has tackled before - helping Japan by helping the world. 
It is nearly three years since former Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone set the nation on this new course, in response to heavy criticism from the United States and other industrial countries over its one-sided trade policies and growing trade surpluses. Since then, Japan has surpassed the United States as the world's largest aid donor and has set a goal of recycling a total of $65 billion over the next three years to countries drowning in debt.
The principal lesson, however, is that it is one thing to declare such worthy intentions and something else to carry them out. The effort is requiring a new range of skills, the retraining of bureaucrats, the cooperation of many departments used to squabbling and a more generous attitude among the Japanese. There is even a problem getting the resources to do the job.
''These loans are more one-by-one, hand-crafted work, and that is more difficult,'' said Takashi Tanaka, the Export-Import Bank's president. ''But because we're a Government institution our resources are limited, and we have to just emphasize a greater effort on the part of our existing people.''
In fact, all of these changes are proving difficult. ''The Prime Minister has said that Japan should make some contribution to global economic management, and we should praise the Government for that,'' said Hiroya Ichikawa, deputy director for international cooperation at the Keidanren, the powerful trade group representing Japan's largest companies. ''But in designing the program we believe they did not achieve their aim. The house is divided on specifics.''
It seems fitting that the focus of the bumpy transformation is the Export-Import Bank, which in its 39 years has been at the forefront of the Government's efforts to promote corporate interests with low-cost loans.
The Japanese economy has been through several tough readjustments during those years, like the oil shocks of the 1970's. But each time, the resilient bank used its lending power to help Japanese corporations rebound stronger than before. It has become a metaphor for Japanese adaptability.
The bank's latest odyssey started in 1986, when Japan began a major economic restructuring to counter the growing criticism of its policies. Among the measures was a program to stimulate Japan's economy in the hope that that would encourage more imports. Another idea was helping the developing world with a combination of loans through the Export-Import Bank and direct aid, handled by other Government agencies.
The timing was critical for the bank. Its traditional mission was winding down, in part because it had done its job so well. With Japanese companies able to compete internationally on their own, they were paying off their old loans from the bank faster than they were taking out new ones. The bank had to find a new mission or watch itself disappear.
''They had quite a lot of money coming in and they were looking for a role,'' said Mami Mizutori, a senior official of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
Japan made its first commitment to recycle some of its trade surpluses to the ailing developing countries in 1986, with a $10 billion program. A year later, an additional $20 billion was committed. Of that amount, the Export-Import Bank was expected to lend about $10 billion over two years. The purpose was to help the countries crawl out from their crushing debt burdens by stimulating productive new industries or helping their economies readjust.
When Japan announced this summer that it would recyle another $35 billion, the Export-Import Bank's overall total rose to $23.5 billion. It has until the spring of 1992 to lend the money. An important reason for the program is that the private sector has demonstrated far different priorities in recycling its share of the Japanese surpluses. Most of this investment goes into American securities, not developing countries, Government figures show.
But the new credits pose a challenge. Traditionally, the bank's financings were tied to helping Japanese companies. There had been a modest amount of what was called ''untied'' lending during the 1970's to support energy development projects in countries like Indonesia. But even in those cases, the energy products were shipped to Japan. Because of that background, Japan's new push on recycling has been met with skepticism in many countries. Many refused to believe that Japan had really abandoned its old commitment to helping Japanese companies first.
That skepticism has not dissuaded the Export-Import Bank from moving ahead. In mid-1986, it lent $80 million to a project in Colombia in a co-financing with the World Bank. The next year it lent $900 million for several projects in Indonesia. As part of the package, private banks lent $300 million - after getting loan guarantees from the Export-Import Bank - and the World Bank lent $2.9 billion. More deals have followed. The benefit of co-financing is that the World Bank is far more experienced in evaluating such loans, and the Japanese can rely on its judgments. In addition, co-financing has helped the Export-Import Bank fend off criticism that it was choosing loan recipients out of self-interest.
As a result, untied lending has soared. From nothing in 1984, it jumped to 467 billion yen in 1987 and 865 billion yen (about $6.5 billion) in 1988, or 59 percent of the year's total credit commitments. At the same time, the amount of traditional lending has declined significantly.
The shift has brought with it some serious problems. Loans to governments already heavily in debt entail far more risk than the bank's traditional credits. ''We have to adhere to sound banking principles, and we intend to keep to those principles,'' said Mr. Tanaka, the bank's president. ''But the portion of risky assets is increasing.''
Another problem is that an original aim of the untied lending was to encourage private banks to continue providing credits. That has been an important aim of the debt-reduction plan proposed by the United States Treasury Secretary, Nicholas F. Brady. Yet this participation has been slow to follow.
There is also some fear within the bank that, as its clientele changes, it will lose the support of Japanese industry, which has been important in the past. Mr. Tanaka denied that this was a problem, but others disagreed.
''There is concern that as we make untied loans we will lose contact with Japanese industries and lose our domestic support,'' said Mr. Kimura, the director of development policy. ''If there were some movement to abolish the bank, the foreign countries will have no voice here. So we have to strike a balance. We still have to support business in one form or another.''
That is a view shared by many important business executives. Mr. Ichikawa of the Keidanren said his organization was strongly opposed to the untied lending policies because they ignored the expertise that the Japanese private sector could bring to bear in helping the indebted countries build their economies. ''Untied money is just throwing it away,'' he said. ''You have a lot more vitality and experience in the private sector and that should be used.''
As a result, Keidanren has set up its own rival aid effort, called the Japan International Development Organization Ltd.
Mr. Tanaka shared at least one concern - that Japan not come to look like a cash dispenser machine. ''The important thing for Japan is to have a grand design for lending,'' he said. ''We do not want to create the image that someone in the third world can push a button and they get Japanese money. We want a plan so that we accomplish something.'' And he admitted that such a plan has yet to be put in place.

HEADLINE: Here Comes the Fiber-Optic Home

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

DATELINE: CERRITOS, Calif.

 BODY:
A team of telephone installers from the GTE Corporation is busy at work in this affluent suburb south of Los Angeles stringing fiber-optic cables into 600 homes, replacing the traditional copper wires that have been used since the invention of the telephone. The experiment - one of many being conducted around the country - will usher in what communications experts see as a new information age in the United States in which fiber-optic cables vastly increase the amount of audio, video and computer data that can flow in and out of the home.
The experiments represent the first step in bringing fiber-optic connections to the nation's residences in the 1990's. The trials are possible because a single thin strand of glass fiber carrying pulses of laser light can transmit hundreds of thousands times more information than the traditional pair of copper wires.
Fiber-optic cables are already widely used in long distance lines and between local telephone exchanges. But extending them into the home could create vast new markets for residential electronic information services that are expected to range from on-line shopping to delivery of entire newspapers electronically and the creation of a new generation of smart home appliances that will combine the functions of televisions, computers, facsimile machines and telephones. Visionaries foresee such things as home banking, electronic mail, picture telephones and customized television feeds becoming standard home fare. 
They envision a nationwide web of fiber-optic cables reaching into homes, tying into a network of fiber-optic ''superhighways'' and connecting residences with large government and private institutions.
But now some Congressmen, consumer advocates, researchers and even fiber-optic proponents are beginning to question the consequences of this technology. They warn that fiber-optic networks may be deployed only for those who can afford the new services. This raises the possibility of creating an information technology elite and erecting a new, electronic wall between rich and poor. ''If it's modernization only, that means that fiber will be first offered in new homes and that tends to push it to the wealthiest,'' said Philip A. Wilkinson, director of strategic planning for the American Telephone & Telegraph Company.
Marc Rotenberg, Washington director of Computer Professionals for Social Responsibility, a lobbying group, said: ''I'm uneasy because it's an opportunity for the telephone companies to stratify services so they can add to existing services with more profitable ones. That's potentially exciting, but it starts to move many people to the margins of the telephone network.''
 
Inner City Lags
 A recent report from the Stanton/Heiskell Center for Public Policy in Telecommunications and Information Systems of the City University of New York warns that the inner city is not keeping pace in new telephone developments. It describes a future where increasingly advanced communication and data services will be offered to telecommunications ''affluentials'' while maintaining only a minimal ''telephone safety net'' for low-income consumers.
Another concern is that fiber-optic networks may divide urban from rural. Richard Adler, a telecommunications industry analyst at the Institute for the Future in Menlo Park, Calif., tells of recently receiving a call from an economic development official in a small Iowa town who said a fiber-optic cable being laid between two larger cities was by-passing his community. The Iowan's complaint echoed a concern often expressed two decades ago by small communities as the interstate highway system was being built and bypassed them.
''There's the danger that older telecommunications networks in small towns will become the equivalent of the Route 66 of the 21st century, with the same failing motels and roadside businesses,'' Mr. Adler said. ''Modern businesses are increasingly making location decisions based on the quality of the telecommunications infrastructure.''
Reese Schonfeld, president of Opt In America, a Washington lobbying organization for fiber-optic networks, points out that the networks have a vast potential for offering interactive education via video and computer links and would be ideally suited to bringing higher-quality education to rural areas and revitalizing small towns. But such links are unlikely to be installed without Government intervention, either with financial assistance or by requiring telecommunications companies to make the installations in return for being allowed to offer new services.
''The most money to be made is at the top end of the market,'' said Gene Kimmelman, legislative director for the Consumer Federation of America in Washington. ''Certain segments of the market will be underserved unless the Government steps in.''
Many fiber-optic proponents fear that letting market forces alone drive the installation of fiber-optic cable into homes will delay widespread development of networks. American electronics companies could miss significant opportunities to develop and sell new products that take advantage of the networks' possibilities. Foreign companies might then step in and both install the networks and offer the services and necessary equipment to take advantage of them.
Experts have estimated that it will cost more than $200 billion to replace the copper network that currently carries telephone service to the nation's 90 million homes. As of now, it is not clear who would foot the bill. New services like home shopping and interactive television are frequently advanced as revenue-generating businesses capable of generating enough profits to pay for installing fiber-optic cables in residences. For now, revenue from basic telephone service alone does not appear to offer sufficient incentive.
Moreover, today the cost of installing fiber-optic links from local telephone company offices to the home is about twice as much as the $1,500 price tag for copper wire. The most optimistic telephone industry officials are predicting it will be cheaper to install fiber optics by the middle of 1991 or 1992. But others say it may be the middle of the next decade before the break-even point is reached.
 
Debating Issues
 Only recently has Congress begun to grapple with these issues. The most attention has been focused on a proposal by Senator Albert Gore Jr., Democrat of Tennessee, for construction of a fiber-optic computer network at an estimated cost of $1.9 billion to link the nation's supercomputer centers. Senator Gore argues that the broad availability of new information services delivered on fiber-optic networks will depend on Federal projects like his proposed supercomputer network to perform a ''pump priming'' function.
''Right now it's a chicken-and-egg problem,'' he said. ''We need to find some way to start the information flow. Once the information starts flowing there will be lots of commercially viable businesses created.''
But Representative Ed Markey, Democrat of Massachusetts, is concerned that the project might merely provide advanced network services to leading scientific researchers but do little for most Americans.
 
Universal Service
 ''The underlying principle of universal service has been part of the communications act since 1934,'' said Mr. Markey. ''If we construct something that is just in the hands of the elite, then we limit the national potential even as we augment the power of a small group. We need to work on these issues in such a way that access is determined by technology and not economics.''
Backers of the Gore plan warn that if the Federal Government and American businesses do not move quickly to install fiber networks in the home, foreign companies will do so as demand develops because American companies will lack the expertise. ''It's not a question of whether fiber networks will arrive, but when,'' said Mr. Wilkinson of A.T.&T.
A.T.&T. officials note that while the United States is debating telecommunications policy issues, both Europe and Japan are making rapid progress toward advanced communications networks. For example, Nippon Telephone & Telegraph is planning to spend more than $200 billion during the next decade on a new fiber-based network in Japan.
Meanwhile, which companies would be allowed to offer residential information services via a fiber-optic network remains a contentious issue in Congress. Under 1984 legislation designed to protect the cable TV industry, telephone companies are barred from delivering video signals to the home. But in recent years, ''fiber-to-the-home'' has become a rallying cry for the telephone companies. Several bills have been introduced that would permit them to own cable television franchises. And Senator Gore and Representative Rick Boucher, Democrat of Virginia, are sponsoring legislation that would allow them to offer their own cable television services.
''There is not going to be a Government program that will bring fiber to the home. It just costs too much money,'' Senator Gore said. ''The way to do it is to create markets.'' He believes that allowing telephone companies to compete with cable television will provide the necessary incentive.
Telephone industry officials have said that the revenues generated from delivering special video services to the home, like an evening of customized television, is the surest way to create the economic upsurge necessary to finance construction of fiber-optic networks. But telephone industry entrance into the cable television business is bitterly opposed by both the cable television industry and the nation's newspapers, which fear a loss of advertising revenue if telephone companies are allowed to provide informational services.
''I don't think that Congress relishes the idea of unleashing these monopoly phone companies,'' said Dennis Mangers, senior vice president of the California Cable Television Association. ''The telephone companies want to be the only wire to the home and they want to do it at the ratepayers' expense.'' The cable industry argues that it is modernizing its own networks - which are free of competition in most cases - as consumer demand for new services increases. It contends that consumer appetite for new services is far less than the telephone companies predict.
To circumvent the current restrictions, telephone companies are establishing strategic alliances with cable providers. GTE, for example, has an arrangement with Apollo Cablevision, which has the cable television franchise in Cerritos. GTE provides local telephone service and has separately contracted to install either coaxial cable, which television uses, or fiber-optic cable to all 16,000 homes in the town. Apollo will then lease access to the cables to provide 36-channel television to the homes.
Telephone companies are also studying ways to increase communication using fiber-optics. For example, at Bell Communications Research, the research laboratories of the seven regional telephone companies, scientists are experimenting with a ''video wall'' that uses fiber-optic cable to link two laboratories 50 miles apart. The wall consists of a giant television screen and a high-quality sound system at each location that is actually built into the wall of a room. Video and audio singals from each location are transmitted between the two sites and workers chat naturally, as if they were separated only by a window. Such technology might provide the basis for home videophone applications.
''Ultimately, fiber-to-the-home permits you to think of communications in a new way,'' said Norwood G. Long, director of fiber optics at A.T.&T.'s Bell Laboratories. ''The fiber-optic network becomes a pipe rather than a channel. You can approach infinity in terms of what you can put over the pipe.''

HEADLINE: Prospects;
An Even Slower Economy

BYLINE: By JOEL KURTZMAN

 BODY:
The economy grew by 2.5 percent in the third quarter, and the unemployment rate for October was virtually unchanged from the month before at 5.3 percent. But employment did soften in the manufacturing sector as sales of American-made autos plummeted. So where is the economy headed? Four economists offer their views.
 
Walter Joelson
Chief economist, General Electric Company. 
 The economy is clearly slowing down and will probably have a dose of stagnation in 1990. The growth rate for 1990 will be below 2 percent. But we won't have a recession. The reason for not expecting a recession is the increasing internationalization of the economy. We can avoid the bottlenecks that accompanied recoveries in the past. Basically all industry now has excess capacity and surpluses so supplies are plentiful. We also don't have a capital shortage - which is perverse since there is a budget deficit - because of the flow of funds from abroad. So the normal recessionary forces are not present.
Two areas that will outperform the rest of the economy will be investment in capital equipment and also merchandise exports. Equipment, electric utilities facilities, aircraft, telecommunications and medical equipment will all be strong domestically and for export. G.E. has seen a 60 percent increase in its export orders in the first half of 1989.
 
Albert Wojnilower
Economist and senior adviser, First Boston Corporation.
 Because of a fully employed labor force, we can only grow at about 2.5 percent and that is more or less what we've been doing, subject to measurment problems with the statistics. The softening of the manufacturing sector does not reflect any change in underlying demand but instead shows that worldwide supplies are ample and inventories have built up.
In the current quarter, we won't make the 2.5 percent growth rate because of the strike at Boeing, the damage from the earthquake in California and the aftermath of Hurricane Hugo. We'll have only about 1.5 percent growth this quarter. The first quarter of 1990 will be better. The decline of the stock market has had no effect on the economy except that lenders are more cautious about lending.
 
Lawrence Chimerine
Economic consultant and senior economic adviser, WEFA Group Inc.
 The economy has slowed further and the underlying growth rate is now 1 to 1.5 percent. It is softer than three to four months ago. We are not in a recession, not yet. But we are losing some of the pockets of strength. Growth in exports is slowing and capital spending has also really slowed down. There is nothing propelling the economy upwards. Retail is weak, construction is weak. But I think we'll get through this without a recession. Consumer confidence has held up. Spending on cars is off, but consumer spending is up. It's not strong, but there are no cutbacks.
 
Robert B. Reich
Professor of political economy, John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University and author of ''The Resurgent Liberal.''
 The third quarter is disappointing. Purchasing managers are slowing down their purchases and there are early signs of a softening if not a recession over the next six months.
The Federal Reserve is not in a stimulative mood and Mr. Greenspan has signalled his interest in reducing inflation to zero. The fiscal stimulus is also slowing down, not because of a budget compromise, but because there are reductions in outlays on the Federal and state levels.
The trade picture also looks bleak. Exports have picked up, but imports are also high. Already, there are signs of a recession in New England and California. Third quarter profits in high tech are a disaster. Even in mature industries like steel, there is a slowdown. And I'm concerned about American automobile companies. It's not going to be a very merry Christmas.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS FORUM: WALL STREET'S DILEMMA;
Volatility Is Causing Investors to Flee

BYLINE: By JOHN H. GOLDSMITH; John H. Goldsmith is chairman and chief executive of John Hancock Freedom Securities Corporation, a holding company which owns the brokerage firms of Tucker Anthony Inc. and Sutro & Company.

 BODY:
Recently I went to Washington to visit with the Securities and Exchange Commission. I met with three commissioners and their staffs the day before the S.E.C. was to approve the New York Stock Exchange's request to permit trading of the new basket of stocks based on the Standard & Poors 500. I was there to make a last minute appeal to delay this attempt to experiment with our securities markets because I believe the basket will increase volatility. But my attempt to stop this form of basket trading failed and the basket was approved the day after my visit.
In response to my complaints that investors are being driven from our markets due to the volatility caused by program trading and index arbitrage, one of the young staff memebers of the S.E.C. said: ''The role of the commission is to protect the markets, not to protect the investor.'' 
Puzzled by this remark, on my return I asked a colleague to check the legislative history of the 1934 act to see whether my assumption about the basis of the securities act was really wrong. He did not have to look far. President Roosevelt, in his message to Congress on Feb. 9, 1934 forwarding what would become the act said: ''I therefore recommend to the Congress the enactment of legislation providing for the regulation by the Federal Government of the operations of exchanges dealing in securities and commodities for the protection of investors, for the safeguarding of value and, so far as may be possible, for the elimination of unnecessary, unwise and destructive speculation.''
We have allowed our financial markets to become casinos and we have focused our regulatory attention on the development of rules to regulate a host of derivative securites that make our markets safe for the players and traders - for the most part a few large institutions and large Wall Street firms. In so doing, we have fostered the same unecessary, unwise and destructive speculation that characterized the markets of the 1920's, by allowing the managers of large pools of capital to create and profit from market volatilty.
The position of our securities and commodities regulators seems to be that what happens in the casino - the New York Stock Exchange, the Chicago Board Options Exchange and the other futures exchanges - is somehow separate and exclusive from the primary market where a business raises capital.
This attempt at intellectual rationalization conforms neither to basic economics nor to the realities of the marketplace. The ability of the country's businesses to raise capital from investors is dependent on the stability of the markets. Market volatility caused by program trading and index arbitrage is causing large and small investors to liquidate their portfolios.
How did we get so far off the track? Where did we lose sight of the reasons for regulating our markets for securities and commodities? The essence of the problem is the index futures contract, without which there could be no index arbitrage. An index future is a wholly artificial device which represents a bet on the future price of a group of stocks, such as the Standard & Poors 500.
This device allows traders to arbitrage between what is perceived to be the future value of the market and the market's current value measured by the prices of the stocks themselves. While I would argue that the index future is without economic validity and diverts capital from the real equity markets, its mere existence might be tolerable.
However, index futures are traded as commodities with one set of rules regulated by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission and the stocks they represent are traded elsewhere with different rules regulated by the S.E.C. Arbitrage between differences in values is one thing, but there is no place for arbitrage between the rules of two regulatory bodies.
If I thought there was any hope of success, I would fight to eliminate the index future contract altogether. Because the volume of the index future represents such a significant percentage of the total volume of the politically powerful commodities exchanges, such a fight would be doomed. It is essential, however, that we fight to eliminate the regulatory arbitrage that occurs between the index future as a commodity and the represented stocks. This means insisting upon one overseeing regulatory authority for both markets with a similar set of rules relating to margins, short sales and general trading policies. Creating a level playing field here will make great strides in the elmination of the unnecessary, unwise and destructive speculation that is creating the volatility in our equity markets.
In recent days, major trading firms have responded to public pressure by agreeing to stop their index arbitrage activities in whole or in part. We heard the same promises in 1987. Now is the time to act.

GRAPHIC: John H. Goldsmith (NYT/Jim Estrin)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS FORUM: HOW TO BALANCE TRADE;
Lord Keynes Had It Right the First Time

BYLINE: By JEFFERY E. GARTEN; Jeffrey E. Garten is a managing director of The Stamford Company Inc., an investment banking firm in New York.

 BODY:
Few would deny that America's spending and borrowing must be brought under control if our gigantic international trade and financial imbalances are to be corrected. But in a seamless, global economy this is only half of the picture. What about the responsibilities of Japan and Germany, both of which have staggering surpluses?
The notion that countries with deficits and surpluses have obligations to change their policies may seem obvious enough. Through most of this century, however, only deficit nations have had to face the music. 
For them, it has been easy to define what should be done - tighten belts, increase productivity, devalue currencies. It has also been possible to force them to change policies. After all, foreign lenders could always bring deficit nations to heel by raising the price of their loans or threatening to stop leanding altogether.
But it has been almost impossible to tame the surplus nations. They have equated their riches with hard work, quality and other virtuous behavior. And their very economic strength made them impervious to outside pressure.
When America was the overwhelming power in the world economy, it was as arrogant and protective of its autonomy as any surplus nation ever was. But since then a lot has changed as the United States has become the largest debtor and trade deficit country, and Japan and Germany have become strong economiies with chronic trade surpluses. Although trade imbalances - like budget deficits - have become tiresome problems, they are today the most serious threat to the world economy.
Washington has been pressing surplus countries on several fronts. It has been urging them to expand their gross national products, jack up their exchange rates, lower their tariffs and quotas. It has pressed Japan and Germany to recycle their excess funds to other countries via investments in businesses, loans and foreign aid.
The problem is that the medicine hasn't been working. While the two big surplus countries have made some adjustments, particularly in the growth and currency arenas, their trade surpluses are not shrinking. What will be required now is more sustained pressure for ever bigger policy changes. This will amount to a continuous full-court press lasting well into the next decade. If managed badly, it could harm the cooperative relations that have served America, Western Europe and Japan so well.
The debate over what surplus nations should do and how to make them do it dates at least from the 1920s when neither Great Britain nor the United States, then the two strongest economies, understood what their international obligations were. The result was an epidemic of protectionism and, of course, the Great Depression. Spurred on by the intellectual leadership of John Maynard Keynes, the distinguished British economist, there was an effort after World War II to create two institutions to police the economic actions of all nations, deficit and surplus alike. The International Monetary Fund was up and running right away. The International Trade Organization, which was intended to be the I.M.F.'s close counterpart, was aborted in the late 1940s. Now we may be paying the price.
The effort failed because the Congress did not want the United States to be tied down by any international rules. In the 1990's, however, America could use the help of a strong international organization which imposes some pressure on surplus countries. Japan and Germany are, for example, increasingly antagonistic to American arm twisting, which they see as bullying which reflects shifting pressures of a fickle and disorganized Congress. They might well be more cooperative under a multilateral umbrella where bilateral passions are submerged in favor of give-and-take among a broader group of nations.
Perhaps we should harken back to what the International Trade Organization was all about. It was based, after all, on two premises that are crucially relevant to today's problems.
First, international commercial policy was seen as more than tariffs and quotas. It was to extend to purely domestic policies that could give a country unfair trading advantages. Examples included business cartels and discriminatory pricing. There are many current barriers which could be added to the list including overregulated and protected financial systems, obstacles to foreign investment, and disregard for patent and copyright protection.
Second, the International Trade Organization was supposed to have equal standing with the I.M.F. and work in close conjunction with it. Lord Keynes and his colleagues understood that achieving some international commercial balance required coordinated efforts on both the monetary and commercial fronts.
Skeptics would say that all the important trade issues are already being negotiated in one forum or another and that thinking about a new organization now is a pointless diversion. But the fact is that efforts to force surplus countries into line are scattered, ineffective, and just about at a dead end. Nowhere is the full panapoly of trade issues negotiated, and nowhere is trade and finance coordinated.
Washington is not achieving much with its bilateral, big stick approach. The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development in Paris does impressive studies, but has no clout. The I.M.F. has a mandate in the currency and monetary arena, but not in trade policy. The General Agreement on Trariffs and Trade - a watered down version of a trade organization - has its hands full with conventional trade issues like agriculture. In addition, the GATT has no enforcement capability, and no discernable relationship to the I.M.F. And the summit meetings between heads of state are only media events.
In today's world of spectacular increases in the movement of goods, services and money, strong international economic organizations will have to assume ever greater responsibility. Whether new ones are established or old ones are restructured is less important than that they have the mandate and competence to press for real change in the right places. When it comes to dealing with the big surplus countries, especially, that's not the case now.

GRAPHIC: Jeffrey E. Garten at his office in New York (NYT/Alan Zale)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: TUESDAY'S STAKES;
Black Politicians Are Leaning Against Some Old Barriers

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE transformation of American politics that began 24 years ago with the passage of the Voting Rights Act may be about to enter a new era.
This Tuesday, L. Douglas Wilder and David Dinkins will be seeking political prizes that blacks have never won before, prizes that can only be attained by extraordinary success in coalition-building among whites. Should they prevail, both men will catapult to the front ranks of American politics.
''What you're seeing is a transition and a maturation in the political process for African Americans,'' said Representative William H. Gray 3d of Pennsylvania, the House Democratic whip. ''Much the same occurred for other groups in America, such as the Irish, the Italians, the Jewish community, the Polish community, whose first political leaders tended to be ethnic leaders, fighting for the ethnic group.'' 
When the 1970's began, fewer than 1,500 blacks held elective office in the United States; today, more than 7,000 do, according to the Joint Center for Political Studies, a Washington research group.
State legislatures, county commissions and local governments that once had only a handful of blacks have gradually been desegregated. Milestones have become routine. In Southern cities with large black populations like Atlanta, civil rights leaders became politicians, then elected officials, then, as the years passed, the Old Guard. One of the oldest, Mayor Coleman A. Young of Detroit, will be seeking his fifth consecutive term this Tuesday.
But for all the progress, many black politicians felt they were pressing against a ceiling in recent years, particularly in the South, where the past 24 years had produced a large, seasoned cadre of black elected officials who were ready for the next step: statewide office. If their ambitions are less grand than the Presidential hopes of the Rev. Jesse Jackson, they may also be more readily achievable.
So it is that Tuesday's election in Virginia, where L. Douglas Wilder may become the first black ever elected governor, is more than just another milestone. Similarly, a mayoral victory by David N. Dinkins in New York City, a city as politically complex as most states, would be another hole in the ceiling.
Neither candidate was taking anything for granted. Democrats were watching the Virginia election with particular anxiety, having seen Mayor Tom Bradley of Los Angeles head into the 1982 gubernatorial election with strong support in the polls, seemingly assured of breaking the color barrier in California, only to lose by about 1 percent.
 
Breakthrough Expected
Still, the expectations were high, the political calculus already being readjusted to reflect a Virginia breakthrough. ''A state like Mississippi or Alabama or Arkansas can certainly have a black governor if Doug Wilder can win on Tuesday,'' said Representative Mike Espy of Mississippi, one of the younger generation of black politicians.
Representative John Lewis, a Georgia Democrat who was a pioneer in the civil rights movement, put it this way: ''There are only so many black majority Congressional districts, only so many black majority towns and cities. To move up and out, people must be able to build broad coalitions.'' Mr. Dinkins and Mr. Wilder are widely viewed as canny coalition builders.
To be sure, there have been black politicians in the past who have run and won in mostly white jurisdictions, notably Mr. Bradley of Los Angeles. But Mr. Bradley was never able to make the leap to Governor, although he tried twice.
Larry Sabato, a professor of political science at the University of Virginia, expects Mr. Wilder to improve upon that. ''Wilder is winning in basically white, conservative territory,'' he said. ''He is disproving the thesis that a black cannot be elected from such a district or state.''
A victory for Mr. Wilder would be a powerful signal to black politicians in the South. Mayor Andrew Young of Atlanta, for example, who is expected to run for Governor of Georgia next year, said he was ''very encouraged'' by Mr. Wilder's ability to build support in rural areas.
Many politicians see Mr. Wilder and Mr. Dinkins as emblematic of what Ronald H. Brown, the national Democratic chairman, calls the ''crossover'' politician, one who has transcended racial pigeon-holing. The population of Virginia is 20 percent black, while the New York City electorate is about 25 percent black.
Mr. Brown notes, ''You've got black voices speaking for the whole party, not just for black Americans.''
Mr. Wilder has campaigned heavily on the issues of abortion rights, development and crime - almost everything but racial pride. Mr. Dinkins has cast himself as a peacemaker who can work across the lines of race and ethnicity.
Both Mr. Dinkins and Mr. Wilder have distanced themselves from the Rev. Jesse Jackson, whose Presidential campaigns were charged with racial pride.
In many ways, Mr. Jackson stands in sharp contrast to the emerging black politicians. He did not climb, step by step, up the ladder of elective office; the two-time Presidential candidate has never held elective office. And some analysts say his lack of such experience might cause him increasing problems. ''His generation may be passing,'' said Mr. Sabato. ''His influence may be reduced, because he's going to have real competition from black politicians who have been elected to something.''
Mayor Young of Atlanta said, ''Jesse will continue to be America's prophet in residence. Doug Wilder will have to administer a government in Virginia. David Dinkins will have to administer a government in New York. They're not going to be competing with Jesse for any spokesman role because they've got another role.''
But Mr. Jackson may be sensing the changing times and preparing to play by new rules. He is still thought to be considering a run for Mayor in the District of Columbia.
As the milestones pass, people like John Lewis, who lived through the rough days of the civil rights movement, when the franchise was a distant dream for many Southern blacks, watch with wonderment.
''When Dr. King spoke in 1957, I think this is what he was talking about,'' he said. ''He kept saying give us the ballot, give us the ballot and we will transform the South.''

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
For the U.N., New Thinking on The Third World

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS

 BODY:
THREE decades ago when President Kennedy called for the United Nations to launch a decade of development for the third world, he spoke of raising a ''banner of hope'' for the poor and hungry.
Every 10 years the United Nations has renewed the pledge. But the gap between rich and poor is widening as third world living standards decline, leaving the officials charged with planning a strategy for the 1990's to wonder why the fourth ''development decade'' should be any better than the other three.
''A dangerous weariness infects the whole development community,'' said Mahbub ul-Haq, a former Planning Minister of Pakistan and an adviser on the United Nations effort. ''We are at a crossroads.'' John W. Sewell, president of the Washington-based Overseas Development Council, which lobbies for third world aid, speaks of the ''growing aid fatigue'' of Western countries depressed by the third world's unending economic tribulations. 
Many economists believe that if there is hope for the 1990's it will come from a growing acceptance by United Nations delegates of free-market economics. Instead of unilaterally declaring a New International Economic Order, the grand plan to redistribute the world's wealth that alienated Western leaders, planning sessions for the coming decade have leaned toward urging the third world to emulate the Asian success stories of Malaysia, Singapore, South Korea and Taiwan.
In a paper prepared for the United Nations, Keith Griffin of the University of Southern California urged the drafters of the new economic plan to recognize that the most successful countries are those with an entrepreneurial culture.
The record of the decade just ending is cause for pessimism, with third world living standards down 1 percent a year on average. In many countries crushing foreign indebtedness, falling prices for raw materials and misguided economic policies have actually reversed development.
The new effort will not focus entirely on free-market principles. It will also reaffirm the West's unfulfilled commitment from earlier decades to give 0.7 percent of its wealth annually in aid.
While third world countries would be urged to reduce red tape and government interference with the economy, they would also be encouraged to respect the environment and do more to improve the health and education of the poor.
 
Conflicting Interests
Of course many efforts launched by the United Nations have suffered because there was no real way to enforce them. The economic plans are guidelines not mandates. Any call for more market-based economies or other changes could run afoul of the interests of some countries' ruling elites.
But drafters of the new plan are considering ways to encourage governments to adopt reforms and stick to them. In return for changes, some countries might be offered more aid and debt relief from industrialized countries.
Discussions of the strategy began during this year's General Assembly and will conclude next year. Dropped from consideration so far are the approaches of the past, which The Economist recently described as ''based on the idea that the rules of orthodox economics do not hold in developing countries.''
In the 1950's and 60's the United Nations efforts promoted the ideas of Raoul Prebish and other economists who suggested that the way to propel the third world toward economic take-off was with import barriers, large-scale aid, centralized planning and other artificial means of propping up economies.
The efforts were not a complete failure. Taken as a whole the third world achieved the 5 percent growth rate set for the 1960's and narrowly missed the 6 percent target adopted for the second decade. But the countries' industries were uncompetitive and the growth was largely urban, bringing little help to the rural poor.
Growth was especially spectacular in a few East Asian countries. While an Indian's average annual income rose from $150 to $250 between 1950 and 1980, a South Korean's climbed from $350 to $2,900.
 
City vs. Country
Some goals expected to be included in the new plan would be troubling to more affluent and influential city dwellers. Improving health and educational standards in the countryside could mean fewer hospitals and universities for the cities. Realistic exchange rates would make imported luxuries more expensive but exports cheaper.
Professor Griffin argues that a pragmatic new approach could yield results because several trends will be moving the third world's way, reversing setbacks suffered in the 1980's. Easing population pressure in many countries should allow poor families to start improving their lot, while reduced military tensions could release more resources for development.
But the next United Nations development strategy will be more modest than the ''banner of hope'' President Kennedy raised in a more hopeful age.
In a recent study of the United Nations' role in development, Donald Puchala of the University of South Carolina said, ''The only thing that is clear is that all previous designs, plans, schemes and models for enhancing the welfare of mankind have been found wanting.''

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Japan Tries to Look Friendlier to Americans

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
JAPANESE officials were hopeful that tensions with the United States on trade and other matters might be eased if Ronald Reagan came to lend his soothing voice to the issues of trade and mutual friendship.
 
So they were surprised when
American attention focused not on what Mr. Reagan had to say, but on how much he was paid to say it. The fact that a Japanese conglomerate paid the former President and First Lady $2 million for their nine-day visit did more to reinforce American anxieties over Japan's economic power than to ease those fears.
Mr. Reagan's visit was followed almost immediately by a new Japanese purchase of a symbol of American culture, as the Mitsubishi Estate Company bought controlling interest in Rockefeller Center. That purchase last week stirred the same sort of American hand-wringing as did the Sony Corporation's acquisition last month of Columbia Pictures. 
In their formal comments, Japanese and American officials say the the latest Japanese acquisitions simply exemplify the extraordinary interdependence of the two most powerful economies on earth. They point out that Japan is still well behind Britain in its direct investment in the United States and has only recently pulled slightly ahead of the Netherlands as the second-largest foreign investor.
A Tokyo newspaper spoke for many Japanese recently when it said that given all the other foreign investment, American concern over Japanese acquisitions must arise from racism. Some American officials say there is some truth to this, but say also that the Japanese would be more welcome if trade and investment were a two-way street. Many Japanese officials say privately that they are increasingly fearful that their country's huge increase in American investments is creating a perception of Japan as less a partner than a rival. Recent opinion surveys showing that Americans generally perceive Japan as more of a threat to their well-being than the Soviet Union have been widely publicized in Japan, stirring a negative reaction that disturbs many experts.
''What I fear most is a resurgence of so-called neo-nationalism in this country,'' said a top aide to Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, referring to nascent feelings that Japan should consider distancing itself from the United States and even sharing some of its advanced technology with the Soviet Union. As it is, there is fear that the tensions are poisoning the atmosphere for reductions in the trade deficit that is the root of the problem.
Japanese point out that no one is forcing Americans to sell their property or businesses. Some Japanese businessmen also profess astonishment that the United States would allow its high-tech industry to cede certain business, such as production of facsimile machines and high-definition television, to the Japanese, or to join in Japanese partnerships rather than compete to produce the next generation of consumer electronics.
 
Intensifying Inequities
Many American believers in free trade who defend foreign investment nonetheless worry about the impact. Some fear that with a slump in American automobile sales, for example, Japanese-owned factories in the United States - generally located in rural areas away from unions and nonwhite workers - could absorb the losses while American-owned factories in urban areas might start laying off their heavily black work forces.
''It's healthy that Japan and the United States are economically interdependent,'' said Kent E. Calder, a leading Japan scholar who is an associate professor of politics and international affairs at Princeton University. ''But there is a great danger that interdependence might intensify inequities in the United States.'' Among the worries Mr. Calder cited was the extensive role of Japanese banks in leveraged buyouts that cause the breakup of American companies and layoffs.
Japan's anxiety about its image led senior officials to send a quiet message over the last year to executives to avoid making ''conspicuous'' purchases of American corporations or real estate. Although several Japanese officials privately expressed dismay at Mitsubishi's purchase of Rockefeller Center, the Government made no comment other than to make clear that such purchases could only occur if there were a willing seller.
Officials in Japan and the United States agree that in the long run the only way to ease frictions is to reduce the $50 billion trade deficit between the two countries, which has given the Japanese an enormous surplus of dollars with which to make their big American purchases.
Nothing in the last five years has had much effect -not the various demands by the United States that Japan open up its markets to American products, and not the sharp devaluation of the dollar starting in 1985. So foreign investment in the United States is likely to grow as long as businessmen in the increasingly interdependent global economy put aside sentimental considerations and do what to them makes economic sense.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Concern Over the Costs Of Malpractice Liability

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
''A CHILD falls off a swing and bumps his head,'' Dr. Otis R. Bowen, a physician and former Secretary of Health and Human Services, used to tell visitors. ''In the old days, you'd tell him to go home and put ice on it. Now you give him $100 worth of X-rays and maybe a CAT scan, and then you tell him to go home and put ice on it.''
The tests are part of a cycle that pits patients, doctors and lawyers against one another, and is under renewed scrutiny by lawmakers and health experts. They contend that high judgments in malpractice cases have inflated costs and undermined health care by discouraging doctors from high-risk practices. 
Their target is ''defensive medicine,'' tests and procedures performed chiefly to help doctors and hospitals protect themselves from possible malpractice lawsuits.
''It's obvious that while health costs continue to skyrocket, the enormous cost coming from tort liability, including defensive medicine, cries out for reform,'' said Senator Pete Domenici, Republican of New Mexico.
Tort suits and insurance regulation are generally matters of state law, but Congress has some regulatory authority under the Constitution's interstate commerce clause. Advisers to Senator Orrin Hatch, Republican of Utah, say he is drafting legislation that could place a ceiling on damages for non-economic injury, such as pain and suffering, and limit attorneys' fees in malpractice suits.
Many lawyers oppose such efforts. Russ Herman, a New Orleans attorney and president of the Association of Trial Lawyers of America, said, ''It is grossly unfair, under the American system of justice, for professionals, be they lawyers, doctors or others who reap maximum economic and social benefits, to limit their own responsibility for damages that they cause their innocent patients or clients.''
''Medicine ought to be defensive,'' he added, ''as should every profession.''
 
A Judgment Call
It is difficult to tell, of course, when tests are necessary, and increasingly sophisticated diagnostic procedures have in themselves led to higher costs. Limits on malpractice costs can address part of the problem, however.
The tests, procedures and consultations performed to avoid risk may help do so; the total cost of malpractice claims, including legal expenses, declined last year to $4.1 billion from $4.2 billion in 1987, and insurance rates have been going down. But health experts say that $4 billion is far less than the cost of testing and treatment performed to avoid suits.
A study by the American Medical Association found that in 1985, malpractice costs, including those for defensive medicine as well as insurance premiums and payments to plaintiffs, accounted for $15.4 billion in doctor bills, or 18.6 percent of the total spent on doctors.
Senator David Durenberger of Minnesota, a Republican on the Medicare subcommittee of the Finance Committee, said that ''the evidence that we have is that the unnecessary utilization of procedures may be as high as 25 to 40 percent of the total cost of procedures.'' The reasons, he said, included both fear of liability and local practices, as when ''everybody has a hysterectomy or a heart bypass.''
In addition, health experts say doctors are discouraged from high-risk patients and procedures that involve risks worth taking.
Obstetrics has been especially hard hit. The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists reported that in 1987, 12.4 percent of its members said they had left obstetrics and practiced only gynecology. Of those remaining, 27 percent had reduced their high-risk obstetrical care.
Martin J. Hatlie, director of the A.M.A.'s panel on professional liability and insurance, said: ''Doctors do make mistakes. They do injure people, and they have an obligation to do whatever they can to minimize that.''
 
'No Guidelines'
The problem, Mr. Hatlie said, is in claims like pain and suffering that go beyond medical costs and loss of income. ''There are no guidelines,'' he said. ''It's a very distorted process.''
Mr. Hatlie said patients in nations with national health care undergo far fewer tests because malpractice settlements are far smaller. This, he said, is in part because in the United States, awards anticipate future medical care, which is assured all citizens in nations with national health care. ''Doctors are much more at risk here than in England,'' he said, ''where no future medical expenses are part of the verdict.''
Malpractice premiums vary according to specialty and geography. The St. Paul Fire and Marine Insurance Company, which cut premiums an average of 14 percent in 32 states in July, says its highest average is in California ($43,901 a year) and its lowest in Nebraska ($5,055). The company insures 31,000 doctors in 42 states, which do not include New York.
In New York, the Medical Malpractice Insurance Association, an association of insurers, charges its highest rate, $124,000, to neurologists practicing in Nassau, Suffolk or Sullivan counties. The lowest rate, $3,771, is paid by dermatologists in rural upstate New York. The average premium is $38,000.
Most states have changed their laws governing malpractice cases, but in limited ways. Massachusetts, Michigan and Minnesota put a $1 million ceiling on damages like pain and suffering, loss of consortium and ''hedonic'' damages such as loss of enjoyment of life. ''That's a fairly high ceiling that would affect only a small number of cases,'' said Mr. Hatlie. In addition, there are many exemptions, such as one in Minnesota for ''any serious injury.''
Some states, including California, have limited attorneys' fees in malpractice cases. Others, including Indiana and Louisiana, have created government funds financed by health care providers and insurance companies, which pay claims above $100,000.
But many experts urge more limits. ''The best efforts in Washington to get the states to address this issue have failed,'' said Thomas R. Burke, a private health consultant who was chief of staff to Dr. Bowen. ''and Federal action is going to be needed.''

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: November 5, 1989

SECTION: Section 4; Page 5, Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1326 words

HEADLINE: THE REGION: Mayor of a Troubled City;
For New York, Two Who Would Be Different

 BODY:
ON Tuesday, New York City voters will elect either the first black mayor for the nation's largest city, where blacks account for about a third of the population, or the first Republican in a generation in a city where Democrats outnumber Republicans 5 to 1.
Whatever the choice, the election signals a turning point in politics and government after 12 years of Edward I. Koch at City Hall.
When Mr. Koch took office, the city was emerging from a fiscal crisis and entering an economic boom. Now the city again faces fiscal difficulties. Crack, AIDS and the homeless are severe strains. In a city of diversity, racial divisions are pronounced. 
The mayoral campaign began last winter with four Democrats and two Republicans. Now it is down to two main candidates, David N. Dinkins, the Democrat, and Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican-Liberal. Six minor-party candidates, including Ronald S. Lauder, the Conservative Party nominee, and Henry Hewes, running on the line of the Right to Life Party, will also be on the ballot.
For all the millions of dollars that were raised and spent, including public matching funds for the first time in a New York municipal election, the campaign leading up to two scheduled debates this weekend has been largely a duel from a distance. Television commercials, sometimes negative, sometimes positive, have been the weapons of choice.
When Mr. Dinkins and Mr. Giuliani have discussed issues, their differences were more in nuance than in substance. Both expressed concern over the quality of life and over the impact of crime and drugs. Outside personalities like Jesse Jackson and Jackie Mason seemed to stir as much comment as Mr. Dinkins or Mr. Giuliani. Here is a look at the candidates and their campaigns.
 
DAVID N. DINKINS
THE Manhattan Borough President since 1985, Mr. Dinkins, 62 years old, is the city's highest ranking black official. Born in Trenton, Mr. Dinkins, a lawyer, attended Howard University and the Brooklyn Law School. Introduced to politics by his wife's father, a Harlem district leader, he served one term in the State Assembly in 1965 before his district was reapportioned. He later served on the City Board of Elections and as City Clerk from 1975 to 1985. In the Democratic primary on Sept. 12 he drew 51 percent of the vote, defeating Mayor Koch, Richard Ravitch, former head of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, and Harrison J. Goldin, the City Comptroller.
 
Stand on the issues
As the front-runner, Mr. Dinkins has tried not to rock the boat by proposing dramatic initiatives. He favors hiring more police officers, assigning an officer to every subway train, postponing construction of a new municipal garbage incinerator in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, using alternative fuels like natural gas in city vehicles to ease air pollution, and cutting city spending by 1 percent across the board - except for the police - to meet a looming budget shortfall. He opposes increasing subway fares, putting tolls on East River bridges and restricting cars in midtown Manhattan.
 
Campaign theme
Asserting that he can unite people in a time of racial tension, he says in his speeches, ''I will reach out to all the family of New York.''
 
Campaign style
On the stump, he is unruffled, courtly and quiet-spoken.
 
Political strengths
He has enthusiastic support among black voters and strong backing from labor unions. In the primary he was supported by 29 percent of white voters and 54 percent of Hispanic voters.
 
Political weaknesses
Critics see his cautious and deliberate manner as indecisiveness. Questions about the management of his personal finances have hurt him. His association with the Rev. Jesse Jackson has also hurt him among Jewish voters, who cast about 1 in 5 votes.
 
Financial support
For the general election campaign, he reported raising $3,085,175 and spending $2,982,520 as of Oct. 30.
 
Campaign's best moment
On winning the primary, he hushed his supporters who jeered the mention of Mr. Koch, saying, ''Oh, no, we're all together now.''
 
Campaign's worst moment
Accounts of apparent discrepancies between the $1 million value Mr. Dinkins once placed on his stock in a communications company and his sale of the stock to his son two years later in 1985 for $58,000 revived memories of Mr. Dinkins's failure to file income tax returns for four years ending in 1972. After not responding at first, he provided information that helped explain the discrepancy.
 
Surprise of the campaign
While some politicians doubted his ability to raise a large war chest, his fund raising for the primary and general election is approaching Mr. Koch's 1985 mark of $7.5 million.
 
What he must do to win
He needs to get a high turnout of black voters and to make strong inroads among white voters as he did in the primary.
 
RUDOLF W. GIULIANI
AS the United States Attorney in Manhattan from 1983 to last January, Mr. Giuliani, 45 years old, gained fame for prosecuting cases involving organized crime, white-collar crime and political corruption. Born in Brooklyn, he attended Manhattan College and the New York University Law School. A Democrat who switched to the Republicans, he was the Associate Attorney General in the Reagan Justice Department before becoming the prosecutor in New York. To friends he was an aggressive fighter against corruption; to enemies he was a publicity seeker. In the Republican primary, he easily defeated Ronald S. Lauder.
 
Stand on the issues
As the acknowledged underdog, Mr. Giuliani has made more specific proposals than his opponent has. He favors an increase in police officers, state legislation to allow confiscation of the assets of drug dealers, a new municipal garbage incinerator in Brooklyn and ''rescue shelters'' to screen various types of homeless people. He opposes putting tolls on East River bridges or restricting cars or trucks in midtown Manhattan. He also opposes Mr. Dinkins's proposal to put a police officer on every subway train, saying it would reduce the transit police's flexibility.
 
Campaign theme
Vowing to root out ''crime, crack and corruption,'' he has invoked the memory of Fiorello H. La Guardia in calling for a fusion, or bipartisan government for the city.
 
Campaign style
He initially seemed stiff and humorless at campaign stops, but recently he has appeared more relaxed, doffing his jacket and occasionally bantering with the crowds.
 
Political strengths
Mr. Giuliani has sought to stress his reputation as a crime fighter and his independence, which, he says, will be needed to overcome the city's problems.
 
Political weaknesses
Making his first run for elective office, Mr. Giuliani has to overcome the Democrats' 5-to-1 advantage in enrollment. Opponents have questioned whether being an aggressive prosecutor was adequate training for a mayor.
 
Financial support
For the general election campaign, he reported raising $1,989,573 and spending $2,035,662 as of Oct. 30.
 
Campaign's best moment
After weeks of trailing by double-digit numbers in various polls, Mr. Giuliani's standing improved after Mr. Dinkins went on the defensive to answer questions about apparent discrepancies in his valuation of stock he owned.
 
Campaign's worst moment
Racial remarks by the comedian Jackie Mason forced Mr. Giuliani to distance himself from his onetime ambassador to the Jewish community.
 
Surprise of the campaign
On the day he announced his candidacy, Mr. Giuliani spent much of his time fielding questions about a Daily News article saying his law firm, White & Case, was a registered agent for Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the Panamanian dictator.
 
What he has to do to win
To overcome the Democrats' numerical advantage, he must create enough doubts about Mr. Dinkins's ability to govern and convince enough Democrats to vote Republican.

HEADLINE: THE REGION: A Governor for Harder Times;
For New Jersey, Two Who Stress Differences

 BODY:
THE next governor of New Jersey will inherit a state that has seen boom times but now faces harder days. Presided over for eight years by Thomas H. Kean, a popular Republican who by law is barred from a third term, New Jersey's economy has expanded. Now the state is facing a budget squeeze as it deals with some of the results of development like traffic and environmental problems while trying to eradicate the decay of Newark and Camden.
The two main candidates, Jim Courter and James J. Florio, both have extensive experience in Congress, where they have more in common than their campaigns would have voters believe. Indeed, the gubernatorial race has been nasty, with Mr. Courter, the Republican, and Mr. Florio, the Democrat, accusing each other of misrepresentation and misdeeds. 
State law provides matching funds and limits campaign spending to $5 million for each candidate. The candidates agree that the biggest problems are drugs, crime, AIDS, waste disposal, high auto insurance rates and a slipping economy but disagree on how to handle them. Most polls put Mr. Florio in a commanding lead. Here is a look at the campaign.
 
JIM COURTER
ONCE a registered Democrat, Mr. Courter, 48 years old, is a conservative Republican from Hackettstown who has been a United States Representative since 1978. He is a former legal aid lawyer and was a Peace Corps volunteer in Venezuela. His base in the northwestern corner of the state supplied him with enough votes in the June Republican primary election to defeat seven other candidates with 30 percent of the vote. Governor Kean did not endorse anyone in the primary.
 
Stand on the issues
He would bar children and teachers who are infected with the AIDS virus from public schools, setting up separate education for the children. He says Mr. Florio is a machine politician who runs Camden, which the Republican calls the state's most corrupt area. Mr. Courter favors less government regulation, and would combat high insurance rates by encouraging competition. He pledges no new taxes and would cap state spending.
 
Campaign style
Starting with little name recognition despite his 11 years in Congress, he has traveled extensively through the state to overcome that. He is a relaxed and easygoing campaigner.
 
Political strengths
New Jersey voters like the prosperity that has come during the Republicans' leadership and Mr. Courter has stressed his ties with Mr. Kean and President Bush.
 
Political weaknesses
Critics say he has little background in the problems that New Jersey faces. In the House, he has specialized in foreign affairs and defense. He modified his position on abortion several times, and now says that while he personally opposes abortion in nearly all cases, he would not prohibit state financing of abortions.
 
Campaign's best moment
In their first debate Mr. Florio, asked about a business deal involving two of his associates, avoided saying whether the associates had been wrong. ''They were wrong,'' Mr. Courter responded, ''so Jim, don't throw stones if you live in a glass house.''
 
Campaign's worst moment
He said he would support a law barring homosexuals from teaching or serving in other positions that would put them in contact with children; he later modified his position to say it was only his own opinion.
 
Surprise of the campaign
The Republicans have been less than enthusiastic in their support.
 
JAMES J. FLORIO
THIS is Mr. Florio's third try for the governor's job; he was unsuccessful in 1977 and in 1981, when he lost a substantial lead and the election to Mr. Kean by only 1,797 votes out of 2.3 million votes cast. He was first elected a United States Representative from the Camden area in 1974. Now 52 years old, he is a lawyer and a Navy veteran. With his name well known statewide and with the support of most of the state Democratic organizations, he polled 70 percent of the vote in a three-candidate race in the June primary.
 
Stand on the issues
Mr. Florio says the government should play a more active role in dealing with New Jersey's problems than it has during the Kean years. He favors the creation of a state prosecutor's office to enforce environmental laws. He says he would delay new landfills and incinerators until he could study other solutions. He supports the death penalty, but would resist expanding it; supports a ban on assault rifles; does not want new taxes, but won't rule them out. To solve the auto insurance problem, he would disband the state-run pool that insures drivers who cannot get coverage elsewhere and would closely regulate the industry. He would not limit abortions or state financing of them.
 
Campaign style
In the 1981 campaign, Mr. Florio was criticized for being brusque, condescending and given to long, boring answers. He has become friendlier and is more at ease in campaigning.
 
Political strengths
He is known as a strong fighter for the environment because of his Congressional work in setting up the Superfund. His views on social issues tend to be more in line with those of most New Jerseyans, based on opinion polls.
 
Political weaknesses
Critics say that Mr. Florio is a loner and that his political base of Camden, the state's poorest area, has not improved during his 15 years in Congress or under his control of the local party.
 
Campaign's best moment
As Mr. Courter praised his own record on environmental issues in their first debate, Mr. Florio retorted, ''Give me a break!''
 
Campaign's worst moment
Despite his attempts to appeal to blacks, he failed to appear at a meeting with state leaders of the N.A.A.C.P. because he was meeting his wife for a wedding anniversary dinner.
 
Surprise of the campaign
His lead in the polls has been unshaken.
