HEADLINE: THE EDITORIAL NOTEBOOK;
Costs of the Intifada

BYLINE: By JACK ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
On the brown velvet sofa in the living room, the father gestures at the street, silent except for the occasional rush of an Israeli jeep. Suddenly, his three boys tumble downstairs, their dark eyes big with alarm: ''Come quick, come quick! There's a big machine!''
The man leads his visitors upstairs to a bedroom that looks familiar to Americans with its Formica bunks, TV and board games. From the window, one can see Israeli soldiers clustered in front of a carpenter's house a block away as a crane lifts the lathe from his shop. The boys are frozen to the window, fear and fury in their eyes. 
Why the crane? Why the deserted streets? Why the heavy military presence? Because here in the Christian town of Beit Sahour a few minutes from Jerusalem, Palestinians have been fighting the newest battle against Israel's occupation of the West Bank and Gaza. Despite daytime curfews and harsh Israeli efforts to make examples of people, the residents of Beit Sahour have refused to pay their taxes - even when that meant seizures of property to be sold at auction.
Last week, the tax boycott ended in a stalemate, an outcome that says much about the whole 23-month uprising, the intifada. For it too seems to have settled into a stalemate. Israel seems to have decided that it can live with the intifada, live with the status quo. But truly, there is no status quo. Israelis pay a painful price for containing the uprising - a price that abrades the army, hobbles the economy and corrodes democracy.
The Army: Israeli troops are not monsters. They struggle to be stern without being brutal. Their bullets, mostly, are rubber. But policing civilians involves constant pressure, especially for Israel's citizen army. Many of the reservist soldiers hate this duty, so alien to the intrepid image of the hostage rescue in Entebbe. The steady erosion of morale worries Israeli commanders.
The Economy: In financial terms, the costliest price is the loss of ''exports'' to the West Bank. Before the intifada, Palestinians bought a billion dollars a year in Israeli products; with boycotts, the figure is down 30 percent. As one Palestinian says, in front of a graffiti-spattered wall, ''The only Israeli product we buy now is spray paint.''
Palestinians also continue to withhold their labor, putting costly pressure on agriculture and construction.
And tourism, which dropped 40 percent with the intifada, is only starting to recover. All told, the Finance Ministry estimates the intifada is costing the country two percentage points of growth - in a year when the economy may barely grow at all.
Democracy: It's one thing to put down short-term rioting. It's another to keep fighting what Justice Minister Dan Meridor calls existential war. Before the occupation, Israel was 85 percent Jewish; there was no tension between remaining both a Jewish state and a democracy. Now, counting the 800,000-plus Palestinians in the occupied territories, Israel is 65 percent Jewish.
The longer Palestinians remain subject to ''administrative detention'' and are deprived of self-government, the more Israelis corrode their own devotion to democracy.
Even so, Prime Minister Shamir's Government seems willing to pay these prices. The hard-nosed calculation seems to be that there are only three levers that might force giving land for peace. The first is world opinion, aroused by the intifada. But the intifada has slipped to page 16 of the world's press, and the Palestinians know that to escalate would delight those Israelis eager for an excuse to use real instead of rubber bullets.
A second lever is domestic political opposition; it exists but it is not strong enough to force change. Labor Party stalwarts are reduced to pleading for the third lever -pressure from the United States. That's not promising either. U.S. diplomats voice constructive intentions, but at the moment they are understandably distracted by the larger intifada that Mikhail Gorbachev has unleashed in the Communist world.
So what of the Palestinian intifada? It will probably drag on, mired in bickering about this five-point plan or that six-point initiative, and the fear and fury will harden in the dark-eyed boys of Beit Sahour.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Global Lukewarming

 BODY:
George Bush's campaign pledge to pay more attention to the environment was good news coming after eight years of Reagan indifference. His early appointments were generally sound, his proposals challenging, his words bullish. ''Those who think we're powerless to do anything about the greenhouse effect,'' he trumpeted, ''are forgetting about the White House effect.'' 
Where has this ardor gone? In a pattern distressingly like the Administration's disarray over Soviet policy, infighting and conflicting signals now obscure the clarity of Mr. Bush's original commitment on at least two priority issues.
Global Warming. Environmental questions are dauntingly complex, and solving them requires painful trade-offs between conservation and economic growth. The so-called greenhouse effect is no exception: experts disagree on just how serious it already is. But no respectable scientist denies that pouring gases like carbon dioxide into the atmosphere will eventually cause the earth to warm up, with consequences that are potentially catastrophic.
The U.S. produces 25 percent of the world's carbon dioxide emissions. To William Reilly, director of the Environmental Protection Agency, this imposes a special obligation on Washington to develop a timetable and strategy.
Mr. Reilly had hoped to carry at least the outline of a policy to an international conference on global warming that begins tomorrow in the Netherlands. He's going, but without a policy. Powerful voices in the Administration - including the Department of Energy and the White House chief of staff, John Sununu - insist on further study, even though 14 months have passed since Mr. Bush's ringing declaration of war on global warming.
Clean Fuels. A tough new clean-air bill is slowly wending its way through Congress, thanks in part to Mr. Bush's original bill and the efforts of clean-air advocates like California's Henry Waxman to strengthen it. But one of the bill's most important provisions has been weakened beyond recognition - and Mr. Bush is largely to blame. The provision would have required Detroit to produce one million cars designed to run on alternative fuels by 1997.
There's disagreement among experts on which alternative fuels would be cleanest or cheapest. But Mr. Bush's original proposal would at least have encouraged aggressive investment in new technology by reluctant auto makers and oil companies.
At a critical moment in the deliberations of Mr. Waxman's subcommittee, however, Mr. Sununu sent word that the White House would accept a weaker provision. Mr. Reilly sent the opposite message. The confusion was fatal: Mr. Bush's cherished alternative-fuels provision was gutted. By allowing two key aides to send conflicting signals, the President had sandbagged himself.
There are now fears of vacillation on a third environmental concern: acid rain. The Bush bill would attack acid rain by requiring utilities to halve their discharges of sulfur dioxide by the year 2000. Mr. Sununu said in a letter to Mr. Waxman that the White House still wants a tough plan. But there is no evidence of aggressive White House lobbying. That's because the White House's chief lobbyist -the man who would be the Environmental President - has forgotten that legislation, like horseshoes, requires follow-through.

HEADLINE: Steel Makes Better Sense Than Concrete in Earthquake Zones

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Reporters are asking the wrong questions, and California structural engineers are trying to justify the unjustifiable, in the collapse of the Nimitz and Embarcadero elevated freeways from a distant earthquake near Santa Cruz, Calif. Federal and California legislators may have to fly to Japan to get honest answers to the correct question: Why were these and other critical structures built with weak, brittle concrete, instead of strong, resilient structural steel?
Legislators must halt the use of deadly reinforced concrete in California by requiring that (a) all freeway structures and other critical above-grade structures be constructed of structural steel with a safety factor of at least eight; (b) the engineering department at the University of California, Berkeley, stop popularizing and promoting reinforced concrete for California, and (c) local governments make dangerous ground conditions in their jurisdictions public by permanently posting maps and explanations. 
Japanese engineers generally refuse to use concrete for above-grade structures because it is rigid, weak and heavy, and quality control is very difficult. One could not find a material more dangerous in a seismic zone. Here are the facts:
* Steel is eight times stronger in tension and shear than concrete.
* Steel is resilient; concrete is not.
* Steel is uniform at the molecular level and therefore is far more predictable than concrete.
* Steel does not have a quality control problem.
Why are engineers in this country using concrete? I believe the answer begins in the publish-or-perish atmosphere of the Berkeley campus, where the engineering department has for years championed use of this material in reams of reinforced concrete research. Generations of structural engineers have been trained at Berkeley.
I retired from the Federal Government (General Services Administration) in 1986 after 25 years as project director on major projects in California. My chief structural engineer and I refused to follow the agency's directive, which demanded that the results of an economic analysis determine whether our buildings be constructed of reinforced concrete or structural steel. The directive may be appropriate in Ohio, but is clearly wrong in California.
 
RAYMOND MATHIS
 Berkeley, Calif., Oct. 22, 1989
 
The writer is an architect.

HEADLINE: What Tax Lawyers Do Mustn't Be Seen as Sin

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I may qualify, in Theodore Seto's view (''Snookered on Taxes,'' Op-Ed, Oct. 17), as a ''fancy, high-priced'' tax lawyer, although I view my charges as reasonable and point out, in addition, that those fees usually qualify for tax deductibility to my clients.
I couldn't disagree more with the substance of his article, however. In essence, Mr. Seto is suggesting that some element of immorality exists in the ''sheltering'' of income from the clutches of the taxing authorities. I cannot subscribe to the point of view that planning one's finances so as to maximize one's after-tax income is in any way, shape or form an unpatriotic act.
Both history and common sense suggest that a cut in the rate of taxes on capital gains would spur the economy, thereby generating more, not less, tax revenue.
Whatever the ultimate impact of any tax-law tinkering of this type turns out to be, Mr. Seto would do well to recall, though, that the deficit he bemoans comes about, not because my clients (and presumably his, as well) consult with us in order to pay no more than what they lawfully owe, but because of the refusal of our solons in Washington to rein in their bloated spending habits and to limit their expenditures in a way that accords with a realistic projection of revenues.
 
IRA B. STECHEL
 New York, Oct. 19, 1989

HEADLINE: The Reversals of History

BYLINE: By Terence Smith; Terence Smith, correspondent for CBS News, covered the Presidencies of Jimmy Carter and Ronald Reagan.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Former President Jimmy Carter is back in the capital for an informal reunion with staffers from his Administration and a symposium in which he'll report on his mediation efforts in eastern Africa, Central America and elsewhere.
Ronald Reagan, fresh from the Orient, is back in his Bel Air counting house going over the receipts from his multi million-dollar visit to Japan.
The contrast between the after-office lives of the former Presidents reinforces a heretical notion I have -namely, that history will soon reverse the popular images of the two men and give Mr. Carter higher grades as President than Mr. Reagan. To be sure, the majority of Americans still regard Jimmy Carter as a failed President - a symbol of indecision, ineptitude and weakness. Mention Jimmy Carter and they think of gas lines, soaring inflation and -most tellingly - the humiliation of the Iran hostage crisis that began 10 years ago this weekend. 
Ronald Reagan, on the other hand, left office at the pinnacle of his popularity. Despite the embarrassments of the Iran-contra affair, the continued captivity of the American hostages in Lebanon and the lingering stench of scandal that surrounded his outgoing Administration, he went back to California bathed in the warm glow of public affection.
But history is a harsher judge. Historians will note, for example, that it was Jimmy Carter who focused the nation's attention on the need for energy conservation and defined human rights as a legitimate consideration in foreign policy.
Scholars will credit Mr. Carter with overcoming steep political odds in winning ratification of the Panama Canal treaty and - most important - personally engineering the major foreign policy achievement of recent decades: the Camp David accords and Egyptian-Israeli peace treaty.
Mr. Reagan will rightly get credit for his brilliant use of the bully pulpit, for his active encouragement of democracy over dictatorship and for recognizing the opportunities presented by Mikhail Gorbachev's reforms. His signature on the INF treaty assures his place in the annals of arms control.
But analysts will also recognize that Ronald Reagan presided over a meltdown of the Federal Government during the last eight years. Fundamental management was abandoned in favor of rhetoric and imagery. A cynical disregard for the art of government led to wide-scale abuse.
Only now are we coming to realize the cost of Mr. Reagan's laissez-faire: the crisis in the savings and loan industry, the scandal in the Department of Housing and Urban Development, the deterioration of the nation's nuclear weapons facilities, the dangerous state of the air traffic control system - not to mention the staggering deficit. The neglect was pernicious, not benign, and the bills, measured in hundreds of billions of dollars, are coming due with alarming speed.
Judgments of the two men at this point are premature and necessarily subjective. But my suspicion is that hard-headed historical review, when it is finally done, will enhance the image of the man from Plains, and tarnish that of the squire of Bel Air.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY

 BODY:

Cosmonauts to Caviar in the Soviet Union
Two new travel opportunities in the Soviet Union seem to illustrate how the Russians are embracing tourism with fresh zeal. One explores the Soviet space program; the other will carry visitors by private train.
Highlights of the nine-day space tour, starting this month and running through April, are trips to Star City, the cosmonauts' training facility outside Moscow, a visit with Russian cosmonauts and visits to the Korolyov Museum, named for the chief Soviet rocket designer, in Moscow, and the Tsiolkovsky Museum, named for the father of the Soviet space program, in Kaluga, 90 miles southwest of the capital. Hotel stays are in Leningrad and Moscow. The tours range from $1,899 a person, double occupancy, to $2,279, and include round-trip air fare. More information: the World of Eva Harris, 54 Danbury Road, Suite 309, Ridgefield, Conn. 06877; 800-937-1550. 
The rail tour is Russia by Private Train, and the train is the Anna Karenina. The two four-passenger cars were originally built for use by government officials. The service is available for private charter, and travelers are allowed to plan the itinerary. The tour operator suggests two routes. Both start in Leningrad and end in Moscow but take different tracks. One, a 12-day Golden Ring trip, centers on the central and northeastern region, taking in cities around Moscow. The other is a 14-day Five Republics tour. It goes through Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Byelorussia and the Ukraine.
Generally, the two cars are coupled to scheduled trains, but they can be hauled by their own engine. On most tours, travelers live and dine aboard their private cars, which also carry two attendants who prepare the meals. Caviar, smoked sturgeon and Russian wines will be served. Each car has two bedrooms, a dining room, a lounge and a full bathroom and its own air-conditioning and heating system. The price is $5,820 a person for 12 days, $6,855 for 14 days. The tours start in April and run to Oct. 31. More information: Abercrombie & Kent, 1420 Kensington Road, Oak Brook, Ill. 60521; 312-954-2944 or 800-323-7308 outside Illinois.
 
Europe in '92: Effect on Travel
The typical traveler to Europe after the 1992 economic restructuring designed to integrate the Common Market countries takes effect will reserve flight and hotel room by calling one toll-free number, rent a room that costs less but is farther away from historic downtown areas and pay for rooms with any number of credit cards, travel experts said at a New York symposium.
These tourists will take advantage of less restrictive boundaries within the European Community by visiting more countries and, as a consequence, make less rigid travel plans, the experts said at the symposium sponsored by Quality International, the hotel chain, last month. In short, they concluded, once all internal barriers to trade are dismantled trips to the Old World will seem a lot more like a trip within the United States.
''We have to walk a fine line,'' said Gerald W. Petitt, chief operating officer for Quality International, which manages many hotels in Europe. He said that what he called the failure of Holiday Inn to succeed with Americans in Europe demonstrates that ''when people visit Europe they want a foreign experience.'' On the other hand, hotels have to be wary of scaring off European travelers, who make up 75 percent of hotel occupants.
Still, Mr. Petitt said, tourists from all countries are coming to expect such American-style amenities as a large bed, computerized reservations systems and cable television in their rooms. There is a large market for mid-priced hotels (about $30 to $35 a person a night), which is currently neglected by European hoteliers, he added.
Experts on tourism and the European community from A.T.&T. and the United States Department of Commerce said that travel should benefit from a unified currency, simplified customs and a more coherent phone system.
Debra Miller, an economist at the Commerce Department's Office of Industrial Trade, said that an agreement to unify production standards throughout the European community would lower the cost for manufactured items and construction. Mr. Petitt estimated that the cost of hotel construction should drop by 20 to 30 percent and that, since hotels usually set room rates on the basis of construction costs, rates should also drop 20 to 30 percent.
 
Shipping Skis
Skiers irked by carrying equipment through busy airports, or by airlines that lose their skis, can have them delivered by Federal Express. Couriers will pick up skis at home or office and deliver them to condo, inn or chateau. The company said that skis should be packed in a ski bag with the FedEx air bill taped to the outside of the bag.
The cost from anywhere to anywhere in the United States is the same; weight, not distance, determines the price. A pair of skis and bag weighing 25 pounds costs $63.75 for delivery the following morning; a 15-pound package costs $51.25. For delivery after two days, prices are $36.50 for 25 pounds and $26.50 for 15 pounds. Delivery to Europe costs more. Basic price for a 25-pound pair delivered to French Alpine resorts is $150. More information: 800-238-5355.
 
Airlines Add French Cities
Flights from Newark International Airport to the French cities of Bordeaux, Marseilles, Montpellier, Nantes and Toulouse were started recently by UTA French Airlines, the only airline offering nonstop or direct service to them from the United States. Passengers on other airlines have to change planes in Paris. UTA's weekly schedule, aimed mainly at business travelers, includes three nonstop flights to Bordeaux (Tuesday, Friday and Sunday), three flights to Toulouse (nonstop on Saturday, via Bordeaux on Tuesday and Sunday) and two to Marseilles (via Nantes on Monday and Toulouse on Saturday). A nonstop flight operates to Nantes on Mondays; Montpellier is served on Friday via Bordeaux.
Air France is also inaugurating direct flights to four French cities, in addition to Paris, from Kennedy International Airport. (It also flies nonstop to Nice in summer; a connection is required in Paris in winter.) New York-Lille-Mulhouse service starts Nov. 9, departing on Thursday, with the return flight on Friday. A Sunday flight from New York and a Monday departure from Mulhouse and Lille will be added Jan. 7. New York-Lyons-Strasbourg flights will depart Monday and Saturday starting Nov. 11; service in the other direction, on Thursday and Sunday, begins Nov. 9. Flights to Lille and Lyons are nonstop; they continue to Mulhouse and Strasbourg without a change of plane. American Airlines has had a daily nonstop from Kennedy to Lyons since May.
The new Airbus A310-300 will be used on Air France flights to the four cities, initially with two-class service. The airline plans to introduce three-class service in March.
 
ROCK ERA EXHIBIT IN LONDON
A permanent exhibition of rock has opened at the London Pavilion, 1 Piccadilly Circus. The Rock Circus represents a history of rock from the 1950's to the present. Visitors see wax figures and electronically controlled models of rock stars and listen to information about them and their music through headphones programmed to respond to each exhibit. At the end of the tour there is a theater show with a revolving auditorium and three stages where electronically controlled, moving, speaking and singing models of singers and groups perform. The Beatles, for example, perform in a reconstruction of the Cavern Club in Liverpool. Among other artists are Elvis Presley, Stevie Wonder, Bruce Springsteen, David Bowie, Elton John and Michael Jackson. Rock Circus is open every day except Christmas from 10 A.M. to 10 P.M. Entry fee: about $6.75, $5 for children.
The exhibition is on the itinerary of a one-week Beatles package that also includes a seat at Paul McCartney's sold-out Jan. 3 concert in Birmingham. Guided bus tours of the Beatles' old haunts in Liverpool, and, in London, a recording session at the Abbey Road Studios, a visit to Cynthia Lennon's new restaurant and a New Year's Eve party are also on the program. The Dec. 29 tour costs $1,349 a person, double occupancy, including air fare, hotels, breakfast and admissions. A land-only package is $800. The tour is offered by Liverpool Productions, 397 Edgewood Avenue, New Haven, Conn. 06511 (203-865-8131).

HEADLINE: Brazil's Atlantic Playground

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE; JAMES BROOKE is the Rio de Janeiro bureau chief of The New York Times.

 BODY:
DWARFED by the transoceanic behemoths of Air France and Varig, a small blue-and-white propeller plane scoots every day past Recife's imposing international air terminal. Once airborne, the plane leaves behind Brazil's northeastern bulge and heads out to sea, in the direction of Africa.
Built with an unpressurized cabin, the plucky 12-seater bounces through squalls and turbulence, always keeping within sight of gray waves and whitecaps several hundred feet below.
On a recent afternoon, after two hours of droning into the empty South Atlantic, my wife and I began to exchange glances tinged with doubt.
About then, we spied our destination - Brazil's Atlantic islands, the miniature archipelago of Fernando de Noronha. 
Rising from the ocean floor 13,000 feet below, an underwater mountain emerged from the turquoise sea, culminating in a 1,060-foot-high peak of rugged gray basalt. Thick green vegetation cloaked the shoulders. Rimming the main island were fingernail beaches of white coral sand studded with black volcanic rock.
In 1503, Amerigo Vespucci became the first European to set eyes on this 10-square-mile island chain. After four centuries of human habitation, Fernando de Noronha is now entering its most accessible and most welcoming era.
Last year, after almost half a century of control, Brazil's military returned the archipelago to civilian rule. Beating back a proposal to build casinos on the island, conservationists persuaded the government to declare 70 percent of this remote archipelago a national marine park.
Today, Fernando de Noronha, the principal island of the 21-island archipelago, is open to the public. With basic lodgings a la 1950's Caribbean, the island offers a wide variety of attractions for its 8.5 square miles.
For scuba divers - or simple snorkelers - the island's clear blue waters are a life-size aquarium of tropical marine fauna. Above water, visitors can observe the somersaults and leaps of whitebelly spinner dolphins. The island's Dolphin Bay is the only place outside of Kealakekua Bay, Hawaii, where spinners are known to live year round.
And for a visitor disillusioned with Brazil's polluted urban beaches, Fernando de Noronha is a step back in time. Beaches are spotless and the water is clear and warm - 79 degrees.
Bird watchers, walking through snake-free underbrush, discover a wealth of equatorial bird life - including two varieties that are endemic to the island.
Amateur historians and vacation philosophers can ponder works wrought by man down through the centuries: the ramparts of a fortress started in the 17th century, when the Netherlands were a world power; the remains of a brutal 19th-century penal colony, Brazil's equivalent of Devils Island; the abandoned Air France building that recalls transoceanic flights here by the air pioneers Gago Coutinho and Jean Mermoz, and wind-battered Quonset huts erected during World War II by American soldiers assigned to guard South Atlantic sea lanes from this lonely outpost.
The American presence, which lasted until the early 1960's, most marked the island, which has only 200 houses.
Inspired by Washington's vision of the island as a granite aircraft carrier, American engineers built the milelong airstrip now used for tourist flights. Today, most of the 1,400 inhabitants receive power from a diesel station installed by Americans and drinking water from a cement rainwater catch basin built by Americans. The summit of the island's landmark, the Pico, is reached by a series of cast-iron ladders riveted to the rock by Americans.
Virtually all visitors stay at the Hotel Esmeralda, the former American base. Today, flop-eared goats and stray horses munch grass by a pay telephone. But by studying the rusted American fire hydrants, the double row of Quonset huts and the faded white curbstones, one can easily conjure up the image of mid-20th century American military culture projected to this end of the earth.
Today, the banging screen door of the old mess hall opens into the Esmeralda's reception area, a well-used bar with broken chairs, and the island's only restaurant. At this self-service establishment, etiquette is boarding house and cuisine remains mess hall - large, bland portions. The bar is well stocked with sodas, beer and the basic hard drinks.
Elena Gavazzi Ribeiro, the jolly Brazilian manager, welcomes visitors with a reminder to set watches one hour ahead of ''the continent.'' Our advice: drink bottled water; bring your own soap and beach towels, and avoid December through March, when Brazilians take their summer vacations.
Visitors no longer lodge in the Quonset huts, called ''igloos'' by the locals. Replacing only the screen windows, the islanders will probably nurse these temporary accommodations into the 21st century. If you enter Aguas Claras, the scuba diving company, you will see why: a prevailing southeast breeze flows through, keeping the inside cool and bug free.
Instead, visitors are lodged in square box rooms. Each is furnished with at least two single beds and single visitors should be prepared to share rooms with guests of the same sex. The bathrooms are cold-water. Cleanliness is such that many visitors will feel more comfortable taking a shower wearing their beach sandals.
Built four years ago, the rooms have no cross-ventilation, no screens for the windows and total dependence on air-conditioning. Unfortunately, the three-unit generating station left by the Americans has dwindled to one generator. To conserve power, air-conditioning runs only from 10 P.M. to 7 A.M. The number of tourists is kept to 100 at any one time and, consequently, the only reliable way to travel to Fernando de Noronha is through a package tour. This includes room and board at the Esmeralda and daily group outings.
The archipelago receives sun 200 days a year, and the rainy season is March through May. The rain leaves most dirt roads impassable, but it also paints the island bright green. During the dry season, from September through Feburary, the island takes on a dusty brown color. Varying little throughout the year, the daytime temperature stays near 78 degrees. The lowest it gets is 64.
We found worthwhile both a bus tour and a boat tour, which went up the lush, leeward side. But this is 3.5 degrees south of the Equator. For Brazilians in string bikinis and minimal male attire, this means slowly turning a pleasant shade of golden brown. For us this meant turning lobster red overnight and then seeking shirts and shade.
It is more fun to explore the beaches and the historical sites at your own pace - on foot or in an old jeep bouncing down the stone roads laid decades ago by prison work gangs.
At the hotel, Bill Guarda can line up a driver and a battered military jeep for about $35 a day. Mr. Guarda rents fins, snorkel and mask for about $3 a day.
A VISIT to Sancho Bay explains why Brazilians fought to have Fernando de Noronha declared a national marine park.
Slipping off a tour boat into the warm waters of the South-Equatorial Current, we donned our rented masks and entered the underwater world. A school of 50 silver fish flashed around a head of fire coral. Nearby hovered a group of Stegastes rocasensis, small yellow fish tinged with purple.
Up and down the volcanic coast, scuba divers can go deeper, exploring gardens of 10 coral species. Underwater fishing has been banned since 1984 and a colorful variety of tropical fish proliferate: queen angel fish, butterfly fish, honeycomb cow fish, yellow goat fish and parrot fish.
Coming up for air at Sancho Bay, we contemplated a primeval scene. Unmarked by a single footprint, a pristine beach gave way to a soaring, concave cliff. Cloaked at lower levels in jitirana creepers, the cliff was a nesting place for several bird species, including the white-tailed tropic bird, noted for long elegant tail feathers. Frigate and white terns sailed silently against a backdrop of the 250-foot-high rock face.
One bird species, Vireo gracilirostris, a small brown brush bird, is only found on Fernando de Noronha. Also endemic to the island is a subspecies, Elaenia spectabilis ridleyania, a melodious, gray-breasted wood-nesting bird named after H. N. Ridley, a British naturalist who visited in 1887.
Because of the steep cliff, Sancho Bay is usually visited by boat. Afterward, one can go a beach north, past the Two Brothers rocks, to Porcos Bay, which offers tidal pools for bathing and more reefs for snorkeling. Or, if it is still early in the day, it is worth moving south to Dolphins Bay.
According to a video, ''Bay of the Dolphins,'' which is shown at the Aguas Claras divers' hut, dolphins have been spotted at this bay since 1700. The bay is a mating, breeding and nurturing area and park authorities ban swimming and boating within an area demarcated by buoys. The untamed dolphins revel in aerial acrobatics. ''They are capable of carrying out several different aerial movements, including spins, somersaults, spectacular leaps and repeated beating of the water with their tail fins,'' Clovis Barreira e Castro wrote in ''Archipelago de Fernando de Noronha,'' an illustrated Portuguese-English book: ''The biologist Liliane Lodi recorded series of up to five somersaults, 14 leaps with body twists, and 10 consecutive leaps.''
Visible in the bay about 125 days out of the year, the community of 150 dolphins is most likely to be sighted from dawn to 3 P.M. For land viewing, arrange the night before to leave the hotel at dawn with a driver and a jeep. It takes about an hour to drive and walk to the viewing spot, at the top of the bay's 350-foot-high cliff. We missed the dolphins. But the island offers other aquatic attractions. Wearing sneakers, you can walk at low tide from Porcos Bay past American's Beach to Boldro Beach, which is below the hotel. Keep an eye out for the boobies and frigate birds that patrol the breaking surf, searching for the flash of a tasty sardine.
The dirt path to the hotel passes the island's one nightspot, the Mirante (Lookout) Bar, where residents dance to lambada, a music popular in northeastern Brazil.
For spectacular sunsets, try the windblown western side of the island, which faces Africa. Reachable by road is Sueste Beach, a calm bay about a two-mile walk from the hotel where Dutch troops landed in the 1600's.
During the day, we visited Leao Beach, a half-hour walk from Sueste down a path bordered by shoulder-high angelica trees that emit a scent like jasmine.
Built up with sand dunes, Leao Beach faces two small rocky islands known as nesting places for the rare blue-faced booby. On the southern end of the beach, the sea has dug channels in the reefs. When waves rush through, seawater sprays 30 feet in the air in a natural fountain.
From January to May, Leao Beach is the scene of a ritual thousands of years old. Swimming from Ascension Island, 900 miles to the west, green turtles return every year to the beach, where they drag themselves up on the sand to nest. To save the turtles from extinction, conservationists now protect the nests, which often contain hundreds of eggs.
On the way back from Leao, our driver stopped for a refresher at a rundown house near a mangrove swamp. On cue, a woman hacked off the top of a fresh coconut and offered us the fresh milk. Her daughter offered squares of cocada, a sweet coconut candy. Each cost the equivalent of 25 American cents.
Indeed, outside of the Esmeralda and its bland fare, the only other food we found for sale was at Dona Zeta's house, where cones can be had of white ice cream made from native graviola fruit. Virtually all food consumed on the island is imported.
Occasionally, islanders slaughter a cow. Many are descended from a Pakistani herd introduced in the early 1950's, when the island briefly served as a veterinarian quarantine for Brazil. In a less successful interference with the local ecology, a farmer introduced Teju lizards here in the 1960's. Instead of killing rats, as intended, the lizards feasted on bird and turtle eggs. Today, many birds nest only on the outer islands.
Among the physical marks of man, the most prominent is Remedios Fort, the largest of 17 abandoned fortifications.
In the 1600's and early 1700's the Dutch and the French repeatedly seized the island and used it as a springboard for invasions of the Portuguese-controlled mainland. After expelling the last foreign occupiers, the French, in 1736, Portuguese colonial authorities completed the fort's construction.
Today, rusted cannon barrels stand watch over trans-Atlantic yachts anchored below in Santo Antonio harbor.
Behind the fort is Remedios, once a penal colony, now a hamlet dominated by a newly restored 18th-century Baroque church.
From the mid-1700's until 1948, criminals and political prisoners were sent here.
In her book, ''Fernando de Noronha: Legends and Picturesque Facts,'' Maria Jose Borges Lins e Silva, a Recife historian, re-creates the sadistic regime of floggings, stone beds, solitary cells and ultimate punishment - abandonment on Rat Island.
In February 1832 Charles Darwin sailed around the island and noted in his diaries that it was ''covered with vegetation.'' Twenty years later, a visitor noted that the only trees of any size were in the prison governor's walled garden. All the others had been cut down to prevent prisoners from building escape rafts.
Women were banned by colonial edict until 1817. The ban was lifted after inspectors repeatedly complained to the Portuguese crown of widespread homosexuality. In the 20th century, prison conditions improved slightly after a crusading Brazilian journalist visited here and penned a pamphlet in 1938 entitled ''Fernando de Noronha: Island of Pain and Suffering.''
Today, the ghosts of prisoners probably smile at the T-shirts now sported by Brazil's new, ecology-minded generation: ''Fernando de Noronha: Preserve it or leave it.''
 
THE ARCHIPELAGO
 
Getting There
Nordeste Airlines flies daily to Fernando de Noronha, leaving Recife, Brazil, at 12:30 P.M. and returning around 3:30. Once a week, on Sunday, Nordeste makes two flights. The round trip is about $140.
No camping is allowed on the island. Park police will allow visitors out of the air terminal only if they have a confirmed reservation.
 
Packages
Brazilian Scuba and Land Tours (5254 Merrick Road, Suite 5, Massapequa, N.Y. 11758; telephone 800-722-0205) offers a round-trip economy flight from Miami with three nights in Recife, six nights and board at the Hotel Esmeralda, five days of tank diving, a tour of the island and a tour of the Bay of Dolphins for $1,599; nondivers $1,399.
Dona Zeta's house has four rooms. The rate is $15 a night, including breakfast, lunch and dinner. Telephone 549-1242.
Dona Pituca's house (next to the church) has four rooms at $15 a night, including meals. Telephone 549-1201. - J. B.

HEADLINE: BLACK UNIVERSITIES: IN DEMAND AND IN TROUBLE

BYLINE: By Eric Alterman; Eric Alterman, a senior fellow of the World Policy Institute, is writing a book on Washington pundits for Farrar, Straus & Giroux.

 BODY:
GARFIELD SWABY LEANS BACK IN A BARE METAL CHAIR BEHIND his beat-up desk, next to a file cabinet that neither opens nor shuts properly. A large, barrel-chested young black man with closely cropped hair, Swaby is sitting in a tiny office on campus that is reserved for the president of the student association, underneath a campaign photo of himself and posters of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and Jesse Jackson. He is musing on his decision four years ago to turn down Yale and attend Howard University, one of the nation's largest black colleges. ''Choosing Howard,'' he says, ''was the best decision I could have made. Now I can chill on a corner with the brothers, or walk into a business meeting and know how to act. At Howard, you learn how to do both.''
Outside, amid the neo-classical towers and imposing brick buildings that distinguish the Howard skyline from the modest houses of the black neighborhood surrounding it, some 12,000 students are pursuing the 122-year-old dream a Howard education represents. They are in good company: A healthy percentage of America's black elite have been educated on this campus in Washington, among them Supreme Court Justice Thurgood Marshall, Atlanta Mayor Andrew Young and Pulitzer Prize-winning novelist Toni Morrison. 
Like many of these graduates, Swaby comes from a predominantly black neighborhood, and when he returns home to Hartford he is disturbed by what he sees - ''kids on street corners doing coke and selling dope.''
''A lot of young people don't have any positive role models in the black community,'' says Swaby, who is currently finishing up his last semester at Howard and hopes to teach in the Washington public schools after he graduates in January. ''That's what Howard has given me - a sense of knowing myself and my own worth.''
SWABY'S COMMITMENT TO HIS COL-lege is emblematic of the quiet renaissance that has been taking place recently at America's top black universities. More and more talented black teen-agers, whether from privileged or disadvantaged backgrounds, integrated or inner-city schools, are turning their backs on Harvard and Radcliffe, Vassar and Dartmouth, Princeton and Smith, and flocking to schools like Howard, and Spelman College and Morehouse College in Atlanta. Of the 106 historically black colleges across the country, these three are part of an elite dozen or so that have been beating out their wealthier, Ivy League counterparts in the race to capture the best and the brightest black students.
Escalating application figures at the top black schools tell the story. In 1979, Spelman received fewer than 1,000 requests for a place in its freshman class; this year, that number nearly quadrupled. With seven applicants vying for each spot, Spelman has become nearly as popular a college choice as Dartmouth.
But while students are evincing greater interest in attending these institutions, the schools themselves are struggling with a series of complex - and often contradictory - pressures as they try to meet the demand. Financially, all are strapped for resources; few appear to be truly solvent for the long run. And even those for whom survival is not in question must wrestle with the twin tasks of improving their own academic standards and national prestige while addressing their larger responsibilities to black education and to the nation's black community.
SINCE LAWS MANDATING NONDISCRIMINA-tion and affirmative action in education were passed more than two decades ago, some Americans have come to view the system of black colleges and universities - once the only training ground for black doctors, lawyers, dentists and clergy - as a bit anachronistic, if not downright retrogressive. Why, after all, should an incoming freshman choose a segregated situation at a school with meager resources and overworked, underpaid faculty? Why, particularly when the top, traditionally white, universities have been recruiting black talent with financial aid and the promise of admittance into America's white elite?
The advantage of rubbing shoulders at Ivy League schools with the children of America's corporate and political elite is admittedly strong. Yet for many black teen-agers, there is a more important consideration: the need to immerse themselves in black culture, with black mentors and other black students. This is particularly true for middle-class blacks who come from predominantly white high schools - a group that accounts for roughly half of the current freshman class at Spelman College, for example. As Alonza Robertson, an eloquent but soft-spoken Howard senior from Tampa, explains: ''My white friends from high school tried to talk me out of going to Howard. But I'd never had a black man teach me before, and when it happened, it made me feel kind of proud.''
''It had always been put in my mind that valedictorians were white,'' says Devray Kirkland, a Howard junior from Massillon, Ohio. ''But at college, I wanted to hang around with black valedictorians, black 4.0's.''
Indeed, there is little doubt that black colleges offer much more in the way of confidence-building and do a better job of nurturing their students through the rigors of college than do most traditionally white schools. At Spelman, for example, if a student's work in Dr. Gloria Wade-Gayles's classes seems to be falling off, the student is far less likely to get a failing grade than an invitation to come talk with her professor about what is wrong. ''If a family member has lost a job or something, I give her space,'' says Wade-Gayles, an associate professor of English and women's studies. ''Teaching at Spelman is not a bottom-line kind of thing.''
Dr. Freddye L. Hill, vice president and dean of student affairs at Spelman and formerly dean of Haverford College, finds that this extra support makes a big difference in(Continued on Page 80) students' states of mind. ''The black students I knew at Haverford may have done well, but I never got the feeling they were happy,'' she says. ''At Spelman, they can sing spirituals in their own voices without feeling like outsiders. Students here feel a sense of oneness with the institution.''
That student-university bond translates into the kind of enthusiasm that borders on devotion, and would be the envy of any college president. Sitting in Spelman's cheerfully decorated dining room, surrounded by portraits of successful black women, a group of graduating seniors all offer the same testimonial to their college. ''What Spelman does is an amazing thing,'' says Jacqueline Scott from Highland Park, Ill. ''It allows black women to define ourselves apart from external pressures.''
Fear of having to contend with the pressures of integration at white colleges prompts many black youths, especially those who come from black high schools, to steer clear of white universities. And judging from the stories heard, such fears are not unfounded. The prevailing metaphor black students use to describe their experience at white universities is that of being in a fishbowl. ''There is a question always following you around: Are you good enough?'' explains Tony James, a black graduate of Stanford University. ''People expect you to prove you deserve to be there because of your color.'' Other students recall being told by well-meaning peers that they were ''acceptable blacks'' or ''nothing like our maids.''
There are less subtle, uglier resurgences of campus racism. In the past three years, more than 250 colleges have reported racial incidents, some of them violent. At the University of Massachusetts at Amherst, up to 3,000 white students chased 20 black students and beat one nearly to death following a 1986 World Series game. Last year, arsonists burned down what was to be a fraternity house for blacks at the University of Mississippi. And at the University of Wisconsin at Madison, white members of the Zeta Beta Tau fraternity wore Afro wigs and blackface and held a mock slave auction.
Black enrollment in all colleges and universities has been on the decline since 1976, but the number of students enrolling in black colleges has held relatively steady. These colleges also graduate a much higher percentage of black students than do predominantly white schools. Today, black colleges enroll only 17 percent of America's black college students, but provide more than 32 percent of the nation's black graduates.
Statistics like these lead to a nagging, underlying question: Is the quality of education at America's best black schools as high as at its top white universities? Students and faculty at black schools chafe at the question. The perception that these schools are somehow inferior to their white counterparts is one they've been battling for years. They admit that their physical facilities are often poorer, and grants for extras such as study abroad are much harder to come by. Yet they are also quick to point out that their students are accepted at the most selective graduate programs in the country.
Most administrators at black schools seem to agree with Dr. Donald M. Stewart, a former Spelman president and current president of the College Board, a nonprofit association that sponsors, among other things, the Scholastic Aptitude Test. He believes that faculty qualifications and course requirements at the leading black colleges are every bit as demanding as those of the top white ones. The real difference, says Stewart, is that ''schools like Morehouse and Spelman, which do enroll many of the best-qualified black students, are also willing to take bigger risks on students who have suffered educational inequities in the past.''
PERHAPS THE HOT-test black school today is Spelman, a women's college of 1,700 founded in 1881 by two white women, abolitionists, at Atlanta's Friendship Baptist Church. Dr. Johnnetta B. Cole is one of the reasons why. Two years ago, Cole became the first black woman to serve as president of the school.
Having been raised in Jacksonville, Fla., in the 1940's and 50's by middle-class parents, Cole considers herself a veteran of the ''Jim-Crow South.'' She was educated first at Fisk University in Nashville and later at Oberlin College in Ohio, then went on to become a noted anthropologist and to teach at Hunter College in New York before coming to Spelman.
Her hair graying around the edges, Cole emits a warmth that is at once maternal and sisterly. Dressed in a stylish blue suit and a bright scarf, she sits in an office that bespeaks a history of exotic anthropological expeditions: a South African bridal sash hangs on one wall, a Bundu mask on another. Gazing out the window at the campus, an oasis of manicured lawns and 19th-century New England architecture surrounded by neighborhood housing projects and the newly merged Clark Atlanta University, Cole recalls another dewy morning last fall. Just before dawn, the new president looked out and saw hundreds of Spelman women walking in a procession, holding candles and singing songs to welcome her.
''What they're really responding to is not me; they are seeing themselves in us,'' she insists, her speech a unique mixture of Oxford English and black vernacular. ''And there is something powerful about a place where students see themselves reflected in positions of leadership.''
In the past couple of years, Cole has fostered a special relationship with her students. Many mornings, she takes a long walk around the campus, and her door is generally open to any student who wants to see her. At times, she admits, her office may appear to be under siege, as students line the halls, waiting for hours for compassion, commiseration and inspiration.
Cole shares the credit for bringing Spelman into the limelight with her friends ''Dr. Bill'' Cosby and his wife, ''Sister Camille,'' who donated $20 million to the college last November. Their gift, which was announced at Cole's inauguration and will go primarily toward a new academic center, was five times larger than any Spelman had ever received. The comedian, who sent one of his daughters to Spelman, had already given the school invaluable publicity by filming campus scenes of the popular television show ''A Different World'' there.
Cosby, a graduate of Temple University, says he made the gift to Spelman because he wanted ''Dr. Cole to understand the love that Camille and I have for this college and for the women who, in spite of the odds against them, come here to challenge themselves.''
The Cosbys' contribution summarily dwarfed all others made to any black school, and was specifically intended to inspire other donors to open their wallets. Historically, the rate of alumni participation in fund-raising for black schools has been only half that of white schools, due primarily to the relatively limited financial resources available within the black community. The United Negro College Fund estimates that as of 1987 the average endowment of its member institutions was a paltry $6,710 per student, compared to the average endowment at primarily white institutions of $19,918 per student. In a recent New York Times article, it was pointed out that ''Cornell's endowment stands at $717 million, which is only $38,652 per student.''
Financial hardship takes its toll in a multitude of ways, touching virtually every aspect of black college life. Howard students protest that they have rodents in their dormitories at night and dirty water in the morning. (A tour of one dorm, however, revealed only typical student squalor.) Security in some of the nation's rougher neighborhoods is also a major problem. At one Howard dorm in downtown Washington, a reporter spied crack dealers working a corner just one block away.
Academic sacrifices have had to be made as well. At Spelman, budding scientists must sometimes make do with laboratory equipment that is nearly as old as they are, according to Cole. Faculty members, meanwhile, at the top black institutions are paid considerably less than their colleagues at the best white universities and are expected to teach far greater loads in often-cramped quarters.
Small wonder that black colleges are having trouble holding on to their faculty, about two-thirds of which is black. ''We are losing our black professors - and they are themselves a rare and endangered species,'' warns Cole. These schools are also in danger of losing the promising students who prefer them to their white competitors. According to the United Negro College Fund, about 90 percent of those enrolled at its member colleges require financial aid. Yet the scholarship money, Cole says, is ''barely a vague imitation'' of what schools like Stanford or Brown can offer.
The financial predicament of the leading black colleges is bad enough, but that of most other black schools is far worse. Founded by various religious denominations in the South during Reconstruction, many of these smaller colleges are now on the brink of extinction.
The perception of Spelman as an elitist school for well-to-do black women concerns Cole, who feels that the top black schools are not doing enough to stem the tides of powerlessness and poverty in the wider black community. ''Spelman has had a long tradition of service, but we need to do more,'' Cole admits. ''How can we call ourselves leaders if we turn away from the very reality that a third of black America lives in poverty? We need to build more sturdy black bridges into our communities.''
ACROSS THE STREET from Spelman lies Morehouse, a men's college founded in 1867 by a former slave and a Baptist minister to teach other former slaves to read and write and to prepare them for the ministry. The school struggled through its early years, moving and renaming itself many times, until the famous black educator John Hope took over as its president in 1906. Under his leadership, Morehouse began to educate not merely future preachers and missionaries but black professionals of all types.
On the spot where Confederate soldiers once staged their most stubborn resistance, during the siege of Atlanta, 2,600 Morehouse men now traverse a 55-acre campus that adjoins Clark Atlanta University. Like Spelman, Morehouse believes in giving its students a healthy dose of nurturing. They are encouraged to conduct themselves like the leaders they hope to become. It is not uncommon, for example, to see students wearing suits and ties to class. They seem to take up these symbols of their future aspirations quite comfortably and without much rebellion. There is a sense at Morehouse that students, faculty and administration alike are all engaged in the same struggle for black pride and achievement. As John Wesley Days Jr., a recent graduate, puts it: ''There is an air of expectancy about this place. We understand that the psychological uplift of our people is rooted in our education.''
A massive, imposing statue of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. stands at the entrance to the chapel on campus, in tribute to Morehouse's most famous alumnus. It was here, in his student days, that the civil rights leader first read Thoreau's thoughts on civil disobedience, and here, after his assassination, that a funeral service was held for the public.
Looming perhaps even larger than King's spirit is that of the man he called ''my spiritual and intellectual father,'' Dr. Benjamin Elijah Mays, president of the school from 1940 to 1967. The son of a sharecropper, Mays instilled in his students, in the words of Morehouse's current president, Dr. Leroy Keith, ''the belief that they could accomplish any task set before them.''
Spike Lee, the celebrated black film maker, is one Morehouse man who took Mays's words to heart. Although his 1988 movie ''School Daze'' is in large measure a lampooning of a Morehouse-type campus, he nevertheless credits his alma mater with giving him the inspiration and the belief in himself to pursue his art. ''Without the strong foundation I received at Morehouse,'' says Lee, who graduated in 1979, ''I would never have gotten through film school.''
Despite this strong leadership ethic, Morehouse - like other black colleges - must contend with some of the same problems that white colleges face. Last month, for instance, an 18-year-old sophomore died in a fraternity hazing incident. The youth, who in childhood had a heart ailment, suffered cardiac arrest after he was purportedly shoved around by members of the college's chapter of Alpha Phi Alpha, the nation's oldest fraternity for blacks. The administration, whose policies regulating pledging activities and prohibiting hazing had been ignored, acted swiftly: two students were immediately expelled and eight suspended for a year; the fraternity was barred indefinitely from campus.
Outside the walls of Morehouse and Spelman, the need for black American leadership is even more urgent, as the education of black youth drifts into a state of crisis. Roughly one-third of all black teen-agers never graduate from high school. And of those who do, far too few make it through college. (Only 31 percent of the black students who entered college in 1980 had managed to graduate by 1986.) Studies paint an even bleaker picture of the black male in particular, who seems to be slowly disappearing from higher education. Against a rise in virtually all other ethnic groups, the number of black male high school graduates in college between 1976 and 1986 fell by more than 7 percent, and between 1977 and 1987, the number of doctoral degrees they earned declined by more than 50 percent. A recent study of high school graduates in Atlanta shows that black men ''were the group least likely to apply to college, the least likely to be accepted and the least likely, if accepted, to enroll.''
For the black community, the implications of these trends are devastating. With fewer role models who hold college degrees, children are less likely to overcome the social and economic barriers that poverty and ghetto life erect on the path to higher education. Leroy Keith insists that the problem of black education is not just a black problem but ''an American one,'' and he blames a decade of ''racism, masquerading as conservatism.'' Johnnetta Cole faults the Federal Government for allowing black life in the inner cities to deteriorate to such a degree. ''Before I charge our people, I charge our Government,'' she says. ''It is just plain absurd to think that we can pull ourselves up by some imaginary bootstrap.''
Nevertheless, students at the leading black schools are trying. Spelman students recently founded the ''African Sisterhood,'' designed in part to foster a relationship between themselves and youngsters living in Atlanta's housing projects. A similar program at Howard also matches ghetto children with positive role models from the university. And at Morehouse, a group of students is starting to organize an after-hours school in the John Hope projects, which is designed, according to Eddie Glaude Jr., a recent Morehouse graduate, ''to let the little brothers know that learning can be cool.''
NAMED IN HONOR OF OLI-ver Otis Howard, a white officer in the Union Army who developed an interest in the welfare of former slaves, Howard University was founded in 1867 and staffed by members of the First Congregational Society of Washington. While the founders intended to establish a black theological seminary, the school's charter, signed and approved by President Andrew Johnson, called for the creation of ''a university for the education of youth in the liberal arts and sciences.''
Today, with 18 separate schools and colleges, nine research institutes and a 500-bed teaching hospital, spread out over five campuses, Howard is unarguably the largest and most prestigious black research university in America - the only one to aspire to the order of a Yale or Johns Hopkins. In recent years, however, Howard's reputation as the historic ''capstone'' of black education worldwide has been challenged, as other black schools claim more and more of the top black students. Last year, for instance, Morehouse and Spelman together attracted 21 winners of National Achievement Scholarships for black students, while Howard, with twice as many students, enrolled only 17. In the opinion of Mary Francis Berry, a Howard alumna who is now a professor of history at the University of Pennsylvania, ''the Howard faculty is not inspired. And important work there is not attended to.''
Howard's administration has recently come under fire in Congress for its management of the nearly $180 million it received last year in Federal funds, which cover most of its academic budget and about 40 percent of its operating expenses. Citing ''management deficiencies,'' a House committee report has called for a full audit of Howard's financial situation.
Moreover, because of its location in the nation's capital, Howard's difficulties are often played out in the national media, most recently against the background of partisan politics. The nomination to the university board of Lee Atwater, chairman of the Republican National Committee, became the catalyst for a dramatic demonstration last March that catapulted Howard into the nightly news. Atwater had offended many Howard students when, as the 1988 Presidential campaign manager for George Bush, he helped create the ''Willie Horton issue.''
''Atwater's use of the symbol of an African-American man raping a white woman,'' according to the editors of Howard's campus newspaper, ''performed a sinister function as the most racist strategy in a national Presidential campaign in the 20th century.''
Angry students who had no desire to see Atwater play a role at their university occupied the administration building and shut it down for three days. They also presented a series of demands, which charged that administrators were dealing ineffectively with problems including a cumbersome financial aid process, inadequate campus security, overburdened faculty course loads and dilapidated dormitories. There were tense confrontations with Washington police, and a high-profile intervention by Jesse Jackson. The demonstration ended peacefully after Atwater resigned and administrators agreed to improve conditions on campus.
James E. Cheek, who announced he would retire as president of Howard, as planned, shortly after the incident, continues to insist that the media played up the demonstrations far beyond their real significance. Though most observers estimated the number of protestors to be 3,000, Cheek insists that ''there were 500 tops . . . and they were exploited by political opportunists . . . like Jesse Jackson.''
Cheek, a lifelong Republican and an outspoken supporter of both Ronald Reagan and George Bush, had himself been criticized by students. Even his defenders admit that in the final years of his two decades at Howard's helm, the black administrator had grown increasingly remote from the black students and their concerns.
Ironically perhaps, the protest seemed to give the Howard community a greater esprit de corps. Many faculty members and alumni supported the students' efforts and viewed the passing of Cheek's baton as an opportunity to revitalize the school. Judging by this year's application figures, which matched last year's record, Howard remains an attractive option to large numbers of America's most talented black youth.
In the wake of the Howard demonstrations, another major controversy continues to rock the black educational community. The issue, briefly stated, is: What should black colleges teach?
Like most black schools, Howard attempts to strike a balance between two separate educational priorities: how to succeed in a predominantly white American society, while building pride in a special black heritage. Business students, for instance, are taught how to deal with racism in the workplace and how to speak the language of white corporate America. At the same time, all Howard students are required to take at least one course in African-American culture.
Still, the curriculum of most black schools remains weighted heavily toward traditional Western culture, which means ''students at Howard learn that their own history and culture is optional, while the Europeans' is required,'' explains Ronald W. Walters, a professor of political science. Many professors and students feel the time has come for a massive infusion of African-American classes.
This kind of thinking is what led to a second set of Howard student demands: That the university establish a graduate program in African-American studies and that more of an Afrocentric thrust be given to all courses. In the end, Howard's administration agreed to study the feasibility of the students' demands. Clearly, though, the issue of an African-American versus Eurocentric education is far from being resolved, and is likely to remain a contentious one in the coming decade.
THE BALANCING ACT facing Howard's next president (to be named in the coming year) and all the top black colleges is a daunting one, to say the least. These schools must somehow divide their attention and meager resources among several priorities. They must continue to provide a top-flight education for some of the nation's best students, while also reaching out to save future applicants from the poverty, drugs and crime that plague much of the black community.
Does America still need its black colleges? Yes, says Michael R. Winston, a third-generation Howard graduate and and a vice president for academic affairs there, who sees their worth in the character of the students they produce. ''We don't have minority students here,'' Winston insists. ''We have nothing but mainstream students who are recapturing what was lost of their intellectual and cultural heritage.''
John Wesley Days, a product of that legacy, states the case for black colleges another way. ''It's far more important to know yourself,'' says Days, remembering his Morehouse days, ''than to own a Harvard sweatshirt.''

HEADLINE: WHITE HOUSE SPEECHWRITER

 BODY:
Let's face it, Peggy Noonan is a genius (along with Ronald Reagan's public relations magicians).
When she joined the Reagan team in 1984, Reaganomics was producing Federal budget deficits of over $200 billion a year and saddling future generations with a mountain of debt. Ms. Noonan and other White House speechwriters somehow portrayed Reagan as the candidate of economic growth and sound fiscal management. 
By the time Ms. Noonan was serving her final year at the White House, the Administration had become mired in scandal - from Iran-contra to Edwin Meese to the bizarre tales of Nancy Reagan's astrology. Yet again, through a wave of the magic pen, she and her colleagues portrayed the outgoing President as a gracious figure of historic proportions, even as a man of integrity.
Either the black art of speechwriting has become too powerful to resist, or the American public has grown too passive to bother.
 
DAVID CALLAHAN
 Princeton, N.J.
