The New York Times

PUB-DATE: November 5, 1989

SECTION: Section 7; Page 15, Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 2531 words

HEADLINE: THE PARADOX OF SLAVERY

BYLINE: By C. VANN WOODWARD; C. Vann Woodward's most recent book is ''The Future of the Past.''

 BODY:

WITHOUT CONSENT OR CONTRACT
The Rise and Fall of American Slavery.
By Robert William Fogel.
1539 pp. New York:
W. W. Norton & Company. $22.50.
Robert William Fogel's ''Without Consent or Contract'' is a sequel to, an extension of and a defense of ''Time on the Cross,'' the 1974 book about slavery on which he collaborated with Stanley L. Engerman. The earlier book provoked more interest, outrage and indignation than any scholarly work on American history since Charles A. Beard's ''Economic Interpretation of the Constitution'' in 1913. Feelings were stirred over both books for much the same reason - those of the public for an apparent assault on national pieties and convictions, those of historians not only for that but also for what they saw as violations of scholarly rules and standards. 
Stressing the statistics and methods of quantification, ''Time on the Cross'' sought to expose and correct the errors of traditional historians about slavery. In place of a Simon Legree or a cavalier fop as the typical plantation master, the book presented a shrewd businessman running a well-managed, efficient and highly profitable enterprise with labor policies that anticipated those of modern industry. Instead of pathetic Uncle Toms or cringing, lazy Sambos, his slaves were diligent, hard-working and very efficient workers - in fact 35 percent more efficient than free Northern farm labor. To all appearances they had adopted or internalized the Protestant work ethic of their master and joined him in pursuit of bourgeois aims and values.
Impossible under the cruel and brutal treatment pictured by the abolitionists and credited by traditional historians, the rational business-labor relations postulated in ''Time on the Cross'' could only exist under a benign order. And such was the slave system uncovered by the cliometricians. According to the book, the diligent field hand was rewarded by 90 percent of the income he produced and induced to work harder by promise of rewards, privileges and promotions that made the whip largely unnecessary. The benevolent and cheerful order was blessed by strong, stable family life with Victorian morals. It was rarely broken by the sale of members or degraded by white sexual exploitation. By this account, few free-labor forces of Europe and America were so well housed, clothed and fed as the South's slaves. Their treatment was said to explain in part the rarity of slave resistance or rebellion and a rate of population increase unapproached by any other slave population. The South of the 1850's, the authors contended, enjoyed more per capita wealth than any European country save England.
Critical response to ''Time on the Cross'' was no doubt sharpened by its polemical style and the strident way in which historians were ''corrected,'' instructed about facts they had long known or findings they knew to be false and lectured about neglecting quantifiable data and methods. But critics also discovered and pointed out numerous lapses in scholarship, errors in fact and breaches in the elemental rules of quantification. Two critics of the book found its casual use of evidence ''shocking,'' and a team of five quantifying historians joined in declaring the work to be ''shot through with egregious errors.'' Some scholars joined in the popular resentment of what was felt to be the moral blindness of the authors. One said that they ''averaged out and depersonalized'' the slave experience, and another that their book ''raises a profound moral issue without treating it as such.''
In ''Without Consent or Contract'' Mr. Fogel has the good judgment to moderate the polemical tone of the earlier work as well as its strident lectures to other historians. In returning to the original economic thesis he tones down some of his previous arguments and avoids repetition of the logic and evidence most discredited by critics. He even admits that ''cliometricians may have exaggerated the role of manufacturing and romanticized the economic dynamism of the yeomen.'' On the whole, however, he sticks to the main points of the original theses and even brings forth new evidence to strengthen them.
So we are still presented with the apparent anomaly of a Southern slave economy that was more productive, more efficient, more profitable and wealthier than the free-labor economy of the North, and slave labor that was diligent, hard-working and far more efficient when used in the gang system than free labor in its own habits. While the ''businessman'' planter is now described as a ''plutocrat,'' we are assured that ''the southern plutocrats were considerably richer, on average, than their northern counterparts'' - about twice as rich, in fact - and that they were much more numerous. The regime of the planter plutocrat, moreover, was as benign as that of the planter businessman -as protective and cherishing of slave family integrity, as nurturing of slave health and welfare and as innocent of brutal punishments, of ''breeding'' for the market and of sexual abuse of slave property. Slave trading was for use, not gain, and accounted for less than 1 percent of planter profits. All this while the per capita income of the South was growing at a rate one-third higher than that of the North, a rate exceeded substantially over a long term only by ''a handful of countries.''
For all that, the new book contains striking departures from its predecessor. It undertakes to ''come to grips with what many scholars see as the unwelcome and ominous paradox'' of a system that was ''horribly retrogressive in its social, political, and ideological aspects,'' yet was found to be efficient, prosperous and benign. The missing moral dimension was not satisfactorily supplied in ''Time on the Cross,'' despite its incongruous abolitionist title. ''The ultimate issues of this book,'' we are assured by its author, ''are moral issues.'' (The new book might well have swapped titles with the old.) By confronting these issues resolutely, he believes, we can not only illuminate the past but gain deeper understanding of ''the issues of our own time in a new way.''
More than half the book is devoted to the antislavery movement and the political struggles leading to the Civil War. This is traditional narrative history, in which quantification plays an insignificant part and innovations are few. Mr. Fogel says he has ''endeavored to make it a good story, one that will be edifying and intriguing to a wide range of readers.'' Intriguing it might perhaps be said to be. It was ''mystics,'' we learn, who solved the problem of evil producing good. Transcending reason and trusting what they took as divine inspiration, the ''mystics,'' or abolitionists, ''declared that slavery was not just a sin, but an extraordinary sin, a sin so corrupting'' as to create ''an insurmountable barrier to both personal and national salvation.''
The familiar story of the antislavery movement begins with the British campaign, to which nothing particularly new is added save by one of the few contributions cliometrics makes to this half of the book. Indexes of Parliamentary votes and sugar prices make it more impossible than ever to defend the old theory that British emancipation was caused by the ''defection of capitalists from the ranks of slaveholders.'' That honor is awarded to the landed gentry, which did ''just enough to ensure that the Establishment enjoyed the allegiance of the middle classes and the upper strata of the laboring class.''
The abolitionist crusade in America was sparked by the British example but fueled by the excesses of religious zeal created in Yankeedom by the Second Great Awakening and its frenzies in the early 19th century. Using evangelical fervor and revivalist methods, the abolitionists stressed personal holiness achieved by repentance. Since slavery was ''always, everywhere, and only a sin,'' the remedy was to stop sinning. But at once. As William Lloyd Garrison had it, ''No plan was needed to stop sinning.'' But that did not get slaves very far toward emancipation.
Desperate to advance their cause, antislavery leaders turned to national politics, and, writes Mr. Fogel, that was where moral ambiguities again set in, for the deeper they became involved in politics, ''the more they conceded principle to expediency.'' The story of sectional conflict and politics, from the Missouri Compromise to Lincoln's election, is retold to show the compromises and the sometimes cynical expedients by which Northern nativism against the impoverished millions of immigrants, and even prejudices against blacks, were used to forge a victorious antislavery coalition against the Slave Power Conspiracy and its allies in the North.
The antislavery people supplied an indictment of the South's morality and culture calculated to ''abolitionize the North.'' Their descriptions of ''the horrors of southern culture,'' according to Mr. Fogel, ''were analogous to the revivalist's descriptions of the pain and torture'' of hell itself. Southern masters not only beat their slaves unmercifully but also their wives. They were filled with ''lust for power'' as well as ''lust for pagan pleasures.'' Theirs was ''an erotic society'' that had become ''one great Sodom,'' compared to which a Turkish harem was ''a cradle of virgin purity.'' They and their Northern allies were bent upon ''outright enslavement of all white labor'' and the reduction of the North to a ''conquered province.''
In what Mr. Fogel calls ''the most massive ideological campaign of the age,'' this indictment of the South was carried to the North in a deluge of propaganda by abolitionists until it became ''routinely published in conventional magazines'' and won the support of ''such towering figures of belles lettres as Henry Wadsworth Longfellow, Ralph Waldo Emerson, and James Russell Lowell.'' In apparent agreement, the author quotes John C. Calhoun as saying that this propaganda would teach the North ''a hatred more deadly than one hostile nation ever entertained towards another.''
The abolitionists' picture of slavery, quite at odds with that of our cliometrician, and the methods they used to destroy slavery, cause ''agonizing dilemmas and paradoxes'' for an author who set out to resolve moral dilemmas. Antislavery heroes prove ''somehow less perfect than one would like heroes to be''; their free labor alternative to slavery was ''still brutal and exploitative,'' and ''the leaders of the struggle to improve the condition of free labor were often aligned with the slaveholders, while the abolitionists were often aligned with the foes of the free labor movement.'' What's worse, ''exaggerations of the severity of slavery divert attention from the novel forms of exploitation that replaced it.'' It is all very confusing, and the author abandons any attempt to present ''an emerging scholarly consensus on the moral paradoxes and dilemmas,'' for no such consensus exists. He can only offer his own solution.
Mr. Fogel finds that the moral crusaders were forced ''to compromise principles, join arms with opportunists, accept immoral propositions . . . and deliberately mislead'' because ''they could vanquish sin only by sinning.'' On the other hand, ''the cause was moral and the intention was virtuous,'' and the deception ''harmed only the slaveholders.'' The Republicans, ''without pandering to northern negrophobia,'' would have lost the election of 1860. So much for the dilemma. In order to ''resolve the paradox,'' Mr. Fogel has to ''cut the tie between economic success (or failure) and moral virtue (or evil).'' While ''slavery was profitable, efficient, and economically viable . . . it was never morally good.'' In place of ''the indictment fashioned by the winners of the antislavery struggle,'' he believes that ''we need a new indictment,'' one more up to date.
He offers his own personal and ''tentative'' moral case against slavery on four counts: it gave one group of people ''unrestrained personal domination'' over another group, a power that was ''by itself profoundly evil and corrupting''; it denied slaves basic economic opportunity; it denied them citizenship and all its rights; and it denied them the rights of ''cultural self-identification'' and ''cultural autonomy.'' While modern opinion would find these counts unexceptionable, Mr. Fogel is frank to admit that much free labor in the world of slavery here and abroad suffered from some of these same deprivations, and that a majority of abolitionists would have opposed extending to slaves and free labor some of the rights that his new bill of indictment denounces slavery for denying.
Still plagued by paradox, the seeker of firm moral ground resorts in the end to ''what-if'' speculation - what if there had been no Civil War? Mr. Fogel believes that war was the only way to end slavery in the United States and is willing to grant, therefore, that this country was the only one of 20-odd slave societies unable to find a peaceful way to emancipation. The South of slavery was growing, not diminishing, in confidence and strength, and he speculates that with independence ''it would have emerged as a major international power,'' perhaps ''one of the world's strongest military powers.'' He speculates also that peaceful secession would have indefinitely postponed emancipation in this country, slowed antislavery movements everywhere, strengthened serfdom in the places it lingered and handicapped the struggle for democratic rights for the lower classes in Europe. These are not conclusions derived from econometrics or science, but they persuade him that the results of the Civil War were worth the lives of 600,000 young men.
This reviewer can only hope that he has been able to do justice to this book, but he has reasons to doubt that this was quite possible. He is informed in a publisher's note at the beginning that this is only ''the primary volume of 'Without Consent or Contract' . . . a nontechnical summary and interpretation of findings by the director of a research group,'' and that there are three companion volumes: ''Evidence and Methods,'' ''Technical Papers: Markets and Production'' and ''Technical Papers: Conditions of Slave Life and the Transition to Freedom.'' Their importance to the volume under review is attested to by innumerable references to them in its notes, references to sources, evidence, authorities, ''the full canon of research on slavery and related topics by the contributors'' and ''extensive discussions of the historiography of the slave system and of the antislavery struggle.'' The publisher's note says that these companion volumes ''are available for those who are concerned.'' It turns out on inquiry, however, that they are only available in manuscript and will not be printed for several months. It is not the practice of responsible journals to review books not published, nor of reviewers to review books in manuscript. If the reviewer appears to have been in error or the author reviewed to have suffered injustice, it would seem that the publisher must share - and, if acting without the author's approval, perhaps shoulder - part of the blame.

HEADLINE: ADVANCE GUARD FOR THE Y.M.C.A.

BYLINE: By TRACY B. STRONG; Tracy B. Strong, the son of China missionaries and the co-author of ''Right in Her Soul: The Life of Anna Louise Strong,'' teaches political theory at the University of California, San Diego.

 BODY:

GOLDEN INCHES
The China Memoir of Grace Service.
Edited by John S. Service.
Illustrated. 346 pp. Berkeley:
University of California Press. $19.95.
The foreign Christian presence in China in the first 40 years of this century increasingly appears to have been an important contributing factor in the slow development of the Chinese revolution between 1911 and 1949. Some sense of this can be gathered from John Hersey's fine novel ''The Call.'' Yet that book and most others on the subject remain focused on the men who lived for their ''call.'' Grace Service's memoir, ''Golden Inches,'' helps us understand that often behind those men, making their work possible, were equally extraordinary women. 
It is a wonderful, sad, moving memoir by an indomitable American who went to China with her husband. Inspired like so many others by the brilliant and charismatic John R. Mott of the Student Volunteer Movement, Bob Service and his wife arrived in China in 1905, before the end of the empire, before the beginning of the revolution. They lived there until 1934, 30 of the most turbulent years in Chinese history.
Service was a Y.M.C.A. secretary based in Sichuan, and, from the image presented here, he was saintly. Completely dedicated to the Y, he labored long and hard to build an indigenous self-help movement in China. Indeed, like many others, he came to feel that ''he had no place in America.'' Behind and beside him, and making his life possible, was his highly intelligent, reflective, well-read and artistic wife, a woman who was self-disciplined rather than overtly pious.
The point of view in the memoir remains hers; the book is only secondarily about successes and failures in bringing the Y's programs to China. The revolution itself is something that happens to her, and must be dealt with like a natural event. ''Golden Inches'' is not a book to read for a new interpretation of the early stages of the Chinese revolution. Rather, it is about the support that men like Bob Service had to have in order to be able to carry out their vocation.
And what support it was - a kind of marriage that seems to have all but disappeared in our time. ''I thought I had given you certainty when I brought you to China,'' Service remarked apologetically to his wife in 1934, after being ''demobilized'' by the Y.M.C.A. in response to economic pressures. Such a vision of ''certainty'' could only be that which a shared sense of vocation can bring. By the time the Services had reached Chengdu (by boat, up the Yangtze) in 1905, their first-born, an infant daughter, had died of dysentery and Bob had contracted a severe case of malaria; within a year, Grace had at least one miscarriage. They still knew no Chinese.
But the Services endured - through civil war, battles, disease, riots - because in a way almost unspoken, but nonetheless absolutely firm, they had each other. After one episode outside their compound wall, Grace Service remarked: ''We heard that there had been some 150 to 200 executions, but soon the whole episode was merely an incident in the course of daily life.'' The Services came to love China and drew strength from it. Their three sons were born in Sichuan.
If the Services tried to accept China as it presented itself to them, they had more trouble with other foreigners. Again and again there are telling passages about the standoffish, almost imperial attitudes of fundamentalist missionaries who put doctrine above love, in contrast to the attempts of the Y to develop a Chinese-based organization. It is interesting to note that the Protestant churches in China are currently trying to follow the pattern of development set by the Y. The Services were people equal to the turbulence of the times in which they lived. ''Golden Inches'' not only gives many fascinating glimpses of historical events; more important, it shows us what it meant to live through those events and deal with them without rancor, resentment or facile anger and enthusiasm. It reads fluidly and plainly. Like most of her generation, Grace Service was not introspective, but her memoir is all the more powerful for not being so: it extends our concept of what can be ordinary.
John S. Service, a Foreign Service officer in China from 1933 until 1945 and one of the first United States Government officials to have understood the nature of the developing Chinese revolution, has expertly edited and annotated his mother's memoir. He has filled in necessary historical information, and he shows just enough filial rebellion in his footnotes to give the reader an added sense of the family.

HEADLINE: A PEOPLE UNDER LOCK AND KEY

BYLINE: By DAIVD SPANIER; David Spanier is a diplomatic correspondent for Independent Radio News in London.

 BODY:

WALL
The Inside Story of Divided Berlin.
By Peter Wyden.
Illustrated. 762 pp. New York:
Simon & Schuster. $27.50.
Ugly, anti-human, provocatively divisive, the Berlin wall has been the political symbol of the cold war. I use the past tense because the wall, evidently enough, is coming down. It may not be removed tomorrow, or even in the next few months, but it will surely disappear in a year or two, unless some unforeseen and disastrous reversal of the whole Gorbachev revolution supervenes. 
Note that the wall is not coming down because the East German regime has seen the light of liberty. It is crumbling because the economic and philosophical system that underpinned it, the mortar that held the whole hateful edifice in place, has collapsed.
Peter Wyden's ''Wall'' is timely. Although it was written before the extraordinary events of recent months, when thousands of East Germans voted with their feet and fled to West Germany and Erich Honecker, the East German leader of 18 years, was ousted, the book sums up one of the crucial events, perhaps the touchstone, of the postwar era.
The Berlin wall, of course, was built in 1961 to keep the East Germans in. That dire need remains. But now, instead of using force and repression - which East Germans will no longer tolerate without a struggle - to hold the people in place, the East German Government itself must change. Whether it can become more responsive to its citizens' aspirations leads to the explosive question of a united Germany. The end of the wall, therefore, will likely raise a new problem.
This book recalls in fine detail how the wall came to be built. It went up suddenly and secretly, to the surprise of the Western allies. At this distance, the event can be viewed with some piquancy and, on occasion, wit. The most entertaining section of ''Wall'' describes how the West's muddled espionage failed to provide warning of the East German plan. It was like a John le Carre spy thriller, but played out as farce.
Mr. Wyden, an American who was born in Berlin, is the author of ''Day One: Before Hiroshima and After,'' ''Bay of Pigs: The Untold Story'' and other books. Accordingly, he has the journalist's virtue of having dug into the records and talked to many of those involved. His style is fast-paced, his analysis only skin-deep, but the depth of his affection for Berlin is never in doubt.
And what a dreadful, mock-heroic epic the story of the Berlin wall is: mock because of the inadequacies of the West; heroic because the building of the wall, it turned out, risked nuclear war. ''The Berlin crisis of 1961,'' the author writes, ''would never be recognized as a time of acute nuclear danger. Yet it was. It was the first time that a major power openly threatened another with nuclear annihilation'' - when the Soviet leader Nikita S. Khrushchev bluffed President John F. Kennedy at the Vienna summit. ''I've got a terrible problem,'' Kennedy told the journalist James Reston. ''If [Khrushchev] thinks I'm inexperienced and have no guts, until we remove those ideas we won't get anywhere with him. So we have to act.'' Mr. Wyden concludes: ''The President now calculated there was one chance in five that Berlin would lead to nuclear war. But who could be sure? Perhaps the risk was greater?''
The cynical view of the East Berliners and the calculation of the Soviet side was that the West would not take serious action against the wall. They were right. (Secretary of State Dean Rusk, went one joke of the day, ''is a recorded announcement.'') ''You must do something!'' Willy Brandt, the Mayor of West Berlin, exclaimed to the American, British and French generals who governed the city. It took many months and the 1962 Cuban missile crisis before that something happened - Kennedy's inspired declaration, in June 1963, to the city and to the world: ''Ich bin ein Berliner.'' It became the most famous phrase of the cold war.
The first half of this big book makes racy reading. The second, containing a lot of factitious material about what happened later, somewhat diminishes what would otherwise have been a much sharper and more salutary jab at our forgetfulness about recent history. But the many moving moments and the tributes to individual courage recorded by Mr. Wyden serve as reminders that the Berlin wall was not about bricks and barbed wire in defense of Marxism, but about people.
 

 
THE UGLIEST LANDMARK
 Before Peter Wyden fled Berlin in 1937, his childhood was scarred by anti-Semitism. In school, he said, his teacher would ''lecture that Jews were the direct descendants of the Devil. And I was the only Jewish kid in the class. Everyone would turn around and look at me to see if my horns were showing.''
He returned to Europe in 1945 with the United States Army, and he stayed on in Berlin for a year working for a military newspaper. It was a historical moment, he said in a telephone interview from his home in Connecticut, a time Germans now call the ''Zero Hour,'' the start of the modern era.
In 1965, Mr. Wyden again journeyed to Berlin, this time with his sons. He realized that the most vivid memory they would have of their father's birthplace was the Berlin wall, and the idea for a book about his native city and its ugliest landmark took root. He said that one revelation in ''Wall'' pleases him more than any other. After two years trying to discover how the East Germans managed to keep their plans for the wall secret, Mr. Wyden found a man who had been forgotten by history - the executive assistant at the time the wall was built to the recently ousted East German leader, Erich Honecker. Mr. Wyden said he rushed to the East to meet the man, and much of what he learned had never before been committed to paper: ''If you were to read these paragraphs to C.I.A. people who were in Berlin at the time, I can guarantee what their reaction would be. They would be quite, quite interested.''
 
J. R. MOEHRINGER

LENGTH: 1247 words

HEADLINE: PERSPECTIVES: The Starrett Proposal;
Giving Housing a Push in Spring Creek

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
THE occasional visitor to Starrett City, the 5,800-unit rental development near the Shore Parkway in southeastern Brooklyn, might be puzzled by the wording of the welcoming sign. It no longer says Starrett City. It now reads ''Welcome to Starrett at Spring Creek.''
The subtle message is that the builders of Starrett City are now developing surrounding land. In the end, Starrett City may become the high-rise centerpiece in a greatly expanding Spring Creek residential district of Brooklyn, running from Fresh Creek on the west to the Queens line.
The new housing would be owner-occupied, low-rise town houses and apartments. Starrett City itself, which opened in the early 70's, may well convert to co-ops or condominiums in the mid-90's, when its first mortgage comes due and a Federal Section 8 subsidy runs out. 
The major element in the building program would be $1 billion in new construction of a planned low-rise community, called Spring Creek Estates, proposed by Starrett Housing Corporation. It would have 4,700 housing units as well as schools, parks and other public facilities, on 230 acres of urban-renewal land east of Starrett City.
The Department of Housing Preservation and Development has given major builders - with minimum assets of $100 million - until Nov. 13 to submit competitive bids for the land under terms that essentially have been negotiated with the Starrett development team. The city would supply about $100 million in the form of $25,000 a unit in assistance for 3,600 income-limited, or ''affordable,'' for-sale units, which helps the builder cover the cost of the on-site improvements, including roads, sewers, water mains, parks and sidewalks, and a bridge across a creek to facilitate acces to the Shore Parkway.
From the standpoint of overall city housing policy, the Spring Creek Estates proposal focuses attention on the direction that Mayor Edward I. Koch's 10-year, $5.1 billion housing program has taken in the middle of its fourth year.
But on two smaller sites close to Starrett City, low-rise home ownership development is already proceeding. The prime financial partner in the two projects is the 68-year-old Disque D. Deane, who in 1985 became managing general partner in the Starrett City ownership group. Robert C. Rosenberg, chairman of Grenadier Realty Corporation, the Starrett subsidiary that manages Starrett City, is the project manager. He also heads Starrett's Spring Creek development team.
''We have one of the finest integrated rental developments on the East Coast,'' said Mr. Deane, who was the Lazard Freres & Company partner who brought together the equity capital for Starrett City. The racial composition was fixed at 65 percent white and 35 percent minority until a United States Supreme Court decision last year obliged the development to rent out vacancies on a color-blind basis. New waiting lists are expected to tilt the ratio toward more minority occupancy by a point or two over a year. Turnover is slow.
Whatever the racial composition, new home ownership on surrounding property is likely to solidify the development and its surroundings. The first new project, The Landings at Fresh Creek, is already in the early stage of construction on 13 acres of the wetlands that protect Fresh Creek, just west of Starrett City.
There are to be 282 condominiums in three-story town houses with salmon-brick facades trimmed in stone and built in five clusters. It is a market-rate, as-of-right development, with 204 two-bedroom, two-bath units of about 1,100 square feet and 78 three-bedroom, two-bath units of about 1,400 square feet. Each unit will have a separate entrance to the street, and each will get one on-site parking space. The architect is Herbert Mandel of Manhattan.
ACCORDING to Harvey Rudman, the managing general partner in the project, the first 114 condominiums will go on the market in February for occupancy next summer. Initial prices are expected to start at about $170,000 for the two-bedrooms and about $220,000 for the three-bedrooms.
The second project has been named Fresh Creek Estates. It is a plan for 477 housing units on a 14-acre site at Flatlands Avenue and Pennsylvanian Avenue, with 267 market-rate town houses and 210 affordable units. This would be a gatehhouse community with a pair of roads along an interior street system, with 210 spaces of covered parking and 267 of open parking.
The developers are proposing state and city assistance totaling about $25,000 a unit, or $5.2 million, to help offset the cost of covered parking and the relatively high land cost for a site that had previously been intended for commercial use. In the affordable units, buyers would meet moderate- to middle-income eligibility standards of the New York City Partnership. Marketed today, the housing would sell mainly to families earning $35,000 to $53,000 a year.
A REZONING is required for the large-scale site plan, which has been developed by the firm of Gruzen Samton Steinglass with Mr. Mandel. The public review is expected next year.
These two projects represent an investment of approximately $115 million, and no small statement of faith in Spring Creek's capacity to draw home buyers. But they fade in significance in comparison with the 4,700-unit Spring Creek Estates plan. It would bring not only housing but also 104,000 square feet of of retail space, 20,000 square feet of professional office space, two elementary schools and an intermediate school.
There would be a 50,000-square-foot community clubhouse with a swimming pool, 65 acres of landscaped public open space, sites reserved for religious or institutional use, and a 60,000-square-foot parcel for an industrial use. The master plan is being done by Cooper Robertson & partners.
The housing component, besides its affordable-housing units, also would have 500 market-rate units, 400 units for the elderly, and 200 units sold to families with incomes in the high $20,000 to low $30,000 range. Buyers of the affordable units will have incomes in the middle $30,000 to low $50,000 range.
In decades to come, Spring Creek could well emerge as a total planned-unit development, with owner-occupied high-rises as its centerpiece and the Estates as its low-rise component, all under single management.
The plan also provides for 50 units to be reserved for use by the state Office of Mental Health, which agreed to yield its claim to 30 acres of land in the urban-renewal area where a children's psychiatric center was once planned. The agency will also be allowed 20 units at Starrett City itself.
From the standpoint of city housing policy, the 4,700-unit Spring Creek Estates plan would provide about 16 percent of the estimated 30,000 new housing units that Mayor Koch hopes to see built under the 10-year plan. It is a big step forward.
An argument could be made that a development consuming as much land as Spring Creek Estates might be planned for a greater diversity of housing types. But the housing build-up in the middle-income spectrum is needed as a boost to the city's attractiveness for the younger workers it needs for economic growth.
The concept of keeping a development of such scale in the hands of one professionally and financially capable development team, which already has a demonstrated commitment to the location, probably would mean, in the end, a better quality of development, a better prospect of completion and a greater asset to the city's housing supply.

HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:

Getting a Code Copy
Question: I have seen references in the newspaper citing various parts of the state's rent-stabilization code designed to help protect tenant rights. I would like to see the guidelines in their entirety. How can I obtain or purchase a copy? . . . B. J., Forest Hills, Queens
Answer: You can buy copies of the code for $54 from Lenz Riecker Publishers, the company that has the contract to print the state's laws and regulations. To order, send a check or money order for the purchase price, plus the amount of any local sales tax, to Lenz Riecker Publishers, 1 Columbia Place, Albany, N.Y. 12207. You will also need to identify the document, in this case Title No. 9, Volume A-1. 
You also can read the code at any of the rent offices of the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal.
 
Who Fixes a Leak?
Question: I am a rent-stabilized tenant in a building that has been converted in to a co-op. For several weeks there has been a bad leak in the ceiling of my bathroom which is now causing the plaster to crumble and fall. There must be some sort of problem with the plumbing in the apartment above me. Whom do I contact to have the leak fixed and the damage in my bathroom repaired, the landlord or the occupant of the apartment upstairs? . . . M. M., Brooklyn
Answer: Whoever holds the shares assigned to your apartment - either the sponsor of the conversion plan or an investor shareholder - is your landlord and has ultimate responsibility for maintaining your apartment.
The corporation, on the other hand, is responsible for maintaining the structure and its board will probably decide if it or your upstairs neighbor should pay for repairs made necessary by the leak.
But from a practical standpoint, you can notify the building's superintendent or some other representative of the company hired to manage and maintain the building. If the problem is not solved by the management company within a reasonable amount of time, you can contact the shareholder of your apartment. If this does not produce the desired results, file a complaint with the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal. Even though the building is no longer a rental residence, the agency still has jurisdiction over the remaining rent-regulated apartments.
 
Built-In Furnishings
Question: Two years ago I rented an apartment in Manhattan with elaborate built-in furnishings, including a conversation pit, a platform bed, cabinets, sliding partitions and a rooftop deck. To obtain the rent-stabilized lease, I purchased the installed furniture from the previous tenant. My ownership of the installations was noted in a side letter of agreement, signed by the landlord, which says it is my option to either leave the furnishings or restore the apartment to its previous condition.
After numerous problems with the apartment and the building owner, I have decided to cut my losses and vacate at the end of my lease. Recently the owner has made noises about how expensive it will be to remove the furnishings. I reminded him about the letter. What is my legal position on this matter? . . . C. C., Manhattan
Answer: The strength of the letter depends on how it was drafted, according to Magda Cruz, an attorney with the firm of Belkin Burden Wenig & Goldman.
''Such a letter would not have to be part of the lease to be enforceable,'' she said. ''But what is important is that it says exactly what is to be done and under what circumstances, and that both parties have indicated that they agree to the terms of the agreement by signing it.''

CORRECTION-DATE: December 10, 1989, Sunday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
Because of incorrect information supplied by Lenz Riecker Publishers, the Q & A column on Nov. 5 misstated the number to use when ordering a copy of the New York State Rent Stabilization Code.
The correct number is Title 9, Executive Volume D.

HEADLINE: Do Housing Covenants Intrude on Rights?

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
FOR a quick glimpse at the housing frontier, consider the garage doors in a development planned by Bernard Bossom in Easton, Conn., and the plants on the deck of Stephen E. Barton's home near Berkeley, Calif.
Both are covered by covenants and deed restrictions - legal controls over the design and use of homes that are becoming commonplace in American subdivisions. Proponents say the controls, which have been applied to everything from the color of Venetian blinds to doghouse architecture, are encouraging good taste, fostering community spirit and raising property values.
But critics insist that the covenants and deed restrictions are an insidious force, sometimes threatening an Orwellian intrusion into the lives and property rights of homeowners across the nation.
Mr. Bossom, who is marketing a subdivision of 37 lots for large new homes, most of them costing over $800,000, is a believer. Those purchasing in his development, Easton Woods, must agree to dozens of covenants, including rules that prohibit cutting down trees, dictate a minimum floor area of 4,000 square feet in every house, and require garages big enough for three cars. 
The developer said his garage doors posed a tough question. One covenant requires that they be hidden from view from the road, and he said he considered requiring electronic openers as an inducement to keeping the doors shut.
''I have an obligation to safeguard the design and character of the community,'' said Mr. Bossom, who, in the end, decided garage door openers represented ''an area of too much detail'' and would not be dictated by his legal covenants, which fill five pages.
In California, Mr. Barton, a city planner, is trying to understand one of the many deed restrictions covering his nine-year old town house on a hillside in Albany, just north of Berkeley.
No neophyte, he directed a 1988 research project into deed restrictions by the University of California at Berkeley and serves as president of the homeowners' association in his own subdivision. He is still perplexed. ''What in the world is an aggressive flowering plant?'' he said, referring to a type of vegetation that is barred from his deck. One likely explanation is that the covenant is intended to protect the subdivision from being overgrown by flowers, but Mr. Barton said he is not certain.
''Some deed restrictions are perfectly appropriate,'' he said. ''But some are not communicated well, and some are outright excessive.''
DESPITE such problems, the use of restrictions is growing rapidly across the nation. An analysis this year found that 17 percent of the American population was living in homes whose design or use was governed by conditions in their deeds or covenants. Twenty years ago, only 1 percent of the population was affected by such restrictions, according to James L. Winokur, a professor of law at the University of Denver, who conducted the study of deeds and covenants.
The controls, almost universal in large condominium projects, are less common - but growing more rapidly - among detached, single-family-home subdivisions and town-house communities.
In most cases, the legal restrictions are written by developers before any of their lots or homes are sold. Homeowners' associations and architectural review boards often implement the rules and mediate disputes. But their intercession is not essential. Indeed, since deed restrictions and covenants are legally binding, it can be left to neighbors to force compliance through the courts.
In the suburbs around New York City, Boston and other Northeastern cities, the restrictions are being used most commonly by developers of expensive subdivisions, who find lengthy lists of covenants a valuable marketing tool. The controls create an image of exclusivity and provide assurances to buyers that others will not build obtrusive homes.
''The idea is to protect people from their neighbors' bad taste,'' said Douglas Kleine, director of research for the Community Associations Institute, an organization based in Alexandria, Va., representing the boards of condominiums and homeowner associations. ''We find that insuring harmony of design tends to preserve and enhance property values.''
Developers in the Sun Belt states, particularly California, have been the most aggressive in the use of the legal controls in new subdivisions. Mr. Barton's 1988 study found that 40 percent of all new homes being built in California were covered by some form of deed restriction or covenant, and the proportion in fast-growing Orange County in Southern California had reached 80 percent.
The variety of restrictions is huge. Satellite dishes, aluminum siding, basketball hoops, exposed clothes lines, fences, pets, flagpoles and outdoor parking spaces for trucks, recreational vehicles or boat trailers are among the most common targets for exclusion. Pink flamingo garden ornaments are banned specifically in some cases.
The covenants often set forth general guidelines on architecture - saying, for example, that homes must be of ''traditional'' or ''colonial'' style - and detailed plans are subject to approval by architectural review boards. But many of the rules are specific, dictating how large homes must be, what building materials must be used and what color they must be painted.
''THERE are vastly more covenants being used, and one result is that more problems are arising,'' said Wayne Hyatt, an Atlanta lawyer who has a full-time practice representing developers and homeowners' associations in their legal disputes with those who violate their covenants.
Some recent cases described by Mr. Hyatt reflect the potential for conflict:
* A homeowners' association in Atlanta unsuccessfully tried to stop a woman from giving piano lessons in her living room, citing a covenant that prohibited using her home for business purposes.
* A homeowners association in Anchorage, Alaska, forced a couple to remove three television antennas from their roof. The couple said they liked watching several televisions at the same time.
* A group of wealthy homeonwers in Oklahoma City, having purchased in a tightly controlled subdivision of homes priced over $1 million, sought unsuccessfully to have their neighbor's satellite dish removed from his front yard.
One problem facing some homeowners is that state laws covering disclosure of the covenants and deed restrictions vary widely, and some families have bought property without realizing the constraints under which they must live.
''If the purchaser is not well represented, he might not be told of the restrictions,'' said Gurdon Buck, a Hartford lawyer who writes covenants and deed restrictions for developers. Connecticut law requires formal disclosure only where the homeowners associations that implement the restrictions assess a fee. Such fees are common, but not universal.
In New York, New Jersey and many other states, no formal disclosure is required, meaning that buyers or their lawyers must closely scrutinize deeds of the property they plan to buy to find the restrictions.
Another problem with the restrictions is that they are difficult, if not impossible, to change once they are established by a developer. Typically, any change requires a unanimous or majority vote by the affected homeowners, Mr. Buck said.
LITIGATION over the deed restrictions and covenants has become a growth industry. The 1988 study by Professor Winokur on deed restrictions and covenants in American homes found that the number of state court decisions involving the restrictions doubled between 1982 and 1987 and Mr. Barton, in his research in California, found that 5 percent of the state's homeowners' associations had been sued during the prior year over the deed restrictions and covenants.
''There are a lot of homeowners' associations out there enforcing rules that they don't fully agree with,'' said Mr. Winokur.
A result, he added, is that the same deed restrictions designed to foster community spirit are creating tension between neighbors.
''If you are trying to create a sense of community you ought to be looking at structures that encourage neighbors to talk to each other, not just their lawyers,'' he said.
Covenants and deed restrictions, although much more widespread over the last decade, are not new in American housing. Until they were largely outlawed by Federal civil rights legislation in 1948 and entirely stricken by the Civil Rights Act of 1964, such restrictions were used as a tool by segregationists, prohibiting the resale of homes to blacks, Jews or members of other minorities.
Although such covenants still exist in some deeds that have been held for decades by an individual or members of the same family, lawyers say they should be ignored. Indeed, sellers who adhere to discriminatory conditions in their deeds would be violating the law themselves and could be sued or even face criminal prosecution.
Another form of discriminatory covenant - barring children from subdivisions and condominium complexes - was largely outlawed this year by amendments to the Federal Fair Housing Act. The so-called ''active adult'' retirement communities and most other retirement communities, except those that abide by rigorous Federal guidelines on the age of the residents and the services they are provided, must now open their doors to families with children.
Covenants and deed restrictions on the design of homes, size of lots and use of common areas have been used by developers for over a century, although less frequently than over the last decade. Proponents say some have been particularly successful, providing examples for the current spate of legal restrictions.
One example is Reston, Va., a tightly restricted community of 19,000 homes west of Washington that began to be developed in the mid-60's. Those building in Reston must adhere to design guidelines that fill a 50-page book and cover myriad details, from architectural style to the color of exterior walls. A master deed for the community also includes many prohibitions - window air-conditioners, clothes lines and television antennas are among the dozens of things barred - and its homeowners association is empowered to force residents to keep their property in good condition, sometimes putting liens on homes and performing maintenance work itself.
Although the community is generally considered a social and real estate success, Reston's residents say some of the idealism that accompanied its creation has come under strain. Among recent changes in its bylaws have been greater protections against harassment and lawsuits against homeowners, including rules requiring written notice before a suit is filed or a lien placed.
''The original people in Reston came with a utopian spirit, but things have changed,'' said Thomas Burgess, executive vice president of the Reston Association, the community's homeowners association. ''People here now are not social pioneers. They are established couples, yuppies and two-income families. Things have just gotten more conservative.''
Developers say few in the current wave of covenants and deed restrictions have been inspired by a Utopian vision. Nor are the restrictions being used for huge developments like Reston, which are no longer being planned because of the scarcity of large tracts of undeveloped land in the suburbs of most cities.
Instead, they say the expanding use of legal restrictions on the design and use of homes has been prompted by rules being imposed on developments by local sanitary districts, planning boards and environmental review agencies.
SINCE developers planning new subdivisions must increasingly write convenants that require homowners to maintain roads, waste-water treatment plants, wildlife preserves and other common facilities, they are also turning to covenants to impose their own vision of community design and character.
''You can no longer build a subdivision for the Ozzie and Harriet model household,'' said Mr. Buck, the Hartford lawyer. He added that covenants are being written by developers to ''find niches'' and ''distinguish one development from another.''
One danger, some say, is that developers using the legal restrictions as a marketing tool may limit their options when economic cyles turn down and home sales weaken. Many builders in Southern California were left with unsold lots in subdivisions that required large, expensive homes when real estate sales in that state turned down early in the 1980's, they say.
A result in California was bitter disputes between homeowners who had invested in subdivisions because they liked the exclusivity created by their deed restrictions and covenants, and developers with unsold lots who suddenly wanted to liberalize the rules. Indeed, some analysts say similar problems may develop in the suburbs around New York City and Boston, where sales volume and prices have been on a two-year decline.
''If you build in a lack of flexibility, it almost guarantees problems,'' said Mr. Hyatt, the Atlanta lawyer specializing in deed restrictions and covenants. ''A lot of developers have lost money on the proposition that they could confine themselves to a market for very large homes.''

HEADLINE: Lincoln Park Journal;
Airport and Borough Disagree on Future

BYLINE: By ALBERT J. PARISI

DATELINE: LINCOLN PARK

 BODY:
WHEN the weather is fine, the small airfield in this Morris County borough is a private pilot's delight. But the airfield and its proposed improvement have become sources of disagreement among its owners, borough administrators and state environmental officials.
''What we want to do here serves the good of a vast number of people, but the obstacles that we've been asked to clear are unfair and unwarranted,'' said Dr. George Peck, a Clifton plastic surgeon, pilot and co-owner of the airfield, which is known as Lincoln Park Airport.
''If they left us alone, this could be a model airport and, most important, an especially safe airport,'' he said, ''but we can only do so much with our hands tied and the field restricted.''
The borough's Mayor, Michael Harrigan, says, however, that Lincoln Park has been striving in recent years to retain its rural identity by controlling development and that the airport, as an integral part of the community, must adhere to borough and state rules. 
For the last four years, Dr. Peck and Joseph A. Rendeiro, a Lincoln Park-based oil-storage farm owner and the other co-owner of the airport, have been trying to get permission to build a new runway and hangars some 500 feet west of an existing use-worn runway and taxiways that date to 1935, when the former celery farm was converted to a grass runway for a flying club.
The airport is an uncontrolled field, meaning that it has no air traffic control tower to guide flights. Pilots using the field follow visual flight rules.
After tests and studies were commissioned by the airport's owners and plans were submitted to the local Planning Board, borough officials chose to put the proposal on hold, deciding that the airfield was in a flood zone - 60 percent of this community near the base of Hook Mountain is so designated by the state - and that jurisdiction over such new construction fell to the State Department of Environmental Protection and the Army Corps of Engineers.
Applications were filed for a Federal Aviation Administration grant of $1.5 million to cover about 90 percent of the construction since the airfield is a state-recognized reliever airport to which excessive light-aircraft traffic from Teterboro Airport in Bergen County is diverted. But additional wetland tests required by the corps were time-consuming, Dr. Peck said, and the approved F.A.A. grant was lost because construction did not occur within a year's time.
Since reapplication would have again been costly and time-consuming, Dr. Peck said, he and Mr. Rendeiro decided to apply to the borough for permission to resurface the existing runway.
''Again the Planning Board said that they couldn't help us and that it was up to the D.E.P. to authorize permission,'' Dr. Peck said.
The Department of Environmental Protection approved the project under the condition that the runway's dimensions would not be altered. The borough, Dr. Peck and Mr. Rendeiro said, ruled that because the runway was in a flood-sensitive area, resurfacing would be permitted only if the landing strip was not raised above its present height.
''What they were telling us was to go right ahead and lay down a new surface, but you're going to have to dig up what you have down,'' Mr. Rendeiro said. ''So in terms of dollars and cents, what should have wound up costing us about $100,000 is going to run about $1.2 million. For that kind of money, we could just as easily have put in that new runway.''
Both men said the new field would have changed takeoffs and landings to over an undeveloped zone and would have further reduced the chance of aborted takeoffs and possible crashes, as well as noise complaints from neighborhoods.
Last month, the Planning Board approved the resurfacing project, said Harold C. Krulder, the board's chairman. While he said he could understand the airport owners' frustrations over building applications and environmental requirements, Mr. Krulder and other borough officials said that harassment of the owners was not the borough's intent.
''The fact of the matter is that the airport, like a good part of this town, is in a flooding zone,'' Mr. Krulder said. ''There are laws restricting use and what can be done on such land. On that, the D.E.P. is quite clear.''
Dr. Peck and Mr. Rendeiro feel that the borough and state agencies have created costly delays so that airport projects would eventually be scrapped.
''This is a privately owned airfield used by the public,'' Mr. Rendeiro said, ''and to go to all this trouble is ludicrous. If I wanted to go ahead and resurface my private driveway by my house, would I have to get this kind of written permission?'' Borough officials said that such a comparison did not apply here. Mayor Harrigan said that air traffic at the field appeared to have increased in recent years and that noise levels had generated complaints from residents.
Some longtime residents and borough officials say privately that the proposed runway and support buildings raised fears that the airfield would further increase its operations. The airport averages some 179,000 arrivals and departures annually, and there are 200 single- and twin-engine aircraft based there as well as a helicopter operation. It is feared that a renovated airfield would open it to small-jet traffic that would add to the noise and safety problem.
But Mr. Rendeiro and Dr. Peck are quick to point out that the proposed airstrip would have been 500 feet shorter than the existing 3,000-foot runway, making it suitable for only piston-driven aircraft and helicopters with the exception of emergency landings.
''What I think we all have to do is understand each other's position a bit more clearly,'' said Steven Schweer, the Borough Council president. ''People feel that a new runway means more traffic and larger types of aircraft, but that's not necessarily the case. As a whole, this community has to understand the airport's needs and it has to understand ours.''
He said that some excessive noise might have been caused by pilots unfamiliar with the airfield and its restrictions, but that that problem was up to the airport owners to police.
Councilman Herman S. Nadel said the airfield was not the only project that had run afoul of environmental decrees over flood-sensitive areas.
''A while back, we wanted to build a local park in that general area and the D.E.P. put a stop to it because of the flooding issue,'' he said. ''If our hands are being tied, they are being tied for both of us.''
The airfield's resurfacing will be done in the spring and the airport will be closed for two weeks, Dr. Peck said.
''We have a great potential here to serve many facets of this community and the aviation community,'' he said, adding that if privately owned airfields throughout the state were tied up by bureaucratic red tape, many would close and air traffic congestion would increase over Newark International and Teterboro Airports.
New Jersey is losing an average of one privately owned airfield a year because of economic reasons, said Paul H. Baker, acting director of the State Department of Transportation's Office of Aviation. Currently there are 14 publicly owned fields in operation like Newark and Teterboro and 41 private general aviation sites like Lincoln Park Airport.
''Airlines are having trouble hiring pilots because there are fewer and fewer small fields in which to train,'' said Erica Graham of West Nyack, N.Y., a flight instructor at Lincoln Park Airport. ''If we don't take measures to keep fields like this one thriving, we're talking about serious problems in the future that will affect everyone, not just the state.''

HEADLINE: HOME CLINIC;
Precautions With Wood Stoves

BYLINE: By JOHN WARDE

 BODY:
IF you are planning to get a wood-burning stove, there are several things to consider before making a choice. First check with your building inspector or fire marshal to find out whether installing a wood stove is permitted where you live and what restrictions and requirements apply.
Decide early where to install the stove. This is important, for many decisions concerning what kind of stove to select derive from it. Factors involved in selecting a site are how much of a focal point in the home you would like the stove to be, whether or not the stove must supply heat to rooms other than the one in which it is installed and how the stove will be vented to the outside. 
Putting a wood stove in a large, frequently used room like a living room, family room or large kitchen is usually best, because there the stove's decorative and heating qualities, as well as its function as a gathering place, can all be enjoyed. But if the stove is intended primarily as a heat source, installing it in a more central although less convivial spot, such as a stairwell or a large foyer, may be appropriate.
Most stove supply stores carry ventilators and small fans that can be installed to direct the flow of heat throughout much of a house. These usually work well, provided the stove is strategically placed.
If a fireplace already exists, you may decide to obtain a stove that fits inside or in front of it. This can be a good idea if your intention is to economize on space or to take advantage of the readymade focal point that the existing fireplace provides.
Placing the stove in an existing fireplace also satisfies the need for a hearth, necessary to protect both the floor beneath the stove and the nearby walls from heat. But think twice before planning to install a wood stove in a fireplace solely to take advantage of the existing chimney. This may be neither practical nor economical, and code restrictions may prohibit it.
Modern wood stoves burn more slowly and at a lower temperature than most fireplace fires. Greater quantities of volatile gases are produced, and as these rise up the chimney, contact with the chimney walls causes some of them to condense and coat the walls with creosote, a flammable tar that is the chief cause of chimney fires.
To improve outdoor air quality, stove manufacturers have reduced the amount of volatile gases emitted by stoves, and this diminishes the buildup of creosote. Nevertheless, reducing creosote also depends on the swift exit of smoke up the chimney, and many chimneys designed for fireplaces are too large to enable the weak updraft produced by a modern wood stove to accomplish this.
The National Fire Prevention Association, a nonprofit organization whose recommendations are incorporated into many local building and safety codes, considers an efficient chimney to be one whose flue opening is no more than than two and a half times the area of the stove's opening. A chimney with a flue area more than three times that of the stove's does not meet association safety recommendations and may not be allowed by some local codes.
For example, the opening of one popular standard-sized flue measures 6 1/2 inches wide and 10 1/2 inches long. This yields an area of 68 1/4 square inches.
Most new stoves have 6-inch diameter outlets whose area equals about 28 1/4 square inches. Comparing these, the size of the chimney flue opening is between two and two and a half times that of the stove outlet. That is an acceptable ratio.
Even if the chimney is the right size, its condition may not meet the requirements of codes incorporating the latest standard of Underwriters Laboratories that it withstand temperatures of up to 2,100 degrees.
Unless you are certain of your chimney's dimensions and condition, have it examined by a professional fireplace mason or qualified chimney sweep. In cases where the chimney is not adequate to use with a wood stove, the usual remedy is either to install a masonry flue liner (there are several types) or to construct a wood stove chimney consisting of double-wall insulated steel pipe inside the present flue.
The cost of materials for both of these alternatives is often about the same. It is usually also similar to the cost of erecting a wood stove chimney separate from the existing chimney.
Wood stoves that are not installed in an existing fireplace are called free-standing. As mentioned, they require a hearth to protect the floor beneath them, and there also must be sufficient clearance between the stove and nearby combustible surfaces to protect these.
Many stoves are equipped with shielding underneath to reflect radiant heat coming from the bottom of the stove. Hearths for this type usually can consist of any noncombustible material, like brick or stone. Both must be mortared or set on a base of sand. Hearths for stoves without heat shields must also incorporate a layer of heat-proof material, like firebrick or mineral board.
The size of the hearth and the amount of clearance required between a stove and nearby surfaces vary according to the size and design of the stove. When estimating space requirements, allow at least 18 inches in front of the stove and 12 on each of the other three sides for the hearth. Between the stove and combustible surfaces other than the floor, allow a maximum of 36 inches.
Heat shielding similar to that used for hearths is available to protect walls. When this is used, clearances can be diminished, sometimes to less than 12 inches.

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY OPINION;
Their Trash Can Be Our Treasure

BYLINE: By Linda Prospero; Linda Prospero lives in Princeton.

 BODY:
I RECOGNIZED the symptoms shortly after we were married: a chronic need to drive slowly through neighborhoods on trash day and an uncanny ability to find treasure in someone else's discards.
Perhaps it was being the child of immigrants that gave my husband his irrepressible urge to seek out other people's unwanted goods. His parents did instill in him a sense of economy long before recycling became de rigueur. Or maybe his training as an engineer gave him the knowledge to figure out how things work, so naturally when a broken toaster came his way, his inclination was to fix it, rather than throw it out. 
His sense of frugality extends to all matters - not even the garbage can is exempt from his review. While some wives might conceal a bill from a hard day's trek to the shopping mall, it is more organic evidence I try, sometimes in vain, to dispose of.
''What, you threw away these perfectly good bread crusts?'' he queries. ''But they're moldy, dear,'' I coyly respond. ''No matter,'' he says, ''the birds will appreciate them.'' The local aviary population must have adored his recent offering of stale pizzelle.
I cannot always be as gracious, however, when his acquisitions begin competing for space in the garage with my car. I was understanding when he brought home the first lawn mower. I even helped him load it from the trash heap to our car (although he was the one who had to verify with the owner that it was indeed placed out for trash).
He immediately started tinkering with his new-found challenge when we got home. In only 15 minutes, the engine was purring. I praised him for his remarkable talent in unearthing and repairing used treasure.
Little did I know I was helping creating a monster. We added the lawn mower to the two we already owned (one was a riding mower, acquired used, of course), but his thirst for new quests was hardly satiated. The hunt was on, now with our 12-year-old son as willing and able conspirator, to track down and repair discarded lawn mowers within a five-mile radius.
Their discoveries were always serendipitous, usually found while en route to a football game, errands or other weekend activity. Over the weeks, it became a familiar sight to see the two males huddled together, trying to solve the mystery of their latest defunct find. The challenge never defeated them, and our garage slowly became home to seven lawn mowers.
Fortunately, new neighbors moved in (lawn-mowerless) and we alleviated their situation in a flash. We also changed the lawn-mower status of a Pennsylvania uncle who had previously used only a manual lawn mower.
And what a stroke of fate it was when I saw a newspaper ad: ''Used Lawn Mower Wanted.'' Did somebody out there know about us? To our amazement, we were actually paid for one of the remaining mowers. Could this be the start of a second career?
My husband doesn't limit his collecting to lawn mowers, however. Through the years he has astonished me with his finds. Coming home from church one Sunday, he spotted a mountainous trash pile with a sign above it stating, ''Help Yourself.'' A pasta machine in its original carton was too good to pass up. And the tripod and camera bag would be great for our nephew, a budding shutterbug. It was a real treasure trove, with plenty of other items left for the next passers-by.
Another time he was driving down an exclusive street in town and found a radio-tape deck in a garbage heap. Undaunted, he brought it back to life with only a few turns of some dials. Another victim of our throwaway society had found new life through my husband's hands.
Being the wife of such a skilled repairman and collector does have its down side. The toaster inherited from my husband's bachelor days is almost an antique, having been repaired many times over in its 25-year life. Perusing catalogues for a shiny new toaster-oven is just a futile exercise, since the old relic refuses to die. Its tenacity to sustain life despite numerous breakdowns has me wondering when I should have it bronzed.
I was really too smug when our 17-year-old dishwasher last gave out. My husband had nursed it through many illnesses, but the latest one seemed too difficult to diagnose. With its guts strewn all about the kitchen floor, he gave me the go-ahead to start shopping the appliance stores.
Before I ever got the chance, however, his ''one last try'' was successful. There went my visions of a pot-scrubbing cycle.
I have to confess that a little of my husband's penchant for reclaiming cast-offs has rubbed off on me. Recently I asked him to stop the car and back up to a trash pile we had just driven by. Leaning against a trash can was an old printer's tray, once used for holding metal type.
I envisioned it hanging on one of our walls holding small bits of memorabilia and bric-a-brac. We threw it into the car and dashed off. I was doubly satisfied to see a similar one, priced at $30, a few weeks later at a flea market.
At this point, the whole family has caught the fever, and although we don't always stop to pick up items we see strewn about the road, we are constantly amazed by the amount of booty that is out there waiting to be reclaimed by anyone with keen eyesight, and the nerve to stop and pick it up.
It also helps being married to Mr. Fix-It. When he opened up the engine to the mulcher he recently found, was he intimidated by the chewed-up wires and the rat's nest inside? Not at all. It took him a few days, but the shredded mulch now surrounding our marigolds is evidence of his persistence.
Now if only an automatic weeder could be found!

LENGTH: 1300 words

HEADLINE: SPECIAL REPORT: THE AVERAGE STUDENT;
Coming of Age

BYLINE: By Laura Mansnerus

 BODY:
What is the average student like as a grown-up? Generally average, social scientists say, but you never can tell.
The question seems pressing now, not only because the education-reform movement of the 1980's has focused on the broad middle range of academic performance, but also because economists do not expect this range to match the middle of the evolving labor market. Simply put by Arnold H. Packer, co-author of the 1987 study ''Workforce 2000,'' ''The average young person is not good enough for the average new job.''
Social scientists, meanwhile, have been trying for years to figure out how to predict the average student's performance in the job market. To do so, they undertake the bulky, expensive and imprecise task of assessing an adult's success, parsing his background and then determining what early variables predicted later performance most accurately. 
In the search for these factors, researchers find a baffling conflation of socioeconomic status and intellectual ability. No single variable is very telling by itself, but if any one variable is more reliable than the others, according to a recent analysis of data from many studies of later-life success, it is scores on standardized intelligence tests.
Prof. John E. Hunter of Michigan State University, a psychologist who reported such research in several journals, said that ''general cognitive ability,'' as measured by standardized tests, is most useful as a predictor of ability in complex jobs, but that even at the center of the scale, a 15-point difference in score corresponds to at least a 15 percent difference in ratings on job performance.
But is a score on an I.Q. test meaningful in every job? ''The answer is yes, in every case,'' Professor Hunter said. The good news, he added, is that education increases intelligence-test scores, albeit modestly.
''Most people think of education in terms of specific things you learn,'' he said, ''and those would have no obvious application to, say, a firefighter. But the firefighter's ability to learn is influenced by education.''
What this means for the future - and the opinion is nearly unanimous - is that more education for more people in the middle might alleviate a dismal situation.
In ''Workforce 2000,'' Mr. Packer and William B. Johnston, both senior research fellows at the Hudson Institute, a research organization based in Indianapolis, projected job openings from 1984 to the year 2000 in 27 occupational categories. The biggest increase in demand, they found, will be for lawyers and judges (a 71 percent increase over existing jobs), scientists (68 percent) and health diagnosing and treating occupations (53 percent). Losses will occur in several unskilled occupations - miners (16 percent), agricultural and forestry workers (12 percent), and assemblers (7 percent).
 
Skill Ratings Have to Improve
Between the extremes were categories like mechanics (increasing by 23 percent), administrative support workers (20 percent) and sales and marketing (39 percent).
Another way Mr. Packer and Mr. Johnston analyzed the data was by rating the skills required in various jobs on a scale of 1 to 6. ''The biggest problems are in 2 and 3,'' Mr. Packer said. ''The people who are 2's and 3's'' - farmers and construction workers, for example - ''are going to have to become 3's and 4's'' - technicians and managers, for example.
''To the extent that any particular job gets more complicated,'' he added, ''it's even worse.''
For now, the profile of the average young worker is not that of the future technician and manager. A recent study of 21- to 25-year-olds conducted by the National Assessment of Educational Progress, found that fewer than 20 percent could decipher a difficult bus schedule and fewer than 40 percent could calculate the change due from a two-item restaurant meal.
While sociologists and economists sort out measures like that, educators are more likely to mention unmeasurable qualities - and to question common definitions of intelligence, itself a measure of many things, and success. ''I think attitude has more to do with it in our school than innate intelligence,'' said Dennis Littky, principal of Thayer High School in Winchester, N.H. ''I have some kids who are real pluggers and are real kind and work real hard, and I'll put my money on those kids. I'm usually right.''
Mr. Littky, who has won several national awards for his programs at Thayer, said about 55 percent of the students there went on to college. And who goes to college, he said, is ''mostly based on class stuff - social class.''
''I have a population of kids who will never be brains in the usual sense,'' he added, ''but will be very successful car mechanics and will be kind to their families and will be a success.''
 
Some Find No Performance-Ability Tie
Of course, some studies have found that in many jobs there is no relationship at all between performance and any measure of cognitive ability - grades, achievement tests, aptitude tests or educational level. Moreover, researchers caution that projections and correlations and statistical middle ranges are just that.
Robert Klitgaard, a visiting scholar at the Rand Corporation and author of the 1985 book ''Choosing Elites,'' said: ''When it comes to later-life success, in our society we do a lousy job of explaining that variation. You may think test scores and grades are crummy, but look at the rest of the things we have to go by.''
Moreover, he said, sometimes measures of ability matter a great deal in matching workers to jobs, and sometimes they don't. They matter, he said, if an employer has a widely divergent applicant pool or is selecting a few people from many applicants, or if fine distinctions are central to the job - say, a linebacker's position - that must be filled.
Finally, Mr. Klitgaard noted, achievement persists in being random. He cites the example developed by the sociologist Christopher Jencks: For two men between 25 and 64, randomly chosen, there will be a certain discrepancy in earnings. But even if the two men are brothers, with the same education, intelligence test scores and work experience, the discrepancy will still be 80 to 90 percent as big as the difference between the randomly chosen men.
Still, one's status as a student is hardly unimportant. Researchers agree that the average performer is better able to improve than is someone at the low end of the scale, and that the bottom is a worse and worse place to be.
''It's much less likely that a kid at the bottom of the scale is going to become a world leader than it is that a super-gifted kid will go down the drain,'' said Prof. James Connell of the University of Rochester, a motivation expert.
Practically all studies find that, whatever happens in the middle, the highest achievers in school do better than anyone else in later life. In a 1975 article measuring the professional progress of 976 white male college graduates working for the Ford Motor Company, for example, Prof. David A. Wise of Harvard found that it varied noticeably according to the selectivity of the colleges they went to and the grade-point averages they earned.
One large-scale study, surveying men who graduated from Wisconsin high schools in 1957, found that 14 years later, men who had I.Q. scores over 120 as 11th graders earned almost 40 percent more than those with scores of 80 or below. One of the researchers, Prof. Robert M. Hauser of the University of Wisconsin, said that reflected the fact that the first group, logically, had more education, and that the difference increases with work experience.
On the other hand, neither factor was important to another question on the survey, to which nine in ten replied that they were not dissatisfied at all with their jobs.
