LENGTH: 2775 words

HEADLINE: Profile: Albert Shanker - Where He Stands

BYLINE: By Edward B. Fiske

 BODY:
ALBERT SHANKER is a man of a thousand surprises.
He came to national attention in the 1960's as the tough, aggressive leader of the New York City teachers' union, the man who twice went to jail for leading illegal strikes. ''I thought he was a reprehensible character,'' said Fletcher L. Byrom, the retired chairman of the Koppers Company Inc., the chemical manufacturer.
The image seemed indelible. In the 1973 Woody Allen movie ''Sleeper,'' the main character awakens in 2173 to find that the United States has been destroyed because ''a man named Albert Shanker got hold of a nuclear warhead.'' 
Yet today, that same Albert Shanker, at age 61, works closely with Mr. Byrom and other corporate leaders through the Committee for Economic Development and other groups seeking to improve American schools. ''Al Shanker understands the problems facing public schools better than any other person in the country,'' Mr. Byrom now says.
William Woodside, chairman of the board of Sky Chefs Inc., confesses that he, too, was startled to discover a thoughtful and open-minded union leader. ''But it's not a disguise,'' he commented. ''There's no Big Bad Wolf under Grandma's shawl.'' There is no granny there, either. The transformation of Albert Shanker from public pariah to educational statesman is rooted in his conviction that American schools are in trouble and that rescuing them will require radical changes in how both schools and teachers unions do business. Failure at this, he says, will lead to ''erosion of public confidence in public education'' and, just maybe, the privatization of public schools.
In the pursuit of such enlightened self-interest, Mr. Shanker has produced one shocker after another:
* In a 1985 speech to the National Press Club, he introduced the idea of a national test for teachers, which unions have long resisted, setting in motion the creation of the country's first national teacher-certification system, beginning in 1992.
* Looking at the declining number of families with children in the public schools, he decided that parents could no longer be relied on to assure adequate public spending for public schools. Now he consciously seeks alliances with the business community because ''it has a stake in quality education.''
* He believes that collective bargaining as usually perceived has outlived its usefulness by undermining public confidence in schools. Teachers, he says, should not only push for better wages and working conditions but also accept responsibility for educational outcomes. Unions should refuse to admit members who do not meet minimal professional standards.
* He has supported merit-pay plans in Tennessee and elsewhere, not because he likes the pay-for-performance theory, but because ''it seemed to be the only form in which the money would be forthcoming.''
* He is currently plugging a ''merit schools'' program that would provide cash awards to the entire staff of schools that meet specified performance criteria. ''I used to shy away from bribery,'' he said, ''but I've come to the conclusion that it has a place.''
Mr. Shanker's American Federation of Teachers, with only 700,000 members, is small compared with its rival, the two-million-strong National Education Association. Yet over the years David has consistently outwitted Goliath. In the 1960's, A.F.T. locals forced N.E.A., which saw itself as a ''professional'' organization, into becoming a true trade union whose affiliates negotiate contracts and call strikes. Then, Mr. Shanker proceeded to stake out the high road and become the public symbol of teacher professionalism.
It is 2 P.M. in the Toronto airport on a recent Thursday, and Albert Shanker is negotiating a folding luggage rack, what he calls his ''heavy industrial-type schlepper,'' down a flight of stairs. On it are strapped two suitcases, the heaviest stuffed with letters, articles, periodicals and other materials to feed his reading habit.
Mr. Shanker does not move gracefully. His myopic eyes peer at the world through large glasses. He has a lanky body with limbs so long that signals from the brain don't always seem to arrive at his hands and feet at the right time. But he's used to it. ''At the age of 12 I was 6 foot 3 and 110 pounds,'' he said. ''I was Jewish and living in a Irish Catholic neighborhood of Queens, so everybody took turns beating up the biggest kid.'' Even under attack, mind and body seemed to move in disparate directions. ''I'd ask myself why are they beating me up, calling me a Christ-killer,'' he said. ''I'd try to put myself in their place.'' He failed to become an Eagle Scout because he could not pass the swimming test.
Mr. Shanker's mission in Toronto is to speak to Ontario teachers union leaders. It will be one of 300 or so public appearances that he makes every year, not only as a union executive but as vice president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and through his service to organizations like Freedom House and the International Rescue Committee. His union salary is approximately $140,000.
He resides in Mamaroneck, N.Y., with Eadie, his wife for 29 years. (His four children, one by a previous marriage that ended in divorce, are grown.) But he lives out of his schlepper, touching down twice a week at his Washington office. He has 700,000 frequent-flyer miles accrued on his Eastern and Continental card, but won't cash them in on free flights; the airlines are run by Frank Lorenzo, who has gained an anti-union reputation.
Mr. Shanker attributes his ability to maintain a killer pace to snap catnapping. ''If I have an hour-and-a-half before a meeting, I can get an hour of deep sleep,'' he said. And he does not let administrative duties bog him down. His union has a staff of 200, all but 40 of them in Washington, and an annual budget exceeding $50 million.
But Mr. Shanker insists: ''I don't have to know everything that is going on, and I don't. The key is to pick outstanding people who are committed to the cause and who like each other.''
Mr. Shanker's day in Toronto started in East Lansing, Mich., where he was guest at a breakfast meeting of school officials prior to a speech to a citizens group concerned with taxes. Sitting at the breakfast table, his body concave, his elbows on the table, hands clasped, he was physically, as well as intellectually, focused on his idea of the moment.
This fascination with ideas goes back to his childhood in the Depression. Morris Shanker, his father, delivered newspapers, and he read six or eight of them every day. ''I've been a periodical junkie for as long as I can remember,'' he said. ''As a kid I'd walk over the Queensboro Bridge to the newsstands outside the library on 42d Street. I discovered The Partisan Review when I was 15. My subscription to Commentary goes back to 1948.''
In 1970, he would begin his own weekly column, not in periodicals but in The New York Times, where it still runs as an advertisement. ''It was a way of dispelling my image as a power-hungry madman and letting people know that we had ideas about education,'' he said.
Mr. Shanker, who has one sister, graduated from Stuyvesant High School, ranking 125 out of a class or 625. He applied to Harvard and was rejected. ''It was,'' he said, ''a great disappointment.'' The University of Illinois at Urbana-Champagne, where he had an aunt, became the school of choice. Then on to Columbia University to earn a doctorate in philosophy. In 1952, running out of ''patience and money,'' he took a year out to teach - supposedly on a temporary basis.
He liked teaching advanced classes but found the others taxing. ''I absolutely hated bing a policeman and a psychiatrist and a jailer with kids,'' he explained. He often marvels at how some teachers can spend lifetimes locked inside rooms with 6-year-olds, devoid of adult contact. What kept him in the profession was the opportunity to build the New York teachers union, which elected him president in 1964.
Both of Mr. Shanker's parents were emigrants from Czarist Russia; politics was part of the air they breathed. Mamie, his mother, a sewing-machine operator, was an ardent member of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers but remained haunted by her past.
''She never got over the injustices of the old system,'' he recalled. ''Whenever politics came up around the dinner table, she would go open the door and look out to be sure no one was listening.''
As a boy, Mr. Shanker would go to Columbus Circle to hear people debating. ''If I saw someone wearing a Willkie or an America First button, I'd go up and debate them,'' he said.
His heroes were people who fought injustice - Clarence Darrow, the lawyer, and eventually figures like Bayard Rustin, the civil rights leader, and Sidney Hook, the philosopher. ''I started reading Hook when I was 15,'' Mr. Shanker said. ''He got involved, sometimes at considerable personal cost, in virtually every major human-rights issue of his time. I very much admired the life that he lived.''
He also admires the finer things in life, especially when they can be obtained at bargain prices. He collects wine and has a recently built cellar with 800 bottles; his eyes light up when he talks his purchases. ''In the 1970's I got a dozen cases of Barolo Riserva for $2.65 a bottle,'' he said. ''Now they're worth $25.''
Mr. Shanker is a sophisticated cook, specializing in Moroccan food, pastries and exotic breads; his cookbook collection numbers in the hundreds. He also collects African art. And he is a hi-fi aficianado, having started building sets from kits as a boy.
Today, he is constantly selling his stereo equipment so that he can buy the latest items on the market. ''Just about everyone in my office has at least some piece that I sold them or heard someone else was selling,'' he said.
Mr. Shanker checks into the car-rental counter and unloads his schlepper into the trunk of a Cadillac with a cellular phone and legroom. He has four hours to kill before his speech, so he does what he normally does in such situations - heads for a second-hand record store. ''I have found bookstores and record stores in cities all over the country,'' he said.
After an hour or so, he emerges with three records, including one of Lorin Maazel conducting the Cleveland Orchestra in Prokofiev's Fifth Symphony. ''Maazel is a good conductor, especially on Prokofiev,'' he said. ''His earlier one on 'Romeo and Juliet' is one of the great performances of all time.''
Mr. Shanker normally shies away from dinner speeches. ''People are tired,'' he said. ''It's not the time to get a message across, and I'm not pulling the schlepper around to entertain.'' This is an exception, though, and it turns out be vintage Shanker. He speaks from cryptic notes scribbled on a folded piece of paper, hands held next to his body, swaying back and forth with his collar rolling up on the back of his neck.
He can be funny. One of his favorite devices is to take an idea he opposes and stretch it to its logical conclusion. When Boston University was negotiating to take over the running of the school system in nearby Chelsea, for example, he suggested that Yale University be brought in to balance the Federal deficit.
That evening he started off his talk with anecdotes on the low quality of American schooling, including one of his favorite statistics: according to literacy studies by the National Assessment of Educational Progress, less than 5 percent of American high school graduates would meet the entrance standards of European universities. ''We're sending 55 percent of our high school graduates on to college, and 90 percent of these couldn't get into college elsewhere.''
He discusses the impending teacher shortage and points out that, in contrast to Canada and other developed countries, teachers tend to rank at the bottom of their college classes academically, not at the top. With a major teacher shortage looming in the 1990's, he says, ''We're going to be digging even deeper and the teachers we hire are going to be dumber.''
To Mr. Shanker the solution lies in a new concept of teacher professionalism, one that would attract a greater number of able people into the field and justify the higher salaries that this would require. ''In the past when teachers used the word professionalism they meant paying them more and leaving them alone,'' he said. ''Now we're talking about assembling a knowledge base, functioning in the interests of students and being accountable for student performance.''
Parents should have a choice on which public schools their children attend, he said, and schools should be managed by teams in which teachers play a role.
Not everyone likes Mr. Shanker's bottom-up approach to school reform. He has had a running battle with John R. Silber, the president of Boston University, over the Chelsea takeover. Mr. Shanker has accused the university of needlessly suspending rules regarding financial reporting and open meetings. But Peter R. Greer, the dean of Boston University's school of education, charges that Mr. Shanker opposes any reform that does not give teachers more power.. ''We're doing top-down reform, so he doesn't like it,'' Mr. Greer said.
In an exchange in the current issue of Commentary, Chester E. Finn Jr., an assistant secretary of education during President Ronald Reagan's second term, calls Mr. Shanker ''one of the authentically insightful and imaginative figures in American education'' but argues that his faith in school reform ''has about it an air of the naive and the romantic.''
He also states that while Mr. Shanker and some of his leading locals are prominently involved in the struggle for school reform, ''other AFT locals are simultaneously going on strike, battling reforms and defending the status quo as if everything were hunky-dory.''
At 5:30 the morning after his appearance in Toronto, Al Shanker is dragging his schlepper through the Holiday Inn lobby. It is a short drive to the airport and customs, where he realizes that he has left his records in the car. That's all right, though; even in Canada, Albert Shanker is KNOWN. ''I trust you based on your reputation,'' the custom official says, waving Mr. Shanker back to his car and volunteering to look after the luggage.
Sometimes, Mr. Shanker tells a companion, customs agents will even motion him to the front of the line. ''A lot of them are moonlighting teachers,'' he said. ''They never go through my bags, but they are apt to ask for a 15-minute update on pending negotiations.''
It is tempting to think that there are several Al Shankers. Shanker the old-line socialist. Shanker the union leader, Shanker the educator. To him, though, they are all of a piece.
''In the 30's unions kept people from being exploited,'' he said. ''Economic conditions are much better now, largely because of the success of the labor movement. But now you have the new problems of the underclass. What we tried to do in the past by economic means can now be done by education. It's really the same thing.''
''I want to create more effective and more humane schools, and to do that you need a new kind of union and new approaches to bargaining. You don't sell a union abstractly. You sell it by building an organization that people want.
In other words, you schlep.
 
ALBERT SHANKER AT A GLANCE
 
BORN: Sept. 14, 1928, N.Y., N.Y.
 
PARENTS: Morris and Mamie; one sister
 
FAMILY: married Edith Gerber 1960; four children, one from a previous marriage
 
EDUCATION: Stuyvesant High School, N.Y.C., B.A., University of Illinois, Urbana-Champagne; philosphy postgraduate, Columbia University (left A.B.D., all but dissesrtation)
 
TEACHING?UNION CAREER: temporary teacher in New York City elementary schools, junior high schools 1952-59; becomes full-time union organizer, 1959; president of the United Federation of Teachers, 1964-85; led a series of illegal teacher strikes, 1967; newspaper column starts as a paid avertisement, 1969-70; president of the American Federation of Teachers, 1974- ; executive vice president of New York State United Teachers, 1972-78; vice president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., a member of the organization's executive committee and head of its international affairs committee.
 
MEMBERSHIPS: Charter member, Congress of Racial Equality, 1960's; International Rescue Committee, 1973- ; education task forces, Committee on Economic Development, 1983- ; task force on teaching as a profession, Carnegie Forum on Education and the Economy, 1985- ; National Board of Professional Teaching Standards, 1986- ; President Bush's Educational Policy Advisory Committee.

HEADLINE: THE NOVEMBER REPORT;
Making College Ends Meet: Terms of Endearment
A Guide to Useful Tuition Tools

 BODY:
THERE'S a wealth of investments available for financing college, and the choice doesn't end with selecting an investment.
You can buy in your own name or in a custodial account for your child. There are tax advantages to custodial accounts: the first $500 earned is tax-free, and earnings between $500 and $1,000 are taxed at the child's marginal rate (15 percent). Any earnings above $1,000 are taxed at the parent's marginal rate until the child turns 14. But there are drawbacks, too: You can't take back the money - your child could decide to blow it on a Porsche instead of going to college. Also, the greater the child's assets, the less financial aid he or she is eligible for. The same amount invested in your name would have much less impact on aid eligibility. 
U.S. Savings Bonds Series EE: Backed by full faith and credit of the U.S. Government. Interest is exempt from state and local taxes; Federal income tax is deferred until the bonds are redeemed. For bonds issued after Jan. 1, 1990, interest escapes some or all Federal tax too, for qualified buyers over age 24: married couples filing jointly with income below $90,000 and single filers with income below $55,000 who use the proceeds to pay for their children's or their own tuition bills. Married couples filing separately don't qualify for the tax break. Denominations range from $50 to $10,000. Cost is half the face value; maturity is 12 years from purchase date, but the bond may reach its face value earlier, depending on the yield variability. The yield, which has been hovering around 8 percent, is adjusted every six months and guaranteed not to fall below 6 percent if bonds are held at least five years. Available at banks and credit unions. No sales or redemption charges.
Zero-coupon Treasury bonds: Instead of periodic interest, zeroes pay one fixed sum at maturity. For example, you could pay $269.60 for a bond that pays $1,000 in 2005 - an effective yield to maturity of 8.39 percent. You can match bond maturity to college years. Although not paid until maturity, interest is taxable every year. Bonds are federally taxable, but you pay no state or local tax. They fluctuate more in value than conventional bonds as interest rates change, so you could lose money if you must sell before maturity. Sold in $1,000 units by stockbrokers. The yield encompasses the sales commission.
Zero-Coupon Municipal Bonds: Also pay one fixed sum at maturity, and are sold in $5,000 units. Interest exempt from Federal tax, and for residents of the state issuing the bond, exempt from state and local taxes. But there's a limited supply of these bonds, and they're often callable - the issuer can redeem them before maturity, returning your investment plus a ''call premium,'' but ending the stream of interest you counted on.
''Baccalaureate'' bonds: These are zero-coupon municipal bonds sold by state agencies and designed for college savers. Begun by the state of Illinois, they have spread to Connecticut, Delaware, Hawaii, Iowa, Missouri, North Carolina, North Dakota, Oregon, Rhode Island, Virginia and Washington. Bonds are available nationwide, and aren't subject to early redemption. Baccalaureate bonds are sold in $1,000 units. In a recent Oregon issue, a six-year bond cost $695 and a 19-year bond cost $282.50 - effective yields to maturity of 6.40 percent and 6.85 percent respectively. (For a taxpayer in the 28 percent bracket, taxable equivalents would be 8.9 percent and 9.5 percent.) Sold by brokers, sales commission is reflected in yield.
College prepayment plans: Florida, Michigan and Wyoming let you prepay the cost of tuition at any state college or university, and five other states have passed legislation for similar plans. The difference between your original investment and its final value is likely to be federally taxable. If the studentwants to go out of state or doesn't go to college at all, you could lose a substantial part of your investment. Cost varies. Michigan, which has processed more than 55,000 applications in first two years of its program, last month charged $1,941 to prepay a newborn's freshman year of college; low-interest loans are available for financing.
CollegeSure Certificates of Deposit: CD's guarantee at maturity to cover college costs, but don't lock you into a college, and there's no penalty if you don't go. Principal and interest are F.D.I.C.-insured up to $100,000. CollegeSure CDs' interest rate floats 1.5 percentage points below an index based on yearly cost increases at 500 private colleges. For 1989-90, the CD's will pay between 7.11 percent and 7.61 percent. Interest is taxable yearly. Early-withdrawal penalties are steep: 10 percent of principal during the first three years, and 5 percent after that. Total current deposit necessary to cover average four-year cost at college in 2004 (15 years): $62,947. Minimum initial deposit $1,000, additional deposits in $250 increments. Sold by College Savings Bank, Princeton, N.J.
Life insurance: Some types of life insurance combine insurance with a tax-deferred account that can be invested in a variety of funds, depending on the policy. After you've paid seven annual premiums, you can borrow from accumulated cash value at nominal interest rates and without tax penalty. You don't have to repay the loan, but some policies reduce your death benefit by the amount of the loan if not repaid. Your policy's investment value is reduced by the cost of the life insurance itself and by sales commissions. Cash value grows slowly in the early years. Policies typically guarantee only that the investment-account earnings won't fall below 4 percent. Costs and effective returns vary dramatically from company tocompany. A $200,000 universal life policy from San Antonio-based USAA Financial Services, a highly rated insurer, would cost a 35-year-old male nonsmoker $3,000 a year. After 15 years, assuming an 8 percent annual interest, the policy's cash value would be $75,144. The loan would not reduce death benefit.
Stock mutual funds: Stocks have outperformed bonds historically. In 10 years ended Sept. 30, for example, stock funds grew 15.98 percent on a compound basis, versus 10.71 percent for bond funds, according to Lipper Analytical Services. Minimum initial investment usually is between $1,000 and $2,500. Sales commissions, or loads, range from nothing up to 8.5 percent of your initial investment.
Borrowing: The vehicle of choice today is the home-equity loan, one of the few loans on which interest is still fully deductible on amounts up to $100,000. Fees for loans can range from $500 to $800. The disadvantage: Your house is collateral for the loan. You can usually borrow up to 80 percent of your equity, either in a lump sum for a fixed rate and length of time, or as a line of credit for a variable rate, paying for what you use. Most lenders set a $5,000 minimum credit-line limit and $100,000 maximum limit.

PUB-DATE: November 5, 1989

SECTION: Section 4A; Page 54, Column 3; Education Life

LENGTH: 2278 words

HEADLINE: THE NOVEMBER REPORT;
Education In Congress
Roundup of Bills from a Full Agenda

 BODY:
While President Bush and the nation's governors have gone public with their concern about upgrading American schools, Congress has been quietly -- and in some instances not so quietly -- churning away at education-related legislation. Herewith, highlights of the lawmakers' calendar . . . 

	Community Collaborative for Childhood	 		Development Act of 1989 (S.123)	 	Sponsor: Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts.
Purpose: Would make preschool programs more widely available to prekindergarten children, in an expansion of existing Head Start programs. Aimed at poor children, it would give Federal matching funds to states that provide comprehensive preschool programs for 4-year-olds. Two-thirds of the funds and half of any new openings created in the program must be used for children whose families earn less than 115 percent of the poverty level, who receive benefits free of charge. Those whose parents earn more may participate on a sliding-fee scale.
The Community Services Block Grant uses the following Department of Health and Human Services statistics to show what the poverty lines are for families: for a family of one, the figure is $5,980; for a family of two, $8,020; for a family of three, $10,060; and for a family of four, $12,100.
Participating states could use Federal money to finance public school preschools, Head Start or other child development programs, but must maintain pupil-teacher ratio of 10 to 1 and operate full days, year round. Proposes allocating $4 billion over next five years.
Status: Reported out of Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee; full Senate likely to consider this year.

	Educational Excellence Act (H.R. 1675)	 	Sponsor: Representative William F. Goodling, Republican of Pennsylvania.
Purpose: The House's version of President Bush's proposed legislation in the Senate, S.695. Offers similar proposals at cost of $421.6 million for fiscal year 1990.
Status: House Education and Labor Committee has held one hearing; no more are scheduled for this year.

	Carl D. Perkins Vocational Education Act (H.R.7)	 	Sponsor: Augustus F. Hawkins, Democrat of California.
Purpose: To insure that vocational education keeps pace with technological change, proposes changes in job-skills training. Recommendations include:
* School districts should emphasize basic academic skills, such as reading, writing and arithmetic.
* Vocational education programs should be called ''applied technology education'' to signify that courses are keeping pace with new technology.
* Instead of earmarking money for different categories of students, such as the poor, women, minorities and the handicapped, states would use a formula that channels money to the poorest districts.
* During fiscal year 1990, money appropriated for vocational programs would rise to $1.4 billion, an increase of $500 million from fiscal 1989.
Status: House passed on May 9, 402 to 3. Under consideration by Senate Committee on Labor and Human Resources.

	Act for Better Child Care Services (S.5)	 	Sponsor: Senator Christopher Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut.
Purpose: Would provide grant program for $1.75 billion in fiscal year 1990 to states that expand affordable child care programs. Has tax credit package to help low-income parents defray costs of child care and health insurance for children.
States would allocate 70 percent of their grants to low-income parents to help them pay for child care. Eligible families include those with children up to age 13 and incomes not exceeding the median income in each state. Remaining money would go to the programs themselves to upgrade quality and increase availability of child care. Three years after the act becomes law, regulations and standards to be set by states.
Tax-credit portion of bill would expand existing earned income tax credit beginning in 1991 to increase money for families with children under age 4: a maximum of $500 for families with one child under age 4 and $750 for families with more than one child under 4.
Health insurance credit to be phased in over four years beginning in 1991. This credit, to help defray health insurance costs for children as old as 19, eventually would provide up to $500 a year. Eligible families include those where one or both parents work and whose combined incomes do not exceed $18,000 a year, with maximum benefit going to those with combined annual incomes less than $12,000.
Increases Head Start's authorization ceiling by $250 million for fiscal year 1990.
Status: Senate approved on June 23. A House-Senate conference committee must now iron out differences before sending it to President Bush.

	Student Loan Default Reduction Act of 1989 (S.1778)	 	Sponsor: Senator Tom Harkin, Democrat of Iowa.
Purpose: Designed to lower the number of student loan defaults.
Schools with default rates of over 25 percent would enter into a four-year default reduction plan. If after four years the school has not reduced its default rate sufficiently or the rate is over 50 percent, Education Secretary could limit, suspend or end the school's eligibility to participate in student aid programs.
The school would have the authority to refuse to certify a student's eligibility for a loan if it determines he doesn't demonstrate financial need.
A national student loan data system would be created to keep track of amounts loaned to students and of those who have defaulted. New loans would not be made to defaulters or to students who have exceeded borrowing limits.
Status: Action unlikely before next year.

	The Community Education Employment	 		Centers Act of 1989 (S.1477)	 	Sponsor: Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, Democrat of New Jersey.
Purpose: Would give students the opportunity to attend school over summer months. In addition to classes, they would broaden experience by going on field trips in a camp-like atmosphere. Centers, situated in the schools and designed for inner-city students, would provide two meals a day, transportation to and from school, part-time jobs, a family counseling service and an on-site job service office.
Students in the centers would take standard core-curriculum courses of high schools, along with strong vocational-education curriculum, and would be offered job training and career-counseling services. School buildings would be open from 6:30 or 7 A.M. to about 7 P.M. to give students a place to study and participate in extracurricular activities.
Limits class size to 15 students, offers teachers extra pay and sets cap of 15 centers nationwide to be established with grants over five-year period. Authorizes $40 million in annual vocational financing to establish and test high schools in low-income areas around the country.
Status: Hearings pending before Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee; may not come to a vote until sometime next year.

	Educational Excellence Act of 1989 (S.695)	 	Sponsor: Senator Nancy Kassebaum, Republican of Kansas.
Purpose: Represents President Bush's first major legislative initiative in education. Creates national reward program for Chapter 1 schools, which receive Federal assistance and provide compensatory education to children from poor families. Cash awards given to public and private elementary and secondary schools that create safe and drug-free environments, reduce dropout rates and make substantial progress in raising student educational achievement. Authorizes $200 million in expenditures during 1991.
Calls for additional money for antidrug education programs. Provides college scholarships for outstanding high school science students, endowment grants to historically black colleges and $50 million to supplement program for magnet schools which attract students with innovative curriculums. Also calls for developing and establishing alternative certification for those who want to teach but don't have formal teacher training.
Other provisions include more money to program offering six-week course of instruction on the Constitution and Bill of Rights at elementary, middle and high school levels; extension of dropout prevention measure, and creation of grant program for colleges to teach middle-school teachers about adolescents.
Bill attempts to decrease number of student loan defaults. Authorizes total expenditure of $414 million for fiscal year 1991.
Status: Passed by Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee with unanimous consent. Scheduled for Senate vote during this session.

	 Head Start Supplemental Authorization Act of 1989	 		(H.R.1300)	 	Sponsor: Representative Dale Kildee, Democrat of Michigan.
Purpose: Would increase 1990 authorization for Head Start by $147 million to $1.552 billion. Head Start provides comprehensive services to meet educational, social, nutritional and health needs of preschoolers from low-income families.
Status: House of Representatives approved bill by voice vote in March; Senate approved in October. President signed into law Oct. 23.

	The Critical Languages and Area Studies Program (S.1540)	 	Sponsor: Senator James Jeffords, Republican of Vermont.
Purpose: To improve students' knowledge of foreign languages. Would provide grants to establish training and development programs in key language and area studies. Authorizes $15 million for each of the next three fiscal years.
Status: Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee has been holding hearings; may not come to a vote until sometime next year.

	Serve-America: The Service to	 		America Act of 1989 (S.650)	 	Sponsor: Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts.
Purpose: Provides $100 million for local agencies, colleges and public schools to create voluntary youth service opportunities for students.
Status: Incorporated into S.1430 The National & Community Service Act of 1989.

	Child Development and Education Act of 1989 (H.R.3)	 	Sponsor: Representative Augustus F. Hawkins, Democrat of California.
Purpose: Would expand Head Start services and activities, including extension of existing programs to full-day, year-round care, for benefit of working parents. Local education agencies required to use Federal funds to expand or establish school-based child care or early childhood development programs offering services to children not in Head Start, making available at no cost, for example, before- and after-school child care to parents whose incomes are below poverty level.
Would also establish day-care programs for children whose parents work or who attend high school or job training programs. Provides tax credits of up to $2,200 for families earning under $22,400, where at least one parent works. Also calls for ban on religious instruction at child-care centers in churches and synagogues receiving Federal aid. Expected to cost $22.7 billion over next five years.
Status: Approved as part of House budget-reconciliation bill. Now in Senate, where House-Senate conference committee is expected to work out differences.

	Excellence in Teaching Act (S.1675)	 	Sponsor: Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts.
Purpose: Aimed at strengthening the teaching profession by reviving the Teacher Corps, which was phased out under President Reagan in 1981. Participants would receive up to $8,000 a year (for two years) in college scholarship aid if they agree to teach for four years in inner cities or in math or science, or teach for five years in areas with shortage of teachers. Also establishes agencies to coordinate recruitment, especially of minorities, in-service training and testing of new teaching techniques.
Authorizes expenditure of $300 million in 1990.
Tries to increase number of minority teachers by identifying high school students interested in teaching, strengthening teacher education at historically black institutions and colleges with high minority enrollment, and making available scholarships and support services to minorities with teaching aspirations.
Would raise the number of early childhood education teachers, establish teacher training programs to establish or upgrade training in math and science, and prepare teachers to help handicapped children participate in mainstream classes.
Status: Hearings in progress; Senate may consider sometime during next year.

	National Teacher Act of 1989 (S.1676)	 	Sponsor: Senator Claiborne Pell, Democrat of Rhode Island.
Purpose: Establishes loan forgiveness program to encourage graduating college students to become teachers. Federal student loans obtained in the junior and/or senior years of teaching at a Chapter 1 school -one that receives Federal assistance and provides compensatory education to children from economically disadvantaged families - would be forgiven over five-year period of teaching.
Also provides grants to local education agencies to examine how reducing class size may lead to improved instruction; establishes programs in teacher preparation, such as senior teachers becoming mentors for beginning teachers; offers grants to establish programs to attract into teaching careers minority candidates already in school support positions or in occupations other than teaching; awards grants in 10 subjects to a national teacher academy.
Estimated cost is $400 million per year from fiscal year 1990 through 1994, plus whatever the cost for those who ask for loan forgiveness.
Status: Hearings in progress; may be considered sometime during next year.

HEADLINE: End Paper: Letters from China;
They Misjudged The Dragon

BYLINE: By Charles R. Reich; Charles R. Reich recently retired as a housemaster at Greenwich High School, Greenwich, Conn.

 BODY:
MOST OF MY 240 graduate and undergraduate students at the Beijing Institute of Chemical Technology were witty, wise, sweet and highly intelligent - sometimes brilliant. They were patriotic, with a deep-rooted love of their homeland, its ways and its people.
They also seemed to love America - and Richard Nixon, about whom they said with simple logic: ''He was a great man because he made our countries friends.''
''The heart of a teacher and the heart of a student are always linked to each other,'' one student wrote to me recently. He and others - Chinese university students, the men and women of Tiananmen Square of June 1989 - write to me still, their professor of English from September 1987 to July 1988 in the Chinese Government's ''foreign expert'' program. 
As a teacher, I had few resources to carry forth a foreign-language program, having quickly discovered that these university students could speak little English despite years of studying it at middle, secondary and undergraduate levels.
Chinese education is archaic, relying mainly upon rote. Locked in my students' brains were a warehouse of English vocabulary and a wellspring of English grammar that had never been opened for regenerative speech.
I realized that we had to spend the year talking to each other and thinking in English. Consequently, our two-hour classes took on a simple format: They would tell me about China, and I would tell them about America.
They puzzled over America, the commonplace and the conceptual. I would describe an American scene, say a supermarket, and then ask them to enter it, walking down imaginary aisles to imaginary checkout counters. One student inevitably asked, ''But why would I need so much food?''
Helping my students overcome their shyness was a constant struggle. Initially charmed by their modesty, I resigned myself to their tradition of self-effacement when trying to get them to form ''English corners,'' groups of eight students that would meet after class on campus once a week to practice English. ''Teacher Charles,'' one student explained, ''you must understand why we do not have English corners as you wish. No one wants to show off.''
They loved American music, especially tapes of Willy Nelson and folk rock, like Paul Simon's ''Graceland.'' They flocked to American films. The movie ''Breakdancing'' was big in Beijing that year and, thinking that all Americans could do breakdancing, they asked me to perform. I deferred to a student who, having seen the film many times, had perfected the slithering movements.
They added more and more Western touches to their clothing, which was already heavily denimed - loud shirts for the men, rather than the prosaic white ones, and sundresses or miniskirts for the young women, which must have made hearts jump even among the old men in the Politburo.
And they loved to talk. But because each of my classes was attended by an official ''class monitor,'' discussion of political topics was reserved mainly for office hours, which my students had not previously encountered. Though the office that was provided for me had little light and no heat, it had two couches, several chairs, a daily Thermos of boiled water for tea - and scores of students stopping by, eager for a word or two.
It was during these times that I, usually a nonpolitical person, inadvertently became a symbol and spokesman for democracy, a misty concept firing the students' imaginations.
To them, it was primarily a way of gaining a few choices in their lives. They wanted something to say about where they would be assigned to work, for example, complaining that too frequently students are sent to remote areas and jobs unrelated to their training, with nothing to do. One confessed: ''I fear that I will spend the rest of my life in Xinjiang Province only drinking tea and reading newspapers.''
They wanted choices, too, about basic conditions, such as where they could live and when they could marry; they had to reach prescribed ages - 23 for men and 20 for women - for government permission. Marriage was also prohibited while they were students, although some had been married before starting their programs.
They wanted to be free of corruption and profiteering of the kind I discovered when one student promised to invite me to the tiny apartment that he and his wife were scheduled to get from her work unit. With sadness and quiet anger, he later informed me that they were disgraced, being unable to fulfill their invitation: They could not afford the payoff for the apartment demanded by the Communist Party official in the work unit.
They wanted to be free to do as they wished in their own homes. That they weren't became clear when another student invited me home, saying that his family had decided it was time for Chinese people to be allowed to have foreign guests. When the head of his mother's work unit learned of the plans, however, the family was warned that the visit would bring heavy penalties, like the loss of both apartment and jobs.
My students desperately wanted more than their meager portion of books, ill-stocked libraries and ill-equipped laboratories; more than a small dormitory space where they had to live eight to a room and were permitted only one shower a week; more than their ration of food -rice dishes mainly, with occasional shreds of pork. (During the Tiananmen Square hunger strikes, I wondered how such undernourished men and women could survive.) Never did their limited vision of democracy call for changing China's form of government, and though they showed no love for the Communist Party, they expressed no desire to replace it.
The reforms they wanted seemed to them a natural progression within the many economic reforms already in motion. ''It is a good time to be in China,'' one student told me. When I asked if a Cultural Revolution could happen again, they said that was not possible. ''Chairman Mao is gone,'' they chided, ''and the party is no longer our parents telling us what to do.''
They misjudged the dragon.
''The younger generation has completely lost hope with our regime,'' says a letter delivered just a few weeks ago. ''Almost every one of my friends intends to go abroad through different channels. Please don't think we are not patriots. On the contrary, we hope to save our homeland. If we remain here, no one knows what will happen to us. So if you are willing to and capable, help me please!''

GRAPHIC: Drawing with excerpts from Chinese students' letters

HEADLINE: Venezuela's Andean Hideaway

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH LLORENTE; ELIZABETH LLORENTE is a reporter with The Record, of Hackensack, N.J.

 BODY:
ALL year long, Caracas and Margarita Island swell with tourists from Latin America, Europe, the United States and Canada. But Venezuelans who want to get away from it all travel to the country's most treasured hideaway - the Andean city of Merida.
Flying into Merida is a little like stumbling upon a kind of Shangri-La. The three-mile-long city remains elusive until almost the last few minutes before landing, when the plane passes between two mountains and suddenly, like an urban canyon, there it lies.
The capital of the mountainous state of Merida, in the country's westernmost region, the city is on a slightly sloping plateau over 5,000 feet above sea level. It is circled by four rivers and small lakes that teem with trout. The city also has dozens of small parks and plazas. At its center, squat white stucco structures with red-tiled roofs, a legacy of Spanish colonial architecture, predominate; on the outskirts modern glass-facade buildings have begun to spring up. 
To many Venezuelans, however, it is the lure of the towering mountain chain hugging the city and the traditional Andean life that is preserved in its villages that brings them to Merida. The highest peaks soar to over 16,000 feet, and artists and writers find inspiration in the landscape, often called the Swiss Alps of the Western Hemisphere by Venezuelans who have visited Europe.
Venezuelans retreat to Merida to reflect. And while the city has seen an increasing number of foreign visitors, mostly from Canada and the Caribbean, the tourism industry in Merida is largely domestic.
For Venezuela, struggling with inflation and still rhapsodizing about its erstwhile oil-rich days, has done surprisingly little to attract foreign tourism. Its currency, the bolivar, has plummeted in value since 1983 and now stands at 38 to the dollar. As a result, a vacation in Venezuela, particularly in the Andes, may be one of the best bargain vacations for the American traveler, who has 10 times more buying power there than only six years ago. Two people can fly round-trip from New York to Merida, for instance, and pay for accommodations, three daily meals and sightseeing for 10 days for less than $1,600. Daytime temperatures hover around 70 to 80 degrees, falling into the 50's at night. Temperatures in the mountains, of course, fall far lower, often below freezing point.
After 1810, when the University of the Andes was founded there, the city of Merida began to assume the trappings of a metropolis. What had been largely a peripheral community in the strongly rural Merida region evolved into a magnet for Venezuela's intellectuals as well as its most affluent college-bound students, many of whom came from Caracas, 300 miles to the southwest.
Today, with some 22,000 students in a total population of about 125,000, plus hundreds of thousands of visitors a year from Venezuela's larger cities, Merida has something of a European feel. And yet there is none of the restlessness and clamor to be found in most cities. With tree-covered mountains, snow-capped summits and four rivers encircling it, Merida has a sense of serenity. Indeed, every day from noon to 2 P.M. banks, stores and post offices close for siesta.
In an increasingly fast-paced country like Venezuela, the down-home, almost vulnerable mien of the Andeans has made them prey to parody. Venezuelans from other parts of the country seem to relish telling jokes about the docile Meridenos. But their teasing is generally taken in stride.
From the moment we arrived from Caracas at the Alberto Carnevale Airport, we were urged to ride the teleferico, the cable car that climbs in four stages to Pico Espajo. The car ascends past the clouds and tundra line at a 30-degree angle. The earliest car usually leaves Calle 25 in the city's Barinitas section at 7 A.M. from every day except Monday and the last leaves at noon, just before the dense, cold fog begins its descent upon the mountains, bringing temperatures well below freezing. The last car down leaves at 2 P.M.
For about $3 a person, the ride offers an uninterrupted view of the entire valley as well as part of the Chama River, several lakes, vast moors and many of the hamlets and villages that dot the mountains. There is a quota of 200 people an hour on the cable car, and as there are often long lines tickets should be bought a day in advance.
The cable car stops at four stations and at each stop villagers are on hand to serve as voluntary sources of information on such things as accommodations and restaurants (a number speak or understand at least rudimentary English, which is the case with many other Venezuelans). There are also cafes at each stop and the local people are always ready to provide first aid for those stricken by altitude sickness, known in Merida as el mal del paramo. Certified medical technicians are at the last stop, Pico Espejo, to treat anyone who is overcome.
BY the time we reached Aguada, the second station (the ride takes 15 minutes between stations, with a 10-minute stop at each), light-headedness had set in and we were promptly whisked off by a villager to a cafe, where waiters brought us hot tea and homemade vegetable soup. They hovered over us until we seemed better. Most of the Meridenos we encountered were hospitable and affectionate people who seemed to take a proprietary interest in helping visitors. While we ate our soup, villagers, accustomed to dizzy tourists, came over to our table with knowing smiles and for about an hour asked questions about the United States, regaled us with tales about their village and offered to put us up free of charge.
In varying degrees the rapid drop in temperature and the thinning air combine to cause altitude sickness in about half the visitors who climb the mountain. Although escaping even minor dizziness is virtually impossible for people unaccustomed to high altitudes, certain precautions will lessen the discomfort. It is best, for example, to sit and relax at each station, for if the dizziness is ignored it can progress to severe headaches and nausea. Anyone with a medical problem, such as high blood pressure or heart disease, should consult a physician.
In our case the dizziness passed, as it does for most people, and we continued to the third station, called Loma Redonda, at 11,300 feet.
This was where we began the most interesting part of our ascent: a visit to Los Nevados, a quintessential Merida village settled by Indians about 400 years ago that has a population of 2,000 and offers probably the best views of the Andes. The journey from Loma Redonda to this agricultural village offers some of most scenic vistas in the Venezuelan Andes and takes about six hours to traverse. But the only way to get there is by walkng or riding a mule. The narrow, rocky trails and hairpin turns along the 2,000-foot descent defy all other modes of transportation.
Remarkably, the passage of time passed virtually unnoticed since for most of the trip our guide, who was one of several waiting at the station, told one historic and folkloric tale after another about each village or site we passed. The guide's fee was only $2.
The villagers of Los Nevados tend fields of potatoes, garlic, wheat and beans. They take their harvest to Loma Redonda by mule, and to Merida by way of the cable car. Visitors can stay overnight in villagers' cabins for as little as $5 for bed and breakfast. Many villagers provide all three meals for that price, and may insist on treating you like a family member, giving you full use of their homes.
Los Nevados itself is more a rest stop than a tourist attraction. Other than a bell tower built in 1915 and the Plaza Bolivar, there are not many other sites or landmarks to visit.
For the hardy traveler there is the last station, Pico Espejo, which has yearlong light snow and offers the closest view of the glacier on Pico Bolivar, which is 16,430 feet high. The temperatures there are freezing, and visitors should dress as warmly as they would in New York in January.
We spent about three days just walking around the city of Merida, visiting several of its many parks and open craft kiosks. One of our favorite parks was El Parque Beethoven, where every hour on the hour three-foot-high mechanical wooden soldiers emerge from a veranda-enclosed German-style chalet and march around it to the beat of Beethoven scores.
Another favorite was Los Chorros de Milla, a zoological park at the end of an avenue of the same name. Peacocks, lions, tigers, among others, are kept in cages around the park, which also has a high waterfall. Just outside the park is an open craft market where Meridenos sell their handmade wood and stone carvings, pottery, wind chimes, textiles and ruanas, or woolen shawls, for as little as $10 each.
A trip to the state of Merida, everyone in Venezuela will tell you, would not be complete without visits to the state's lakes and their world-class trout fishing and the villages of Jaji and Los Aleros.
Jaji, about a 20-mile car ride west of Merida, is often called the state's most beautiful village. Dominated by red-tile-roofed buildings, Jaji is a 17th-century village that was restored in 1971 with cobblestoned plazas and colonial-style churches.
In Los Aleros, another village that has been restored, stationary 1920's and 1930's cars have been dotted around the narrow, steep streets and an old-time telegraph is in working operation. The most popular tourist attraction here is an 80-foot tunnel that runs through the Cave of the Weeping Woman. The cave has been converted into a kind of amusement park fun house, with witches and goblins that jump out and surprise you while mechanical screams fill the dark, dank air.
DOWN in the valley the influence of the Spanish in Merida, who arrived in the 1600's, is to be seen in the red-roofed Colonial homes, the light-skinned, blond and red-haired settlers and the swift tempo of life.
But if one thing has remained the same in Merida throughout the last two centuries, it is the stark difference between the rural and the urban ways of life. Each has maintained its identity, its customs and its idiosyncracies. Although some villagers, who are mostly laborers and farmers, have discarded their donkeys for modest, often rickety cars, a good many still prefer four-legged transportation along the narrow, winding, rock-strewn mountain trails.
In a country seemingly in love with the latest - in clothing, videos and appliances - Meridenos are considered the keepers of traditional Venezuela.
 
A VISITOR'S GUIDE TO MERIDA
 
Getting There
Merida can best be reached by air from Caracas on Avensa Airlines or Aeropostal. The trip last about 45 minutes and costs $50 round trip, calculated at a rate of 38 bolivars to the dollar. Pan American World Airways, American Airlines, Eastern and Viasa, the Venezuelan airline, all have daily flights to Caracas from New York.
 
Hotels
Although hotel rates have increased about 30 percent since early this year, there are still many bargains.
The most expensive would include the Hotel Park and Hotel Pedregoza.
Hotel Park (Calle 37, Avenida 4; telephone 634866) has 133 rooms and a travel agency and restaurant on the lobby level. A double room is $26 a person a night.
Hotel Pedregoza (Pedregoza Norte; 632505), just outside the city, includes a lake, riding trails and a children's play area. It has 104 rooms. A double room is $32 a person a night.
Hotel Belesante, in the La Hacienda area of Merida (691655) has been recently renovated with spacious rooms and a restaurant. It has 63 rooms and rates are $21 a person for a double room. Hotel Valle Grande (El Valle; 443011) has 80 rooms and 30 chalets, a nightclub, restaurant and a mini-golf course. Horses can also be rented. Double rooms are $21; two- to four-bedroom fully equipped chalets cost $30 to $70.
More information: Association of Merida Tour Guides (525080).
 
Dining
Merida dazzles with dining bargains. Two people can have a three-course dinner at a fine restaurant for about $16 with wine. Venezuelan cooking is heavily influenced by Spanish food. Special holiday foods are also served at Christmas, which is celebrated from November to January, and at Easter. The food at those times would include tamales filled with meats or vegetables. Following are some of Merida's restaurants:
Il Duce (Avenida Las Americas; 632814), one of the finest in Merida, serves a pasta appetizer, a chicken entree, dessert and a beverage for about $10 a person.
La Casa Vieja (Avenida Los Proceres; 635885) serves typical Venezuelan cuisine. A plentiful seafood dinner, with appetizer, beverage and dessert costs about $6 a person.
Hotel Valle Grande (El Valle; 443011) has a restaurant that serves both Spanish and Venezuelan dishes. Dinner costs about $8 a person.
 
Getting Around
Taxis are available for travel in Merida City, but a car is needed to visit the mountain vilages. Car rental rates range from $45 to $60 a day.
The mountain roads leading to the villages are narrow and winding, and Andeans are notorious for their daredevil driving. Drive defensively, and avoid driving at night. Also, those who drive up the mountains are susceptible to high-altitude sickness. Take winter clothing along and make more rest stops as you go higher. - E. L.

HEADLINE: For Hindus, a Temple of Their Own

BYLINE: By SHARON L. BASS

 BODY:
FOR 10 years, Hindus in Connecticut have worshipped in a community center and a school cafeteria or traveled out of the state. Now, they have a temple of their own, the first of its kind in the state.
Called Shri Satyanarayan Temple, it is perched on a hill surrounded by eight acres of wooded land in Middletown, across from Middlesex Community College. Though construction has not yet been completed, 200 of the state's 1,000 Hindu families have been meeting in the white concrete building for the last two months, holding prayer services to the deities, dance classes for children and festivals for all. 
Temple members say it is good to have a place they can call their spiritual home. ''I feel at home because I know there's a place I can come to,'' said Krishnan Gopal, a member of the temple and its board of trustees. Dr. Gopal is a radiologist at Windham Community Memorial Hospital in Willimantic. There are eight other board members, seven of whom are also medical doctors.
 
A Way of Life
''Hinduism is 100 percent of my life, it is a way of life for me,'' he said.
Dina Bhatt said she used to go to a temple in Queens, N.Y. ''It feels good to have a place of our own,'' to indoctrinate the children into the Hindu faith and help strengthen the adults' faith, she said.
''The temple represents the fulfillment of a longtime dream,'' said Rao Singamsetti, who is the president of the Connecticut Valley Hindu Temple Society and an associate professor of economics at the University of Hartford.
During the 1960's, many of the Hindus in Connecticut came to the state from India, either for employment or to go to graduate or medical school. Because of the immigration patterns, Dr. Singamsetti said, ''most of us who were drawn here are professionals.''
 
Semblance of Our Heritage
Dr. A. V. Srinivasm, the acting priest, said: ''We came to the United States with the idea that we'd go back to India, but the majority of us have settled here and our children are growing up and we want to make sure they grow up with some semblance of our heritage.'' Dr. Srinivasm, a founding member of the Hindu temple and an engineer for United Technology in East Hartford, started the Hindu Society in Connecticut in 1979; one of the prime goals of the society was to build a temple.
Exposing their children to the Hindu way of life was the major motivation for establishing the temple, members say. Although Dr. Srinivasm said they have faced no obstacles since they started building the temple four years ago, it has taken a lot of money and work. So far, it has cost $600,000 for architectural and construction costs. All the money, he said, has been donated by the people of the temple.
Still needed to be constructed is a sanctuary in the two-story building, which has a community center, kitchen and priest quarters completed. A section of the main lobby is currently used for worship and prayer.
During a recent Sunday afternoon, dozens of Hindus filled the temple. A dozen girls wearing long, straight dresses, called salwar, and slacks, called kamiz, participated in a classic Hindu dance class taught by a woman wrapped in a red sari and seated in a chair. With expressionless faces, the dancers followed their teacher's verbal instructions.
 
Dance Imparts Discipline
The dance, explained Dr. Gopal, as well as the other cultural and religious activities, ''gives the children discipline.''
''As we get older, spiritual needs become more important,'' he said. ''You tend to think more spiritualistic and less materialistic.'' Adults gathered in the makeshift sanctuary, a corner of the first floor, sitting barefoot and cross-legged on scattered rugs. On the pink and cream walls around them hung prints of the Hindu gods. An elderly woman, wearing a brown and white sari, burned incense, lighted candles and chanted as she offered prayer to Satyanarayana, the presiding deity of the temple. The three major Hindu gods, said Dr. Srinivasm, are Siva, Brahma and Vishnu.
After the prayer service, the adults talked about the progress of the temple and how far they had come.
''He was just born when we began digging,'' said Manahar Velandy, a psychiatrist, pointing to his 4-year-old son, Vishwam.
Vishwam's 11-year-old brother, Siddhartha, said he enjoyed helping the grownups with the religious rituals. ''It's just nice to have this kind of place in the United States. In India, they have all this kind of stuff,'' he said, referring to the pictures of the deities and the incense.
Besides dance classes and services, the temple offers religious discussions and music lessons on instruments like the violin as well as the sitar and the veena.
 
Divinity Within
Hinduism is practiced by roughly 600 million of the 850 million who live in India, said Dr. Srinivasm. In the United States, he said, there are about 20 Hindu temples and more are cropping up now. The principal belief behind Hinduism, he said, is that every human being has divinity within. ''We believe in nonviolence and non killing,'' said Basau Swamy, a temple member. ''To kill a living being is a sin.'' Most Hindus are vegetarians.
Reincarnation and good conduct are integral parts of Hinduism, said Dr. Srinivasm. Good conduct with money, family and work matters ''leads to salvation, a place of supreme bliss where you're never born again,'' he said. Conduct is defined according to one's age and station in life.
He said there is no beginning date for the practice of Hinduism. ''We never believe anything begins or ends completely. It's a continuum.''
While anyone is welcome to visit or join the temple, Dr. Srinivasm said Hindus do not proselytize. ''We believe God is one and any path or religion to God is fine,'' he said. He recited a popular story among Hindus to illustrate his point: ''A person drinks water from a lake and calls it water. Another comes along and drinks some water and gives it a different name, but it's still the same water from the same lake. What does it matter what you call it?''

HEADLINE: Proposed City Charter Raises Sharp Argument on Land Use

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
As the merits of the proposed charter revision have been debated before community groups throughout New York City, no issue has sparked more passionate divisions - or probably confused more people - than the plans for regulating land use.
The Charter Revision Commission and its supporters say that the plan would transfer final authority over the most important zoning and land-use matters from the Board of Estimate to the City Council. The commission has proposed eliminating the board.
Under the proposed charter, land-use initiatives involving zoning changes, urban renewal plans and most city-owned residential property would automatically go from the Planning Commission to the Council. 
Other matters, including selecting sites for city projects like incinerators and shelters, would be reviewed by the Planning Commission; they would go to the Council only if the affected borough president and community board appealed the Planning Commission's decision, or if the Council voted to take jurisdiction. How Much Control for the Mayor? Proponents say the two-step system would insure that the Council reviewed significant or controversial land-use initiatives, without becoming inundated by administrative matters.
But some opponents contend that all land-use decisions should be made by elected officials, in this case the Council. These critics say that the charter commission's plan is seriously flawed because too many land-use initiatives would be decided only by the appointed officials on the Planning Commission. And they say that the mayor would control that panel, because he would appoint 7 of its 13 members.
They also say that the new mechanisms for appealing decisions to the Council would be cumbersome; the Council might have to vote once to take jurisdiction, a second time to have a proposal taken out of committee and a third time on the actual proposal.
Other opponents assert that the mayor must have much more control over the Planning Commission so that a citywide perspective would prevail. Otherwise, they say, it will be difficult to win approval for highly disputed projects like drug-rehabilitation centers or homeless shelters.
 
Questions and Responses
During debates, critics have harshly denounced the charter commission's land-use vision. Commission members say that many critics misstate what the proposed charter says. What follows are some of the most significant questions raised by the opponents, with responses from the commission.
Would the proposed charter give the mayor a new veto on land use?
Borough President Fernando Ferrer of the Bronx has often said that the proposal would create an alarming new power for the mayor. ''It grants the mayor something he never had before - a veto over the Council's decision on land use,'' he has said.
Eric Lane, the charter commission's executive director, says that the veto would simply mirror the voting dynamic that now exists.
 
Mayoral Veto on Land-Use
The proposed charter would allow the mayor to veto land-use matters approved by the Council, but the Council could override the veto with a two-thirds vote. Mr. Lane says that replicates what happens on the Board of Estimate now. The mayor has 2 of the 11 votes on the board, meaning it requires 6 of the 9 remaining votes -two-thirds - to defeat a mayoral initiative.
Would the Council have to vote on land-use questions?
Opponents including Marcy Benstock, the executive director of the Clean Air Campaign, and Leslie Lowe, a lawyer who is a member of Community Board 2 in Manhattan, contend that the Council would never have to vote, not even on zoning changes that would go to it automatically.
''Elected officials don't have to vote on matters that affect your survival,'' Ms. Lowe said during a debate. Leasing Waterfront Property But Mr. Lane said that the proposed charter is similar to the current Charter on this question. If the Planning Commission approves a land-use or zoning matter now, the Board of Estimate must vote on it within 60 days. If it does not, the Planning Commission's decision is final. The deadline is intended to force decisions within a reasonable time.
The proposed charter says that the Council must hold a public hearing and take ''an affirmative vote'' to approve or disapprove a Planning Commission decision. It also says that if the Council fails to act within 50 days, the commission's decision is final.
Mr. Lane said there are no instances known in which the Board of Estimate failed to act, and that there is no reason to assume the Council would be less responsible.
Would the new charter allow waterfront property to be leased without the approval of elected officials? Creating or Closing a Loophole? Ms. Benstock said at a debate that the charter ''will encourage giveaways of public waterfronts.''
The revised charter would allow the city to lease city-owned wharf property. If the property were to be used for waterfront commerce or navigation, the lease would require a vote of three-quarters of the Council.
But the proposal says that the lease would be considered approved if the Council failed to act within 45 days. Ms. Benstock says the time limit is a large and potentially devastating loophole.
But the charter commission's lawyers say that the current charter exempts all waterfront leases from the city's formal land-use review, to encourage companies interested in using the waterfront for shipping, cargo and related uses. All the Charter requires for approval of such leases is a three-quarters vote of the Board of Estimate. Some city agencies have used the quick procedure on waterfront leases for restaurants and other businesses unrelated to shipping or navigation, the charter commission says.
The proposed charter attempts to close the existing loophole, said Andrew Lynn, a staff lawyer for the charter commission. For the first time, any leases on city-owned wharf property that did not involve shipping and cargo would have to go through a complete land-use review, Mr. Lynn said.
The proposed charter leaves intact the quick approval for leases involving shipping and navigation, he said.

HEADLINE: How Really to Cut Down Illegal Immigration;
Protect the Innocent

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''Jobs Being Filled by Illegal Aliens Despite Sanctions'' (front page, Oct. 9) was foreseen by opponents of immigration reform legislation. That law was a mismarriage of ''reforms'' sought by two minorities in Congress, the Hispanophobes, who wanted to keep out Mexican migrants, and the Hispanophiles, who wanted legalization for illegal aliens already here.
The ebb and flow of Mexican migrants across our Southern border is likely to continue as long as there are jobs here that are shunned, for whatever reasons, by legal residents. Bogus documents were the inevitable consequence of the law's requirement that employers demand proof from each new employee of his right to work in the United States. 
We could control our border more effectively if we allowed short-term legal entry for screened Mexicans who can produce police clearances and family data from their home communities. Such migrants would enter through normal channels and could be monitored while here to assure timely departure. This would be far more orderly than a situation in which otherwise harmless job seekers must sneak across the border or be smuggled in by ''coyotes.''
The opponents of short-term legal entry argue that such a program would make it easier for migrants to find jobs, thus depriving legal residents of employment opportunities. That is a myth refuted by credible studies and by the experience of employers whose premises have been raided by Immigration and Naturalization Service agents to arrest and deport undocumented Mexicans. Most of the vacated jobs went begging until ''illegal aliens'' came back to take them. A President's Council of Economic Advisers report found that the Mexican migrants who come here temporarily for hard-to-fill jobs benefit the economies of both countries.
The flood of harmless migrants who must sneak or be smuggled across the border because there is no legal alternative are used as cover by the drug traffickers and other criminals, who are a serious threat to our country. By establishing a legal, short-term entry procedure for the innocuous migrants, we would divert the Mexicans who benefit our economy to normal entry channels and thus make it far easier for our border officials to apprehend and prohibit entry by the malefactors, who must of necessity find illegal ways to enter our country.
 
E. M. GILES
San Antonio, Oct. 9, 1989

HEADLINE: Best Foot Forward, or Close

BYLINE: By ROBIN FINN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 5

 BODY:
The National Horse Show concluded its debut at the Meadowlands tonight with a familiar trill from the huntsman's horn and the $50,000 Big Apple Grand Prix, an ironic link to the show's former home site of the last 105 years.
Thirty-four horses attempted the imposing course of the Big Apple, a World Cup qualifying event, and five earned a trip to the jumpoff, where Hiro Tomazawa of Japan, on Don Carlos, managed the only clean ride and a time of 32.01 seconds.
Beezie Patton, who withdrew from the jumpoff after Northern Magic twice refused its first obstacle, was named the show's Leading International Rider; the United States took the Leading International Team award; Greg Best was Leading Open Jumper Rider, and Ian Millar of Canada, victorious last Thursday in the Puissance, was Leading Foreign Rider.
 
Teen-Ager Wins the Maclay
In the Rolex-Maclay National Championship for the A.S.P.C.A. Horsemanship Final, a local challenger, 16-year-old Raymond Texel from Eatontown, N.J., outrode a field of 98 this afternoon on his 11-year-old thoroughbred, Meet the Press. 
Texel said he did not mind being the first Maclay champion not to claim the honors at Madison Square Garden because, having never ridden there, he did not miss it.
The National, anxious about having gone suburban by moving to New Jersey after holding court in Manhattan for over a century, struggled all week to retain its old pomp at its new Meadowlands address and succeeded in matters practical if not sentimental.
But from the horses to the riders to the Dalmatian that followed the carriage of dignitaries into the ring on opening night, the change of place was felt in marked ways.
 
Manhattan and Money Desired
The horses, accustomed to stuffy fifth-floor quarters at Madison Square Garden, breathed more freely in their tents in the Meadowlands parking lot, but some suffered a case of wet feet, because of stall flooding when it rained.
The riders grumbled about missing Manhattan and something they described as ''the aura'' there. They also felt a more vigorous recruitment of sponsors was in order to bolster the National's $240,000 in prize money.
The Dalmatian, sensing himself far from his usual opening night stomping grounds, had to be shooed into the ring last Tuesday.
The National left the Garden for reasons best described as economic, although a smattering of sour grapes had seemed to ferment between show officials and their Garden counterparts.
The National said it felt stagnated by the Garden's confines and tariffs. The Garden said it could not avoid charging city occupancy rates to the National merely out of a sentimental interest in keeping the event in New York. Hence the move.
 
A Vote for 'Eliteness'
''They did a nice job here,'' said Anne Kursinski of the United States Equestrian Team. ''But I hope they can keep the eliteness and streamline it so it doesn't turn into just another indoor show. It should be a show for the cream of the crop. That's what made it work at the Garden.''
The Meadowlands, which negotiated a three-year contract with the National, promised it would be a robust and cooperative ally to the National, and by most accounts, it was. David Distler, one of the show's three assistant managers, said the Meadowlands staff members, from administrators to union crews, were consistently obliging.
''The ring itself was impressive,'' said Best, who finished third in the Big Apple on Gem Twist. ''For sure nobody can say the social aspects were comparable to those at the Garden. But on the other hand, I don't think the physical aspects of the Garden facility can compare to these here.''
 
Dirt Needed a Dryout
There were, however, relocation problems. The first crisis occurred a week ago after more than a million pounds of dirt freshly imported from Sparta, N.J., was installed in Byrne Meadowlands Arena and found to be too damp by the footing consultant, Hermann Duckek of Denmark.
All day Monday, the staff supervised a frenetic removal of the dirt to the parking lot, where it was sifted and dried and ultimately reinstalled.
''Had it been raining on Monday,'' Distler said, ''we would have been dead in the water. But that put us a full day behind in our preparations, and as a result, the stable area wasn't really prepared when the rain hit on Tuesday.''
 
Hectic Improvisation
Scant hours before the show's formal opening Tuesday evening, Distler and his associates scrambled to construct enough makeshift dikes to keep the parking-lot runoff out of the stalls.
''There's trouble in river city, literally,'' Distler said as he searched in vain for a free moment to exchange his workwear for the suit required by his ringmaster duties.
''Everybody talked about how unhealthy it was for the horses to be cooped up at the Garden,'' said Leslie Burr Lenehan, a gold medalist in the 1984 Olympics. ''But what if we'd had a hurricane out there instead of just a storm?''
Inside the arena, all was warm and dry and colorful. Boutiques dotting the concourse sold everything from saddles to jewelry to furniture, all with a tony equine theme.
 
Some Diversions Dragged
Some of the innovations on the show's expanded program seemed well-suited to the family entertainment the Meadowlands hoped to provide, but others took up time that might have been more efficiently devoted to jumping classes.
The Superdogs from Canada, and Rugged Lark, the world champion quarterhorse stallion, charmed and invigorated the audience. But lengthy classes dedicated to elusive arts, like carriage competition and sidesaddle, needed streamlining.
The National lost the bulk of its Long Island audience this year, but increased support from New Jersey and from Westchester and Rockland Counties compensated, the event's organizers said.
The show typically draws 60,000 customers to provide $1 million of its $2 million operating expenses, and by the close of this afternoon's Maclay program, which drew 9,400, that goal had nearly been passed.
