HEADLINE: U.S. Abruptly Closes a Route for Soviet Jews

BYLINE: By ANN COOPER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Nov. 5

 BODY:
Overwhelmed by an unexpected tide of Soviet Jews seeking to emigrate, Washington has closed off an important immigration route to the United States sooner than expected. The move prompted a rush by thousands of Jews today to beat the deadline.
This fall, with Soviet restrictions on the departure of Jews easing and the demand for United States visas soaring, the State Department announced that the special route for Soviet Jews, a circuitous path through Rome or Vienna, would soon be closed.
Washington originally planned to close the route after processing the immigration requests of all Soviet Jews with exit visas dated before Oct. 1. 
Last week, the State Department set another deadline. Every prospective emigrant with properly dated Soviet exit documents would also have to obtain Israeli visas by today, or forfeit the right to use the Vienna-Rome route to the United States.
Jewish citizens seeking to emigrate from the Soviet Union first obtain Israeli visas, which are granted automatically through the Dutch Embassy in Moscow. Many then apply to the United States Embassy for refugee status and seek American citizenship. As an alternative, many travel to Rome or Vienna while ostensibly on their way to Israel, only to seek United States asylum once they arrive in Italy or Austria.
For years, Washington has assailed Moscow for controlling the tide of Jewish emigration. But with the Soviet Union now permitting Jews to leave in record numbers, the United States has sought to limit the influx of emigrants by imposing a ceiling of 50,000 for the coming year.
Those who met today's deadline can use their Israeli visas to leave the Soviet Union, then follow the route through Vienna and Rome, which for years has been virtually the only path for Jewish emigration from the Soviet Union to the United States.
American consular officials said they abandoned plans to keep the route open until the end of the year mainly because the number of Soviet Jews already on the way was likely to fill the quota of 50,000 Soviet refugees set by the State Department for the fiscal year that began Oct. 1.
There are 1.8 million Jews in the Soviet Union, and as many as 150,000 were expected to seek American citizenship this year.
Officials also said they had begun to find evidence of forged documents among would-be emigres who missed the earlier deadline requiring that they have Soviet exit visas by Oct. 1.
Jews who did not make today's deadline will now have to apply directly to the United States for permission to immigrate.
They will find the way blocked by tens of thousands of other citizens trying to move to the United States, and by the American ceiling.
Those who are not accepted as refugees may be offered the opportunity to immigrate under a special parole program. But they must have American sponsors who will guarantee their economic well-being.
 
Dutch Officials Sought Extension
Soviet Jews also have the option of emigrating to Israel. But over the last two years, as Soviet officials have eased restrictions on Jewish emigration, more than 90 percent of those departing with Israeli visas have gone to the United States instead.
The unexpected policy change was announced by United States officials on Thursday in a meeting with Dutch consular officials. The Netherlands represents Israeli interests in the Soviet Union, including the issuing of visas.
Many applicants heard of the decision on Voice of America, the United States Government radio service, and rushed to Moscow from all over the Soviet Union to make today's deadline.
Dutch officials asked the United States to extend its new deadline for a few days.
When American officials declined, the Dutch decided to keep their consular office open on Sunday in order to issue last-minute visas.
The new deadline was largely a reaction to an unexpected flood of 11,000 Jews who arrived at the Dutch consulate last month with Soviet exit visas dated before Oct. 1.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (99%); AUSTRIA (92%); NETHERLANDS (90%); RUSSIAN FEDERATION (90%); ITALY (72%);

HEADLINE: Campaign Matters;
Asking Voters To Accept Much On Sheer Faith

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
Not since the election of Judge John F. Hylan, a former locomotive engineer, as Mayor in 1917 have New York City's voters been asked to accept so much on faith.
David N. Dinkins, the Democratic nominee and one-term Manhattan Borough President, boasts modest relevant experience in municipal government. Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican-Liberal candidate and a former Federal prosecutor, offers none.
So far, what the major-party candidates have achieved, while confronted with a billion-dollar deficit, is a higher level of expectation than either may be able to fulfill and an emerging, if premature, nostalgia for the incumbent, Edward I. Koch. 
Mr. Dinkins promises to help the poor and achieve racial harmony; Mr. Giuliani promises to repel the plague of crime and drugs. The rap against Mr. Dinkins is that he is too deliberative and vulnerable to the importunings of organized labor and social-welfare advocates. Mr. Giuliani's perceived liabilities are his political naivete and a sedimentary philosophical foundation on which he stands as a man of many convictions.
Yet New Yorkers know by now that their mayors are seldom what they seemed.
In 1965, John V. Lindsay inveighed against power brokers but eventually struck an accommodation. Comptroller Abraham D. Beame said he knew the buck, but, through little fault of his own, presided as Mayor over a city others had to help rescue from the brink of bankruptcy. Mr. Koch was a profligate son of Greenwich Village, but, by necessity, metamorphosed almost overnight into a fiscal conservative.
This year, there are added reasons for uncertainty. The fulcrum of the campaign appears to be whether, as Mr. Dinkins implies, racial harmony is a prerequisite for economic prosperity or whether, as Mr. Giuliani suggests, a healthy economic climate - abetted by reduced crime -will generate a more enduring calm.
That Mr. Dinkins would be the city's first black mayor injected the same uncertainties that earlier political pioneers had set off. With blacks overwhelmingly supporting Mr. Dinkins, white Catholics generally for Mr. Giuliani, and Hispanic voters more divided, Jews -who represented the largest contingent of white voters for Mr. Dinkins in the Democratic primary - appear to be pivotal again, and this has provoked hand-wringing. Many of them are sensitive about being singled out.
''They don't want to do anything to make the Jewish community stand out and to bring on the kind of anti-Semitism they are worried about,'' said Assemblyman George Friedman, the Bronx Democratic leader.
In 1965, in fact, some among the one in four Jewish voters who helped elect Mr. Lindsay on the Republican and Liberal lines feared that Mr. Beame, as the city's first Jewish mayor, would become the scapegoat if the melting pot boiled over. (After Mr. Beame won in 1973, John J. DeLury, the president of the sanitation workers union, said bankers never would have pulled the plug on a non-Jewish mayor).
Merits aside, some Jewish voters may be motivated by guilt. Others, like some whites in general, may have abandoned Mr. Dinkins because of concerns about his association with the Rev. Jesse Jackson.
Jews, says Albert Vorspan, senior vice president of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, ''do not have to support Jesse Jackson out of some misconceived Jewish guilt,'' but nor, he said yesterday, should they reflexively judge Mr. Dinkins guilty of associating with Mr. Jackson without assessing his own record.
''There is a name for that - it is racism,'' Mr. Vorspan said. ''It is time to exorcise that dybbuk, lest Jesse Jackson become our excuse for racial stereotyping and hatred.''
Some people said Mr. Dinkins never would have been taken seriously had he been white; others said he would have breezed into office had he not been black. There are other grounds to judge him on, but race will presumably figure in many voters' minds. How many, and whether they vote for or against him as a result, New Yorkers will know tomorrow. What they still may be less confident about is what kind of mayor either candidate would make.
Which brings us back to Mayor Hylan. On Jan. 1, 1926, he was struck by how well the permanent government of his day was represented at the inauguration of his successor, James J. Walker. ''I want to congratulate you that so many of your friends are present,'' he wryly told the new Mayor. ''As I look about me, I remember some of their faces on Jan. 1, 1918, and again on Jan. 1, 1922.''
Later, Mayor Walker graciously restored Mr. Hylan to the bench - this time to Children's Court in Queens. What did the appointment mean, Mr. Walker was asked.
''It means,'' he replied, ''that the children now can be tried by their peers.''

HEADLINE: Treasury Auctions Expected to Be Delayed

 BODY:
With Congress yet to pass legislation to raise the nation's debt ceiling, this week's scheduled Treasury auctions are likely to be disrupted.
The first sale was scheduled to begin with today's regular weekly auction of new three-month and six-month Treasury bills. Tomorrow the Treasury planned to begin its quarterly refunding, starting with new three-year notes, followed on Wednesday by a 10-year note auction and on Thursday by auctions of 30-year bonds and 36-day cash management bills.
As a result of the delay on increasing the debt ceiling, there has been no when-issued trading, market participants said last week. And none is likely until the Treasury has received authority to go ahead with the auctions. 
Among the Government agencies expected to issue debt this week is the Student Loan Marketing Association, which plans to announce today the interest rate for a $500 million issue of short-term floating-rate notes with a maturity date of May 10, 1990. The notes will be priced at a spread to the bond equivalent rate of the 91-day Treasury bill and interest rates will be adjusted on the day after each Treasury bill auction. Should the Treasury auction not take place, the notes will then be priced off the previous auction.
The Federal National Mortgage Association plans to announce the interest rates tomorrow on two debenture offerings totaling $2.3 billion in three-year and 10-year maturities.
By late Friday, the outstanding three-month bill was bid at 7.83 percent, while the six-month bill was bid at 7.69 percent.
The following new fixed-income issues are scheduled this week:

HEADLINE: Greek Conservatives Lead in Votes But Fail to Win Majority of Seats

BYLINE: By MARLISE SIMONS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATHENS, Nov. 5

 BODY:
The conservative New Democracy Party won the most votes in general elections today, but it failed to get enough votes to gain a parliamentary majority and form a government.
Greece is now facing another uncertain period of political negotiations to form a government, and the country may be forced to hold a third round of general elections.
The preliminary results took Greek politicians by surprise. Indications were that the financial and political scandals involving Andreas Papandreou, the Socialist leader and former Prime Minister, would give his longtime conservative rival, Constantine Mitsotakis, a majority in Parliament. 
With 96 percent of the vote counted, New Democracy had 46.4 percent of the vote, the Socialists had 40.8 percent, and the Communist-led Coalition of the Left had 10.8 percent. Small parties and independents won about 2 percent. #3 Seats Short of Majority The incomplete count gave New Democracy 148 seats in the 300-member Parliament, 3 more than the party won in elections in June, but still 3 seats short of the majority needed to form a government. The Socialists were expected to win 128 seats, with the remaining 22 seats going to the Communist coalition and independents.
''New Democracy has undoubtedly won the elections,'' Mr. Mitsotakis announced. But unable to hide his disappointment, he said Greece had ''entered a very difficult period, and the future is uncertain.''
He said that rather than seeking to form a coalition, he would go to Parliament to ask for a vote of confidence.
One of his aides said that Mr. Mitsotakis would try to convince legislators that Greece will lose valuable time holding yet another round of elections and that he would therefore try to form a minority government.
 
Economic Needs Not Met
But party officials conceded that this would not give Greece the strong government it needs to tackle its economic difficulties and make changes required by the end of 1992, when the European Community removes most of its remaining trade barriers.
The lack of a majority government has also led Greece to postpone talks with the United States to renew the agreement covering American military bases here. The present agreement expires in seven months.
Mr. Papandreou appeared elated tonight, calling the results ''a moral and political victory'' for the Socialists. After eight years in office, he lost the elections in June, but then as now the conservatives failed to win a majority.
At that time, however, conservatives and Communists were united by their indignation over what they called unprecedented levels of corruption by the Socialists, and they formed a temporary coalition for the sole purpose of prosecuting high officials of the outgoing Socialist Government.
Parliament since then has ordered Mr. Papandreou and five of his ministers to stand trial on an array of charges, including illegal phone tapping, bribery and embezzlement of public funds.
 
Many Remain Faithful
Several commentators said they were stunned by the large number of voters who had remained faithful to the Socialists despite the scandals and accusations of past months.
The Socialist leader has remained defiant through the parliamentary inquiries. He campaigned largely on the message that he is the victim of a political vendetta and that both Communists and conservatives were out to destroy his party, the Panhellenic Socialist Movement, which he founded in 1974.
''Greeks believe that political life and politicians are corrupt anyway, some more, others less,'' said Panayotis Dimitras, the director of a polling organization. ''The moral issue here is not as important as in other countries.''
 
Communist Betrayal Charged
Mr. Papandreou also clearly benefited from his assertion that he is now the only true representative of the left. The Communists, he charges, betrayed their ideals by cooperating with the right in the effort to put him on trial.
It appears that the Communists have paid a high price for their alliance with the conservatives. The incomplete results showed them losing eight seats, compared with the June results. In the last weeks their alliance with the conservatives has caused a split in their ranks and led to the departure of leaders of the Communist youth movement and several other party officials.
Some Greek commentators believe that the vicious campaign against Mr. Papandreou in many newspapers and radio stations has made his supporters rally around him.
''The mistreatment and slander over Papandreou was an index of how irresponsibly Greek politics functions,'' said Adam Pepeladis, who has served as a state bank director for both conservatives and Socialists. ''People sense the malice of it all. For heaven's sake, corruption and phone-tapping have been going on in Greece for more than 40 years.''

HEADLINE: In New Jersey, Florio and Courter Stress Stark Contrasts

BYLINE: By PETER KERR

DATELINE: ASBURY PARK, N.J., Nov. 5

 BODY:
Voters are facing a dramatic choice in New Jersey Tuesday between a Democratic candidate for governor who offers a return to activist government and a Republican who promises to continue the Reagan agenda with a battle against big government, taxes and crime.
In essence, it is a confrontation between a candidate, Representative James J. Florio, who believes the anti-government sentiments that brought Ronald Reagan to the White House are beginning to ebb, and his opponent, Representative Jim Courter, who believes the future depends on continuing policies that have spurred economic growth through the 1980's.
They clash in a state that was blessed by enormous economic growth in recent years and where Republican leaders have been highly popular. But it is also a state where voters are becoming anxious over the overdevelopment and pollution that growth has created.
The candidates emphasized those themes today as they urged voters at campaign stops throughout the state to cast their ballots despite polls that showed Mr. Florio with a lopsided lead. Mr. Florio and Mr. Courter each appealed to New Jerseyans to vote for their parties' Assembly candidates who are locked in a tight battle for the state's lower house. The polls will be open in New Jersey from 7 A.M. to 8 P.M. Tuesday. 
 
Growth and Congestion
In the last 10 weeks the stark philosophical contrast between the two men has often been obscured by one of the nastiest campaigns in memory. And their differences have often been expressed in emotionally charged social issues, like abortion and the rights of homosexuals. But just beneath the surface of the campaign, experts say, lie critical questions about how Americans confront a future of limited resources and how they can preserve the promise of prosperity and an environment that no longer offers unlimited room to grow.
In many parts of this, the most densely populated state in the nation, it sometimes seems residents are developing a mindset in which quality of life is often as important as quantity of wealth, and where voters recognize they can no longer exploit a world of boundless physical frontiers.
''New Jersey is squarely facing many of the problems that other states are going to face in the next decade,'' said Cliff Zukin, a former professor of politics at Rutgers University. ''The state has grown and people are happy with that. But growth has created major development and congestion problems. Its landfills are being closed and that is going to strain its tax structure. New Jersey leads the nation in toxic wastes.''
 
Economic Concerns
Mr. Florio, whose Congressional career was steeped in environmental issues, is offering New Jerseyans a promise of revitalized government, saying that with all the bounty created by economic expansion, the 1980's have bequeathed clogged highways and environmental hazards that only government can solve.
''I am going to leave New Jersey cleaner and greener,'' Mr. Florio said recently at a campaign stop in Belleville, N.J. ''Clean water and clean air are such an axiomatic value.''
Mr. Courter, a six-term Congressman from the state's rural northwest, promised to continue the prosperity that took place in New Jersey during the terms of President Ronald Reagan and Gov. Thomas H. Kean. He has pledged not to raise taxes and has proposed a cap on state spending as well as a plan to bring dow high automobile insurance premiums through deregulation and increased competition.
''I desperately want to make sure the economic success we have had in New Jersey, the creation of three quarters of a million new jobs, is not placed at risk by virtue of New Jersey being less competitive,'' Mr. Courter said in a recent interview.
 
Series of Fiscal Crises
The race this year takes place against a backdrop of political success for Republican chief executives in the 1980's in New Jersey. Independents and Democrats helped give victories twice to Mr. Reagan and once to George Bush. Four years ago, Mr. Kean, a Republican, was re-elected with 70 percent of the vote.
When Mr. Kean first took office in 1982, New Jersey was one of the East Coast's most beleaguered states. Tens of thousands of manufacturing jobs had been lost in the 1970's, and the unemployment rate was nearly 10 percent. State government lurched from fiscal crisis to fiscal crisis.
But by 1986, New Jersey's sprawling suburbs had become magnets for high-technology industries and corporate offices. The unemployment rate eventually dropped to below 4 percent, and until last year, the state reported large budget surpluses.
Pledging to keep New Jersey an inviting home for business, Mr. Courter has warned voters that his opponent will raise taxes and once again stifle opportunity for all New Jerseyans.
Though he supports a number of environmental protection initiatives, the government role Mr. Courter has emphasized most is in fighting crime. He promises to alter the current death penalty statute, which he blames for the failure of the state to carry out executions, and has promised a strong effort against drugs.
 
Anxiety After Growth
To solve the problem that has outraged voters more than any other, Mr. Courter has offered a plan to deregulate the automobile insurance industry and allow competition to cut high premiums.
''New Jersey doesn't have bad drivers,'' Mr. Courter said repeatedly. ''It has bad laws.'' Despite a general satisfaction among voters with growth and Republican leadership in the last decade, the problems that have accompanied economic boom have created anxiety.
In the last eight years, local property taxes have soared, and as more cars bumped into each other, the cost of automobile insurance has jumped. Increasingly, the desire to preserve virgin stretches of green land and shoreline have collided with centuries-old traditions of home rule that let towns and cities grow as they wished.
Polls by the Eagleton Institute showed that 40 percent of the people who drive to work in New Jersey have had to change their schedules to avoid congestion. The polls found that a majority of New Jerseyans now believe that there has been too much growth and development in the state. Mr. Florio has tried to tap those feelings.
Early in the campaign, Mr. Florio announced the election was about ''clean water,'' a phrase that became an emblem for protection of air, water, beaches and open spaces. He has said he would appoint an environmental prosecutor to make sure polluters were brought to justice. And he has called for a crackdown on the automobile insurance companies, saying the industry needs more regulation, not less.
 
Troubled Courter Campaign
Recent polls have shown Mr. Florio leading Mr. Courter by large margins. The latest poll, released today by the Eagleton Institute, showed Mr. Florio with a 24 percentage point lead over his opponent. The poll was conducted by telephone with 1,000 people during a five-day period ending last Thursday. It had a margin of error of plus or minus 4 percentage points.
In part, Mr. Courter's campaign has been troubled, both Democrats and Republicans agree, by an inablility for him to get his growth and small government message across to the voters. Through the late summer and early fall, he was forced to spend too much of his time explaining his positions on abortion and homosexuals.
Though Mr. Courter was a strong supporter of anti-abortion legislation in Congress, he announced shortly after the Webster decision was handed down by the United States Supreme Court last summer that as governor, he would not impose his opinions on New Jersey.
With polls showing that a large majority of the public opposes new restrictions on abortion in the state, Mr. Courter is believed to have lost votes both because of his anti-abortion record in Congress and because Democrats said he ''flip-flopped'' on the issue. Mr. Florio said he opposes any changes in the current laws.
In addition, in August Mr. Courter said he believed in limiting the rights of homosexuals to work as teachers, foster parents and camp counselors. Less than three weeks later, he changed his position.
The Courter campaign was also hurt, his campaign says, by the negative television advertisements against him. Since Mr. Courter started the campaign far less well known than Mr. Florio, he had to introduce himself to the voters while simultaneously trying to strike back.

HEADLINE: Doctor Who Billed Millions Is Cut by New York Medicaid

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK

 BODY:
At Dr. Giovanni del Gizzo's storefront office in East Harlem, patients began lining up as early as 5 A.M. They sat for hours in a crowded, smoky lobby for what was often only a 30- to 45-second consultation with the doctor, who almost invariably handed them a prescription for a battery of drugs worth $150 or more. The state, under Medicaid, picked up the entire tab.
''I'm making history here,'' the gaunt 61-year-old physician told a reporter one day last month as he sat at his desk, signing prescriptions, lecturing patients and sipping from a cup of chicken broth. He described himself as a ''miracle worker,'' capable of curing dozens of people an hour of problems with heroin, crack or alcohol.
New York State Medicaid officials have a different view. Saying that Dr. del Gizzo billed the state for unnecessary prescriptions and laboratory tests, they expelled him late last month from the program, which is intended to provide free medical care to the state's poorest citizens. 
In the 12-month period ending in August, Dr. del Gizzo ordered $3.9 million in prescriptions and other services -the largest annual billing by a doctor in New York in Medicaid's 23-year history. In the last two years, Dr. del Gizzo has received nearly $1 million in fees for his own services.
State officials, noting that New York's program is the biggest, said they believed this was the largest billing in the nation.
''This guy is the Dwight Gooden of Medicaid billers,'' James Durkin, the director of the state Department of Social Services office that investigates abuse of the Medicaid system, said in an interview before Dr. del Gizzo's expulsion. ''He has an arm that just won't quit.''
Each of the next two highest billers in the New York program ordered just over $2 million in services and prescriptions in 12 months. One has been expelled from the program and the other is under investigation.
State officials say many of Dr. del Gizzo's patients flocked to him not because they sought treatment but because they could profit by illegally selling the free tranquilizers, antidepressants and inhalators that he ordered for them. Others were said to be addicts who simply used the prescription drugs to amplify the effect of illegal drugs.
 
Assembly-Line Treatment
Officials emphasize that most doctors serving Medicaid patients are conscientious and struggle under a system that pays them as little as $11 per visit. But those like Dr. del Gizzo who treat patients in assembly-line fashion can bill hundreds of thousands of dollars for doing relatively little, they said.
Later this month, the state will impose new restrictions to curb visits to multiple doctors under Medicaid. But these limits have drawn stern criticism from health-care advocacy groups. They contend that the rules may punish the great majority of legitimate Medicaid recipients, while cases like Dr. del Gizzo's show that the state can already determine who is abusing the system.
The procedure under which Dr. del Gizzo was expelled dragged on for more than a year and came to a close only after he used numerous appeals.
Officials say that the delay in expelling him illustrates how difficult it can be to force out a doctor even after evidence of subtantial abuse has been gathered.
Medicaid, which is available in all 50 states, is paid for by a combination of Federal, state and local funds. In New York, which spends 20 percent of the nation's Medicaid funds, the program has an $11 billion yearly budget and serves 2.3 million people.
The state estimates the annual cost of such abuse at $150 million, but some private watchdog groups say it is much higher. In some cases, officials have been successful in compelling doctors to reimburse the system or imposing liens to recover money. But, investigators say, there are hundreds of other unscrupulous operators to take the place of those expelled.
It is not clear whether Dr. del Gizzo will face criminal or disciplinary charges. The state's file on his practice, which includes reports by undercover investigators of coercion for unnecessary services and a peer-review finding that his practice was both ''abusive'' and ''dangerous,'' has been referred to the special state prosecutor for Medicaid fraud and to the State Health Department panel that can revoke medical licenses. But officials in both agencies would not comment on whether any actions were being contemplated.
Dr. del Gizzo's office is on the ground floor of a three-story white-brick building at 23 East 115th Street in Harlem. Also on the block are vacant lots, a liquor store and a small grocery.
What the state claims was fraud, Dr. del Gizzo described as efficient treatment. During an interview before his expulsion, conducted while he saw patients and dispensed prescriptions, he vigorously denied all charges that he dispensed drugs for anything other than legitimate medical care.
''I see literally hundreds of people a week,'' explained the doctor, who came to work that day in checkered slacks and a yellow sweater.
''Some cases take 30 seconds, some, of course, a little longer,'' he said. ''I have so much work to do here, such a volume of cases. Drugs and alcohol we get here. We get everything. We get AIDS, we get homosexuals, we get transvestites. We get pneumonia, we get gall bladders. I am telling you, we get everything.''
 
Dirty Tile Floors
Dr. del Gizzo said he was conducting a ''major experiment'' in drug and alcohol treatment and expressed no objection when a reporter asked to watch him at work.
Based on per-visit rates established under the Medicaid program, the state paid Dr. del Gizzo $512,318 last year and $435,826 before he was expelled this year, according to Department of Social Service records. Prescriptions, sonograms and blood tests ran the cost of many patients' visits into the hundreds of dollars.
Dr. del Gizzo's office, with its dirty tile floors and artificial-wood paneling, was crammed with people. The waiting room was enveloped in a haze of cigarette smoke and a din of complaining.
''Hurry it up in there,'' one patient shouted through a small plastic window next to the locked door leading to the doctor's cubicle. At 2 P.M., a posted cardboard sign indicated that there were still 89 people waiting to get in.
A typical exchange occurred between the doctor and John Judson, 32, who said he was unemployed and had come in because of problems with alcohol and a variety of pains.
''So?'' asked Dr. del Gizzo. ''You are doing better? You are not drinking?''
''Oh yes, doctor,'' said Mr. Judson. ''Thanks to you.'' ''Your life is better than before?'' ''Yes.'' With that, Dr. del Gizzo signed a form. On it were two-week to one-month prescriptions for Buspar, a tranquilizer; Zantac, an ulcer medication; Elavil, an anti-depressant; Proventil, an inhaler used to quell asthmatic symptoms; Feldene, an anti-inflammatory drug that eases back pain, and Lotrimin, a cream for rashes. Mr. Judson left, and another patient quickly stepped in.
Whatever the case, the treatment appeared to be about the same. The doctor, who received a medical degree in 1951 from the University of Naples in Italy, seemed to give everybody a brief lecture on the dangers of drugs or drinking, and then he signed a prescription.
The same drugs showed up over and over on the prescription forms. Some were mood-altering anti-depressants, some were for ulcers or asthma or stomach irritations.
Ninety-four percent of prescriptions Dr. del Gizzo wrote last year were for pharmaceuticals on the Department of Social Services' list of ''abused prescription drugs.'' These include drugs that can easily be sold on the street or can provide high revenue for pharmacies that buy them back on the black market.
A three-month supply of the ulcer medication Zantac, for instance, is worth $115.56 when reimbursed under Medicaid. On the black market, however, it can be purchased for as little as $5, said John P. Wrafter, director of the bureau of provider audit at the State Department of Social Services.
Two of the three pharmacies that filled the highest volume of Dr. del Gizzo's prescriptions were expelled from the Medicaid program earlier this year after undercover investigators witnessed black-market purchases inside or near the stores, Mr. Durkin said.
One, the Lenox-SSim Pharmacy at 184 Lenox Avenue, closed. The other, Nino Drugs, at 77 East 115th Street, obtained a temporary injunction but is now being sent a final expulsion order by a state judge.
The doctor who randomly reviewed 10 of Dr. del Gizzo's cases for the Department of Social Services described his prescriptions as ''a polypharmaceutical flood without adequate justification,'' and said the files showed ''excessive visits'' by patients with little indication of their problems.
''The most serious issues of quality of care arise in this practice because of repetitive prescription of controlled substances for long periods of time to patients with a track record of substance abuse,'' said the report, by Dr. Robert Matz, medical director at North Central Bronx Hospital.
Dr. del Gizzo was informed in June 1988 that he was to be expelled from Medicaid. But he remained in practice while his case was under appeal.
The appeals ended in a decision to expel him as of Oct. 26. Technically, he is still entitled to write prescriptions under the program until Friday, but he would receive no payment for his services.
Last week, as he shut his doors, Dr. del Gizzo posted a notice saying he had been ''closed illegally by Medicaid'' and urging former patients to call the Governor to protest.
''You don't understand,'' the doctor told an investigator one day in September. ''Nine out of 10 patients in here, I cure.''
''Yeah?'' the inspector snapped back. ''What do you cure them of?''

HEADLINE: 'Revisionist' Influence Seen in Japan Talks

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5

 BODY:
Even though Carla A. Hills, the United States Trade Representative, finds the idea of managed trade repugnant, she has a number of outside advisers, principally from the business community, who argue that the closed nature of Japan's economy thwarts classical free-trade solutions for correcting trade imbalances.
Thus, these advisers say, governments have little choice but to intervene more in global commerce.
These people are among a wide-ranging group of students of the Japanese economy who call themselves ''revisionists'' because their recommendations for dealing with Japan depart from traditional free-trade remedies.
While Mrs. Hills believes that such intervention ''sells our industry short by putting a ceiling on what we can sell'' the views of the revisionists are likely to play a prominent role as talks about lowering Japan's trade barriers enter a second round Monday and Tuesday. 
Many of them are members of the Advisory Committee for Trade Policy and Negotiations, a group organized to advise the trade representative on policy matters. The revisionists, include economists from the Harvard Business School, the Massachussets Institute of Technology and the University of California at Berkeley, analysts including James Fallows and Karel van Wolferen, and some business leaders.
 
Blueprint by March
It was the revisionists who were, in large part, responsible for the effort to deal with some of the basic problems in trading with Japan. This week's talks follow those initiated by the United States last summer on the so-called structural impediments.
No major breakthrough is expected this week, but American trade officials said they will ask Japan to deliver a blueprint by next March describing how it intends to get rid of the barriers.
The barriers include a rigid distribution system that hurts Japanese consumers by making prices for Japanese goods 20 and 30 percent higher than they are, say, in New York. In addition, weak antitrust enforcement permits bid rigging, market allocation, group boycotts and other anticompetitive practices that work to exclude foreigners from the Japanese market.
In agreeing to take up the agenda, Tokyo insisted, and the United States agreed, that the talks focus as well on American structural barriers, like the high rate of consumption, high cost of capital and low savings, all of which work to weaken American exports and increase imports.
In the discussions, the revisionists' hand will be strengthened by statistics that suggest that trade balances do not adjust to economic variables in Japan the way they do elsewhere.
While greater government management of trade is resisted by the Bush Administration, which prefers free-market solutions, the revisionists' diagnosis of the trade problem has already had a substantial influence on the dialogue with Japan.
Their hand is strengthened by statistics. For example, despite the virtual halving of the dollar's value against the yen since 1985, the deficit with Japan has remained stuck at more than $50 billion. During that time, the American trade deficit with most other countries has declined.
A deficit with the European Community of $26.4 billion in 1986 has been wiped out, and the United States is even running a small surplus -$108.5 million - with Europe so far this year.
''The old ways of looking at the trade deficit with Japan just haven't worked, and we have to look at some other things. We have to be pragmatic and practical about this,'' said Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana, the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee's trade subcommittee.
 
'A Lousy Process'
He called the current round of talks ''the most important trade negotiations that the U.S. has ever entered into'' and warned that if they do not achieve results by next summer, he will introduce legislation aimed at sanctions. ''I am confident this legislation will pass Congress,'' he said.
But while the revisionists have complained for years of Japanese trade protection, some of them label the currents talks a diversion.
''We have a lousy process that goes nowhere,''said Rudiger Dornbush, a professor at M.I.T. ''The Japanese are offended when we make our demands. So then we retreat, and life goes on as before. The fact is that Japan remains a very closed economy, and we're getting nowhere.''
Clyde V. Prestowitz Jr., a Commerce Department official in the early 1980's who was among the first to note the extensiveness of Japanese trade barriers, commented: ''It's hopeless to try to change the Japanese in a reasonable period of time.''
Mr. Dornbush, Mr. Prestowitz and other revisionists are promoting some form of managed trade.
Under the Dornbush solution, the Japanese would agree to raise imports of manufactures by 15 percent a year over 10 years. If the target was not met, there would be an automatic tariff on Japanese exports to the United States.
Mrs. Hills said the United States has a ''holistic approach'' for dealing with Japan through the structural barriers initiative, sectoral negotiations to open up markets for American supercomputers, lumber and satellites, and the Uruguay Round of multilateral trade negotiations under which Japan and more than 100 other countries are discussing liberalizing trade.

HEADLINE: Swapo Leader Winds Up Election Campaign

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GOBABIS, Namibia, Nov. 5

 BODY:
On the red-dirt outskirts of this arid cattle town, Sam Nujoma, the leader of the South-West Africa People's Organization, offered the voters his version of the territory's pending transition from colonialism to independence.
As Mr. Nujoma told it, his organization, popularly called Swapo, had forced South Africa, through 23 years of unrelenting guerrilla war, to accept an independence plan for Namibia under United Nations auspices.
He promised a crowd of about 1,500 supporters that his Government would not need to depend economically on South Africa, that it would promote land redistribution but not take property without adequate compensation and that Swapo had educated a cadre of engineers, teachers, doctors and scientists in exile who could run the country once it gained independence. 
It was Mr. Nujoma's last scheduled appearance in an campaign that ends Tuesday with elections to choose a constituent assembly that will draft a constitution before Namibia becomes independent next year.
 
Majority for Swapo Expected
Swapo is expected to win a majority of the ballots cast by 700,000 registered voters, but it is uncertain whether it will get the two-thirds necessary to let it to impose its own constitution.
As with political campaigns elsewhere, some of Mr. Nujoma's assertions would be challenged by the other parties, not to mention the South African authorities.
Swapo's guerrillas, who operated from bases in Angola, never established a permanent foothold in Namibia because of interdiction by the South African-led security forces. And the political settlement that linked Namibian independence to the withdrawal of Cuban forces from Angola, where they have been supporting a pro-Soviet Government against a South African-supported insurgency, was reached last December by Angola, Cuba and South Africa with the mediation of the United States. Swapo was not given a voice in the settlement.
''Swapo waged the struggle for the last 23 years against the Boers,'' Mr. Nujoma said, referring to the Afrikaners, South Africa's dominant white ethnic group. ''Swapo stood firm and said 435 is the only solution to bring about peace in this country,''
 
Drew World Attention
Resolution 435 is the document endorsed by the United Nations Security Council spelling out the terms for Namibian independence.
Mr. Nujoma took credit for mobilizing world opinion against South Africa's occupation of Namibia and paid emotional tribute to the United Nations Transitional Assistance Group for its role in supervising the transition.
Mr. Nujoma's overwhelmingly black audience was decked out in the blue, red and green colors of Swapo, and many wore its campaign badges.
With loyalties dividing largely along ethnic lines - Swapo's roots lie in the Ovambo majority - there seem to be remarkably few undecided voters as the campaign winds down.
 
Controversy Over Broadcasts
Controversies over Swapo's alleged mistreatment of dissidents in exile and ill-fated infiltration of guerrillas into the country in April were overtaken by a propaganda windfall last week.
South Africa put its security forces in the region on the alert as Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha accused Swapo of infiltrating hundreds more insurgents into northern Namibia.
Mr. Botha cited the interception of radio messages he said had been broadcast by United Nations posts monitoring the border area. The United Nations group rejected the messages as forgeries, and Mr. Botha later conceded that there was no evidence to show that they were genuine.
Mr. Botha flew to Windhoek yesterday to discuss the matter with the United Nations representative and South Africa's Administrator General.

HEADLINE: Legislation On Buyouts Is Unlikely

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5

 BODY:
After expressing intense interest early this year in regulating leveraged buyouts and their financial underpinning, high-risk, high-yield ''junk bonds,'' Congress's attention has waned. The lawmakers lost enthusiasm in part because the market for such transactions has weakened, but for political reasons as well.
Within the Administration, concern about the economic and social costs of rapidly growing corporate debt has been outweighed by the antipathy of top officials toward Government regulation of the markets. Without a change of heart in the Administration, Congress seems unlikely to move further.
In a leveraged buyout, the hottest ticket on Wall Street through most of the 1980's, a group of investors using borrowed money, generally acquired by issuing high-yielding ''junk bonds'' to investors, buys the controlling stock of a company, often in cooperation with its top managers. 
Early this year, during a flurry of hearings by several Congressional committees, one economist after another warned that such transactions threatened to unbalance the nation's corporate structure and could lead to a raft of bankruptcies in the event of a recession.
 
'Significant Dangers' Cited
For example, Henry Kaufman, the Wall Street economist and consultant whose views are valued on Capitol Hill, told one committee that leveraged buyouts posed ''significant dangers to the economic and financial well-being of this country.''
The legislators became concerned in part because they feared that the companies involved might be unable to make debt payments in a recession or a business slump. They also worried that fear of being taken over would cause managers to focus only on short-term profits and that, in the event of a buyout, businesses would close or relocate and constituents' jobs would be lost.
But in the end, Congress failed to act this year, largely for these reasons:
* Many lawmakers believe the markets are correcting the problems on their own, as several buyout deals have faltered since spring and investments in junk bonds have dwindled.
* Despite a nearly universal view that the tax code unfairly rewards borrowing and penalizes investments in stock, neither the legislators nor their expert staffs could devise a correction that would not cause new and probably more serious problems.
* Lawmakers were cowed by the possibility that the stock market would plunge and that they would be blamed as they were in 1987, when approval by the House Ways and Means Committee, without debate, of a measure that would have limited some tax advantages of leveraged buyouts was seen by some as a reason for the October market crash.
* Buyout deal makers lobbied heavily against further regulation and contributed generously to political campaigns, while no forceful lobby arose on the other side.
* The most influential legislators became absorbed with other issues, including capital gains taxes, air pollution and public disclosure of takeover deals. Elsewhere in the capital, the Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating who issues, buys and defaults on junk bonds, officials said, but stiff new regulations do not seem to be in the offing.
The new S.E.C. chairman, Richard C. Breeden, has declined to take a strong position on the question of leveraged buyouts. And Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, who has expressed concern in the past about leveraged buyouts, told a Senate subcommittee recently that he expected them to become ''a thing of the past.'' He urged Congress to ''see what the market has produced as a cure'' before taking action.
 
'I Have Not Given Up'
Representative Bill Gradison of Ohio, a senior Republican on the Ways and Means Committee, reflected the view of most lawmakers. ''We won't move in this area without active involvement by the Administration,'' he said.
Some strong opponents of leveraged buyouts are determined to press their case again next year. ''I have not given up,'' said Representative Byron L. Dorgan, a North Dakota Democrat. ''This is a very troublesome problem, and eventually we're going to have to deal with it.''
But Mr. Dorgan agreed that he was unlikely to succeed as long as the Bush Administration was so adamantly opposed to action in this area.
Congress did take some minor steps this year, none of which is likely to have a significant effect on leveraged buyouts. The law to rescue failed savings and loan institutions prohibits such institutions from investing in junk bonds. The overall budget bill now before a House-Senate conference, would limit interest deductions for a particular kind of junk bond, similar to a zero-coupon bond.
In addition, the House last week passed a bill that would require the Secretary of Transportation to reject any airline buyout that he found to be contrary to the public interest because it would affect safety, hinder competition, cost jobs or result in foreign control of the carrier.
 
Modest Measures Pending
A similar measure has been approved by a Senate committee. But Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner has opposed the legislation, and President Bush might veto it. Even if it becomes law, experts believe the measure would have little effect, given Mr. Skinner's opposition.
Other modest measures that may be enacted this year would restrict certain pension money from being invested in junk bonds and limit leveraged buyout companies from collecting refunds of back taxes because of operating losses resulting from some debt payments.
Corporate restructuring in general and leveraged buyouts in particular have shaken American business in recent years. According to the Treasury, the value of debt-financed takeovers was $160 billion from 1983 to 1988, 15 times their value in the previous five years. Although Congress periodically debated the trend, it was not until the biggest leveraged buyout ever, the $25 billion RJR Nabisco Inc. deal at the start of this year, that prominent lawmakers expressed a determination to act.
 
'Congress Went Galloping'
''After RJR Nabisco, Congress went galloping,'' said Bartlett Naylor, a former staff assistant on the Senate Banking Committee and now a senior analyst at the Investor Responsibility Research Center. ''Congress went galloping. That one seemed to be an awful expression of greed.'' For example, Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, the firm that put together the deal to buy RJR Nabisco, made $75 million in fees on the deal, almost as much as its stake in the investment pool that bought the company.
Early this year, Jim Wright, then Speaker of the House, called together a half dozen of the most influential House committee chairmen and urged them to begin work on legislation to limit leveraged buyouts and the junk bonds that finance them.
At first, the new Bush Administration did not discourage the lawmakers. At a news conference a week before his inauguration, Mr. Bush suggested that changes in the tax laws governing such deals might be needed, and Mr. Brady worried that too much of the country's talent and resources were wasted on ''financial engineering.''
Congress began work on two fronts, taxes and regulation.
 
Twice-Taxed Dividends
On taxes, politicians and academic experts agree that the law's favorable treatment of debt and unfavorable treatment of equity are engines that propel leveraged buyouts and ought to be corrected.
Companies financed with borrowed money can deduct the interest payments they make to bondholders and other creditors. But companies financed with equity, or stock, cannot deduct their dividend payments. The dividends are, in effect, taxed twice: once when they are counted in the profits on which corporate taxes are based and again when they are counted as income to stockholders.
''From a tax-policy standpoint, anyone would say that the right policy is to have a level playing field for debt and equity,'' said Robert J. Leonard, chief counsel of the Ways and Means Committee and one of the top tax experts among Congressional staff members.
There were large obstacles, however, to policies that sought to correct the problem.
Taxing debt would put American investors at a serious competitive disadvantage with those from abroad, where interest payments are generally deductible. Moreover, since most corporate borrowing is an essential business expense unrelated to takeovers, a change in the tax law to limit junk bonds would require different treatment for different forms of debt. ''We could not find a way to attack the cancer cells without damaging the healthy ones,'' a Congressional tax specialist said.
 
No Political Constituency
On the other hand, allowing deductions for dividend payments could cost the Treasury as much as $50 billion a year in lost revenue, a sum the Government cannot afford. Moreover, there is hardly a political constituency for such a move. Most corporate executives oppose dividend deductions, believing they would only increase pressure on them to pay higher dividends and not allow the untaxed profits to be used for new investment.
As for increased regulation, Representative Edward J. Markey, Democrat of Massachusetts and chairman of the Energy and Commerce Committee's finance subcommittee, has been working most of the year on legislation to require more public disclosure about takeover deals and to guarantee that buyers have their financing in order before a tender offer is made.
But when Washington's attention to takeovers began to flag, Mr. Markey turned his primary focus to other legislation dealing with regulation of the stock and commodity markets that he thought more likely to become law. No bill on buyouts has been introduced.
And the Bush Administration has become increasingly hostile to Congressional action in this area. Earlier this year, Transportation Secretary Skinner said he wanted the authority to review takeovers in the airline industry to make certain the buyers' heavy debts would not affect the safety of air travel. Recently, however, the Secretary has opposed such legislation.

LENGTH: 952 words

HEADLINE: Paper Companies Contemplate Hard Times

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
While the Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation contemplates a $3.1 billion takeover bid from the Georgia Pacific Corporation, other paper- products companies are wrestling with the question of whether, given the downturn expected in the industry during the next year, this is a good time to acquire a paper company.
Industry analysts, who generally predict that growing capacity will outstrip demand within the next year, forecast that paper prices will tumble in the next two years, making paper companies less expensive to buy. They also predict that in an industry where few companies have more than a 15 to 20 percent market share in any product, a weakening of the market will compel producers to achieve economies of scale through acquisition.
 
Few Predictions
For the moment, at least, there are few predictions about who would acquire whom. But several analysts contend that the largest players in the industry - International Paper, Kimberly-Clark, Scott Paper and James River, for example - are the most likely to take on acquisitions to solidify their positions in the market. 
The difficulty in predicting acquisition targets, analysts say, stems from the high profitability of nearly all the players in the industry during the last two years. Some, however, consider likely targets to be those whose value is tied more to papermaking machinery than to the timber they own: Champion International, Boise Cascade, Temple-Inland, Union Camp, and Chesapeake, for example.
The bid last week by Georgia Pacific to acquire Great Northern, the nation's ninth-largest producer of paper products, has shattered the unofficial rules of cordiality that have for years governed takeovers in the industry. American paper companies have tended to acquire their competitors only to act as a white knight, thwarting a hostile bid.
Many analysts now see the rules changing dramatically, suggesting the emergence of paper and forest products companies like Weyerhaeuser, Abitibi-Price, and International Paper as potential bidders for Great Northern. Jefferson Smurfit, and Champion International are also mentioned.
 
Not If, but When
''I think there will be further consolidation in the industry,'' said Robert Schneider, a paper industry analyst with Duff & Phelps Inc. in Chicago. ''It's not a question of if, but of when and who.''
The outlook for the next few years seems bleak after the giddy growth in profitability that characterized the last two years. Paper demand has outstripped supply, causing prices in the industry to increase. Industry earnings, also fueled by the strong exports brought on by a weaker dollar, soared to a record $8.1 billion last year, a 45 percent increase from 1987.
But the growth rate is slackening, with some analysts predicting that industry earnings will increase only 5 percent this year, to $8.5 billion. And analysts predict that earnings will decline 20 percent next year, to $6.8 billion, and another 25 percent in 1991, to $5.1 billion.
At the same time, the industry spent heavily on new equipment, causing capacity to rise dramatically. The industry, which raised capacity by 1.6 percent in 1985, will add nearly 3 percent to capacity this year. All of that comes at a time when demand has grown at only better than half that percentage.
''The amount of capacity that will be added in the period between 1987 and 1991 will be the greatest amount ever in the United States,'' said Sherman Choa, an analyst with Salomon Brothers. ''Capacity will increase by 3.7 percent in 1991, which means that the industry is adding capacity faster than likely demand growth.''
 
Operating Rates Down
Operating rates - considered by many to be the key barometer of the industry's health-have dropped below 93 percent, which analysts describe as evidence that a buyer's market is emerging. According to the American Paper Institute, operating rates in the nation's paper mills are now about 92 percent, down from an average 95 percent last year.
''And looking forward into next year, we look for operating rates to decline more,'' Mr. Choa said. ''That means that prices will drop, and the seller's market we've seen over the last few years will come to an end.''
Paper company executives, while they foresee more difficult times, say they will not be particularly severe. ''We expect slower growth, but I don't expect that we'll fall off a cliff,'' said Burnell R. Roberts, chairman of the Mead Corporation, the nation's sixth-largest paper producer. ''Of course, capacity additions will have an impact.''
Many paper company executives are beginning to see themselves as potential acquisition targets. Several industry officials, who asked not to be identified, said the bid by Georgia Pacific signaled a more aggressive acquisition posture in the industry.
The signs of weakness in some products are becoming clear. Prices of newsprint have fallen precipitously, to $650 a metric ton, down 20 percent from a year ago. A projected addition of two million tons of capacity scheduled for next year, about 12 percent, will further erode prices, analysts say.
No one company controls a dominant position in any of the product areas. But a combination of Great Northern and Georgia Pacific would make the combined company the largest producer of linerboard and a rival to International Paper in uncoated papers.
''Many other companies will have to be concerned about new and vigorous competition in market pulp, linerboard and uncoated paper,'' said Gary Palmero, an industry analyst at Oppenheimer & Company. ''In downturns, that creates competitive pressure. It has existed before, but this time I think the response of the companies will be different.''

HEADLINE: Victory Gratifies Colorado

BYLINE: By MALCOLM MORAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOULDER, Colo., Nov. 5

 BODY:
The goal posts at Folsom Field had been adjusted so they would collapse under the weight of delirium. The team had been working toward this moment for years, since Bill McCartney became the coach in 1982 after the brief and economically chaotic Chuck Fairbanks era came to a close.
But when the moment arrived Saturday afternoon, after Nebraska's desperation last-second heave had fallen to the ground in the end zone, no one could have been prepared fully for what would happen next.
In another place, at another time, the outpouring of affection symbolized by the sudden disappearance of two goal posts would be little more than the climax of a memorable afternoon. 
 
Gratifying Sight for Team
But here, in a community that not long ago had an adversarial relationship with its football team as a result of the repeated legal problems of some of its members, on a campus where some players once preferred to play on the road, the sight of thousands of fans on the field, and the sounds of many still shouting hours later, completed a transformation in the perception of a team by its town.
''I think they can be nothing but proud of us now,'' said J. J. Flannigan, the University of Colorado's senior tailback.
Flannigan scored two touchdowns in the 27-21 victory, which brought the Buffaloes closer to a Big Eight Conference championship and the anticipated Orange Bowl matchup against Notre Dame.
In March 1988, a report by the campus police declared that dormitory residents on the Colorado campus feared that ''the football players would now be free to intimidate and assault them with no fear of legal repercussions.'' Incidents of vandalism, assault and robbery had disrupted life on the campus.
 
Older Players Take Charge
Flannigan had been one of the players involved in an incident; on Saturday, after each carry, thousands shouted his name in celebration.
In a meeting before the season, senior members of the team decided that the repeated incidents reflected a lack of discipline that also extended to practices and games. Selfishness became a team issue. Demands were made. Challenges were issued. Players were asked if they would be willing to sacrifice personal statistics if the result led to a greater good.
''That's what we've been saying all year,'' said Bill Coleman, a senior offensive tackle. ''It's no longer, 'If I have a good game, maybe I can be all-Big 8 or I can be all-American.' Now it's 'I have to have a good game if we are going to win.' ''
''We pulled together,'' Flannigan added. ''We said, 'No more.' There are harsh punishments. The first time something happens, you're out for a game. If it's your second time, you're off the team.''
 
Putting Words Into Practice
Flannigan's first touchdown was perhaps the play that best illustrated the team concept. It came on the third Colorado possession of the game, after an early Nebraska interception and a 51-yard screen pass to Bryan Carpenter shocked the crowd on the first Husker play from scrimmage.
From the Colorado 30, Darian Hagan, the sophomore quarterback, started an option run to the left, exploited the opening between two defenders, and turned upfield. As he reached the Nebraska 40, after a 30-yard gain, a Husker defender was closing in. Flannigan stayed just behind his teammate.
''You have to stay with him all the time,'' Flannigan said. ''He saw me one time and didn't pitch it. So I knew he was going to pitch it any time.''
In full stride, Hagan lateraled the ball to his left toward Flannigan, who went up the sideline for a 70-yard touchdown. Flannigan was credited with all 70 yards under the statistical guidelines, but everyone knew who had created the play.
Now the Buffaloes are in position to win their first outright conference championship since 1961. And Notre Dame, which tied a school record with its 21st consecutive victory by defeating Navy, 41-0, could combine with Colorado to create the fourth bowl-game matchup of undefeated, untied teams in four seasons.

LENGTH: 1694 words

HEADLINE: Washington at Work;
2-Summit Plan Reflects the Bush Style of Diplomacy: Intense and Personal

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5

 BODY:
One of President Bush's favorite expressions is a leftover bit of slang from the 1960's. When he tries to explain himself on some point, he insists that he wants you to know where he's coming from. And, in turn, he wants to know where you're coming from.
The phrase has now entered the official argot of the White House. When Administration officials explain the ''Big Summit'' and ''Little Summit'' with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union, they say Mr. Bush wanted a preliminary session of ''information without protocol.''
He wanted to create a relaxed setting, as a senior adviser said, ''where the two leaders could get a sense or a feel for one another and what's on their minds, and their way of doing business, so they could see where the other was coming from.'' 
Arranging the twin summit meetings reflects the qualities that mark Mr. Bush's foreign policy. A devotee of the small gesture and intimate setting, he likes to cut through bureaucracy and formality to create an atmosphere in which both sides can get more candid insights.
Mr. Bush, his advisers say, wants to ask Mr. Gorbachev questions like: ''Where do you think things are going, what are your plans down the road, what are the rough spots, what is your future?'' But that is the atmosphere he prefers in making policy, too - bypassing the screening process of lower-level officials and holding information among a tight group. It can help him, as it did in the hostage crisis last summer, and it can hurt him, as it did in the failed Panama coup last month.
''He likes to talk to people in the least constrained environment possible, because he knows that the same words in a different setting can have a different impact,'' said Mr. Bush's chief of staff, John H. Sununu, who was at Camp David Saturday with Mr. Bush planning the December session in the Mediterranean.
Mr. Bush has faith in his ability to look someone in the eye and judge things ''first hand.'' He has a spymaster's passion for secrecy and keeping information among a tight group of aides, endowing diplomatic initiatives and foreign policy crises with the hide-and-seek aura of a C.I.A. operation.
In a radio interview with ABC News broadcast Saturday, Mr. Bush was asked what was the most satisfying accomplishment of his 10 months in office. The former Director of Central Intelligence said keeping the news of the ''Little Summit'' confidential nearly four months ''brought some satisfaction to me.''
 
Why the Summit Secrecy
He hates unapproved disclosures and loves to spring stories on an unsuspecting press corps. He has made it a cardinal rule that his Administration not conduct ''diplomacy on the front page.'' He insisted on secrecy about the summit arrangements because he did not want to be faulted if it fell through and the Soviets had said the Americans could never keep such a negotiation secret for any length of time.
''I think there may have been a little chiding from the Soviets that 'You can't keep this a secret, America can never do that,' '' said Marlin Fitzwater, the Presidential press secretary, one of a handful of aides who knew about the plan. It was considered miraculous here that the secrecy held for so long. Mr. Bush was furious when someone in the Administration leaked the story to The Washington Post the day before the announcement.
 
'Discipline and Steel Will'
Mr. Fitzwater said Mr. Bush shrugged off suggestions that, given his initiative to get to know Mr. Gorbachev better, he was taking unnecessary heat for timidity toward cataclysmic changes in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. ''We could have said back in July that we were getting ready to do something, and that probably would have headed off the timid stuff,'' Mr. Fitzwater said. ''But the President has this kind of discipline and steel will to say, 'I know what I'm doing. Let them throw the rocks at me.' ''
But as a National Security Council review indicated after the embarrassing failed Panamanian coup, the style on foreign affairs that Mr. Bush may have developed in his year at the C.I.A. under Gerald R. Ford could be a handicap in the Oval Office.
He compartmentalizes information, taking it from many directions but sharing it with few people. He likes unfiltered information straight from the field instead of having the contradictions ironed out by lower-level specialists. Administration officials said the most extensive use ever had been made of specially designed communciations networks, put in place by the National Security Agency, that allow instant access to intelligence reporting.
''He's turned the Oval Office into 'Mission Impossible,' '' said a top Republican official with close ties to the White House. ''
In many ways, the handling of the summit plan bore all the earmarks of a classic intelligence operation, allowing reporters and the public to draw misleading and incorrect conclusions based on hints and statements that were deliberately ambiguous.
In essense, Mr. Bush and his advisers created a fog of public uncertainty about the course of United States-Soviet relations when there was in fact private certainty.
Even as senior Administration officials like Vice President Dan Quayle and Robert M. Gates, the deputy national security adviser, were publicly suggesting that Mr. Gorbachev's chances of succeeding were dim, and giving the impression that there was division over how to deal with the Soviet Union - in fact, there was a behind-the-scenes unanimity on a policy moving in a clear and opposite direction.
 
Parties, Picnics and the Mets
If the President's penchant for secrecy in foreign policy was shaped by his time at the C.I.A., his penchant for doing business in informal settings was influenced by his two years at the United Nations.
In the early 1970's when he was the United States representative at the United Nations, Mr. Bush entertained diplomats extensively with his wife, Barbara - cocktail parties in their apartment in the Waldorf, picnics at the compound in Connecticut, expeditions of bewildered diplomats who had never seen American baseball to night games at Shea Stadium to watch the Mets, in which his uncle, Herbert Walker, owned a part interest.
Mr. Bush said as he left the United Nations post that he had learned the lesson that it is essential to look at a problem from the opponent's point of view. ''A sympathetic understanding,'' he said, ''is a very important part of the process of establishing a foreign policy.''
Mr. Fitzwater said that Mr. Bush ''learned to exploit the social aspect of his job as U.N. Ambassador so he could open up a lot of different lines of communication and channels of information.''
 
Intensely Personal Diplomacy
The press secretary said Mr. Bush maintained the same method - intensely personal diplomacy - as Vice President, traveling extensively abroad and meeting as many officials in each country as he could, heads of state to foreign ministers to ambassadors to defense ministers.
Mr. Bush ''became a separate conduit,'' Mr. Fitzwater said, in addition to the State Department, which heads of state for other governments could use ''to get messages to President Reagan.''
''As President, Mr. Bush essentially conducts himself on foreign affairs in the same way in terms of maintaining these kinds of personal channels of communication and diplomacy,'' the adviser added. ''That's why he had 18 bilaterals as soon as he landed on his trip to Asia.''
President Bush turned etiquette topsy-turvy by calling world leaders, including Mr. Gorbachev, to talk about his new position; it was customary to wait until leaders called him.
He made an intense round of personal calls in the hostage crisis of the summer, to world leaders and contacts from his days at the United Nations and as Vice President. Aides say he still picks up the phone to make more casual calls. Last week, he called Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto of Pakistan to congratulate her on winning a vote of confidence.
 
Mubarak Saw the Orioles
He has made outings like the one to the Mets a hallmark of his Presidency. He took President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt to a Baltimore Orioles game, where he was announced as a special guest to the bemusement of the sports fans. He took Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel to the Air and Space Museum to see the movie ''To Fly.''
As weekend guests at his Kennebunkport, Me., home, he has entertained President Francois Mitterrand of France, Prime Minister Poul Schluter of Denmark and Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada.
''Whether he is taking Mubarak to the ball game or taking King Hussein down the river from Mount Vernon on a boat,'' Mr. Sununu said, ''each expedition is designed to create an atmosphere.'' Western leaders credited Mr. Bush's successful appearance at the Paris economic summit to the rapport the stiff and elegant Mr. Mitterrand forged at Kennebunkport with the informal Mr. Bush.
When Mr. Bush told his national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d last July in Paris that he wanted a conversation with Mr. Gorbachev without checklists or agendas, Mr. Scowcroft warned that it would be risky to meet without a structure or without formal results in the way of communiques or accords.
 
Some Have Reservations
Indeed, White House officials are still wary that in settings designed to promote cozy exchanges, the President could be predisposed to feel warm toward a leader who did not merit it. In the case of Mr. Gorbachev, who has a proclivity for surprises, Mr. Bush could be put on the defensive by an unexpected Soviet gambit designed to take advantage of the scheduling vacuum of an unstructured meeting.
But he was determined to do his diplomacy en famille, and he, Mr. Baker and Mr. Scowcroft devised the two-summit approach. So, even though those who know Mr. Gorbachev say he is all business and not the sort who likes to ''put his feet up,'' the two will have, on adjoining Soviet and United States battleships, ''A Mediterranean Moment.''
''It will be informal but not too informal,'' Mr. Fitzwater said. ''No shuffleboard or volleyball.''

GRAPHIC: Phot of Presidents Bush and Francois Mitterrand in May near Mr. Bush's weekend home in Kennebunkport, Me. (Reuters)
