HEADLINE: Jerome Robbins Is Resigning As Co-Director of City Ballet

BYLINE: By ANNA KISSELGOFF

 BODY:
Jerome Robbins, whose highly unusual and diverse works for the New York City Ballet sealed his reputation as one of the 20th century's great choreographers, will resign on Jan. 1 as co-director of the City Ballet to pursue projects in several fields, the company announced yesterday.
Nonetheless, Mr. Robbins said, ''I will be around for a couple of more seasons'' at the City Ballet, where he will soon begin rehearsing the dancers for a retrospective of the ballets he has created since 1944. The company will present a Robbins festival at the New York State Theater in the spring.
Mr. Robbins, who was 71 years old on Oct. 11, then plans to continue writing his memoirs and to develop his ideas for an autobiographical theater piece.
''It's important at my age to do other things,'' he said in New York just before leaving for the premiere yesterday of the Paris Opera Ballet's production of his 1970 ballet ''In the Night.'' ''I'm resigning from the New York City Ballet; I'm not retiring from the field.'' The choreographer spent last month in Paris, rehearsing the French dancers. 
 
Martins Alone at the Top
Mr. Robbins's resignation now leaves the City Ballet's other co-director, Peter Martins, for the first time with ultimate responsibility for the 41-year-old company's artistic policy. Lincoln Kirstein, the City Ballet's co-founder with George Balanchine, resigned as general director at the age of 82 on Sept. 12.
Mr. Robbins, in fact, has reduced his involvement with the City Ballet since the summer of 1988, when he began work on ''Jerome Robbins's Broadway.'' His resignation is thus not expected to have any immediate effect on the City Ballet's policies, although Mr. Martins's artistic control has obviously been consolidated.
Both Mr. Robbins and Mr. Martins - who is 43 and a former principal dancer in the company - were named co-directors with the joint title of balletmaster in chief shortly before Balanchine died on April 30, 1983. Mr. Martins, who joined the City Ballet in 1970, has essentially been in charge of day-to-day operations. Mr. Robbins's prestige as a choreographer and his continued creativity -he has choreographed nine new ballets since 1983 - allowed him to focus on his own works inside the company and more general policy.
The two men did not always see eye to eye on every issue: Mr. Robbins, for example, declined to create new works for the company's 1988 American Music Festival, which was conceived by Mr. Martins. But they generally worked in tandem and the excellence of the company's dancing has been maintained.
In commenting on Mr. Robbins's retirement, Mr. Martins said that the choreographer ''has played a monumental role in shaping the artistic esthetic of this company,'' and that ''we shall always welcome him back.''
 
The Strain of a Broadway Show
In April, Mr. Robbins cited the ''enormous toll'' of more than 23 weeks of rehearsals on ''Jerome Robbins's Broadway,'' the anthology of excerpts from musicals that he had directed or choreographed, and announced that he was taking a leave of absence from the City Ballet. The show opened in February, and Mr. Robbins continues to audition new cast members personally.
The choreographer has been associated with the City Ballet for 40 years. Balanchine invited him to join as a dancer and choreographer in 1949 and made him the company's associate director the same year.
Explaining why he chose to resign at this time, Mr. Robbins said in a statement: ''I joined the New York City Ballet in 1949 for a single purpose: To work for and with George Balanchine. I felt blessed by working in shared intimacy with Mr. Balanchine and thrilled to be part of the growth and development of the company.
''His death six years ago was traumatic to all of us and clearly signaled the end of an era. It was imperative to help the company deal with its loss, heal its wounds and find a directional movement without Mr. B's presence. I feel now that the transition has taken place, closing that period. The company is strong, dancing the repertory with ever extending artistry and with deep confidence and commitment. I relinquish my position with undiminished love for the superb dancers.''
Mr. Robbins said he was ''deeply grateful'' to the staff and to ''Lincoln Kirstein, of course, for everything.''
 
What Next? 'Europe Beckons'
In addition to the theater piece and his autobiography, Mr. Robbins said that ''Europe beckons with invitations to direct operas and stage ballets there,'' and that ''this does not preclude the possibility of my working with the New York City Ballet on new ballets in the future.''
Speaking more informally in an interview, Mr. Robbins said that directing any other company was of no interest to him.
''No,'' he declared emphatically when asked if he would consider becoming artistic director of American Ballet Theater. Mikhail Baryshnikov left that post in September.
As for the Paris Opera Ballet, where there are reports that Rudolf Nureyev might be replaced as artistic director, Mr. Robbins replied with a reference to the working conditions: ''I would only wish that on my worst enemy - to become director of the Paris Opera Ballet as it is now organized. And that has nothing to do with the dancers.''
More generally, he added: ''I have no great ambitions to babysit a board, temperamental dancers, feisty unions and economic pressures. I've seen many creative people sink under these burdens. I'm essentially a choreographer. That's my talent and I'd like to save my juices for that.''
 
No Desire for His Own Troupe
Mr. Robbins left the City Ballet between 1959 and 1969 to devote more time to Broadway, experimental theater and the only troupe he ever headed, Ballets: U.S.A. The group existed from 1958 to 1962, when it disbanded.
''I could have had a company of my own easily anytime,'' he said. ''But I felt New York City Ballet took care of all my problems and gave me advantages.''
The attraction was that ''with Mr. Balanchine, there was a concentration on dance'' as a whole rather than on ''personalized sectors or little kingdoms,'' as he felt had been the case at American Ballet Theater. Choreographers were concerned only with their own works there, he said. Mr. Robbins created his first ballet, ''Fancy Free,'' in 1944 while a dancer at Ballet Theater.
When he joined the City Ballet, Balanchine personally went out and bought masks for Mr. Robbins's first work for the company, ''The Guests.'' ''What was on the table was dancing, not whether it was his ballet or my ballet,'' Mr. Robbins said. Balanchine allowed him an individual voice, and no Robbins ballet ever resembled one done by Balanchine.
 
Balanchine a Guide, Not a Pattern
Mr. Robbins said Balanchine's work should serve ''as an example of what a ballet should be,'' but it should not be imitated. The reason ''we don't have any choreographers today is that they're copying the latest dress style and following a pattern instead of making it organic to themselves,'' he said.
Balanchine's lasting legacy is present in the quality of his ballets, Mr. Robbins continued, and this is transmitted to the dancers producing a ''specialness that no other company has.'' This was not idle praise in his view but a professional assessment of the City Ballet dancers. ''The specialness comes from the training the dancers get by dancing and experiencing Balanchine ballets,'' he said. ''It is the nobleness of what it is to dance ballet and to dance those ballets.''
Turning to more immediate concerns, he said that Edward Villella, now director of the Miami City Ballet, had agreed to return for the Robbins retrospective at City Ballet. He will appear in the role he created in the 1972 ''Watermill.'' Mr. Martins has suggested that Dance Theater of Harlem and Ballet Theater, which perform Robbins works that are not in the City Ballet repertory, be invited to take part in the Robbins festival.
 
Reticence on His Projects
Mr. Robbins was more reluctant to be precise about his other projects. ''I've been working on a theater piece for 10 years or so,'' he said. ''It comes out of my own experience.''
Asked if he was now writing his autobiography, he grinned and said, ''Yeah.'' Every day? ''Not at all, in bits and spurts,'' he replied. ''When I finish I'll finish.''
Mr. Robbins also said he had ''an interesting offer from an opera company in Europe to direct an opera I've been wanting to do,'' but declined to name the company.
Summing up, he said: ''It's time to shift gears. There were times 15 years ago when I didn't think I would ever do another ballet. I never knew 'Fiddler on the Roof' was going to be my last musical for 20 years. You never know when you're not going to do anymore.''
And then Mr. Robbins added, ''I guess I'm what you'd call a freelance choreographer.''

PUB-DATE: November 6, 1989

SECTION: Section A; Page 22, Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 574 words

HEADLINE: How Really to Cut Down Illegal Immigration

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your front-page report Oct. 9 on continuing heavy illegal immmigration despite the Immigration Reform and Control Act enacted in 1986 highlights the defects of that act. As forewarned by some of us who were consultants to the select commission and the legislators, undocumented entries cannot be controlled and halted by a simple procedure on the ''demand'' side, namely by requiring employers to check legal-residence documents for all new hires.
Apparently, because fraudulent documents can be obtained by workers and accepted by employers, only a portion of jobs for illegals has ''dried up.'' Consequently, there is little discouragement to surreptitious entries and little pressure to return home. You report that thousands continue to enter the country illegally every day; Immigration and Naturalization Service data for the first six months of fiscal 1989 suggest about 800,000 a year are apprehended for illegal entries across the borders. To that, add overstayers on visitor visas. 
These trends are more ominous than you indicate. For one thing, the diversion of some good jobs away from illegal aliens is not only pushing some migrants into sweatshop work at substandard wages and conditions, but it may also drive others into crime: burglaries, muggings, drug dealing. Furthermore, every new inflow adds to the burdens on local communities and social infrastructure. Meanwhile the pressures to migrate from Mexico, Central and South America, Southeast Asia and other lands are intensifying, not only because of poverty but also economic stagflation, foreign-debt burdens, political and military upheavals, increased mobility, organized border crossing and highly profitable drug smuggling.
The promising signs immigration officials cite to allay criticism come down at best to a vaunted decrease in apprehensions of about 55 percent for 1989 compared with 1986. But the 1986 figure represents a rise in crossings to beat the passage of the new act and perhaps to qualify for ''amnesty.'' Apprehensions have surged in recent months, so the estimated annual rate is not far from mid-80's figures.
Reconsidering the 1986 act, we might ask, Why not adopt a real, fake-proof identification card (with picture, fingerprint, height and weight) for all legal residents? The usual protests about invasion of privacy sound increasingly hollow.
If we are not prepared to apply massive enforcement - a Berlin Wall at the borders and immigration agents in every business and tourist circuit - nor to spend huge sums on the economic development of Mexico and other countries, we must look for other approaches.
One of these is to dry up the jobs for illegal aliens by pre-empting them with legally admitted temporary workers. This would draw on our relatively narrow but longstanding and successful experience in this country with H-2 workers, and would extend to urban jobs the H-2 provisions for farm labor scarcities as already written into the immigration act. These workers would come in varying numbers, for variable periods, as needed, but without dependents. Repatriation would be insured by government-to-government arrangements for the next cohort, and by withholding part of their earnings until their return, providing a lump sum of savings to spend or invest at home.
 
EDWIN P. REUBENS
New York, Oct. 10, 1989
 The writer is an emeritus professor of economics at the City College of New York.

HEADLINE: Baltic States Should Have Independence

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your observation that the Baltic republics, Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia, ''are far from becoming economically viable in the next few years'' (''A Sound Course on the Baltics,'' editorial, Oct. 21) applies more to the Soviet Union than to the Baltic states. The three republics, although producing only 4 percent of the Soviet gross national product, account for 12 percent of Soviet consumer-goods production. The economies of these three are well diversified in sharp contrast to the monocultures the central government in Moscow forced on many other areas. In addition, about 25 percent of Soviet trade flows through the Baltic states, a source of substantial income even now. 
The three republics know that the Soviet Union will always be their major trade partner. But since Moscow cannot yet concede that private ownership is a powerful stimulant for economic growth, to mention one factor blocking meaningful economic reform in the Soviet Union, the Baltic states are making a case for doing it their way, to use the phrase Gennadi I. Gerasimov, Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman, applied to Hungary and Poland (front page, Oct. 26).
Given demographic change fostered by central government policies - in Estonia the number of Estonians grew 1.6 percent over the last decade, while the number of non-Estonians, mostly Russians, increased 16.6 percent - concern over an ever-increasing immigration rate is understandable. Even Moscow, under similar pressure, has taken steps to limit immigration in sharp contrast to policies that heretofore have favored movement of the Russian population to the Baltic states.
It is difficult to understand why peaceful Baltic states, as independent as Finland, could not be more attractive economically than they are as stunted socialist republics in the Soviet Union. The West should also keep in mind that of all the countries trampled in World War II, all regained independence, even if nominally, except for three. Are Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania once again chips in a big-power exercise of ''improving relations''?
 
 
 
AGO AMBRE
Silver Spring, Md., Oct. 26, 1989
 The writer is an economist in the Department of Commerce.

HEADLINE: A Sandinista Promise Gone Sour Alienates Nicaragua's Working Class

BYLINE: By MARK A. UHLIG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Nov. 6

 BODY:
On a crumbling wall here, some aging graffiti sum up the Sandinista National Liberation Front's pledge to the urban poor: ''Workers! The F.S.L.N. will never let you down!''
In broad red brushstrokes, the slogan defines the revolutionary compact that once bound the Sandinistas to Nicaragua's working class, helping the insurgent movement to seize power in 1979.
But after three years of political and economic crisis, the promise has faded along with the paint.
Battered by galloping inflation, Nicaraguan workers have seen their real wages fall by more than 90 percent since 1981, forcing huge cuts in private consumption. Large-scale layoffs of Government workers and a deep industrial decline have left thousands of people in Managua and other cities without jobs. And with national elections less than three and a half months away, the urban workers who once sustained the Sandinista Government have now become one of its most serious potential liabilities. 
 
Prices Rise as Salaries Lag
''For us, the economy has been destroyed, just destroyed,'' said Alcides Flores, a 42-year-old worker in Managua. ''Every day the prices go up, but our salaries stay the same. People are doing anything they can just to survive, and they blame the Government for what is happening to us.''
In the last week, the issue of economic hardship has been overshadowed here by the Government's decision to end its cease-fire with contra rebels and by fears that new fighting may interfere with national elections scheduled for Feb. 25.
But workers in Managua, which has been relatively untouched by direct effects of the war against the contras, dread the threat of renewed fighting also for its economic cost. Some opposition leaders have accused the Government of raising the specter of war precisely to distract people from the hardships of daily life.
Over the last two years, the Sandinista Government has taken tough measures to halt the economy's rapid deterioration, which Government officials ascribe to the heavy burden of the eight-year war against American-backed rebels. Those measures, mainly deep cuts in Government spending and investment, have succeeded in reducing inflation, which reached an annual rate of 36,000 percent last year, to less than 10 percent a month.
 
'Life Is Horrible'
But the fight to regain control of the currency has left the economy in a deep recession, particularly in the industrial sector, which is expected to shrink by roughly 20 percent this year alone, according to confidential Government figures. The consequences of that contraction are being borne largely in urban areas, which account for more than 80 percent of the country's industry. And with nothing to fall back on but their shrinking salaries, urban workers - who make up an estimated 25 percent of the nation's voters - have felt the full force of Nicaragua's economic crisis.
''Life is horrible right now,'' said Luis, a 30-year-old driver who asked not to be further identified. ''We have been left out, put on the margins, and the situation just keeps getting worse. I think the problems are irreversible.''
In dozens of interviews throughout Managua and surrounding areas, low-income workers from the public and private sectors alike expressed despair about their economic circumstances and many said that economic reasons alone would compel them to vote for the opposition. Although most of those interviewed said they believed the war had been important in starting the economic slide, few said it could justify their continuing hardship. And many said flatly that they did not believe the Government was able or willing to solve the nation's economic crisis.
''We used to eat three times a day, like normal people,'' said Luis Edmundo Sanchez, a salaried laborer in Managua. ''But I can only afford to eat twice, and it is the same with everybody I know. The only ones who can afford to eat are in the Government.''
 
Favored Treatment for City
Such criticism is a dramatic change from the early days of the Sandinista regime, when the Government, acting to fulfill its revolutionary ideals, used subsidies and price controls to give city dwellers more favorable terms of trade than their counterparts in the countryside, bringing a surge of prosperity to Nicaragua's fledgling proletariat.
Those policies, together with the start of the contra war, helped produce a nationwide exodus from the countryside to the cities, giving Managua one of the highest urban growth rates in the world. According to official estimates, the capital now holds more than one million people, or one-third of all Nicaraguans, gravely straining housing, water and sewerage services, which are barely suitable for half that population. All of the city's services were badly damaged in the devastating earthquake of 1972 and were never substantially repaired.
To halt the influx to the cities and to reduce discontent that gave contra forces rural support, the Government changed its economic policies in 1984 in favor of rural producers. A gradual increase in the relative prices paid for farm products, together with a new emphasis on redistribution of land into individual farms instead of large cooperatives, helped to reduce rural support for the contras.
But the new policies did not halt the migration into the cities. And they only compounded the problems of the thousands of Nicaraguans who had already abandoned the countryside for the city.
 
Many Eat Just One Meal a Day
Economists who have studied the resulting economic collision say it combined a glut of workers with a battered urban economy. And it was compounded by an American embargo on trade with Nicaragua, poor Government management and uncontrolled inflation caused by high military expenditures.
The most important problem, the economists say, is not the supply of adequate food and other products at city markets, but the low buying power of the workers who consume those goods.
At current exchange rates, for example, a typical Government-paid laborer earns about 500,000 cordobas, or roughly $20, for a month's work. That salary must be stretched to meet rising prices, which have left a single one-pound can of powdered milk, enough to feed one child for three to four days, costing more than 80,000 cordobas, a pound of pork at 24,000 cordobas, and a pair of shoes at 600,000 to 800,000 cordobas.
''By the time we get paid, the money has already been spent just to pay for food,'' said Alberto Ruiz, a 32-year-old government construction foreman. He said most families had given up eating meat, and many had been reduced to one meal a day.
Experts say the collapse of real wages masks an increasing reliance on barter, payments in kind, gifts from relatives abroad and unrecorded transactions on the black market - the so-called informal economy.
''There is not a formal social safety net,'' said Mario Arana Sevilla, an economist at a Government-sponsored research institute in Managua. ''But there are informal ways, informal strategies that people have worked out in order to get by.''
 
Consumption Down Sharply
But official figures show that per capita private consumption has fallen by at least 70 percent under Sandinista rule. In an election season that figure alone has placed the Government on the defensive. And while many diplomats and economists believe that the Government recovery plan is well designed, they note that it demands harsh sacrifices now for stability later - a trade-off that could hardly be more damaging to the Sandinistas' election efforts.
Economists say the Government is likely to benefit politically from the large numnber of workers who are paid directly by the state and who may vote in favor of Sandinista leaders to protect their jobs. Approximately 58 percent of urban workers and about 71 percent of skilled technicians are employed by the state, according to a recent study.
The economic recovery measures also provide near-term benefits for some groups, notably small entrepreneurs, who are now viewed as vital to an economic revival. But many diplomats note that the entrepreneurs and market vendors were among the first, and the bitterest, enemies of the Sandinistas. And they doubt that the Government will win many new votes among such dedicated opponents.
Instead, the diplomats say, the Government's greatest efforts at this point are likely to be directed not at winning back disenchanted urban workers, but at avoiding new economic shocks that would alienate still more. In a country where exchange rates are watched as avidly as sports scores, rumors abound that the Government is preparing a new devaluation that would perhaps halve the value of the cordoba against the dollar. And critics of the Government argue that the cost of the election itself may touch off a round of economic shocks that could be catastrophic for Sandinista prestige.
''The Government will have to spend at least $25 million on election costs, and it is also reaching the part of the production cycle where it must pay producers for goods that have been exported,'' said Mario Alegria Castillo, a private economist. ''If it doesn't get some form of outside help, it will have to cover that cost by printing money, but that would mean new inflation. It is like a baseball runner who has been caught between the bases.''
 
'Everything Will Be Better!'
In a tacit acknowledgement of their weak economic record, Sandinista leaders have adopted a forward-looking campaign slogan: ''Everything will be better!''
The slogan, Sandinista officials say, refers to the influx of new aid, particularly from Western Europe, and to improved commercial relationships that they believe will follow if the election process is judged to be free and fair, certifying Nicaragua's democratic credentials. Part of such a new environment, they say, would be the ending of the United States trade embargo and the withdrawal of American opposition to multilateral lending to the Sandinista Government.
But such optimism is viewed coldly by many Managua workers who assert that Sandinista leaders have already forfeited the allegiance of the urban working class. Several said that if relations with the United States were the answer to the economic crisis the opposition was better suited for the job. Well-publicized foreign donations to the opposition parties here have been interpreted by many Nicaraguans as proof that the opposition, not the Sandinistas, has better access to the foreign money necessary to relieve Nicaragua's crisis.
''Everything will be better, but only because they will be gone,'' said a Managua heavy-equipment operator, referring to the Sandinistas. ''The worker won't give him his vote.''

LENGTH: 668 words

HEADLINE: U.S. and Japan Refuse Curbs on Carbon Dioxide

BYLINE: By PAUL L. MONTGOMERY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NOORDWIJK ANN ZEE, Netherlands, Nov. 6

 BODY:
The United States and Japan refused today to accept strong measures on curbing the release of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere.
Attending a 70-nation conference on global warming, both countries, two of the world's most industrialized, said they would not endorse a commitment to control emission of carbon dioxide by the year 2000. Experts say such emissions are a major cause of the warming of the atmosphere, known as the ''greenhouse effect.''
William K. Reilly, the head of the Environmental Protection Agency and leader of the American delegation here, said the Bush Administration recognized the carbon dioxide problem but believed that further study was necessary before binding controls could be proposed. Limiting excess carbon dioxide produced by the burning coal in power plants or gasoline in automobiles is the main target of the global-warming conference. 
Environmentalists and several governments in Scandinavia and Europe have called for controls to keep carbon dioxide emissions at current levels. They are also seeking ways to save energy and curb gasoline use to reduce the emissions. Oil and coal companies and large industrial users are the main opponents of such a strategy.
A number of countries among the 70 represented by environmental officials in this western Netherlands seaport were preparing a tough declaration proposing specific curbs despite the opposition of the United States and Japan. A Netherlands plan for holding carbon dioxide emissions to the 1988 level by the year 2000 was the preferred approach. Such a declaration would not be binding on the nations that sign it.
Brice Lalonde, the French environmental secretary, said Britain was the only one of the 12 nations in the European Community to oppose immediate targets for carbon dioxide curbs. Eastern bloc participants like the Soviet Union and Poland have also opposed specific targets, saying such controls would be too costly to their economies.
The conference is one of a series that has examined the greenhouse effect and related problems.
The United States has said the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, sponsored by the United Nations and the World Meteorological Organization, is the proper forum for introducing declarations on specific curbs. That panel's three working groups are led by the United States, Britain and the Soviet Union - all opponents of immediate action. The panel is not expected to produce a final report for another year.
The United States is the principal source of carbon dioxide in the world, producing 23 percent of the total, according to United Nations figures from 1985. The Soviet Union produced 19 percent, followed by China, with 10 percent; Japan, 5 percent; West Germany, 4 percent; the Britain, 3 percent, and France, East Germany and Poland, 2 percent each.
 
Worsened by Forest Loss
The industrial pollution is made worse by the steady destruction of the world's forests because trees contribute to the recycling of carbon dioxide and the generation of oxygen.
Environmentalists say every year's delay in curbing carbon dioxide adds greatly to the danger because the damage in the atmosphere is cumulative. Some scientists say carbon dioxide emissions might have to be cut by 70 percent or more in the next half century to restore nature's balance.
The Netherlands announced plans today for unilateral action to cut emissions. The country has the most advanced environmental protection plan in the world, including stringent curbing of automobiles.
The last Dutch Government fell in May over aspects of the plan, but the new Christian Democrat-Socialist coalition, scheduled to take office on Tuesday, has said it will put the plan into action.
Eduardus Nijpels, the interim Environment Minister, said at the conference today that the Netherlands would cut carbon dioxide emissions in 1990 by 2 percent, and 2 percent more each year to a target of 8 percent in 1994. The Netherlands would be the first country to take such action.

HEADLINE: U.S. Considers East German Measures Inadequate

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6

 BODY:
Bush Administration officials said today that the situation in East Germany was unstable and unpredictable because the steps taken by the country's new leaders were inadequate to end the turmoil there.
The State Department reacted coolly to measures announced by Egon Krenz, the East German leader, that would allow East Germans to travel outside their country for up to 30 days a year.
''It does seem to signify a liberalization when compared to existing travel rules,'' said Richard A. Boucher, the deputy spokesman at the State Department. ''Nonetheless, the changes are still far from full freedom of movement, one of the basic human rights which we've always called for and always supported. We'll just have to see whether this proposed new law will satisfy the wishes of the East German population.'' 
American officials said they had no reason to believe that Mr. Krenz would emerge as an advocate of economic and political change in the mold of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet President. ''Gorbachev shows native curiosity,'' said Herbert S. Okun, an expert on Eastern Europe who served as the United States Ambassador to East Germany from 1980 to 1983. ''He likes give and take. Krenz is leaden, heavy and plodding.''
A State Department official said: ''The outlook for East Germany is quite dim. It will be difficult to stanch the flow of people out of the country. I foresee increasing social unrest, and there is an existential problem, too. If the leaders make the necessary reforms, they may reform themselves out of existence. They may self-destruct. The regime has been illegitimate, and has been perceived as illegitimate, for a long time.'' On Friday, Mr. Krenz announced the dismissal of five senior members of the Politburo. But Administration officials said they would not praise that move until they saw who the replacements were.
John Edwin Mroz, president of the Institute for East-West Security Studies, a research center in New York, said, ''There is a real question whether East Germany can remain a viable state.
''You have a revolution from below,'' Mr. Mroz said. ''It's an explosion in East Germany, whereas there was a gradual process of evolutionary change in Hungary and Poland. The East German leadership has a salvage operation, and they are following, not leading, the people.'' He said it was ''inconceivable that the Soviet Union would allow a total breakdown of law and order in East Germany.''
President Bush's national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, and other Administration officials said Washington stood ready to help West Germany if the flow of East German emigres became unmanageable. But the United States does not appear to have concrete plans, and Administration officials said they would not provide such assistance unless Bonn requested it.
 
'We Have Not Been Approached'
''We would have to be approached by the West German Government with a specific request for assistance,'' Mr. Boucher said. ''At this point, we have not been approached. We also expect the West Germans would first approach the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, since the High Commissioner has primary responsibility for such international assistance.''
Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said: ''Although we see large numbers of people leaving, the rate of entry into West Germany appears manageable at this time. We believe West Germany is doing an excellent job of handling this flow of people.''
On the CBS News program ''Face the Nation,'' Mr. Scowcroft said Sunday that the orderly exodus of East Germans could become chaotic if ''something unexpected'' happens.
The situation is complicated because ''there's no East German nation,'' Mr. Scowcroft said. The East Germans ''distinguish themselves only by their political and economic system,'' he said. So ''to the extent they reform'' that system, ''they undercut their reason for existence,'' he said.

HEADLINE: Lubec Journal;
As Small Town Burns, Its Tight Fabric Frays

BYLINE: By LYN RIDDLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LUBEC, Me.

 BODY:
Marylyn Curtis had planned to spend Thanksgiving with her daughter in Chicago, but a recent series of suspicious fires in this seaside town, including one in an abandoned church next door to her home, have changed her plans.
''I've stayed close to home ever since,'' said Ms. Curtis, who is the town clerk. ''I am petrified. I'm just thankful that the wind wasn't right to take down my house, too.'' 
Nineteen suspicious fires in the last three months have terrified the 1,800 residents of this remote community, which is the easternmost town in the United States. Even though the two-man police force and seven reserve officers make extra nightly rounds, residents have begun to stand guard over their property, turning on outside lights and loading their firearms.
''People are so scared they don't go to bed at night,'' said Sharley Fitzsimmons, the foreman at McCurdy's Smokehouse, where a fire in August caused minor damage to a storeroom.
The most recent fire, a few days ago, destroyed a summer home eight miles from the downtown section. Two weeks earlier, the former Disciples of Christ Church was burned. The first two fires were on July 31. Fire officials, who hesitate to estimate monetary loss, say an elderly man's home and two churches were destroyed; other buildings suffered less damage. Fires were also started in an abandoned canning plant, a restaurant, six uninhabited houses and a garage. Two houses were set ablaze more than once.
''It's very obvious it's a set fire,'' said Ladd Alcott, the state's Assistant Fire Marshal. ''A building with no electricity will sit like that for 200 years.'' Some of the buildings, including both churches and a few of the houses, were without electricity.
Although local investigators say there are suspects, they add that they are a long way from making arrests. They say they perceive no apparent pattern to the fires; all but three have occurred in a lovely hillside neighborhood of turn-of-the-century homes. All were set at night. None of the buildings were occupied, leading investigators to believe that the arsonist or arsonists wanted to avoid hurting people.
The local police and fire departments, the Washington County Sheriff's Department and the Maine State Fire Marshal's Office are cooperating on the inquiry, said the Fire Chief, Errol Tinker, who heads a 30-person volunteer force. He, like others, believes the fires are the work of several ''copycats.''
''I just wish it would stop,'' said Chief Tinker. ''It's hard on me. It's hard on the men. We've loaded more hose in the last month than we normally would all year.'' Lubec averages 40 minor fires a year.
Once a thriving port on the Lubec Neck peninsula, this town bustled with 18 sardine-canning plants at the turn of the century. In the last few decades, all but two plants have closed, and recent figures put the unemployment rate at 24.8 percent.
Lubec is a close-knit, friendly town, and the fires have bewildered residents and set them on edge.
''Ten, 15 years ago, a guy was burning down buildings, but everybody knew who was doing that,'' said Howard Jones, who runs a combination liquor store and gas station here. ''They just had to wait and catch him in the act. But these fires - no one knows.''
Many of his customers and friends say they are keeping their weapons loaded, Mr. Jones said. Law enforcement officials worry that an innocent person may fall victim to an anxious property owner.
Chief Tinker takes little solace in the perpetrators' seeming concern about hurting people. ''They are hurting people financially and emotionally,'' he said. ''It's taking its toll, especially on the older people.''
Seventy-four-year-old Waldo Hoar may have lost the most. His large Victorian-era house and all its contents were destroyed last September. A month later, someone set fire to the little that was left.
''I just couldn't believe it,'' Mr. Hoar said. ''I never done no one no harm. Why would they be in there doing stuff like that to me?''

HEADLINE: TALKS AT BOEING APPEAR STALLED

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Nov. 6

 BODY:
Five weeks into a strike that has virtually shut down airplane production at the Boeing Company and cut a $2 billion annual payroll in half, this city is starting to get jitters over the prospect of a walkout that could last through Christmas.
Although the Seattle economy, one of the healthiest and fastest growing in the nation, is not nearly as dependent on Boeing as it was during Boeing's last peak period 20 years ago, the strike by 58,000 machinists is starting to hurt retailers, from small lunch shops to department stores, throughout the Puget Sound area.
Economists worry that the strike, which looks as though it will last at least another month following a breakdown of talks over weekend, will drag other segments of the Northwest economy down with it as it continues.
''The main impact now is the loss of that huge wage bill, the millions of dollars that are normally floating around the economy from weekly paychecks,'' said Robert Chase, an economist at the University of Washington. 
 
A New But Similar Offer
After a week of negotiations, Boeing made a new offer to leaders of the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers on Sunday. The offer was essentially the one that had been rejected by members in early October, except that the company offered bigger bonuses. The union leadership dismissed the new offer.
The offer would have provided an average bonus of about $3,000 by this Christmas, and two smaller bonuses in the next two years, a 7 percent increase over the previous offer. In the past, Boeing workers have accepted fat bonus checks at Christmas in lieu of general wage increases. This year, with Boeing reporting record third-quarter profits of $242 million, union leaders have urged their members to resist the temptation of instant cash and to hold out for better contracts to get them through the coming years.
The total package offered over the weekend is roughly the same as the previous offer because money would be taken from cost-of-living increases to pay for the bonuses. The proposed wage increase of 10 percent over three years remained the same.
On the picket line, many Boeing workers who have been living on $100-a-week strike benefits and have been pressed by mounting bills said they were tempted to take the new package, which Boeing called its final offer.
 
Best 'in Recent History'
''We look at this economic proposal as the best offer to machinists in the United States in recent history,'' said Larry McKean, Boeing's chief negotiator.
Leaders of the machinists, however, rejected the proposal as ''an insult'' and said it would not be submitted for a full vote of the union membership. They adopted a new slogan for the strike: ''No money, no airplanes.''
Harold Carr, a spokesman for Boeing, said 10 percent, or about 5,800 workers, have crossed picket lines at Boeing plants in the Seattle area and in Wichita, Kan., and Portland, Ore.
Union leaders say commitment to the strike in Seattle remains firm. ''This is the strongest strike I've ever seen,'' said Tom Baker, chief negotiator for the machinists. ''There is no reason, other than Boeing's cheapness, to grant workers in the nation's No. 1 export industry second-rate or third-rate pay raises.''
Union leaders also realize the strike is starting to hurt Boeing. The company has delivered 16 airplanes, most of which were already nearly completed, since the start of the Oct. 4 walkout. Frank Shrontz, chairman of the Boeing, reported last month that the strike would have ''severe adverse impact'' on fourth-quarter profits.
 
Lower Projected Profits
One analyst, Paul Nisbet at Prudential Bache Securities Inc., has lowered projections for Boeing's fourth-quarter profits from $1.75 a share to $1. ''There is intense pressure to end this strike,'' Mr. Nisbet said. Although only one in 10 jobs in the Seattle area is tied to Boeing, as against one in five two decades ago, the amount of money pumped into the regional economy from Boeing wages is much greater, by percentage, according to some economists.
''The typical Boeing worker makes much more than 20 years ago, so when you have a strike, consumer buying of such things as washers and dryers and cars and televisions are hit very hard,'' Mr. Chase said. The city as a whole, however, is not nearly as tied to Boeing as it once was. Seattle has become a prosperous regional center for finance, software manufacturing and Pacific Rim trade, according to a recent report by Salomon Brothers Inc..

HEADLINE: Oakland's Dowdy Image Is Shattered

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 6

 BODY:
This misunderstood city on the east side of San Francisco Bay is taking stock of its earthquake experience and finding unexpected promise in the rubble.
While the 15-second jolt last month claimed historic buildings here, closed department stores, shut City Hall and turned welfare tenants out of dilapidated hotels, Oakland's leaders predict that their immediate problems will be outweighed by a long-term gain. And even in the short term, Oakland is benefiting, as residents confined by a crippled highway network are discovering their city and spending money at home instead of across the bay.
''It's a blessing in disguise,'' said Edward J. Blakely, the chairman of the graduate program of city planning at the University of California at Berkeley, a longtime resident of Oakland. ''This gives us all kinds of opportunities to seize.'' 
 
City's Inferiority Complex
Until now, Oakland has been a city with a terrible inferiority complex despite its championship baseball team, scorned as San Francisco's plain stepsister and feared because of crack and crime. But the 7.1 temblor that rocked the region on Oct. 17 has done wonders for Oakland's public image and its sense of itself as a brave and singular place.
''Sometimes I think we've believed our own bad press,'' said Jerry Westenhaver, general manager of the Hyatt Regency, Oakland's largest hotel with 468 rooms.
Before the earthquake, many people outside the Bay Area had no idea where Oakland was. Others considered it a dangerous, unstable city where housing projects crackled with gunfire and narcotics arrests soared, where the school system was on the verge of collapse and municipal hospitals had become M*A*S*H units.
 
A New View
These days, that perception has changed.
Millions of people around the world know that Oakland faces San Francisco across the severed Bay Bridge. They know that in days of terrible stress there was virtually no looting and rioting here, even in the blighted neighborhood beside the collapsed Nimitz Freeway, where 41 motorists were killed.
And they know that many more might have died beneath the curtain of crushed concrete were it not for the bravery of residents who scaled the ruined roadway to pull strangers to safety.
 
Crossing the Bridge
Similarly, Oakland's self-image has been transformed by the trauma.
Long before the earthquake, the 356,000 people who live here treasured their city for its unpretentious ways and its racial harmony, for its well-kept homes, its gentle sunshine and its wide vistas. But despite their genuine pride - almost a reverse snobbery about choosing a city without San Francisco's cultural smugness or Berkeley's ideological airs - most residents of Oakland still regarded their hometown as an outpost. To work, to shop and to dine often meant that people here crossed ''The Bridge'' and went to ''The City.''
Without the Bay Bridge, an eight-mile drive becomes a 35-mile jog to the north or an even longer trip down the east shore of the bay and back up the peninsula to San Francisco. Commuters can make their way to work using a patchwork of ferries, trains and buses. But for the time being, Oaklanders who have any choice are staying home.
 
Crowded Stores and Restaurants
While San Francisco restaurants are struggling, missing their usual complements of tourists and East Bay residents, Oakland's are full. While San Francisco's merchants worry about failing business, Oakland's are bragging about crowded stores. Some San Francisco businesses are setting up temporary satellite operations in the East Bay to eliminate commuting, prompting a run on prime office space in what had been a sleepy market.
Robert C. Maynard, editor of The Oakland Tribune, calls the current situation a reversal of the usual ''trans-bay wealth transfer.'' San Franciscans ''thought they didn't need us near as much as we needed them,'' Mr. Maynard said. ''They are about to make the discovery of their lives: how dependent they are on East Bay residents and East Bay dollars.''
Mr. Blakely agreed. ''What seems to be happening,'' he said, ''is people are moving around the East Bay without reference to San Francisco. We are developing a sense of subregional economy. I think the psychology of this could be long-term. We may develop a new sense of civic destiny here.''
Oakland was in a frenzy of self-promotion just as the earthquake struck, in the middle of a World Series that pitted the hometown Athletics against the San Francisco Giants. Besides the hope that a victory over their cross-Bay rival might boost civic spirit - a celebratory mood that the earthquake precluded as irrelevant - Oakland boosters saw the Series as an opportunity to show off to visitors their redevelopment projects, waterfront mall, downtown saltwater lake, hillside mansions and bustling Asian neighborhoods. While the earthquake canceled that opportunity, it provided another.
Part of the World Series tour for visiting journalists, conducted by the city's public relations firm, was a sculpture in a downtown plaza called ''There,'' in recognition of Gertrude Stein's lament that ''there is no there there.'' Nothing has so shaped Oakland's dreary image as this passage from the writer's 1937 memoir, ''Everybody's Autobiography.'' Misconstrued for more than 50 years, the phrase was meant to mourn the disappearance of Miss Stein's childhood home in Oakland, and not to characterize the city where she grew up.
This sort of misunderstanding galls Oaklanders, who complained that even during the earthquake they took a back seat to San Francisco, which is twice as populous and where most news organizations have their headquarters. Mayor Art Agnos of San Francisco got more attention than Mayor Lionel Wilson. And the 2,500 people displaced from their homes here were seen less frequently on television than the 1,100 new homeless in San Francisco, most of them well-to-do residents of the Marina district.
 
'Count Your Blessings'
But being slighted in this way was another boon for Oakland, some local leaders said, leaving the impression that the East Bay is a safer place to live or invest. ''The Mayor wanted more coverage,'' Mr. Blakely said. ''I told him, 'Count your blessings.' ''
Mr. Blakely and others hope the earthquake will not only increase pride and business here, but give the city a chance to correct some of its design flaws, like a diffuse downtown and a freeway system that isolates and thus blights West Oakland.
Forty-seven percent, of Oakland's residents are black and the city has been designated America's most integrated by a group of University of Wisconsin researchers, who determined that only 2 percent of the city's blacks lived on segregated blocks.
One of Oakland's proudest accomplishments is its relative racial peace. In the 1960's and 70's, when the nation was torn by race riots from Watts to Harlem, Oakland did not burn. In the 1980's, when racial tensions have again divided cities, Oakland's black professionals live peaceably beside their white counterparts in $300,000 hillside houses where roses and lemon trees bloom year-round.
''The divisions here are economic, not racial,'' said Mayor Wilson, a pitcher in the Negro leagues, a lawyer and a judge before his election 12 years ago.
Oakland has a thriving black middle class and its members dominate the city Government and run many cultural and civic institutions. Still, the city is better known for its underclass, the 18.5 percent of Oakland's citizens who live below the poverty line.
The city's worst poverty is concentrated in West Oakland, the neighborhood where Huey P. Newton developed the Black Panther Party in the 1960's and last summer died in a drug-related shooting. This is the same area that is adjacent to the Nimitz Freeway and its residents were among the earthquake's heroes.
For some in Oakland, current circumstances are an excuse to thumb their noses at San Franciscans who have treated them with scorn, or as Mr. Maynard puts it, ''like we were a colony, like we needed them to complete our lives.''
For others, recent events are merely an accident of nature that helped Oaklanders break the habit of crossing the bay and left city leaders privately celebrating the closure of the region's main transportation link.
''I've been in meetings,'' Mr. Blakely said, ''where people said they were delighted the bridge fell down.''

HEADLINE: D'Amato Acknowledges Plea for a H.U.D. Grant

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato acknowledged yesterday that his office had asked Housing Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr. in 1986 to approve $5.9 million in grants for an upstate project being represented by his brother's law firm and developed by one of his campaign contributors.
But he said the letter requesting the funds was written by the head of his Syracuse office, who was authorized to sign his name, and he insisted that he had not learned of its existence until last Friday, when Newsday questioned him about it for a story published yesterday.
Newsday, which reproduced the letter, said that Mr. Pierce had at first ''temporarily rejected'' the fund request on technical grounds, but that the Department of Housing and Urban Development had since awarded $6.4 million to the project in Sackets Harbor, N.Y.
The project, a complex of new and rehabilitated housing, retail stores and a new conference center and country inn, is being built on the site of Madison Barracks, a historic military base on Lake Ontario, 30 miles from the Canadian border. 
 
D'Amato Under Fire
Senator D'Amato, a New York Republican who has been under fire in recent months for supporting Federal housing grants that were said to have benefited his friends, relatives or campaign contributors, called the 1986 request for Federal aid to the project an appropriate effort by his office to help an economically depressed community. ''Would I have supported the project had I known about it?'' he said in an interview. ''Absolutely. There was no reason not to. In reviewing the merits of the request, this project was in a highly distressed area -the local officials were desperate when they approached us.''
At the time, the Senator said, the Jefferson County community had the state's highest unemployment rate and many residents had left to find work elsewhere.
The Senator said the request for funds had nothing to do with aiding his brother, Armand, a partner in a Mineola, L.I., law firm representing the project, or Jobco, a Great Neck, L.I., developer whose owners have contributed to his campaigns. Armand D'Amato has done legal work for Jobco for years. Federal election records show that Jobco's owners have given $9,600 to D'Amato campaigns and gave a fund-raising affair for his 1986 campaign.
''My brother didn't come to my office for any aid,'' Senator D'Amato said. ''His office did not make a request of my office. The project should be judged on its merits alone. People up there were desperate for help.''
 
Assistant Wrote Letter
The Senator said Jobco was not even the project's developer when his office was first approached in 1984 by the Mayor of Sackets Harbor and an economic development agency for communities in New York and Ontario in the St. Lawrence River-Lake Ontario region. The original developer went bankrupt and Jobco took over the project in 1986.
Mr. D'Amato acknowledged that the letter of July 15, 1986, requesting H.U.D. funds for Sackets Harbor had been written by Gretchen Ralph, the executive assistant in charge of his Syracuse office, one of the Senator's five regional offices in the state. He noted that she signed his name to it, and called that routine, noting that tens of thousands of letters over his name go out each year without his personal perusal or signature.
Ms. Ralph did not return a call yesterday. She was quoted by Newsday as saying that at the time she sent the letter she did not know the identity of the developer or the fact that Senator D'Amato's brother represented the project.
While contending that Ms. Ralph had done nothing wrong, the Senator said his office last year had changed its procedures to insure that letters to and from Cabinet secretaries and other high officials are all seen by Mr. D'Amato's top legislative and staff aides, if not by the Senator himself.
Mr. D'Amato also accused Newsday of ''a new low in journalistic standards.'' He said that portions of a letterhead showing that the letter came from his Syracuse office were whited out in the paper's Long Island edition, as if to suggest it had been sent from Washington.
The Senator also said the newspaper had used a quote to create a distorted impression. Newsday said he had told one of its reporters two months ago: ''I have absolutely never asked for any H.U.D. grants or anything else for Sackets Harbor or Jobco or the project up there.''
Mr. D'Amato did not deny making the statement, but said he had been talking to the reporter about a housing program known as Moderate Rehabilitation, not about Urban Development Action Grants, such as were made in Sackets Harbor.
James Toedtman, Newsday's managing editor in New York, said that a staff artist had mistakenly whited out the Syracuse address on the front page of the Long Island edition. Robert W. Greene, the assistant managing editor, denied that the quote had misrepresented the Senator. ''It was not out of context,'' he said. ''It speaks for itself.''

HEADLINE: Battery Park City Rousing From a 2-Year Fiscal Sleep

BYLINE: By SUSAN CHIRA

 BODY:
Battery Park City, the 92-acre development whose expansion halted after the 1987 stock market plunge and economic slowdown, is ready to create new neighborhoods to the north and south.
As the project expands, the weaknesses of Wall Street continue to dog its planners, who have been lauded for doing what was thought to be impossible in this day and age. A government agency, working with architects and private developers, has created an attractive, financially successful community in lower Manhattan with a social purpose: The first $1 billion of its revenues is paying for low- and middle-income housing elsewhere in New York City.
The World Financial Center, the four office towers in the development, has reaped substantial profits, and the apartments are 98.4 percent occupied despite a flat real-estate market.
 
A Harder Road Ahead
But developers think future success on that scale will be harder to achieve and will take new thinking. 
The young investment bankers envisioned as the primary buyers of condominiums and cooperatives at Battery Park City are being laid off, and the double-income-no-kids couples who moved into the one-bedroom apartments that dominate the housing stock are having those kids and scouting for more space. Expensive retail outlets in the office buildings of the development, like many others in the city, report low sales. Planners are weighing how to connect the new settlements north and south to the neighborhoods across West Street and how to lure more New Yorkers to a place many still perceive as hard to reach.
The size of apartments, the types of stores and the connections to the rest of the city may have to change, say planners for the Battery Park City Authority, the state body that holds title to the land.
Battery Park City now is a cluster of apartment buildings and town houses that echo the designs of lower Manhattan and the Upper West Side. The housing is grouped around vest-pocket parks, an esplanade along the river with stunning views of the Statue of Liberty, a yacht harbor and the South Cove, which is so quiet that people strolling through it can hear the water lapping against the piers. The design has won praise from architects and urban planners.
Other cities have looked at its mix of public and private financing, its mingling of private residences with public spaces, as a model, said Meyer S. Frucher, a former president of the Battery Park City Authority.
The 6,000 people who live there - a fraction of the 20,000 or so expected to eventually - generally rave about the views, the parks and esplanade, and the sense of community. Thomas DeFrancesco, the managing agent of Gateway Plaza, the first apartment complex built, remembers the first tenants in 1982 gamely walking over planks and unpaved roads. Now, says Con Howe, executive director of the City Planning Commission and one of the early residents, neighbors relish the quiet that outsiders may see as isolation.
''I think everyone who lives in New York City treats their neighborhood as an enclave,'' he said. ''If anything has been done that's brilliant - almost without quick parallel - it's that for the residents, it feels safe. But it doesn't seem that the general public is excluded.''
A survey of the 5,500 people who lived in Battery Park City last year found the biggest complaint was limited services. They wanted more supermarkets, fruit markets and restaurants, as well as a movie theater. Most wanted better storage space in apartments, which many say are beautifully designed on the outside but too small inside.
 
Activity North and South
Now the project is moving into its next phases. In the northern sector, crews are putting up a new building for Stuyvesant High School; a developer just won a bid to construct the neighborhood's first residential building, and the authority projects a November ground-breaking for the largest park to be built in New York City in decades. A ferry service to Hoboken opened last month.
To the south, a chain-link fence still separates Battery Park from Battery Park City, but construction has begun on two more apartment buildings, and the authority has just designated a developer for a third.
These apartments will all be sold or rented at market rate, making it unlikely that the makeup of the population will change much. The 1988 survey found that the mean age of the residents was about 38 and the mean household income $102,632.
While officials responsible for Battery Park City pay homage to the idea of economic integration, they argue that the value of this prime waterfront land makes it impossible to build lower-income housing on it without government subsidies. David Emil, president of the Battery Park City Authority, said several studies of ways to reduce housing costs had projected only minor construction savings.
''I would like to build an economically integrated community,'' Mr. Emil said. ''I believe there is only so much intervention a government agency can make and be effective.''
 
Subsidies Aid Development
In the economic boom of the 1960's, Battery Park City was conceived as a mixed-income residence with generous government subsidies. The New York City fiscal crisis of the 1970's almost doomed it. It was reborn in the recovery of the 1980's with state and city subsidies in the form of tax incentives to the developers of office buildings and luxury housing aimed at the young executives of Wall Street.
Today, amid budget squeezes, officials and many housing advocates argue that the same subsidies would serve more people in need if used not in Battery Park City, but on cheaper land.
''I will listen to any idea they have for actually dropping the economic level of the people in the development,'' said Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. ''You can use the wealth more efficiently there by keeping the levels high and drawing down money for other uses.''
Richard A. Kahan, who as president of the authority in the late 1970's rescued Battery Park City and oversaw the development of its master plan, likes spending the revenues on cheaper housing. But he said he hoped some of this housing would be built in Battery Park City itself for the many modestly paid workers in the financial district whose bosses now can walk to work.
''Rather than having nothing but an upper-income enclave in a neighborhood that has so many workers, I support a search for a way to provide housing for some of them,'' he said.
 
Bigger Apartments in Demand
The next few apartment buildings planned, however, will probably be even more expensive, because many will be larger in response to the demand from expanding families. The largest apartments sold the fastest in newest building, the Regatta. Mr. Emil said.
But the financial community's problems have affected the project, said Fabian Palomino, chairman of the authority. Some developers delayed beginning construction for more than a year for fear of rushing new buildings into a weak market, he said. The delays prevented the state and city from receiving payments for the land. Developers were also slower to bid on new buildings; requests for proposals for the north residential area were issued in June 1988, and the authority named one of the developers last month.
The slowing economy has also hurt retail sales, particularly at the World Financial Center. Real-estate developers say the goods in the shops may be too high-priced. Several Wall Street lawyers and executives interviewed at the center said they had no time during lunch to shop and often walked past the stores after closing hours.
Clerks at Cignal, which offers high-priced casual wear, and Il Papiro, an imported paper goods shop, said sales were slow. Real-estate developers and some of the retailers in the complex also say that Olympia & York, the Canadian developer of the World Financial Center, is subsidizing the retailers by charging them little rent or only a percentage of sales.
 
A Turnaround Envisioned
The developer can well afford to do so, since the company has reaped huge profits on the office buildings. which are now more than 90 percent leased. Anita Contini, a company spokeswoman, said, ''Olympia & York will stand behind its tenants.'' She also said the latest sales figures showed a steady two-month improvement that signaled ''the beginning of a turnaround.''
Much will depend, she and others said, on how well Battery Park City succeeds in overcoming the perception that it is inaccessible. To reach the subways or the rest of Manhattan requires walking over pedestrian bridges or crossing busy West Street. For now, despite promotions for concerts at the World Financial Center, Battery Park City remains quiet, with not too many visitors.
On sunny weekend afternoons, as crowds a few blocks south jostle for spots on the Statue of Liberty boats, the Battery Park City esplanade may be host to no more than a dozen strollers, soaking in the silence.

HEADLINE: Rivals Make Last-Day Push In New Jersey

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA

 BODY:
Ending exhausting campaigns that began more than half a year ago, the candidates for governor in New Jersey crisscrossed the state yesterday before returning to their home bases to await the results of today's election.
Besides selecting a successor to Gov. Thomas H. Kean, who is prohibited by the state Constitution from seeking a third term, voters will also elect all 80 members of the General Assembly, as well as two state senators and many local and county officials.
Voters will also decide five public questions that would authorize spending $590 million for human service projects, new prisons, bridge repairs and preserving farm land and open space. 
New Jersey's polls are open from 7 A.M. to 8 P.M. Jan Burgio, the Secretary of State, has estimated that 60 percent of the state's 3.8 million registered voters will go to the polls. In 1981, the last time there was no incumbent governor running, the turnout exceeded 64 percent.
 
Mindful of 1981
Representative James J. Florio was at Newark's Penn Station just after dawn, greeting commuters and hoping to shore up the lead he has held almost from the beginning.
Ever mindful that he lost the 1981 election to Mr. Kean by only 1,797 votes, Mr. Florio has not let this campaign coast, no matter how far ahead of his Republican opponent, Representative Jim Courter, the polls have shown him.
After leaving Newark, Mr. Florio traveled to his political homeland in the south part of the state, attending a rally with local legislative candidates in Vineland.
''From what I sense here, this enthusiasm, this willingness to stick to it,'' Mr. Florio said, ''it's an indication that tomorrow we're all going to be celebrating.''
Mr. Florio has recently campaigned with legislative candidates, as the Democrats hope to win back the majority in the Assembly, now held by Republicans 41-39.
 
Rally at a Race Track
Mr. Florio ended the day at a rally at Garden State Park, a Cherry Hill horse-racing track where his campaign aides said he was met by about 2,000 supporters.
Mr. Courter, dismissing recent polls, campaigned with local candidates at a nutritional center for elderly people in Lyndhurst. He discussed his proposal to hold down property taxes of homeowners who are 65 or older, and, as he has often done during the last month, he reminded voters of New Jersey's high unemployment and inflation under the administration of Brendan T. Byrne, the Democrat who preceded Governor Kean.
''I have an abiding faith that the people of New Jersey are not going to want to go back,'' Mr. Courter said.
He then traveled to Ocean County, where his aides have said he must do well with independent and swing voters to have any chance of victory, to shake hands with shoppers at the Foodtown Shopping Center on Route 37.
Mr. Courter then dipped down into his opponent's Congressional district, greeting commuters at the Lindenwold station of the Patco high speed rail line.
He ended the day by returning to Hackettstown, where he lives, to join his family at a favorite-son thank you rally at David's Country Inn on Main Street.

HEADLINE: BATTLE IN INDIANA LOOMS ON GAMBLING

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: GARY, Ind., Nov. 6

 BODY:
Voters in this economically depressed steel town endorsed casino gambling by a wide margin in a nonbinding referendum Saturday, clearing the way for a battle in the State Legislature over casino legislation.
Mayor Thomas V. Barnes of Gary and other casino advocates say the city could support five casino-hotels on the shore of Lake Michigan; they would create 25,000 casino-related jobs and 10,000 for construction workers, the advocates say.
Those figures, coupled with a 60.4 percent vote in favor of casinos, make a strong case, the advocates say. Of the 22,042 people who voted, 13,309 favored casinos and 8,733 were opposed. The turnout was 32.3 percent. 
 
Revitalization as the Pitch
''An opportunity for jobs and economic revitalization - that's going to be the pitch,'' said State Representative Earline S. Rogers, a Gary Democrat.
Gov. Evan Bayh remained opposed, but said, ''I'm opposed to casino gambling, but I'm willing to sit down and look at all the arguments for and against and I have yet to do that. You never say never.''
There is little chance that a casino bill will get far in the Legislature in 1990 if the Governor threatens a veto, said the State House's Republican speaker, Paul S. Mannweiler.
 
Lobbyist Sees 50% Chance
''The more we tell our story, the more people look at the numbers, the more inclined they are to look at the opportunity favorably,'' said Robert Spolyar, a lobbyist for a casino operator, Resorts International of Atlantic City. ''I think we've got a 50 percent chance and I'm conservative.''
Governor Bayh said he believed the referendum result was important but uncompelling, given the low turnout.
Mayor Barnes said the turnout was modest because it was the first time an election had been held on a Saturday. It was an experiment with electronic voting machines that intimidated some voters, as did saving money by opening just 18 polling places instead of the usual 155.
Any effort to bring gambling here faces strong moral objections, said Mr. Mannweiler, the State House Republican speaker: ''In my mind, even though Gary says this is a local-option issue, that we ought to help Gary help themselves, casino gambling is not something I look very favorably on seeing in the State of Indiana anywhere.''

HEADLINE: Immigrants' Town Is Divided Over Measure on Language

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOWELL, Mass., Nov. 3

 BODY:
This riverfront city of old textile mills and factories has always drawn immigrants by the thousands. First there were the Irish and the Italians, then the Greeks and Poles. Most recently, Latin Americans and Southeast Asians have migrated here for jobs.
Relations among the various groups have not always been smooth, and a nonbinding measure on Tuesday's ballot that would declare English the city's official language has produced an ugly division between those who back it and those who say it could create a tool of oppression if it was re-introduced as a binding measure. 
Mayor Richard P. Howe says the issue has needlessly brought racial and ethnic animosity to the surface in a relatively peaceful period. But the measure's sponsor, George D. Kouloheras, a member of the School Committee, says he does not want to inflict pain on any ethnic group but simply wants to protect a language ''under attack.''
Nearly 40 percent of Lowell's 100,000 residents are Asian or Hispanic and no one disputes the value of conducting most of the city's affairs in English. But some worry that the move might be a first step toward policies that discriminate against people who cannot speak English, or cannot speak it well.
 
Divisive, a Cambodian Says
''I feel it is a divisive community strategy,'' said Boran Reth, president of the Cambodian Mutual Assistance Association here, who came to the United States in 1981 after his family was killed in the Cambodian civil war. ''The Cambodian community feels that they are not welcome in this city, and the purpose of this seems to be to punish the people who cannot speak English or speak English with accents.''
Mr. Kouloheras, whose parents emigrated from Greece at the turn of the 20th century, has joined the Washington-based organization U.S. English, which promotes the use of English in government.
''We have sort of a laissez-faire attitude that English is our language,'' Mr. Kouloheras said, ''and it is best to establish some principles that will guide the courts and policymakers in the future. It's best to take benign action now before the problem reaches a crisis. The minority language population continues to grow.''
''These measures are always so vague,'' said Martha Jimenez, a staff attorney and policy analyst for the Mexican American Legal Defense Fund in Washington, ''and no one is really sure what they mean. But the pattern has been for people to interpret them on their own, and it leads to an increase in private discrimination. People try not to be overtly racist, because they don't want to be labeled, so to a great extent language can be used as a proxy for that.''
 
Trouble Where There Wasn't Any
The referendum, coming when Lowell and much of Massachusetts are in an economic slowdown, seems to have prompted ill will toward recent immigrants. Lowell now has 25,000 Cambodians here and several hundred Vietnamese, Thai and Laotian families.
''This has brought out the anger and resentment and frustration that hadn't seemed to be a problem recently,'' Mayor Howe said. ''People are calling up radio talk shows to express their objections to Southeast Asians in the city. We were well on our way to making this system work when along comes George,'' a reference to Mr. Kouloheras.
Desegregation of Lowell's schools, begun in 1987, is now all but complete, with busing to classrooms beyond students' neighborhoods for racial balance. The plan had been hotly disputed. Shortly after it went into effect a young Cambodian boy, fighting with another boy as both waited for a bus, was pushed into a canal and drowned.
Most Asians came here in the last five years, and that has has strained on services, especially the school system. Last year the city spent $10 million of its $51 million budget on bilingual education and busing to keep the schools integrated.
 
The Influx of Children
About 3,400 of the 13,000 students are Asian, and 2,000 are Hispanic. Last year, Mayor Howe said, Asian children arrived at a rate of 30 to 50 a week, forcing the school system to rent extra classrooms and hire bilingual teachers. Many Cambodian children spent their earliest years in Thai refugee camps and came here with no formal education, Mr. Boran Reth said.
The superintendent of schools, Henry J. Mroz, said he favored extra Federal aid to help cover the costs of educating children who came with no English. ''It's all right to welcome people in,'' he said, ''but you have to provide for them.''
Mr. Mroz said he expected the referendum to win approval from most voters. The school committee endorsed it last week. ''It's not to divide people,'' Mr. Kouloheras said. ''It's to unite people. E pluribus unum.''
