HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Debt Ceiling Delays Sale By Treasury

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The Treasury was forced to postpone its scheduled weekly auction of three- and six-month bills yesterday because Congress failed to pass legislation raising the debt limit.
Continued delay in passing the debt limit bill casts doubt on whether the Treasury will be able to proceed with its planned quarterly refunding auctions later this week, when $40 billion worth of securities are to be sold.
Those auctions are tentatively scheduled to start today, with the sale of $10 billion worth of three-year Treasury notes. Late yesterday the Treasury said it would not announce a postponement of the issue until this morning, if necessary. 
Meanwhile, prices of Treasury notes and bonds moved lower in very light trading yesterday.
''The market is a little weaker due to the uncertainty and disappointment in not knowing what is going to happen,'' one government bond trader said.
''But when the auctions finally do take place we will see good demand for the issues, including foreign demand,'' the trader said. ''Even though the employment numbers last week didn't show weakness, a lot of folks out there think the odds are strong we will have a recession in the next six months or so. At current yields, that makes the return on the new securities look attractive.''
Some of the price declines recorded early in yesterday's session were made up later when it became apparent that stock prices, which were down sharply from the opening bell, would not recover. For the day, the Dow Jones indusrial average fell by 47.34 points.
Among Treasury issues, the 8 1/8 percent bonds of 2019 were offered at a price of 101 31/32 late yesterday, down 1/4 of a point, to yield 7.95 percent. Early in the session the closely watched issue was off by as much as 3/8 of a point.
In the secondary note market, the 8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 100 7/32, down 2/32, to yield 7.96 percent. And the 7 5/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 99 10/32, down 1/32, to yield 8.00 percent.
Meanwhile, Treasury bill rates rose modestly.
 
Three-Month Bill Rates
In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.83 percent, up two basis points, or hundredths of a point. And six-month bill rates were up one basis point, to a late offered rate of 7.68 percent.
The current logjam in Congress over the debt ceiling is causing some anxiety on Wall Street, but the current situation is not without precedent.
Conditions were strikingly similar in November 1985, when debate over the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings budget bill delayed an increase in the debt ceiling. The quarterly refunding auctions were held up as a consequence, although all three segments were eventually sold to investors by the end of November.
Louis v.B. Crandall, chief economist at R.H. Wrightson & Associates, an economic consulting firm, said that at least one of the auctions was likely to be delayed.
''As things now stand, the Treasury will run out of cash on Thursday,'' he said.
''To meet cash needs, their first priority will be to sell the Treasury bills that were postponed on Monday. After that, they will probably sell securities with the shortest maturities, because they need the least amount of handling. As a result, we think sale of the 30-year bond portion of the refunding will be delayed until after Nov. 15, the normal settlement date for the auctions.''
Activity in the corporate debt market was highlighted by the sale of $300 million of 30-year debentures for the United Technologies Corporation.
The 8 7/8 percent issue, which includes language to protect investors against so-called event-risk, was priced at $98.974, to yield 8.974 percent, one percentage point over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 1/8 percent bonds at the time of pricing.
Bear, Stearns & Company acted as lead manager on the transaction, which is rated AA-3 by Moody's Investors Service and AA-minus by the Standard & Poor's Corporation. The event-risk language was rated E-3 by S.& P. In response to falling interest rates, new corporate debt issuance last month soared by 57 percent from September levels, to $12.51 billion, analysts at Moody's reported yesterday. October was the most active month since May, when $14.21 billion worth of corporate debt was issued.
For the first 10 months of the year, companies have issued $93.97 billion worth of debt securities, Moody's said, up slightly from $92.35 billion issued over the coresponding period a year ago.
Activity in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds was light yesterday, dealers reported. Prices of most issues rose by about 1/8 of a point.
Participants in the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds said that prices of most issues also rose by about 1/8 of a point on slow trading.

HEADLINE: Venezuela to Buy Rest of Citgo

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Nov. 6

 BODY:
In what would be the first case of an OPEC member owning all of a large American oil refiner and marketer, Venezuela's state-owned oil company said today that it had agreed to acquire the remaining 50 percent of the Citgo Petroleum Corporation.
Petroleos de Venezuela, which bought half of Citgo from the Southland Corporation three years ago for $400 million, said it had reached a preliminary agreement to pay $675 million in cash for the rest of Citgo. Southland said the final terms of the deal were still being discussed.
Southland, which owns the 7-Eleven chain of convenience stores, said it would continue selling the Citgo brand of gasoline at pumps at its stores. The company, based in Dallas, has been selling assets to raise cash to lower debt taken on two years ago when Southland was taken private in a $4.9 billion buyout. 
 
Looking to the Future
Rosario S. Ilacqua, an analyst at Nikko Securities International Inc. in New York, said members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries wanted to assure future outlets for their oil production, and the United States was the world's biggest market.
Two other OPEC members, Saudi Arabia and Nigeria, have already made moves into the American market.
A year ago, Saudi Arabia paid $1.28 billion in cash and oil for 50 percent of Texaco Inc.'s refining and marketing system in 23 Eastern and Gulf Coast states. Last month, the National Petroleum Corporation in Nigeria signed an agreement to buy 49 percent of a Kansas refinery for an undisclosed amount from Farmland Industries.
''These foreign countries now have a vested interest in the U.S. refining and marketing industry,'' said Victor Burk, the managing director of Arthur Andersen & Company's oil and gas industry services program in Houston. ''They will be interested in maintaining as much stability as possible in the oil and gas industry.''
Last year, Citgo was the nation's ninth-largest gasoline marketer, selling 5.2 billion gallons, according to National Petroleum News, an industry publication. Most of its sales were through outlets in the South, Southwest and Midwest. Of its 7,700 retail outlets, 1,856 were 7-Eleven stores operated by Southland.
Citgo, based in Tulsa, Okla., has been increasingly profitable in recent years. It earned $75.7 million for the first half of the year, matching its profits from the corresponding period in 1988 - its most profitable year. Over all, the company's profits nearly doubled in 1988, to $165.6 million, compared with $85.7 million in 1987. Its sales last year totaled $4.1 billion, compared with $3.9 billion in 1987.
The company's prime asset is a large oil refinery in Lake Charles, La., which has a daily capacity of 320,000 barrels. Citgo also owns the fourth-largest refinery in North America for industrial lubricants, and a compounding plant in Cicero, Ill. The company valued its assets at $1.4 billion at the end of June.
Philip K. Verleger Jr., a petroleum economist who is a visiting fellow at the Institute for International Economics in Washington, said market values for refineries had risen along with gasoline demand in the United States.
He added that it was unclear how Petroleos de Venezuela would finance the purchase.
 
Request to Creditors
The drop in oil prices in the last three years has forced the Venezuelan Government to tighten its belt. The country's Minister of Planning, Miguel Rodriguez Fandeo, recently asked its bank creditors in the United States to write off half of their outstanding loans to his Government.
Markeeta McNatt, a Southland spokeswoman, said the company would apply all of the proceeds from the Citgo sale to reducing its bank debt, which totaled $1.54 billion at the end of June. The net cash proceeds from the deal should amount to more than $500 million, she said.
The spokeswoman said Southland was ahead of its goal to regain profitability by retiring most of the bank debt by 1993.
Southland has been on a financial tightrope for two years, since borrowing the $4.9 billion for the leveraged buyout in December 1987. It raised $744 million last year by auctioning 6 subsidiaries, 910 convenience stores and other properties.
 
Income Falls Short
But operating income for Southland's approximately 7,000 7-Eleven and other convenience stores has fallen short of the projections included in the buyout plan. In May, Jere W. Thompson, Southland's president and chief executive, said the company was considering the Citgo sale, as well as that of several distribution and food-processing centers.
Southland, the nation's 12th-largest retailer before it began shedding its assets, lost $236.4 million in the six months that ended in June, compared with a loss of $132.4 million in the 1988 period. Its interest costs were $287.4 million in the first half of the year, compared with $277 million.
The company acquired Citgo from the Occidental Petroleum Corporation in 1983 for $780 million.

CORRECTION-DATE: November 9, 1989, Thursday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Tuesday about the oil company Petroleos de Venezuela misstated aspects of the agreement to add the Southland Corporation's 50 percent stake in Citgo Petroleum to the 50 percent it already owned. Petroleos paid $290 million, not $400 million, for the stake that it bought in 1986. Southland says it is ahead of schedule in paying off $1.54 billion in bank debt due in 1993; it has not said it expects to become profitable by that year. Because of an editing error, the article also misattributed an estimate of the cash Southland would receive. The company did not provide a figure; $500 million was The Times's estimate, based on available information.

HEADLINE: Programs Send Dow Down 47.34

BYLINE: By PHILLIP H. WIGGINS

 BODY:
The stock market was engulfed in several waves of futures-related trading yesterday that sent the Dow Jones industrial average down 47.34 points, to 2,582.17.
While that is about 13 points higher than the level of 2,569.26 that the Dow reached on Oct. 13, when it plunged 190.58 points in a sudden selloff, most other major averages ended the day below their October lows, indicating that the post-Oct. 13 rebound has been almost erased.
Declines on the New York Stock Exchange, at 1,180, far outnumbered the 355 issues that gained in price, and that performance was reflected in the broader measures of the market.
 
S.&P. 500 Down 5.01 Points
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index lost 5.01 points, closing at 332.61, while the New York Stock Exchange composite index dropped 2.51 points, to 184.77. 
On the American Stock Exchange, the market-value index dropped 3.11 points, to 368.68, while in over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index plunged 4.95 points, to 448.02.
However, some market participants said that the Dow's 1.8 percent decline was exaggerated because it occurred in thin trading. Although New York Stock Exchange volume was up from 131.5 million shares on Friday, it was at a still slow 135.5 million shares yesterday.
 
Producer Prices Awaited
Robert E. Walsh, a portfolio manager at Jenswold, King & Associates in Houston, said, ''Investor complacency is likely to continue until the next meaningful clue on inflation is revealed on Thursday when the Producer Price Index for October is announced.''
A significant factor in the selling was index arbitrage programs that involved the selling of shares and the purchase of stock index futures, notwithstanding a plea last week by the Big Board that all traders refrain from program trades, which have been blamed for much of the market's volatility.
Market participants attributed some of the selling to continuing disappointment over third-quarter earnings, apprehension about fourth-quarter results and sharply lower bond prices.
The Dow was off nearly 15 points in the first half-hour of trading, stabilized a bit, and then began a slow but steady decline to a 45-point deficit about 2:30 P.M. It then recovered about 10 points, which one trader attributed to some buying programs. But it plunged again about a half-hour before the final bell.
The Big Board's proposed rules that would temporarily halt the use of exchange computers for program trades after the Dow has fallen as little as 30 points are not yet in effect because they are awaiting approval by the Securities and Exchange Commission, a Big Board spokeswoman said. No so-called circuit breakers that temporarily delay trading in either the stock or stock index futures markets were set off by the decline.
One stock index trader said that the sell programs occurred at the opening, 10:15 A.M., 11:10 A.M., 1:25 P.M., 2:10 P.M. and shortly before the final bell.
''My guess would be that most of the heavy program trading was done by investment advisory firms that do index arbitrage for institutional clients since many brokerage firms are on their best behavior in the current furor surrounding program trading,'' he said.
 
I.B.M. Declines 1 7/8, to 96 5/8
Among individual stocks, I.B.M. fell 1 7/8, to 96 5/8, trading as low as 96 1/2, the lowest level for that stock since early 1983. ''It's not computerized stock trading that is destroying this market; it's trading in computer stocks,'' one trader quipped. But Compaq, which plunged on disappointing earnings forecasts last week, recovered 3/4, to 89 3/4, as it introduced a new personal computer.
Amax was the most active stock, slipping 1/8, to 22 1/4. The stock went ex dividend yesterday.
Philip Morris was the second-most-active issue, falling 1 3/8, to 40 3/4. Allan Kaplan, an analyst for Merrill Lynch & Company, lowered his rating on the company to ''above average'' from ''aggressive buy,'' citing higher rates of taxation on tobacco at the state level.
UAL, the parent of United Airlines, fell 4 1/2, to 180 1/4, even though a principal in Conistan Partners said he remained optimistic that some type of transaction could be achieved at UAL.
Ryder System jumped 1 1/4, to 22 3/4, after the transportation services company announced that the Itel Corporation had indicated its intention to purchase at least $15 million worth of Ryder's stock. Itel, which is involved in container leasing, slipped 3/8, to 21 1/4.
Active blue chips yesterday included Ford Motor, off 1 3/4, to 43 7/8, and Chevron, down 4, to 64 5/8, as takeover speculation surrounding the company appeared to ebb.
Precious metals stocks continued last week's strength as Newmont Gold rose 1 7/8, to 43 7/8; Newmont Mining 1 1/2, to 42 7/8, and ASA 3/4, to 52 3/8.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Shearson Warns Staff More Cuts Are Likely

BYLINE: By SARAH BARTLETT

 BODY:
Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. warned its employees yesterday to brace for another round of layoffs in the next few weeks, and officials said privately that the number of those dismissed could be as high as 700 to 800 people.
Shearson's staff reduction would be the largest in many months on Wall Street, and it is likely to add to pressures on the local economy.
A spokesman for the company said the cuts would occur across the board, in all departments. But, he said, those with back office functions, like operations and systems management, are likely to be the most affected. At last count, the firm had 38,500 employees. 
Shearson executives attributed the layoffs to a continuing slowdown in the financial markets.
In a note to employees, Shearson said the decision had been taken after a review of the firm's expenses and in light of an impending move by a number of its employees to a new office building it has constructed in lower Manhattan.
In the third quarter, although commissions rose, Shearson's investment banking revenues were the weakest they have been for almost two years. That is a reflection in part of a dearth of corporate underwritings as well as a slowdown in the merger and acquisition business.
Like other firms, Shearson is also expected to have a decline in trading profits this quarter as a result of the stock market's recent plunge and the general pressure on takeover stocks.
Adding more pressure to Shearson is the fact that on Oct. 30, Moody's Investor Service placed Shearson's debt and commercial paper under review for a possible downgrade. In doing so, it cited the industry's profitability problems as well as Shearson's exposure to commercial real estate through one of its subsidiaries. A downgrade would raise the cost to Shearson of financing its activities.

HEADLINE: Philippine Debt Is Rescheduled

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: MANILA, Nov. 6

 BODY:
The Philippines and the United States have agreed to reschedule payments on $362.2 million of Manila's debt, the Philippine Finance Secretary, Vicente Jayme, said Sunday.
The United States was the first creditor to carry out an agreed rescheduling of Manila's $2.2 billion debt under a pact with the Paris Club. Mr. Jayme said the Philippines hopes to agree on rescheduling terms with 13 other club members before the end of this year. 
 
United States Ambassador
Nicholas Platt said the agreement provided ''a breathing space for the Philippine economy'' and was ''intended to support the democratically elected Government.''
President Corazon C. Aquino, who began state visits to the United States and Canada Saturday, said her trip would focus on increasing trade and investment and securing debt relief.

HEADLINE: Rules Issued to Saving Units; Losses Seen

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Nov. 6

 BODY:
Federal regulators today announced new, more stringent financial standards for the nation's savings institutions and predicted another heavy loss for the industry in the July-September quarter.
The financial standards, released by the Office of Thrift Supervision in Washington, will require owners of savings and loan associations to back their lending with more of their own capital starting Dec. 7.
The standards, required by savings-industry rescue legislation enacted three months ago, are intended to provide a bigger cushion of capital to absorb losses from bad loans before an institution fails. 
Speaking at the annual convention of the United States League of Savings Institutions here, James Barth, chief economist of the Office of Thrift Supervision, said industry losses would total at least $2.5 billion in the third quarter. If Mr. Barth's projections prove to be correct when the official third-quarter results are reported next month, it will be the best quarter since a $1.8 billion loss in the third quarter 1988.
 
Rate of Losses Slowing
Savings institutions lost a record $13.4 billion last year. This year's losses, $9.7 billion in the first nine months, are running slightly behind the 1988 pace.
Still, depositors withdrew about $9 billion more than they deposited in September, Mr. Barth said. This amount compares with $5.1 billion in August and is close to the record $10.8 billion in January, he said.
The thrift office estimated that 800 of the nation's 2,600 solvent savings institutions, holding about 45 percent of the industry's $1.3 trillion in assets, fall nearly $20 billion short of the new capital standard.
Brian P. Smith, the league's regulatory expert, said several hundred savings institutions would be able to reduce or otherwise adjust their balance sheets to meet the standard quickly. But about 300 will likely fail and several hundred others will take longer to comply, he said.
Because regulators will impose growth controls on institutions lacking capital, some customers of savings institutions may find it more difficult to get a loan, Mr. Smith said.
Mr. Barth said institutions have been anticipating the capital rules since the summer by selling assets, such as loans and real estate. In September, savings institutions sold $15 billion in assets, up from a record $13.4 billion in August.
 
Money Rift Imperils Closings
In another matter, the chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, L. William Seidman, warned that his agency might have to suspend closing the 260 failed savings institutions in its control unless Congress and the Administration resolve a money dispute in a few weeks.
The savings legislation enacted in August provides $50 billion to handle roughly 500 failed institutions. But the F.D.I.C. needs to borrow at least an additional $50 billion that would be repaid as it sold loans and real estate acquired from failed institutions, Mr. Seidman said.
Without the temporary money, the F.D.I.C. could either raise cash by the quick sale of properties once owned by savings institutions - a move likely to unsettle already depressed real estate markets - or it will have to keep money-losing institutions open, adding to the burden on taxpayers, he said.
The F.D.I.C., he said, is caught in a dispute between the Bush Administration, which wants the additional borrowing kept out of the Federal budget, and Democrats in Congress, who want the borrowing in the budget, which would swell the deficit by tens of billions of dollars and increase pressure on President Bush to agree to a tax increase.

HEADLINE: Bank Choice On Mexico

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 6

 BODY:
Mexico has received replies from 42 percent of its foreign creditor banks on a debt renegotiation plan, and 90 percent of them are opting to reduce principal and interest rather than grant new loans, the official news agency Notimex said today.
Notimex, quoting unidentified banking sources in New York, said the banks hold $21.8 billion of the $52.7 billion in private debt covered by the renegotiation agreement. 
The agreement, reached in July with a committee of 15 of the creditor banks, gives banks three options: they can cut principal, cut interest or grant new loans.
Notimex said 53 percent of the banks that have informed the creditor committee of their decisions are opting to cut principal, while 37 percent are cutting interest and 10 percent will make new loans.
The committee, which is headed by Citibank in New York, represents nearly 500 banks.
The renegotiation agreement has been hailed by Mexican officials as a big step toward resolving Mexico's foreign debt crisis. Mexico owes a total of more than $107 billion to private and government creditors. It is the second-largest foreign debt in the developing world.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Mostly Higher In Dull Day and Gold Rises

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar ended higher yesterday against most important currencies in quiet, uninspired trading.
Gold prices also rose. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery closed at $381.50 an ounce, up $3 from Friday. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted a late bid for gold at $380.25 an ounce, up $2.55.
Currency traders said technical factors within the market, fueled by continued firmness in interest rates, were largely responsible for the dollar's rise in New York. Overseas, trading was also described as featureless.
''It was very, very quiet; there's no particular trend at the moment,'' said a trader at a large Frankfurt bank.
In New York, the dollar rose to 143.85 yen, up from 143.25 yen Friday. The dollar fell to $1.5767 against the pound from $1.5685.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Friday's quotes, included: 1.85325 West German marks, up from 1.84675; 1.6245 Swiss francs, up from 1.6205; 6.2820 French francs, up from 6.2630; 1,356.50 Italian lire, unchanged, and 1.17075 Canadian dollars, down from 1.17235.
Late dollar rates in Europe, compared with Friday, were: 1.8517 West German marks, up from 1.8470; 1.6240 Swiss francs, up from 1.6210; 6.2805 French francs, up from 6.2620; 2.0910 Dutch guilders, up from 2.0825; 1,357.25 Italian lire, up from 1,356.25, and 1.1712 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1723.
Silver prices were mixed. On New York's Comex, silver for current delivery rose to $5.238 an ounce, from $5.227 late Friday.

HEADLINE: Careers;
Europeans Seek M.B.A. Candidates

BYLINE: By Elizabeth M. Fowler

 BODY:
EIGHT foreign business schools held a two-day forum in New York on Friday and Saturday to raise interest among prospective students. And some of their deans have been visiting around the country hoping to lure good teachers away from leading American graduate schools of business, permanently or temporarily.
As students entered the meeting room in the Essex House hotel, they were asked to fill out an application and they received a brochure with six colorful national flags on its cover -Dutch, Swiss, French, British, Spanish and Italian, denoting the nationalities of the business schools whose representatives manned tables around the room. The brochure was called ''Your M.B.A. in Europe.'' 
There is little doubt that thousands of young Americans aged 23 to 30 and over are interested in getting an M.B.A. abroad. The forum was attended by more than 500 prospective students.
The foreign business schools confirmed the interest. Claire Guedron-Pike, director of the M.B.A. program at the Institut Europeen d'Administration des Affaires, or the Insead Business School, in Fontainebleau, France, said: ''We had more than 3,000 applications from 50 countries for 420 vacancies this year. The 210 who started in September included about 21 Americans. The 210 who will start in January will include about the same number.''
Insead began in 1959, and for the first 10 years no women applied. ''One of our first woman graduates in 1968 was Helene Ploix, now an executive director of the International Monetary Fund in Washington,'' Ms. Guedron-Pike said.
Insead, unlike most American graduate business schools, has language requirements. Students must know English and French well enough to understand lectures in both languages. Before the intensive 11 months of study ends, they must pick up a third language, if they lack it. In contrast, the Rotterdam School of Management, which is part of Erasmus University in Rotterdam, the Netherlands, has classes in English.
Foreign language ability is not a strong point at American graduate schools of business, with exceptions like Thunderbird, the American Graduate School of International Management in Arizona, which emphasizes international affairs, but several have begun to stress foreign languages and look kindly on applicants who speak other languages in addition to English.
S.D.A. Bocconi, affiliated with the University of Bocconi, Milan, Italy, is bilingual, but Dr. Luigi V. Tava, the director of the M.B.A. program, spoke of a section to begin next fall where the teaching will be in English - a move to attract more English-speaking students. They are expected to pick up sufficient Italian late in the program to be literate in Italian. He also mentioned a new master's program for those not wanting an M.B.A. but needing management background for jobs with organizations like the International Monetary Fund.
'' I am going to Boston to Harvard Business School to persuade some professors to teach at our school during their sabbaticals next year,'' he said, indicating the difficulty for foreign schools at a time of a worldwide shortage of teachers with doctorates in business subjects.
The length of the programs varies as widely as the nationalities of the schools. For example, I.E.S.E., the Insituto de Estudios Superiores de la Empresa, which is affiliated with the University of Navarre and is in Barcelona, Spain, offers a two-year bilingual course in Spanish and English, with a summer in between for working on a company project, very much like traditional two-year programs at most American graduate business schools. Two - namely Insead and the International Institute for Management Development, or I.M.D., in Lausanne, Switzerland - offer accelerated M.B.A.'s that can be completed within a year of intensive work.
The cost of these schools is roughly in line with American business schools, although the comparison is not exact because of different student housing and eating arrangements as well as the length of study. For example, the I.M.D. program costs about $20,000 for the intensive yearlong program with free lunch and a month's vacation.
Interest in the foreign business schools has grown this year for varied reasons. More and more American companies recruit at major European business schools for international staffs. Some applicants want short, intense programs. Many like the idea of studying in Europe, looking ahead to 1992, when trade barriers drop - an economic challenge for business worldwide.
Some of the eight schools consider students on the basis of personality and experience, as well as the Graduate Management Admission Test. Most require personal interviews. But the number of openings is relatively small. Europe in recent years has been graduating 3,000 M.B.A. students a year from its leading schools compared with 70,000 in the United States.
The other schools represented at the forum were the Institut Superieur des Affaires, or I.S.A., in Jouy-en-Josas, France; the London Business School, London, and the Manchester Business School, Manchester, England.

HEADLINE: DINKINS DEFEATS GIULIANI IN A CLOSE RACE; WILDER SEEMS VIRGINIA WINNER, FLORIO IN; VOTERS, 5-4, APPROVE NEW YORK CHARTER;
FLORIO VICTORIOUS IN JERSEY BATTLE

BYLINE: By PETER KERR

 BODY:
Representative James J. Florio swept to a lopsided victory yesterday in the race for governor of New Jersey as voters rejected the campaign of his Republican opponent, Representative Jim Courter, who promised to fight crime, taxes and big government.
With 98 percent of 5,845 precincts reporting at 12:35 A.M. today, the vote was:
 
Florio 1,321,065 (62%)
 
Courter 794,633 (38%)
The Democrats also regained control of the State Assembly.
''One New Jersey that's cleaner and greener, that's what we strive for,'' Mr. Florio said last night before 800 jubilant supporters at the Ramada Renaissance Hotel in East Brunswick. ''We sent a message of hope and determination to those who believe, as I do, in a woman's right to choose.''
The Democrat will succeed the two-term Republican incumbent, Thomas H. Kean. 
 
Activist Approach Embraced
According to a New York Times/ WCBS-TV News Poll of voters leaving polling places, New Jerseyans overwhelmingly rejected the conservative message of Mr. Courter and embraced Mr. Florio's activist approach to government.
In a harsh campaign marked by sharply negative television ads by both candidates, Mr. Florio promised to crack down on the automobile insurance industry and environmental polluters.
Mr. Courter conceded at 9:20 P.M. before supporters at the Hanover Marriott Hotel in Whippany. Congratulating Mr. Florio, he said: ''Tonight we have fallen short of our goal, but we can hold our heads high because ours was a campaign of ideas and principles. Ours was a positive campaign.''
Sounding themes that contrasted sharply with the Democrat's, Mr. Courter had promised to extend the politics of Ronald Reagan into the 1990's in New Jersey. Above all, he promised to continue prosperity by keeping taxes from rising.
The two men clashed in a state that was blessed by enormous economic growth in recent years and where Governor Kean was highly popular. But it is also a state where voters are increasingly anxious about the congestion and pollution that growth have created.
Among the issues that propelled Mr. Florio to victory, the poll showed, were New Jerseyans' concerns over high automobile insurance premiums, the environment in the heavily developed state and abortion - issues that the Democrat stressed throughout the race.
 
Right to Abortion Backed
The poll showed that a majority of New Jersey voters wanted no changes in current abortion laws and that those concerned about abortion voted more than 2 to 1 for the Democrat.
Mr. Florio won in all areas of the state outside Mr. Courter's Congressional district, among whites and blacks, men and women. Three of 10 Republicans gave Mr. Florio their support, with Republican men and women voting for the Democrat in similar proportions.
In Congress Mr. Florio had opposed new restrictions on abortion, while Mr. Courter had voted in favor of several anti-abortion bills.
The issues that Mr. Courter hoped would carry him to victory - a promise not to raise taxes and to fight crime with a toughened death-penalty law -carried far less appeal to voters, the poll showed. And even among those who felt most strongly about taxes, Mr. Florio won.
 
Prosperity No Help
In addition, Democratic and Republican politicians said, Mr. Courter's campaign, coming off a tough primary against four other Republicans, suffered from poor organization in its early stages and difficulty in getting his message to the voters.
The New York Times/WCBS-TV News poll queried 1,642 voters as they left polling stations in 40 randomly chosen precincts across the state. The poll reports a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points. WCAU-TV, the CBS afffliate in Philadelphia, also sponsored the poll.
In a state carried by Republican Presidential and gubernatorial candidates throughout the 1980's, the poll found voters saying that they saw Mr. Florio as a moderate like themselves and the current Governor, Mr. Kean. Nearly half the voters described Mr. Courter as a conservative.
 
Fight Over Center Ground
From the start of the campaign, after the two men won their party nominations last June, each tried to portray the other as out of step with the majority of New Jerseyans. Mr. Florio described his opponent as an extreme conservative and himself as part of ''the sensible center.''
''If you liked Michael Dukakis,'' Mr. Courter said repeatedly, ''you'll love Jim Florio.''
Unaffiliated voters and Democrats helped give victories twice to Ronald Reagan, once to George Bush and twice to Mr. Kean. But in yesterday's race the Democrat held onto nearly nine of every 10 Democratic voters. The poll showed unaffiliated voters preferred Mr. Florio to Mr. Courter by more than 2 to 1.
Mr. Courter, whom the Democrats accused of ''flip-flopping'' on the abortion issue when he said that as governor he would not impose his personal anti-abortion beliefs on the public, also failed to gain strong support from anti-abortion voters. They split about evenly between Mr. Courter and Mr. Florio.
Mr. Florio, an eight-term Congressman from Camden County who wrote the nation's Superfund law, premised his campaign on the idea that New Jerseyans would elect a governor who was pro-government if that government was lean, effective and a protector of the environment.
 
Taxes and Crime Stressed
Mr. Courter, a six-term Congressman from the state's rural northwest, promised to solve the problem that has outraged voters more than any other -expensive automobile insurance - Mr. Courter proposed to deregulate the industry, which he said would allow competition to drive down prices.
''The state of New Jersey doesn't have bad drivers,'' he said many times. ''It has bad laws.'' But voters who listed automobile insurance as the most important issue in determining their vote favored Mr. Florio almost by 2 to 1, apparently accepting his message that big insurance companies, not big government, were to blame for high rates.
Among those who listed the environment as the most important issue in determining their vote, the margin for Mr. Florio was more than 2 to 1.
 
Negative Attacks Pay
The poll results also indicated that Mr. Florio had achieved some success with his early negative attacks on Mr. Courter, in which he accused his rival of lying and of leaving toxic wastes on land he owned.
The object of the attacks, political consultants said, was to portray Mr. Courter as dishonest before Mr. Courter could muster a similar charge. In addition the attacks were designed to put Mr. Courter on the defensive before he could get his message accross to the voters.
The poll showed that what mattered most about the candidates themselves in determining voters' preference was honesty. Those who considered honesty the most important factor favored Mr. Florio, 3 to 2.
 
Character Assaults Criticized
The campaign for governor this year was widely criticized as the nastiest in memory in the state. Both men assaulted each other's character and broadcast commercials that pictured their opponents as cartoon characters with noses resembling Pinocchio's.
The poll showed that New Jerseyans blamed both candidates about equally for the tone of the campaign.
After insurance, the environment and abortion, voters listed taxes as the issue that most influenced their vote. But those who listed taxes favored Mr. Florio. The other issues of crime, the death penalty and political corruption were each cited as most important by only one in 20 voters.
Voters also approved $590 million in five bond referendums to preserve New Jersey's shrinking tracts of undeveloped land, rebuild bridges, provide for the disabled, build prison cells and help prevent ocean pollution.
In his victory speech, Mr. Florio painted a picture of a state united.
''We showed the power of people coming together,'' he said. ''One New Jersey, where everyone's children are safe and free from drugs. One New Jersey, where all of us can turn on the faucet and be sure we have good clean water. One New Jersey that's cleaner and greener, that's what we strive for.''
 
How the Poll Was Conducted
The New York Times/WCBS-TV News exit poll is based on questionnaires completed by voters as they left polling places throughout New Jersey yesterday. WCAU-TV in Philadelphia also participated in sponsoring the poll.
The poll included 1,642 voters in 40 randomly selected precincts.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20, the results based on such samples should differ by no more than 3 percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking to interview all those who voted for governor of New Jersey.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of voter opinion on Election Day may introduce other sources of error into the poll.

HEADLINE: U.S. Scholars Say East Berlin Can't Turn Tide

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON

 BODY:
While they say the consequences of the sudden and mounting demonstrations in East Germany defy precise prediction, American scholars specializing in German and European affairs generally agree that the mass marches have gone beyond the point where force could be used to quell them.
''It's quite clear what's going to happen,'' said Ronald Asmus of the Rand Corporation in Santa Monica, Calif. ''It's the beginning of the end of one-party rule. The question is whether there remains enough substance for a second German state to exist.'' 
Mr. Asmus, fresh from a visit to East Germany, said the opposition was becoming more organized as it kept marching. Referring to the parades through East Germany's second-largest city, he said, ''In Leipzig, there isn't a party person to be seen, leaving the people in control of the city.''
Robert Gerald Livingston, director of the American Institute for Contemporary German Studies in Washington, described the East Germans as ''poised between anxiety and exhilaration.''
Like his colleagues, he noted that the Germans, by reputation, were an orderly, even submissive, people, adverse to messy uprisings. In addition, he said, ''East Germans have had no experience with democracy.''
''Basically, what I think is that you got the first German revolution from below,'' he said. Other attempts had historically either failed or had been imposed from above, like the West German democracy born under military occupation.
 
'Salvage Operation'
John Edwin Mroz, president of the Institute for East-West Security Studies in New York, said there were indications of ''a major debate in the Kremlin how far this situation can be allowed to go.'' He termed changes now offered by the party leader, Egon Krenz, a ''salvage operation.''
The present crisis, Mr. Mroz said, ''had built up, with no steam valves, to the explosion we now have.'' He said the East German uprising was distinct from the evolutionary processes in Hungary and Poland in that it had a far broader base.
In Lepzig, for instance, a ''vast majority'' of the work-age population from workers to students to artists had taken to the streets, he said.
George A. Carver Jr., a senior fellow at the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington. said, ''In having to cope with this kind of popular uprising, they can't move against it with tanks like they did in Hungary'' in 1956.
''This is going to cause some heartburn in the Soviet general staff, not to mention the East German Politburo,'' he said.
Mr. Carver suggested a degree of helplessness on the part of the East German authorities now that ''several genies are out of the bottle.'' He commented, ''I doubt that even Egon Krenz knows what's going on there.''
''I don't really see any easy way out and they, I'm sure, don't either,'' he said. ''But the Germans are not Hungarians or Poles, and I can't see the party letting itself be shoved aside.''
 
A Desire to Decamp
Mr. Carver said the East German economy had been considered the standard to which the rest of the Soviet bloc aspired. ''But the bulk of the population set their standards by what they see on their TV screens from the West,'' he said. (Most East Germans have been receiving West German broadcasts since the authorities long ago gave up efforts to jam them.) Among the ''genies out of the bottle,'' Mr. Carver cited the desire of many East Germans ''to decamp for the West.'' One reason for this, he said, is that they find life ''stifling and gray.''
Another reason was a mounting desire for reforms, posing a quandary for a party for which a monopoly on power remained essential. ''They want to push reforms past the point where a Communist state can't allow them and still remain a Communist state.''
Concerning such demands for power sharing, Mr. Carver said, ''I do not see that Krenz and the Politburo will want to go that way and become a carbon copy of the West German state, which is so much more effective.''

HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
Amid Winds of Change, A Summit Conference

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7

 BODY:
President Bush is meeting with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union early next month, he says, to get to know the cut of his jib as the two leaders face together the hurricane of history that is blowing across Europe.
But there will be more to it than that, of course. Summit conferences always produce something, even when that something is nothing -which is why many Presidents have been so reluctant to take part except when the outcome was more or less foreordained. It is far from that on this occasion. 
The pressures are already building in Washington and elsewhere. Some specialists on foreign policy argue that the United States must reassert its leadership, starting now, or West Germany and Japan, which share American values but not all American interests, will shape a post-postwar world that is not entirely to American tastes.
Others worry that in a rush to help Mr. Gorbachev put his new ideas into effect, the United States will forget that the Soviet Union still has selfish interests, too, in places like Vietnam, Afghanistan and Ethiopia.
For his part, Mr. Gorbachev clearly approaches this shipboard meeting off the coast of Malta - the Love Boat summit, as some would have it, or the Club Med summit -with a long shopping list. He needs help in trying to keep economic frustration from drowning political hopes in towns and cities all across the Soviet Union. He needs reassurance that the United States will not seek to profit too quickly or too greatly from the instability on his exposed western flank.
''Next year will be Gorbachev's most difficult year,'' a senior American official said, ''and that fact defines the context for Malta.''
But so does the political situation in the United States.
As the President prepares for his trip, liberals are calling for the diversion of scarce tax resources from tanks and warplanes to an assault on the nation's housing, education and drug problems. Some groups, like Sane/Freeze, advocate a 50 percent cut in military spending by the year 2000, which evokes far less derision now than it would have only a year ago. And some Democratic analysts think Mr. Bush is about to lose one of his party's most potent electoral weapons, its primacy on foreign policy questions.
''Events have taken away a club that Republicans have long used to beat Democrats over the head,'' says Geoffrey D. Garin, a poll taker who works for Democratic candidates.
But conservatives, who have played a large part in the President's success (even if many of them have never trusted him the way they trusted Richard M. Nixon and Ronald Reagan), will also be watching. They want Mr. Bush to exercise continued caution on arms control and, as Vice President Dan Quayle put it in California not long ago, to insist that the Soviet Union manage its reforms by itself.
''Mr. Bush probably cannot get through the fall without choosing,'' wrote Patrick J. Buchanan, the conservative commentator, who sees Malta as a key moment for the President. ''He will emerge either as a Dwight D. Eisenhower, splitting the difference with the Democrats, or in the Nixon-Reagan mold.''
But it is the riveting events in Eastern Europe that will supply the immediate backdrop for the talks between Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev. What will they say about Poland's new non-Communist Government, or the apparent disintegration of Hungary's Communist Party, or the migration of hundreds of thousands of East Germany's best and brightest young people to the West?
Many events are important. A few truly capture the world's attention. What is happening in Leipzig and Prague and Warsaw and even Sofia is both important and captivating, and no matter how hard the White House tries to play down expectations for this first East-West summit conference of the Bush Administration, the expectations will remain, here and abroad.
That common European home Mr. Gorbachev likes to talk about is under construction now, and people everywhere want to know what it will look like.

PUB-DATE: November 8, 1989

SECTION: Section A; Page 31, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 691 words

HEADLINE: Bush Nominates Watt II

BYLINE: By John B. Oakes; John B. Oakes is former Editorial Page Editor of The New York Times.

 BODY:
George Bush, who not so many years ago was justly critical of Ronald Reagan's ''voodoo economics,'' has become past master of an even more illusory art form: voodoo politics.
Nine months into his Presidency, despite constant admonitions to read his lips, it is rarely certain just what those lips are saying, and whether they mean today what they seemed to mean yesterday.
In no public issue is George Bush's voodooism clearer than in the crucial one of environmental protection. At the same time as he was proclaiming himself an ''environmentalist,'' President Bush promoted - to one of the most powerful environmental posts in Government - a proven anti-environmentalist named James E. Cason, who earned his spurs in the Interior Department as a faithful disciple of former Secretary James G. Watt and successors. The Senate is expected to vote within the next few days on Mr. Bush's nomination of Mr. Cason to be Assistant Secretary of Agriculture for Natural Resources and the Environment. 
This is not a minor office. Its incumbent is responsible for managing and protecting nearly 200 million acres of one of the nation's most critically threatened and valuable natural resources, the National Forest system. The Soil Conservation Service, too, would be under Mr. Cason's jurisdiction, directly affecting the wise management and sustainable productivity of America's rural farmland.
For these duties, Mr. Cason has neither professional, educational nor managerial qualifications. But he does have a record. In the highly strategic positions of Deputy and then Acting Assistant Secretary of the Interior for Land and Minerals Management, he worked assiduously on behalf of private timber, oil, gas, coal and speculative real estate interests without regard for the environmental considerations that were his sworn duty to protect.
Mr. Watt's protege worked not only against the environment but, consistently, against the taxpayer. Late last year, he approved a revision of Federal audit regulations that would have cost Federal and local governments - and saved 12 major oil companies - scores of millions of dollars in unpaid or underpaid royalties. Mr. Cason signed this deal on the stationery of the oil companies' attorneys.
In 1986, Mr. Cason approved granting title to some 82,000 acres of Federal oil shale land to private claimants, at a cost to them of $2.50 per acre. Some 17,000 of those acres were sold within a few weeks for $37 million. Two years later, while Congress was belatedly considering a change in the law that had made this unconscionable transfer possible, Mr. Cason rushed out to Colorado to urge more claimants to line up at the trough while they could. They did so by the thousands.
Mr. Bush's nominee played a particularly unethical role in the recent ''spotted owl'' controversy in Oregon, where timber operators and environmentalists fought over logging on federally protected lands. He attempted to distort in one case, and to suppress in another, scientific reports that came to conclusions unfavorable to the timber industry. His new post will place him in a stronger position than ever to disregard the law and help the loggers continue to undermine the shaky protection now afforded to the rapidly disappearing old-growth forests of the Pacific Northwest.
Only last December, he proposed, at potential cost to the taxpayer of hundreds of millions of dollars, to undercut existing protection of national parks and other fragile Federal lands against the threat of strip mining.
To every mining claimant, oil and gas developer, timber operator, coal producer, Mr. Cason's natural response from his former post at Interior was to shout: ''Come 'n' get it!'' And they came - to such an extent that at least four of his most dangerous decisions have had to be rescinded or reversed by the department in the last few months.
Now the Bush Administration is fighting to reward this proven anti-environmentalist with a position of even greater environmental signficance and power than the one in which he so miserably failed to carry out his trust.
The Senate has no decent choice but to reject him.

INDUSTRY: NAICS 213112 OIL & GAS INDUSTRY (87%); 

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (79%);

LENGTH: 773 words

HEADLINE: FOREIGN AFFAIRS;
Japan's Looking Glass

BYLINE: By Flora Lewis

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
The manuscript that is the rage of Washington, ''The Japan That Can Say 'No,' '' is beginning to cross the Atlantic. Europeans who know of it are appalled, though it is not about Europe and a lot of the America-bashing points are endorsed by European businessmen.
''American business is not serious,'' said a French investment banker. Akio Morita, chairman of Sony and co-author of the supposedly private document, puts it succinctly, saying Americans look ahead 10 minutes while Japanese look ahead 10 years. 
But there are ominous historical echoes in sections written by the other co-author, Shintaro Ishihara, a former Minister of Transport who is openly, imperatively nationalistic. They worry people who remember the World War II Axis.
Speaking of superconductivity as a key to the future, Mr. Ishihara writes: ''This type of technology does not exist anywhere in the Soviet Union or the United States. It exists only in Japan and West Germany. If the giants in the economic field and the politicians can join together around this type of technology, it would open up new possibilities for our advancement. Whether or not this can be achieved depends upon our large and small choices in the future; in sum it is a question involving the sensibilities of our politicians.''
This has to be read with other passages to get the nostalgic flavor. The writer deplores what he considers Japan's failure to free its mentality from ''the dregs of the postwar period.'' He notes economic successes in Korea, Taiwan and Singapore, pointing out they ''were all, at one time or another, under Japanese administration. We are aware that some negative things happened under the Japanese administration, but it cannot be denied that many positive things were left behind.'' That isn't the way other Asians remember Japanese occupation.
The document was supposed to be for internal consumption only, but was translated and sent to the U.S. Read on the plane from Washington to Paris, it brought another startling reminder of how many longstanding assumptions about the present world are collapsing before our eyes.
There are obvious and important differences in the co-authors' approach. Mr. Morita evidently means by learning to say ''no'' a switch from traditional Japanese equivocation to greater candor in dealing with foreigners. Mr. Ishihara means ''calling America's bluff'' with tough threats.
Mr. Morita says the U.S. is needed in the world and worries that if America can't restore effective production, ''we might go bankrupt together.'' Mr. Ishihara says Japan ''needs Asia more than America'' and suggests revoking its U.S. security treaty and establishing ''a much greater deterrent capacity'' of its own. An atom bomb ambition? Not clear.
But they agree that the U.S. is doomed as a superpower because of economic self-indulgence, indiscipline and executive greed. ''The time will never again come when America will regain its strength in industry,'' says Mr. Morita. ''We are going to have a totally new configuration in the balance of power in the world.''
Mr. Ishihara speaks more in anger and less in sorrow. ''There is no hope for the U.S.,'' he says, arguing that ''economic warfare is the basis for existence in the free world.'' At another point he foresees ''the end of the modern era as developed by white Westerners. History is entering a new period of genesis,'' perhaps an apposite remark to the thesis of Francis Fukuyama, a State Department official of Japanese ancestry, that history is ending with Communism's collapse.
No doubt this document we weren't supposed to see can be matched for Japan-bashing, jingoistic arrogance by some American supernationalists, pot and kettle. But there's truth in it.
Recognition of serious American flaws (Mr. Morita calls the gap between rich and poor ''outrageous'') should come as no surprise. We've been talking trade and budget deficits, homelessness, crime and drugs for years. The other day The New York Times reported that a 17-year-old model student who was shot to death haphazardly by a stranger was the eighth high school student killed in New York City in eight days.
But the revealing shock comes through foreign eyes, which strip away the illusion. Dramatic changes in the Soviet bloc offer unimagined opportunities for reshaping the world. There are great risks in the transition, but reason for great hopes. And there are new threats.
The Japanese document is irritating and in some parts ugly. Still it is useful. The greatest danger for America's future now comes at home. That is the basis for our place in the world and our value to the world.

SECTION: Section B; Page 6, Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1248 words

HEADLINE: THE 1989 ELECTIONS: Transition;
Changing of the Guard: Goal Is Slow and Easy

BYLINE: By FRANK LYNN

 BODY:
The style and tone with which David N. Dinkins will confront some of the most serious problems New York City has ever faced will be more reminiscent of former Mayor Robert F. Wagner - slow and easy - than of Edward I. Koch - fast and frenetic, Dinkins associates agree.
Like Mr. Wagner, who was known for keeping a quiet counsel while in office from 1954 to '65, Mr. Dinkins and his closest aides are reluctant to even discuss whom the Mayor-elect plans to take with him to City Hall. But Mr. Dinkins has indicated his preference for a strong first deputy mayor.
He and his allies - liberal Democrats and members of minorities and unions - will undoubtedly want to emphasize social welfare problems and promote programs to solve them. But that agenda could fall victim to the constraints of a budget whose deficit is likely to grow. 
''The economy of the city is slipping,'' Felix G. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, said yesterday. Mr. Rohatyn, a financier and an economic adviser to Mr. Dinkins, said that to stop the decline the new administration would have to cut costs, keep wage increases to a minimum in city worker contracts and drastically reallocate resources away from politically sensitive institutions, like community school boards.
 
Harking Back to '53
Unlike the fiscal problems Mr. Dinkins faces, the changing of the guard at City Hall may be the smoothest since 1953. That was when another Manhattan Borough President, Mr. Wagner, prepared to walk across Centre Street from the Municipal Building to City Hall to replace a fellow Democrat, Vincent R. Impellitteri.
The expected ease of the transition, in which Mr. Dinkins will become the city's first black mayor, does not diminish its historical significance. But it contrasts with the experience in other cities, where the election of a first black mayor was more of a revolution than an evolution.
New York's Democratic establishment will likely remain in control. Its members, in and out of government, deal easily with each other, even in heated primary campaigns.
Heads will roll, but quietly. There will be no demands for mass resignations. And some Koch administration officials will not resign; some have passed the word that they would like to stay. A number of them are considered close to Mr. Dinkins.
Several of Mr. Dinkins's associates did not agree on just how bold Mr. Dinkins's appointments would be.
 
'Should Set a Standard'
His campaign manager and perhaps most trusted associate, Bill Lynch, said that the Mayor-elect ''is very conscious that he is the first black mayor and should set a standard.''
Barbara J. Fife, another member of the group that has run the Borough President's office while Mr. Dinkins ran for mayor, said, ''David has been a player in city government, not an outsider.''
Nathan Leventhal, the president of Lincoln Center and a former Koch deputy mayor who heads an unofficial transition planning group appointed by Mr. Dinkins, noted, ''You can have a smooth transition and still have profound changes.''
Basil Paterson, a close Dinkins associate, said he thought the Mayor-elect ''has to stamp a new image.'' But he added: ''That doesn't mean he's going to do it. He might be more comfortable with some of the familiar faces.''
 
Gathering on Central Park West
Mr. Paterson is also a member of the transition planning group, which has been meeting mostly in Mrs. Fife's Central Park West apartment and which may foreshadow what a Dinkins administration might be like.
Mr. Leventhal, Mr. Paterson and another member, Gordon Davis, a lawyer, were high officials in the early Koch administration; Mr. Paterson is also one of the most influential black politicians in the city and state.
Mrs. Fife, a liberal Democrat and veteran of many campaigns, is likely to play a major role in the Dinkins administration. The fifth member, Victor Kovner, another liberal Democrat and an anti-Koch veteran of the political wars, is best known for his influence in selecting judges. A close adviser to Mr. Dinkins, he is already unofficially the first appointee of the new administration as corporation counsel.
All are Manhattan Democrats, but an expanded post-election transition committee may be announced as early as today when Mr. Dinkins meets with the original group.
 
Business Is Watching
The city's finances will dominate the next administration; therefore, Mr. Dinkins's main appointments are expected to be his first deputy mayor, the director of the Office of Management and Budget and director of municipal labor relations. These are considered crucial positions because potentially budget-breaking city labor contracts expire in mid-1990.
Mr. Rohatyn said that the financial and business interests in New York will be watching whom Mr. Dinkins appoints as budget director, deputy mayor for operations and deputy for economic development.
Mr. Davis, one of the members of the transition group, put it more colorfully. ''Moody's and Standard and Poor may not vote on Election Day, but they start voting the day the mayor picks a budget director.''
Different mayors have handled the question of deputy mayors differently. Some have made their deputies equal to one another, as Mr. Koch did early in his tenure. Others have had strong first deputies, as Mr. Koch now has in Stanley Brezenoff. Mr. Dinkins has told friends that he wants a strong deputy.
 
Rumors Abound
Among the documents the transition group will give the Mayor-elect are charts showing the organization of City Hall under the last three mayors, who at various times relied on chains of command built around many deputy mayors or special assistants.
This morning Mr. Brezenoff will give Mr. Dinkins's representatives a memorandum from each city agency listing current programs, priorities and immediate problems. The stack of paper was a half-foot high two days ago.
City Hall has been rife with rumors, most of them mentioning names associated with the Koch administration or those of his two predecessors, Abraham D. Beame and John V. Lindsay. But in interviews, many of those mentioned - including Mr. Paterson, Mr. Levanthal, Mr. Davis and the former City Council president, Carol Bellamy - said they intended to remain outside government.
Two of Mr. Dinkins's closest associates are also unlikely to join a Dinkins administration. They are Representative Charles B. Rangel of Harlem and Percy E. Sutton, the former Manhattan Borough President who in 1977 was the first serious black candidate for New York City mayor. Mr. Sutton is also the wealthy head of the Inner City Broadcasting Corporation, the company at the center of a campaign furor over Mr. Dinkins's stock holdings.
 
'Slow and Steady'
Leading the list of potential Dinkins appointees are Mr. Lynch; Mrs. Fife; Harold Ickes, the campaign counsel and strategist; Kenneth Sunshine, another top campaign aide who is a young veteran of the political wars, and Betsy Gotbaum, an investment banker who was the campaign's chief fund-raiser.
Mr. Paterson said he hoped the Dinkins administration ''hits the ground running.'' But Mr. Lynch, like his boss, is known for his thinking a long while before acting.
Mark Green, the public-interest lawyer and a Dinkins adviser, said Mr. Dinkins followed ''the tortoise strategy'' in his campaign - ''slow and steady wins the race.'' Several Dinkins colleagues predicted he would adopt the same strategy in his early days at City Hall.

HEADLINE: THE 1989 ELECTIONS: Governor-Elect
MAN IN THE NEWS: James Joseph Florio;
Careful and Determined

BYLINE: By PETER KERR

 BODY:
One day last month, a tired James J. Florio was jogging with a longtime friend in Central Park when the two middle-aged men pulled around a curve to face a sharp incline in the road. The friend stopped to rest. Mr. Florio broke into a sprint.
''He felt he had to test himself,'' recalled the friend, Lewis Katz. ''He felt that he should be fully winded before he stopped.'' 
Self-discipline and a drive for perfection have been constants throughout the life of Mr. Florio, the 52-year-old Congressman from Camden County who rose from being a tough street fighter and high school drop-out to become a respected member of the House and, now, the Governor-elect of New Jersey.
His victory came at the end of a campaign that many politicians regarded as almost error-free, though also perhaps one of the most negative in New Jersey history. It was the result of assiduous planning that Mr. Florio, a Democrat, began almost eight years ago after he lost a race for governor by 1,787 votes to Thomas H. Kean, a Republican. After studying his mistakes from that loss and to make sure that they were not repeated, Mr. Florio this year put together a campaign of which he demanded that everything be done right.
''Ladies and gentlemen, help me avoid that aggravation again,'' he said at a campaign stop Sunday with his wife, Lucinda, near him. ''I don't need it. Lucinda doesn't need it.''
 
A Different Vision
The man who will succeed Mr. Kean in Trenton is an unabashed advocate of government; lean and effective government, Mr. Florio promised voters. In this he has a far different vision from those offered by Ronald Reagan and George Bush when they carried New Jersey in three elections in the 1980's, campaigning on the theme that government was the problem, not the solution.
James Joseph Florio was born on August 29, 1937, in Brooklyn, the son of a painter in the Brooklyn Navy Yard. After the war, when his father lost his job, Mr. Florio recalls, the family struggled. At age 12 he developed an almost fanatical work schedule and a spartan sensibility.
''My philosophy has always been, I have one pair of shoes because I have one pair of feet,'' he said. ''My father always worked, always worked very hard. It is just beyond comprehension that anyone would not.''
At age 17 Mr. Florio dropped out of high school to join the Navy, where he fought as an amateur boxer and received blows that crushed his left cheekbone, leaving half of his face permanently sunken.
On his return, he earned a high school equivalency diploma, considered becoming a New York City policeman, but decided to attend Trenton State Teachers College, where he graduated magna cum laude in 1962 with a degree in social studies.
Later he took graduate courses at Columbia University on a Woodrow Wilson Fellowship, and in 1967 he received a law degree from Rutgers Law School. As a law student he worked at night as a janitor to support his wife and three children. Mr. Florio was later divorced.
At 25, he went to work as a district leader with the Camden Democratic machine and pursued politics with the same energy. Starting with an Assembly race in 1969, Mr. Florio ran for public office 15 times in 20 years.
During that time almost all the factories in the city of Camden shut down and its white work force moved out. The new suburbanites, often enraged at the city and minorities, were pried loose from the Democratic coalition by Republicans during the Nixon and Reagan years.
But Mr. Florio developed a political style that appealed to both the new suburbanites and the poor minorities remaining in the cities, stressing issues like the environment, transportation and day care that defied easy labels of left and right.
In 1974 he defeated the conservative Republican congressman, John E. Hunt, and went on to be re-elected seven times. New Jersey politicians say his working weekends and visits to constituents made him a familiar face in every volunteer firehouse and veterans hall in the district.
In the House, Mr. Florio earned the respect of Democratic colleagues for his record on consumer issues, transportation and the environment. He wrote the 1980 Superfund law that allocated billions of dollars to clean up toxic-waste sites.
Public policy became his passion; he was known to work nights and weekends studying issues and legislation.
''If an issue is in his area of interest, he knows it cold,'' said Robert G. Torricelli, Democrat of Hackensack.
In 1979, Mr. Florio led a rebellion against the Democratic machine dominated by Mayor Angelo J. Errichetti of Camden. Mr. Florio's supporters have since dominated politics in the county.
Mr. Florio first ran for governor in 1977, when he finished fourth in a field of 10 Democrats vying for the nomination. In 1981, as his party's nominee, he watched a substantial lead over Mr. Kean in the polls slip away in the last weeks. The vote was so close that it took a month of recounting ballots before Mr. Kean was declared the victor.
Critics pointed out that in 1981 Mr. Florio lost the race by stressing America's ills and attacking the policies of Mr. Reagan, who just months earlier had won in New Jersey. They pictured Mr. Florio as a man out of touch with the times.
 
The Technocrat's Image
In addition, opponents said that the 1981 race revealed Mr. Florio as a brusque loner and technocrat, well-versed in public policy but insensitive to people. Republicans relished the contrast to Mr. Kean and Mr. Reagan, who campaigned in the state as avuncular leaders of a reborn party.
This year Mr. Florio addressed both of those criticisms in a carefully planned campaign that presented new arguments for his policies and a new persona for the public.
He praised New Jersey's seven years of economic growth under the Republicans, but said that good times had brought worries about overdevelopment and pollution that required an active government to solve.
In a detailed recounting of voting records, Mr. Florio contended that he was closer to the popular Mr. Kean on the issues than his Republican opponent, Representative Jim Courter.
Again, with hard work (and under the influence of his new wife, Lucinda, and his two new grandchildren, campaign aides say) he altered his image. Television cameras frequently found him crouching to ask a child her name with Lucinda by his side, radiating affection. In recent days Mr. Florio told gathering after gathering that his grandson, a todler, had just awarded him the title of ''Pop-pop.''
At its heart, the campaign seemed to integrate both the political man and the private one: a faith that with hard work and revitalized government, America can keep its promise of a better life for its children.
Mr. Florio said at one campaign stop: ''I want to make sure there is opportunity for the next generation.''

GRAPHIC: James J. Florio, who was elected governor of New Jersey, after voting yesterday in Blackwood (The New York Times/William E. Sauro)

LENGTH: 563 words

HEADLINE: THE 1989 ELECTIONS: Legislative Race;
Democrats Win The Assembly In New Jersey

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN

 BODY:
Democrats recaptured control of the New Jersey Assembly yesterday the same way they lost it four years ago: in a landslide victory by a candidate for governor.
In 1985 it was a lopsided re-election victory by the Republican incumbent, Thomas H. Kean, that ended 16 years of Democratic control and gave his party a 50 to 30 majority in the 80-member house. That margin was whittled to 41 to 39 in subsequent elections, and yesterday, as Representative James J. Florio swept into the governorship, Democrats regained control. 
''Our victory was so broad and so deep we have won control of the Assembly,'' Mr. Florio told his supporters in East Brunswick last night.
Steve DeMicco, the director of the Democratic committee that coordinated the Assembly races, and Cliff Pintak, director of the Assembly Republican campaign, both said the Democrats had won from 42 to 45 seats to capture the Assembly.
 
'Definite Coattail Effect'
''There was a definite coattail effect from the win'' by Mr. Florio, ''and it became a tug of war for us to try to make up ground,'' Mr. Pintak said.
The change in control sets the stage for the election of a new Assembly Speaker and the man first in line is the Assembly minority leader, Willie B. Brown of Newark.
However, Mr. Florio could lend his support to someone from his own part of the state, the deputy minority leader, Wayne R. Bryant of Camden County.
The other deputy leaders, Joseph V. Doria Jr. of Bayonne and John Paul Doyle of Brick Township, are also said to be interested in the Speakership.
The Assembly races had the same general themes as the gubernatorial campaign: automobile insurance, the environment, taxes, drugs, gun control and - in a few districts where sharp lines could be drawn - abortion.
The new Assembly will join the Democratic-controlled Senate in January in facing some new economic realities and some stubborn old problems, including the state's expensive automobile insurance system.
 
A Kean-Florio Budget
Soon after they are sworn, the new Assembly members will receive a budget proposal from Mr. Florio, even though it will be more a product of the Kean administration than of Mr. Florio's transition staff.
The Legislature and the governor will then have until June 30 to adopt a balanced budget. Because the slowing state economy has produced lower-than-anticipated tax revenues, that first budget may the last that the new governor and new lawmakers can adopt without new taxes or drastic spending cuts.
Eight years ago Governor Kean and the Democratic-controlled Legislature also found it necessary to raise taxes.
 
School Tax Ruling Soon
An issue that was not evident in the recent campaigns, however, could prove to be overriding. The New Jersey Supreme Court will rule soon on the constitutionality of the state's system of financing public education, and that decision could force a revision to the state's tax system.
The case focuses on many of the same arguments the court faced in 1973, when it ruled that the state's reliance on property taxes to finance public education discriminated against children in poorer urban districts.
Critics now contend that even though the state enacted an income tax and raised aid to schools, the reliance on local property taxes is still too great and the imbalance between city schools and affluent suburban ones continues.
