HEADLINE: THE 1989 ELECTIONS: The Virginia Contest
MAN IN THE NEWS: Lawrence Douglas Wilder;
From Confrontation to Conciliation

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RICHMOND, Nov. 7

 BODY:
The story of L. Douglas Wilder is the story of a provocative outsider to a pragmatic insider, and in the process made history.
It is a story of growth, in a man and in a state, and how that state, the heart of the Confederacy and about 80 percent white, gave broad backing to that man, a grandson of slaves, as its governor.
In Doug Wilder, Virginians are getting a 58-year-old chief executive whose life began on the ragged edge of poverty, amid virulent racism, but whose record is one of steady achievement: decorated Korean War soldier, self-made millionaire trial lawyer, 16-year veteran of the State Senate and some of its major committees, Lieutenant Governor and the country's highest-ranking black elected official for the past four years.
But Mr. Wilder's record is not without smudges. He was reprimanded by the Virginia Supreme Court in 1978 for ''unexcused, unreasonable and inordinate procrastination'' in handling a client's case. He is also a landowner whose investment property was cited several times by community groups and officials in Richmond for being rundown, a taxpayer who has not always made the payment deadline, a politician whose ambition sometimes has been so headlong that it has hurt the cause of his own Democratic Party. 
This fall, the Republican gubernatorial candidate, former Attorney General J. Marshall Coleman, repeatedly cited these omissions and commissions as evidence that Mr. Wilder tended to ignore or sidestep the important details of life.
 
Symbolic and Tangible Change
Mr. Wilder's political journey, from precinct rallies to the Governor's Mansion, took 20 years, a period of great personal and political evolution.
He is far different from the man who showed up in January 1970 to be sworn in as a state senator. He is as quick as ever with a quip, even quicker with a politician's toothy smile, and he still loves a good argument, a meaty issue, a loud party. But other things have changed, some only symbolic, others tangible, all important.
Back in 1970, Mr. Wilder sported flamboyant shirts and a bushy Afro and his agenda, as the first black state senator since Reconstruction, called for establishing a holiday to honor the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., passing fair-housing laws, abolishing the death penalty and expunging the words ''massah'' and ''darkie'' from the official state song, ''Carry Me Back to Old Virginia.''
His manner was often confrontational, and his tongue could be as tart as vinegar. In his first speech as Senator, a moment usually reserved for inanity, Mr. Wilder scolded his colleagues, telling them that the state's treatment of blacks had been ''shameful.''
Today, the Afro has given way to a conventional coif, the shirts are buttoned-down pinstripes, black state legislators are no longer a novelty and the Wilder agenda is conventionally, conservatively mainstream, which is where the votes are in Virginia. His call is not for righting old wrongs but for fiscal responsibility, better roads and schools, cracking down on drugs and imposing the death penalty on drug kingpins.
The old tartness still flashes now and again, but mostly it is submerged beneath a soft and even courtliness. While he still loves a good party, a game of pool and his two Mercedes roadsters, he has acquired a taste for baroque music, and sometimes, in those few moments he takes off from politics, he dips into a Greek or Roman classic.
He lives on Richmond's North Side, several miles from where he was reared, and on those rare nights he is home for dinner he often cooks barbecue, using a sauce whose recipe he refuses to share.
 
Calculated Compromise
In sum, he is a politician who has become an establishmentarian, a man who has gradually replaced deliberate confrontation with calculated compromise. For example, while campaigning this fall, Mr. Wilder pragmatically surrounded himself with white aides, aware that a mostly black entourage might stir second thoughts among the state's predominantly white electorate. He insisted time and again that race was not a campaign issue, that voters should be concerned only with his government experience and with his platform.
Race, of course, was an issue, to a degree, though by the end of the campaign it was obvious that it was no longer a very exploitable one in Old Dominion politics.
''Times change, things change, people change,'' is the way the Governor-elect explains his moderated appearance and his movement from the political left toward the center.
Among the ''things'' that have changed are the demographic and economic makeup of Virginia. In recent years, as more and more Federal workers, lawyers and lobbyists moved to the Northern Virginia suburbs of Washington and as more and more military spending and personnel poured into the state, the Old Dominion has moved toward the middle from well to the right.
The state that required a young Doug Wilder to drink from 'Colored Only' public fountains and to attend segregated schools is now referred to by some as the ''New Dominion.'' It more nearly resembles a booming border state than a never-say-die slice of Dixie. In the state's most populous areas, two of every three voters were born in some other state.
 
Skill in Abortion Issue
Mr. Wilder's strong showing like that of four years ago, can be attributed in good part to his adroitly positioning himself to take advantage of the changes in Virginia, and his handling of the abortion issue is perhaps the best measure of how well he understands his state.
He strongly favored abortion rights, while his opponent opposed abortion except to save the pregnant woman's life, raising the possibility that Mr. Coleman might be able to use the issue to tag Mr. Wilder as a liberal. But Mr. Wilder spun the issue on Mr. Coleman so effectively that it was probably the crucial element in his victory. He argued that Mr. Coleman's position was the stand of zealots, and that a true Virginia conservative would never permit zealots to trample the Constitution by limiting individual rights.
Through his years in public life, Mr. Wilder's opponents have frequently charged that he lacks fixed political principles, that he is a rank opportunist. But the voters have never really seemed to buy that argument.
 
Thrift and Hard Work
Mr. Wilder was born on Jan. 17, 1931, in Richmond's Church Hill section. His father, Robert, whose parents were born into slavery in Virginia in the 1830's, sold insurance and his mother, Beulah, worked as a maid.
The Wilders were never dirt-poor but had to save their pennies. Lawrence Douglas, the seventh of their eight children, grew up in a stable home in which the verities of honest labor, Baptist church on Sunday and a good education were ingrained.
After graduating from high school in 1947, Mr. Wilder enrolled at Virginia Union University, a black school in Richmond. Tuition was only $100 a semester, and he could live at home. He took a degree in liberal arts, keeping in the back of his mind that he might go on to study law.
But before that could happen, he was drafted into the Army and within a few months found himself as an infantryman on the front line in Korea. He won a Bronze Star on Pork Chop Hill for braving artillery fire, aiding wounded comrades and helping capture 20 enemy soldiers.
It was in Korea that Mr. Wilder first spoke up about civil rights. Some fellow black infantrymen were complaining that even though President Harry S. Truman had ordered the Army desegregated, whites were still getting all the promotions. Mr. Wilder took their case to his commanding officer, and thereafter blacks in the outfit began to win promotions. Among them was Mr. Wilder, who left the service in late 1953 as a sergeant.
 
Establishing a Reputation
In 1956, after working various odd jobs around Richmond, Mr. Wilder went to Washington and, using his veterans benefits, enrolled in the Howard University School of Law. He graduated three years later.
While a student, Mr. Wilder courted and married Eunice Montgomery, an economics major from Philadelphia. They had three children: Lynn Diana, now 30; Lawrence Douglas Jr., 27, and Loren Deane, 26. In 1978 the Wilders divorced, with the court papers being sealed. Mr. Wilder remains single, and when he goes to public events he is often accompanied by his daughter Loren.
After graduation, he returned to Richmond, and within a decade, he had established himself as one of the city's more successful trial lawyers, although, as the State Supreme Court was to say, he sometimes let details and deadlines slip.
He had also established himself as one of the city's leading blacks and, on that basis, decided to enter politics in 1969 when one of Richmond's seats in the State Senate became vacant. With the help of a heavy black turnout - the city's electorate was about half black - and a split in the white vote, he carried the day.
Mr. Wilder eventually become a power in the General Assembly, partly through seniority and partly though using compromise and pragmatism. But at times he rankled his Democratic colleagues by throwing around his political muscle, once threatening to run a splinter campaign for a United States Senate seat if the party convention did not pull back from nominating someone he viewed as too conservative. In the Democrats' disarray, a Republican won the seat.
Another time Mr. Wilder, as Lieutenant Governor, publicly criticized a major tax initiative that the Democrats had struggled to pass to finance badly needed highway construction in the state's booming areas. He argued it was regressive.
Shortly after that, Charles S. Robb, a former Democratic Governor who was elected United States Senator in 1988, sent Mr. Wilder a letter that concluded: ''Your credibility with most key participants in the political process is disappearing rapidly and many who have supported you in the past are no longer sure you can be trusted.''
 
Practicing Coalition Politics
But by 1984, Mr. Wilder's political stature was such that he felt confident enough to try for the lieutenant governorship. The manner of announcing his candidacy tipped off how he planned to win: He stood in the State Capitol before a portrait of the late Senator Harry F. Byrd Sr., the conservative's conservative in the Old Dominion and an architect of Virginia's ''massive resistance'' to court-ordered desegregation.
''I believe in coalition politics,'' Mr. Wilder declared.

ECONOMY
 
Four Senators tried to persuade a regulator to drop a regulation that would have stopped Lincoln Savings and Loan from making the risky investments that eventually led to its demise, the former head of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said. [Page D1.]

HEADLINE: Times, Citing an Ad Slump, Will Close a Printing Plant

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES

 BODY:
The New York Times announced yesterday that advertising volume had declined so much in the last two years that it would shut its northern New Jersey printing plant by the end of next year as part of its overall strategy to reduce costs.
Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, publisher of The Times and chairman of The New York Times Company, told union leaders that the printing plant in Carlstadt, N.J., would be closed and its operations transferred to a plant under construction in Edison, N.J.
''We must find ways to reduce our costs to weather what might well be a growing storm,'' Mr. Sulzberger told the union leaders, who had gathered at his invitation in the company's board room.
While the unions were expecting a reduction in jobs when the highly automated Edison plant began operations, the consolidation will probably mean even greater reductions.
George E. McDonald, president of the Allied Printing Trades Council, an umbrella organization for the city's newspaper unions, responded to Mr. Sulzberger's announcement: ''We'll start talking about it now so we don't stumble into a lot of extra problems. We're committed to work together.'' He said unions would negotiate any changes from a united front. Talks with individual unions are to begin in the near future. 
Lance R. Primis, the president of The Times, said the paper was prepared to work with its unions, and mentioned the possibility of buyouts and contributions to union welfare funds as an inducement to long-term staff reductions. The Times employs about 1,100 at Carlstadt.
The Times did not say to what extent it hoped to reduce its staff.
Kevin R. Gruneich, a newspaper analyst for First Boston, called The Times's decision ''clear-eyed.''
''The economic deterioration seen within The Times's market demanded a radical move by Times management, and I think this is delivery of such a move,'' he said.
The Times said no decision had been made on what it would do with the Carlstadt plant.
The plan was announced after the financial markets closed yesterday. On the American Stock Exchange, the company's shares gained 25 cents, to $26.75.
For readers of The Times, one significant aspect of the announcement is that it delays the paper's long-range plans to become a full-color paper.
 
Plan for Sunday Color Unchanged
But the consolidation will not alter the paper's plan for printing some sections of the Sunday issue in color, which was originally to be the sole function of the Edison plant. Color will be restricted to sections that are printed in advance, including Travel, Arts and Leisure, Sunday Business and The Book Review. The Magazine and the television section are printed commercially.
Mr. Primis said the Edison plant would begin some operations early next year.
Mr. Primis said that paying for the Edison plant, which will cost more than $400 million, would reduce the paper's earnings by $38 million annually for many years through depreciation charges.
He said the paper hoped to recapture a substantial amount of this expense through reductions in labor costs, though he said he did not expect to achieve such saving immediately. He declined to outline precisely what saving The Times hoped to realize from each union.
The Times's advertising volume declined in 1988 by 5.4 percent from 1987 and has dropped again this year. Mr. Primis estimated that ad volume for 1989 would be below 1984 levels and that there would be a further decline in 1990. The drop has been particularly significant in real estate, help wanted, automotive, financial and retail advertising, big components of many Sunday sections.
 
'87 Market Crash Hurt
The stock market collapse in October 1987 prompted a sharp decline in financial advertising. That, combined with a downturn in the economy of the New York area, has hurt advertising sales throughout the region.
On the job front, The Times's hands are partly tied because of six-year contracts that expire in March 1993. Under those contracts, staffing levels at the Edison plant are to be negotiated after the equipment is in place, with binding arbitration to resolve any disputes if agreement cannot be reached.
While that contract was signed with the expectation that the Edison plant would produce only Sunday sections, Mr. Primis said its provisions apply to the consolidation.
The Times acquired the Carlstadt plant in 1975 and installed black-and-white presses, which are used to print many Sunday sections and about 40 percent of The Times's daily papers. The daily circulation is 1.1 million. A similar number are printed at the paper's headquarters on 43d Street in Manhattan; about 20 percent are printed at plants around the country. $1 Billion Investment When The Times's board gave approval in 1987 to proceed with the Edison plant, the Carlstadt operation was expected to be used to publish the daily paper, and, eventually, to have new color presses installed. An additional new color printing plant was expected to replace the printing in the 43d Street building, with the total investment estimated at $1 billion.
Mr. Sulzberger said yesterday that the 43d Street plant would remain as it is until the advertising marketplace improves significantly.
The board approved construction of the Edison plant in anticipation that advertising volume would continue to grow as it had in much of the 1980's.
In 1987, The Times published almost 19 percent more advertising than in 1983, and the number of pages had grown to the point that a new printing plant was needed.
Mr. Primis said that as a result of the advertising decline, the Edison plant alone would be sufficient to handle daily and Sunday printing. That made the Carlstadt plant redundant, he said.
To facilitate an agreement on the installation of modern presses that require fewer workers at the Edison plant, The Times negotiated special provisions with the Newspaper Printing Pressmen, whose 500 members were considered crucial to the new operation. 10-Year Agreement Unlike other unions, the pressmen negotiated a 10-year agreement that will keep staffing of the new automated color presses at roughly the levels of the black-and-white presses now in operation.
Mr. Primis said he hoped the pressmen would agree to renegotiate staffing. He said The Times realized that a significant inducement, like a generous buyout offer, would be required.
He noted that securing press staffing reductions is a principal target of The Daily News in its coming negotiations. Mr. Primis said The Times was likely to seek any concessions The Daily News secured.
John P. Kennedy, president of the union, said he would be reluctant to reopen the contract's staffing provisions ''absent a great deal of incentive to do so.''

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Rise On Sign of Fed Easing

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
A sign that the Federal Reserve Board might be easing monetary policy sent prices of Treasury securities surging yesterday.
The Fed's move pleasantly surprised traders and many analysts.
After a stronger-than-expected October employment report was released Friday, market participants reluctantly concluded that the central bank would not act soon to push rates lower, possibly not until early in 1990.
But that view changed swiftly yesterday, after the Fed added to reserves to the banking system when the overnight Federal funds rate -the rate it most closely controls -traded at 8 11/16. By late in the day, the funds rate was at 8 1/2 percent, down from the 8 3/4 percent level where it was since early October. 
The Fed's action had an entirely salutary effect on prices of secondary Treasury issues. But some traders questioned whether the move might alter investor interest in the quarterly refunding auctions. Those were delayed on Monday, but now can be held after Congress last night passed legislation to raise the nation's debt ceiling. 8.5% Fed Funds Seen ''The Fed's operations suggest we are on the way to an 8.50 percent funds rate,'' said Darwin L. Beck, a money market economist at the First Boston Corporation.
''A number of analysts, myself included, looked at the economic evidence presented in the Fed's beige book, in the purchasing managers' survey and in the employment report and concluded that they would not ease immediately. But the governors must have taken time to look at the numbers more closely over the weekend and concluded that maybe they needed some insurance.''
Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at the Chase Manhattan Bank, said that despite the moderate tone in the recent economic reports, ''the risk of recession is still greater than the risk of greater inflation.'' He added: ''That is the environment in which the Fed should ease policy. And as long as the industrial sector of the economy continues to be weak, we should look for further easing moves.''
 
Salutary Effect
In addition to having an impact on the Treasury's refunding, analysts said the move to a lower funds rate could well spur banks across the country to cut their prime lending rates, currently at 10 1/2 percent.
''Once the Fed ease becomes unequivocal, a cut in the prime rate seems likely,'' said John Lonski, senior economist at Moody's Investors Service.
''If Fed funds drops to 8.5 percent, the 2 percentage point gap between the prime and the funds rate would be so far above its five-year average of 1.65 percentage points that the failure to cut the prime would be most surprising.''
By late in the day, the Treasury's 8 1/8 percent bonds of 2019 were offerd at a price of 102 30/32, up a full point, or $10 for each $1,000 face amount of securities, to yield 7.86 percent.
Treasury note issues also posted strong gains, and short-term bill rates fell sharply.
In late trading, the 8 1/4 percent five-year notes were offered at 101 23/32, up half a point, to yield 7.81 percent. And the 7 5/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 99 5/8, up 10/32, to yield 7.83 percent.
In the secondary Treasury bill market, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.75 percent, down 8 basis points, or hundredths of a point. Six-month bills were offered at 7.55 percent, down 13 basis points. And one-year bill rates fell by 15 basis points, to a late offered rate of 7.31 percent.
 
Question to Congress
Yesterday's big drop in yields may not be long-lived once the $40 billion worth of Treasury offerings that make up the quarterly refunding are finally offered to investors, traders said.
''I don't think that most of our core customer base will jump at the refundings if yields stay at these levels, even if the Fed has eased,'' one bond trader said.
The Treasury, which will run out of money tomorrow, said yesterday that it planned to sell $16 billion worth of three-month and six-month bills on Monday.
The big rise in Treasury prices spilled over into the secondary markets for corporate and tax-exempt municipal bonds.
 
Municipal Bonds
In the municipal bond market, traders said that prices of most issues rose by 1/4 of a point to 3/8 of a point in fairly brisk trading.
A number of new tax-exempt issues were priced yesterday, including at $177 million offering of general obligation bonds by the State of Pennsylvania.
The offering, which was made at competitive bid, was won by a group led by Citibank. The serial bonds which make up the offering carry maturities that range from 1990 to 2009. The issues were reoffered to investors at yields from 5.90 percent on bonds maturing in 1990 to 7.10 percent on securities maturing in 2009.
The issue is rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service and AA-minus by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
In the corporate bond market, the Texas Utilities Electric Company priced $150 million of 30-year first mortgage and collateral trust bonds through an underwriting syndicate led by Salomon Brothers.
The 9 7/8 percent bonds were priced at $99.279, to yield 9.95 percent, 2.07 percentage points above the prevailing yield on the 8 1/8 percent 30-year Treasury bonds at the time of pricing.
The issue, which is noncallable for five years, has a final maturity of Nov. 1, 2019. It is rated Baa-1 by Moody's and BBB by Standard & Poor's.
Prices of most secondary investment-grade corporate issues rose by about three-quarters of a point, traders said.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Trade Law's Tangled Web

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
IT seemed like a legal loophole begging to be closed: if foreigners were caught dumping, say, color televisions in the United States, why let them get around the law by bringing in the picture tube and chassis and then slapping together the parts in some dockside warehouse in Seattle?
In fact, ''anti-circumvention'' rules, supported by both Democrats and Republicans and included in the Omnibus Trade Act of 1988, could deter much-needed foreign investment. The first serious test of the rules' impact pits a domestic maker of forklift trucks against a who's who of Japanese conglomerates. If the Portland-based Hyster Company wins, several Japanese companies may abandon forklift assembly operations in the United States, reducing competition and depriving American buyers of the fruits of Japanese innovation. 
American forklift makers have been hammered by imports since the late 1970's. By 1984 they had lost two-thirds of the market for small, gasoline-powered models, mostly to the Japanese. In the scramble to survive, the three largest American builders have adopted varying strategies.
The Clark Equipment Company set up a joint manufacturing venture with A.B. Volvo and agreed to market forklifts made in South Korea. Caterpillar Industrial Inc. shut down its domestic plants and imported forklifts from South Korea and Britain. Hyster also shuffled its production, relying less on American factories and more on plants in Europe and Brazil.
But Hyster decided to lick the foreigners as well as join them. With the support of its unions, it filed an anti-dumping suit against Nissan, Komatsu, Toyota, Mitsubishi and a handful of other Japanese manufacturers. In 1987, the Commerce Department ruled that the Japanese had been selling forklifts below their home market price. It assessed countervailing duties ranging from 17 to 51 percent.
The decision cost Japanese manufacturers tens of millions of dollars. But it is unlikely to do Hyster much good unless the company can foil Japanese plans to produce in the United States.
Since the mid-1980's, Japanese makers have been swiftly pushing ahead with plans to assemble forklifts in the United States, using domestic and imported parts. Hyster now contends that these facilities are superficial ''screwdriver'' operations, intended primarily to circumvent the 1987 anti-dumping decision. If the Commerce Department agrees, the Japanese-American hybrid forklifts will be subject to the duties levied against imports.
The Japanese may win the case on the merits. Local content in the forklifts now assembled in California, Illinois and Texas reportedly exceeds 20 percent - much more than the percentage in the egregious examples that Congress apparently had in mind when it drafted the anti-circumvention provisions. And while it has no direct legal bearing, Hyster's own heavy reliance on imported parts could undermine the company's case.
However the forklift case is decided, it raises a disturbing public policy issue. One reason - probably the leading reason - Japanese and European companies have built plants in the United States in the last decade is to bypass American trade barriers. Often decisions to invest here come only after importers have been stung by unfavorable trade rulings. Indeed, to some pragmatic observers, the resulting flow of foreign capital and technology is the best justification for tough trade laws.
But foreign companies must learn to walk on American soil before they can run. Typically they start conservatively, relying on trusted sources back home to provide most of the parts for American assembly. Only after they have trained managers, taken the measure of the local work force and tested local suppliers with small orders do they bet the reputation of the company on a product that is largely American.
How then will the Commerce Department be able to distinguish between companies circumventing the trade laws with screwdriver operations and those that are simply too cautious to invest heavily before they have accumulated a few years' experience in the American market?
Most likely, not very well. How much the resulting uncertainty will influence decisions to invest in the United States cannot be predicted. But it cannot bode well for American consumers, who in an age of increasing domestic market concentration have grown dependent on foreign competition to keep quality up and prices down.

HEADLINE: Rise in Consumer Debt Slowed in September

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7

 BODY:
American consumers dramatically slowed their taking on of new debt in September, adding only $606 million in what analysts said was new caution about buying cars and other expensive items.
The Federal Reserve Board reported today that consumer credit increased at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of just 1 percent in September, down from a revised 4.6 percent rate of advance in August. For all of 1988, consumer credit increased 8.5 percent. 
August's net debt increase totaled $2.66 billion, a sharp revision from the $3.48 billion originally reported last month.
The pace of net borrowing in September was the second slowest of the year after an actual decline of nine-tenths of 1 percent in July. That was the first drop since January 1987, when consumer debt fell 3.4 percent.
Consumer spending is closely monitored as a gauge of the economy's health because it represents two-thirds of all economic activity. The economy, particularly housing and manufacturing, has become sluggish in recent months in response to the Fed's campaign to restrain growth and ease inflationary pressures by keeping interest rates relatively high.
 
Car Loans Rebound a Bit
Auto loans, which had dropped sharply in July, rebounded a bit in August, driven by end-of-model-year sales incentives and higher prices for 1990 models to come. The August sales had the effect of stealing from those ordinarily expected in September.
As a result, auto loans in September dropped $842 million, a 3.5 percent annual rate of decline, the Fed said. They were virtually unchanged in August after declining 6.9 percent in July.
Sandra Shaber, an economist with the Futures Group, said the Fed report might not accurately reflect the amount of consumer debt since people have other ways to borrow, such as home equity loans, that are not included in the survey.
But she said consumers were becoming more cautious in their spending, particularly for autos and other durable goods - big-ticket items expected to last more than three years that are often financed by loans.
The category of debt that includes credit cards slowed to a 4.7 percent annual rate of growth from a 21.2 percent advance in August. Total revolving credit increased $756 million, compared with a gain of $3.37 billion in August.
Bank and credit union loans not secured by real estate rose by $785 million, a 4.8 percent annual rate of growth. That compared with a decline of $29 million, or two-tenths of 1 percent, in August.
Mobile home debts continued to fall, down $91 million, or a 4.8 percent annual rate of decline. This category has fallen for eight consecutive months, including an August drop of $692 million, or 35.1 percent.
The various changes left total consumer debt in September at a seasonally adjusted $703.6 billion.

HEADLINE: Volatility Study Urged

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7

 BODY:
The head of a leading Wall Street firm said today that the New York Stock Exchange should undertake a thorough study of computer-driven program trading to determine its impact on the volatility of the stock market.
Frank Zarb, chairman of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, said the issues were complex and the industry, not Washington, should take the lead in determining what steps were needed to cut down on volatility and revive investor confidence. The Wall Street executive said that he did not think that the move by the New York stock Exchange to halt program trading in a voluntary way would work well and he had doubts whether it was called for.
Mr. Zarb told a group of economists that it might be a good idea to focus on the current structure of the futures markets where investors have put down only 5 percent of the value of the stock instead of the 50 percent margin required to buy stocks.

HEADLINE: In Japan, It's Costly to Be a Consumer

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7

 BODY:
Japanese consumers are paying about twice as much as Americans for electric shavers, floppy disk drives and camera lenses and three and a half times as much for spark plugs, a survey conducted by Japanese and American Government agencies showed today.
On average, the prices of the 122 products surveyed were 41.7 percent higher in Japan than in the United States. The study confirmed what numerous observers have concluded, but the fact that the two Governments now agree on a set of comparisons has assumed major importance in talks they are holding on what American officials call structural barriers to imports in Japan.
The Bush Administration, seeking Japanese consumers as allies in its bid to open markets, points to the study as evidence of price fixing, bid rigging, market allocation and other anti-competitive practices in Japanese distribution and procurement, which it says curb imports unfairly. 
The Japanese Government has not previously acknowledged that prices for retail goods are higher than in other countries.
 
Will 'Study the Reasons'
Toshiyuki Takano, information counselor at the Japanese Embassy, declined to comment today except to say his Government would ''study the reasons which have caused these differences.''
The survey results also reflect Washington's view that Japanese consumers have been denied benefits of the doubling of the yen's international value. Under normal economic conditions, the more a currency rises, the more bargains that should mean for the country's consumers.
Not all the products were higher in Japan. Most electronics products, for example, were cheaper. But of the 35 electronics products sampled, 27 were made in Japan. Eighty-four were higher in Japan and 38 higher in the United States.
''In the end everything comes down to what the price is, and if the market is working the price will reflect an operating, competitive market, which we like to think we have in the United States,'' said J. Michael Farren, Under Secretary of Commerce for international trade administration.
 
Sweeping List of Demands
In a sweepiing list of demands, the United States is asking Japan, among other things, to slap down companies that fix prices, strengthen its Fair Trade Commission, stop collusion in its beef, construction and soda ash market, repeal legislation permitting small shops to block the opening of large department stores and buy more computer chips.
The Japanese insist that the talks are about barriers not just in Japan, but in the United States as well, and have cited various factors that they say impede exports, like the American penchant to consume rather than save and the high budget deficit.
The initiative on structural barriers was taken by the United States in May as part of a series of actions to implement the 1988 Omnibus Trade and Competitiveness Act.
It was at the first round of talks on the initiative in Tokyo in September that the two Governments agreed to conduct the price survey. A second round concluded today, and a third round is expected in January. American officials acknowledged that only modest progress was made. But at a briefing, officials on the American negotiating team, representing the Departments of State, Treasury and Commerce, the Office of the United States Trade Representative and the Council of Economic Advisers expressed the hope that Tokyo's position would change after the elections expected early next year.
''There was less flexibility on their part in reaching a common ground on the nature of the problem, even problems which do appear to be widely recognized in Japan,'' said Charles Dallara, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for monetary affairs.
Staff members from the Commerce Department and Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry got the data as a result of joint expeditions to department, specialty and discount stores in Tokyo, Osaka, New York and Chicago between Oct. 18 and 28.
 
No Brand Names Disclosed
Comparable goods made in Japan, in the United States and in other countries were covered. Because of fears of ruffling manufacturers, brand names were not disclosed.
The capital goods studied included scientific instruments and dental products. Of 22 such items studied, 15 were more expensive in Japan than in the United states.
Of the 15, 5 were made in Japan, 3 were made in the United States and 7 produced in other countries.

HEADLINE: Report of Research Curb By Bush Stirs Criticism

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
A bitter controversy has been touched off by reports that the Bush Administration plans to scale back the Pentagon's role in several technology-development programs intended to help American industries compete internationally.
The dispute centers on reported changes that would curtail the activities of the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, or Darpa, and other Government initiatives. The changes have been discussed widely within the Government in recent days. 
In recent years, Darpa has played a central role by financing and coordinating several research programs, including the development of advanced chip-making equipment and research on high-definition television.
 
To Be Made Public
The dispute will be made public today by Representative Mel Levine, Democrat of California. He said he would contend in testimony before the House Committee on Science, Space and Technology that the Administration was seeking to eliminate money for Sematech, a chip-making consortium financed by Darpa, and other civilian technologies.
He also plans to discuss Bush officials' plans to reduce support for the Commerce Department's Technology Assessment program and to merge the Defense Manufacturing Board with the Defense Science Board.
''The bottom line is that the Administration is on a search-and-destroy mission to root out vital programs which are essential to the health of the economy,'' Mr. Levine said.
The Administration confirmed yesterday that it was planning to merge the Defense Manufacturing Board, organized in March to advise the Pentagon on manufacturing matters, into the Defense Science Board, an older body provides advice on technical matters.
But Robert C. McCormack, the Acting Deputy Under Secretary of Defense for Acquisition, strongly denied the reports that the Defense Department was considering whether to eliminate its support for Sematech. ''No way,'' he said. He added that a research program on high-definition video displays was continuing.
 
Seen as Clarification
''There's a nervousness in the front office about starting our own industrial policy down here,'' said Mr. McCormack, who has been in charge of the department's programs to support the defense industrial base program, a group of technological research projects intended to help American corporations compete with those of Japan and Europe.
Mr. McCormack said he would not consider the planned measures a ''pullback'' of the Defense Department's role. Rather, he said, they are a clarification that the department will not subsidize other industries as it does the semiconductor industry through its support for Sematech, the consortium based in Austin, Tex.
He said merging the two advisory panels was suggested by John A. Betti, the Under Secretary of Defense for Acquisition, a former executive vice president of the Ford Motor Company who assumed his Pentagon position in August.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Precious Metals Prices Rise Mainly on Foreign Demand

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Precious metals prices continued to climb yesterday on the Commodity Exchange in New York, largely on an increase in overseas demand. Dealers attributed the overseas buying, much of it from the Mideast, to the diversion of assets from securities portfolios as well as an increase in domestic speculative interest in gold.
''Some trace the demand for gold to the so-called shift to safety from the turbulent financial and equities markets,'' said Bette Raptopoulos, a metals specialist at Prudential-Bache Securities. ''But there are many factors responsible for the recent rise in precious metals prices.'' 
One factor for the recent surge in gold prices and trading volume has been the rise in prices after a long decline that carried the spot price of bullion from $450 an ounce at the start of 1989 to a low of $360 in mid-September.
At the close of trading yesterday, the spot December gold futures contract was up $4.60, to $388.40. The next active contract, for February delivery, also rose $4.60 to close at $392.90. Following the strength in gold, the spot price of silver for delivery in December on the Comex rose 2.7 cents an ounce, to $5.295, with the March contract up 2.9 cents, at $5.415.
Platinum futures prices followed gold and silver, with the spot January futures up $4 an ounce, to $550.60 at the New York Mercantile Exchange.
As for the revived Mideast interest in gold, Ms. Raptopoulos said that ''the farther one is from a marketplace the more exaggerated the news.'' She added, ''This may explain why many Mideast and other overseas investors are so concerned about the recent sharp declines in our stock market.''
Some domestic investment portfolio managers have also shifted some assets to shares in gold mining companies. When there is a pickup in interest in gold shares, it usually stimulates interest in the actual metal, particularly among the speculative element, Ms. Raptopoulos said.
Among other factors that have lent support to gold prices is the recent weakness in the dollar, which is held by many investors in countries with much softer currencies. Many overseas investors also believe that the Federal Reserve will have to move to reduce interest rates to prevent a further decline in the economy. Lower interest rates will make dollar-denominated investment less attractive to foreign investors.
Still another factor bolstering gold prices, Ms. Raptopoulos said, is the temporary shortage of refined gold available to jewelry manufacturers in Europe. Whether the shortage is real or has been caused by the refiners holding out for higher prices is debatable. ''But we think it will be of short duration,'' she added.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off in World Trading, Reflecting Concern on Rates

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar weakened yesterday against all primary currencies, reflecting concern that interest rates in the United States were heading lower.
Gold prices rose sharply here and abroad. 
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery closed at $386.20 an ounce, up by $4.70 from Monday. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted a late bid price for the precious metal at $384.75 an ounce, up by $4.50 from Monday.
Currency traders said worries that the Federal Reserve might be easing its credit policies, in light of recent evidence showing an economic slowdown, depressed the dollar's value but supported gold prices.
''The dollar's upside position is very limited under that scenario,'' said Ronald H. Holzer, the chief dealer for Harris Trust and Company in Chicago.
He said the traders were paying particular attention to the Federal funds rate, which is the interest on overnight loans between banks and a rate over which the Fed has some control. Federal funds traded at 8 1/2 percent late on Tuesday, down from 8 11/16 percent late on Monday.
In New York, the dollar closed at 142.95 yen yesterday, down from 143.85 yen on Monday.
The dollar was also weaker against the British pound, ending at $1.5865 in New York, compared with $1.5765 late Monday.
Other late-dollar rates in New York, compared with those late on Monday, included: 1.8430 West German marks, down from 1.85325; 1.6165 Swiss francs, down from 1.6245; 6.2470 French francs, down from 6.2820; 1,348.00 Italian lire, down from 1,356.50, and 1.17125 Canadian dollars, down from 1.17075.
On the New York Comex, silver for current delivery settled at $5.265 an ounce, up from $5.238 late on Monday. The metal rose in London, to $5.26 an ounce, from $5.25.
